'This is it.' Keitaro thought. 'No matter how much punishment I can go through, I won't survive whatever they are about to do. Power of seemingly being immortal or no. I. AM. DEAD!' Cried Keitaro in his head.

Naru looked at him, before noticing his lack of attire. She also saw Shinobu standing there, starting at him. She Turned as red as she could, and was about to kill the manager, before smelling something absoulutely amazing. It made her stop in her tracks, and all anger vanishied in an instant. Why was she angry again? She looked back at Keitaro, blushed, and turned her head.

"H-h-hey. W-we w-wer-were lo-loking for y-you Keitaro. D-di-dinner is ready. Please come clothed." She said as she slowly backed around the corner, eyes averted the entire time.

"Yes. Please hurry senpai." Shinobu said as she made her way back down the other end of the hall, not casting a glance back the entire time, although, Keitaro knew she was blushing the entire time.

Keitaro, for his part, stood there, still trying to cover himself, shocked to his very core. He wasn't dead for one thing. And another thing was that He didn't even sense hostillity from Naru at all. She seemed more timid than anything else. And the fact that neither one of them screamed in shock was another thing as well.

'Wha-what just happened.' He thought as he started to come out of the shock. Quickly making a bee-line for his room, he saw the tome . 'C-could what it have said be true?' He thought to himself.

What does he do now?

Even later that night, someone else had came into Keitaro's room, not being quiet, but not causing ruckus in the dark hours of the night. As she entered the room, the moonlight shone on her, showing it to be Motoko, with her long dark hair framing her face. She looked angry for a moment, before smelling the same thing Naru did.

'Wait, if Su is here, then that means...' He thought, before he saw the form of Motoko standing above him. Forgetting what had transpired earlier that evning, he started to plead with the kendo practitioner, although it was quiet as he didn't wnat to wake anyone else. "Please Motoko, don't hurt me! I didn't know she snuck in here again! I'm sorry!"

Motoko stood still for a moment, before she reached out to grab Su's arm once again. "It is alright Urashima. I had got up to grab a glass of water, and when I came back, Su was no where to be found. Judging by her actions in the past, I figred she would come here." She said, causing Keitaro to remember what had happened earlier.

Keitaro stood up, with a little help from Motoko, hoping Su would loosen her grip a bit to slide down to the bed. However, this had the unknown effect of making Su grab onto Motoko, getting both of them stuck in her vice grip face to face. Both Motoko and Keitaro blushed from the close contact of their faces. Landing with a small oomph from both vitcims, Motoko sighed. "We will be here for a while Urashima." She said as she laid there, unable to move her arms as well.

After that, there was a long silence. After that, Keitaro decided he would start step two. "Hey, Motoko?" He asked, getting the girls attention. "Can I ask you a question?"

Motoko looked at him, blush still on her face. She silently nodded.

"What I want to ask is..."

" Why do you hate men in general?" Keitaro asked.

Motoko blinked three times before sighing. She didn't expect that question. She figured that he deserved to know though, since he would likely be on the receiving end of more punishment that seemed unnecessarily harsh to him.

"Well, it started with my upbringing. I was taught to be a strong independent person, regardless of gender. I was told, that to rely on others was a sign of weakness, and I couldn't have that. I was to inherit the family dojo, and to take over as head of the family." She said, before she frowned. "Well, that's not entirely true. My sister, Tsuruko, was to be next in line. However, she gave up the sword for love. She gave up her way of life, for a man! She thought she couldn't live with out him, so she was weak! And I hate him for making my sister weak. I refuse to be weak in any form, so I harden my heart to any men!" She said. "That, and the fact that all men are perverts. They think of nothing but violating women, for nothing but their own pleasure!"

Keitaro didn't know what to say. So, he asked another question. "Alright, so why do you hate me specifically?"

Motoko was once again surprised. She felt the anger flow out of her. "Why do I hate you? You ask why I hate you, but you do not look at your position." She said.

"Hey, this isn't my fault!" Keitaro cried out.

"Not this position!" She said, blushing even harder then before. "I mean, look where you live. Look where you work! A man shouldn't live or work at a woman's dorm. Its just not right. Haruka should be the one who runs it."

Keitaro just shook his head. "Aunt Haruka has her hands full with the tea shop. She doesn't have time to run the dorm."

Motoko just blinked again. Why had none of the others thought out such a thing? In fact, why hadn't she? She cursed herself for not noticing sooner.

But Keitaro wasn't done. "Besides, what makes you think I'm a horrible person?"

"How about all those 'accident's' that happen around here all the time? There is no way that one man can be that unlucky!"

Keitaro sighed once again. "Motoko, if you were to ask any of my family, they would tell you I have been accident prone my entire life."

Motoko would have narrowed her eyes, but felt no need to do so. "Alright, fine. Lets say you are very unlucky. But you still lust after women like any other man."

Keitaro shook his head as much as he could. "Your getting lust confused with natural human attraction. Just because I think about women does not mean I will actively seek them out in an attempt for my own pleasure."

Motoko closed her eyes. "That is enough for one night Urashima. No more questions. I still have my practice in the morning."

Keitaro sighed. Hopefully he did the second step right. "Good night Motoko." He said, before he fell back to sleep.

Motoko just blushed lightly, soon falling back to sleep.

And all the while, Su was hugging the both of them tighter then ever.

1551221211222.title: Step three: Make them know who YOU are!

15512212112221.content:
Keitaro quickly got up, ready to go talk to Motoko. Making his way through the halls, enjoying the early morning. As he made his way up to the roof, he heard the other tenants sleeping away. (They were all on the way to the stairs, and some snored a little loud.)

Making his way up the stairs, he could hear the rush of a sword being swung. Slowly making his way up, for not wanting to startle her and make her hit him out of reflex, he saw her. She was standing there, sword over head, making vertical slashes in the air. Keitaro could see that she was starting to sweat, even from his position on the steps. 'Wow, she sure is amazing.' The thought drifted across the surface of his mind, not fully his own but still a part of what he thought.

He watched her as she stopped her swinging, and breathed deeply. Deciding that now would be a good time, Keitaro walked up the steps as quietly as he could and leaned up against the rail to look into the sun rise.

Motoko turned around, looking for the towel she brought up to wipe the sweat from her brow and palms. She, however, was shocked to see Keitaro. "Is there something you need Urashima?"

Keitaro was silent for a minute before he was ready to speak. "Well, since what we talked about last night was rather personal for you, I figured it would only be fair to tell you a bit about myself."

"That is not nessecary Urashima."

"Yes Motoko, I think it is." He said in a slightly forceful tone, surprising the kendo girl. "I think that it would be better for everyone if you all started to get to know me. The real me, not as what you all see me as."

Motoko stood there for a moment. Did any of the girls really know him? Shinobu idolized him, Su saw qualities similer to her big brother, Kitsune only saw a bank and comedy club, and both her and Naru saw him as another male, to be detested as something vile.

No, they reallly did not know who Keitaro Urashima was.

"Very well Urashima. We will talk."

So for the next hour or so, Keitaro and Motoko sat there, talking about Keitaro's past, faults, dreams, and hobbies.

At some point, the two had been sitting so close toghether, they had their arms wrapped around each others sshoulders. By the time Keitaro was done, Motoko had a lot to think over, maybe their manager wasn't so bad after all. Smelling a wonderful smell wafting up from the kitchen area, and their stomachs growling at thm, the two decided that it was time for breakfest.

Later that day, around 3:30, Keitaro had finished most of the fixing up he had to do. Breathing heavily of the fresh air, he decided that he would head back to his room and rest, possibly find something to help with Naru. He knew that even her hatred for him was stronger then most things. Considering she had enough fire power in one punch to send him into the lower parts of the stratosphere, he was a little wary. But the book hadn't lead him astray yet!

Arriving back to his room, he quickly picked up the book and began flipping through it. Finding the pages that contained the strange symbols again, he noticed something called 'the gift of forgiveness.' Wondering what it was, he quickly began to read.

"The Gift of Forgiveness is a truly special thing. It grants the user the ability to say 'I'm sorry' through almost any medium, for nearly anything, even stuff that happened in the past that would never be forgiven in the eyes of the receiver." He read, before having to stop.

He heard a strange sound. It sounded like...tearing? He looked around for where the noise could be coming from. His pants? No. His bed sheets? No, that wasn't it either. Looking up, he saw Naru's Lidou-kun doll was stuck on some slightly splintered boards. Knowing how much that doll meant to the girl, he tried to get a step ladder to grab it. While he succeeded in getting the step ladder, he had got a hold of the doll when

*BOOM!*

Something exploded below, causing him to fall of the step ladder, ripping the doll as he pulled it with him. As he landed, he saw the arm of the little cartoon squirrel fly at his face. Getting up, doll arm in hand, he looked around the room, trying to find the other pieces.

The head had landed on his bed.

The other arm and one foot were knocked slightly under the dresser.

The last foot had landed in the glass of water he had set up on his desk.

The torso and tail were still in his other hand.

'Man this thing went everywhere. But now I got to sew it back together AND find out what just happened.' He thought, before he decided to shrug it off for now. He had worked real had today. He needed a break.

Picking the book back up, he began to read again.

"Now, the Gift of Forgiveness is a powerful ritual. As such, the effects are powerful. However, the medium used as the gift has to be something that the receiver holds close to their heart. Simply place the medium on the runic circle shown in the book, and the ritual will be immediate. Also note, that if the gift is broken, the ritual will repair it, as long as it is not beyond repair. Once the ritual is done, simply give the gift back to the receiver and ask 'Can you forgive me?' They should only be able to blush, nod their head and say 'All is forgiven.' Use this if the person you are trying to talk to is a person to normally be wary of. Also note that this effect is increased if the giver and receiver are stuck in a embarrassing situation. Due to this, it is best to wear the spray from step one. Also note that this actually passes step two for the receiver."

Keitaro just stared at the page for a while, before he quickly gathered up the pieces of the Lidou-kun and placed them on the circle.

He was half expecting there to be a bright flash of light. Sadly he was disappointed. All it did was make the circle glow red, before it let off a puff of smoke. When the smoke cleared, the doll was back in perfect shape.

Smiling at that, Keitaro picked up the doll, and went off in search of a compromised Naru.

Keitaro went looking around the dorm for Naru, hoping to find her in a compromising position. Normally he wouldn't think that, but the tome of infinite pervertedness was starting to drain more of his morals even quicker. One thing the Eronomicon did was corrupt the marked harem god, ever so slightly at first, but faster as time went by, and even faster, in a burst, if the user followed the directions to a T in getting in a normally embarrassing position or used something in it, like the gift of forgiveness ritual. That one drained up a lot of morality. Now, if only Keitaro wasn't such a good fellow in the beginning, he would have taken a larger drop in morality into another zone of actions.

On his searching for Naru, he noticed a dropped article of clothing. Walking up to it, he saw that it was a bra. Specifically Naru's. The one that she wore when she punched him into the floor.

Picking it up, he smiled. He knew where to go.

~Laundry room

Keitaro stood outside the laundry room, bra and doll in hand. He heard Naru mutter about losing a bra through the door. He smirked as he put his hand on the door.

Hearing the door open, Naru looked to see who it was. Seeing that it was Keitaro, she started to get angry again. And just like the last time she wanted to get angry at him, she smelled something so good, it caused her to forget any anger. Considering she was only in bra and panties at the moment, she was very embarrassed. Seeing the bra in Keitaro's hand, she was even more embarrassed.

"Y-y-yeah? Is th-there s-s-something you need K-K-Keitaro?" She asked.

Keitaro lifted up the hand with her bra, holding it in front of her. "I believe this is yours." He smiled.

She blushed harder at that. Going to snatch the bra away, she noticed what was in the other hand. "My Lidou-kun doll! But, why do you have him Keitaro?" She asked, genuine curiosity was etched onto her face as she looked at him, still blushing.

"Well, remember when you hit me hard the other day?" He asked, making her think for a moment before she nodded. "Well, I think that you caused some of the wood to brake, giving it just enough room to fall down into my room. However, with everything that was going on today, what with Su making things explode, I think it got caught on the way down on those broken boards. When I noticed, it was just starting to tear. I had tried to grab it, but as soon as I got a hold of it, something else exploded. This knocked the step ladder out from under me, and I fell, bringing little Lidou-kun with me. He... kinda fell to pieces after that. But," he said after Naru clutched the doll to her chest. "I sewed him back together, good as new. So, I have to ask." He said, making the girl look into his eye's. "Can you forgive me?"

Naru felt very strange upon hearing those words. She felt as if Keitaro didn't need to even ask for forgiveness. After all, it wasn't her fault her Lidou-kun doll was torn apart, now was it? She also felt as if some events that she didn't feel like ever forgiving the ronin for, seemed petty. With those thought in mind, she blushed even harder, remembering all the time he had groped her, saw her like he was doing now, or did something that she found perverted. She felt as if those didn't matter anymore. Looking back to her dorm manager, she nodded, a smile on her face. "All is forgiven."

And just like that, the tension left the room. It was calm. Very calm.

Percy undid the seat belt before he kicked at the window. Surprisingly, it flew off nearly ten feet from the car before it his the ground, despite being so low to it.

Sally would have made a fuss, if whatever was hunting them wasn't doing so. Right now, she needed Percy to be safe.

Percy undid Grovers belt, grabbing his arms so he didn't fall on his head. He slowly pulled both of them from the car, Sally scooting out behind them.

"Percy, I need you to run up that hill. You'll be safe there. Go!" She said, pushing him on.

Percy wanted to move, but it felt like something was keeping him there. A memory of something.

The air was still charged with static, but his hairs were falling down now. It seemed that whatever it was in the air was fading.

"What are you doing Percy? Run!" His mother yelled at him.

But Percy stayed stock still. Where had he seen this before? And why was there a little bit of extra weight in his pocket?

Sally looked between Percy and the shadowy figure that was approaching them. It stood at twelve feet tall, about three-hundred pounds of pure, beefy muscle. Horns stood atop its head, while a bulls snout jutted from its face, with a large ring in the nose.

The beast had hair going down it's entire body, a cow's tail swishing back and forth.

It also wore a pair of pure white fruit of the looms underwear.

The Minotaur.

Sally wanted to speak, but the sight of it made all noise catch in her throat. That beast was after her son!

Seeing them, the bull-man lowered his head, snorting twice before it ran at them at high speeds.

Sally, stepped in fear as she was, pushed both boys with the strength that only a mother had when her children were in danger, sending them sprawling far enough away that the Minotaur couldn't turn to them.

So it grabbed her instead.

It stopped running when it caught her, looking at her with almost no intellect in the beasts eyes.

Seeing that it was not male, or young, the Minotaur started to squeeze the life out of the human. It's was not what he was looking for.

"Ack--Ugh! Ah Percy!" She managed to scream out, making Percy's brain kick into high gear.

And he remembered.

It was his first year at camp half-blood when his mother was abducted by Hades. The Minotaur, the car, his mother, grover.

Everything came back.

But how? What?

That strange power!

Had it sent him back in time?

Right now, he didn't care. Right now, he had his mother to save.

He placed Grover down, turning to face the hybrid moster.

His eyes went wide however, when he say his mother start to shine golden. "NO!" he yelled, before his mother disappeared in that shower of golden light.

Just like the first time.

Percy looked at where his mother was just moments before, when he glared at the Minotaur with as much hate as he could muster. "You! I'll kill you!" He yelled, making the beast turn towards him. Percy quickly ran away from Grover, running towards the right, closer to the camp boundries. There were more trees there for him to use against this monstrosity once more.

And so, the Minotaur charged. Percy stood still for a moment, before leaping to the side.

The Minotaur buried it's horns right into a tree, getting them stuck.

With out thinking, Percy jumped on the beasts back, pulling it's head back in a fury.

However, this pulled out the bulls horns from the tree.

Unflinching, Percy grabbed both horns, pulling heard on both of them.

*SNAP SNAP*

Both horns broke off, making the bullman cry out in horrible pain.

Percy wasted no time though. He jumped back on the monster, using the horns to stab at the thing to keep himself on as it flung about in pain. Percy kept climbing higher and higher, using the horns like ice picks to climb up to the beasts head, were he drove both horns into the beasts skull.

The Minotaur let out one last cry before it exploded into gold dust, signaling that it had been sent back to Hades once more.

Percy fell from the air, landing in the golden remains, both horns in his hands. From the adreniline rush, though fading, he did catch sight of a blond haired girl and a man with a horses body.

And what was in his damn pocket!

155222222222222222211222.content:
Percy woke up, feeling slightly groggy. Better then he did last time he was awake though. He had that feeling... what did Annabeth call it? Deja vu? Yeah... that.

He sat up slowly, knowing from experience that if you sat up to fast that you're liable to lose your lunch quickly after waking up from a black out.

He looked around, seeing that the room looked strangely familiar.

'Oh... what did I hit my head on? I thought I saw that grease-ball Gabe's car again, with my mom and Grover and the Minotaur. But... that was five years ago. What in Tartarus?' He thought, before he felt something in his back pocket still. 'What is that?'

Percy moved his hands into his back pocket, pulling out something kinda hard and rectangular. Looking at it, Percy saw that it was one of those pocket note books that people put stuff like notices in. He had seen paul with them before. He had one for birthdays, one important dates other then birthdays, one for school events or meetings, and possibly more.

Though this one had fancy writing on it, not that he could make it out just yet. His head hurt, and his dyslexia was acting up majorly now. He put it back in his pocket, one of the side ones, laying down again.

He closed his eyes for a moment, waiting for the pain to pass. Once it had, he opened his eyes.

Only to meet stormy grey ones.

Percy stared up at them as they widened in surprise, before they pulled away, revealing the person who they belonged to.

Percy had to do a double take, seeing the person they belonged to. He could never forget the long blond hair, or the face that, though younger, was etched into his heart and soul.

Annabeth Chase.

Although, she looked just the same as when he started camp.

Fearing this could be some kind of trick, Percy sat up, fighting down the wave of nausea as he stood up, looking with hard eyes at the look-alike of his hopefully soon-to-be girlfriend.

The look-alike Annabeth regarded him with those sharp eyes of hers, though a look of awe was hidden barely in them.

"Who are you?" Percy asked, hands going for the pocket he kept riptide on, but not finding it. Giving it up for lost, as strange as that seemed with the magic pen/sword that could never get lost, he got into one of the only fighting stances he knew.

Unfortunatly, he was no good with any of them. he had tried to train in them, but he never got the hang of it.

The blond-haired look-alike adopted a hard gaze, looking at him with the intent to unlock all his secrets. "Your rude you know. Why don't you give me your name first?" Even her voice sounded like Annabeths, though younger once again. And a little uppity.

Percy kept an eye on the girl, watching for any sudden moves. "Percy."

"Annabeth." She said, cutting it quick. "But, since your up, I guess I should take you to Chiron. Though you were out for less time then he guessed." She said, before she turned away, walking through the door. She obviously expected him to follow her, which he did. Things made little sense right now, so why not. Wasn't like he's be in any more danger then he already was, if he was in any.

He followed the look-alike through the halls of what seemed like the big house at camp. It was strange. He recalled having done this before, though it was slightly different from before.

He walked onto the patio that wrapped around the big house, seeing a man in a wheelchair playing a game against a man with a hawian t-shirt and what looked like a bad hangover with blood shot eyes.

Chiron and Dionysus.

"Chiron, Mr.D. He's awake." The look-alike said, moving back a bit to the railing to look over the realistic camp copy. Seriously, what was messing with his mind?

"Oh? Well, it seems that you're getting a little lax in your practices Chiron. You said he wouldn't wake up until tomorrow." Dionysus said, playing his hand.

"I was sure that he would not awaken for at least another day." Chiron said, before he looked at the cards. "Oh, you've won. Well, what better timing though." He said, turning in his fake wheelchair to look at Percy.

Percy could only look unimpressed at this. Whatever was messing with his head would have to try better then that.

"Hello Percy. It must be a surprise to see me here, I'm sure. I never did like this thing." He said, pointing to the wheel chair. "Limits my mobility. Wait, you think I'm handicapped still. Oh, where are my manners. Allow me to re-intriduce myself. I am Chiron, Percy Jackson. I'm sure you remember that from my lectures."

And, just like last time, Chiron had gotten out of his wheelchair in a dramatic way, showing off the horse body that he kept hidden.

Upon not hearing anything like shock or awe that he was expecting, he looked down at Percies unimpressed face.

"Okay, yeah. I know your chiron, and your Dionysus." Percy said, pointing at the god of wine.

"Oh? And how do you know that? I must say that you seem to be full of surprises." Dionysus said, looking directly through Percy. Though he did sense a strange aura that seemed to come from the boys pocket. It felt like his own cup. It made almost anything drinkable, with no ill effects other then making the drinker a little tipsy.

In other words, A godly item.

But it felt foreign. None of the gods had items that felt like this. What was the boy playing at?

"Really? Whatever monsters playing with my head right now needs to step up the act. Going into my memories, really? I think I read something about that in that guide to monsters." Percy said, musing to himself.

"Wait, memories?Percy, what are you talking about?" Chiron asked, a confused look on his face.

Annabeth looked back at Percy, wondering what he was talking about.

"Yeah. Last I remember, I was at Olympus. The war had ended, with Kronos "

"What? Kronos? War! Percy, what are you talking about?" Chiron trotted nervously in place. The former king of the titans name was enough to make him nervous.

"Um... I'm talking about the war. Shouldn't whatever is looking through my memories know that? If it thinks it can mess with me by going back in time in my head, then it's dead wrong." Percy said, looking around.

"Percy, I assure you that this isn't a memory. What's this about a war?" Chiron said, trotting nervously. Did the boy get hit on the head to hard or something?

"The war with the titans! Okay, lok. If you are a monster that's going through my memories, then would you at least try to make it seem less obvious? Really, at least put some effort into it."

"Percy, there is no monster that goes through your memories in greek myths. Drain you of them, yes. But, unless you're in Tartarus, then you won't be seeing any memories of yours without looking at them yourself." Chiron said, making Percy look up at the centaur.

"Yeah? How do I know you ain't messing with me more?" Percy said, Making Chiron sigh.

"Annabeth, would you mind taking Percy around camp? Mr. D. and myself have things to discuss.

Annabeth looked at Percy with Curiousity, before she grabbed his shoulder, thrust a box into his hands and walked, his shirt pulling him along with her.

Choice 2: The Eronomicon gives Percy a seal to make Annabeth remember some of the future, with a few 'modifications
to her memory.

1552222222222222222112222.content:
Percy was being pulled around by the look-alike of Annabeth, who was telling him about the camp. Showing him the forge where all the metal things used in camp were made. A few kids of Hephestus had stopped working long enough to make a quick wave or nod of greeting.

She showed him the stables where the horse's were kept, which all took a liking to Percy once more. She took him to the archery range, where a few kids of Apollo's were firing their arrows, hitting near the bulls-eye alot.

Basicly, she showed him everything she did the first time. Percy held the box under one arm, his hand in the pocket with that strange pocket book. He looked around, bored about what was going on.

Annabeth lead him out into the woods, going to show him the frthest that the barrier that was Thaila's tree could go.

However, the strange pocket book grew hot, and burned Percy's hand. Unknown to the demigods, the book had burned a seal into his hand, which would begin a ritual most amazing.

Percy let out a yelp, feeling the book burn him. He pulled his hand out of his pocket, shaking it. There wasn't a stream or anything around, so he couldn't just step into some water to stop the burning.

Annabeth turned around, seeing him shake his hand. Wondering what had happened to the new guy at camp, she moved over to him, looking at his palm.

However, the second her hand touched his, her eyes went blank.

~Olympus, shortly after the death of Luke and Kronos, but before Percy disappeared~

Annabeth shuddered as the wave of power flowwed over her. She knew what that entailed.

Luke was dead.

She wanted to cry, but found she had no tears to shed at the moment. She raced through the streets of the gods home, hoping to make it back to the throne room in time.

However, as soon as she opened the doors, she saw Percy get struck by something. This object had a lot of power it seemed, as it tore open a swirling vortex. Annabeth watched, helpless as Percy was at the epicenter of it, no doubt being swallowed by whatever the thing was.

The part of her that was constantly curious was facinated by the swirling mass of pure energy.

The part of her that loved Percy cried out in terror.

She looked on, as not even a minute later the vortex faded, leaving nothing where Percy should have stood.

He was gone.

Annabeth wanted to cry. The guy she was going to confess to had, after his greatest task, been caught up in some kind of portal, with who nknew what happening to him.

He could be torn to shreds by it! O-or possibly changed so much that he wasn't Percy anymore. Or he could be somewhere far away, in another dimension perhaps, well beyond the gods reach.

However, Annabeth could not cry for long. She felt a tugging on her soul, such as when she took that blow for Percy that she knew would have killed him, despite having the same power Achillies did. She resisted the tug, fearful of what it was. She couldn't die yet! She had to help Percy! Even if the gods couldn't do it, she would fight through all the titans and Typhon if she had to!

But, then she heard a voice.

'Fear not child. You are merely being called back.' It said, sounding only in her head.

'Yes,' Another voice said, completely different from the first. 'You should follow the tug. It is bound to happen at some poin or another.'

Annabeth looked around, wondering who could be speaking to her.

Her grey eyes widened, seeing three old woman. They were sitting near the fire in the center of the room. One was using a spool to spin a seemingly endless amount of yarn. The second was measuring it out, using nothing but a trained eye to keep track of how long it was. The string was all types of colors, aqnd each segment of color seemed to change in length until the second lady measured it.

Then, the third lady, who had a large, intimidating pair of bronze scissors, cut each segmant, perfectly Annabeth might add.

The fates.

The three old women stopped their tasks, looking up at Annabeth.

'Yes child. Follow the tug. It will lead you to many new things.' A thrid voice said. 'And you like new things, don't you?'

Annabeth could only nod. What else could you do with the people who literally controled when you died? Even the gods were subject to their will. The fates also woved the tapestry of destiny, which all beings adheared to, god or mortal. While they did not directly control what happened, they did bend things to their favor a bit.

'Then follow the tug. Follow it, and greet Perceus Jackson once more.' The second voice said.

'Do not worry child. We shall accompeny you.' The first voice said, making Annabeth go even more into shock.

But she could not resist the tug any longer. What the fates spoke of was something that promised to be amazing and new to her.

And a child of Athena never let anything new slip from their grasp.

Annabeht felt her soul leave her body, watching as it slumped to the ground. The fates had disappeared from her view, thugh she felt as if they were right next to her.

She closed her eyes, thinking of the man she was going to meet.

She felt herself being pulled back. It felt strange. She was staying where she was, but she felt as things passed her by. Maybe not places, but times. Maybe that vortex that swallowed Percy had taken him through time.

But when?

The fates said that the tug would take her to Percy, and she wasn't going to distrust them.

Though, Annabeth did feel a little wierd. She felt as her love for Percy grew a thousand fold, turning into something that was absolute for her.

The want for him to be happy also grew, though many, many more times then the love had. She wanted him to be happy, no matter what now. Wether it was with her, or that stuck-up bitch Artemis. Even if he wanted to be with her mother, she would be happy. Or with all of them at once, with many, many more girls.

Annabeth felt things slow down around her. Her feet started to feel things again. She opened her eyes, only to find Percy looking at her.

Annabeth felt her body heat up, as she felt her hand on his. Though, as she looked at him, something was off.

He was younger.

Annabeth stared at him, not really caring that he was younger. He was there, and that's what mattered to her.

"Percy." She said, making him look at her.

"Yeah?" He asked, not believing this was the real Annabeth.

"It is you." Annabeth said, a few tears streaming down her cheeks.

She quickly tackled Percy into a hug, wrapping her arms around him.

"Percy! I'm so glad your alive! After that explosion on Olympus, and the vortex, and..." She stopped, crying into his shirt. "I thought I lost you."

Percy looked down at the younger Annabeth, seeing how distraught she was. His inner gentleman made him wrap his arms around her, hugging her.

"You know?" He asked, not really believing it.

Annabeth nodded. "After you gave Luke the dagger, there was that huge explosion of his power. I ran up through Olympus to get back to the throne room. I saw you get hit by something, and a strange vortex opened up. After it disappered, you were gone. I thought you were dead or worse."

Percy scoffed at that. "What's worse then being dead?"

Annabeth didn't even lift a finger to punch him. The relief was to great. "But then, I felt a tug. I thought I was dieing again. But then the fates appeared, saying that I should follow the tug. It would lead me to you. And the were right." Annabeth said, tears still falling from her eye's.

'Indeed young one. We did say that, did we not sisters?' A voice invaded both their minds. It wasthe first one Annabeth heard.

'Yes. And we did not lie.' The second voice said.

'No we did not. And I think the young ones would like to see us themselves.' The third voice said.

Both demigods looked around, wondering where the voices were coming from.

However, when Percy laid eye's on the beings that held those voices, he nearly had a heart attack.

For the fates were not three old hags, like they were when they first appeared to Percy.

No, they were three beautiful women.

One was about Percy's height when he was still sixteen. She had flowing red hair, with deep, golden eyes. She had tan skin, covered by a librarian's outfit.

The second one was about Percy's mother's height. She had pitch black hair, done up into a ponytail. She had deep, red eyes that stared right into Percy's. She had ivory skin, which was covered by a seamstress' uniform.

The thrid sister was easily the tallest, standing at about six foot three inches. She had silver hair. Not grey, silver. It shone, bouncing the light that landed on it off in such a way that made her even more beautiful. She had pure black eyes, though they seemed kind. She wore a doctors coat, though she somehow made it alluring without making it skimpy.

'We are the fates, Persues Jackson.' The first sister said in his mind. 'I am Clotho, and these are my sisters, Lachesis and Atropos. We have come to you Perseus, with a request.'

Percy only looked at them, not making a move. he feared the fates, like any sane person would.

Clotho seemed to smile at this. 'Fear not. This task shall bring you no harm. We only wish for one thing.'

"A-and what is that?" Percy asked, wondering what they wanted.

Clotho smiled once more. 'We only wish that you would lay with us, and allow us to stay with you. Forever.'

At that, Percy's mind went on shut down. He was lucky he was already on the ground.

What was going on?
1552222222222222222112222.title: Future Annabeth brought to the past.

15522222222222222221122221.content:
Percy woke up, a faint pounding in his head. Those were some really weird dreams he had.

Going back in time?

Bringing Annabeth's soul back in time as well?

And the Fates, the actual Fates, wanting to get with him, and be with him forever?

How hard did he hit his head?

'You have not hit your head, Perseus. That has happened, every thing you thought of to yourself.' A familiar voice said, though he could not see it.

'Yes. You have gone through time. You have brought the girl's soul back with you, though it was a little later then expected.' Another voice said, still unseen as the first one.

'And we do wish to lay with you. We have grown lonely over the countless millenia.' A third voice said, unseen as the other two.

'Yes, so very lonely. But you will change that. You will change that for all those who suffer cruel injustice.' The first voice said.

'The gods have done many things wrong.' The third voice said.

'Yes, many things wrong. But you shall right those ancient wrongs, Perseus. In golden Ichor, if need be.' The second voice said.

Percy stood up, looking around him.

Only to notice something.

Nothing was moving.

Not just the normal kind of not moving.

No, there was an eerie stillness about this.

Though he only noticed it when he saw Annabeth, stuck in a position that had her looking down at the spot he just stood up from. She would have looked at him immediately if he stood up as he did, probably going to smack him for almost hitting her when he stood up.

Also, there were leaves in the air. Not falling, like leaves should. Just kinda sitting there, floating. Suspended.

'In time, Perseus.' The third voice said behind him, making him turn around.

Only to come face to chest with a woman in a doctors uniform. He looked up, seeing that it was the silver haired woman. Atropos if he remembered correctly, and wasn't going insane.

Atropos gave a slight giggle, her chest bouncing so slightly. 'Not insane, Perseus. Though even we admit that it is surprising and unexpected. Wouldn't you agree sisters?'

'Yes sister. Quite strange indeed. Though... we have a feeling...' Another woman, this one dressed as a librarian, appeared next to Atropos. This one was Lachesis if he remembered.

'That it may have something to do with that pocket book of yours.' Another one said, appearing opposite Lachesis. She was wearing a seamstresses outfit. Clotho.

Percy's hand went to his pocket at the mention the strange book. "What, this?" He asked, pulling it out.

The three nodded. 'Yes. We have seen it before, many times.' Clotho said.

'It has come to this world many times. It seemed that it was searching for something. But it never found it.' Lachesis said.

'Until now.' Atropos told him.

The three pointed at him. 'It has finally found you, Perseus Jackson. It has found who it has chosen.'

Percy looked at them, curiousity and mental exaustion on his face. "Chosen me for what? I mean, seriously. If this is actually happening, then I have to beat Kronos all over again. I have to go through this stupid war again. Is it so hard to ask for a freaking breather in life?" He asked, looking down at the little book.

The three woman frowned, sadness on their timeless faces. He would have had much, much more to do, wether or not the book had come to him.

The disappeared, only to reappear behind him.

Clotho pulled him flush against her, her arms over his shoulders and her hands resting on his chest. Lachesis appeared on his right, hugging his side. Atropos mirrored her on the left.

'Fear not Perseus. That is what the book is for.' Clotho said, moving her hands in circles on his chest.

'Yes. It will make things easier for you, if you read it and take what it says to heart.' Atropos said, hugging him a little tighter.

'Yes. No matter how strange it may be, or how you might not understand right away. It is there to help you, and you alone.' Lachesis told him.

'But, through you, it shall help many others. Just not in the way you might think.' Atropos said.

"What do you mean? Help others? And what was that bit earlier about righting ancient wrongs?" Percy asked, a little uncomfortable about the situation. He just didn't want to say anything that might make them mad. After all, they controled when he died. "And that whole...being with me thing. What's up with that? I mean, i'm nothing special." He asks.

'Says the child of prophecy and a child of one of the big three.' Clotho said, a small smirk on her lips. 'But you are wrong. You are special, though you do not acknowledge it.'

'Yes. That book proves it, though it is not what makes you special.' Atropos said.

'Though those questions are for a later time. Just know that we are on your side.' Lachesis said.

'Besides, think about those you can save. Maybe you can change Silena's allegiance.' Clotho told him.

'Or save Zoe, perhaps?'

'Bianca?'

'Free Calypso?'

"Alright, I get it." Percy said, sighing as the three let go of him and reappeared in their previous spot. "I have to go through this again. But, I guess I can change some things. Shouldn't you be against that by the way?" He asked, getting small smiles from the three.

'Normally, we would. But this is a special case.' Atropso said.

'After all, those things weigh heavy on your conscious.' Clotho said.

'And you are our future husband. We will always make allowences for you.' Lachesis told him.

Percy shuffled nervously. "Yeah, I still don't know how to act about that." He confessed.

The three nodded. 'That is fine, Perseus. It would be strange if you did. After all, one does not become "engaged" to the beings of our stature so easily. Though you will grow, over time, to understand and embrace it.' Atropos said, disappearing

'To become what you are truely meant to be.' Clotho said, before she vanished as well.

Lachesis walked up to him, carressing his face with a small smile on her own. 'Trust us, Perseus. We do not wish to bring pain to you. You are destined for many, many things. Some will see them as morally wrong, when the action is for the better. Some will claim you seek to usurp them, when they have stayed too long on their seats of power. The world is changing Perseus, and you shall be be the one to make it so.' She said, before she captured his lips with her own, though only for a split second.

Percy was shocked, though the feel of her lips made him forget it for a second. He had never been kissed before, and he still had the mentality of a sixteen year-old guy. Though the war had made him keep any hormones in check, here there was no such way to surpress it.

Lachesis pulled away, a small blush upon her face. She had a small grin on her face though. 'Just remember, Perseus. We are on your side, and we can take a more active role. We can, and will, help you. Unfortunatly, our duties must be tended to. Though we will try to make time. But know this. You can not kill Luke. He will pay for his crimes, both future and present, but not now.' She said, sternly with the warning about Luke.

Percy nodded, though he had a small frown on his face.

Lachesis smiled softly. 'I understand what you must be feeling. But you might want to take your mind off of those thoughts. Once I leave, time will flow once more. I suggest you sit out here with the child of Athena and look over that book." She said, pointing to the book, which was still in his hand.

Percy nodded, looking down at his blond friend. What was she going to think of this?

'Fear not, Perseus. She will accept it. I think she will put aside any negative thoughts about this.' The last sister of fate said, a small wink before she vanished as well.

The sounds of birds and other woodland critters sounded out, as the rustling of the trees in the wind was heard once more.

"Percy, how did you get up there? You were just laying down." Annabeth said, before she looked around. "Where are the fates?"

Percy looked down at the book in his hand. "I'll tell you about it Wise-girl. But fiorst, why don't we find somewhere comfy to relax and read."

Annabeth, despite her new outlook on Percy, couldn't help but make a face. "You? Read? Guess I'm rubbing off on you." She said, a fake snooty tone.

Both of them shared a laugh at that, before the two wandered for a bit.

After finding a good spot, the two sat down, backs against a log. Percy cracked open the book, uncaring of how Annabeth leaned against him.

"Alright. Now, the first thing in this book is...

"The harem gods music box?" Percy said. "What in Tartarus is a harem god? I don't remember any of them among, well, any of the gods, major or minor. Not even among the titans."

Annabeth sighed gently, wishing Percy was just a little smarter. Though she too was curious about a harem god. "A harem is when a guy has many women in a relationship. Mostly for the wealthy and powerful, though not unheard of major Hero's getting one." She said, going slightly into lecture mode. Hey, she wouldn't be a child of Athena if she didn't have one. "But... I'm not sure about a god of them. I don't think there is a harem god. Read on, I'm curious now."

Percy half chuckled, half-groaned at that. He knew that things that got the Wise-girl's attention would be solved, or destroyed trying.

"Alright, alright. Let's see. It says..."

Long ago, as the Eronomicon traveled the many worlds and universes of the multiverse, it came upon a strange scene. A woman, average looking at worst, sat in the middle of a field. The field itself seemed to be glistening with dew, though it was still the middle of the night. The Eronomicon, curious as to what a woman would be doing out in the middle of nowhere, floated over the field. As it got closer, it heard that the woman was singing. And, stranger yet, The Eronomicon found itself crying. It then noticed the field around it was doing the same. The grass, the rocks, the bugs that buzzed around and the flowers. All of them were crying along with it.

So enraptured by the music from this woman, the Eronomicon stayed where it was until the woman had finished her song.

Her song was a tale of unrequited love. Of how a goddess of music, Melum, was enraptured by a god of love. She had tried to earn his attention, his love. From gifts to her beautiful music, she tried to garner the tiniest bit of romantic interest.

But one day, in front of his father, the goddess had asked why he ignored her no matter what she did.

Forced to even acknowledge her in his fathers presence, the god had not answered, but instead posed his own question.

"Who are you?" He asked.

With those three words, her entire world shattered. All she had done, all she had given had been worthless. He would never acknowledge her, much less love her.

She had ran from the gods home, her voice wailing in both sorrow and anger. All who heard her felt her sorrow, her pain, and her anger. They felt the utter loneliness she felt, like they were unwanted.

But they also felt the rage directed at the god. Even the other gods were effected. In a fit of rage not his own, the gods father had bludgeoned him for the goddess, tore at his limbs and gouged out his eyes.

In the end, the goddess had the last laugh in a way.

But now, every night she would come to this field and sing her heart out. The anger had faded over time, but the sadness never healed. It was impossible for her to let the feeling of having her heart ripped out go.

But still, she wanted to be of use to someone. If she was loved by them, then so be it. But she never wanted to fade into the ether, return to nothing.

And thus, the Eronomicon gained an idea.

Once her song was finished, as the field around her cried in sorrow for her, The Eronomicon approached her. It told her of someone who would have a use for her, who would love her.

The goddess, overjoyed at this prospect, asked what it would take to be with this man. She cared not if he would use her for her body, or her talent. Only that he would want her.

The Eronomicon told her that it had not yet found the one, but he was out there. That it was searching for a man worthy of it, and through it, her. It told her to seal herself in a music box so that it could carry her through the multiverse, as she was not powerful enough to make the journey herself physically.

The goddess promised she would, and using the music box the ancient tome had provided her, sealed herself away, awaiting the one who would call upon her and free her from the music box.

Unknowingly, the music box would copy her power of music, though it would only sing of the love and devotion that she had for the harem god.

But alas, her song was not meant to be understood by all.

Those that can hear only a hint of music emanating from the box will feel the love and devotion for the harem god, but it is a fickle thing, destined to fade over time.

Those that can hear the music, but cannot understand the Lyrics, will also feel the love and devotion for him. Though it may fade overtime, it will always be in their mind, silently comparing all other men to him and finding them wanting in kindness and love.

Lastly, for those that can hear the song in all its glory, shall be filled utterly with the love and devotion that the goddess of music feels. It will become reality to them, unwavering and absolute. It would never fade, and the harem god would only be the one for them for eternity.

Percy set the book down, rubbing his head. Surprisingly his Dyslexia didn't kick in, but reading so much in one sitting hurt his head regardless. It hurt to pay attention.

Annabeth, used to the massive amounts of reading, looked a little saddened at the story. But then, it was only a story, right?

She had been raised, in a word, to believe that only the Greek gods existed.

But then again, they did go to Egypt a lot in the old days. Back when vacations didn't actually exist and the gods had more responsibility.

Did that have something to do with it? Did other sects of gods exist?

She didn't know.

And Annabeth Chase did not like 'not knowing' at all.

Then again, she seemed to have been brought back in time to Percy's first year at camp. Not to mention that the fates wanted to... 'lay' with Percy. That thought alone made her blush.

It seemed that everything she knew to be possible was being systematically torn asunder and trampled on.

She kinda liked it.

Truths exposed that were kept hidden behind lies. Truths likely kept hidden by Zeus, king of paranoia. Annabeth always liked the truth, though she understood the need for secrecy in dire situations.

"We should use it." She said suddenly, making Percy look at her through his fingers.

"What? You don't really think this is real do you?" Percy asked as he continued to rub his aching head.

"Wouldn't make much difference if it did would it?" She asked. "Besides, it seems like your the only one who can free her if it is real. Think about it Percy! She could help turn the tides of war against Kronos a lot earlier!"

"Yeah, but what about that whole Harem god stuff?"

"Yeah, what about it?"

"What would the gods think if I, supposedly, am to be some kinda god? You think Zeus would let me live? You know as well as I do how the guy gets even someone even mentions someone that is almost as strong as him he snaps! Besides, my uncle isn't very fond of me anyway. Especially if we are back in time! Remember? He tried to kill me in anyway possible on the hunch that I somehow stole the master bolt before I even knew I was a demi-god!" He said, watching the sky for any thunder clouds. Calling on the king of Olympus when you are, technically, wanted for a crime, even if you didn't commit it, is stupid.

"Think Seaweed-brain! One of the first things about being a god is immortality! If you at least get that, then Zeus can't kill you! Nothing will! Besides, it would be better then that stupid blessing that you got like Achilles'!"

"Yeah!? Okay, fine! Let's say that happens. What about the whole 'other women thing' huh? What would I do about that?" He asked angrily.

"I don't know! But it's either that or go through this with nothing but our knowledge of the future! Didn't the Fates say anything about this?" She asked.

Percy thought about it, recalling the conversation.

"Y-yeah. I... I guess they did. Read what it says and take it to heart. No matter what it says, even if I don't understand it, that it is only trying to make my life easier." He said, looking down at the book, more specificly the page that had a picture of an old wooden box. It looked kinda like the one his mom had that she would keep jewelry in that played music when it opened and spun a little ballerina around to the music. Nothing even strange about it.

But then again, that was normally the dangerous stuff in his world.

He sighed in defeat, knowing what she said was true. Besides, he was curious as well. If this goddess was real, and he was this chosen god or whatever, then he was the only one who could save her. The one she had waited who knew how long for.

"Fine, how do we do this?"

"I don't know. Doesn't the book say anything about it?"

Percy shrugged his shoulders, before turning the page back to the cover page.

It read 'Place hand on image and call forth the name of the object you desire.'

Shrugging once more, Percy did as told. Placing his hand upon the picture.

"Music box of the Harem God!" He said loudly.

For a second, nothing happened. Then his hand started to burn as light poured from between his fingers, though it did not breach the tree tops. It did, however, blind both demi-gods for a moment.

After about a minute, the light died down, and Percy felt his hand resting on a wooden box. It took a moment for the light in his eyes to die down so he could look, only to clarify that it indeed was the music box.

Percy only stared at it, his eyes wide.

It was real.

All of it.
1552222222222222222112222121.title: Music box of the Harem god.

15522222222222222221122221212.content:
Percy looked at the box in his fingers. He picked it up carefully, not know if it could be broken or what could happen if it could and did. He looked it over, seeing that it was in perfect condition, but a plain as the image suggested. Not a splinter, chip or anything.

Percy looked at Annabeth, who was rubbing her eyes to clear them.

"I-it's real." He said, almost not believing despite the evidence literally in the palm of his hand. "It's really real."

"Uh, what? It is?" Annabeth asked, blinking owlishly to get used to normal daylight again.

"Yeah! I'm holding it in my hand right now!" He said, holding it up for her to see.

Looking at it, Annabeth felt a little giddy. "Percy, do you know what this means?"

"Yeah." He said, nodding. "I guess I'm going to become a god. Of harems. Whatever that is."

Annabeth rolled her eyes, but he was somewhat right. "Well, yeah. But not just that! It means the fates were telling the truth! And there are other gods out there! And this book can help us win this war!" She said, almost bouncing in excitement at the possibilities.

Percy sighed happily, knowing that some things will never change.

"Yeah, now how do we free her without calling the wrath of the gods, literally? Actually, how do we free her?" He asked, knowing Annabeth would come up with a plan of some kind.

Annabeth went from giddy to thinking mode in no time, planning out how to not get them killed.

"Well, if she were to appear in front of a lot of people we couldn't be killed without Zeus having to make something up on the spot. We both know that he sucks at doing that. People wouldn't start to question him since they are basically told that the gods can do as they wish, even if we don't like it, but for two kids to be violently killed would draw many glances to Zeus, and it could provoke a more bloody war that will leave him worse then Kronos. Your dad would make anything Zeus could do seem kind in comparison." Annabeth said. "And without the master bolt, your dad would wipe the floor with him, natural laws be damned."

Percy nodded. Besides, if his dad could cause major earthquakes, who's to say he wouldn't literally shake mount Olympus apart? "Yeah, I'd like avoid that, especially the part where we die." He said, looking at the music box in his hands, wondering if the goddess, Melum, could hear them.

"And the biggest gathering will be tonight to welcome you to camp. It would be best to free her then, otherwise we could be easily killed by anyone." Annabeth said, making Percy nod. "But the problem comes in how to free her in the first place."

Percy just shook his head. "Don't know. But there might be a clue in the book."

"Speaking of which, wouldn't this be the Eronomicon mentioned in the story?"

"Huh. I guess it would be. Let's see. It says 'To call the goddess from her music box, simply utter this Phrase.'" He read, though he didn't say it. That would set her free before the right time.

"Can you remember it?"

"Yeah, I think so." He said, before looking down at the music box in his hand. "Don't worry. You're almost free. Just wait a little longer." He said.

Standing up, and helping Annabeth up as well, he started to make his way back to camp, music box and the box containing the minotaur hors tucked under his arm, the Eronomicon stuck in his back pocket.

"Percy?"

He stopped, looking at Annabeth. "Yeah?"

She fidgeted, looking down at her shoes. "T-there's something I want to tell you."

Percy turned around, wondering what she was talking about.

"Percy... I...I..." She couldn't say it. For some reason, her tongue tied itself as she tried to say it.

"What is it?" He asked.

Annabeth moved close to him, seeing as words wouldn't work.

"What are you do-hmmp!" Percy tried to ask, only to have her lips crash against his. Her kiss was awkward. She didn't have the faintest idea as to how to kiss romantically, though that didn't stop her from trying to show how much she wanted it.

Pulling back, Annabeth breathed out "Open it."

Percy was dazed, being kissed by the girl of his dreams does that to a guy. "Wha?"

"Open the box. I...I can't say it on my own." She said, blushing and looking away.

Percy nodded dumbly, setting down the box with his horns. He grabbed the lid of the box, opening it up.

And heard the most beautiful sound in the universe.

It put the Muse's to shame when they sang together in perfect harmony even.

Hell, he couldn't even understand hear half the words, seeing as they were garbled to him, and it sounded better than anything else he'd heard.

It made him feel like he was floating on air. Like there was a woman singing to him, and him alone. In fact, he was certain there was, though she was in the music box. But she was aware of everything outside the music box.

He looked at Annabeth, who looked like she was ready to cry tears of happiness as she looked at the music box.

Suddenly, the box snapped shut, cutting off the sound. Percy watched as Annabeth let a few tears fall as she looked at him.

"I...I love you." She said almost suddenly before she crashed against him again, kissing him with all her feelings forced into that one action. It was still awkward, due to both their inexperience, but that would fix itself over time.

The two stayed there for a while, Kissing each other on the forest floor. Just enjoying the others presence.

Percy didn't even have to say anything, knowing that Annabeth knew he loved her back.

They would have stayed longer, but some nymphs came by, giggling up a storm at the couple.

"Um... You wouldn't tell anyone about this would you?" Percy asked, blushing a bit at being caught.

The lead nymph walked forward, sashaying her hips with a seductive smile on her face.

"We might keep quiet, for a price." She said, batting her lashes at Percy.

"Y-yeah?"

"Mm hm." The nymph hummed while nodding.

"What do you want?" He asked, wondering how Annabeth was taking this so calmly. Nymphs were known to be seductive, though not all wanted to do anything with men. It was just in their nature to be cock-teases.

"Well," She said, getting her face close to Percy's own. "You could always come by my tree. Maybe shake the leaves a bit, if you know what I mean." She said with a wink, but looking at Annabeth out of the corner of her eye.

It was also well known that Nymphs liked to stir up trouble between couples. Luring men by the nose, letting them break up with their loved one, only to dump them on the spot. They didn't mean any harm, but they considered it to be a prank of some kind, or a test of faithfulness. Depends on the Nymph you ask.

"W-well I-I-I"

"It's fine." Annabeth cut him off mid-stuttering, looking directly at the Nymph. "So long as you keep your end of the deal, all of you," She said, looking at the rest of the Nymphs. "And not tell anybody about this."

The Nymph and her friends looked directly at Annabeth, eyes wide. Was she serious? She would really share her boyfriend with other girls just to keep her relationship secret? That had never happened before, in the history of Nymphs.

Ever!

"You serious?" The Nymph, who was still in Percy's face asked, looking at Annabeth out of the corner of her eye.

"Deathly." She retorted almost instantly.

The Nymph stood up, going back to her friends in a huddle.

They sat around for awhile while the Nymphs discussed the deal. Was it worth it? Could they keep the promise?

After some debate, the first Nymph went back to the two.

"Alright, fine. We have a deal." She said, putting out her hand.

But Annabeth shook her head. "Nuh uh. You have to swear on the river Styx, all of you."

The nymph bristled slightly at that, but nodded. "I swear upon the river Styx that Neither me or my friends will tell anyone in anyway that you two are in a relationship, lest our tree's and bushes spontaneously combust." She said through gritted teeth. There went her gossip, but she needed a good lay.

The sky overhead shook, signaling that the deal was set. If any of them let anyone know about Percy and Annabeth, they would die. They couldn't even leave a note anywhere that said the fact on purpose!

"Good." Annabeth said with a smirk at getting one up on nature's hussies. "We have a deal. We'll set up a schedule or something. But now we got to head back to camp." Annabeth said as she stood up, holding her hand out to Percy.

Percy, still gob smacked at what Annabeth just did, took her hand wordlessly as he grabbed both the music box and the minotaur horn box, letting her lead him back to camp.
15522222222222222221122221212.title: Plan of action, a confession, and a wonderful deal

Pulls the lid back, uttering the phrase and letting Melum free to sing her song!
155222222222222222211222212121.content:
Percy was sitting at the Hermes table. The camp had just finished dinner, and soon it would be time for the bon-fire.

After returning to camp, Percy had a little bit of a tough time with remembering that he was back in time.

It started off with him almost walking to cabin three, Poseidon's cabin, his cabin.

When a few of the campers asked him about, he just played it off as being interested in it, saying that he liked the design. They took that at face value, remembering what it had been like their first time at camp.

Then it came with meeting Luke at the Hermes cabin. Percy had tried to be civil, he really had. But, well, it was kind of had being civil with the person who had tried to kill him multiple times and end the world as he knew it.

He kept himself from decking the guy in his scarred face, but when Luke had questioned him about the look about him, Percy said that it was the fact that his mom was killed, or so it seemed, by something he only thought to be a myth.

Luke tried to cheer him up, saying that he knew what is was like to lose his mother to the horrors of the Greek stories.

While Percy knew that was true, it didn't make him feel any better. Luke was still evil, even if he didn't show it.

It didn't help that it seemed that Dionysus had Grover tailing him as soon as he got back to camp, though he did so badly since Percy could easily tell where the Satyr was most of the time.

Surprisingly, unlike last time, Clarisse hadn't bothered him. He guessed hearing how he brutally killed the thing with both it's horns made her not want to mess with him, though he doubted that was actually the case. This was a daughter of Ares we're talking about here.

The day had passed relatively smoothly after that, though Percy and Annabeth had to be careful because of Grover.

After meeting Luke, Percy and Annabeth had gone down to the arena to spar, Annabeth's reasoning that they should get their bodies back into tip-top shape for the coming quest to go get the master bolt.

They had gathered a crowd of onlookers, much to their dismay, but it didn't seem to matter. The crowd just chocked it up to natural talent, or maybe he was another Ares kid.

They continued to spar long into the day, the crowd eventually becoming most of the camp, minus Chiron and Mr. D. and other campers. Neither had an idea as to why, but they were kind of glad that they weren't there.

After that, nothing happened for the rest of the day worth mentioning. Percy rested after the spar until it was time for dinner. That's it.

He was brought from his thoughts as Luke patted him on the back. Looking around, Percy saw that he and Luke were the only ones left, the others going to the amphitheater for the large bonfire, and not the sacrificial one.

"Hey Percy, you coming?" Luke asked him, hand on his shoulder. "I mean, It's not everyday we get a new camper, and Apollo cabin tells the best campfire stories."

Percy grit his teeth, though he didn't show it. "Yeah. Um, would you mind if I went back to the cabin to get something?"

Luke shook his head. "Nah, go ahead. Though I can't say for certain it's still there. You know, being the cabin for the god of thieves and all." He said with a chuckle.

Percy shook his head, forcing a smile. "Ah, I'm sure it's fine. I'll see you at the bon-fire." He said, waving off Luke.

"Alright. See ya there then." Luke said walking off, waving back at Percy.

Once he was sure that Luke was gone, Percy ran back to the cabin, digging through his meager amount of stuff. He found the music box, picking it up gently and raced out to the bon-fire.

"Don't worry. You'll be free soon." He said to it as he ran through camp.

Once he had arrived at the amphitheater, Apollo cabin was already in the middle of a comedic rendition of the story of Theseus and the Minotaur, though Dionysus looked dark as the story was told. No surprise there though. It only reminded him that he wasn't allowed to see his beloved during his time as camp director.

Heading down the steps, he saw Luke waving to him, patting a seat next to him.

Percy grimaced slightly, though he quickly put the smile once more as he moved to sit next to Luke.

"Hey, get what you're lookin' for?" He asked.

"Yeah, I got it." Percy replied.

"Cool. Didn't expect that. Figured it would being sold at the camp store or something tomorrow."

"Yeah." Percy said. "Hey, do they take volunteers Luke?"

"Sometimes. Depends on the story Apollo cabin's telling. Why, got a story or something newbie?" Luke joked.

Percy fingered the box in his hand. "Something like that."

Luke looked down, seeing the music box. "What's that? Something to do with your story?"

"Kinda. I would say that the music box is the story though."

"What? Whatever. Make it yourself? I wouldn't have you pegged as a kid of Hephaestus, but there's been weirder things then a kid of old fire beard being skinny. One time, we a camper who could grow things like a daughter of Demeter or Mr. D., but was actually a daughter of Aphrodite. Stayed perfectly clean every time she helped in the fields. Not even a speck of dirt on her shoes!" He said with a laugh.

Percy let out a genuine laugh. That image was funny. Maybe she had some more godly ancestry then just her mother? Was that possible?

"Oh look! They're nearly done! Just the final scene with Theseus leaving his girl behind for old Mr. D. to take back to Olympus. Yeah, like that worked out for her." Luke said, a little contempt seeping into his voice. Not a lot, and you would have to be listening for it to hear it, but it was clear as day to Percy.

Once the play was done, and Dionysus looked a somber fellow, the crowds were cheering and laughing as the entire cabin took a bow, though the guy in the Minotaur costume had troubles getting back up the fake head was so heavy.

Chiron walked onto the stage, clopping his hoof for attention.

"Good evening everyone! Now I all know you've seen our new family member, but allow me to formally introduce Perseus Jackson!" He said, getting a round of applause. No matter your attitude to them normally, It was always welcome to have a new camper. New kid for the Ares kids to beat up on, or the Aphrodite kids to mess with. But it meant that another one of them had survived to make it to camp. That number was always low.

"Stand up Percy." Luke said, patting him on the back.

Percy appeased the crowed, standing up as they cheered for another win against the dangers of being born a demi-god.

"Come on down Percy." Chiron called out, making the camps cheer louder. They knew what was coming up.

Percy was confused however. He didn't remember any of this.

Doing as the centaur told him, Percy went down to the stage, standing next to the horseman with his music box in hand.

"Now tell us Percy. Do you remember a time you've had something strange happen to you, almost unexplainable before, but now makes sense? All the campers have had at least something, some kind of monster attack them, or watch them when they were little. Anything like that?" He asked.

Percy nodded. "Yeah, but do you mind if I did something else?" He asked, holding the music box up for the centaur to see.

"Hmm. I don't see why not. Very well. Though I don't see what could be so interesting about a music box." Chiron said, giving it a critical eye as well as Percy. The crazy talk he had spouted earlier that day had thoroughly disturbed him. Talk of war, and the titans rising once more.

Percy stood to face the cheering crowd, looking for Annabeth, who gave a thumbs up.

Percy breathed in, reached for the music box lid and...

Percy has Melum sing her tale, giving Chiron a little to go on.
1552222222222222222112222121212.content:
Percy hooked his fingers around the edge of the lid, ready to pry it off.

'I hope this works.' He thought, feeling the sweat drip down his brow. It was, literally do or die time. He could be struck down by lightning as soon as he let her free.

Percy tore open the music box, letting the song play for all to hear.

And, due to the amphitheater, which is made with carrying sound in mind to make sure the people at the top could hear, the song rang out loud and clear, echoing into the forest.

The guys were wondering what the heck it was, and why it did nothing, while the girls started crying, though at different levels of intensity. Most were just hearing a hint of the music, though that was more then enough to drive them to tears at the sound. The others, minus Annabeth, were hearing the music, but not the lyrics, and they cried harder then the girls from before.

Annabeth was the only girl unaffected, having heard the full brunt of the song. It was still beautiful to her, but it didn't have to do anything to her. She just smiled as the music filled her soul once more.

Chiron, who was stamping his hooves in worry, looked at the music box, figuring it to be the source of the problem.

"Perseus Jackson! Close that box!" Chiron yelled, preparing to force it closed if necessary.

'Now or never' Percy thought, seeing Chiron about to charge him.

"Melum! I release you from the music box!" He yelled. "Come forth! Your master has need of you!"

Just like that, the box started to shake violently in Percy's hand. He stood there looking at it, not exactly expecting this.

Cracks appeared in it, running all around it as the music got louder and louder, light emanating from both the open lid of the box and the numerous cracks, steadily growing brighter and brighter.

It seemed that the other guys started to hear it as well, because Percy could hear the guys asking what that sound was, referring to the music box.

Even Chiron and Mr. D. noticed The music, though neither was as transfixed as the demi-gods, they still found themselves curious as to who or what Percy was summoning. It wasn't as if they could stop it now.

Percy continued to look at the box, watching as the fractures grew wider and wider, the light brighter and brighter, the sound louder and clearer.

Then, suddenly, it floated out of his hands, still shaking, the light growing to almost unbearable levels. Everyone was forced to avert their eye's as the small box shook wildly, the song reaching it's crescendo.

*BOOM*

The box exploded, whipping up a strong wind around the entire amphitheater that mirrored the song's tone, tearing at people's hair and clothes, blowing debris everywhere from the stage, which now had a large crater in it.

Suddenly, abruptly, the song ended.

Percy coughed, rubbing his eyes to see anything, looking to see if anyone was injured.

Only to be met with pure blue orbs staring into his eyes. No black pupil or white sclera, only pure blue.

Percy stumbled back slightly, putting some distance between himself and what he could only assume to be Melum.

He looked her over. Other then her eyes and slightly paler then normal yet shiny skin there was nothing overly notable about her appearance.

She was about 5' 6'' tall, with a thin body type. Her face was thin, from her nose to her chin. Her chest was nothing large, maybe a lower c-cup. Her stomach was flat, neither muscle nor fat. Her hips were small, with a pert rump. Her legs were slender, delicate, ending in petite feet. And her hair, which was shoulder length, was black, contrasting with her skin perfectly.

"A-are you Melum?" Percy asked, wanting to make absolutely sure.

The woman smiled, nodding. "And you are my master. The one who has called me from the music box." She said, her voice carrying above the still rushing wind perfectly, though she barely spoke above a whisper it sounded. Just the sound of it made Percy go weak at the knees. It was the voice he had definitely heard earlier in the woods when he used the music box, the voice singing to him. "May I know the name of my master?" She asked.

"Perseus Jackson. But my friends call me Percy." He said, not really sure how to address the literal goddess before him. She was being subservient, though most people he knew were aggressive most of the time, especially the goddess's he had met.

"Perseus? Perseus." Melum said, testing out the name. "Yes. A fine name for a good master. I am your humble servant Lord Perseus. Command me, and I shall do my best to follow through in whatever you may ask." She said with another small smile.

Perseus Jackson! What in Tartarus have you done?" Chiron yelled above the dying winds, making his way through the field of debris with great difficulty.

At the sound of hostility in his voice, Melum placed herself between Percy and the centaur, ready to defend him from any harm this potential enemy may try to cause him.

Scrambling into the crater at the epicenter of the blast, Chiron found himself staring down with a stone-faced Melum.

"Madam, I don't know who you are or how you got here but I ask that you step aside." Chiron said, though it wasn't a matter of asking. He was ordering her.

"I cannot do that. What are your intentions towards the master?" She asked rigidly, her tone brooking no room for argument.

"Master? What in the name of... Do you speak of Perseus Jackson? I wish to know what he has done to ruin the amphitheater and why!" Chiron said, puzzled as to why this woman was regarding Perseus as her master. It was getting strange, even for him. Never had he seen anything like this in his immortal life.

"He freed me, pure and simple. I was inside the music box, waiting for a long time for someone to release me. He was worthy enough to come into possession of it, and he chose to free me, though he did not have to." She stated, the melodic tone in her voice gone, ready to make the centaur feel pain if she needed to.

This only made the puzzle harder for Chiron, not really understanding what was happening. Last time he saw Percy, at least three days ago, He had nothing special about him other then being a demi-god. And yet he now had this strange woman calling him master? What in the name of the gods had happened in such a short amount of time?
1552222222222222222112222121212.title: Freeing the goddess!
