15522222222222222221122221212121.content:
Melum stood ready, in case the centaur charged. He seemed confused, but she couldn't let down her guard. If he tried to attack, she would end him.

"Wait!" Percy yelled at the two, trying to keep things civil. He needed to do something! Chiron wanted to know what was going on, but was ready to attack due to the strange and destructive arrival of Melum. Percy admitted that Chiron had the right to know what was happening, and that the camp wasn't under attack or anything. "Melum! Sing!" He told her suddenly, thinking that while it was a long shot, Chiron would at least calm down a bit.

"About what my master?" She asked, her tone going from the one she used with Chiron to the soft melodic tone once more.

"Sing your song, about your past!" He said, making her nod.

She drew in a deep breath, the very air ringing as she did, as if knowing what was going to happen.

Chiron was about to order her to stop and stand down, but before he could do so, and before Melum could sing, a large pillar of fire erupted in the middle of the two.

"Perseus Jackson!" A booming, angry voice called out from the raging inferno, making Melum move back closer to Percy.

Percy watched as the fire died down, revealing a large winged, burning man like thing with what looked like charred skin. He defiantly didn't remember anything like this.

"Perseus Jackson!" The man-thing roared again. "Return my helm to me! I know you have taken it! Just like my brother's Master bolt!" He roared, looking directly at Percy as he flapped his fiery wings in a fury. "But I will offer you a deal. Bring me back my helm, and I won't reduce your mother's soul to ash. However, whether she lives is yet to be seen."

"Who are you to order my master?" Melum asked, the steely tone in her voice once more.

The flaming demon turned his gaze to Melum, his face a sneer.

"You dare question me, wench?" He asked, looking directly into her eyes. "I am Hades!" He yelled, the fire around him flaring higher.

Melum let the flame lick at her skin, not caring. It mattered little to her right now. What mattered was that this... being... tried to order her master around. She could sense he was a god, but he looked a demon in his current guise. Was he truly a god in this realm, or merely an interloper in matters that he should not tamper with?

"That matters little to me. Now, leave. Or I will make you." She said to him, earning a growl for her efforts.

"You think to order me? I am the lord of the dead!" Hades yelled, flinging his arms forward. At his behest, the flames that swirled around his feet and hands shot towards Melum and Percy, twisting into black hellfire, normally seen only in Tartarus.

"Melum!" Percy yelled, wishing he had a water source close by. Not that it would do any good, but he would have felt better knowing he can do something. Nothing he could create could have even stood close to his underground uncle. He had seen those flames before, during the battle at the base of the empire state building, just before Hades summoned his armies. It left a large trench in the middle of the street, which some of the skeletal warriors used as, well, trenches.

Melum closed her eyes. The flames did not make her fear for herself, for she could not die. But her master was not so lucky as of now. The bond of immortality had not yet formed, though it had begun in taking root. Ever since he had first touched the Eronomicon, the process had begun.

She took a deep breath. She heard her masters worry for her, but not for himself. It brought a small smile to her face, knowing that in the few moments he had known her that he already cared for her.

She snapped open her eyes, looking directly at the barrage of flame. With no effort, she released the air in her lungs. It wasn't really singing, closer to yelling or screaming, but not quite that either.

It sounded strangely beautiful, though it had a physical force behind it that dissuaded one from the sheer beauty of it. It could be compared to opera, but that was a stretch to do so.

The sound, and the force it carried with it and embodied, raced along the ground, tearing chunks from the stone, stirring up a great wind and leaving a large trench in its wake, the ground and air around it shaking horrendously as the sound waves passed.

The sound connected with the hellfire, keeping it from moving forward towards them. Melum continued to sing, keeping up the sound barrier, as the flames melted the stone underneath it to lava in mere seconds.

Hades, surprised that someone could withstand the flames of punishment, poured more power into it, hoping to incinerate the one who dared to order him about.

Melum returned the favor, letting her own power rise. The sound got louder, more intense. The trees around the amphitheater let loose great cracks, though thankfully there were no nymphs in these trees, just in case a play went wrong somehow and the area around it caught fire or exploded.

However, the sound became painful for most of those hearing it. The sound itself promised pain for Hades, but in turn it caused those around the two divine beings to feel the pain she wanted to inflict on him.

Percy, Annabeth and Chiron included.

Percy went to his knees at the sound. It felt like something was splitting open his skull, worse then any headache he had received in the past from any number of monsters, injuries or anything else. It didn't help with the rushing wind and shaking ground, though he could stand easily on that. His dad did cause earthquakes after all.

Hades grimaced. He had no love for the children of the Olympians, but he could not kill them. His family, how he detested that word, would all turn their attention on him. Zeus was still angry about him sending the monsters after his newest daughter, Thalia Grace, even though Zeus broke the oath. And his other brother, Poseidon would likely flood the underworld, or at least try to, if he killed Percy.

Oh yes. He knew that Poseidon had a child, breaking the oath himself. Technically, he had the right to kill him, but it would not be without retaliation.

"Enough!" Hades roared, letting his flames die down slowly. Melum did the same. She would not provoke him into unnecessary battle, knowing that it would likely put her master in danger. "If you wish to reclaim your mothers soul, Perseus, then you will come to the underworld. Return my helm to me, and your mother will be free." He said, his voice a, literal, deathly whisper.

The flames rose high around Hades as he curled the wings around his body, his black gaze looking at both Percy and Melum. The flames grew bright, forcing the ones that weren't gods to look away. With a great explosion sound coming from the fiery tornado, the flames died down, leaving a melted patch of earth where hades stood.

The light faded, Percy could look again. He saw Melum, crouching over him, tears in her eyes.

"Forgive me master. I did not mean to harm you. But it was the only way to stop him." She said, her voice sad, but not shaky. "I will take any punishment you would wish to give me." She said, her head bowed. "Just, please, don't send me away." She said, her voice almost choking. She feared that, despite his kindness earlier in freeing her, he would be angry with her. Angry enough to send her away.

She knew she wouldn't be able to handle that.

The one person she felt she could be useful to, sending her away, was her greatest fear. It had been since she had accepted the books deal. Without him, she felt that her immortal life would be meaningless. She would be worthless, and likely fade back to nothingness, or so she felt.

"Why would I do that?" He asked, looking up at her. "I never turn my back on people. Especially when they need me." He said, standing up. "C'mon. Don't cry." He said, pulling the goddess into a hug.

Melum stiffened. He wouldn't... leave her? More tears sprung to her eyes, though these ones of happiness. She slowly wrapped her arms around him, hugging him back as the tears started to fall silently.

Percy just patted her back, rubbing it slowly. He looked up, hearing the clopping of hooves, to see Chiron stand over him.

"We need to talk, Perseus." The old centaur said, his tone brokering no argument but without the hostility it held earlier when Melum was released.

Percy Nodded. "Yeah. We do. But you have to promise me something." Percy said, his own tone saying that he was dead serious.

"We'll see." The horse man said, turning away towards the big house. Percy, after motioning Annabeth over, made his way to the big house. He knew what was likely to happen. He kept his face blank though. It was a matter of life and death right now, and one false move could end in both his and Annabeth's death.

Whether it be from Zeus, or an angry camp director had yet to be seen. Dionysus was likely going to tear into him for this. Not to mention that the news he had could spell trouble if the god did hear it. What he was about to tell Chiron would be only for him. It would have to stay between them and Chiron, or the fates would have a hard time sorting out the mess that would happen with the knowledge of the future falling to the gods.

The quest is differant, the fates speaking through the Oracle.
155222222222222222211222212121212.content:
Chiron rounded on Percy as they entered the meeting room of the big house.

"You will explain what is going on here, Perseus." Chiron said, look Percy dead in the eye. "From they insanity you were spilling earlier when you awoke, all the way to your... friend." He said, glancing at Melum.

"I will Chiron, I promise. But two things need to happen. One, I need to know if Mr. D is here." Percy said, his own seriousness look boring into the centaur.

Chiron shook his head. "No, he was called to an emergency meeting of the gods. Something I think has to do with what you did at the amphitheater. He left just before Hades appeared." He said, running his head to dull the last vestiges of pain caused by Melum. "You are lucky to have survived young lady." He said to Melum.

"The one you call Hades could not have killed me. There is only one who could do so, and that is only by leaving me with no purpose, no use." She said, her voice once again melodic.

"Indeed." Chiron said, gazing over the goddess. She seemed to have that... aura... that gods had, so it was likely she was in possession of immortality. "Whatever the case may be, I must ask. Why is Ms. Chase here?" He asked, turning to the blond.

"Let's just say that I can back up his claims Chiron." Annabeth said, her tone being the one she used when she would be listened to, even if others didn't want to hear. Percy had been on the receiving end of it a few times during the war.

Chiron sighed. "Very well. I won't ask until after whatever you have to tell me."

Percy nodded. "Yeah, that's probably best. But..."

"But?"

"I need you to swear on the River Styx that what I tell you does not leave this room, and stays between us. If you can't then you're going to only trust us on blind faith, if you'll trust us at all." Percy said.

Chiron bristled. He hated swearing upon the River of death. But, he had never heard this tone during his time teaching Percy.

"Very well. I, Chiron, Swear upon the River Styx to not tell a single person, god, mortal or anything else about what is said in this room." He said, the sky rumbling in acceptance of the oath.

Percy nodded, visibly relaxing. "I, Perseus Jackson, swear on the River Styx that what I am about to say is the truth." He said, the sky rumbling again. "There, that should prove what I'm about to say."

Chiron nodded, wondering how Percy knew about ancient Greek customs that weren't normally touched upon in the mythos. "Very well. I am interested in where this has to go."

With that, Percy told Chiron a lot of the future. Several things, such as Luke turning traitor and the Eronomicon were left out, as well as his relationship with the fates and Annabeth.

Hey, that stuff was personal.

Tale finished, Percy sat down in the chair, a glass of water appearing. He wasn't so good at long stories, and that was the longest he had told with having to make sure he didn't give anything away that he shouldn't.

He also explained Melum's music box as something he gained on the return trip through time, which he explained as Kronos' last ditch effort to harm him in some way.

Annabeth was silent through the whole thing, surprisingly enough for her, interjecting when Percy forgot a crucial detail here and there. Her late appearance was explained as her getting caught a little while after Percy, so she ended up a little behind.

Chiron got up and began trotting around, muttering things that are usual in a scenario like this, like 'Not good, Not good in the slightest' and 'By the gods, how did this happen?' all the while.

"You see why I wanted it kept secret Chiron?" Percy asked, making the centaur nod gravely.

"Indeed. If something like this were to come to the knowledge of the gods, everything would fall apart. The gods would war amongst themselves, blaming one another for this as the titans marched upon Olympus. Oh this is very bad. A second titan war will be catastrophic, no matter how much we know of the future. By telling me this, you could have already changed things, not to Mention the arrival of a new goddess." He said, looking at Melum. "And, for you my dear, I think you should be wary of Zeus. His promiscuous ways will likely try to claim you as well."

"And he shall never have me, unless my master wishes it." She said evenly.

"Which I don't and will never." Percy said, a grimace on his face. No way he could do that to someone, whoring them out. The thought sickened him immensely.

"Ah, but I fear Zeus will not like that and try to press his luck. He never did take Rejection well." Chiron said. "There was this one woman, during the old days, that wanted nothing to do with the guise Zeus had set himself up with. Even when he had shown her that he was undeniably the king of gods, she wanted nothing to do with him. In a fit of rage, Zeus ordered Aphrodite's son, Cupid, to strike her heart with a little Experiment Hephaestus whipped up for the love god. A Lead tipped arrow with a golden sliver in the heart of it. This would make her love only the most horrible man in the world, hating everyone else. it eventually drove the poor woman to madness, though I won't say what she did." he said, shivering. "But, suffice to say, Zeus has an intense Jealous streak longer then the Straights of Hercules and the Fields of Asphodel combined."

"It matters not. If he tries to harm me or my master, he will feel my wrath. I am not bound by your rules, Centaur. Only by the Rules that govern all gods." Melum said, her blue eyes flashing slightly in anger.

"Yes, well, take it as fair warning anyway." Chiron said, coughing into his hand. "Anyways, I think it's time for you to see the Oracle to obtain your quest. A little Early, I know from what You've told me. But it doesn't seem like anything would benefit you from staying for the capture the flag tournament. And don't worry about Mr. Underwood. He will accompany you along on your quest still. Melum, despite her standing, considers herself your servant. Therefore, she would not count as one of the people on a quest. Heroes of old had Retainers and the like on quests they were supposed to undertake alone sometimes, and this would be no different." He said, ushering the marked one up the stairs to the Attic. "I will be attending to the wounded, so I will not be here when you come down." He yelled up as the door closed. Taking another moment to calm himself, Chiron trotted out of the big house and over to the Apollo cabin to help the injured of Melum's arrival.

1552222222222222222112222121212122.content:
Percy looked around the derelict attic, remembering his first time in the place. He was still skeptical at the time, and this was one of the last things to make it real to him.

The memorophilia of quests long completed were gathered here, though for what purpose Percy still didn't know.

But the one thing that Percy was up here for was to speak with the Oracle, the dried husk that Hades wouldn't let die. Poor woman.

Percy walked along the only clear path, leading right where he needed to go.

He stepped before the mummified corpse of the Oracle, wondering if his quest this time would change. He took a deep breath to prepare himself, because speaking with the Oracle was never easy.

"What is my destiny"

Almost instantly, the green smoke poured out of the skeletal mouth of the Oracle. Though there was much, much more of the smoke this time, more than any other time he had seen the Oracle.

As he watched, the smoke formed into three feminine forms, before actually solidifying.

'Hello, Perseus.' The soft voice of Atropos rang in his head.

'We were expecting you.' Clotho said, smoothing out her clothes.

Percy was a little startled by their appearance, but he put that aside. "Um, hey." He started, lamely. "I, uh, came for my quest. Is this one of the way's you'll contact me?"

Lachesis nodded at him, lips curved slightly in a smile showing her amusement with his reaction. 'Indeed. We'll take care of your quests, along with the child of Athena when needed. We'll tell the two of you if some things need to be taken care of on your journeys.'

"Oh, alright then." Percy said. "So, what's my quest?"

'Well, the quest will be the same as last time, so the prophecy regarding it will be the same.' Clotho said. 'You will go west, and face the god who has turned.'

'You shall find what was stolen, and see it safely returned.' Lachesis said. 'You shall be betrayed by one who calls you a friend.'

'And you will fail to save what matters most in the end.' Atropos intoned. 'But you already know all that, and I hope you remember.'

Percy nodded. "Yeah. I go to visit Hades and fight Ares. I find the Master bolt and Hades Helm, and bring it back. Luke," He paused, the memory of the day Luke attacked him rising up. "Luke will betray me, and the rest of us. And I'll 'fail' to save my mom from Hades." He said, putting his head in his hand. "But, somethings not right. Hades never showed up here demanding his helmet back before."

'You're right, he did not.' Atropos said, putting her hand on her chin.

'Things will change Perseus. Have you ever heard of the butterfly effect?' Clotho asked.

"The what?"

'We'll take that as a no.' Lachesis said. 'To put it simply, even the smallest change to the past can greatly alter the future. You woke up early, and you were more brutal with your slaying of the Minotaur. Those acts alone caused great changes in the future, though they may not be obvious at first.'

'Along with our standing beside you, and the knowledge you posses, along with the book and what it holds, the future is in chaos.' Clotho said, pointing at Percy's pocket where the book resided. 'We have been working hard to settle things down, but with the things that book can do and where it has been, it is harder to do so.'

'Though we don't blame you or the book.' Atropos said quickly, seeing a small amount of guilt on Percy's face. 'But let us forget about that now. We are almost finished re-weaving our tapestry of fate up to a certain point, and it need not concern you yet.'

'Yes, we have a few things that you need to fix on the quest.' Clotho said. 'You remember Medusa, correct?' She asked, getting a nod from Percy. 'Right, well, we think that the poor girl has been punished long enough.'

The others nodded in agreement. 'It is unfair that she be punished for so long for your father's deed. We think the time is right to lift her curse, and make it a gift.' Lachesis said.

'A way to make up for all the suffering she had to go through, being turned into a monster none could look upon.' Atropos said.

Percy nodded, though a little uncertainly. "Um, how? I can't look at her, as you said. And even if I could, how could I break the curse?" He asked.

'Hmm, yes. It is quite a tall order, as humans put it.' Clotho said, humming in thought. 'The first part is simple enough, the book should have something in it to combat such things. Ask the goddess who is not of our world. She has a much more intimate knowledge of what it contains, we would think. As for the second, we have little to work with.'

'Yes, only Athena could do so, unless the book has something to do about that as well.' Lachesis said. 'Ask the goddess about that as well, Perseus. If not, we are sure we could work events your way.'

'Yes. We could find a way for Athena to become repentant enough to feel guilt for what she has done, though that would take time.' Atropos mused. 'And then there is the fact that if our help is not needed, Athena may seek retribution against you.'

'Which we will not allow.' Clotho and Lachesis both said adamantly. 'Perseus, we ask that you plan for such an occasion if our help is not required. For this, we know that the book will help you.'

"Alright?" Percy said, having to take all of that in. "Anything else?"

The three sisters of fate looked at one another for a few moments, before nodding. 'Yes. We think that it is time the mother of monsters, Echidna, be brought to heel.' Atropos said.

'Indeed. Her abilities would make a boon for our side in the war, and it would slow down the monsters working for the gods who are sent after you.' Clotho said, nodding her head again. 'The book could help you in that regard as well.'

"Um, I don't know how, but alright then. I guess I'll ask Melum as soon as I can." Percy said. "Anything else I should do?"

'No, that is all. Though if anything new comes up in the weave of destiny we will let you know. Farewell, dear husband. Until next time.' Lachesis said, turning into green smoke.

'Indeed. And hopefully you will be more accepting of us as we wish you would be.' Clotho said before she, too, turned to smoke.

Atropos moved away from the swirling green smoke, moving closer to him. 'Yes, dear husband. We will wait for you though, until you feel comfortable sharing your bed with us.' She said, as like Lachesis before her, she pulled him into a kiss, though this one lasted a little longer.

Once she pulled away from Percy, giving a mischievous smile at the, once more, flustered look on his face. She placed her hand on his cheek as she slowly turned to smoke from her feet up. 'Until we have time again, sweet Perseus.' She whispered lovingly as the rest of her body turned to smoke.

The green smoke whirled into a single cloud once more, before entering the Oracle once more.

It took Percy a moment to come back to his senses. The feel of their lips on his was amazing still, and it brought his natural hormones out. He squashed them down, seeing as he had more important things to do, such as get ready for his quest, along with his secondary objective's.
1552222222222222222112222121212122.title: The new quest and the start of a grand legend.

15522222222222222221122221212121222.content:
Percy walked down the stairs from the still creepy attic, hoping that nothing would get out of hand anytime soon. It seemed that his future would take that in spades, and then some. He suppressed a sigh, bringing a hand to his head.

“Why does my life have to be so messed up?” He asked no one in particular. “Well, I can't say that the fates are doing it, and I can't say they got it out for me.”

Unfortunately, it seemed that some being that was more powerful then the fates did have it out for him.

“Percy!”

Percy took off down the halls hearing his name being called, especially considering it was Annabeth who was calling for him.

“Annab-Oof!” Percy tried to call, before he collided with someone and fell. On reflex, Percy put his hands out to the side, keeping from falling right on them. Below him was Annabeth, who was rubbing her forehead.

Percy blushed at how close they were, but stood up, helping Annabeth as he did so. “What's wrong? Where's Melum?”

“That's the problem!” Annabeth said frantically. “Some campers followed us here. They were from the Apollo cabin and the Ares cabin!”

“What?” He asked, almost yelling.

“Never mind right now. I'll explain on the way.” Annabeth said, grabbing his hand and pulling him along. “Come on!”

The two of them raced down the hall of the big house, flying down the stairs as if they were blessed by Hermes.

“What's going on Annabeth?” Percy asked as he ran.

“Well, you were up there for a long time. It's been a few hours since you went to speak with the oracle.” She said, stopping as they opened the front door. “See? The sum's rising already!”

It was true, the sun poking above the mountain tops of their secluded camp. Percy could almost imagine a tired Apollo yawning as he drove the sun, in whatever form it may be, over the horizon.

“Whoa.” Percy said as he shielded his eyes from the sun. “How'd tha-”

“No time!” Annabeth said, grabbing his hand again. “We gotta find where they took her.” She said, pulling him off the porch and into the camp grounds.

“Do you know why they took Melum?” Percy asked, almost falling over as Annabeth stopped to look around for any indication they might have been there.

“Percy, think.” She said, narrowing her eyes at a few broken branches that were being fussed over by some nymphs. “Her entrance wasn't exactly the nicest. I saw a lot of campers sustained wounds from everything that transpired at the amphitheater. My guess is that the Apollo cabin is after her because she gave so many people injuries that they've been working overtime to heal them. Ares, well, do I have to explain?” She asked.

Not waiting for an answer, she ran off past the nymphs, pulling Percy along again. He nearly tripped over one of them as they lashed out with their legs, thinking he might have been the one to do this to their homes.

They were running through the camps woods now, dodging through the trees with ease. More and more signs that a large group of people had been through there showed up, though not as obvious as the nymphs and their trees. It seems they got more careless the further away they got from camp.

“Hey, do you guys think we're far enough away now?” They heard, making the two of them crouch down and hide behind a fallen log. “ I mean, we've been leading her through these woods for about twenty minutes now.”

“Micheal Yew, son of Apollo.” Annabeth whispered, recognizing the voice. He went MIA during the final battle of the war, so it was a little bit of a jolt to hear his voice again.

“Yeah. Too bad we can't knock her out. Would be so much easier to have dragged her out here.” A gruffer voice said.

“Austin Reeds. Just by the sound of his voice, a child of Ares.” Annabeth whispered again. “This isn't good. Both are the second in command of their cabins.”

“Well, if some people hadn't been known for using excessive force, we would have tried that.” Micheal said. “You know, you almost hurt Annabeth pretty badly back there.”

“Who cares?” Another gruff voice said. “She's just another child of Athena. What could she do, read us to death?” He asked mockingly, laughing at his own stupid joke.

“I... I don't recognize that voice.” Annabeth said. “Must have been a relatively new camper at this time.”

“Shut up Kevin.” Austin said. “I swear, you must be stupid or something.” A loud smack sounded, followed by a yelp from Kevin. “Yeah, we should be far enough out by now.”

Percy looked over at Annabeth, only now noticing that she had a bit of red in her blond hair, mostly the back of her head. Anger started to rise in him, even if it was against other campers. Just what in Tartarus were they thinking?

He was about to ask, when she looked at him with a look that told him that they would talk over it later. It still didn't lessen the anger he was feeling right now though.

Percy dared to peek over the log, seeing Melum gagged with a cloth, both tied over her mouth and by a ball of it in her mouth if he was seeing right, and her hands tied. Several kids of Ares, which he could tell were his because of their usual physical characteristics of being big and burly, were holding celestial bronze weapons to her as a kid from Apollo cabin pulled on the rope that bound her hands.

Melum held her head high though, not looking worried in the slightest. She may not have been able to use her powers at this time, but she had nothing to fear from these mortals.

Percy ducked back beneath the log, looking at Annabeth. “What happened? Why didn't she fight back?”

Annabeth looked at him, her storm gray eyes showing that she felt responsible. “We were sleeping. You were taking so long, I started to get tired. Melum decided that she would be better fit to serve you if she was rested, so she decided to sleep too.” She said. “Next thing I know, I hear the sounds of a group entering the big house. It was starting to get light outside, so I couldn't tell who it was right away. I sat up to ask what they were doing, but Keith, I guess, hit me in the back of the head. It almost knocked me out, and I could hear them ambush Melum while she was still sleeping. There was a bit of a struggle, but Melum didn't fight back with her power. I had asked her after you went up to not use her voice on any campers, just for safety reasons. If she could stand toe to toe with Hades, then who knows what she could do to others if she wanted or if she felt she was in danger.”

Percy nodded, though this did bring more anger to him. Sure, they might be friends in the future, but right now they had crossed a line. One that they would all know in the future, and that is that you never, EVER, fuck with his friends or family. He was about to go over the log to attack, but Annabeth put a hand on his shoulder.

“No. Not right now. We need to be able to disarm them somehow... or something. Going at them would be suicide right now. The Ares kids would kick the crap out of you.”

“Don't you have your baseball cap?” Percy asked, getting a shake of the head in response.

“No, I left it in the cabin. I didn't think I'd need it.” She explained. “I should have thought of something like this.” She berated herself.

It was Percy's turn to grab her shoulder. “It's not your fault. With everything that's happened o far, it's no surprise that you forgot it.” Percy said, looking her directly in the eye. “I guess I'll have to wing it right now though.” He said, looking over the log again.

He was taking note of the situation again, when he heard the sound of someone else approaching. Thankfully, it was from a different direction then theirs.
15522222222222222221122221212121222.title: Hostage situation!

155222222222222222211222212121212221.content:
“That's her?” The voice, gruff yet definitely female, asked harshly. “She doesn't look like much.”

“It's her alright. I saw her fighting Lord Hades with only her voice.” Austin said.

The girl grunted. “Fine. I guess looks can be deceiving after all.” The sound of a blade leaving its sheath rang through the clearing “Now, what should we do with you? I could easily just beat the ever-loving shit out of you. And Really, I should. Invading our camp like that.”

Percy and Annabeth looked over the log, seeing a girl with long brown hair. She had her sword drawn, pointed right at Melum's face.

“You see, we really don't like it when people try to invade us. I don't know the last time someone tried to invade, but I heard that it was the Ares cabin that lead the charge. And then you come along, and ruin that honor for us. Make us all look weak.” The girl said, poking the tip of the sword to the girls cheek in an effort to get her to flinch. Getting no reaction out of the goddess, the girl growled out, putting more pressure on the blade.

“Wha? Clarisse!” One of the Apollo boys said, his voice rising in a panic.

“What?!” She snapped.

'Clarisse?' Both Percy and Annabeth thought, giving each other a side long glance.

This girl looked nothing like Clarisse, or anything like a child of Ares for that matter. For one, she wasn't tall, over bearing or muscly for that matter. ALL children of Ares looked like warriors ready for battle. Though she did look athletic, something Percy noticed involuntarily. Though it was more sleek then most children of Ares.

Her hair was still a light brown, though it was longer and, dare they say it, more feminine. Nothing close to one of Aphrodite's kids, but more, normal they guessed. Her eye's weren't piggish, and while her skin seemed to be dirty, it didn't look like it was made of wood or anything.

In fact, the only thing that looked remotely like Ares on her would have to have been her mouth. It still had that normal sneer on it, well normal enough for a kid of the war god.

But, all in all, she looked like a regular girl.

Well, that is, if she weren't holding someone at sword point.

The Apollo boy was pointing at Melum's cheek, where Clarisse's sword was cutting. A golden liquid was dripping slowly from the wound, staining Melum's skin golden.

Ichor, the blood of all gods.

“What?” Clarisse asked, bewildered. She pulled her sword away. Even Ares kids knew not to mess with gods, but she didn't think that this little girl was actually a goddess. She had thought that Hades was going easy on her for some reason, like she was a spy of some kind.

'Now!' Percy thought, thinking to take advantage of their panic. He leaped over the downed log, running at them in a full on sprint. As they looked back at him, he flung himself forward, tackling Austin to the ground.

Austin, who was still recovering from the shock that they had abducted a GODDESS of all people, went down like a sack of potato's. He grunted as Percy dove into his stomach, knocking the wind out of him as he fell. His world went black as he felt something hit the side of his head really, really hard.

Percy fought the pain in his hand after slamming his fist into Austin's skull. As expected, he had a hard head like his dad. He quickly grabbed the sword in Austin's limp hand, Whipping the blade around so he struck Micheal with the flat of his blade.

With a resounding crack, the blade broke across his chest as he was flung back. His hands flew from the rope, bits of blood flying from his mouth as he tried to gasp for air.

'Two down, five to go.' Percy thought, whirling around again to face Melum's kidnappers. He had flung the broken handle to the side, not wanting to actually kill anyone.

You know, despite how angry he was right now. But that didn't mean that he would leave them in good shape, if the two he had already taken down were any indication.

Off to his side, Percy heard the crack of breaking wood. He glanced only for a second, long enough to see that Annabeth had taken another of the Apollo camper's bow and broke it over his head, knocking him to the ground with a hard thump.

Guess she wasn't playing around either.

By now, at least Clarisse had regained her wit's.

“What the hell are you doing?” She barked at the two other Ares campers and one Apollo kid left. “Get them!”

The Ares kids snapped to attention, their holds on their blades tightening as they charged at Percy. The one Apollo kid still standing tried to run back to use his bow to try and distract Percy with close, but not too close, fake out shots.

Only for him to get tripped by very displeased Annabeth. The last thing he saw was her sneaker before darkness overtook him.

She knew that it wouldn't be enough to seriously hurt a Demigod, but it was enough to knock him out. She was not going to mess around with them. One thing that people would fear later on at the camp would be an angry Annabeth.

Her mother's battle goddess side shown through then, and in no small amount either.

She picked up the bow, taking a few arrows out of the boy's quiver. She knocked the Arrow, pulling back as far as her arms allowed her.

'Please, Lady Artemis.' She began her prayer to the huntress, because she was sure Apollo wasn't going to be in the mood to listen right now. 'Let my arrow strike true.'

She took aim, aiming at Kevin's leg. Someplace that wouldn't cripple him, but would take him out of the fight. She held her breath, trying to steady her aim.
155222222222222222211222212121212221.title: An more feminine Clarrise?

choices: Melum forces Clarrise to understand her song
1552222222222222222112222121212122211.content:
'Release, child of Athena.' A soft voice sounded in her head. A feeling of clarity washed over her, the bow weighing nothing in her hands even with the draw weight pulling on her, sadly, undeveloped muscles of her younger body.

She took a breath, looking down the shaft of the arrow one last time. It wasn't even shaking the tiniest bit.

She let the arrow fly, seeing that it flew true.

Kevin was about to make an attempt to slice Percy, when his leg gave out beneath him. It took a moment longer for the pain to register in his mind.

But when it did, hoo boy...

Kevin went down screaming, clutching at his leg. It didn't even cross his mind to try and pull it out, but he just sat there screaming like a baby.

Just like his dear old dad would. Must be in Ares gene's.

Annabeth silently thanked the moon goddess, promising to sacrifice some food next chance she could. She dropped the bow, drawing her ever-present dagger as she rushed in to get Melum.

Percy leapt back from the remaining camper besides Clarisse, who looked like she was ready to burst a vein, if the fact that her face was turning as purple with rage was any indication.

Percy dodged to the side as his opponent struck again, trying his hardest to cleave him in two. The Ares kid swiped his sword to the side, hoping to catch Percy before he could move again.

Only to feel something grabbing his wrist, before it was snapped, like a small twig.

Percy let the water he had pulled from the air fall to the ground, glad for the extra bit of strength. He wouldn't have been able to snap his wrist as his body was. He hoped that something would help that process of growing along quicker then, you know, actually growing. It would be a pain to get back to the prowess he had before coming back in time.

He would kill Kronos, immortality be damned.

Percy looked up at Clarisse, seeing as how she was the last one left standing. She had her sword gripped in her hand, the tip stained gold with Melum's blood.

“Give it up Clarisse.” Percy said, locking eyes with her. He would not back down, and he would show her that he was not a force to reckon with.

“Well, if it isn't the newbie.” Clarisse said mockingly, glaring at him. “Sorry I wasn't able to give a good old Camp Half-Blood traditional welcome yesterday. How about I give you a good old fashioned beat-down instead?”

Clarisse lunged at Percy, swinging her sword down to cut him. He swatted her blade away easily, using more water from the air to enhance his strength.

The sword flung out of her grasp, flying into a dead tree, where it embedded itself.

“Damn, of all the days to leave my spear at the cabin.” She muttered, taking a swing at Percy. “Your not bad, though I can tell your not one of my half brothers.”

Percy dodged to the side, pushing her arm up as her punched her hard in the gut. “No, I'm not.”

Clarisse dropped her elbow, hoping to catch him upside the head. “Well, still, not bad. You know, if you didn't look like such a pussy I might actually have found you interesting.”

Percy dodged inside her guard, getting right up in her face. “And if you weren't such a bitch, you might actually get someone to like you.” Percy said, putting his hands on her shoulder's, both encased in water.

“Wait, water?” Clarisse said, understanding dawning on her. “Oh hell. You're the kid of old sea beard.”

Percy said nothing, making water encase her arms, not letting her flail at him.

“Hey, Annabeth? You almost done?”

“Almost! Just gotta cut this last rope. They used stuff that normally only Hephaestus cabin can use. So either they stole some, tricked them into giving them some, or they had some inside help. Not sure which, since they're all likely.” Annabeth said, cutting through the last rope that bound Melum.

“Hurry please. I'm not sure what to do with Clarisse here.”

Annabeth refrained from making a retort, just the last few strands about ready to be cut. Man, this celestial bronze rope was annoying to cut through. Well, if it caught Zeus or Ares, it had to be strong. That, and it was invented by the smithing god himself, so there was no questioning it in how well it did it's job.

Her dagger cut through the last thread, the rope that bound Melum's hands falling to the groung. Melum quickly undid her gag, spitting out the wadded up ball in her mouth.

“Melum, are you okay?” Annabeth asked, looking for any marks on Melum besides the cut that was healing on her cheek.

“Yes, I am fine. Though I would like to ask that if this happens again, that you remove my gag first.” Melum said, though she did look at both Percy and Annabeth with gratitude, Percy more then Annabeth though. “I will simply sing the bonds off if that happens.”

Annabeth took a moment to smack herself in the forehead. The book did say that she was able to make the rocks, flowers and even the earth cry for her. “Right, sorry.”

Melum shook her head. “No need to apologize. I am happy that I was able to follow the mistress' orders, and that both master and Mistress came to my aid. Though I am sorry for being a burden upon you for this.” She said, looking down again.

“Hey, It's no problem.” Percy said. “But, uh, is there anything we can do about Clarisse? To make sure she won't go yapping about my dad?”

“I could sing to her, force her to understand completely if you wish it, Master Perseus.” Melum commented.

“Master? What the Fu-” Clarisse started to say, before Percy made some more water from the air, dense enough to block her mouth but not enough to make her drown.

“Is that the only way?” Percy asked.

“No, not in the slightest.” Melum said with a shake of her head. “The great tome that you carry has many things that would ensure that she would keep your secret.”

“Really?” Well, I suppose...”

15522222222222222221122221212121222112.content:
“Do you know anything in the book that could something like that?” Annabeth asked, Interrupting Percy.

“Of course, Mistress.” Melum said. “Though, off the top of my head I can think of one that would be best used for right now. If I may ask, could I see the great tome?”

“Yeah, I guess.” Percy said. “Back pocket, right side.”

Annabeth moved to grab it, slipping the little book from Percy's pants. She took it back to Melum and handed it to her.

Melum for her part, took the pocket book like she was being given a child. She took it with care, gently holding it and looking it over with a reverence that was almost unheard of for anyone to have for anything, and almost what she felt for Percy.

She opened it, looking through it for what she knew would work best.

“Here it is. Master, if it would please you, draw out this item to use. I would be happy to explain what it does, if you wish.”

“Explanation first please.” Percy said, not knowing what he was subjecting Clarisse to. Though he did have a feeling...

“As you command.” Melum said. “This is the amulet of twisted Justification. If you put it on someone, they will follow any command or opinion you give them. But, it is not slavery. They give themselves reasons as to why they should listen to you, justifying it in a perfectly rational way. If you were to say, for example, that the one who wears this should give up their job, they will justify it as not being happy with it.”

“Wow. That was... oddly specific for an example.” Percy said. “Is there anything else in there that is a little more, I don't know, less binding?” He asked.

“No Master Perseus. There isn't.” Melum told him. “This is one of the less imposing artifacts in the great tome, as it still allows the person it is used on to retain their free-will. Unless, you say that they shouldn't.”

Percy sighed, but nodded. “Alright, fine. Sorry Clarisse, but I gotta do this.” He said, looking at the struggling form of Clarrise.

She looked like she was trying to say something, most likely to cuss him out, but her water gag kept her silent. Her arms were still pinned in place by the water, and Percy had done the same with her legs as well a bit ago.

Letting go of her, but willing the water to stay as it was, Percy moved over to Melum and Annabeth. He looked on the page, which showed a tattered picture of the amulet.

It looked like a normal necklace, at least around the lace part. The amulet itself, however, took the cake. It was shaped like a seven-pointed star, though there were two lines of whatever it was made of intertwined with one another. From the tell-tale lines about it, it was apparently supposed to be shiny or glow or something.

Percy, put his hand on the book, directly over the image. “Okay, let's see if this works the same. Amulet of twisted Justification!”

Once more, blinding light shot out from the image. It blinded Everyone, save Melum and her godly eyes.

Once the light died down, Percy found something resting in his hand. He gave it a squeeze, feeling seven sharp points stab slightly into his palm.

Once he could see again, he turned his hand over to see the object.

Like in the book, it was a seven-pointed star. And he was right, it was very shiny. It reflected the light of the sun in many color's, since it was acting like A prism made of crystal. And that was what it was exactly was made of. Pure crystal, clear as the water in an untouched lake.

The lace that it hung from was silk, though when he tested the strength of it, he found that he just hurt his arms. So, magic string it seems. Works for him.

He walked over to the still blinking Clarisse, who was thankfully still bound by the water. He held it up, looking at her through the empty middle of the amulet.

“Like I said Clarisse, sorry about this.” He said, looping the silk around her neck, Letting the amulet fall to her chest.

Nothing happened. Nothing at all.

“Umm, did it work?” Percy asked, looking Clarisse in her rage fueled eyes.

“Try it Master Perseus.” Melum whispered in even more reverence. “Command her.”

Percy looked unsure, but he did as asked. “Um, Clarisse, would you stop looking at me like that.” He said, looking at her eyes.

Immediately, her eye's stopped being so... Ares-ish. She didn't look like she would murder him for beating her in a fight anymore. She still looked like she would Murder him, but only because she was tied up at the moment.

“Stop looking at me like that too. Just... be civil.” Percy said, still hesitating.

Immediately, her look did go civil. Almost like she could sit down and have a nice conversation with someone.

He let her gag dissipate, after making sure she wouldn't choke on it.

“Alright, Alright.” She said, sputtering. Seems like he didn't get all the water. “You beat me in a fight, fair and square. What do you want from me?” She asked, acting like a civil prisoner of war, knowing she was beat.

“Well, we could start by making sure you keep our secret just that.” Annabeth said, taking charge. “You won't tell anyone what happened here, and you'll, ah, 'convince' the people that helped you kidnap Melum to keep it to themselves. By force if Necessary.”

“Hey, book bitch.” Clarisse said, still keeping her tone civil. “He beat me in a fight, not you. So only he's able to order me around.”

“Hey!” Percy said slightly angrily. “She only said what I would have said. So your going to do that.”

Clarisse looked at Percy, shrugging. “Sure, why not. I can do that Newbie.” She said. “I can see why too. You've got a goddess at your beck and call, and it seems that the head of the lamest cabin already has something for you.”

Percy nodded, surprisingly not blushing. He could tell Clarisse was being honest. He shared a look with his new girlfriend, and it seems they were sharing thoughts on this.

Definitely worked. Cause Clarisse wouldn't have agreed to this otherwise.

“Later, once we leave camp on our quest, I want you to go speak with Chiron. Tell him Percy said that you could know what was going on, that should allow him to keep his oath. Keep that a secret too.” He said, making her nod.

“Alright, sounds like somethings up. And it seems you would need one of the best fighter's in camp. I can work with that.” She said with a smug grin. “Anything else?”

Percy stopped to think on it. “Yeah, two more things for now. Try and treat people better. Nothing too extreme, otherwise people may begin to be suspicious of you or something. But trust me, it will help more in the long run. And keep an eye on Luke for me if you can. Send me an Iris message if he starts to do anything suspicious.”

“Alright, I think I can do that. I mean, we are all family. But I'm still going to be a hard-ass to them, toughen them up. And I'll keep an eye on the camp pretty boy, at least the one that isn't one of Aphrodite's sons. Always thought he seemed fishy after his failed quest.” She said, easily agreeing to his requests and justifying it to everyone, mostly herself.

Percy nodded, satisfied. “Hey, Melum? If I take this thing off of her, will all those things I asked her to do stay with her?”

The goddess nodded. “Yes Master Perseus. Since it made her justify it to herself, she thinks that she thought of it herself, despite us talking about it in front of her. If anyone checks to see if she was being controlled in any way, they would find nothing, magical or otherwise. The great tome had made sure of that.”

Percy nodded, licking his lips in thought. Unbidden, a thought came to his head. It seems he could make Clarisse do anything he wanted her to do right now. Sure, she was a bitch for the first few years, but she became a great friend and ally later on.

He was having a moral dilemma right now, and he didn't know what to do. His hormones were kicking up a notch, urging the thoughts that weren't completely his own.

'Should I really...?' He thought to himself. 'I mean... if it helps next year... I suppose...'
