155222222222222222211222212121212221122.content:
“Clarisse?” He asked.

“Yeah, what now?” She asked, still tied up.

“If I asked you to become something like a slave, but not exactly that...” He started, only to be interrupted.

“Like a Retainer?” Clarisse asked.

“Yeah, I guess that's the word.”

“Yeah sure, why the hell not.” Clarisse said, shrugging again. “I mean, not only did you over power nearly everyone here, you kicked my ass easily, you seem to know more things then you should about our life despite being new to it, and it seems I ain't got much of a choice, now or later from what I can tell.” She said. “That, and it seems you're trying to defend the camp from something, and you knew that I would be the best one to defend it while you were gone. So, for trusting me without knowing me, and kicking such ass, I guess I'll join you willingly. Beats having it forced on me later and losing what makes me, me.”

“You know what that entails, right Clarisse?” Annabeth said Evenly, having taken some offense to the 'Book Bitch' comment earlier.

“Yeah yeah. Listening to everything I’m told, no matter what it may be, whether I like it or Blah blah blah.” Clarisse said. “I don't care really. Like I said, better to do it as myself then lose myself later on. I don't want to be some mindless fuck toy, alright? If I got fuck someone, I want to at least be able to enjoy it. I know that's something I'm going to have to do at some point.”

Percy and Annabeth blinked owlishly (Pardon the pun) at that. Damn, that amulet was effective. Or was this Clarisse's strategic mind working with her self preservation instinct? Did it matter?

“Okay then.” Percy said, reaching for the necklace. “Like I sa-”

“Yeah, go Talk to Chiron, don't tell anyone about this, keep idiots here quiet. I got it, I got it.” She said. “I'm oath bound to follow your words now, and like I said I ain't got much of a choice. I can't try and kill you to get out of this either, as people in the old days did. Besides, if I did try something, I'm pretty sure that I would get a knife in the ribs and the goddess over there screaming at me. And if she could hold back Hades easily, then I don't want to mess with her.”

“Wise choice.” Melum commented, her voice steely with a dark glint in her eyes. “If you even think about harming the master, then your fate is already sealed. Trust me mortal, anything you think I can do, I can do so much worse. I will sing death knells that will shred your soul, burn your flesh and dissolve your bones. There will be nothing left of you to torture, and I will still not be done. I will-”

“Melum!” Percy said, nearly panicking. “Stop!”

The goddess fell silent immediately, all manner of menace flowing out of her, adopting the subservient look again. “Forgive me Master Perseus. I have over stepped my boundaries. But I will never allow anything to happen to you, please understand that.”

Percy... really, REALLY didn't know what to say to that, how to feel about it. But he tried his best to convey his... Gratitude?

“T-thank you.” He said, putting a hand on his chest, urging it to slow down. He had heard and seen some terrible things, but that took the cake. “Just... don't say things like that around me again... alright?” He asked.

“As you wish it, my master. I will not speak of it with you in ear shot if I do need to say it again.” She said.

Clarrise though, despite possibly having her very existence threatened, just gave a grin and a barking laugh. “Damn! She's probably scarier then my old man!” she said, shaking her head with a few more laughs. “But seriously, as I said earlier. I can't do anything about my situation now. Us kids of Ares have a code of honor, despite how we act for the most part. I said that I would be your 'retainer',” she said with vocal quotes obvious. “ And I meant it. I'm stuck with that choice now, until one of us dies or you release me.”

Percy nodded, though he was still uncertain. 'Man, I guess the fates were right. Things definitely not like last time.'

'Yes Perseus.' A familiar voice voice suddenly sounded in his head. 'Be glad that everything you see isn't warping and distorting, changing colors and/or other unpleasant things.'

'Clotho?' Percy asked. 'Something up?'

Clotho sighed. 'Something we've noticed, a little too late. All the work we just did, well, undid itself.'

'What happened?'

'It's quite strange, really. Whenever we try to implement you into the weave of fate, it unravels. As of now, we have no control over you.' She said.

'Wait, what?!' Percy said, panicking again.

'Don't worry, nothing will happen to you.' Clotho assured him. 'But we might need to pull you to our weaving chambers so you can take a look yourself. You and the goddess, since she has knowledge of the book it seems. She might know what is happening.'

Percy nodded, though he was starting to get a head ache. It seems things just kept happening and piling up.

“Percy? Percy?”

Percy jumped, Annabeth waving her hand in front of his face.

“You were spacing out Percy. Everything okay?”

Percy nodded, though with a shrug. “Don't know. We'll talk about it later, once we're out of camp. It has something to do with 'them'.”

Annabeth looked confused for a moment, before understanding dawned on her. She nodded in understanding. Their... familiarity with the Fates was something that they had kept, not uttering a peep about them at all to Chiron. For all the centaur knew, Percy nor Annabeth had ever met the three powerful beings.

Percy looked at Clarrise, still held in his water with the amulet around her neck. Percy grabbed the necklace, and took it off. He moved the water away from Clarisse, though he kept it at the ready.

She rubbed her arms, glad that Percy had dried her clothes. “Thanks 'Boss.' I guess I'm going to have to get used to calling you that. Unless you want me calling you master?”

Percy shook his head, though the image of this new Clarisse calling him master did pop into his head.

Damned Hormones...

“Okay, now that this mess is dealt with, we should get back to camp. We've got to get ready for our quest, and get them some medical attention.” Percy said, gesturing to the other campers, who were still unconscious. “I'll let Chiron know that we'll leave later today, and Clarisse will talk to him after that. Annabeth, you take Melum and introduce her to Grover. You're the best one to make him understand without telling him too much. Also, let him know that Chiron wants to talk with him. Me and Chiron will be making plans for... upcoming events.”

“Got it.” Annabeth said, offering her hand to the still sitting goddess. “Come on Melum, let's go introduce you to a friend of ours.”

Melum took the hand offered, though she didn't really use it to pull herself up. “Thank you mistress, but do not allow me to burden you or the master any further.”

Annabeth just rolled her eyes, pulling the goddess up with gentle force. “Come on, none of that.” She said, gently pulling Melum back towards camp. “And what's with you calling me Mistress?”

That was the last thing that Percy or Clarisse heard as the two walked out of hearing range.

Percy coughed, only know taking note of what Melum was calling his girlfriend. He caught Clarisse looking at him, also wondering what was going on.

Percy could only shrug.

Clarisse looked at him strangely, but shrugged. “So,” She started, changing the subject. “Any reason your not taking me on this quest that you supposedly have?” She asked, though Percy could sense the genuine curiosity.

“Yeah, there is. First is the reason of keeping an eye on things like I said.” Percy said, putting up one finger. “Second, is for you to train harder. You'll need it next year, trust me. Third, I wouldn't want to take one of the strongest fighters at camp away in case of something unexpected happening, worse then monsters. Fourth, and last that I can think of, is that if you join in on this quest, people are going to get suspicious. We really don't want that.” Percy said, making Clarisse nod.

“Okay, the first and fourth I understand, and some of the third. But, what about next year would I have to train for? And what's worse then the monster's, which I should tell you can't get into camp.” She asked, trying her hardest to not glare at Percy. It was still in her nature, Damn it!

“The second thing Chiron will tell you about. As for what's worse then monsters, I really don't want to think about it. Crazy stuff happens around me, and that's for a demi-god.” Percy said, trying to suppress a headache.

Clarisse shrugged again. She was curious, but it seemed things would be explained to her soon enough. “Fine, I can wait for the info. Mind helping me gather these pussies someplace where they won't get sick? Not that it isn't anything Apollo cabin can't heal, but still. Takes a day to heal up completely, and that means one less day of training.” She asked, gesturing to the unconscious campers. “Unless, you're going to have me do it all by myself?”

Percy shook his head. “No, no. Don't worry about it, I'll help. Surprised they're still unconscious though.” Percy said, grabbing the Ares kid he had knocked out and snapped the wrist of before his short, one-sided battle with Clarisse. He dragged the kid, by his shoulder, to a spot that wasn't damp enough to do much in a short amount of time.

So, for the next seven or eight minutes, Percy and Clarisse moved people about, before heading back to camp. All the while, Percy was thinking on whether or not he should tell Chiron a little more on what was going on...
155222222222222222211222212121212221122.title: Justified servitude

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Grover, Percy, Annabeth and Melum were all sitting in the back of the camp van. Argus was driving them to the city, all but his main eyes closed.

Grover was constantly shooting Melum nervous glances, averting his eyes when he thought he might have been caught.

Only, that it didn't do him any good. Percy and Annabeth were used to Grover's tell signs, and could easily tell he was going into major panic mode, mentally, and yet dying to know what was going on.

Sure, Annabeth had tried to explain to him. But she really couldn't do so without letting somethings slip that were better left unsaid, but she tried her best. So, in the end, she really hadn't said much at all.

“Percy?” Grover whispered, not for the first time. “Can you please tell me what's going on?”

Percy sighed, yet again. “No Grover, not yet. Trust me, I wish I could. But you aren't good at keeping secrets, and right now that's a necessary thing. Maybe once this quest is over I can tell you a little bit. Maybe things may happen that force me to tell you, I don't know.”

Grover groaned slightly, not liking that he was being kept out of the loop. “But you haven't even been claimed! You're on a quest without being claimed! That's never happened before!”

Percy sighed. The fifth time in two minutes. “I'll tell you this, Grover. This goes over the heads of the gods. Way, way over their heads.”

“Wha-”

“Three old ladies with yarn, Grover.” Percy said, though he didn't like saying it. The fate's definitely weren't old, by appearances at least. He would also have to apologize for that when he got to talk with them next.

Grover froze. Then, he started to shake. It was not lost on him what Percy was saying.

“Y-Y-You m-mean...”

“Yeah.” Percy said with a nod. “That's all I can say, and Annabeth can back me up on this. Right, Wise-girl?”

Annabeth looked at Percy with a playful glare. “Sure thing, Se-” She started to say, only to catch herself almost making a slip up. “Yeah, I can do that. Just trust us Grover. You're better off not knowing any way.”

Grover shook a little more, almost letting out a scared bleat. “A-all r-right. I-i-if you s-say so.” He said nervously as he looked down.

Percy sighed once more. Man, he was doing that a lot today. “Look, G-man. You're still my best friend. It's just... somethings are really complicated. And top secret. If the wrong people heard about this, then very bad things will happen. Worse then whatever the gods are going to do.”

Grover nodded, though he looked like he was about to have a heart attack. Worse then whatever the gods could, and apparently were going to do?

“Hey, Argus. Would you mind not telling anyone about what we're talking about back here?” Percy asked the multi-eyed monster.

His response was a thumbs up.

“Thanks. Glad you understand the gravity of whats going on.” Annabeth chimed in, smiling at Argus.

He only nodded, keeping his main eyes on the road. He didn't even open an eye to look at them.

It was silent for a few more minutes, as the country-side changed slowly to the city sprawls.

When the hundred eyed man stopped the van, it was near a place Percy hadn't been for a good few years. Someplace both he and his mother were happy to put behind them.

Gabe Ugliano's apartment.

“Since I'm back in time, that means that asshole's back.” Percy mumbled, looking at a missing child/wanted poster with his face on it. He didn't bother to pull it down, knowing that it didn't matter.

“Hey Percy, Isn't this where you used to live?” Annabeth asked, looking around.

“Yeah, if you could call it that.” Percy said, gritting his teeth. He hadn't thought about Gabe for years, how his step-father, it made him nauseous to say that about the guy, lived in this part of the city.

Grover was covering his nose. “Yeah, I can smell him from here. Smells like cigarette smoke and garlic. And beans, lots of beans. You know Percy, your mom was smart. Your step-dad smells so human that it would cover you for a long time, masking your demigod scent from any monsters. She loved you a lot to put up with him.”

Percy grimaced, but held his tongue.

“Satyr, I would ask you not to speak of this. It seems to upset Master Perseus.” Melum said, speaking for the first time since camp.

“Yes ma'am.” Grover said hurriedly. He could smell the power rolling off of the woman when they were at camp. Though he wasn't sure as to why this very powerful woman kept referring to Percy as Master.

All Annabeth had told him was that she was an ancient being, probably older than the titans. And that why she was there was something that was also, coincidentally, top secret.

Other then that, all Grover knew was that she could stand flame to voice against Hades. That was only because he had been in the very back of the amphitheater, where there was the least damage done to both campers and the architecture.

~Some time later~

“So you're saying that I'll be able to look at Medusa if I use this... Ritual?” Percy asked, looking at Melum.

Currently, they were still waiting for the bus. The demigod's and satyr had played Hackey sack for a while, but the fun had worn off after a while, and Grover ate the apple mid-game. So, Percy had pulled Melum aside to ask her about anything that could help in the tasks the Fates had given him. Medusa specifically.

The goddess nodded. “Yes, Master Perseus. The Ritual will give you immunity from Hypnosis, literal Death stares, or any other ocular effect that isn't beneficial to you. It will also allow you to see 180 degrees around you, which would help in battle.”

Percy nodded. It sounded really good. It would help a lot.

And that worried him.

“Anything I should know? Like, it's not going to damage my eyes irreparably after a year is it?” He asked.

Melum shook her head furiously. “Oh no Master. I would not let you do this if it would do something like that. It is entirely beneficial. But I would like to say that if you wish to not attract unwanted attention, to do this inside a building, or under a thick canopy of trees. Something to block the light that emits from the great tome. Though, I should mention that you will be able to tell where people are by their aura.”

“What do you mean?”

“Well, I don't know the exact details, but you should be able to easily tell women apart from men. Women are supposedly to glow with a pink aura. Men don't show an aura, therefore it is easy to tell them apart.” Melum said. “Forgive me for not knowing any more Master. I was in a lucid state during my time spent in the Great tome.”

Percy put a hand on her shoulder. “Hey, none of that. It's not your fault, and I don't blame you. Thanks for letting me know what you could tell me. I'll think over it for a while, talk to Annabeth about it. She deserves to know if I do anything that alters my body... again.” Percy said, mind drifting back to his dip in the river Styx and gaining the blessing of Achilles. Since he wasn't totally exhausted, he guessed that he didn't have the blessing anymore.

“If it pleases the Master, then it shall be.” Melum said, bowing her head as Percy shook his. He had tried to ask her to not call him 'Master' but she insisted on doing so. He had given up on trying to change her mind.

“Hey Percy, the bus is here!” Grover called. “Come on!”

Percy closed the book, slipping it into his back pocket. His hand drifted over Riptide in his side pocket, glad to have the weapon back in his possession. Truth be told, he felt a little defenseless without it.

On it!” Percy called, offering his hand to Melum. “Come on, we need to go. The bus won't stay for long.”

She took his hand graciously, letting him help her to her feet. She dusted off the front of her dress as Percy pulled her along, getting anything that may have fallen on her off. She wanted to look her best for her master.

When they got on the bus, they found a spot at the very back. There was a problem though...

There was only room for three people to sit down...
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: The Eyes of a god

choices: Zeus tries to fry the bus
Percy crashes the bus, just like last time
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Grover was sitting when Percy and Melum got on, hairy arm propped to hold his head as he starred out the window. Annabeth was standing, looking at him.

“Good thing you hurried. The driver was going to leave any second if I hadn't promised to give him a tip.” She said. “Oh well, doesn't matter now. Could you sit down so that we can go though?”

Percy was about to sit down, but then he noticed something.

“Annabeth, there's only room for two more people.” Percy said.

“So?” She asked, not seeing his point.

“You and Mel sit down. I'll find a seat a few rows up.” Percy said, making Annabeth roll her eyes.

She grabbed his arm, pulling him back and making him stumble into a seat, opposite of Grover. Annabeth took the empty spot in between them, leaving Melum standing there.

“You too Mel. Sit down.” Annabeth said, holding Percy in place with her tone telling him not to protest.

The goddess nodded. “Of course.” She said graciously, omitting her title for Annabeth since they were in public.

Melum moved in front of Percy, smiling down at him. She turned around, and sat on his lap. Nothing provocative, but she did lean back against him with a sigh of content.

Percy, for his part, tried to fight down a blush. Blood was rushing down to his, ahem, personal trident. The close contact of Melum, coupled with the fact that she smelt strangely like ambrosia made sure that he was in a losing battle.

His rod prodded against Melum's rear, though she didn't make a fuss over it. She merely shifted her position, almost making Percy moan as she pseudo-hotdogged him through her dress and his jeans. Even if she wasn't curvy, it was still a pleasant feeling that his mind noted and filed that it liked quite a bit.

Just like Annabeth or the Fates when they kissed him.

Annabeth didn't bat an eye. She knew what was going on, being as perceptive as she was, but she honestly didn't care. If Percy wasn't going to complain, then she wasn't going to either.

At the wheel, the driver was about to carry on, when a few old ladies appeared to be heading towards his bus.

Now, for a couple of teens he would have sped off if it wasn't for the promise of a tip. But for three old ladies and their rottweiler, who also looked old and slightly deformed, he would wait. Besides, it looked like it would rain any minute.

As the three old ladies boarded, Percy and Annabeth gasped.

The Furies, and apparently a two-headed hell hound.

“Crap. Percy, what should we do?” Annabeth asked. “We can't fight them on the bus, too many people, and a hell hound makes it harder.”

Percy was about to say something, when Melum spoke. “If I may, I know of several seal that you could apply to your hand to detain them and help us in the future.” She whispered.

“I'll do anything right now. What is it Mel?” Percy asked, hand moving to his pocket to grasp Rip Tide.

“Simply put your hand on the Great Tome. Say imprint seal of Anthro-ization times four, and then touch them one at a time. Do the same with the other hand, but say slave seal.” She said.

“Mel, I don't want sla-”

“Save it Percy. It's in that book that the fates told you to use. We don't have time, and it would be a great advantage for the future to have the Furies themselves under control.” Annabeth said.

“Book? What book?” Grover asked, keeping a scared eye on the three deadly old ladies.

“Fine.” Percy said. “We'll talk about it later Grover. Just get ready.” Percy said as he put his hand in his back pocket with a little movement. He did as Melum instructed with his hands. “Annabeth, can I borrow-”

“Way ahead of you Percy. Melum, stand up real quick.” She instructed, giving Percy her Yankee’s ball cap.

~Later in Lincoln tunnel~

The Furies stood up, turning back to look at them discretely. Their hell hound, which had been staring at them with both heads started to growl, both sets of fangs barred.

Only for Percy to not be there.

All they saw was one Demigod, one Satyr, and one women they couldn't tell what she was besides very powerful.

They would find their prey though, through any means.

They started down the Isle, the hell hound following close behind, fire flickering behind their teeth. Their hand bags turned into fiery whips, which they lashed furiously.

“Where is he?” The first Fury hissed out, pulling back the whip to strike at Annabeth. “Where is the thief?”

“He's not here.” Annabeth said, unflinchingly starring at the Fury.

The monster wailed, flinging her whip forwards. The other people on the bus panicked, seeing three old Ladies beating on two teens and a sickly looking 20 year old while their dog growled and barked. Despite the darkness, the sound of old women yelling was utterly terrifying as they beat the group with what looked like purses.

And then Percy did something that he vaguely remembered doing in the past. Something incredibly stupid, but working in the end.

He rushed up to the front of the bus as they were nearing the tunnel, and grabbed the wheel. He turned sharply to the right, slamming the vehicle into the side of the tunnel. Sparks flew from the metal on metal contact as those inside the bus were flung about.

Well, except for Annabeth, Grover and Melum. They were all ready for it.

The whip that meant to hit Annabeth missed by a hair, scorching the seat between her's and Grover's head. Annabeth drew her knife in an instant, swiping it at the Fury's hand and making her drop the whip with a hiss of pain.

The hell hound would have pounced, if it weren't for Percy moving the bus left and slamming right again, sending it into a wall.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Damned Furies!

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
As everyone tried to stay up right, Percy managed to make the bus veer off to the side of the road, down an exit and through dozens of streets. The driver played an excellent part as well, putting the pedal to the metal in his fear of ghosts taking over his bus.

When they were down a familiar rural road of Jersey, Percy pushed the wheel to the left, sending the into the woods on the side of the road. He pulled the emergency brake, causing the bus to spin out of control.

Inside, people and monsters were being flung around like rag dolls, mortals and Grover screaming in absolute fear.

The bus stopped, smashing into a tree. A few more slams were heard, which Percy could only hope was the Furies and their pooch hitting the windows. Especially since they were hard slams that sounded like they would break bones.

The Emergency light blinked on weakly, the doors flying open. The driver ran out of the totaled bus, screaming something about it being possessed. The mortal passengers were quick to follow, almost pulling Percy along with them until he managed to move into the driver seat.

The Furies and their pet stood there, trying to regain their balance. They had taken a few nasty hits to their heads.

The trio in the back took this opportunity to rush by, almost knocking the four baddies down again.

“Hey!” Percy yelled at them, taking the hat off. “Over here you over-grown bats!”

The Fury Percy recalled calling Ms. Dodds at Yancy academy snarled. She snatched up her whip, turning and pointing. “Kill!” She shouted.

Their dog growled, growing larger as it ran at Percy, both sets of fangs barred.

Only to smash through the windshield as Percy jumped out of the way at the last second.

Percy ran from the bus, the Furies hot on his heels. He could feel the heat of the flaming weapons almost licking his back. The sounds of Snarling soon joined the chase.

Only to hear the sounds of Hilary Duff being played on reed pipes.

Vines erupted behind Percy, tangling the Feet of the Furies and completely ensnaring their pooch.

“Now Percy!” Annabeth yelled. “Use the seals!”

Percy stopped, looking back to see that the four chasing him were being wrapped in vines. The vines had already muzzled the Hell hound. The Furies were trying to claw at the plants, but Grover was playing too fast, too loud, and too horribly for the vines to break. It was almost like the earth itself was trying to do the best job it could to make him stop playing.

Thankfully, Melum joined in. She sang, making more and more plants erupt from the ground, taking the whips from the Demonic Grannies. The very air reverberated around her, making sure Grover couldn't be heard. Even the plant life around Melum was growing.

What she sang, Percy couldn't tell. It was in a language that was completely alien to him. It was almost like she gave emotions sound. She sang in a voice that was as clear as crystal, musical perfection once again.

And the Earth loved it.

Percy walked slowly up to the entangled monsters. The Furies glared at him, but the Hell hound was incredibly calm.

“Give us back what you stole.” They all hissed in unison. “Give up, and you will not face the eternal torment of those who offend the gods.”

Percy raised his hands, looking at the seals. He looked at the Furies, who were still struggling. “How about no.” He said. He wasn't going to let anything, or anybody for that matter, kill him.

“Zeus will destroy you.” They hissed. “Lord Hades will have your soul! He will let us personally take care of your torment, and you will know why we are feared!”

Percy said nothing. He slowly moved his hands towards the one that he remembered disguised herself as Ms. Dodds.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: A helpful technique

choices: Athena undoes the curse, having a change of heart after so long
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy looked down at the piles of dust at his feet. He felt slightly sick to his stomach, handling that like he did. But now he had some people on the inside, and very powerful people for Allies now as well.

Alecto, Megaera and Tisiphone, the three Furies. They were now under his control. Three of the most fearsome monsters were now under control.

Well, not so fearsome now, in appearance at least.

The three, upon being touched with the seal of Anthro-ization, had rapidly changed form. Thankfully it was blocked out by a large light show, or Percy might have thrown-up at what he may have saw.

At least they didn't look old anymore...

And, not only that, but he now had a very powerful two-headed hell-hound as well. Apparently, it was a straight descendent from Orthus, the Two-headed brother of Cerberus. Apparently that was the one dog that he found at that one ranch a year or so back.

Not only that, but the dog was now... humanoid? It seemed to resemble a woman, though it had dark fur all over it.

No extra heads though, but it did have a tail, ears and claws.

And a split personality.

One wanted to kill him, the other called him 'Alpha' a lot and seemed to enjoy his company, among other things.

And she spoke in jungle speak. Yeah.

Percy had given orders to the Furies, telling them to stop blaming him and start looking for Hades Helm, though he worded it as 'whatever it is your trying to find.'

The Furies had no choice but to obey, though they did grumble about it and said what they thought of him besides. Cursing him with empty words that didn't, couldn't, have any real bite to them.

He admitted, during it all he did get a little angry. One of them had commented that his mother would make an excellent toy for Hades, which they would be sure to make him watch.

Not long after, she was a pile of dust.

A fitting punishment is what she said it would be, to see his mother used.

And she had gotten hers for it.

The other two had said that he might as well send them back to Hades the fast way, so they could start their search quicker, having nothing to go on.

Two more piles of dust joined the pile.

The Hell hound had swapped between telling him to send her back too, and begging to stay with her Alpha.

In the end, she had stayed with them. Though it was under strict orders to not harm anyone, not to try and escape, not to try and make things difficult for them and to try not to get them killed. One side of her happily agreed, the other was very reluctant.

Melum had stopped singing a while ago, but not before Annabeth had pulled Grover from his panic attack flute playing.

“Percy, you alright?” Annabeth asked, moving to put a hand on his shaking shoulder. Very rarely did Percy get angry.

The Furies had pissed him off that bad, threatening his mother as they had.

It was silent for a moment before Percy spoke, and it was barely above a whisper.

“We're going. Now.”

He turned around, walking away from the mass of vines, which had torn under the growth of the Hell-hound's new body. The Docile personality followed, well, like a love-struck puppy.

He moved past Annabeth, Grover and Melum, taking his pack from her as he went. He capped Riptide, slipping it into his pocket as he walked towards the forest. It was getting dark out, and Percy wanted to get to someplace quiet, someplace to think.

Reaching the tree line, Percy stopped to look back. Everyone else was following him, though only Grover was at him like he was slightly horrified at what he had done. Annabeth and Melum had concerned faces, and it was hard to tell which of the two was more worried.

“Annabeth, is the next stop where I think it is?” He asked. “You know, where she is?”

“Yeah, I'm pretty sure.” Annabeth said, knowing exactly what Percy was talking about. He had briefed her on what the Fates were asking him to do before they met up with everyone to head out on the quest.

Percy nodded. “Okay. Once we get there, and do what we need to do, we can rest. We can figure out a plan of what to do then.”

“P-percy?” Grover stammered, taking his bag From Melum. He was glad that she had thought to grab their packs, since they had forgotten them. “W-what w-w-was that? W-wha-what d-d-d-d-did you j-just do?”

“When we get to where we're going Grover, I'll tell you.” Percy said. “But to do that, I want you to promise me that you won't tell a single soul about it. No one, human or not.”

“Y-yeah Percy. I promise.” Grover said, looking at Percy with wide eyes. “I swear it on the River Styx. I won't tell anybody.”

The sky rumbled as rain started pouring down.

Great, just great.

At least the canopy was thick beneath the trees.

Wait a second...

~Later~

Percy walked into the building, the smell of food washing over him more strongly then it had outside, across the freeway.

“Where are your parents young man?” An old, middle-eastern voice said. “It is much to late to be out.”

Percy looked to his left, seeing the veiled form of Medusa, glowing with a pink outline. Floating above her were several words, bullet point style. The first read 'Show you are a child of Poseidon.'

“Look, I'm not going to beat around the bush.” Percy said. “I know who you really are. Could we just not do the whole kind old lady who's really a monster act?”

Medusa scoffed. “Such an impetuous young man. Very well. I would love to fight you, but I can tell who your father is. You smell of the sea-breeze, and you have your father's eyes. What is it that you want?”

“What I want, Medusa, is to help free you from your curse.” Percy said.

Medusa's hair hissed. “Foolish child. This curse cannot be lifted by anyone other then the Gray-eyed one.” She said angrily, before taking a deep breath, patting her hair. When she spoke again, it was with a little bit of charm added to it. “Why don't you stay here Percy. Become a statue. It would be less painful then the quest you have been sent on. I would polish you everyday, make sure you sparkled and that you would never turn to dust.”

“It's not going to work Medusa. You can't charm me, and you can't turn me to stone. Besides, helping you is a quest from the Fates themselves. It's going to happen one-way or another.” Percy said, looking right at her.

“Very well. If you say that I cannot turn you into a statue, why don't we test that?” She hissed out, hand reaching for her veil.

She ripped it off, looking right at Percy. Full on, face to face.

Nothing.

“What?” Medusa asked. “H-how can this be? No, you must be a trick. A trick to give me hope, only to crush it.”

Percy shook his head, getting closer. “No tricks Medusa. The Fates think you've suffered enough for my dad's mistake. Asking you to meet him in Athena's temple like that.” He said, stopping just in front of her, holding up his hand. “Scratch me. Prove to yourself that I'm not a trick.”

Medusa looked at Percy's hand, her snakes hissing in confusion. She brought up a wrinkled hand, quickly swiping it across the back of Percy's hand, drawing blood.

Lightish red blood, with the occasional goldish drop.

His blood was turning to Ichor.

“Y-you're real.” Medusa said. She sat down on a stone bench behind her, looking at Percy the whole time, reciting those two words over again for about two minutes before going silent.

Percy was looking at her, curiosity taking hold. “Uh, you okay?” He asked, taking note of the words over Medusa's head becoming 'Free from curse, by whatever means possible.'

“I-is my torment over?” Medusa asked, her voice tired. “Will I finally be free? To walk amongst people again?”

“Yeah.” Percy said. “You will...”
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: In the lair of the snake, freeing the woman

choices: Athena makes a surprise visit, none to happy that Medusa is free
Some dark truths come to light
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“How?” Medusa asked. “How do you plan to free me from this curse?”

“This.” Percy said, holding up a bracelet. It was pure gold, with ancient runes that not even Melum could read. Percy though he could read a small bit of it, but he figured it was just his dyslexic mind playing tricks on him. “Wear this. I have it on good authority that it'll make your curse something that you can control.”

Medusa looked at the bracelet, staring at it with a disbelieving look. “Do you think me a fool Percy? A simple trinket cannot undo what has been done to me.”

“Well, considering the fact that I'm the first and only person that you could look at without them turning to stone, I'd say it's a pretty good chance.” Percy said.

Medusa sighed heavily, but took the bracelet anyway. “Very well. It never hurts to try, as I've seen over the many centuries I've been cursed.”

Medusa slipped the bracelet over her hand. For a moment, nothing happened, and Medusa was going to make that known if she didn't feel a great pain in her stomach.

Medusa doubled over, her hair hissing in pain. She felt as if she was burning, the bracelet being the strongest source of the feeling.

“Y-you t-tricked me.” Medusa said, clawing at the trinket, desperate to break away from it. “I-I sh-should h-have k-known. Just l-like any o-other-” She would have continued, if the pain hadn't intensified. The feeling from the bracelet started to spread throughout her body, ever so slowly, so agonizingly.

Percy starred, shocked at what was happening. Not only the fact that Medusa was hurting, and that he was responsible for it, but at what was happening to her.

The skin around the bracelet smoothed out, softening. It was so sudden, yet it spread slowly. The effect crept up her arm, spreading across her body as she writhed, her hair biting the air and hissing even more.

As it spread, the effect shaped Medusa. Her chest puffed up a bit, though it was hard to see under all her clothes. Her body slimmed, becoming curvier as her hips grew ever so slightly. Her ass grew as well, though not by much.

As the effect of the bracelet spread towards her head, Medusa let out a loud, pained scream. Her face smoothed out, looking more like it belonged on a twenty year old then a monster.

As the Bracelet's power reached her hair, the snakes gave one last hiss of pain as they fell limp. As Percy watched, their scales softened, turning black, dissolving into individual strands.

Hair.

Medusa's hair.

Medusa's pained cries slowly ended, becoming sobs, which in turn died down to whimpers as Medusa laid on the ground.

Percy slowly moved towards Medusa, having backed up when she started trying to grab him. “Medusa?”

The woman, young woman Percy would add, looked up at him. Her face was streaked with tears, something which Medusa herself thought had dried up long ago.

“Why Percy?” She asked, sniffing back tears. “Why would you do this to me? Why give me hope, only to cause me pain?”

“Medusa, I-” Percy started to say, only to have her move away from him.

“No! Stay back!” Medusa cried. “You're just like the Grey-Eyed One!”

Percy moved towards her, reaching out to grab her shoulder. “Medusa, I th-”

“Stay Back!” She yelled, trying to swipe at Percy with her claws.

Only to have him catch her hand.

“Let go! Let go Damn you!” She yelled, trying to break free of his grip. “Haven't you caused me enough pain you pig-headed monster!”

“Woah, what?” Percy asked. That was different. He could understand her not trusting him, but this was something else entirely. Her entire demeanor changed from cursing him to being afraid of his mere presence.

“Are you going to be just like your Father? A horrible monster of a god?” Medusa asked accusingly, her struggles not ending.

“Medusa, I have no idea what you're talking about.” Percy said. “Just look at yourself.”

“Why should I?” Medusa said, going completely still. “What's going to change? I'll still be the hideous monster, and I'll still be punished for something that I couldn't stop.”

“Just... look.” Percy said gently. Something was definitely off here. “I'm sorry that happened. I didn't think it would be painful. Just trust me on this. I wasn't lying about being able to look at you, was I?”

Medusa said nothing, but she did slowly raise her head. She had her eyes closed, facing Percy's hand as it held her own.

Then, slowly, Medusa opened her eyes, taking only a glance at what she saw.

Her eyes shot open in shock.

The hand that Percy was grabbing wasn't wrinkled or clawed. It was a human hand.

One she hadn't seen in a long, long time.

“What? I-I don't understand.” She said. She looked at her other hand frantically, feeling her face with it. Only then did she realize that she didn't hear hissing. She grabbed at her hair, expecting to find snakes writhing in her grasp.

Only silky black threads of hair were grasped between her fingers.

Tears welled up again, this time of happiness. “I'm free.” She said softly. “Finally free, after so long.”

With those few words, and the realization that her nightmare was over, the emotional dam burst. She laughed as tears rolled down her face. She shook with silent sobs, blocked out by the sheer joy of her new freedom.

She even had her old body back! It was like she hadn't aged a day.

And that other curse, one that Athena hadn't put on her. One that was as bad as being turned into a monster.

She wrapped her arms around Percy, catching him off guard.

“Thank you.” She whispered, over and over again. She buried her face into Percy's chest, her tears not soaking his shirt.

Percy awkwardly returned the hug, patting her back. “It's going to be fine.” He said, not sure how to console her. How do you help someone who was a literal monster for so long, now human again? Above Medusa floated the words 'Take her. She's yours', but Percy ignored them.

Behind Percy, there was the sound of the door sliding open.

“Are you sure this is the right place? It smells like a monster here, and these statues are creeping me out. That one even looks like my Uncle Ferdinand.” He heard Grover comment. “Oh Percy. There you are.”

The sound of two pairs of shoes. Claws and hooves hitting the floor sounded behind Percy, moving close. Grover was about ask what Percy was doing, when he started to sniff the air, gaining a panicked look. “Percy, Get away from her! She's a monster!” He said, grabbing a tin can to throw.

“No Grover, she's not. Not anymore.” Percy said evenly, feeling Medusa flinch at being called a monster.

“What are you talking about?” Grover asked, keeping his can at the ready. Man, he wished he could fight with a blade or something.

“That's something we're going to talk about. Annabeth, could you get everyone some food?” He asked his girlfriend, getting a nod.

“What Alpha doing with lady? She smell like snake.” The hell-hound stated, submissive personality taking the lead at the moment.

“We'll talk about that. Just wait for some food, Okay?” Percy said, but phrased it as if asking a question.

“And that's the gist of what's going on Grover.” Percy said, sipping on a soda.

They were all sitting in Medusa's food court, while Medusa herself was in her room freshening up. They had just finished dinner, introducing Melum and the Hell-hound, which they had yet to name since she wanted Percy to name her, to the wonders of fast food.

Grover was starring at Percy, looking between him and Annabeth every so often. His eyes were wide with disbelief since the story started. He wanted to disbelieve it, think Percy was pulling a joke on him or something.

Two things stopped him though. One being the fact that Percy had laid the book he was talking about, the Eronomicon, out on the table, flipped to the page that described the Bracelet that was on the woman's arm.

The other one was that Percy was a bad liar.

“You see why we didn't want to tell you?” Annabeth asked.

Grover looked between them again. “So, you're telling me that you two,” He says, pointing to Percy and Annabeth. “Come from the future. There's going to be another war with the titans, and Luke's going to become the living shell of Kronos. She,” He said, pointing to Melum. “Is a goddess from another universe, who was kept in this book.” He said, pointing to the Eronomicon. “Which, if what you telling me is true, will turn Percy into a god.”

“Yeah, I guess.” Percy said, shrugging. “Still not entirely sure on that last part though.”

“And,” Grover said as he put his head in his hands. “You're telling me that the fates aren't old ladies, but are actually beautiful women who want to be with Percy. All THREE of them. And they also want you to clean up the gods messes from a long time ago, leading a change in the order of things.”

“Got it so far Grover.” Annabeth said, yawning. She was glad Percy was letting him in on this, but it was taking a while. She wanted some sleep dang it!

“How are you okay with that?” Grover asked incredulously. “From what you told me, you two were about to hit it off!”

“Yeah, well things happen Grover.” Annabeth remarked. “I really don't want to have to fight against the Fates, literally, for Percy. Besides, from what Percy told me, they seemed insistent on Percy helping women.”

“Alright, fine. I guess I can understand that.” Grover said tiredly. This was putting a crazy, unwanted spin on his life. “But right now, we're currently in the lair of Medusa, former monster due to both your godly parents, who is now un-cursed thanks to Percy.”

“Yeah, though something still bugs me about that.” Percy said. “She called my dad a pig-headed monster of a god. Before she put the bracelet on, she was all love-stuck on my dad.”

Grover sighed. Normally, he would freak out, but this was just too much. The implications were too much, and he just couldn't feel much about it. What could he do about it?

“Well, on the bright side I find the Great Lord Pan.” Grover said with a hollow chuckle.

“And kinda become his successor, becoming the new god of the wild.” Percy said, trying to help his long-time friend. “You gonna be okay G-man?”

“I don't know Percy. The proof's right in front of me, but I don't know what to feel.” He said.

Percy reached to pat his friend on the back. “Sorry for dumping this all on you, but-”

“It was either that, lie to me or do something else to me with that book.” Grover said, shuddering at the thought. He really didn't want to know what it could do to him. “I shouldn't have bothered.”

“It's alright Grover. You were just curious, and rightly so.” Annabeth said. “We're outside the camp borders now, and we can and will get attacked by monsters. Even more so since Percy's a child of the Big Three. If Percy was doing something that could have gotten us all killed, you could have tried to talk him out of it.”

“Besides, I hated lying to you Grover. Even if it was just for this little bit.” Percy said.

Grover shook his head. “No, it's fine. You had all this dumped on you, and you were tossed through time. I think it was harder on you then this is on me. And I see why you don't want the gods to know bout this.”

“Know about what?” Came Medusa's voice from the doorway behind the counter, followed closely by Medusa herself.

“Nothing you need to worry about Medusa.” Percy said, turning and smiling gently at her. “How you feeling?”

Medusa blushed slightly at his smile. It had been so long since she had been able to actually talk with people, much less anyone smiling at her. “O-oh, I'm fine. Better then I have been in centuries, thanks to you.” She said, moving to sit down between Percy and Melum.

She was wearing a black dress, though it seemed to be fashioned slightly after something that a priestess wore back in ancient Greece. Her feet were bare, and she wore several other bangles on both wrists now. She had forgone the veil, having no need to hide her face anymore.

“Hey, Medusa, would you mind if I ask you something?” Percy asked, getting shake of her head as an answer. “Why did you go from asking me to stay with you because of my father, then flip out when I got near you?”

Instantly Medusa went from smiling at him warmly to looking down, shaking slightly with a haunted look in her amethyst colored eyes.

“Hey Medusa, you alright?” Percy asked, reaching out to touch her shoulder only to have her flinch away from him.

It seemed to bring Medusa out of her trance though, since her eyes came back into focus. “O-oh. I-I'm sorry. I-it's just that...” She trailed off, taking a deep, shuddering breath. “Do you know the true story behind why I was turned into a monster?”

“Wasn't it because you and my dad did some stuff in Athena's temple?” Percy asked.

“No.” Medusa said. “Well, in a way, yes. But it wasn't what I wanted.” She said, gaining that haunted look in her eye again. “No, that isn't what I wanted at all. I think I should tell you what really happened, all of you. I should start by saying that I was a priestess of your mothers Annabeth. Me and my two sisters. We did our duties diligently, as any priestess should. We had all taken vows of chastity, just like your mother. But then, one day, your godly parents got into a horrible fight. Athena won, leaving your father the sore loser. So, in the ways that the gods did back then, he decided to get revenge. He was looking around for priestess' of your mother, finding one to despoil and claim as his own, likely to sire another child as well. Unfortunately for me, he took fancy with me, and began to pursue me with the hopes of taking me from your mother's services.”

She shivered a bit, as if she could see it happening again before her eyes. “When he grew tired of trying to sweet talk me, he decided to press harder and harder. He would harass one of us whenever me or my sisters would leave the temple. Soon, we were fearful to leave. We prayed to Our Lady, but she did not hear us. It finally happened when a visitor to our temple lead him in during the night.” Tears welled up in her eyes once again, but she didn't even notice them. “Once he was in, he made his way to our bed chambers and... and...”

She couldn't say it. It was too painful to bring it up. Tears started to fall again, landing on the table as she shook. She could see it happening again, felt as violated as she did that night so long ago.

The demigods, goddess and Satyr, watched as Medusa broke down crying once again. It didn't take much to put two and two together.

Percy wrapped one arm around her, though it was a little awkward due to the height difference.

“A-and w-when he f-finished... Athena f-found h-him s-standing over m-me... S-she c-c-cursed m-me a-and my si-sister's t-thinking w-we had l-let him in...”

Percy felt himself getting sick. Was his father really capable of something like this?

Well, considering their old ways, not to mention all the half-human monsters that came about because of the gods, it seemed like a possibility.

“A-and then... h-he c-cursed u-us too... w-went around a-and spread t-the story t-that I-I loved him a-and b-betrayed m-my L-Lady...” Medusa was just bawling now. She couldn't talk anymore as the horror of that event rushed over her again.

Percy met Annabeth's eyes, both hardened.

Oh yes, Percy was going to talk with his dad about this.

Having Melum help him get Medusa standing, The two of them helped Medusa back to her room, Melum sitting with her for Percy as she continued to cry.

Percy went back out, sitting down. He felt drained, and he wanted to sleep. He voiced that opinion to everyone, and they all agreed.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
It was going to be a long trip to Denver. Three days by train.

Pretty costly too.

There was Percy, Annabeth and Grover, which was almost 200 dollars. Add in Melum, The Hell-hound woman and, surprisingly, Medusa, and it was another 200 dollars. Then pay for sleeper cars, and it all came to around 700 dollars.

Though it seemed Medusa had saved up money from her time as a monster, easily having more then enough to pay for them all.

Percy wanted to object, but she wasn't having any of it. She was going with him, specifically him, and she was going to do her best to help him out. Besides, she wanted his help to learn how to control her abilities, when she was told that that was something else the bracelet did for her.

Grover also had said that Medusa still smelt like a monster, so it would provide a bit of extra protection against future monster attacks.

Grover and Medusa had been told that their next target was the gateway Arch, which is why they were going to St. Louis. And what they were trying to do there.

Grover had nearly choked on the tin can he was eating when he was told that their next target was the Mother of Monster's, Echidna. Even Medusa was wary about something like that. Not to mention the Chimera.

But it was decided. They made plans, deciding that Melum would stick with him at the top, since she was really the only other person in their group that could stand a chance against Echidna. The Hell-hound had wanted to stay, both personalities having their reasons to do so. The submissive one because she wanted to stay with her Alpha, and the aggressive one because she wanted to fight a strong opponent, like the Chimera, but Percy put his foot down.

So there they were, all of them spending the days on the train in their car. During the times when the Hell-hound's submissive personality was active, Annabeth tried to teach her more about the English language, and bits of Greek and Latin here and there.

It was going... okay? It was difficult, to say the least. At Random moments, she would switch personalities, making it difficult to get through lessons. Strangely, she seemed to take to Latin better.

Sleeping arrangements were a bit strange. Grover had his own bed, and the hell-hound slept on the floor of her own accord. Percy was willing to sleep in one of the chairs, but none of the women, besides the hell-hound, were having it. Annabeth offered to share her bed with Percy, getting sputters from Grover.

Surprisingly, Percy didn't seemed opposed to the idea, nor embarrassed.

Melum herself offered to do the same, even taking his spot on the chair if he didn't want to share a bed with anyone. Percy assured her that she didn't have to do something like that.

Medusa was slightly hesitant about it, but she too offered to share a bed with Percy. Percy smiled gently at her, saying that if she was uncomfortable with the thought, then she didn't have to offer. For some reason, Medusa felt her heart beat faster at this, pink dusting her cheeks. Especially when she looked into his eyes, which were a deep sea green that seemed to glow in any light.

In the End, Percy ended up sleeping besides Melum, due to remembering that they had to meet the Fates. Annabeth seemed strangely unruffled by this. She merely shrugged, giving him a kiss on the cheek and slipping into her bed for the night.

Percy yawned, bored of watching the scenery pass. The sun had set a while ago, so it was even harder to see anything. But it still surprised Percy how much the mist could hide, since he had seen centaurs, satyrs, nymphs and what he thought was the Neamian Lion. He briefly wondered if it would be beneficial if he could take its pelt ealier.

Turning to his shared bunk, below Medusa's, Percy carefully crept over. Grover was long asleep, and the hell-hound was sleeping near his bed. Percy briefly wondered about Mrs. O'leary, the tank-sized hell-hound Daedalus had given him to take care of.

He slipped beneath the blanket, aware that Melum was watching him the whole time, her blue eyes shining in the dark.

“Are you feeling well Master Perseus?” Melum asked, not for the first time. She had been concerned since the night before, as his demeanor had changed as Medusa told her story.

“Yeah Mel. I'm fine.”Percy said, yawning again. “Come on, we need to get some sleep. The Fates want to talk with us, something that the book's doing to their work.”

“Of course Master.” Melum said.

Percy closed his eyes, the sound and motion of the train making it hard to sleep.

That is, until a haunting sound filled the train car. And not in the bad way either. It was soothing, making it easier to sleep. Percy could feel himself slipping away, drifting to sleep easier. He knew it was Melum singing, since she was the only one capable of sounding like that. His last conscious thought was of doing something for her, even if she protested to it.

~

Percy's eyes flew open. He was laying someplace he wasn't familiar with, and this wasn't one of his prophetic dreams that loved to trouble him.

'Ahh, welcome dear Perseus. Welcome, traveling goddess.' Three voice said simultaneously.

It was then that Percy noted that he did feel warmth next to him. “You must be the Fates that Master Perseus was talking about.” Melum's voice said, the warmth moving to stand up.

Clotho and Atropos chuckled, While Lachesis merely smiled. 'Correct, Traveler. We are the ones who weave the tapestry of fate, a delicate process.' Her smiled disappeared, replaced with a frown. 'Which is why we called you two here tonight.'

“You said something about it unraveling?” Percy asked, standing up and looking around the chamber. It was a large stone cavern, lit with what looked like stars from beneath them and... was that Olympus down there? Percy could see a large loom in another chamber behind the Fates.

'Yes, that is true.' Clotho said. 'Whenever we try to incorporate you into the weave, it falls apart. We were hoping that the Traveler could explain why that is.'

Percy got a good look at them now, trying not to think about the fact that he was standing above Olympus. All three were dressed in white, form fitting dresses, though they retained their appearance's of youth.

“I, unfortunately, do not know. The Great Tome has not seen fit to give me that knowledge.” Melum said. “However, I know that inside the Great Tome you might find the answers you seek.”

'Inside?' Atropos asked, raising a delicate eyebrow. Percy was wondering the same thing.

“Yes.” Melum said, staring unflinchingly at the three beings. “Inside. The Great Tome has an entire universe inside of it, as well as being sentient. I'm sure that it would be happy to answer your questions, as well as meet the one it has marked.”

The Fates looked at one another, once again seeming to have a conversation silently. 'Very well. How would we go about entering the book?' They all asked.

“Master, could you take out the Great Tome?” She asked, getting a nod as Percy pulled it from his back pocket. “All you need to do is put your hand on it, all of us, and command it to grant you entry Master.”

Percy nodded, putting his hand on the book. Clotho, Lachesis and Atropos each placed their hand on Percy's, with Melum merely holding an edge.

“Uh, I command you to grant us entry?” Percy said, unsure of himself.

A flash of light erupted from beneath their hands, though thanks to everyone having godly eyes, none needed to look away.

But it did cause Percy one major headache, as everything turned black again.

He felt the hands of the fates and Melum disappear, causing him to worry. Had he done something wrong somehow? Or was he the only one allowed inside the book?

“Melum? Atropos?” He called out. “Clotho? Lachesis? Is anybody there?”

Who answers?

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Greetings Marked one.” A booming voice echoed, seemingly from all around.

“Hello?” Percy asked. “Are you the spirit of the book?”

“Correct. I am the spirit of Eronomicon. Do not fear for your women, they are fine.” It said. “I must apologize for the darkness, but it will pass in a second. Your mind was not fully capable of handling the dimensional shift, therefore the darkness.”

As it spoke(?), Percy saw light enter his vision again, mere specks at first, but they grew.

When Percy could see again, he saw that the Fates were looking around for the source of the voice. Melum was looking at him with a small smile, holding her hand out. It was only then that Percy noticed he was laying on the ground.

Taking her hand, Percy got off the ground and looked around the room.

Well, more like a stone tower room the size of Yankee Stadium. It even had large windows dotted around the room.

There were tables, bookshelves, even paintings and a large basin filled with strange chemicals.

But no one besides him and the women.

“Whoa...” Percy gasped, looking around. “Um, we came to ask a few questions? Would you mind answering them?”

“Of course. Anything for the Marked one.” It said, not unlike Melum in tone and respect. “What is it you wish to know?”

“Well, the Fates want to know why every time they try to add me to pattern of fate it falls apart.” Percy said, “Do you know anything about that?”

“Of course I do.” It said, though there was no disrespect in it's voice. “It is because, through my influence and nature, you are no longer a singular universal being.”

“What?” Percy said, confused. He really didn't understand what he was being told.

“To put it simply, you are beyond this universe. You exist beyond any singular universe, and therefore are not bound by its destiny.” It said. “By not being bound to its fate, you can no longer be controlled by any universe's rules, besides the rules that govern all universe's simultaneously.”

'But that causes problems for us.' Atropos said. 'We need certain event to happen, but without Perseus they cannot come to pass.'

It was silent for a moment, the fates seeming to hold their breaths.

“It is... not impossible to come to a deal, regarding your circumstances and positions as weavers of fate.” It said, as if contemplating something. “You could work with the Marked one to weave him into the destiny of this universe, if he so chooses.”

The Fates looked at him, before looking at each other once again.

“But know this.” It said, sounding slightly aggressive, once again not unlike Melum when Percy was threatened. “If you try to weave him to your wiles, making him a puppet, there shall be... undesirable consequences.”

The Fates looked unperturbed by the threat. 'We would never think of doing so. We only want what is best for Perseus, but he is integral to the survival of our world as a whole.'

'Hmm... Very well. I sense the truth behind your words. We have an accord.” It said. 'Whether or not the weave is stable is left to the Marked one to decide. I am merely a tool for his glory. I exist to serve, and serve is what I shall do.”

'Well, you picked a good chosen.' Clotho said with another small laugh. 'Perseus is, with no question, the greatest hero our world has seen. He will easily surpass the gods, since we believe it is time for a change in leadership.'

“Yeah, speaking of that, I've got another question.” Percy said. Suddenly, he could feel the full attention of the Eronomicon focused on him, as if eager to answer his questions. “What exactly is a harem god, and what does it have to do with me?”

“Hmm... a question that is not easily answered.” It said, and Percy could almost see a figure rubbing its chin in thought. “Would you like a full explanation now, or a summery for the moment?”

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy thought about it, but decided on the long version. “Full explanation please. I want to know what's happening.”

“Very well, Marked one.” It said. Suddenly some very comfy chairs appeared, one for each of them. “Please, sit. It will be a while. I will have the Keepers make some refreshments. And Marked one, would you please allow me to have them take care of your sword while we wait?”

Once Percy and company had sat down, Percy hesitantly placing his sword on a table which promptly made it vanish, the Eronomicon began it's explanation.

“The Harem god, which is you Marked one, is the one who I have chosen to own everything that I contain, including myself. He is a god unlike any other, who will become the most powerful being in existence. The Harem god is the one to inherit my creators will, since he is no longer able to do so himself.” The Eronomicon began.

“As the Harem God, you will have the knowledge and power of infinite worlds, infinite universe's at your disposal. Even now, as you sleep, I am working to rid you of your mortal limits, allowing you to access heights never before seen. You will be stronger, faster, more resilient. I have almost finished ridding you of your natural-born ailments, and I am implementing knowledge of languages long forgotten by mortals and gods as we speak. Everything I contain is used to serve you, Marked one. There are things inside this tome that could end the world with but a whisper, all at your command, Melum being one of them that you have called upon. But that is not the main purpose of the Harem God. No, no. The Purpose of the Harem God is to know the love of Many women, to know all things perverted and bring down the harsh 'justice' of those in power, by any means possible.” It said, tone gaining a fervor that was almost crazed, frightening Percy a bit.

“You have already started down your path to taking the mantle of the Harem god, setting things in motion that cannot be stopped now. You have already taken on the eyes, and gained a sizable following of women already, powerful ones at that. I am sure you have felt power flowing into you, feeling your natural power grow by leaps and bounds.” It said, tone becoming more controlled. “Women are your source of power, Marked one. Like any god, you need followers, and Women are yours. They will provide you with power, pledging themselves to you and your cause.”

The voice paused, taking a deep breath. “Ah, forgive me. I nearly lost myself in my explanation. But know that everything in here is at your command, Marked one. Everything that I contain is for you, and you only, to use at your discretion. You have tasted the power at your fingertips, and it must feel pleasant.”

Percy tried to calm himself. It was scary, having a disembodied voice go completely nuts over the fact that he was, well, him. And he had a lot of experience with disembodied voices.

But he had to admit, the book wasn't wrong. It was pleasant, somewhere in his mind, to have such power at his finger tips. It wasn't the kind of pleasant that every titan and rouge demigod assured him he would feel if he joined them in destroying Olympus, and beyond what Aphrodite's presence felt like. Those types of pleasant felt... wrong, dirty and not real. Fabricated to make him think that it would be good to join them.

But not this. No, it felt genuine.

“I-is there anything else I should know?” He asked, wondering whether or not he wanted to know. “Any Drawbacks or anything?”

“Beings of order and virginity would oppose you, if that is what you mean.” It said. “Otherwise, I can think of only one thing that you might want to know.”

“Yeah? What's that?”

“Well, you may find that you will change over time. Not your physical appearance, but you might find yourself doing things that you might not otherwise do. Things that you have been taught in society are undesirable.” It said.

“Like stealing and stuff like that?” Percy asked, though he felt as if he was only touching the tip of the ice-burg here.

“That is certainly one thing, but I was hinting at things in a more sexual nature.” It said.

“Whoa!” Percy said, standing up from his chair in a flash. “I don't want to become a rapist! Or a pedophile or anything like that!” He said, feeling sick to his stomach. 'I don't want to be like my dad.'

“I never said that you had to, or would. It depends on how far you yourself are willing to go.” It said. “But, I could try to help you keep some bits of your morals, though it is against my nature to do much in that department. And when I say that, I mean that I am literally incapable of doing much for that, but I can try. I will see if I can copy certain morals and permanently integrate them into you, so that you will not become a 'rapist.'”

Percy calmed down slightly, nodding. Man, things were just beating down on him. One thing after another.

“Okay... I... think I can work with that.” Percy said, sitting down.

At that moment, several glasses of water popped up by everyone, and Percy was quick to drink it. He needed to think.

“Marked one, I couldn't help but hear all your conversations about your quest.” The Eronomicon said, dragging Percy from his thoughts. “If it would please you, I can offer advise on what items would help you in the near future.”

Percy sighed, but then he thought on it. Would it really be that bad if he prepared more using the book?
