Annabeth was shaking Percy. They had half-an-hour until they made it to St. Louis, and he was still asleep. Both he and Melum had slept throughout the previous day without stirring once, and Annabeth was starting to get worried. What was Percy doing?

Suddenly, both Percy's and Melum's eyes flew open. Percy blinked his eyes, letting out a groan.

“Ugh, what's going on? How long was I asleep?” He asked, moving to sit up.

“Percy!” Annabeth said, grabbing him in a tight hug. “Are you okay? What happened with the Fates? What took so long?”

“Whoa, Annabeth. Slow down.” Percy said groggily, though he did return the hug earnestly.

Annabeth felt something wash over her, as she shuddered as her arousal spiked suddenly. It took everything she had to not moan out loud.

“Oh, sorry. Forgot to turn those seals off.” He said, letting go of her as his arms and legs glowed, even from underneath his clothes.

It took Annabeth a moment to feel confident walking again, as her legs turned to mush when Percy hugged her. It took even longer for her to be able to speak.

“Percy, what happened?” She asked, glad that Grover was getting some food with Medusa, and the hell-hound was sleeping soundly still.

Percy stood up, stretching his arms into the air. He felt like he had slept for days, though that couldn't be possible, could it?

“It's a long story Annabeth, I'll tell you later. How long was I out for? It feels like I slept for weeks.”

“Try two days, or close to it. We're almost to St. Louis now. Come on, you must be hungry.” She said, pulling him and Melum, who had just stood up, out the door and towards the dining car.

~Later, near the arch

“Are you sure this is going to work?” Grover asked. He could smell an extremely powerful monster around, one that wasn't Medusa or a Hell-hound. And this was before they went underground, so there should have been no reason.

“Yes Grover, I'm 100 percent sure. Relax.” Percy said, having one hand in his pocket, grasping the new Riptide and something else, which is what he planned to use on Echidna and chimera.

As They neared the Elevator, Percy had Melum Medusa and the Hell-hound go up first, along with a family and their little boy. Behind them was a large lady carrying a barking and growling Chihuahua.

Echinda and the Chimera.

Percy made no movements that would make her suspect him knowing who she was.

When the Elevator came down again, Percy, Grover and Annabeth got loaded into it with Echidna, the Chimera yapping all the while.

“No parents?” Echidna asked.

“Already up there. Wasn't enough room in the last elevator.” Percy answers, making the disguised Chimera bark.

“Hush Sonny, not now.” She said, stroking her back.

“O-oh?” Grover said, stuttering slightly. “Is that his name?”

“No.” She said, smiling a horrible smile.

When they got out at the top, Percy actually took the time to enjoy the scenery. After all, it wasn't often that he got to stay in high places with a view like this. Zeus would have blasted him with his master bolt if he tried. The only time he did get to be up in the air was on a Pegasus.

It didn't seem like very long when The park ranger was calling for everyone to move near the elevator to leave, as the monument was closing for the night. Medusa, the Hell-hound and another family got on the elevator down. On the Next Elevator, Annabeth and Grover, along with the family with their kid got on.

Now it was Percy, Melum, Echidna, the Chimera and the Park Ranger.

The poor park ranger.

“Hello Echidna.” Percy said, walking up next to her as she looked out the window. “How's the little Chimera doing?” He asked in a baby voice, making the monster bark angrily as he chuckled.

“My, someone seems confident in themselves. But I'm surprised you knew who I was.” Echidna said, her voice trying to be menacing. And it would have been as well, if Percy wasn't used to much scarier things yelling at him and cursing his name.

“Yeah, well, I know a lot of things that I shouldn't.” Percy said. “But why don't we skip all the witty banter. I've got a lot of energy to burn, and I need to fight something. I wonder if you or your son could give me a challenge though.”

Echidna growled at him, like her son. “Arrogant little brat. Very well.” She said, letting the Chimera jump from her arms and onto the ground, where it began to transform.

Percy only yawned.

Melum started her part, having rehearsed it back on the train. She ran over to the park Ranger, who obviously noticed something was wrong with the lady and her dog. “Sir, I'm going to need you to leave. I've been helping that boy track down the people who kidnapped his mother. This lady is a part of that group. Alert the authorities.”

Whether or not the guard believed her didn't matter. His mortal instincts were telling him to scram, and he did so. He pushed out the emergency exit, calling into his radio for back-up.

The Chimera tried to lunge at Percy, but water formed in front of it, blocking its path. “Ah ah ah.” Percy chided. “We don't want the fight to end so soon, do we?”

Wrapping the water around the lions mouth, Percy just vanished, appearing next to Echidna, grabbing her arm. “Enjoy. You'll be much more pleasing to the eye.” He said, as she was engulfed in light.

Percy jumped several feet in the air, something that should have been impossible, and landed perfectly on the Chimera's back. The diamondback snake tail tried to bit him, but Percy moved just inches out of the way every time, disappearing and reappearing in different spots on its back.

As the light died around Echidna, Percy grabbed the snake, causing light to erupt from the Chimera. He vanished and appeared next to Echidna again, slipping something around her neck.

The new and improved Echidna blinked her eyes, rubbing them to get them to stop being blurry. After doing so, her eyes landed on Percy.

However, instead of hatred, she looked at him with love. Pure, undiluted, unfathomable love. Something that only Melum and Annabeth had in their eyes.

She was quite the looker now as well, almost something beyond mortal comprehension. She had slimmed considerably, even growing a few inches. Her hair, which hung to her waist, was black. Her assets grew considerably, though her clothes were still falling around her. Her skin was tinged green, and covered in scales on her arms and legs. She had a long, thick snake like tail, almost dragon like, which was probably stronger then it looked.

Percy whistled, teleporting back over to the Front of the Chimera as he slipped a ring onto his hand, putting another onto the now human figure of the Chimera.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: What's the worst that could happen?

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
As the light died around the Chimera, Percy took in the new woman's form.

She had fur, much like the hell-hound, though it was more golden like a lion. She had a large golden mane, surrounding her head, and a long tail sprouting from her backside, looking like a snake's skin tipped with a rattler. Her fur was enough to cover certain parts of her, and she also had a large tuft of fur covering her breasts, which were quite large. Atop her head stood large, curling horns.

Percy smirked, thinking of an emotion. Immediately the Chimera smiled, showing off her human teeth with extra pointy fangs, poking just from under her lip.

Another emotion, and her face frowned, gaining a sad look that looked absolutely adorable on her face somehow and a sad bleat like a goat.

Yet another and she growled, shaking her tail, sounding like a whole band of Maraca players.

“Good, they worked.” Percy said. “Glad those worked right.”

Melum walked up beside him, smile adorning her face. “Congratulations Master. It seems that you are taking to your new power nicely. You didn't even have to use your sword.”

Percy grinned, patting the pocket with Riptide. “Yeah, well, that's for something else. C'mon. Let's go before the police show up.”

Percy put his hands on Melum, disappearing wit her. He reappeared without her, putting one hand on the Chimera's shoulder, who walked over to him like a loyal puppy, and the other on Echidna's. In an instant, all three of them vanished, the process easier with the power that surged through Percy.

Having the mother of monsters and one of her most powerful children at his command did give him a sufficient power boost after all.

They reappeared at the base of the arch, where Melum was waiting, watching as police helicopters and other vehicles rushed the seen, with a news van not far behind.

“C'mon, lets get out of here. Melum, do you know where everyone else is at?” Percy asked.

“Yes, they should be at the train station waiting for us as per your orders.” She said. “I saw Mistress Annabeth and the Satyr get into one of those 'taxis' just before you arrived. Judging by the time it took to get here, they should be there in five minutes.”

Percy smiled at her, making Melum flush. “Good job Mel.” Percy said, moving closer to her. “Maybe I should... reward you later.” He whispered, wrapping his arms around her as he activated the seals on them.

Melum gasped, moaning. It was a delightful sound, hearing the goddess mewl under his careful touch, the growing wetness between her legs becoming more evident.

Unfortunately, they didn't have the time to take it further then that.

“Echidna, place your hand on my shoulder.” Percy said, the Chimera already doing so. He deactivated the seals. When she had done so, Percy vanished, pulling them along with him to their destination.

~Later, in their suite on the train.

“Everyone, say hello to Echidna and the Chimera.” Percy said, pointing to each as they sat on the chairs in the room. “They'll be joining us for the remainder of this quest.”

Grover nearly choked. “By the gods.” He whispered. “I-I didn't think you would... could do something like that. I'm going to need nose plugs or something.” He muttered, laying down on his bed.

Percy grinned at Annabeth and Medusa. “Why don't I take you two to the dinner? My treat.” He said, though he did level an eye at Medusa. “And I mean it. You won't pay for this.”

Medusa nodded, blushing. She was so unused to the way things were done now, never having the chance to really live in the moment.

“Excellent.” Percy said, grabbing both their hands. “Melum, keep an eye on things would you?”

“Of course Master.” Melum said with a smile, happy that she could help and that he trusted her enough.

“Now, hold on, and close your eyes.” Percy said.

Both women wondered what Percy was talking about, but complied. They closed their eyes, holding tightly onto Percy's hands.

In an instant, everything seemed to rush away from them. They couldn't hear or feel the train.

“Okay, you can look now.” Percy said, letting go of their hands.

Both women did so. When they saw where they were, they felt their breath taken away.

They were on a cliff, forest at their backs, looking out over the city as the sun set behind it. In the distance, they could see their train speeding forward.

“Percy, what happened?” Annabeth asked, once she had gotten her voice back.

Percy lifted his feet, pointing to his shoes. Annabeth could tell that they weren't his normal shoes, instead looking like some very expensive, but oh so comfortable running shoes.

“There's a reason I was asleep for so long.” Percy said, before going on to explain what happened when he met with the fates, going inside the Eronomicon and talking with the book itself.

He then went on to explain that it felt like he spent a few weeks in there, at least according to Melum. He had some things done to his body, as well as taking a few more artifacts for their journey. He told her about the shoes, known as The Boots of the Wandering God and how he took possession of them.

Among the things that had happened, Percy had a list to tell her and Medusa. He had the Seal of the addicting limb placed on all four of his limbs, and he had learned a fighting style called the Casanova's dance, making Medusa stifle a laugh. Apparently, he was a child of Aphrodite's, and he had the unfortunate luck of stumbling onto her lair one evening. She really didn't like him, hearing about his exploits from the grapevine. He was one person that Medusa gladly turned to stone.

Percy had also received the Lover's Necklace, which was what was around Echidna's neck, and the Empathy Rings, which he wore one of and the Chimera wore the other.

He also had the Tongue of the Silver Serpent ritual placed on him by the Keepers, insanely beautiful women inside the Eronomicon that acted like a hive mind in some ways, yet individually in others.

Percy popped away for a moment, reappearing with a table, candles and some food.

From Paris.

So for the next hour or so, they all sat atop the cliff, eating their food and getting to know one another. Well, Medusa got to know them, and they learned about Medusa.

Apparently, she had loved the sea before what happened with Poseidon. Her favorite color was red, and she loved her family more then anything else. Which only served to depress her when she remembered what had happened to her sister's, both of them fading from existance.

Percy consoled her, remembering something the Fates had told him before he left. Even if something fades, it could be brought back if someone believed in it hard enough. That was something he hadn't known, and was grateful they had told him. Now he only had to do some research on beings that had faded and remind people that they existed.

Medusa had taken the news well, almost crying again. Man, was she emotional.

The night ended, for Medusa at least, when Percy gave her a rose, taking her back to the train. As she set it down, she accidentally pricked her thumb. She couldn't help but smile though, knowing that Percy wasn't like his father. Inside her heart, love started welling up incredibly fast. When she fell asleep, she dreamed of the green eyed demigod constantly, always happy moments. Always loving moments. Always him, with her.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Lover's neckalace, Rings of Empathy

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy appeared next to Annabeth after putting the table back in its rightful place, the owner of the restaurant never noticing it was missing. They sat on the edge of the cliff, watching as the lights in the city flickered on, the sun nearly gone down completely.

“You know Annabeth, I'm kinda glad.” Percy stated, holding her against him. “Despite everything that's happened, I'm glad. I mean, sure, we'll never have a normal relationship now, but we never really would have in the first place. We're both Demigods, and our parents hate each other, not to mention all the crazy stuff we would have gotten into after the titan war. And trust me, it would have been horrible.”

“How so?” She asked, leaning her head on his shoulder.

“According to the Fates, there would have been another gigantomachy.” Percy said, making Annabeth look at him curiously.

“A what?” She said, for once clueless about what Percy was talking about.

“A war with the giants, the ones who were supposed to tear down Olympus because of the way Zeus ruled.” Percy said. “Gaea would have tried awakening, which would have caused more conflict since she would have tried to destroy the world to make it anew.”

“We would have met the roman counterparts of both the gods and Camp Half-blood. Strange, isn't it?” Percy said with a laugh. “Mr. D. would actually be friendly towards us.”

Annabeth giggled softly. “Now there's a thought.”

“Yeah.” Percy said, looking up as the stars started to shine in the sky. He almost caught himself looking for Zoe's constellation. “But I would have lost my memory in a gambit due to Hera's meddling. I would have forgotten about everyone I knew, everyone I cared about. We would have lost more people in that war then in this one, and we would have to fight some of the most powerful beings in existence. But at the same time, we would have made many friends and brought peace, or some semblance of it, between the true civilizations of Greece and Rome.”

“Mhm.” Annabeth hummed in thought. “Doesn't sound too bad. We could deal with it, I would like to think.”

Percy held Annabeth tighter. “Yes, we could have. But I almost lost you too many times Annabeth. We were separated for a long time, at least a long time for demigods. Not only that, but we were dragged to Tartarus. Not just the place, but the primordial being himself. And that's just the tip of the iceberg.” Percy said, feeling tears gathering in his eyes at the thought of losing Annabeth.

Annabeth thought on that, the news not entirely shocking. But still, it was disheartening.

“But I don't have to worry about that now. With the Fates working with me to weave a better future, and the power that I now have, I can stop all that. I can make sure that Gaea doesn't start another pointless war. But first I've got to deal with this one. Unfortunately, Kronos needs to rise. He needs to put up a serious threat to the gods. I can't save Luke, Annabeth, not even now. He needs to become the new vessel of Kronos. But I'll make sure he's redeemed in the after-life.” Percy said, pulling her against him even tighter. “And then there are my new responsibilities.”

“Responsibilities?” Annabeth asked, watching as the moon rose over the horizon.

“Yeah, responsibilities.” Percy said. “Due to my new position as the Harem god. Well, Marked one as the book called me. I'm not really there yet, but I'm already on my way.”

Annabeth looked up at Percy, the unasked question of just what is a Harem god on her lips. But Percy beat her to it.

“Like all gods, I need to have followers. People who believe in me, and not just in the 'you can do it!' family or friend way. Lover's, slaves, concubines, wives, call it whatever you want. But Women are the ones who need to be my followers. They are the 'Harem' in Harem god. Millions of women, Annabeth, Millions. Not to mention that I'm not a true part of this universe anymore.”

“What are you talking about, not part of this universe?” She asked, not caring about the other part. She already made her peace with it.

“Well, since the Eronomicon is not actually part of any universe, it is beyond them all. Same with me now. That's why the Fates couldn't weave me into the pattern. I'm beyond their power to control.” Percy said, looking up at the full moon. They still had a few weeks left until the deadline, due to his leaving very early. They had time to plan still, and Percy was thinking on it a lot.

“But doesn't that leave you defenseless against the gods?” Annabeth asked, worried for her boyfriend.

Percy shook his head. “No, not in the slightest. The Eronomicon has tons of stuff in it that would work against the gods. The book reworked Riptide, merging it with several other swords and coated it with a metal of its own creation. Riptide is unbreakable now, and sharper then ever, and it could easily take down a god. And that's not pride talking, but facts. I used it to slice through some of the hardest materials known to man like a hot knife through butter. Not to mention my new eyes that I got before we helped Medusa. I told you a bit about them, but I can see things that normal people, even demigods can't look at. Whether it be Medusa's gaze or a god's true form. Illusions don't work on me now either. And neither of these are the true purpose of the eyes.”

“And what's that Percy?”

“To be able to see what it takes for a woman to join me. So that I can make her mine.” Percy said, looking at Annabeth.

“What's it say about me then?” She asked.

“It says that you are already mine.”

Annabeth's lips twitched upwards, forming a smile for a moment as she moved even closer to Percy. “Well, your eyes see the truth then.” She said, gently pressing her lips against his.

Percy was eager to kiss back, turning to wrap her in another hug. In an instant, They were in the woods, Percy pressing her against a tree as they continued to kiss. His hands held her sides, the seals turned on at a low power, providing Annabeth with constant pleasure, but only a little.

Annabeth could feel her own hormones acting up, despite still being in her pre-teen body. She wanted his touch, craved it. It was becoming an almost physical need to have him touch her.

When Percy pulled back, she was panting, her face flush with arousal. “Percy...” She said throatily. “Please, don't stop...”

Percy's eyes twinkled in the dim light of the forest, but he shook his head. “No Annabeth, not tonight. Not when Artemis is watching so closely. Besides, we're still young. Though give it a few weeks, and we'll be back in our older bodies. The seal I used to bring you back in time to me is aging our bodies at a rapid rate, and will only stop when we're in the prime of our memories. In a few weeks, I will take you.”

Annabeth almost moaned at being denied, but she held it back. Just a few weeks, and she would be back to her older body. Then she could have Percy. She nodded weakly, accepting his terms.

“Good. Now, we should get back to the train. We have to make plans for dealing with Ares.”

The world slipped away around her, blurring for a moment. Then she felt the rocking of the train, the sounds of the wheels turning on their tracks. The cabin was dark, but the blue of Melum's eyes cut through the darkness again. The twin blue orbs passed over them, and Annabeth thought she saw the flash of a smile for a moment from them.

She felt Percy kiss her cheek tenderly, laying her down. It was only then that she realized Percy was carrying her bridal style. She felt so safe in his arms, she almost didn't want to let go of him, didn't want him to let go of her.

But with a look from Percy, two green eyes glowing softly, Melum began singing. A soft lullaby, just like the one two nights ago. Annabeth felt her eyelids grow heavy, the music entering her soul once more. She drifted in and out of sleep, falling deeper and deeper every time she blinked. Soon enough, she was sleeping soundly, a smile gracing her lips.

Soon, she would be with Percy. She looked forward to the day.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy looked at Melum, sending an unspoken message.

'I'll be back soon. Get ready to leave, and make sure they're asleep.'

Just a glance at her, and she understood. She nodded her head, starting her song once more.

Percy vanished once again, reappearing far away, but not as far as Paris. It was a hill, topped with a lone Pine tree that reached for the heavens. It over looked a camp, most of which was silent and dark, save the clang of hammers at a forge of late night campers of cabin 9 working hard on their latest project.

Camp half-blood.

Percy was standing next to Thalia's tree. He had in his hand an old fashioned label maker. “Hey Thalia. I know you don't know me, but I know you can hear me. And, believe it or not, I know you Personally. Time-travel is tricky business after all.” Percy said with a small laugh. “But I just want you to know, I'm sorry for what your dad did to you, what my dad and Hades made him do. A lot of things about the gods right now are messed up, and we get blamed for just existing. But don't worry. In a years time, you'll be free of this tree. It'll seem bad at first, and I can only guess it will be painful for you, what's going to happen, but just try and stick through it.” Percy said, groaning when he realized he made a bad pun.

But, then again, when did he get so good with words? Guess it was the serpent tongue ritual at work, plus the Eronomicon working its own magic.

He looked down at the item in his hand. Was he really going to do something like this? It seemed like it. But would it be a gross breach of the trust that him and his cousin would have in the future? Almost certainly, yes.

As he began making a label, he thought about what it did.

'The Label Maker of Ownership. To use it is to take complete ownership of something, ownership so strong that it rewrote reality. Every person who ever existed, and has yet to exist would accept my ownership of whatever I label. They would accept that I could do anything I wanted with it. Though it had to be something Tangible, something for the label to stick to. It would take three days to take ownership of someone else though.' He thought, printing the label.

'Though this is a special case. Thalia is bound to the tree, so if I take control of the tree I take ownership of her.' He thought, looking at the label in the darkness. 'A useful tool when needed, but easily broken.'

Percy peeled the tape off the back of the label, holding it inches from Thalia's tree. “Forgive me Thalia.” He said, applying the label to the bark, watching as it burned itself into the wood and the label turned to smoke.

Other then that, nothing happened. No light show, no tears in the fabric of space or time, nothing.

It was almost as if nothing had happened.

To the rest of the world, save Percy, nothing had happened at all. Things had been the way they always had been. None would know, save for him, what he had done that night, under the full moon. Percy put his hand on the bark, and he swore he almost felt a heart beat, with a familiar voice on the wind as it sung through the branches.

Forgive what Percy?

Not even Thalia herself would know. To her, it would be as natural as anything else. It had always been that way, even if she was older then him by a decent bit. She was both a person and an object, but both halves of her being were his property. To do with as he pleased.

Percy put the label maker back in his pocket, the Eronomicon storing it once again. He sat down under the tree for a bit, looking up at the sky. The branches parted slightly, moving out of his view.

“So you are conscious in there after all huh?” Percy asked. “Don't worry, I'll get you out of there soon enough.”

A while Later, Percy stood up, saying his good-byes to Thalia, his Thalia now. In another instant, Percy was gone, almost as if he was never there. Anyone who could understand the language of nature would have heard her whispering good-bye to him, wanting to beg him not to leave without her.

But to protect the camp was what he had told her to do, long ago. In a dream that happened before she was even born. Percy had told her to protect the camp, though she did not know his face or name at the time. He owned her, and she thanked him for it. She took his purpose to heart, and was now the tree that sustained the barrier that protected the camp. Until he said otherwise, she would continue to do so.

She would wait for him forever.

Because that was what property did.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: A powerful item, easily broken

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy appeared in the big house. Everything was dark, save for a light down the hall. Percy made his way down the hall, feet never making a sound despite the loose floor boards. In fact, Percy's feet would never make a sound again unless he willed it. Such were the perks of having shoes that belonged to a god of thieves, not unlike Hermes, but more specialized in traveling and thievery-like skills.

Percy peered into the window, seeing Chiron in his magical wheelchair at a desk, grading papers. Old habits died hard, though he supposed that Chiron never stopped teaching, only changing his methods of doing so over the years.

Percy knocked on the door, making the immortal centaur look up from what was most likely ancient Greek tests. He wheeled over to the door, wondering who could be wanting to speak with him at that hour.

“Percy? What in blazes are you doing here?” Chiron asked upon realizing that it wasn't an Iris-message. “You should be halfway to the underworld by now!”

Percy shrugged. “Yeah, I should be. I can be back there in a second though.” He said casually.

Chiron was about to raise questions about how he planned to do that, but decided against it. Percy was extraordinary, even for a demigod. Not to mention having a goddess from before the titans at his beck and call, having some deal with the Fates themselves among any number of other things that Chiron had a feeling were being kept from him.

In short, it would only raise more questions while giving him a headache.

“Why are you here then Percy?” Chiron asked, skipping straight to the point.

“Just a heads up on what's going on. Don't want to send an IM for obvious reasons.” He said, the teacher seeing his point. No need to let the gods know what they don't need to know.

“Yes, well, could you please make it brief? I have to finish correcting these papers, since your little... whatever you did to Clarisse and having me explain it took up an entire day.” He said, causing Percy to smile guiltily.

“Well, Medusa has been dealt with, and Echidna and the Chimera are now on our side.” Percy said, knowing that they were on 'his' side specifically. “We're on a train heading to Denver right now, and we should be there tomorrow afternoon at latest.” Percy said.

Chiron nodded, taking that in. They were making excellent progress, and Percy was doing well in his mission for the Fates. “Good, good. I want to know how you did it, but at the same time I know it isn't for me to know. Anything else I should know?”

“Not really.” Percy admitted, since there was nothing else Chiron needed to know. “But I also came by to check on things around camp. Have people started taking sides in this whole thing?”

Chiron sighed, rubbing his face. “Oh yes. I'll tell you Percy, It's starting to look like another Trojan war here. Athena has sided with Zeus, as usual in Olympian conflicts. Aphrodite, Ares and Apollo are siding with your father, seeing reason to know that you are not the culprit. And, as I'm sure you know, the kids tend to reflect upon their parents rivalries. And, I'm sorry Percy, but Poseidon told me to let the campers know that you are his son. Most other Olympians are neutral as of now, but it won't be long before they are forced to pick a side. Dionysus hasn't been back since you called your goddess from her prison, so I've been forced to run the camp entirely by myself during these pressing times.” He said, and Percy could see the strain taking its toll on him.

“Sorry, but the Fates have things worked out right now. Next I gotta meet Ares and do something stupid for him. Grab a shield or whatever.” Percy said. “I'll try to hurry though. Oh, and prepare for some new campers and several new faculty members.”

Chiron nodded. “Very well. I won't ask, since I don't want to have anything else loaded in my saddlebags for the moment. Now you should head back to your train.” Chiron said, making Percy nod. Then, as Chiron blinked, Percy was gone. He briefly wondered how Percy had done that, before dismissing it as he moved back to his desk. He had papers to grade after all, he had no time for stress induced hallucinations.

~ Back on the train

Percy reappeared in their suite on the train, hearing everyone snoring softly. Melum looked at him questioningly.

'Is what you planned still on tonight?' She asked silently, making him nod. He held out his hand, letting Melum take hold of it. In yet another instant, they were in the wilderness somewhere. There were lots of tree's and rocks and other nature-y things.

Percy reached into his pocket, a soft glow emitting from it as a flute materialized in his hand. It was a simple flute, made of brass. It was old, Percy knew, but it didn't look it. He had spent some of his time asleep practicing it, and he wanted to test it out in the real world.

He glanced at Melum, both of them nodding. Tonight they were working as one. Not as master and servant, but as two musicians.

Percy brought the flute up, putting his fingers in their proper place as he recalled the tune he wanted to play.

He noticed several nymphs were poking out of their trees, watching him curiously.

Without a word, Percy began to play the flute.

The nymphs found themselves being drawn out of their trees inexplicably, the movements not their own. They found the music pleasing though, and it had been a while since they had danced to such a wonderful tune. They let their bodies move to the music, letting themselves enjoy the melody.

And then Melum began to sing, tone perfectly matching Percy's playing. She sang a song without words, as was her way for most occasions, but she never really needed them. She could give voice to any number of emotions with just her voice alone, no words ever passing her lips.

Around her, everything began to feel an emotion. From rocks, to the trees, to the nymphs and the bugs. The birds that were awoken did not flee at the noise, and the wolves added their own chorus to the song.

The emotion was different for everything. Each individual had their own reaction to Melum's pure voice. The rocks cried, the tree's roared, the birds and bugs all rang out in harmony. The Nymphs themselves, however, felt the stirrings of feelings in their chests. Feelings of love and devotion for someone they didn't even know. Some thought that the two who were making the music were the servants of this mystery man, while others thought that the man was the one they felt for. Others still thought that it was Melum herself that these feelings were for.

Of course, as they continued to dance, they pieced it together that Percy was the man they were thinking about.

Percy paused his playing, regaining his breath. He took a sip of water, offering some to Melum.

The cheers and cries of joy echoed throughout the forest as all nymphs within a two mile radius heard the song, all coming to dance, all echoing the same thought. They wanted Percy to play, they wanted Melum to sing, though they didn't know who their entertainers were that night. They just knew that it felt right.

Percy smirked as several Nymphs tried to pull him into a crowd, saying not a word to them. When he brought the flute to his lips once more, they all hushed, waiting for him to start again.

And start again he did. A different tune this time. One that caused their feelings to grow by leaps and bounds as they danced, becoming something genuine, enhanced only by Melum singing the song of the music box, praising the Harem god in his glory.

And so it continued, into the night. By the morning, Percy had ensured that these nymphs would follow him, truly believing in him and his cause. They would spread word of what he did that night, singing praises of him for the rest of their lives. They had all understood Melum's song, well and truly. She didn't even try to force them to understand, it was just something that Percy helped along with his flute.

When Percy got back on the train, the sun was starting to rise. Everyone was still sleeping, and he wanted at least a few minutes rest. His lips were dry, his lungs sore. But it was worth it. He could feel more power flowing through him, making him less tired then he should have been. The Flute was in the Eronomicon once more, awaiting him should he need it again.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy awoke, being gently shaken by Medusa. “Wake up Percy. We're almost to Denver.”

Percy nodded, still groggy from his night out. He got up, grabbing his pack and heading to the dining car. He would rather face Kronos one on one at full power then go without a meal today. After all, he did have to deal with Ares, god of being an asshole.

~Later that day~

Percy and Co were sitting in a diner around dinner time, all in different groups. They had spent the day shopping for essentials, such as clothes, meals for on the road and other such things. Well, one could say shop, another could say Grand Larceny. Percy had been using his new shoes abilities in any and all thief skills to help save them some money. Besides, everything they took was way overpriced anyway. The shop keepers never noticed the items missing, even before their very eyes.

One would be inclined to say that it was the mist or divine intervention or something along those lines. But no, it was all Percy. He was just that good now.

Echidna and the Chimera had followed him around like lost puppies all day. The two had modeled clothes for him, something Percy found himself enjoying immensely while the Chimera was stumped about the concept of clothes in general. He was even tempted at one point to go into the changing room with them, but held off. He was sure not even the mist could hide him doing something like that, and he wasn't willing to pull out something too powerful and risk drawing attention to the group.

As they sat in the diner, Percy was watching the news.

“...Once again, we would like to bring attention to the apparent kidnapping of Sally Ugliano, age 32. Her son, Perseus Jackson, age 12, has been following some kind of trail, helped by a woman believed to be a private detective in his attempts. Surveillance footage from the Gateway Arch shows Perseus Jackson confronting an unknown woman as his traveling companion hurried to tell a park ranger to alert local authorities. Unfortunately, the camera's become damaged and they could not offer any assistance. Neither of them were found anywhere near the arch, and it is unknown what could have happened to them. This woman that Perseus confronted may be part of a kidnapping ring, as evidenced by the string of missing persons reports on the east coast. Any information on Perseus or this woman should be reported to the local authorities...”

Percy hunched down, making sure that none of the diner goers saw him.

“Wow Percy.” Annabeth said statistically in a hushed voice. “Following a kidnapping ring?” She asked teasingly.

“Hey, it was the only thing I could think of that might have made sense on such short notice.” Percy said. “But let's not focus on that at the moment. Food sounds good, and Ares should show up any minute.”

A nice looking waitress walked up to them, pen and pad in hand. “And what would you kids like.”

They placed their orders, and the waitress was about to leave when the building started to rumble.

“And show time.” Percy said, sitting straight up as everyone stopped their conversations.

A large Harley motorcycle pulled up to the diner, red headlight shining into the diner and making it look like everything was covered in blood. The gas tank was painted with flames, which looked like they were actually flames as they danced, which Percy wouldn't doubt. On either side of the gas tank, there was a shotgun holster, currently filled with the weapons. The seat was made of leather, but Percy could tell it was definitely human skin.

And riding atop the nature loving pacifist's nightmare was Ares, looking all big and bad. He wore a red muscle shirt, black jeans and a black leather duster, hunting knife strapped to his thigh. He wore red wraparound shades, as usual, and he wore his same battle scarred face.

Pity that.

When he walked into the diner, a hot wind blew through the place. People rose in their seats, looking like they were about to leap at the people they had been talking to not moments ago. Ares waved his hand at them, dismissing them from his battle aura and making them sit down.

He walked over like he owned the place, sliding in the booth as the waitress blinked before turning and heading to the kitchen.

Poor Grover was being squished against the wall, trying to be as far from the war god as possible.

“So you're old Seaweed's kid, huh?” He asked, looking at Percy with a wicked grin.

“Got it in one.” Percy said, faking surprise. “My, you're smarter then common sense would dictate.”

And Percy was immediately on Ares' bad side. Oh well.

“Listen you little brat.” Ares Growled. “I couldn't care if you were my half brother, you talk to me like that again and I'll send you right were you want to go in a casket.”

Behind Ares, Percy saw Melum stand up, Medusa grabbing her arm and making her sit down as the goddess almost tried to kill Ares.

Ares calmed down slightly, obviously trying his hardest to keep up his act to make Percy do this so he would have to give him the back-pack with the master bolt. “So where's your 'goddess' that caused so much trouble at that summer camp for cannon fodder? Decided to ditch you? Wouldn't be surprised.” He said, barking out in laughter like he made the funniest insult ever.

Percy rolled his eyes. “What do you want Ares? I got a quest I'm working on right now, and I don't need anything else working against me.”

Ares growled again, his eyes flaring up behind his glasses. “I know about your little quest. Besides, you've got loads of time till the summer solstice. You should feel honored that a god is directly giving you a quest. All you have to do is go to this little water park a mile west. Get something that I forgot there, bring it back and bam. You got yourself a ticket west. Tell you what, since I'm feeling so generous I'll tell you something about your mom as a bonus.” He said.

Percy watched as Ares disappeared, as if he had never been there. Grover moved to the side, glad he could breath again. Annabeth looked at Percy, wondering what they should do.

“Hey, I'm eating first. Ares comes after that.” Percy said with a shrug, watching as the waitress, easily in her early twenties, brought their food. Percy winked at her, making her blush as she hurried to escape his eyes.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Ares, god of Assholes

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“I do not like him Master.” Melum said heatedly.

“No one does Mel. No one does.” Percy said as they walked the mile to the water park. He could feel her anger at the war god becoming his, like everyone else. “Here's the plan. We go in and grab it. Simple as that. No dealing with Mechanical spiders or anything, no risking our lives for Ares stupid shield. Grover, remind me to beat it with a hammer or something.” Percy grumbled the last part.

“I don't think that would be a good idea Percy.” Grover said, looking around for Ares to jump out and do something.

“Sarcasm G-man.” Percy said.

It was silent as they continued their walk, though Grover was looking a tad uncomfortable.

“What's up Grover? You seem down.” Annabeth asked.

“Oh, it's nothing...” Grover said, biting back a sigh.

“C'mon Grover, tell us. It's nice to have your input on things.” Percy said, looking back at his long time friend.

Grover looked down, stopping. “Do you guys even need me on this quest? I mean, really?”

Annabeth turned to look at him. “What? Of course we need you on this quest!” She said.

Grover shook his head. “No, it doesn't seem like you do. You've got an incredibly powerful goddess, Medusa, a hell-hound, The Chimera and the Mother of all Monsters here!” He yelled. “What would you need me around for? Percy's got a whole bunch of stuff he can do, and Melum could do anything I can do, like, a million times better then I ever could!”

Grover looked on the verge of tears. “I’m just useless dead weight.”

Percy sighed, moving to Grover. He put his hand on his goat buddies shoulder. “Grover, you're forgetting two important things here. One, you're as important to this as anyone else. Two, and more importantly, you're my best friend. If there was any man I had to see all this crazy stuff with, It'd be you. You like my brother.” Percy said. “Now get those downer thoughts out of your head. We got a quest to do, and I can't have you slacking on me now.”

“What can I add to this quest Percy?” Grover asked.

Percy sighed. He was hoping to keep this bit of info to himself for a while. “You can help keep me grounded Grover. That book I have is going to turn me into a monster at some point, something that you might not be able to recognize. I won't look it, but I will. Maybe it's already happened and I’m better at hiding it then I thought I would be.”

“Why don't you just get rid of it or something? Burn it?” Grover asked.

“I can't Grover.” Percy said. “I'm no longer part of this universe. The book is the only thing keeping me here now, acting as an anchor. If I destroy it, I'll... I'll fade.” He said, making everyone besides Melum look at him in worry.

“What? Percy! Why didn't you tell me?” Annabeth asked.

“Because I didn't want you to worry.” He said, head down. “If I destroy the book, I'll be thrown from the universe into the void beyond. The only true way to kill a god. My boots? The only things remaining from a god who wasn't strong enough to withstand the trip between universes. He's dead and gone, not even someone believing in him would bring him back.”

He had seen the void, when he put on the shoes. He saw the very last moments of the gods life, saw the creeping nothingness attack. It was only thanks to him not actually feeling what the god felt that he had kept his mind. It was jarring though.

“It's true. I wasn't strong enough to make the trip myself. The Great Tome carried me within it, allowing me to pass through the void between universes.” Melum said, shivering.

“See? Sure, it's incredibly powerful, and making me into a god, but I'm doing something dangerous here. The very concept of 'Me' would cease to exist.” Percy said, looking at the ground. “Do you see why I can't destroy it now Grover?”

The Satyr nodded. “Y-yeah Percy. I do.”

“Then help me Grover. Help me in a way that Annabeth, Medusa or any women that fall to me can't.” Percy looked into Grover's eyes, his sea-green eyes looking haunted by the thought of the void. “Help me stay me.”

Grover nodded shakily. Losing his best friend like that? Something that was worse then fading? “Y-yeah Percy. I'll try.” He said as he shook.

Percy sighed in relief. “Thank you Grover. You have no Idea what that means to me. So never, ever say that you have nothing to contribute to the group. IF it weren't for you, I probably would have already gone crazy with power. I would have said 'fuck this quest' and done my own thing. I'll tell you now Grover, I will make sure that you get your own happy ending to this crazy thing called life.” He said wholeheartedly. He meant it too. If Grover wasn’t there, he would have likely snapped with all the sexual tension.

It had only been four day since he started the quest too...

“Now come on, we need to do something Ares is to much of a pussy to do himself.” Percy said, picking his own spirits up. “And Grover, I think I should introduce you to a certain Nymph sooner then you normally would have met her. It'll have to wait until we got back to camp though.”

Grover nodded... but he didn't know how to feel about that.

~Later, back at the diner

Percy threw the shield at Ares, who caught it effortlessly.

“Surprised you survived.” Ares said, tossing Percy a back pack. “Here you go. Some extra supplies for your trip. And a ride west.” He said, pointing at a large truck. “Oh, and before I forget, I want to say that-”

“My mom's not dead. I know.” Percy interrupted. “Whenever someone dies in anything dealing with you guys and monsters, it's always a bloody and horrible death. And it's pretty evident, since only gods can do the whole glowing sparkle thing that a god took her. Besides, Hades said as much when he charged into camp demanding that I bring back his helm.”

“Corpse breath did that?” Ares asked with a whistle. “Heard about that from the horse man when he had to come explain what had happened at that mud pit. Didn't believe it until now though. Man little cousin, you got everyone hating you.” Ares said with a chuckle, getting on his Harley. “See you around, if you live that long.”

Ares tore off into the distance, leaving a trail of red smoke and a laugh echoing into the distance.

“Man, I can't wait to run him through.” Percy said. “Oh well, we got what we need from him. Grover, me and you are going to hop in the truck. Annabeth, I'm going to take you and the others to Vegas Directly. Wait for us outside the lotus hotel and casino.”

“Why are we going there Percy?” Annabeth asked warily. She didn't want to lose any time to that place.

“We're going to pull two campers out of there a few years early.” Percy said with a smirk.

“You mean-”

“Yeah, I do. Besides, a bargaining chip with Hades couldn't hurt. He seems more aggressive here then last time.” Percy said. “Now hold on.”

Grover watched as Percy vanished and reappeared three times, taking two to three girls with him each time. When He appeared for a fourth time, Percy looked at Grover. “Let's move. Despite what it says on the truck, It's not very kind to animals.” Percy said, hopping in the trailer.

But not before looking back into the diner, seeing their waitress holding onto a rose, blushing at him and waving good bye.

~Later, down the freeway

The truck pulled over to the side of the road. Like, way over. A zebra and an Albino lion burst out of the trailer, both running off into the wilderness.

Two men slipped out of the cab of the trailer, something horrible and irrevocable done to them in revenge for what they had done to the animals. One dose of Bestial lust seal each, highest setting. Show them what it was like to be an animal, and what they would do would cause for them to be caged up like wild animals.

Now that was justice, Harem god style.

“Let's go Grover. I think we did our good deed for the day.” Percy said, putting a hand on Grover's shoulder. In the blink of an eye, they were in Vegas, outside the Lotus Eater's new pad.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Annabeth waved over to them, the other women following behind her as she jogged towards them. “How'd it go?” She asked.

“Just fine.” Percy said. “But enough about that. Medusa, you're with me. Everyone else, just mill around and try not to get mugged or mistaken for a hooker.”

Medusa seemed uneasy though. “Are you sure this is the place Percy? Even monsters are weary of the Lotus Eaters.”

Percy pulled her hand into his, calming her down. “Don't worry. We'll be fine. Besides, this will be the best time to see if you got better at using your curse as an ability.” He said, pulling her in.

The doorman smiled at them as they walked in, welcoming them and hoping they enjoyed their stay. Percy made his way to the front desk, Medusa in tow. He rang the bell, getting the attention of someone who looked like a manager.

“Hello, and welcome to the Lotus Hotel and Casino. Please enjoy your stay.” He said, holding out two cards.

Medusa was looking at them, trying to fight the urge to take one.

“No thanks. We're here to pick up our friends.” Percy said. “They're siblings. Bianca and Nico Di Angelo.”

The man looked at Percy, that smile never leaving his face. “Very well, I shall have someone find your friends. But, while you wait, why don't you relax for a bit. I insist.”

Medusa reached for a card, but Percy grabbed her hand. “No, I insist you find them now. Trust me, I'm not messing around.”

The mans smile never left his face as he pushed the cards closer to them. “But I insis-”

“Medusa, now!” Percy yelled.

Instantly, Medusa's eyes shone an eerie purple and her hair floated up with a life of its own. Percy could hear the faint hissing of snakes in the air.

The Lotus eater's smile finally fell as he was turned to stone, cards and all. Percy took Riptide out, uncapping it and smashing his stone face with the hilt of the sword. Capping it, Percy shook Medusa, snapping her out of a trance. Once the man had turned to stone, her stone gaze had stopped itself.

“Oh? Percy, what just happened?” Medusa asked, rubbing her head.

“Everything's Fine Medusa. You did good.” Percy said, ringing the bell again.

“Hello, and welcome to the-” The man stopped himself, looking at the destroyed statue of his buddy.

“Look, you will bring Bianca and Nico Di Angelo here now, or you'll end up like him. Only in tinier pieces.” Percy said glaring. He could almost feel time start to fluctuate.

“Of course sir.” The new manager said, hurrying away. In mere minutes, he was back, followed by two kids.

“Here they are sir. I trust it is to take them to see their father?”

“In a way.” Percy said. “Hello you two. I'm your cousin Perseus, but everyone calls me Percy.” He said, smiling at the two in a way he hoped inspired confidence and trust.

Nico, who was shorter then Percy remembered, smiled a toothy grin. “Hello, I'm Nico. Do you know about Mythomagic?”

Behind him, Bianca sighed silently, but smiled at him nonetheless. “Nice to meet you. I'm Bianca. Please excuse my brother, he's addicted to that game.”

Percy waved it off. “Nah, It's okay. Kids gotta have something to occupy his time. Now let's go.”

“Whose the lady?” Nico asked suddenly, pointing at Medusa.

“Nico, don't be rude.” Bianca said, tapping him on the back of his head.

“No, It's alright.” Medusa said. “I'm your Aunt Em. Nice to meet you two.” She said with a smile.

Bianca gave her a skeptical look as they walked. “You don't look related to us at all.”

“Married into the family Dear. Now come along.” She said, ushering them out the doors.

“Ah, fresh air. And it's still night time!” Percy said. He was happy to be out of that place.

“Percy!” Annabeth called, running over to him.

“Hey Annabeth.” Percy said, hugging her. “How long were we gone?”

“Just over an hour. But we need to get out of here soon. People have been mistaking the older women for hookers, which I'm blaming you for by the way, and the Chimera broke two peoples hands when they tried to touch her.”

Percy growled slightly, his eyes flashing brightly. “Good. Though she might have been feeling my frustration with the hotel's service.”

Percy pulled away as Medusa maneuvered the two newest people of the group over to them.

Bianca Blushed, seeing the other women of the group, as well as having a look of disbelief on her face. “Wha-”

“It'll be explained later. Hold on, and close your eyes.” Percy said, placing a hand on both children of Hades' shoulder's.

“What are you-” Bianca said, though she almost threw up as everything about her view of reality shifted.

Literally.

When she looked around, she was in a big house, and not on the streets of Vegas.

“Chiron, are you here!” Percy called out. Soon the clopping of hooves sounded throughout the house.

“Percy, is that you again?” An old, but powerful voice sounded behind her.

When Bianca turned around, it took everything she had to not scream in absolute terror.

A centaur was standing above her!

“Cool...” Nico said, turning to look at the new arrival.

“Hey Chiron. Look, I'm going to be frank here.” Percy stopped. “Man, that isn't even funny when I've seen how things were going to go. Anyway, these are the new campers I was telling you about. With the group we got right now, I can't look after them. I need you to explain to them the basics, being demigods and all that. If you can't, have Clarisse do it, but tell her I said be nice to the Newbies. Our group is going to take a few days getting to Hollywood, so if you could get the other campers used to them before the cat gets out of the bag of who their father is that would be great.”

Chiron could already feel a headache coming on. “Very well Percy. I'll see what I can do.” He said with a sigh.

“Thanks Chiron. Well, I gotta get back to Vegas. Stop anymore idiots from trying to feel up the chimera.”

Chiron gave Percy a look, that nowadays would be called 'a total WTF look.' He really wanted to know know, but at the same time the thought horrified him.

“I'll explain later. Bye you two, be good now you hear?” He said, acting like an uncle or something. “Oh, and Chiron, whatever you do, keep them away from Luke. I cannot stress that enough. In fact, please don't let anyone know that they're here, not even the king of paranoia.” Percy said, nothing but seriousness in his tone.

Chiron nodded, since it seemed Percy only talked like that when it was something that could end the entire world. “Very well Percy. Anything else to report?”

“Nope.” Percy said. “later.”

Chiron blinked and Percy was gone again, but the two other children were not. So that means that when he talked to Percy that night, it wasn't a hallucination.

Chiron looked at the shaking and pale girl who looked like she was going to pass out. “I should get the smelling salts ready.” He said with a sigh, just in the event that it did happen. “Call Clarisse here too. Might make the transition easier.” He said.

He felt something pull at his tunic hem. He looked down to see Nico looking at him in wonder. “Are you really a centaur?”

Chiron put a hand to his head. It was going to be a long few days. The youngest he ever dealt with was ten. Annabeth was a special case, since she acted like she was at least thirteen when she was seven, not to mention her growing up on the streets for as long as she did. Even then, most freaked out at the fact that the Greek myths were true...

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy appeared outside the casino once again, and was greeted with a scene that made his blood boil.

Several men, obviously drunk on both alcohol and the mood of Vegas, were circling the women like vultures.

“C'mon baaby.” One of them said, trying to look classy as he nearly swayed on his feet. “I can pay you really~ good to keep me company.” He said, lecherous grin on his face.

“For the last time, we said no!” Medusa said, glaring at him. She was tempted to use her glare on him, she really was. “We're not prostitutes you drunken idiot!”

One of the other ones laughed, reaching a hand out to grab Melum's dress which the goddess slapped away. “In these kinds of outfits? Nah, I think you're just playing hard to get.” He said, fumbling for his wallet. “Don't worry, we got the money for your services.”

“Are you worse then a fool?” Melum asked, her eyes sparkling dangerously. “Leave now. My patience wears thin.”

“Don't be like that.” Yet another said. He smelled the strongest, most likely being the drunkest of them. “This short one looks quiet nice though.” He said, reaching for Annabeth. “Always did love blonds.”

Instantly his hand was caught by the Chimera. There was a sharp cracking sound, then a crushing noise, and then the man began to scream. Any and all bones in his hand were not only shattered, but crushed to dust. His hand was bleeding profusely.

“No touch.” The Chimera growled. “Go now.”

Obviously the other men were drunk beyond reasoning though. They ignored their screaming friend, though passerby's did not. Several people screamed, and at least one called an ambulance. The drunken men did not move away though, but one did sneer at them.

Percy had more then half a mind to have the Chimera just kill them. Dark? Yes, but right now he didn't care. That one man was lucky he only had his hand crushed beyond repair. No one was going to touch Annabeth, or any of the women for that matter.

“Well, we tried the easy way.” He said, words still slurred. “Now listen to me you slut.” He said, raising a hand to smack Medusa.

Only to have a sharp pain go through his chest, and then nothing.

Percy pulled Riptide out of the man. One by one, he saw all the bonds the man had forged dissipate as blood pooled beneath him. Co-workers, family, friends, acquaintances, even strangers he had passed by on a walk, anything linking him to anybody was gone.

Percy couldn't feel bad for what he had done, and that was his own thought. Not the power of one sword, merged with Riptide.

No, that power only made everyone else look down at the corpse. No one screamed, no one was shocked or scared or horrified. They felt nothing for the man they had seen murdered. Nothing at all. They couldn't care less that he had died before their eyes.

Such was the power of the Severer. To cut the bonds between people, leaving not one trace of any emotion between those whose ties it cut. And that was why no one cared at all. They couldn't care.

They couldn't even say 'wow, he deserved that.' or 'man, that guy was an asshole.' They felt nothing. They didn't care that he was murdered.

Even if he lived, any wife or children he had wouldn't have cared.

And neither would he. He wouldn't have cared either, had he survived.

The only one it didn't effect, couldn't effect, was Percy.

He would probably feel bad later, feel the blood on his hand. Mortal blood, human blood.

But it wouldn't weigh against him if he stood before the judges of the dead. They wouldn't care either.

Percy held his sword up to the other guy's throat. “Go. Now.” He growled out.

It seemed as though he finally got the message, drunk as he was. He backed away in fear of the weapon, but not in fear that it had just killed. No, as far as he cared he would have been the first victim to a deranged kid. He turned and ran, stumbling in his drunken attempt at fleeing.

Percy capped Riptide, taking a breath to try and calm himself. The sounds of sirens were getting closer, and the man whose hand was as good as gone was still screaming, begging for the pain to end.

“Let's get out of here.” Percy said, moving to the center of the group. “Everyone grab hold of me.” He said, wrapping Annabeth into a protective hug.

Everyone did, eager to get away from the city. Too much hassle.

In an instant, they were all in Hollywood.

“We're finding a hotel.” Percy said, tone brooking no arguments. He wanted some time to rest before heading down to the Underworld. It was only the first after all, so they still had twenty days until the solstice.

Everyone nodded. They could all tell Percy was on edge. The Chimera made this more obvious since she seemed to reflect Percy mood a lot. She was agitated, which was easy to tell on her. She wasn't good at hiding emotions after all. Her fur ruffled up, and she let out a menacing growl as her tail started to shake, the occasional hiss passing her lips.

For the next hour, they all looked around for a decent hotel, far enough from the underworld to relax in. To finally rest in.

~The next night

Percy and Co. had found a Best Western hotel, decent priced and everything. Percy had payed for three rooms. Echidna, the Chimera and Peísma (Footnote Greek for Pet, spelled in English), the hell-hound that Percy finally decided on a name for, would share a room. Melum and Medusa in another, with Percy, Annabeth and Grover in the final one.

Percy gave strict orders to Peísma to be on her best behavior. If he had complaints from hotel staff that she had destroyed the room or attacked them... well, Percy left that hanging in the air. He was still mad about Vegas, incredibly so. But he was also angry at himself, and he felt sick as well.

He had killed someone. An actual person. A mortal. They weren't just going to reform, like monsters. And despite being drunk, they probably didn't deserve it.

But he would never know. Not now anyway.

No one would grieve for him. No one would care that he died. Hell, no one would celebrate his death even. He was forgotten now. Nothing connected him to life anymore.

Percy had, essentially, doomed the man to fade.

He felt bile rise in his throat.

He wanted to reassure himself that they were going to try and take it too far, but he just couldn't. He couldn't honestly tell himself that they deserved it, even if one of them had tried to take Annabeth, tried to hit Medusa.

When he saw their actions though, how they were acting towards the women, he felt a surge of anger. More angry then he ever had in his life, he acted without thinking first.

That made him no better then Ares.

Beside him, laying on the bed, Annabeth turned on her side. She was watching as Percy shifted between anger and guilt, the occasional sickly grimace. She had a feeling as to what was bothering him, and he needed to talk about it.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Percy?” She asked gently, placing her hand on his shoulder.

“Am I a monster Annabeth?” He asked suddenly.

Annabeth shook her head, not taken aback by the question. “No Percy, you're not a monster.”

“I killed someone Annabeth. They're dead because of me.” Percy said, looking up at the ceiling still.

She shook her head again. “Yes, but that's not the point. I can't feel anything for what he tried to do, something I know you had a hand in, but I know what he was going to do. You did it to Protect Medusa, protect us. Even if we can do it ourselves, you wanted to protect us. What do you think he would have done to Medusa if she had been by herself? He would have put her through what happened to her with your father.” Annabeth told him. “The other guys were going to do the same thing if they couldn't have gotten us to go along with them, they would have just forced us. The fact of the matter was that despite us being able to protect ourselves, you did it nonetheless. I don't think we could ever thank you enough for that.” She said, kissing him. “I can't say I know how it feels to kill someone, and I hope I never know either. But don't ever think that You're a monster for protecting people. That's not like you.”

Percy turned to look at her. Her hair was down, and she was in laying under the blanket. She had a white tank-top on, Percy could tell. The moonlight shone on her through the window, the waning moon shining off her skin. It danced in her hair, twinkling in her eyes.

Percy could see as she aged ever so slightly, looking closer to thirteen or fourteen now. Her breasts had started to grow, since she had gotten a bra when they were in Denver. The seal that brought her back was working well at least.

He spread the rumor that I betrayed you, that my sisters betrayed you. It wasn't until Percy freed me from your curse, and his, that I have been able to feel happy again. For years, I had no one to keep me company but my statues.”

She began to laugh, which was a little off-putting given the situation. “It seems that your actions have come to bite you in the end though, Athena. The fates have decided that the current rule is lacking. The gods break sacred promises and their unjust actions are being rectified. They ready for war. War they could avoid, if they could stop being so petty. Zeus is still powerful enough to rule, but he would rather have everyone fear him and the power of the Master bolt. Such a shame to see Olympus fall so far.”

Athena renewed her struggle's, trying to break free. She couldn't even appear in one of her temples, she was so weak. Whatever the goddess had done to her, she was too weak to truly fight.

“But that doesn't concern you anymore, Athena.” Percy said, making Melum help Medusa, the latter of which had burst into a fit of psychotic laughter, tears still flowing down her face. It was incredibly unsettling. Percy made a drawing motion above the Eronomicon. A small light shown from the book, before Percy grabbed something from the air. “Not after tonight.” He said, vanishing from her sight.

But, as she watched, those lights became images. Images from her eyes, making her remember every things she had ever done. She saw everything with perfect clarity, it was like she was relieving her immortal life.

That included all the travesties she had personally caused. They began showing up faster and faster, she heard the screams louder and louder, the people she killed or tormented in her anger. The pride that she had subjugated other to, using them to release her anger. She saw the night with Medusa and Poseidon in perfect clarity, heard their begging to drive Poseidon away, their pleads to help them.

She saw the contest with Arachne, who was by far the better weaver then Athena. But Athena never wanted people to know that, so she facilitated the events that made Arachne kill herself. Her only pity, if it could have been called that, was to turn the woman into a spider, so she and her children could weave for all eternity.

All this and more flashed before her eyes. Not all bad, since she had seen some good things there as well.

Athena could feel the strain on her mind. She... hadn't done all that stuff... had she? It all began to weigh down on her. Had... she really been such a horrible god?

Athena screamed, the lights ending.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
She was panting, the strain almost breaking her. But she had pulled through. But she saw everything. She remembered everything. Every single thing she ever did, she remembered.

And she felt horrible for it. The weight of her mind would not go away. It already started gnawing at her. Corroding any sense of what she should do anymore. What was right? What was wrong? Had she been living a lie for so long, being one of the oppressors, that she had lost sight of what was true justice?

What was Justice anymore?

Unbidden, tears sprang to her eyes. Not from the pain. No, she deserved that. She deserved all the pain she had ever dealt a thousand-fold.

She looked at Medusa, still laughing. Had she broken the poor woman, one of those she promised to protect in exchange for worship? It seemed to her that she had. The roots around her mouth had moved, allowing her to speak.

“How?” She asked, her throat suddenly dry, her voice cracking as she held back sobs. No, she couldn't cry. She didn't deserve to cry.

“Excuse me?” Percy asked, looking concerned for Medusa. He was seriously thinking of leaving Athena and taking her to a hospital to have her hand checked out. He wasn't any good with medicine, even now.

“How do I make up for what I've done?” She asked. “Please, I beg of you. Tell me!”

“That's up for you to decide.” Percy said, walking away from her. He placed his hand on Medusa's shoulder, kneeling down and pulling her into a hug. Her laughing cracked, breaking into sobs. “Mel, keep an eye on her. I'll be right back.” Percy said, vanishing without even seeing if Melum would protest.

Melum did as told, making sure that Athena didn't try to escape. She could have left though, Since Athena didn't even budge an inch. Not even a twitch of a finger.

It took ten minutes for Percy to return, and when he was he wasn't happy. “I've got Medusa resting in a hospital right now. They're going to try and fix her arm, and they gave her something for hysterics.” He said, his eyes glowing with anger. “What are you going to do, Athena? Are you going to run to Olympus if I let you loose? Tell Zeus that someone opposes his regime, and is gunning to take him down? Are you going to let the guilt weigh down on you for the rest of your life? And all three of us here know that forever is a long time.” Percy said.

He was genuinely pissed. Before, with Vegas, he was angry. This time he was absolutely livid, and would probably have murdered someone if they so much as looked at him funny. He was pretty sure a few doctors and nurses would be having nightmares for a long time.

It was silent for a while, Percy watching Athena, waiting for an answer.

“Please. Let me serve you.” Athena said quietly, looking down at the ground with hollow eyes.

“And why should I do that?” Percy asked. He was tempted to leave the goddess there, feeling the guilt. And he Knew what he had done to her with the item from the Eronomicon!

“Please, I beg of you! I know it won't be enough to make up for all I've done. Nothing will. But please, let me try!” Athena said, begging him. “I will do all you ask of me. I will try to atone for all I've done, even if I have to betray my father!” Her voice grew wild, her normal composure meaningless now. “I will do all you say for the rest of my eternal life! An eternity of servitude, that is all I deserve! For everything I caused, or did not stop when I could have!” Tears were falling from her eyes now. “Please! Let me try to atone!”

She was openly weeping now, begging, pleading to let her try and make up all for all she had done.

Percy grimaced. 'Damn it. I still can't stand seeing a woman cry.' He said, mentally cursing herself. He walked up to Athena, who looked at him with hopeful eyes. “Fine. If you want to serve me, then I'll hold you to that.”

Athena nodded earnestly. “Anything! I will Serve faithfully! I will never question anything you tell me to do!” She said, taking on a fevered tone. “I deserve nothing more! I will act as I always have, a puppet! A loyal dog! I will be your sword and your shield! I will do anything for you! Anything!”

Percy nodded, absently wondering if he was turning more and more into something like his Father. “Very well Athena. I accept your servitude. It shall be known that you are trying to atone for your actions.” Percy said. “Melum, if you would.” He said, gesturing at the roots.

She nodded, merely gesturing at the plants. They seemed to respond, as if awaiting her orders. The roots unwound from around Athena, sinking deep into the ground.

Percy didn't know how she did that, honestly.

Athena fell to the ground, landing on her hands and knees. She was breathing hard, tears still falling from her face. “Thank you... for allowing me to atone...” She said, her voice choked with sobs.

Percy grimaced. Maybe at Athena, maybe at himself. He didn't know. But he knew one thing, well and true.

The Proud Goddess Athena was Broken.

~ The next day

Percy woke in Melum's bed. She had been so loyal, so faithful. She had deserved a reward.

It had been a bit of a hassle to get her to accept a reward from him though. She tried to deny it, saying that she existed to serve him. Even if it was true, Percy still wanted her to know he valued her.

All she asked was that he lay with her for the rest of the night.

Nothing sexual, unless he wanted it. Just for him to lay there, holding her.

Percy had laid there, holding her tightly against him. Her nude frame pulled against his own, and Percy couldn't find himself complaining much about her form, no matter how much she protested that she wasn't good enough, not beautiful enough.

He had lain there until she had fallen asleep, her head resting on his chest. She had a content smile on her face, sleeping the best she ever had.

Athena was, hopefully, back on Olympus, tell Zeus that she still couldn't find the master bolt. She had been given orders to act naturally, act loyal to Zeus, until the time was right. She was to keep tabs on Olympus for him though, if the gods started to act before the right time.

Percy glanced at the clock, broken from his memories of the previous night. He would go see if Medusa was feeling any better today. He hoped she could still speak Greek, since it was a Greek hospital he had taken her to.

The clock read 9:13 A.M.

It seemed he needed less and less sleep as well, as his power increased.

Percy sighed. He didn't want to move from his spot. Melum was warm. Strangely so. Must have been a godly thing.

But, alas, he had things to do today.

He gently moved from the bed, Melum moaning softly at his missing warmth.

Percy moved to his room, trying out shadow-walking for the first time. It was...strange, to say the least. It was very cold, and obviously very dark. He couldn't shake the feeling that something was watching him, though he had no fear for it.

He appeared in the bathroom, the light's off, swathing the place in darkness. He walked out, hearing both Grover and Annabeth still snoring. He gently kissed Annabeth, grabbing the Master bolt Backpack and vanishing. He had work to do.

“Fine, fine. Just give me a second.” She said, waving dismissively at him. She floated over to the backpack, kind of just phasing into it. “Ah, that's better.”

When she appeared again, she looked like the skimpiest hiker ever. She had on short shorts that could qualify as panties, and nothing more then a bra. She had on hiking boots and gloves, as well as a cowboy hat. Her hair was brown, in a long ponytail.

Percy nodded, shaking his head. “Sorry, didn't mean to bark at you. I'll go relax or something.”

She huffed. “Yeah, well, you better. I don't have to take you yelling at me for just letting you know what's going on.”

Percy only nodded, leaving the chamber.

~Back on Earth.

Percy appeared in his room with Annabeth and Grover. He got dressed, after seeing that he hadn't even been gone for an hour.

Time to see Medusa.

He vanished, appearing in the Greek hospital.

“Hello, do you have the room with my aunt?” He asked, walking up to the receptions desk, effortlessly speaking Greek.

“Name?” The lady asked, typing on computer.

“Her name is Emma, I brought her in last night with the broken wrist?”

“Floor 3, room 316.” She said, not even looking at Percy.

“Thanks.” Percy said, walking to the elevator.

After looking around for a bit, Percy found the right room. He knocked on the door, getting a strangled “Come in.”

He opened the door, seeing Medusa laying in her bed. She was covered in a hospital gown, looking blankly up at the ceiling.

“Hello 'aunty Em'.” He said, using her old alias for her store.

She instantly brightened, smiling at him. “Oh Hello Percy. Good morning.” She said, smiling. She waved with a cast on her arm.

“How are you feeling?” Percy asked, sitting in the bedside chair.

“Much better, thank you. The doctors and nurses made sure that I was feeling well after giving me this cast. I felt much better when I woke up, I know that.”

Percy nodded, smiling at her. “I'll bet. Getting that much pent up emotion our of your system would be kind of draining.”

Medusa chuckled weakly. “You have no idea.” She said, enjoying his presence. “So, how's our 'friend'?” She asked.

“Oh, she's fine.” Percy said. “She won't be bothering anyone else. She saw the error of her ways.”

Medusa smiled, almost evilly. “Good, good. I'm glad she knows what she put others through.”

“Yeah, I guess I would.” Percy said. “And I should pay upfront, since I doubt they would find the address of Olympus.”

Diamonds, emeralds, rubies, sapphires, and many, many more. The gems were normally for enchanting with a ritual or seal, or if he wanted to experiment to try and create a new item himself that he could keep in the Eronomicon.

But it wouldn't hurt, taking a few out to pay for a hospital bill.

“I'll be right back.” Percy said. “Gotta get the money to pay the hospital bill.”

Medusa smiled. “Alright then. Hurry back.” She said, watching as he disappeared. She settled in, waiting for him to return.
