1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy exhaled, letting all tension flow from his body. He closed his eyes, raising his arms, palms pointing down to the ground. He focused, mentally pulling on something. The eyes on his gloves glowed sinisterly.

Instantly, four tunnels of rock exploded out of the ground. They were large enough for fully grown people to easily jump into and climb out of.

'Minions, to me!' Percy called mentally.

'Yes sire.' A smooth, feminine voice replied. 'Alright you sorry lot! Get out there!' It shouted, the sounds of large amounts of women clamoring in glee.

Percy stepped back from the tunnels as the ground started rumbling. It got worse and worse each passing second, the sounds of foot steps hitting the ground.

“Wehe! Yahoo! Yeah!” And other sounds of excitement rang out, as women literally launched out of the tunnels, landing and immediately running towards Percy.

The flow just wouldn't stop, more and more women flying out of the tunnels and running, bowing eagerly before him.

“Master!” They said as each of them bowed down. Looking at it, there seemed to be four groups of similar women, like four women cloned endlessly.

The first group were all blonds, all having brown eyes that were dull, lacking much in the way of intelligence. They all wore armor, though it was revealing at places where it wasn't vital they cover up. They all wielded some type of weapon, though it was mainly swords and maces, though a few also had axes and flails.

The second group were all red heads, with large ram-like horns and blazing yellow eyes. They wore bikini's, showing off their almost always flushed skin. Their hands danced with flames, and they seemed to be a bit more intelligent then the blondes. They had the classic devil tales, which flickered with flames as well, being the only group that had the extra appendage.

The third group were possibly the skimpiest ninja ever. They all had green eyes, with black hair. Their hands had long, sharp claws where their nails should have been. They seemed to blend in though, their forms becoming see-through every second. They had shifty eyes, and a gaze that seemed to always look for a weakness, showing that they were good at knowing when to strike.

The last group had women in robes, hiding most of their bodies. Their eyes were blue, but they didn't seem all there. But Percy knew they were by no means stupid. Their lips constantly moved, speaking incantations rapidly, their hands twitching every other second or so.

All in all, Percy had the start of a small army. Easily 150 of each group, at the least.

“Alright, Listen up!” Percy said, making them all stand at attention. Even the robed ones ceased their chanting to focus on him, their eyes turning sharp, easily the most intelligent of the four groups. “I want four equal groups to go around and stop the fighting! Stop the fires if you can! I want no killing, but be as brutal as necessary!” He commanded. He got whoops of joy, cheering him. “If you find a Half man, Half horse creature, tell him that Perseus would like to speak with him! Now go!”

In a wave, the women split into groups at the robed one's commands, before rushing to follow the orders they had been given. As they ran, amidst the psychotic laughter and screams of joy, there was a singular cry that sounded the most.

“For the Overlord!”

Percy sat on the porch, watching as the horde of, somehow terrifying, women charged. The Ares campers fumbling for their weapons before the waves ran over them, speaking and yelling in a horrifying frenzy. They were knocked out, possibly a few broken bones, as they were stripped of anything the women thought they could use.

“I love the minions.” He said, grinning viciously. “Work well, and are quite the crowd control.”

'Indeed, sire.' The smooth female voice said. 'Quite the nasty little bunch, those women. And I must say, they are much better then those imp forms they had previously.'

“Yeah yeah.” Percy said, waving to the invisible voice. “Anyway, have you figured out a place for a new 'dark tower' yet?” Percy asked.

'No sire, not yet. We don't know the areas around here that well. I could send a few Succubi around and scout if you desire.'

Percy thought on that, watching as the red headed women absorbed the fire from the burning buildings. 'Do it, but on strict orders not to attack anyone. I swear, if another tries to drain someone during a mission...'

'As you command sire.' The voice said. 'They should be heading out right... now.'

More women burst from the ground, these ones different from the minions. First of all, these ones could fly, as evidenced by their demonic wings. They had normal skin, being a light pink and black hair. If not for the wings, they could have passed as human. They wore a black corset, which only made their impressive bust seem larger, along with garter straps which held up thigh length stockings. They also sported a ribbon collar choker, each one a different color to differentiate between the otherwise clones.

The succubi bowed, taking off to search for a suitable area for their new abode.

'Good. I hope that they don't get shot down.' Percy thought.

'You know as well as I do sire that that won't happen.' The voice said.

'Ah, but you forget Murphy's law.' Percy replied, teasingly.

'Ah, right. Forgive me sire.' The voice said.

'Calm down. You won't end up like that rat Gnarl, or that sniveling jester.' Percy said, thinking back on the traitorous old minions. One did not betray Perseus Jackson so easily. Not anymore.

Those thrice damned 'heroes', as they liked to call themselves. Utter disgraces to the term, that's what they were.

'Thank you sire.' The voice said, relieved. 'You truly are more forgiving then Lady Lilith.'

'Yeah yeah. Don't let her hear you say that though.' Percy said. 'She would- Wait, gotta go. The centaur is here.'

Percy stood up, Chiron approaching with his bow drawn. “Percy? Is that you.” He asked warily, arrow knocked on the string.

“Long time no see Chiron.” Percy said, waving at him with a smirk.

Chiron looked at Percy suspiciously. “Are you here to retrieve that item you left me?”

“Chiron, don't even try to pull that on me.” Percy said, looking the centaur dead in the eye. “Where are Nico and Bianca?”

Chiron sighed. “Oh, it is you Percy. Sorry, but you can't blame a person for being cautious. They're inside the big house, in the basement. It was the safest place for them right now, and there was nowhere else for them to go.” Chiron said, nodding back into the house. “But Percy, what happened to you?”

“No time to explain Chiron. And before you ask, yes I did have something to do with the army of women that are attacking the camp. Just to let you know, they're... friendly. Just make sure to keep them from having anything sweet, or magical. Makes them weird and dangerous. Oh, and the flying women in skimpy clothing too. Don't shoot them down.” Percy said, walking back into the Big house.

Chiron just stood there, looking at where Percy had been. His headaches were becoming more and more frequent...

Percy walked with a whistle, passing by the lounge/meeting room, waving at Seymour as he walked by. He walked into the kitchen, ignoring the squawks from the Harpies. He opened up the basement door, walking down the steps. His eyes glowed in the dark, piercing though it.

He looked around the basement. He saw Bianca, her aura showing up bright in the dark. Above her read the words 'Give her a family and non-brotherly love.'

'Now where's Nico?' He asked, making his way to Bianca.

Only to feel something bounce off his side, a blade by the feel of it.

Percy reached down, grabbing the arm of Nico. “Settle down Cousin. It's me, Percy.” He said. “Look, I came to pick you up. We're really going to see your father this time, I swear.”

“Percy?” Bianca's voice rang out. Her form stood up, running to him and Nico. She wrapped her arms around him. “Percy!” She said, hugging him. “Thank god... Er... the gods that you're here!” She said, before thwaping him alongside the head. “You're a jerk! Leaving us here for almost a month!”

“Hey, look, I'm sorry.” He said, totally unaffected by her attack to his skull. It barely even reached, the girl having to stand on her toes to get a good solid hit. “But it was either that, or not have enough time to explain everything about being a Demigod. Or train you, or anything else for that matter. But look, we need to get going. I'm really going to take you to your father this time. I promise you that. Besides, there's kind of a war going on up top.” He said. “Both of you, close your eyes. This is going to get weird.” He said.

He waited a minute for them to comply, when he kicked off from the ground.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Minions, charge!

choices: Other business to attend on the river of the dead
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Good, good. Now, I'll be back in a few minutes. Going to go pick up my cousins from camp. I think it's time they met their father.” Percy said, vanishing...

Only to reappear a second later with two new people.

“Hey guys, miss me?” He asked with a knowing grin.

“Percy, you were only gone for a second.” Annabeth said.

“Wait, let me guess.” Grover said. “Your boots also allow you to travel through time.” He said, completely neutral in tone.

“Got it in one, G.” Percy said, making Grover face-palm. “Come on, you walked into that one.” He said, making Grover nod with a sigh.

Percy looked down at Nico and Bianca. “What, no gasps? No 'He's a satyr?' or anything?” Percy asked.

“No, the shock wore off after the first week.” Bianca said.

“Darn.” Percy said, snapping his fingers. “But you're not even going to ask why I've changed so much?” He asked, making Bianca give him a flat look.

“In the last two weeks, I've been thrown into a whole new world where anything I thought was real and fake has blurred.” She said. “I could probably rationalize anything anymore.”

“Point.” Percy said. If only she knew what was beyond. well, everything.

“Can we go now?” Grover asked. “Olympus is on the verge of war you know.”

“Yeah, you should see what I'm about to unleash on the camp to quell the fighting.” Percy said. “Let's go.”

He walked into DOA recording studios, everyone else following him.

The lobby was crowded as ever, the souls of the departed waiting for their chance to ride the ferry. Muzak (Actually spelled in the book, so don't correct) played on hidden speakers. Everything about the place seemed dead, which was fitting.

Percy walked up to the raised Podium where the ferry man sat.

“Yeah? What do you want?” Charon asked, putting down the obituary section of the news paper.

“Look, we want passage across the river. I know you're the ferryman, Charon.” Percy said, looking right into the tortoiseshell glasses of the dark figure.

“Eh, we've got a brave one here.” He said, grinning. “Another hero, here to cause some sort of trouble.”

“Look, we can do this the easy way, or the hard way. I ain't got the time for you to be a selfish prick.”

Charon sneered, making all the souls restless.

“Try your wo-Urk!” He started saying, before Percy literally grabbed his throat. Something that had never been done before.

“Look.” Percy said, utterly calm about the fact he was choking the ferryman across the river Styx. “I'm trying to be nice here. I haven't had a very relaxing year. I've seen so much death that you couldn't begin to think of how many times your little boat would be full. I've seen entire worlds end, hell, I've CAUSED entire worlds to end. These hands, holding you by the throat right now, have killed gods more powerful then you could imagine.”

“You're... Lying!” Charon choked out, trying to Pry Percy's hands away from his throat.

“No, I'm not. Look into My eyes, Ferryman. You'll see that I am not a good person. Not anymore. Kind, yes. Good? Not on your life. I've raised an evil empire, killing a god of evil in the process, and took his place. So don't try to start anything. Now, I'm only going through you to get to the underworld because it's the official channel, and some things need to be set in motion by going through that channel.” Percy said. “I'm going to let go of you in ten seconds. If you help us, I can make it worth your while. If you refuse... well, I'll just add another tally to my body count. And trust me, you won't come back from the grave if I do.”

Percy held his grip, putting only the smallest amount of Pressure on Charon's throat. Though that had the effect of almost crushing his throat.

Percy let go, letting Charon take deep breaths of nice, stale, dead air. He fell back, behind the desk with a thump, wheezing for breath.

Percy stepped back, crossing his arms, watching the desk like a hawk. His eyes glowed eerily, and the shadow of a terrible helmet appeared over his face, covering it in pure darkness.

Charon slapped a hand on his desk, pulling himself up while the other rubbed his throat. “Fine...” He wheezed out. “Get on the damn boat...”

He moved off his pedestal, wading through the dead souls to get to the elevator.

“C'mon, let's move. And for the love of everything, stay close to me.” Percy growled, making the group nod, Grover and the two youngest members shaking at the display. His helmet was gone, but the souls of the dead had given him a wide berth for the moment, but only that one horrible moment.

Everyone crowded behind Percy as he made his way, moving ghosts out of his way like he was going through a crowd.

“Hey, shut up! Don't get mad at me! Sorry I'm alive then, asshole!” Percy yelled, the ghosts yelling at him as they were moved forcefully. They had seemed to ignore what had happened, trying to forget it. They might have figured that it was some postmortem insanity.

Bianca and Nico had to cover their ears, being the only other ones who could hear their yelling.

They filed into the Elevator, Charon swatting away the spirits as they tried to enter without paying. The souls of those who could pay looked expectantly at Charon, their boarding passes being held up.

“Now, everyone who isn't used to sudden transitions please close your eyes.” Percy said as the Elevator descended, Charon putting his key card away.

It was silent, as the living huddled around Percy.

Charon looked over Nico and Bianca. He scowled at Percy. “If you said you were here to bring the boss's kids to him, I wouldn't have said a word.” He grumbled, occasionally still rubbing his throat.

Percy shrugged, taking something out of his pocket. He motioned for Charon to hold out his hand, something the slowly skeletonizing figure was hesitant to do.

When he did though, Percy pressed the item into his hand. Charon held it in a bony had, looking up at it as the scenery changed to a wooden barge.

He had a large topaz in his hand, easily worth 20 grand.

He chuckled, despite his throat still being sore. “Well, at least you're a godling of your word.” He said, stowing it in the pocket of his Italian suit.

“I told you. I may not be good, But I am kind.” Percy said, keeping a hand on Annabeth.

Soon, they were floating on the river Styx.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Bully the lazy Ferryman. He deserved it anyway...

choices: She spits in his face. The hard way it is, Styx...
She accepts, showing it with a kiss.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Grover, I want you to watch over Annabeth for me.” Percy said, letting go of her as he walked over to the side of the boat.

Below him were the polluted waters of the river. It looked dark and oily.

“Meet me at the judges. I won't be long.” Percy said, jumping over the side, landing on the water's surface. He ran along the river, heading upstream, the boat quickly disappearing into the mist behind him.

As he ran, bones and fish floated by, along with old, unfulfilled dreams that were cast aside or forgotten.

After about an hour of running, normal speed, along the river, Percy came across a waterfall.

“Hello!” Percy called. “I know you're there, Styx!” Percy said.

“What do you want?” A feminine voice called from above the waterfall.

“I want to talk with you!”

There was no response for a minute. “Fine. I'll be down in a second.”

Percy saw a figure swim down the waterfall, just under the water. Percy walked to shore, where the figure was obviously swimming.

Percy watched at the figure emerged from the water, completely naked, untouched by the rivers pollution.

She was dark skinned, with silver eyes and long, oily black hair. She was tall, almost standing at the same height as Percy. Her assets were overall small, save for her shapely legs. She looked at him with disinterest.

“What do you want?” She asked, an unhappy look plastered on her face. “Can't you leave me alone? Everyone else does.”

Percy shook his head. “Nope, can't do that.” He said.

Styx looked at him, eying him carefully. “I know you. You're the brat of Poseidon's, that lousy ingrate. Both him and Zeus.” She grumbled. “Nothing's sacred anymore, I swear.”

“Look, I know you don't like me. I'm the result of a broken Promise made by the gods that they weren't supposed to break. But don't get mad at me for being my father's son. I didn't choose to be his kid.” Percy scowled. “And for the record, I don't like Zeus or my father either.”

Styx just 'Hmph'ed' “Yeah, well, you don't know what it's like. They promised to only use my name when it was a sacred Promise. Now they use it for everything, and never keep them. So, not only are they breaking a sacred law they created, my name's being dragged through the mud and has lost all meaning. Ooh, so the sky rumbles, big deal. The little lightning brat could do that himself.” She said, crossing her arms. “Maybe I should have fought for Kronos. Sure, he was a murderous, paranoid, Delusional, idiot of a titan, but at least HE never made Promises he didn't intend to keep.”

“Kronos made Promises?” Percy asked, raised eyebrow.

Styx sighed. “No, not really. All he ever did was order the titans around and torture humans for sport. But that's not the point. You see my river?” She asked, pointing to the oily water. “I can handle the broken dreams. They float on down the river to the Lethe. But the broken and forgotten promises? No, that stuff sticks around as long as I do. Worse then any oil spill, since Promises are always broken or forgotten, more so then dreams.”

Percy nodded. “Well, sorry, there's nothing I can do for that 'yet.'” Percy said, thinking the last word to himself. “What I can do is offer you my help in taking down Zeus and Poseidon. And without working for that little titan.”

Styx looked at him, one delicate eyebrow raised. “'Little titan?' You must be arrogant or a fool. I may not have been fond of Kronos, but he was powerful. There was a reason it took Zeus, Poseidon and Hades working together at the same time to take him down.”

Percy shrugged again. It was understandable that people didn't think he could take down the ruler of the titans. “Well, I gotta lot of things going for me.” Percy remarked. “I got Clotho, Atropos and Lachesis working with me. As in, directly working with me. I'm incredibly powerful on my own. These gloves I got can do things you wouldn't believe. Same with the shoes. I can't be killed with something like the Master bolt, or anything for that matter by virtue of immortality.”

“And, to top it all off, I have not only an army at my command that is almost infinite, if not all that resilient, but I also have several incredibly powerful goddess's working both with and for me.” He said, looking right at Styx. “So, you tell me. Who's going to win in a fight between me and Kronos?” He asked.

Styx just huffed. “You're bluffing. No one could wield that kind of power.”

She stumbled back, suddenly realizing Percy was in her face. She hadn't even seen him move, and she never blinked or looked away.

“You see, I'm not just anybody.” Percy said, grabbing her arm gently. Styx felt pleasure well up in her, desire rising for who she liked to call the child of a broken promise. “I can do things even the gods would do well to Fear. I could easily take Olympus down on my own, today. But I won't. Do you know why?” He asked, Styx moaning at his touch as he gently stroked her face. “Because it would be too simple. Too easy. Too... boring.” Percy hissed the word Boring out. How he was able to do that without any S's in the word would remain a mystery. “Now, we can do this one of several way, but I'll break it down to two. The easy, pleasurable way, for both me and you. Or, I can use one of many... powers... at my disposal to make you want to join me. Personally, I would prefer the easy way myself. I don't like to try and force people. I don't like feeling like my father. But I will if I must.” Percy said. There was one thing that kept him from being like his father.

Women wanted him.

He leaned down, putting his face to hers. He could see as she started to lose herself to his power, his loosening of the gauntlets chains a bit.

Oh yes, that was something Percy had trained, keeping control of the aura the Gauntlets emitted to women. He could control it now, effortlessly. Same with the strength, and his boots. And any other aura he had.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Other business to attend on the river of the dead

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
She spit in his face, trying to pull her arm away. Even though she could feel the pleasure, the desire, she tried to escape.

Percy could commend her for that. It wasn't something that most women could do.

He wiped the spit from his face. It was no skin off his nose. He wasn't going to get all uppity at something minor as that.

“Hmm, tragic.” Percy said, waving his hand over the Eronomicon. Out popped a large stone tablet, featureless except for the sheer smoothness of its face. It reflected the pitiful amount of light in the land of the dead.

Percy activated the Silver Tongue of the Serpent, holding onto her shoulder as he slowly let more of the gauntlet's power loose.

“Touch the stone.” He whispered. To Styx, he sounded so charming, so convincing, that combined with the pleasure that was washing over her, she almost came on the spot. “All your troubles will wash away, my dear. You won't have to worry about your river, or the gods anymore.”

Styx found herself raising her hand, against her will. She desperately wanted to fight it, fight Percy. But he sounded so sure of himself, so convincing that she wouldn't have to worry anymore. It would be nice, not worrying about her river anymore. Let her sister, Lethe, take care of everything that floated down.

She touched the stone tablet.

Instantly, she felt her mind go blank of any emotion. She remembered events, but not the emotions she used during them. She didn't even remember what words like 'happy' or 'sad' meant anymore.

Percy watched, his eyes devoid of joy. He never liked to take such control of a person, but it was something that he had grown accustomed to doing. It never felt very pleasant.

But it was a necessity.

He thought about how he wanted to remake Styx, in terms of personality.

'I could go the emotionless route, but it takes too long. But it is a little more gratifying, building up someones emotions to just the right mold.' He thought. 'But it would suit my plans just fine if I rewrote her personality. Much less pleasant though. It makes it seemed forced, unnatural. Or, as a thought, I could go in the middle. Let her retain basic emotions, but have no concept of where to feel them. Takes less time, but it flows better in terms of emotional strength. Forcing something to fit only cracks, or worse, shatters the object. Shaving it down to fit and filling in the holes later, however, would work just fine.'
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: She spits in his face. The hard way it is, Styx...

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Another choice chapter. Unfortunately, it had to be done.

So, shall the titaness of the river Styx be forcibly rewritten? Or shall she be reduced to merely the most basic understanding, knowing what the emotions and feelings mean, but not where to place them?
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Forced rewrite or basic understanding.

choices: Something is holding the group up. Possibly the Furies
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
'Basic concepts it is.' Percy decided, getting to work. 'Let me direct her personality in a not so subtle way, while not having to explain to her what the concepts mean all the time. It works well, even allowing me to give her personality quirks, guilty pleasures and the like, as well as control who she hates, who she tolerates, what she aspires for...' Percy shook his head. 'When did I get this cunning? I remember a time when I would run in head first. Not to say that I don't still do that, but... matters such as this were so far beyond me merely a year ago.'

He worked for what seemed like ten minutes. He stripped away all her emotions, previous attachments, current attachments, desires and more. He left only the barest foundations for any emotion, any hopes or dreams.

Work completed, Percy removed her fingers from the tablet. Once she had no more contact with it, Styx blinked, a little bit of her intelligence coming back.

Percy reigned in the power of the gauntlets, sealing off his serpentine tongue with it.

She looked at him. “I know you.” She said emotionlessly. “The child of a broken promise.”

“Yeah, that's me.” Percy said, concealing a smirk. “What do you feel about it?”

Styx put a hand to her head, like she thought she should know, but the knowledge just wasn't there. “I don't know. What do I feel?” She asked, still as emotionless as a robot.

“How about happy?” Percy asked, knowing this would be the first step.

A small smile twitched upon her lips, tugging at the corners of her mouth. “Yes, I feel... happy.” She said, looking at him with a small smile, as if unused to such an action. “But why do I feel happy?” She asked, going back to an emotionless drone.

“Because you love me?”

She smiled again, moving close to him. “Yes, that is right. Because I love you. And...being near those you love... makes you happy.” She said, reaching out to grab his hand.

“Do you know what else you love doing and makes you happy?” He asked, setting up a little tirade to set a more stable foundation for her personality.

“No.” She said, holding his hand.

“You love listening to me. It makes you happy when you do.” He said, making her nod. “You love being used by me. It makes you feel good when I use you.” He said, making her nod. He put a hand on her breast, giving it a gentle squeeze, making her moan. “You love believing me, no matter what. You are happy when you do.” He said, making her nod. “You love being loyal to me, and only me. It makes you very happy.” He said, making her nod. “You love truth and justice. It makes you happy when they are upheld.” He said, making her nod. “You love me unconditionally. It makes you happy, knowing this.” He said, making her move closer to him. “You lust for me. You like this feeling.” He said, and she grabbed at his crotch. “But what do you hate?”

She took her hand out of his, placing it to her head again. “I don't know.”

“You hate lies, unless they are necessary. They make you angry.” He said, making her nod. “You hate those who break promises. They make you vengeful.” He said, making her nod. “You hate intolerance. It makes you both sad and angry.” He said, making her nod.

And so it went on. For another ten minutes, Percy built up her new personality, her new self. She accepted it all, Percy telling her how to feel, what to feel, who to feel for, everything.

She desired to topple Zeus and Poseidon, and she hated them for breaking promises. She loved being touched by him, no matter where they were. She had the guilty pleasure of having someone watch her as she had sex, and a guilty pleasure of watching someone have sex.

That last one was because of the minions never minding their own business. It had rubbed off onto Percy, it seemed.

She had many other things that Percy had told her how to feel, what to like and dislike. But Percy had also left a lot blank, so that she could build a little bit of her personality herself.

So, Percy basically made her a willing slave, who loved him unconditionally. She was lustful, but knew when to keep in control of herself. She loved being used by him, being owned by him. She would do anything he told her, believe anything he told her.

If he said the sky was orange with magenta stripes, the sky was orange with magenta stripes. At least, to her it would seem that way. It might just swap the normal blue of the sky with the aforementioned color scheme in her mind so she would think that it was, and it might alter what she thought about other things that were blue as the sky.

Percy wasn't a brain surgeon after all.

It was all precaution to Percy. Several things had gone wrong the first time he had done something with the tablet. He had corrected those mistakes, vowing to never make them again.

It was horrible seeing a woman tear her soul apart as it fought inside her body. Two sides of the same coin, but in such fierce opposition to the other that they couldn't stand existing with the other.

It was even worse when they fought over whether or not they hated him. Whether or not they tried to kill him.

It had happened so fast, so unexpectedly. There was nothing he could do to save Jewel.

Well, until he went back in time again to fix what he had broken beyond repair. To warn himself of his mistakes.

But still, the scare was there. The scar was there. Neither could be forgotten.

That was also why he was hesitant to just rewrite her personality, rather then build from the ground up.

It was like a mask that was made for your face. If it didn't fit, it didn't fit. Trying to force it would cause damage.

That was what the personality was to the soul, essentially. If he had just rewritten her personality, it would have only buried the old one underneath it. If strong enough emotional stimuli had brought it out... well, the consequences would not be pretty.

“C'mon Styx. We need to go speak to your favorite of the big three, and my favorite uncle.” Percy said, wrapping an arm around the titaness's shoulders. She was hugging him back, giggling as she tried to grind against him.

In a flash, they left the black, volcanic banks of the river Styx, going to meet the judges.

~ At the judges

Percy appeared in the center of the line awaiting judgment, Styx clinging to him still. The souls of the dead were yelling at Percy, telling him to get out of the way.

“Damn it.” Percy said, rubbing his head. “One bad thing about becoming a god of the Abyss is that you can hear souls clearly. And there are definitely more here then... well, there. Never did find out the name of that world.”

“Oh, does it hurt my love?” Styx asked, ignoring the dead.

Percy shook his head. “Nah, just annoying. Though not as much as the god itself. I swear, he never shut up. Well, at least until I roasted him from the inside out, crushed his skull and absorbed his powers. At least the wraiths never talked.” Percy said, thinking back on his undead underlings.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Like clay from a river bed

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Who's a good puppy? Who's a terrifying beast of despair?” Percy heard Echidna cooing in the distance. He also heard the sounds of a large, three headed guard dog enjoying the attention from its mother. “That's right, you are! You are!”

“I think they're this way.” Percy said, pushing through the line of the dead, basically carrying Styx. “It's not play time anymore.” He said, making her huff playfully.

“Fine, I guess I can stop trying to fool around with you if I must.” She said, acting all dramatic. Hand held to her forehead and everything.

“Maybe later.” Percy said, hands going to grab her rear. “But not now. Business before pleasure, after all.” He said, walking over the hill. He could easily see through the gloom of the underworld, see his group and Cerberus.

Speaking of which, said giant, three-headed rottweiler was currently letting all souls pass unhindered as it lay off to the side, having two heads being scratched behind their ears at the same time. The third head would have been pouting, if it weren't busy growling at the Chimera, who in turn growled right back.

“Mommy's missed you.” Echidna said. “Have they been treating you well down here? Playing fetch with the souls of the tormented, like we agreed?”

Cerberus whined, making Echidna gasp, as if in horror. “The nerve of them! When I agreed to let you become the hound of Hades, I made sure you would be cared for.” She said, growing angry. Kind of like a mother who found out the daycare she left her kid at had neglected them. “Well, you won't have to worry about that anymore.”

Percy appeared next to Echidna, setting the titaness he was carrying down. Cerberus growled at him, only to have Echidna shush it. “Be nice, Cerberus.” Echidna ordered, causing the rottweiler to whimper again.

“Chimera, come here please.” Percy ordered. The beast-woman nodded, ignoring her sibling as she moved to her Alpha. “Hold out your hand for a moment, the one with the ring.” He said.

Percy looked over the ring, after she had done so. He carefully inspected it, even pulling out a pair of glasses to look at them.

He reached into one back pocket, a light glowing from it. Percy pulled out a roll of paper, with a strange, headache inducing image. It was an absolute mess to behold, but also... ritualistic.

Percy took out a pencil, erasing and redrawing the smallest lines, maybe mere centimeters off of what they were before. He added circles, triangles, a five pointed star and several new lines, always tweaking them to something only he could see.

Annabeth, Grover and Medusa all really wanted to ask him what he was doing, but Melum shushed them. Whatever her master was working on, it was important.

“Got to account for the soul bond, adding the link for both rings.” Percy muttered, twisting the Chimera's ring several times. “Not to mention the one way empathy and mood control. Have to make sure that I get it the right way as well. Wouldn't be good if I got that reversed. Damn, I wish I could have tested this out in a controlled environment.”

Percy sighed, rubbing his head. “Well, I think that's it.” Percy said, straightening up. He rolled up the paper, putting it back into his pocket. It glowed twice, the paper disappearing for a second before reappearing. He pulled the paper out again, though it was visibly smaller this time. “Now, to see if this works.” Percy said.

He placed the paper on the Chimera's ring, light erupting from it. Everyone shielded their eyes, Cerberus only able to close its eyes.

When the light died, Percy was holding a ring instead of paper. It looked exactly like the one the Chimera wore.

“Annabeth, could you do something for me?” He asked, looking at the blond haired beauty as she rubbed her eyes.

“Yeah, what?” She asked, blinking. She caught the golden ring as it sailed right towards her. She looked at it, as if questioning its very existence.

“Wear it. I want to see if I made it right.” Percy said.

Annabeth nodded, putting the ring on her finger. Instantly, she could feel what Percy felt. Apprehension, worry for her, hope, among other things. She... couldn't feel anything herself. She tried, she knows she did.

Then she found herself smiling. Then worried, then sad, then happy again.

Percy walked to her, slipping the ring off her finger. She was in control of herself again, she could feel it. She held her head, the feeling of controlling her own emotions rushing back.

“I'm sorry.” He whispered, holding her in a hug. “But I had to know.”

Annabeth didn't say anything, trying to ease the pain.

Percy let go of her, walking to the crouched form of Cerberus. He put the ring in his back pocket, and like the paper it flashed, vanishing and reappearing in his hand.

“Good. Now I can make copies as need be.” Percy said, mostly to himself. He pressed his hand to the book, the ring still in his palm. “I wonder... No. No experiments right now that aren't necessary.” He said, berating himself. He slipped the ring out, holding it as he imprinted a seal onto his hand. One he had used quite a few times in the past, even in this world, his home world.

He moved up to the large hound, who felt like it should back away in fear. Primal fear, the fear of the unknown. And Cerberus certainly didn't know what the person could do, nor what he did.

“It's going to be okay.” Percy said, gently. He extended his hand for the large dog to smell.

Well, maybe the human wasn't so bad.

Cerberus sniffed at the offered hand, three noses taking in the scent.

Well, he didn't smell of bad intentions...

“It's okay, baby.” Echidna said, rubbing the side of Cerberus's right head.

Percy placed his hand upon the middle snout.

And then there was a bigger, more intense light.

Cerberus howled, all three heads snarling and snapping at the air. It backed up, rearing onto it's hind legs as it's body was engulfed in pure light.

When Percy could see again, for even the light was too much for his eyes, he saw...
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Who's a good giant demon dog from hell? You are!

choices: Hades comes to meet them, dressed in full battle gear
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
A giant, furry foot?

Percy looked up, following the leg that was attached to the foot. Up... up... up...

You guessed it, still up...

“Holy shit.” Percy said, starring in awe. He wasn't expecting this at all. “I think her head touches the ceiling.”

Indeed, the giant woman was Cerberus. The former hound of Hades.

Where the dog had been twice the size of a woolie mammoth, it seemed the woman was easily the height of a certain storm giant, if not larger.

Moving quickly, Percy imprinted yet another seal into his hand, slapping it onto Cerberus's foot. Well, pinky toe. Instantly, the gargantuan woman shrank in size, growing smaller and smaller before she could actually do any damage.

“That was too close.” Percy said. “That could have gone badly. Really badly.”

“What happened?” Everyone but Melum and Styx asked, rubbing their eyes. Even shielded, they still almost went blind.

“Don't worry.” Percy said, brushing off their questions. “It's best you don't know.”

Now that he could see Cerberus's full body, Percy took in an eye full.

Cerberus was darker then pitch black, except on her belly, the inside of her legs and the underside of her arms. Those were a dark mahogany. Her fur was coarse, though it was shiny nonetheless. She had one blue eye, though it was more leaning to a slight purplish color, and a dark brown eye, almost like fresh dirt, both almond shaped. She had a short muzzle, filled with still surprisingly sharp teeth. A long tail swung from behind, sweeping the ground behind her. She was also very well endowed, rivaling Clotho in the breast department, while Lachesis was now having close competition for having a great rear end.

Percy slipped the ring onto the dazed woman's finger, though she did try to pull away. If Percy wasn't as strong as he was, his arms would have been ripped off.

Instantly, Percy could see that the ring took effect. The Chimera and Cerberus both looked the same, in terms of their eyes.

“Oh my!” Echidna squealed! Yeah, that's right. Echidna, mother of all monsters, squealed. “Oh, my darling girl is so adorably dangerous.” She said, hugging her new humanoid daughter. She was referring to Cerberus's teeth and claws, which still looked like they could eviscerate someone like they were a wet paper bag.

Cerberus ignored her mother, looking directly at Percy. “Alpha.” She said, bowing her head. She twitched, lifting her head. She now had blood red eyes, staring him directly in the eyes. “Alpha.” She said, this time a little more primal and forceful.

She twitched yet again, Percy able to see her eyes shift to a deathly blue/purple. “Alpha.” She said, happily wagging her tail as she looked at him.

“I give!” Grover yelled, looking at the new addition to the group. “What's next? Artemis? Athena? HERA?”

Nico and Bianca were looking, though neither was absolutely sure what they were seeing. Nico was too young to understand the implications of a dog turning into a woman, but Bianca wasn't.

“What did you do to the big dog?” Nico asked innocently, looking curious.

Bianca could only watch. She couldn't even voice her... wonder? Horror? Complete and utter bafflement, coupled with a wonder if she was in a coma of some kind, and had been for a long time?

Yeah, it was probably that last one.

Cerberus twitched again, going back to her original personality. Percy guessed that would be the neutral one.

“C'mon. We gotta move.” Percy said, picking up Cerberus. She would need to get used to walking on her own time. “Melum, toss me the master bolt backpack.” He ordered, catching it with ease.

He walked through the metal detector, which made a high-pitched sound before completely short circuiting.

“Huh, too much magic power I suppose.” Percy said, looking as the contraption started melting. “Oh well, no skin off my back. I can give my uncle the money. Oh, and you two better cover your ears.” He said, pointing at Nico and Bianca. “Going to get really noisy for the three of us. Melum, can you hear them?” He asked, curious.

“Yes, but I can easily ignore them.” She said, even toned instead of whispers. It was quite nice, hearing her talking normally.

“Good. Cause we're going to the place with the most dead under the earth.” Percy said, walking around the heap of slag. “Welcome to the Fields of Asphodel.” He said, walking into the dark mist beyond.

~ About an hour or so later

Percy looked up at the obsidian palace. “Still got nothing on the dark tower.” He muttered, looking specifically at three bat like women flying above the palace. “Hey!” He yelled. “Go tell Hades that we want to speak with him! And no funny business either!”

There was a faint screech of anger, but the three women flew down into the palace, disappearing from sight.

“Chimera, Peísma. Help Cerberus walk.” He said, putting the newest monster woman down. Chimera and Peísma did as told, Cerberus growling slightly at Chimera, though giving Peísma a good lick to the side of her head.

Made sense, since Cerberus was technically her ancestor, and Cerberus probably thought of her as a pup.

“Nico, Bianca, up front with me.” Percy ordered, making the two scuttle quickly in fear.

Seeing this, Percy sighed. “Look, you two don't need to be afraid of me. For all my menacing presence, I wouldn't think of hurting family. Well, unless they needed a good ass-kicking.” He said, drawing a glare from Bianca at his use of the swear. “Oh, don't look at me like that. Kids gonna learn to swear at some point. Though if you don't want him to hear anything too bad, keep him away from Ares.” He said. “Now come on. Let's go meet your dad, and my uncle.”

“Wait.” Bianca said, stopping him. “You said That we're meeting our father, right?”

“Yeah.”

“But we're going to see the god of the dead?”

“Yes, we are.”

“So that means...” Bianca said, realizing the implications only now.

“Hades is your father, yes.” Percy said. He wondered if he should tell them they were the half siblings of Adolf Hitler. Nah, better not. “So? I'm a child of Poseidon. He's not supposed to have children either, not anymore.”

“But-” Bianca started to protest.

“But what?” Percy asked, turning his eyes towards her. “Your father is one of the most honorable Olympians. He may be lord of the Dead, but he is not evil. His children may have done horrible things in the past, but he is not responsible for their actions. Whether or not you accept him is your choice, but for all intents and purposes He is one of my favorite Gods, personally. He may be shrewd, but that's only because his family has turned their backs on him.”

He looked back, starring her in the eye. “Would you abandon the people who need you the most?” He asked. “Your brother? Your Father? Both need you equally, but for different reasons. Nico still needs someone to watch for him and help him grow. And I think your father has already lost enough.”

Percy sighed. “It won't be easy, I know. You'll be ostracized for being children of Hades. But you got family here. And not just down here,” He said, waving around him. “But you got me, Melum, Annabeth and everyone else here. Right?” He asked, getting rounds of agreement from everyone who could talk.

Bianca looked down. She had been thinking of trying to pawn Nico off on somebody, anybody really. Just a month in that hotel had already driven her crazy. She didn't want to have to watch out for him all the time.

Percy knealt, placing a hand on both hers and Nico's shoulder's. “Look, not everything you hear about the gods is true. After several things came to light, I'm not very fond of my own Father. You remember aunt Em?” He asked, getting nods. “She was Medusa. And yes, she did turn people to statues. But before you freak out,” Percy said, seeing both go pale. “I solved her little problem. My dad...” He paused, looking back at her, getting a nod. He wanted her permission. “Well... he did some bad things to her. Athena cursed her, and then my dad did even more bad things. It scarred her, and I know it still does. But she wasn't as bad as the legends made her out to be. Hades isn't evil, and Zeus isn't a great ruler. Remember that.” He said, standing up. Without another word he walked through the bronze gates of the fortress.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Good work throwing the shoes Grover.” Percy said to his Satyr buddy. “I almost forgot about them. Glad you didn't get dragged to Tartarus.”

“Well, I wasn't going to fall into Kronos's hands.” Grover said, trying to put on a show of bravado.

“I would have got you Grover.” Percy said. “Trust me, I would have.”

Grover nodded, sensing the truth behind Percy's words. He wasn't lying at all, he knew it for certain now.

“No one ate the fruit, right?” Percy asked, looking back. They had just passed through Persephone's garden, with the dreaded fruit of the underworld. He got shakes of their heads, telling him that they didn't. “Good. We're almost there.”

The large group walked down the hallways, the dead military that Hades used as palace guards bowing to Bianca and Nico. The dead came from all era's of history, all nationalities. Though none of them were from a time older then the start of the Greek pantheon.

Nico was looking around, finding it all to be, in his own words, awesome and cool. Bianca was less excited, though she did try to stay strong.

Two large bronze doors appeared out of the gloom, signifying the end of the hallway. Two U.S. Military men were carrying RPG's, guarding the door.

Percy was about to open the doors when they opened by themselves, letting the stalest air ever flow through.

Grover had to cover his nose, it was so foul.

The group walked in, the throne of Hades Occupied.

He was as Percy remembered him. Ten feet tall, dressed in black robes and crowned with braided gold. His skin was albino white, his shoulder-length hair an oily black. He wasn't compensating for anything with his physique, unlike a certain war god, yet he still radiated a godly power. His eyes were radiating that same, devilish charisma that any leader would, if you could call the likes of Hitler or terrorist leaders, well, leaders. That same charm that could make people lose any and all sense of decency or morals, and do horrible things.

But, then again, that wasn't really his fault. Just the way he was born.

“Hello Uncle.” Percy said, unafraid of the Aura Hades emanated.

Hades eyes bored holes into Percy, glancing irritably at Melum once or twice. “You are foolish to come here, child of Poseidon. And you as well, outsider.” He said, looking at Melum. “I should incinerate you here and now.”

“You can try, Lord of the dead.” Melum said, glaring right back at him, her voice scathing.

“Now now Mel.” Percy said, raising a hand. “Uncle, we came here to negotiate and come to an agreement.”

Hades was snarled at Percy. “For my helm? Bah. You just want to take more from me don't you? In the name of your Father? If you want your Mother back, you will give me my helm. Or she will die!”

“Come now uncle, surely you can see reason.” Percy said, his finger twitching. That was another thing Percy never forgot. His mother was held captive. “Yes, I have the master bolt, but I never stole it from Zeus. And I don't have your helm.”

“Lies!” Hades roared. “I am not as foolish as my youngest brother. You and your father cannot fool me! You were the thief on the winter solstice! It was then that you stole my helm, and the master bolt! I will not be strong-armed into supporting your father!”

“I don't give a damn about my father!” Percy roared, voice deeper then Hades. Armor appeared on him in a flash, covering his entire body. He posed a powerful, terrifying figure, his eyes glowing a poisonous green instead of sea green (Foot note: Armor looks like this http://overlord.wikia.com/wiki/File:Arca...). “Now give me back my mother Hades!” He demanded.

Hades didn't seem to be put off by anything though. He merely leaned back in his throne, holding up on hand with a glowing orb. “Oh, you mean her?” He asked, loosing a golden fire ball at the steps of his throne.

Sally Jackson appeared in the explosion, frozen it time. The pain of the minotaur crushing her body was etched onto her face

“Yes, I took her Perseus Jackson.” Hades growled out his name like it disgusted him. “Just as I said I did. I knew you would come to bargain for her soul. Return my helm to me, and she will be free.”

Percy growled, the eyes on the gauntlets focusing angrily on him. Percy's anger fueled them, and they wanted to feed on this gods power. “We don't have your helm!”

“Pity.” Hades said, Sally disappearing as he held up a golden orb again. “Perhaps I should just crush her, be done with it.”

Percy snarled. He really didn't want to do this. “Wait just a damned minute Hades.” Percy said, reaching behind him and Grabbing the Di Angelo children. “You wouldn't risk the lives of your children, now would you?”

Hades stiffened. “What?” He asked, looking at the children in Percy's grasp. His eyes widened. “How- No. It must be another trick.” He said, glaring at Percy.

“Willing to bet?” Percy asked, putting the smallest amount of pressure on Nico's arm. “Sorry about this.” Percy whispered.

“Ow! Ow ow ow ow!” Nico cried, the finger spikes digging into his shoulder.

Bianca looked up at him with horror etched into her features. She tried to tear from his grasp, but his grip was too strong. “Hey! Let go of him!” She said, trying to hit Percy.

All she did was bruise her hand.

“Don't make me do this Uncle.” Percy said, slowly increasing the pressure on Nico's shoulder.

“Ow! Stop it Percy!” Nico said, blood starting to seep through his clothes.

“Enough!” Hades roared, making the room shake. He appeared in front of Percy, fist already flying at his face.

Percy held fast, letting Hades's fist connect with his face. He didn't even budge, nor did he let go of the children.

“Your move, Uncle.” Percy said, his voice sounding metallic in his helmet. “Either you agree to talk civilly, or you lose a child. And don't try to destroy my mothers soul. Don't try to bargain, don't try to weasel your way out of it. Just... talk.” He said, trying to calm himself. “And trust me, it won't leave you empty handed.”

Hades growled, the dead taking aim at Percy. He didn't understand why he couldn't hurt the child of Poseidon. He didn't understand how Percy could know that he had children, nor where they were. He couldn't fathom how much he didn't know, nor how little power he held in the situation.

Hades was at a disadvantage.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Hades took a deep breath. He would negotiate. He couldn't lose a child. He had so precious few, even before the pact of the big three.

“Very well.” He said, though it wasn't hard to hear the dissatisfaction in his voice. “I will hear what you have to say, child of Poseidon. Just please, do not hurt my children anymore.” He said, looking down at them with a look of fatherly worry.

“As long as you hold your end of the bargain, Uncle.” Percy said, pulling his fingers out of Nico's shoulder. He gently pushed the boy back to Annabeth, who began to wrap up the wounds and gave the boy some ambrosia. “Shall we begin the 'negotiations'?” Percy asked.

“Here is as good a place as any.” Hades said, sitting on his throne. He gestured to the guards, signaling them to leave. They saluted, sinking into the ground.

Percy nodded. “It's going to take a while, so I've got a little help to keep Zeus and Poseidon from starting the war while we talk.” Percy said, as three familiar women in white dresses appeared.

Hades raised an eyebrow. “And who are these?” He asked, genuinely curious as to who could freely enter his domain, and more importantly, his home.

'You should know us well, Hades.' One said, her black eyes glinting with mirth.

'Yes. Do you not remember how we helped during the gigantomachy?' Another chided, fiery eyes twinkling knowingly.

'Or perhaps how even you cannot fight our power?' The last asked teasingly, her golden eyes focused on Hades.

“The Moirae?” Hades said, questioningly.

“Got it one Hades.” Percy said.

'Yes, it is us.' Atropos said, moving to sit at a long obsidian table that appeared.

'We shall be... mediators, of sorts.' Clotho said, sitting next to her sister.

'And time outside this room is currently on hold. We believe Percy has a tale to tell.' Lachesis said, sitting on Atropos's other side.

“And negotiations.” Percy reminded, sitting at the opposite end away from Hades. He wasn't actually sitting, per say. But it was more a relaxed slouch then anything else. It was as if he knew exactly what he was doing. As if he knew Hades couldn't touch him. It didn't even look uncomfortable in his armor!

He had never let go of Bianca either...

“Let my daughter go.” Hades growled.

“My Mother then. I won't let you hold the cards, Hades.” Percy said, trying to keep a calm tone.

Hades glared, but a snap of his fingers and Sally's soul orb was in Percy's hand, claws still stained with Nico's blood.

“Thank you.” Percy said, releasing Bianca. She immediately ran over to Nico, whose wounds from Percy were just starting to heal. “Look Hades, I'm going to get right down to business. The tale can wait until the end. You don't like either of your brothers, I don't like my dad or Zeus. The Fates want me to take them out. They say it's time for a change in regime.”

Hades eyebrow rose. “Really?” He asked, looking at the Fates for confirmation. “Do tell then. Do tell.” He said, leaning forward.

Percy smirked, not that anyone could see it. 'Hook, line and sinker.' “I'll level with you Hades. There will be a war soon. Kronos will rise, and so will the other titans. Make no mistake, they will come back. Zeus won't listen to reason.”

Hades snorted. “Naturally. Zeus always was arrogant. Even though we worked equally, he always tried to take the credit for all out achievements when we did work together. Father, Typhon. It didn't matter.”

Percy nodded. “Right, that's another problem. Typhon will rise again.”

“What!” Hades shouted.

“But don't worry, he will be put down. For good this time.”

“How?” Hades asked. “How will the greatest threat to us gods 'be put down?'”

“Patience, Uncle. It will be told soon enough.” Percy said.

“How do you know these things?” Hades asked. “Surely the Moirae haven't given you knowledge of what is going to happen?” He asked, the three shaking their heads.

'No, it is not us who gave him knowledge.' Clotho said.

'No, knowledge need not be given if it has already been learned.' Lachesis added.

'The knowledge is his, though it has not yet come to pass.' Atropos stated.

“Come now Ladies.” Percy said, chiding them for their cryptic ways. “What they mean to say is that I've already lived through this once. Time travel, if you will.”

Hades scoffed. “Please. You expect me to believe something as stupid as that? I'm a god, boy. I know for fact that time travel is impossible.”

“Not when Kronos's energy is in flux, and another source of powerful energy connects with it.” Percy countered. “It ripped open a hole in the space-time continuum, with me right at the epicenter.”

'It's true, before you accuse him.' Lachesis threw her two sense in, silencing Hades accusation of lies.

“Fine.” Hades said, though not with a grumble. “That would explain the knowledge about where my children were kept hidden from my brother, among other things. But that still doesn't explain the outsider.” He said, looking at Melum.

“Ah, once again the tale will explain.” Percy said. “We're getting off topic. I want an alliance. Not between you and my father, but between you and me.”

Hades scoffed again. “Why should I ally with you, demigod?”

Suddenly Hades could feel a hand on his throat, crushing it. He could feel his godly energy being drained, his very being unraveling.

“Because,” Percy said, glowing eyes Narrowed as Hades started struggling for breath. Which was odd, since air was something that gods didn't need. “If you don't, I will kill you and take command over the dead. I will take your spot as lord of the dead, and I will make sure you know it as you die. Everything you held dear would fall to my command. Persephone, your children. Every. Single thing. And make no mistake, I can and will do it, if you force me.”

As suddenly as it appeared, the pressure on his throat vanished, Percy back in his spot as if he didn't move. “But I'll be honest here. You're one of my favorite gods. At least you can hold your promises. Though I have no doubt that is because Styx was always so close, keeping an eye on you. You actually seem to care for your family, even if you're willing to play chess master to try and give them the roll in the great prophecy. You are somewhat above petty squabbles, since I know you would ride to your families help if they truly needed it, despite everything they've done to you.”

“What they've done to me hardly counts at 'petty.'” Hades snarled.

“No, it isn't. Killing the woman you love, and trying to kill your children when they were still young? No, that's not petty at all. Ostracized you for being lord of the dead? No, that's not petty either. That's borderline hate right there.” Percy admitted. “But their time has come, Uncle. Olympus will change. One way or another.”

“You speak like a mad man, Jackson.” Hades said. “How I would love to see my brothers taken down a notch or twenty, I have no real desire to see Olympus fall.”

“Who ever said it would fall?” Percy asked. “I said it would change. Zeus will likely die, as will my father. Zeus will never take this laying down, and I will take my father down for... Personal reasons.” Percy said, dodging around his reasons for killing Poseidon. “Either way, Olympus would retain the other gods, barring them trying to keep Zeus in power through any means necessary.”

“And how do I know you won't turn on me?” Hades asked.

“A justified question, I'll admit.” Percy said, his voice laden with amusement. “Simply put, you don't cross me. You don't betray me, and I don't turn my sights on you. If you do that, you can live freely.”

Hades crossed his arms, looking at Percy. “Other then that, what would I get out of this?” He asked, not entirely sure whether or not to buy his Nephew's claims.

Percy smirked again. “Well, how does respect among your fellow gods sound? Free reign to go where you want to go without fear of provoking a war if you so much as look outside the underworld?” Percy asked. “I'd also be willing to lend a hand in keeping the underworld secure, due to... my own workforce, I guess you could call it.”

“Work force?” Hades asked, eyebrow raised again.

“It's still part of the story. Though I think it is time to tell the tale.” Percy said. “Otherwise, you would not give thought to my claims. Best settle down and get comfy. It is quite the tale.”

“Where to begin...” Percy mused, tapping a clawed finger on a chin, hidden in darkness.

'Why not the beginning, Perseus?' Clotho asked, looking directly at him.

'Yes, after the defeat of Kronos.' Atropos said.

“Would be a good place as any to start.” Percy said, his armor clanking as he shrugged. “Well, it all started in the throne room of Olympus...”

He glanced at it, disbelief in his eyes. He looked at Percy. “And you say that behind you are not only Echidna, but also the Chimera and Cerberus?”

“Accept your proposal.” Hades said. “I do not know if you could kill a god, as you claim, but I do not wish to chance it. I will help you change Olympus, Perseus Jackson.” Hades said, standing up. “Future... Harem god.” He said, the title feeling strange on his tongue.

Percy smiled at his Uncle, though it was unseen. “Glad that you did. Honestly, you and Hestia are my favorite gods. Would hate to have to get rid of one of you.”

“What else could I say to one who has bedded the Moirae?” Hades asked. He was still in shock about that, and only the Fates made him believe. “I would be a fool to go against the only person they favor.”

“And you are no fool.” Percy said. “This proves it.”

“Normally, this would be the time to say something like 'We shall see.'” Hades said. “But I highly doubt that you could disappoint.”

“I would hope not.” Percy said, nodding. “Now, I believe we should get to business at hand. Outside this room, Zeus and Poseidon are about to go to war. Ares has your helm. I'm going to head up with my group, and I'm going to fight Ares. Send the Furies up there ASAP.”

“And what of my children?” Hades asked, looking at Nico and Bianca.

“Do you want them to stay here?” Percy asked. “You could train them in their powers, make them stronger then the camp ever could.”

Hades nodded, thinking. “Yes, that does seem like a sound plan.”

“Then they'll stay. Just try and send them up to camp every once in a while. I can take them to explore the world and learn how well they trained. Besides, I don't think you would be breaking any sort of cosmic laws or any other crap like that.” Percy said, standing up. “If you are, just have some ghosts train them. Just keep them away from Minos. He'll try to manipulate them.”

Hades growled again. “Foolish ghost. If he tries anything he'll be sent so deep into the fields of punishment that he'll wish he were in Tartarus.”

“Just don't jump the gun and punish him for something he may do.” Percy warned. He walked back to Nico and Bianca, the latter glaring at him while Nico flinched.

Percy knelt down, looking into Nico's eyes. “I'm sorry Nico. I didn't want to hurt you. But you see this?” He asked, holding his mothers soul orb up. “This is my mother. Your father held her captive, due to a misunderstanding. I had nothing to bargain with that I could stand to lose. So I had to use both of you.”

His helmet disappeared, showing his eyes. They were hard, but had a certain softness to them. “I'm sorry that I had to do that. I'll understand if you both resent me for that.” Percy said. “But at least I brought you to your dad, didn't I?” He said, standing up.

“W-where are you going?” Bianca asked, looking up at him as his helmet appeared again.

“I'm going up top. Got to fight our cousin. You two are staying down here, to learn how to use your powers. And, hopefully, to bond with your dad.” Percy said.

“Wait!” Hades called, making Percy look back at him. “What about security? If Cerberus won't be here anymore, who will help guard the underworld?”

“I never said she would be leaving.” Percy said. “I'd be willing to let her stay, if you actually take care of her this time. It doesn't have to be anything fancy, but at least let her have a few breaks for play time. I'm sure she would love to play fetch still.” He said, looking right at Cerberus, her triangular ears perked. “Right?”

“Play! Fetch!” She said, her playful personality showing, her bluish eyes sparkling at the prospect of playing.

“See?” Percy asked. “But I'll also supply some of my more powerful wraiths. Good thing about them compared to this world is that they don't complain. They just follow orders.” Percy said, snapping his fingers.

Instantly, several skeletons shot up from the ground. They looked like Hades undead servants, but they only wore armor. Said armor was rusted, with blood stains and gaping holes in the armor. It only carried a sword, looking like basic infantry for an old army, before guns. It was a nasty looking cleaver, also rusted and stained with blood.

The next one was almost the same as the first, but it wore heavier armor that was less damaged, as well as a helmet. It carried an even bigger sword then the infantry.

The third one was dressed in lighter armor then the bulky one, but more then the first one. It held a musket, seemingly made of hollowed out bones.

The last one was drastically different. It had a robe, and wielded a scythe. It looked like the typical grim reaper. It's skull showed under the hood, bleached bones spattered with blood. It's grin seemed very... off, unlike a normal skeletal grin. It screamed insanity in the dead being. Even it's eyes followed suit, the empty sockets somehow shining with insane glee. The weapon it held was jagged, and it's bony fingers held it with intent to use it on anything they could.

“You four will grab the strongest under your command.” Percy said, already delegating orders. It wouldn't do anything to greet them with any pleasantries. “You will be stationed here. Reapers will take the fields of Punishment. Go.” He ordered. The robed one bowed, bones rattling as he sank back into the ground. Even that sounded like insane laughter.

“The rest of you will provided security where it is needed. Commanders will have platoons of twenty skeletons each, and you will regularly patrol the underworld looking for souls trying to escape, and trouble makers. You are by no means to enter Elysium, under no circumstances at all. Go” He ordered. The sword baring skeletons bowed, jamming their swords into the ground as they did so. They too sunk into the ground.

“And the musketeers will provide extra support at the gates. You will watch for runners, and shoot to capture. Now go.” Percy said, dismissing the final skeleton. It raised the musket high up in the air as it sank into the ground.

Everyone was looking at what Percy did, even the Fates and Hades.

“Percy, how-” Annabeth started to ask.

“After I killed the Forgotten god, the dead pledged to serve me. Simple as that.” Percy said. “The dead come from that world, so don't worry. And, even as we speak, more and more people die of natural causes. I gave strict orders for Rose, Velvet or Jewel to not attack anyone. Collect taxes, yes, but no killing.”

Everyone just... nodded. They really couldn't do anything else. Well, Annabeth, Grover, Nico, Bianca, Hades and the Fates did. The others didn't care if Percy had done that.
