And Corpse Breath would have been mad at both of them because he doesn't know who stole his helm.” He said. “Though I don't know how you knew I had the helm.” He said, taking a ski mask out of his pocket. He set it on his handle bars, making it turn into an elaborate bronze helm.

“Yeah, well I don't give a damn what you planned you fuck.” Percy said, walking towards him, Grover behind him. “What I care about is kicking your ass. I know you won't give me the helm. Oh, and Phosphora is pissed at you for tampering with her home.” Percy said.

“Phosphora?” Ares asked. “Don't know who that is, but she sounds hot.”

“Oh she's hot alright.” Percy said, vanishing for a second, reappearing with the master bolt sheath. “Hot enough to glass half the continent, at least.” Percy said.

“What?” Ares asked, obviously not understanding.

“She's the master bolt you moron!” Percy said. “She wants to fry you personally for messing with the magic of the sheath.”

Ares growled. “Call me a moron one more time Jackson.” He said, his glasses melting. “I dare ya.”

“Moron. Fool. Idiot. Retarded monkey. Fucking stupid.” Percy said. “Gonna do something about it?”

More and more sand turned to glass around Ares, the air getting hotter and hotter. Several feet away, a surf board stuck in the sand burst into flames.

A boar erupted from beneath the glass, sending shards of it everywhere, some bouncing off of Percy's armor. Grover was safely behind Percy, so he wouldn't get hurt.

“That's your target Grover. You deal with the boar, and I'll mess with Ares. I believe in you G-man.” Percy said, running at Ares, leaving Grover to fend for himself.

Percy vaulted over the giant boar, stomping the glass back into sand as he landed. The boar didn't stop charging, going right for Grover. “Screw you Percy!” He yelled as he brought out his new pipes.

Ares smirked at Percy. “Going to leave your friend to die?” He asked tauntingly.

“Nope.” Percy said. “I know that Grover can beat that undercooked barbeque easily.”

“You know, I'm surprised.” Ares admitted, his atomic explosions for eyes glaring heatedly at Percy. “How are you staying alive when you're so close to me? Right now you should be cooked in that tin can. Like a tuna.”

“A lot has changed Ares.” Percy said, circling Ares as he took out the master bolt and Riptide. “Everything as you know it will never be the same.”

Ares snorted, not unlike a bull or ram. “Please. You expect me to fear you?” He asked.

“You would do well to fear me, Ares.” Percy said, hearing as Grover started playing his pipes.

“Hah! That's a good one.” Ares said, slapping his leg as he laughed.

Only to have a fist meet his face, breaking his nose as he went flying back.

Ares screamed in pain, holding his nose, golden Ichor spilling down his face. “What the Fuck!”

Percy appeared over Ares, stepping on him with one foot. He slowly applied pressure, breaking ribs.

“Fear me now Ares?” Percy asked, narrowing his poisonous eyes. He held the Master bolt to Ares's throat, sparks arching to the god.

“Not even the smallest bit.” Ares aid, holding his nose.

Percy and Ares turned, hearing a pig squealing in pain. Grover was playing his pipes rapidly, large amounts of seaweed strangling the large boar, one of its legs broken.

“Yeah, Go Grover!” Percy yelled, cheering his friend on. He felt his foot heating up, as Light started shining below him. “Grover! Glasses!” Percy yelled, getting a thumbs up.

Percy looked down, at the glowing, golden Ares.

“You damn demigod! Why won't you just die!” Ares roared, grabbing Percy's leg in an effort to throw him.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Off to fight war itself

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy moved from Ares, kicking his hand hard, breaking it if the sound Ares made said anything.

“Becuase I don't feel like it!” Percy retorted, looking at Ares. The war god now stood taller then Percy, at least eight feet tall. His clothes had turned to gleaming Bronze Armor, the bat having turned into a sword in his hands.

Ares got up, using a knee to help him stand. “Fine.” He said, still holding his nose. “I'll just have to beat you to a bloody puddle then.”

Percy scoffed. “Good luck with that. One more hit and you'll be running to Olympus begging for someone to heal you.” He said. “Well, if I let you go, that is.”

“Like you could beat me.” Ares said, cracking his nose into place.

“Look at yourself Ares.” Percy said, still holding the master bolt and Riptide. “If you can't tell, I can look at your godly form. I'm not dead, so that should tell you something. And not only am I kicking your ass, but I'm doing so with no effort. Grover took care of your little pet, which you were cowardly enough to use in the first place. Face it. You lose.”

“I never lose!” Ares roared, getting to his feet and charging at Percy, attempting to skewer him.

Percy sighed. “Phosphora, would you mind?” He asked, holding the Master bolt aloft.

Ares charged blindly, heedless of the danger. All he wanted was Percy's head hanging above his fireplace. Speaking of which, he would have to get a fireplace.

Only to get the biggest shock of his life.

Ares went flying back, twitching as smoke rose from his blackened body. His armor was melted, his skin was scorched, charred.

When he hit the ground, he could do nothing but lay there. He couldn't even scream, as he wanted.

Ares let his golden form go. Well, it was more like he didn't have the energy to keep it up any longer.

Ares opened his eyes, painful as even that was. He couldn't hear anything, and he wanted to know when Jackson was coming to fight.

Only to see large, towering walls of water on every side of him, trying to crash down.

If Ares could speak, he would have said something along the lines of 'Fuck my life.' as Percy appeared above him, both weapon poised at his throat.

“You see now Ares?” Percy asked. “How powerless you are to fight me? And it's not even because of the master bolt that I won. No, that was only Phosphora's revenge. I could have done so much worse. Taken your immortality, ripped out your immortal soul, or any number of things really. I could have stolen every single memory you ever had, leaving you as helpless as a newborn baby. But I didn't.” Percy said, calming himself. “You are weak Ares. Always have been, always will be. Despite being the god of war, you never could take pain. You never planned anything. The only thing you had was strength. That alone makes you weak.”

Percy put riptide away, capping it with one hand. He lifted the master bolt away from Ares, wondering what he should do with the god now. He'd broken Ares, he knew. But should he kill him the literal way, or the metaphorical way?

On one hand, Percy would take his power fully, and his title as god of war, along with everything Ares claimed was his.

But on the other, Percy would have another ally against Olympus. It would also Change the status quo, though he wasn't sure if that was a good thing or not.

Decisions, decisions.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Breaking War

choices: Elsewhere, or stick with the group at Camp
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy placed his hand in a small pouch at his waist. “Give me the spell, tome. Gender change, level one, version one.” He said, light shooting up from the leather pouch.

Percy pulled his hand back out, holding a glowing... energy. It couldn't be described, really.

He held it up to his face, whispering words into it. Not English either, though that would have sufficed. Nor was it Latin, though that would have also sufficed.

No. Percy whispered in a language that the people of this world could not describe. It wouldn't drive them mad, as some languages he knew. But it would probably knock them out as their brains tried to comprehend the tongue that he spoke. And really, that was a blessing.

No, he was speaking a language that worked best for certain types of magic, such as the one he was currently using now. A language of complete change and magic. One that any who could use would have to tread carefully, and speak softly. It was a powerful language, that could do many things when used in whispers.

And Percy was currently using it to empower the spell in his hand.

That was another thing. Percy had learned how to take the pure form of magic from spells, incantations and the like. That, coupled with the boots enhancing any and all thief like skills he might pick up during his immortal life, allowed him to steal the magic energy that anyone used against him. Useful didn't begin to describe it.

The previous overlord learned that the hard way.

But, holding the raw energy of magic also had other uses, as well. It was more powerful then the 'refined' magic that almost every mortal and most godly beings used, if harder to control. But that also allowed many previous rules to be circumvented, with the right preparation, and normal limits of magic to be easily passed. Combined with the language he was using...

Let's just say that not even Ares would remember being, well, him.

Percy ceased his whispering, holding the, now wild, energy in his hands. It was kept firmly in his grasp though, no chance of it escaping. He flicked it at the charred, broken body of Ares.

Quickly, but not yet instantly, the energy engulfed the broken god, shielding what was happening from sight.

Percy ignored that though, knowing it would take some time, and the bodily damage would need to be repaired still. He held up the Master bolt, looking directly at it. “See? Told you I would be able to handle you soon Enough Phosphora. And I delivered as promised, frying the war god. Now, just a little demonstration for Zeus, and we should be good. Might involve even more time travel, but that hardly phases me anymore.” He said, knowing he couldn't hear the female personification of the most powerful weapon in the world. “Better get you back to you home, and bring Ares back up top.”

In a flash, everything in that area that didn't belong there was gone, the waters crashing down.

Percy reappeared back on the beach, Master bolt and Ares in hand. Metaphorically for Ares, of course.

Grover was standing next to a large pile of monster dust, a strange seaweed sculpture growing from the ground.

“Hey! How'd it go?” Percy asked, making Grover look up from his pipes.

Grover shrugged. “Better then I thought it would. The boar didn't land a single hit. What about you?” He asked.

“Well, I've got fried War god. I think I broke Ares, showing him that he wasn't as bad as he thinks he is.” Percy said.

“You kill him?” Grover asked.

“Nah. Something in my mind I consider far worse. Remember when you joked about waking up as a girl?” Percy asked. Man, did that feel so long ago.

Grover went wide eyed. “You didn't...” He said, making Percy jerk a thumb at the glowing form of Ares.

“It's happening right now. I figured another ally would do us good.” Percy said. “And don't worry. I only use that when I think someone truly deserves it. You're not losing your manhood, unless you do something absolutely horrible.”

“Warning taken.” Grover said, covering his groin. “So, what's going to happen to hi- er, her?”

“Eh, don't really know. When Ares goes female, he's not going to remember ever being male in the first place. The new woman will probably still have the same personality, but she'll rewrite her own history in her head. That much I do know. But I'll be able to do something if she tries to do anything funny.” Percy said, with a shrug. “Anyway, I'm going to go get the Sheath for Phosphora, grab Annabeth, Melum and Styx, and we can leave.”

“What about Echidna?” Grover asked.

“She'll meet us at camp in a few weeks.” Percy said. “She's going to help train the campers for war. I might pop in to grab Medusa though.”

Grover nodded. He didn't want to know why Percy would grab Medusa, his Satyr mind instantly going the route into the gutter. But, Grover had some inkling that sexual reasons might not have been the only thing Percy had planned.

Percy vanished, reappearing a few moments later with Melum, Annabeth and Styx. The Master bolt was nowhere to be seen, though Percy was wearing the backpack. “Now everyone come on. I'm going to drop everyone off at Camp. Annabeth, I want you to ask Chiron to heal up our new ally. Nectar and ambrosia, lots of it. Melum, I want you to take control of the minions and make sure they aren't running rampant. Styx, you'll stick with me. We'll be heading up to Olympus together. You can chew out Zeus and My father then.” He said, taking total command. “Any objections?”

He received a raised eyebrow from Grover, as if thinking 'You really think I'm going to object?' Otherwise no one objected.

“No? Alright then.” Percy said, as the scenery shifted around them. “Camp Half-blood. Annabeth, I'll take my mother's soul now.” Percy said, eerily calm about the subject matter.

Annabeth carefully handed the golden fire to Percy, which he in turn held with an even greater care. He looked down at the small, flickering flame, a great happiness shining in his eyes.

But there was also... indecisiveness. He seemed to be deep in thought about something important, looking at that fire.

Strangely enough, the sound of cheers and shouts sounded. This was enough to bring him from his trance.

“Someone, put that,” He said, pointing at the energy cocoon on the floor. “On the bed. That would be the minions, making all that noise. Someone go make sure they haven't started a bonfire made of the campers or anything.”

“But I thought you said you quelled their destructive nature?” Annabeth said, looking at Percy.

“Well, given how many magical items are here, I don't know. Makes them crazy, and monstrous, when they come into contact with magic that isn't my own, or the tower heart's.” He said. “Haven't learned how to control that yet. And until I have them attuned to more magic through the tower heart, specifically the magic of this universe, it will be a hazard to leave them unsupervised for much longer. Who knows what the mist could do to them.”

Melum nodded. “As you wish it, Master, it shall be done.” She said, quickly leaving through the door.

Grover looked away for a second, hearing what sounded like a scream. When he looked back at where Percy had been, the demi/semi god was already gone.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy and Styx appeared at the entrance of Olympus, just outside the elevator from the Empire State building.

Percy looked at Olympus with disdain. Every time he had been here, he was in a life-threatening situation. Mostly from the gods, wondering if they should just kill him for being the child of Poseidon.

Arguing from the top of the floating mountain peak could be heard, even down there.

Percy sighed. “We better go. It seems that the gods are about to go to war.” He said to Styx. He followed, his armored boots making loud clanking sounds as he walked up Olympus.

As he passed, Nymphs and Satyrs hid from his intimidating presence. But Percy knew they were there. Well, the Nymphs at least. But he knew that where Nymphs were, Satyrs were never far behind.

As he and his companion trudged farther up the mountain, the arguing got louder, and the residents of Olympus seemed more on edge. Like they were waiting for the inevitable to happen, they just didn't know when it would explode into all-out war.

It didn't take long, maybe half an hour or so, to reach the summit. Percy was able to make out the words clearly now... well, he had back done there, but now it was even clearer.

However, all noise ceased as his boots clanged on the steps, echoing throughout the large throne room.

As Percy stepped into sight of the gods, all eyes turned towards him. Even Hestia, who was tending her hearth.

It was a uneasy silence, as the gods were wondering who the armored figure was.

Zeus in his pinstriped suit, sitting on his throne of pure platinum, narrowed his eyes at Percy. “Who are you, who would walk into the throne room of the gods?” He demanded.

“Someone who just did you a favor.” Percy said, holding up the backpack. “Catch.”

With that, he flung the backpack across the room, directly at Zeus.

Zeus caught it, looking at it with a raised eyebrow.

“Well, open it!” Percy said. Did someone really have to explain things, simple things, to Zeus?

Now, normally Zeus, or any of the gods currently there, though Ares did go missing, would have killed the man who dared talk down to them, but they were Curious. What could the man be? He didn't seem to have the power of a god, but he seemed utterly unconcerned about where he was. What could he have brought for Zeus? And who was the woman behind him?

Zeus unzipped the backpack, looking in. The only sign of him being surprised was the slight widening of his eyes.

“Everyone, save for Poseidon, leave.” Zeus commanded. “Now.”

The gods looked at one another, before they all vanished. Something was happening, but their king had commanded them away. Even Hestia left her hearth, the fire seeming less welcoming as it crackled.

Zeus pulled the Master bolt from the backpack, no longer the cylinder capped with bronze. It was a twenty foot javelin of pure lighting, making the air in the throne room charged with energy.

Zeus looked at Percy again. “I'll ask you again. Who are you?”

Percy lifted his helmet off, his face hard as he looked at both Zeus and his Father. “I am Perseus Jackson. The one you falsely accused of stealing your bolt.”

Zeus bristled. “I accuse those who are guilty, boy.” He said, looking down on Percy, even from across the throne room.

“And I am here to say that I am not guilty.” Percy shot back.

Zeus was about to retort, likely with a barrage of lighting bolts following his words, but Poseidon spoke.

“Tell us your story, boy.” The god of the sea said. “I would like to know why my son looks like a trained warrior.”

“You would still claim him then?” Zeus asked, looking at his brother. “You would claim to have sired a child against our sacred oaths?”

The woman next to Percy bristled, about to say something, but Percy held up a hand to calm her.

“I've admitted to my wrong doing. Now I think we should hear him speak.” Poseidon said, looking back at Percy. It was not unnoticed that both gods stole glances at Styx, eying her like meat.

So, Percy told them a little about what had happened. Most of it lies, or at least half-truths. Lies about Melum entirely, such as her being a goddess from before Gaea's time. As such, he was her only connection to the world that kept her from fading (Not entirely untrue, thinking back on it.) She had helped train him, singing so beautifully that time halted in it's flow to listen.

Percy could see their minds working to think about wooing the goddess, but only for her power. It disgusted Percy. He may have been Lust incarnate, a womanizer and the Overlord of evil... but even he still had standards.

Anyway, he told them about his quest, the dreams he remembered having (Another thing the Eronomicon improved, his memory) about Kronos (Without naming the titan lord of course), Ares Betrayal (Only the fight with him, not what had happened to the war god after) and all that. He held back certain topics, such as anything having to do with the Eronomicon, his various relationship's, the servitude of Athena, Medusa or the deal with Hades.

Zeus scratched his beard, flakes of electricity sparking out of it. “I sense he tells the truth. That would also explain why Ares left on his own during the... meeting...” He said, looking side-long at his brother. “But these dreams...”

Zeus and Poseidon spoke quickly, in ancient Greek. Percy didn't bother listening in. He knew Zeus would deny it being his Father, rising again from the deepest pits of Tartarus.

Zeus held up his hand angrily. “We will speak of this no more.” He said, standing up. “I shall go to purify this in the waters of Lemnos. That should cleanse the human taint.”

Percy scoffed. 'Human taint... please. He's just being all high and mighty about being a god again. It's not like it's corrupted or anything.'

“Actually, Lord Zeus.” Percy said, trying to be civil with an extremely uncivil person. “I've also brought someone else here, as you can see.” Percy said, motioning to Styx. “She would like to talk with you, both of you.”

Styx glared at both of the gods, making them shudder for an unknown reason.

“And... who may that be?” Poseidon asked.

Styx scoffed loudly. “Well, I'm surprised that you don't remember me. You always use my name, but never actually hold to it.”

Percy nodded to the three of them. “I'll leave you to it.” He said, before looking straight at Styx. “You're welcome to come by my house when you're done here. I'll try and air out the garbage.”

With that, Percy turned to walk away. He was barely down the steps when Styx began chewing the gods out.

It brought a smile to Percy's face.

He looked at the small orb in his hands again. He remembered having the same choice, long ago. At camp, with Clarisse. But now, with his own mother, he had little idea of what to do.

Should he include her into his Harem? Would that be another great betrayal, Like Thalia? To manipulate her so? Had she heard everything he had spoken of with Hades? Was she aware of what he was doing now?

Percy sighed. Too many thoughts. This wasn't something he could just ask her though. But the more important question plaguing his mind was if she were in a similar situation like Medusa. He didn't know. But if she was...

He'd be the True god of the Sea far sooner then planned...

Percy walked down the path to the elevator, ignoring the now more active residents of the mountain. They sensed that whatever problem was brewing with the twelve major gods was quelled, for now. They hadn't heard about the master bolt being stolen. No, Zeus wouldn't allow that knowledge to go free.

The weaker beings still coward at his mere presence, hiding as he passed. He had put his helmet back on as he left the throne room, so no one could see his face. His cape bellowed in the wind, striking an imposing figure.

But Percy smirked again. 'Phosphora will stick to the plan, I hope. Just a few years, until the end of this damned war. Then she can be free of Zeus.' He thought. 'As will we all.'

Percy looked at the ball of flame in his hands, his mothers soul. “Well, time to get you home...” He said, vanishing in front of the elevator.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Hollywood, five minutes later

“Hey.” Percy said, making Medusa jump. She hadn't even felt his presence. “Whoa, it's just me.” He said, putting a hand on her shoulder.

Medusa calmed, hearing his voice and feeling his touch. “Oh, Percy.” She said, placing a hand on her heart. “You scared the life out of me.”

“Sorry.” Percy said, pulling her into a hug. “I was wondering if you minded coming along to my old house. Help me with something...” He said, holding her close.

Medusa sighed happily, melting into his arms. “Anything. You know that.” She said, before looking up at him. “But why didn't you just keep me around then?” She asked, taking note he was out of armor now.

“Because I didn't want my Father figuring out who you are.” Percy said, sitting in a chair, never letting go of Medusa. “This is a nice hotel you got here.” He said, looking around.

“Yes, well, I didn't want to live in the back alleys. Echidna and the others may have monstrous strength, among other attributes, but all I have is my eyes. If someone covered my eyes, I'd be powerless.” She explained.

Percy nodded, smoothing her hair. “So I take it that they're going to be staying in the less human friendly areas of town then.” Percy stated. “Well, that's fine. If that is what they want, then that's fine. I just hope that Echidna doesn't sacrifice anymore people to gather her children. But enough about that. Shall we go?” He asked.

“One moment, let me grab the gift you gave me.” She said, prying herself from his arms. She sauntered over to the bed, hips swaying a tad more then normal. She bent down, her dress tightening around her shapely rump as she crawled onto the bed.

“Are you trying to seduce me?” Percy asked, raised eyebrow.

“Perhaps...” Medusa aid, wiggling her hips some more. Percy's eyes followed them, something she took pride in. “Is it working?”

“It would be...” Percy said, standing up. “But, unfortunately we don't have time for that.”

Medusa pouted. “Fine...” She said, grabbing her new Staff off the pillows. “Let's go then.”

“I'll have you back before long.” Percy said, grabbing Medusa tightly once more. The area around them turned black, a pure void of all color's, sounds, and sensations. Everything but his body against hers.

Medusa shivered, pulling herself even closer to him. Whatever this place was, she didn't like it.

Buildings melted into existence before her eyes. It looked like a run down part of Manhattan. Even the sounds, suddenly louder then she would expect, were that of the city. A much different state of being then that black void.

“Gabe, please. I'm tired, and I don't know what's going on.” A voice said, sounding both confused and sleepy. “Just... please let me go to bed.”

“Oh no.” A nasty voice said, one that made Medusa recoil at the sound. And the stench of the place... even monsters would avoid this place like the plague. “You've been gone for a month. That means you've got a months paycheck to make up on. You will get your ass out there and work, now!”

Percy used all his self control to keep himself from going in there and killing Gabe in the most brutal way he could. It wasn't worth it, it would scare his mother back to Hades, and he didn't want anything the bastard might have had if he killed him.

“I think I know why you called me here now.” Medusa said, covering her nose. The stench from this close to the door was repugnant, and she almost lost her lunch.

Percy nodded, his jaw tightened so hard he couldn't speak. If his teeth were any less strong as they were, they would have broken.

Sally sighed, something that was audible from outside. “Yes... Okay Gabe. I'll get going then...” She said, resigned to what was happening.

Percy nodded at Medusa as he walked forward. It took everything he had not to bust down the door as he knocked. Cracks did erupt along the door though.

“What the hell?” Gabe said. “Who the hell's banging on my door right now? Sally, get that.”

There was the sound of footsteps, then the rattle of the door knob, and the squeaking of the hinges as it opened.

Sally Jackson stopped at her doorway, looking up at Percy with very little recognition in her eyes.

“Yes?” She asked, stifling a yawn. “Can I help you?”

Percy unclenched his jaw, seeing his mother alive and well. Not just in a soul ball form either. But moving around of her own accord. “It's me mom. Percy.” He said.

“What?” She asked, blinking. “You must be mistaken. Percy's-”

She stopped, looking at the man again. While he may not have been her little boy, she noticed that he had qualities that she figured he would have later on in life. Except for the being extremely tall part. That same unruly black hair, those same sea green eyes, that tanned skin that he always had...

“It's a long story mom...” Percy said. “But first I need to do something. C'mon Em.”

“Percy, wha-” She said, only to have Percy gently move her away, Medusa following closely behind.

“Who's at the door Sally?” Gabe called, never getting up from the couch. He looked at Percy, his eyes widening. “Jesus fuck! Who the hell are you! Get outta my house!” He said, leaping up in a surprising display of any movement at all.

Percy said nothing, walking closer to the fat bastard with a death glare. Said bastard was backing away, trudging through ankle high garbage, knocking over beer cans and all round almost failing to stay upright.

This man, he could never forget. A horrible person in general, even in public, his tormentor for the times he was home before his demigod life began, and worst of all in Percy's eyes, the abuser of his mother. Oh yes, that was something he never forgot. Not even before this new mess started with the Eronomicon.

“Stop! I-I'll call the cops!” Gabe said, bumping against a wall.

Percy still said nothing, merely watching as Gabe slid to the floor, a slightly fouler odor emanating from the man now.

“Fine!” He cried, trembling. “Take whatever you want! The TV, the food, my beer... My wife!”

A fist planted itself elbow deep in the wall above his head. Percy's eyes were glowing dangerously as the air wrapped around his other hand, a terrifyingly visible effect, causing cracks to appear mid air as he clenched it into a fist.

“Pathetic.” Medusa said, holding her dress up as she tried to step around any garbage. It wasn't easy in her high heels, but she made due. “Such a disgusting human is real?” She asked, her amethyst orbs reflecting her disgust as she looked down at the man.

“Medusa...” Percy said, his voice deep and rumbling, completely different to his regular voice. The area around him darkened, and the armor slowly bled into existence across his body. His eyes were turning that poisonous shade of green again, his pupils glaring, like spotlights upon Gabe Ugliano. And... was that a tremor in the wall?

“I understand.” She said.

“Please!” Gabe said, openly sobbing now. He didn't like what was happening, and it didn't seem like it would end well for him. So, he did the only thing he knew how to do with people that were better then him.

Beg and plead and grovel, then if he lived, curse their very names. This situation would warrant a call to the police as well.

“Please! Don't hurt me!” Gabe pleaded.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“And why should I let you plead?” Percy barked. “Useless fucks like you, thinking your top of the world for no god damned reason! Think you're all high and mighty because you hit women? Threaten kids? Huh?” Percy asked, lashing out.

Honestly, it was a miracle Gabe didn't explode.

“AAH! Fuck!” Gabe cried, clutching his stomach. Internal bleeding was a certainty, and unrepairable. Most likely didn't have some organs left to fix. He coughed, sending blood all over the trash.

“Well guess what! That karma is a real bitch!” Percy said, stomping on a knee, making Gabe cry out again. His knee caps were likely dust, the area already swelling with blood.

“Where's your power now?” Percy asked, roughly picking Gabe up by his tear stained shirt. “Where is it? Where's that power you loved flexing now?”

Gabe just couldn't speak, and he was losing consciousness fast. He was starting to feel light headed, color draining from his face. He felt heavy... but also light. Percy's words were fading, like his vision. It was all blurring...

He looked behind Percy, seeing something beyond his attacker...

Large flames rose up from nowhere, and he heard mad cackling. It was getting clearer and clearer as Percy faded.

Percy looked, seeing the light fade slowly from Gabe's eyes. “Oh no you don't.” Percy whispered. “Medusa, now. Do it now.”

Percy dropped Gabe down, his body landing in a heap. He knelt down, moving Gabe to Face Medusa.

As those flames moved closer, the last thing Gabe saw was a flash of purple before it all went dark.

Percy stood up, looking at the grotesque statue. It wouldn't be good for anything. Maybe gravel, but even that was a stretch.

“P-p-percy...” Sally's voice asked, thoroughly disturbed by what she just saw.

Percy looked back, seeing his mother looking at them with wide eyes, shaking like a leaf in the wind. Her face was pale, and her back was against the wall near the kitchen.

“Mom...” Percy said. The dark aura vanished, his armor following suit. The cracks in the air disappeared. He pulled his arm from the wall, part of the dry wall falling on Gabe's stone body. His eyes turned back into their natural sea-green, looking at his mother with concern.

'Damn it.' He thought, scolding himself. 'It happened again, didn't it. I blanked out. Damned rage. Damned ruthlessness! My mother shouldn't have seen that. I need to stay in control! But it's so damned hard with people who push all the wrong buttons!'

Percy took a step forward, walking with his head hung down. He slowly walked towards his unmoving mother, not even saying a word.

Sally, for her part, couldn't move. Her mind was trying to process what had happened. All she could do, was watch as the thing that claimed to be her son approached, shaking. Her body wanted to run, her mind agreeing, but she just couldn't move.

She looked up, keeping her eyes on the monsters face as it stood before her. It towered over her, casting a shadow.

If she could think clearly, she probably would have thought something cliched. Probably along the lines of 'this is it, huh...' or 'Is this the end?' But she couldn't even think that. Not with this hulking figure looming above her.

“I'm sorry you had to see that.” The monster whispered, leaning down slightly to wrap his mom in a hug. He hugged tight, picking her up off the ground. It only took a few more seconds, but she went limp in his arms. He sighed.

“What should we do?” Medusa asked, looking around.

“I'm smashing the statue.” Percy said. “And then we're torching the place. No one will think twice about it, if the supervisor knew what's happening here.” He cast a look at all the trash. Even in the kitchen too, ankle high garbage.

“Where will we take her?” Medusa asked, looking at Percy's mom.

“Camp half-blood first, to explain things to her when she wakes up. Then, we'll see where she wants to go. I'll give her the means to do whatever she wants.”

Medusa nodded. She started to ask something, but she paused. Was it right to ask something like that?

But Percy heard her stop mid breath. He knew that sound, distinct as it was from other breaths. He knew she wanted to say something. “What is it Medusa?”

Medusa fidgeted, but opened her mouth again. “Will she be... joining us?” She asked, waiting for a rebuttal.

“I don't know yet, Medusa.” Percy said, sighing as he looked at his mothers face, ignoring the floating words above her. “I don't know yet.”

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy stood on top of a building, watching as the apartment belched out smoke. The sounds of sirens were already getting closer, and a large gathering of people were watching.

No one who lived near the apartment was left inside, all part of the crowd. No one noticed how there was a part of the sidewalk that was cracked and indented, as if something had gone through it.

“No one's going to die in that fire. Good.” Percy said, looking down at his mother again.

“Those minions do a good job...” Medusa said, looking at the billowing smoke. “Nothing in that place is going to survive.”

“What the minions can do, they're the best at. I'm still surprised that becoming what they are now had such a profound effect on them. Increased mental capabilities, durability, and aptitude for what they do. Honestly, they're probably the best army to have.”

Medusa nodded. “It seems that way, if what you said during your tale is any indication. How many conquerors would beg to have an army like that. Working together perfectly, taking any orders they receive, a willingness to die for their leader...”

“Something I try not to make them do.” Percy said. “Well, at least not before killing my predecessor for the title of Overlord. Didn't mind tossing them into a boiling cauldron when they were foul little imps. My armor is really useful. Extremely durable on it's own, but with certain modifications...” He said, trailing off.

Medusa rolled her eyes. “Yes, yes. I'd love to hear about your smithing and magical crafting prowess and all, but I think we need to get going. Your mother looks like she needs a nice bed to sleep in. And we don't want to get caught.” She said.

Percy nodded, shifting his mother slightly in his arms. He held her gently, wondering something once more.

“Yes... perhaps that would work.” He said to himself, before vanishing with Medusa from the roof top.

~Camp Half-Blood

Percy and Medusa appeared in the room with the energy covered Ares. The glow was starting to die down, and the cocoon seemed thinner then before.

“Seems like Ares, or whatever name she gives herself, will be awakening soon.” Percy said, walking to the door with Medusa following close behind.

Percy walked down a few doors, opening it to find another guest room/makeshift hospital room. Not as good as the ones in Apollo cabin, but still good for just recovering.

Entering, he placed his mother on the bed. He knew from experience that they were comfy. He pulled the blanket over her, looking down at her sleeping face.

“Medusa, watch over her.” Percy said, making the woman nod. “I'm going to go quell the situation outside.”

He knelt down, kissing his mothers forehead as he strode from the room. He stopped, just before leaving though.

“For what it's worth Medusa, I want to thank you for everything you've done for me.” Percy said, not looking back before he vanished around the corner.

Medusa watched him go, pulling up a chair. She felt happy that he didn't just think of her as a tool, a possession. Though, she had a feeling that even if she did, she wouldn't have cared.

He thanked her. His voice was quite sincere as well, without his special rituals or seals or whatever. He sincerely thanked her.

But she still shook her head. “You fool. I can never repay you. This is the least I can do.” She said, before turning her attention to the unconscious woman. She too wondered if Sally Jackson was like her, in terms of their relationship with the sea god.

~

Percy threw open the front door to the Big House, taking a quick survey of what he saw.

Minions, all accounted for. Campers tied up, and a large burning... something behind them. That must have been the fire he heard earlier.

“Perseus Jackson!” Chiron's voice called, the centaur galloping up to Percy from the forest. “You will tell me what is going on right now or-”

“Or you'll what, Chiron?” Percy asked, leveling a glare. The minions readied their weapons, ready to beat the horsey-man to death.

Percy shook his head, gesturing for the minions to stand down. “Sorry about that. Just had a very bad anger issue a little bit ago.” He explained. “But I'll tell you what is going on in a bit. Melum! Clarrise!”

Immediately, the two were in front of him. Neither looked winded after their dead-sprint to him.

Clarisse whistled upon seeing him, looking him up and down with approving eyes. “Now you look like someone I could be proud to be a servant of.” She said, giving him a thumbs up.

Percy and Chiron both raised eyebrows. “You're not curious as to why I look like this?” Percy asked.

“Nah.” Clarrise said with a shrug. “One of the robed women told me that you were a powerful warrior now. Surprised they knew I was a retainer of yours.”

“Yeah, they can sense that type of thing. Apparently serving under me leave a mark or imprint on your soul.” Percy said. “Any problems Mel?”

The goddess shook her head. “No. Only one camper tried to do something after most of the fighting was quelled. That was the scream you likely heard earlier.” She said. “He's being taken care of right now.”

Percy nodded. “Good, good. Chiron, did Annabeth come see you?”

The centaur blinked. When did Percy become a leader of some sort? “Uh, yes. She did. Asking for the ambrosia and nectar storage. She said that someone was horribly hurt.”

Percy nodded again, closing his eyes. “Good. We're going to need that when our special guest wakes up.”

Chiron opened his mouth to speak, but Percy held up his hand. “Just wait for half an hour Chiron. Once I deal with this, I have something else to deal with, then we can talk.”

Percy stepped up to the railing of the porch. “Camp Half-blood!” Percy said, calling out to the conscious campers that were tied up. He didn't know where they got the rope, but he wasn't going to call anyone out on it.

“The war that was building on Olympus has been averted! When you are released, you will go to your cabins! Make no trouble, or there will be consequences!” Percy said, before gesturing at Melum and Clarisse. “Start cutting them loose. Make sure there is no trouble. If they start, break an arm or something. Make sure they don't think we're messing around.”

“Perseus, what are yo-”

“I will not allow this camp to be torn apart Chiron. Not over petty squabbles.” Percy said, interrupting the centaur.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy turned to re-enter the Big House, when pained yell and squelch sounded, reaching his ears. Percy turned around, since the pained yell was definitely one of the minions.

One of the blues had a dagger going through her heart, stabbed by the camper she had freed. It seemed to be a boy from Hermes cabin, though he didn't look like the roguish god. Probably an unclaimed kid.

Rage boiled in Percy. No one did that to his girls! NO ONE!

The minions around the boy were about to pounce on him, as more robed women hurried to their sister. The stabbed woman had already fallen to the ground, unmoving. She was dragged back, away from him.

The camper got up, going to run for the armory.

“STOP!” A voice roared, shaking the ground. Everyone froze, save for the blues as they desperately tried to save their sister.

All eyes turned to Percy, who was once more clad in his armor. But it was different. It was pitch black, sucking in light, like a black hole.

“BROWNS! DETAIN HIM!” Percy shouted, again shaking the ground.

Immediately, several of the brown-eyed women jumped on the camper, pinning him down. He tried to struggle, his demigod blood and ADHD trying to make him get up and fight.

Percy walked from the door, the wood cracking under his feet. The steps broke, his foot falls heavy on the wooden boards.

No one said anything, the only sounds that of Percy's armor and the campers struggles.

Even the ground cracked. As he passed, the minions bowed, any who were in his way moving to the side, pulling campers out of his way.

Good thing too, since Percy was causing some serious damage to the hard, packed earth.

Soon enough, Percy stood over the struggling boy.

“Hold him up. I want to see him kneel.” He said, quietly.

Moving quickly, the minions propped the boy up, on his knees with his hands behind his back.

Percy crouched down, looking the boy directly in the eyes. He could see the fear, yet the sheer audacity to do what he did shown as some type of pride.

On the campers part, he would have screamed if he could. He couldn't see anything about Percy's face. It was a void, nothing but black. It didn't help that all the light around him seemed to die down.

It was quiet for a bit, as Percy stared into the campers eyes without blinking, not even moving. It was like he turned into a statue.

“How is she?” Percy asked suddenly, making the camper flinch.

A blue sighed. “She is gone, Master. Stabbed right through the heart with one of these bronze daggers. For some reason, we cannot heal it as we normally could.” She said, looking sadly at the corpse of her sister.

Percy growled, a terrifying sound. Like a hell hound would appear and kill the camper on the spot. “Take her back down the minion gate. Take her to Morticia, and have her use one of those prisoners to resurrect her. I won't be losing any of you, especially not to some upstart punk.” He ordered, making the blue nod. The robed ones picked up their sibling, taking her back to the tunnels.

No one said anything still, as Percy never took his eyes off the camper. Chiron wanted to speak, but he just... couldn't. For some reason, he just couldn't.

It was a few more minutes before Percy spoke again. The camper was starting to sweat.

“So, you think you are hot stuff huh?” Percy asked, unnervingly calm. “Think you're some big damned hero for stabbing someone who cannot defend themselves in an attempt to get away from nothing but going back to the cabins?”

“W-W-Wha-”

“Don't talk.” Percy said, still unnaturally calm voiced. Even some of the minions fidgeted at that tone. Nearly every camper already did. “So you think you're in the big leagues now?”

“I-I”

“I said, don't talk.” Percy said again. “Do you know that you killed someone who healed sick people? Dying people? Children?” He asked, still calm.

“N-no...”

“No, you didn't.” Percy said. “May I ask, why, you did that?”

“B-because she w-was an i-invader...”

In a flash, a hand was gripping his face, hard. “You think that's an excuse do you?” Percy asked, still calm. “Tell me, other then detain you all to keep you from fighting a pointless fight, what did any of these women do?” Percy asked, gesturing to the minions.

“N-nothing...” He said, his face starting to hurt very badly.

“Ah, I see. So, other then make sure you guys didn't kill each other, they did nothing wrong. And she deserved to die for that.” Percy said, still that unnatural calm voice.

And then the laugh... oh gods, the laugh.

It started low, with no mirth or joy to it. But it was a real laugh alright.

A laugh of insanity, that is.

“Do you hear that Minions?” Percy asked, never halting his laughing. “You did nothing, so you deserve to die!”

The laughing grew louder. “Isn't that nice? For all the trouble you went through, you have to die!”

The laughing grew louder still, and even Melum was starting to feel some type of fear, though hers was for her masters sanity.

Then the minions began to laugh, along with Percy. That same insanity tinged their otherwise normal voices.

Percy stood up, laughing still. “Isn't that rich!” He said, doubling over in laughter.

Everyone there that wasn't a Minion was starting to feel primal fear, the insanity leaking from Percy and the minions. Whatever these women looked like, they obviously weren't human.

And then, it stopped. Everything was silent. Almost as if it was rehearsed or something.

But it wasn't rehearsed, not at all.

All the minions looked at the lone camper, making him squirm once more.

Percy crouched again.

“I'll show you what happens when you kill a woman and I learn about it.” He said calmly, as if he hadn't just had a psychotic episode of laughter. “Especially when she has done no wrong.”

The camper opened his mouth to say something, but it was cut off by screams.

His own, to be exact.

“AHHHHH!” He screamed, his arm cut away from his body. Tears sprang forth, falling with no shame.

Percy picked up the appendage, holding Riptide in his other hand uncapped.

Percy watched as blood spurted from the campers right shoulder, tapping the ground with the arm.

Without Percy speaking, one of the scantily clad fire women walked over, placing her hand on the wound. Flames spread, cauterizing it.

“Here you go.” Percy said, offering the bloody appendage to the red. The smell of roasting flesh started to waft around the camp quickly, some campers losing their lunch.

The woman brought the arm to her mouth, taking a large bite. Her surprisingly sharp teeth tore into the flesh easily, ripping it from the bone.

She chewed, giving Percy a hug before skipping away with her meal.

The boy never stopped screaming either. No one could blame him though.

Percy looked at the boys face, unmoving, unflinching. If one could see his face as of now, it would be as stone.

“This is why you do not even think of harming a woman in my presence, much less kill one.” Percy said.

Finally, the screaming stopped, Silenced by Riptide's edge. Instantly, everyone stopped caring about the boy. They ceased caring about Percy's actions, torturing the boy.

Percy stood up, dusting his hands off after capping riptide once more.

He stopped, shaking his head. “Now, everyone, Listen carefully. When you are released, go to your cabins. Clean yourselves up. Good day.” He said, walking back to the Big House.

As he opened door, he paused. “Chiron, please try to calm the campers now, and make them cooperate right now. Melum, you help. Minions, make sure everyone stays where they need to stay. Clarisse, please come with me.” Percy said, his armor gone, having faded as he walked away from the scene of the execution.

There really was no other word for it.

Execution.

Such a horrible word, for a horrible event.

Clarisse only nodded

Percy felt something tap his shoulder. He looked over, seeing one of the Ninja girls/Green Minions. She pointed to the corpse, raising an eyebrow in silence.

“Go ahead. Feast, use it for a training dummy, I don't particularly care.” Percy said. The ninja girl bowed, turning transparent and walking away.

“You talking to one of those sneaky bitches?” Clarisse asked. Percy raised an eyebrow, turning to look at her. His eyes held a questioning gleam. “What? They look sneaky, and they weren't too nice about stopping the fighting. Thankfully those robed ones can heal.”

“Ah.” Percy said, turning around again. He started walking again, opening the door and entering the big house. “Tell me, I didn't see Castellen around. Where is he?”

Clarisse closed the door behind her, shrugging. “Dunno. I think I overheard one of the Apollo kids saying that he'd been asleep for several days. They haven't been able to figure out the reason either.”

Percy stopped for a second, thinking. “Hmm. Must be having a very long talk with the bastard right now.”

“Talk? With who?”

“Never mind that. You did good work Clarisse. You will be rewarded nicely for that.” Percy said, moving again. “But later. Right now, I have some business to attend too. And you need to meet someone, when they awake.”

Clarisse looked at Percy with a raised eyebrow. “Well, alright then. Thanks for the reward, I guess.” She said. Her mind started drifting, not of its own volition, towards thoughts of what this 'reward' could possibly have been. Given her status as Percy's “Retainer” it was no wonder her mind drifted to the bedroom.

Not that she would mind, looking at him. Percy seemed to be well built for someone who should only be twelve. Wearing armor, the blood of his enemies splattered across said armor, and being a generally imposing figure.

It made the blood of war in her burn with passion found only in the teenaged daughters of, well, a war god.

“In here.” Percy said, drawing her from her thoughts. He was holding open a door for her, with a strange cocoon on the bed. “Wait until the energy dissipates, then talk with the person. You should be able to figure out who they are soon enough. Annabeth should be back shortly with nectar and ambrosia to heal up their injuries.”

Clarisse nodded. “Alright. I'll wait I guess. Should I be civil or what?” She asked.

“I would be cautious, but be strong. This person is more like you then you may know.” Percy said, something akin to amusement in his voice.

As soon as Clarisse entered, Percy closed the door, heading back to his mothers room.

“How is she?” He asked, opening the door.

“Still unconscious.” Medusa answered from her chair. “But otherwise fine.”

Percy nodded. “Good. Good.”

He walked next to Medusa. He leaned down, giving her a quick kiss. “Thank you. I should take you back to you apartment then.”

Medusa shook her head, wrapping her arms around her love. “That can wait. I would like to spend a little more time with you, if I could?”

Percy smiled at her. “Sure. No problem at all.” He said, giving her another kiss. “But once I have an answer from my mother. And only if I don't find reason to immediately go to war with Olympus.” He said, frowning slightly.

Medusa sighed. “You sure know how to put a damper on those warm fuzzy feelings, huh.” She said. “But I understand completely.”

Percy nodded, stealing one last kiss. “I'll see you in a little bit.” He said, vanishing from Medusa's arms.

Medusa blinked. She didn't expect that. She figured he'd wait for his mother to wake up.

She shook her head, sitting down. Maybe a nap wouldn't hurt for now. She had a long day so far.

~???~

Sally was sitting at a table in her house. It was nothing fancy, just perfect for two people. Just perfect for her and her son.

It was quiet, solitary and far from the dangers of their world. Never mind Poseidon, never mind their wars, never mind horrible Gabe Ugliano.

“Hey mom, I'm home!” She heard Percy call, running through the front door.

“How was school today Percy?” She asked, sipping some coffee.

“Eh, it was okay.” Percy said, entering the kitchen to grab an after school snack. “Hate math though. Mr. Randell's boring as all heck.”

Sally laughed. “Yeah, math wasn't my favorite subject either in school.” She said. “Did anything interesting happen today?”

Percy shook his head, sitting across from his mother. “No. Why?”

“Oh, no reason.” Sally said. 'Good. That world has left us alone.' She thought, taking another sip. Only to realize she was out.

Sally shrugged, standing up to get another cup of coffee. She added a bit of creamer, and a dash of sugar.

And the blue food dye. Can never forget that.

Sally hummed as she did all this, eyes half closed at the peace of it all.

Tapping the side of her coffee cup with her spoon, she set it in the sink to wash later.

“So, Percy. Did you see any cute gir-”

*SMASH*

Coffee washed over the tile flooring, the coffee cup shattering as it fell from her hand.

Sally shook, her eyes wide in horror.

Where her little boy sat was a dark, imposing figure.

“W-who are you?” She asked. “What are you doing in my house?”

The figure looked around, ignoring her for a scant moment.

“Who are you?!” Sally asked again, reaching for a phone.

“Is this what you wished for? What you truly wanted?” The figure asked, turning his eyes back to her, freezing her in her place.

Not that the eyes held any malice. No, they didn't.

The figure stood up, a towering figure, and slowly walked to her.

Sally stood stock still. She couldn't have moved if she wanted too.

The figure stood above her, looking around again. “Is this what you want, mother?”

“I-I don't know who you are, but I am not you mother.” Sally said, trying her hardest to keep calm.

The figure sighed, closing his eyes. “It is understandable that you would deny me for what I look like. Would this be any better?” The figure asked, armor melting away into shadows.

Sally, for all her fear, gasped in wonderment.

As the dark, terrible armor faded, she could see who exactly it was that wore it.

Her little boy.

Well, not so little, really. He was older. Stronger. Perhaps a little battle-weary, to her eyes.

He towered over her, at seven feet tall. That swath of black hair he had hung just over his eyes, looking as if it hadn't seen a shower in weeks, if not longer. His face was clean shaven, not a hint of stubble. His eyes regarded her with warmth, though that only eased her mind slightly. His skin was tanned, like an islander or a surfer.

He looked so much like his father when her and Poseidon had been together. When she was younger.

But there was no mistaking it.

It was her baby boy, all grown up.

In a world where he had to fight it seemed.

Their world.

The world of gods and monsters.

“Come, mother. Sit down.” Percy said, taking his spot at the table. “There's so much we need to talk about. So much I need to tell you.”

Sally Jackson didn't move. Couldn't move. She was so busy having trouble trying to wrap her mind around what was happening.

Percy sighed, standing up. He walked over to his mom, grabbing her hand gently and walking her over to the table. She followed, an unconscious reaction to being pulled along, robotic. Percy gently pushed her into a chair, going to grab her another cup of coffee.

Setting the mug in front of her seemed to snap Sally out of it. She looked around, blinking. This wasn't her apartment...

“Hello mom.” Percy said.

Sally jumped, looking at Percy.

“Percy?” She asked, reaching a shaking hand up to try and touch him, make sure he was real.

“Yes mom. It's me.” Percy said, allowing her to touch his face.

Small table.

“B...But how?” Sally asked. “Just a few minutes ago you were my baby boy.”

Percy sighed again. “I know, I know. I saw it all before I intruded on this place.”

“Place? This place? Where are we?” She asked, feeling something akin to anxiety.

Percy looked around, taking in everything his eye caught. “Currently, we are in your mind. Specifically, a place your mind would go to as it tries to rationalize what happened in the real world, keeping you distracted in a fantasy to keep your mind from rejecting the work.”

Sally could only blink. Percy never talked like that...

“Simply put, we are in your minds safe room, if that makes any sense. Perhaps it is the subconscious, but I don't really know if that's the right name for it.” Percy said, looking around still. “And from the looks of it, you wished to be as far away from the world as possible. With me growing up normally, living a boring, but peaceful life.”

“Percy, what's going on?” Sally asked, feeling confused. Her head was starting to hurt.

“Try to relax mom. Please. I just need to talk with you, explain what's going on in the real world. Explain what happened with... Gabe...” Percy said, trying not to call the pile of rubble formerly known as Gabe Ugliano something horrible in front of his mother.

Flashes in Sally's mind. Blood, Gabe being turned to stone, Gabe crying and begging...

She gripped her head. It was painful.

“No... Percy isn't like that. My baby boy wouldn't do that.” She said, her body curling up. The pain was getting worse.

“Mom, relax.” Percy said, if a little forcefully. “You're going to hurt yourself.”

“No!” She yelled, nails digging into her head. Another image, Percy hurting Gabe, beating the man senselessly.

Gabe might have been an inhuman monster, for a human that is, but not even he deserved that.

“Mom!” Percy yelled, seeing blood start to trail down her fingers.

“Percy... No... not like that...” She said, trying to deny it.

Percy grabbed her hands, pulling them away from her head. 'Shit, this isn't good. She needs to calm down, or her mind could snap from how forcefully she rejects what happened.'

The image around them started cracking, blurring, shaking.

“Oh no.” Percy said, looking around him in horror. “No. Please no.”

A bit of reality fell away, revealing empty blackness behind it.

“Shit!” Percy said. “Gotta move fast.”

He vanished, letting the world of his mothers mind collapse around her.

~Back in the room in the big house

Medusa was just starting to fall asleep when a wild thrashing made her jump. Her eyes flew open, seeing Sally as she convulsed. The previously unconscious woman's eyes were open, looking about wildly with no focus, no recognition or understanding.

“Move!” Percy shouted, appearing next to the bed.

“What's going on?” Medusa asked, backing both her and her chair up to give him space.

“Her mind is falling apart. She cannot grasp the fact that I did what I did to the Bastard in front of her.” He said, pulling out the Eronomicon.

“C'mon... C'mon...” Percy said, flipping through the pages of the little pocket book. “I know you would have something to do something about this. Anything would work, just let me help her Damn it!”

The Eronomicon, sensing the Marked one's desire, flipped to a page in the small form it held. It would do as the Marked one asked, but maybe not in the way he expected, but it would have to do on such short notice.

Percy glanced it over, knowing the book wouldn't lead him astray. He grit his teeth in anger, but he had no choice.

“Memory Databanks!” He called, furiously and desperately. The room was engulfed in a light, quite like all the other times Percy called something out from the book or used a powerful ritual.

There was also an audible 'thud' signaling that something mildly heavy was called out.

Medusa blinked her eyes furiously, catching Percy's silhouette furiously moving and putting something on Sally's head.

When she could see again, Medusa saw that a strange machine was attached to Sally's head, securely despite her seizure. Blood poked it's way from her nose, slowly running down her face.

“Work Damn you! Work!” Percy said, drawing Medusa's attention to him. The strange helmet-like machine was connected to a computer through several thick wires. The computer was on an old, but elegant desk, made of what looked like fossilized wood. Strangely enough, it didn't seem to be connected to any source of electricity.

“Percy, what are you doing?” Medusa asked, before the door burst open.

“Percy! What's wrong?” Annabeth asked, holding a bag of Nectar that she was going to give to the new Ares. When her eyes landed on Sally, the bag dropped, spilling the food of gods on the ground.

“No time to explain!” Percy said, watching as warning symbols flashed on the moniter, but a progress bar filled up steadily. “C'mon, work.” Percy said, tapping the desk with anger evident in his voice. All he could do now was wait, and watch, and hope. He couldn't think about anything else...

78%...

85%...

92%...

100%...

A message popped up on the screen, though Sally did not stop having her seizure.

'Download complete. Please detach helmet from subject. Refer to the help menu for Uploading copied soul to a new body.'

Under that, another message popped up.

'Warning! Subject is rapidly losing all brain functions! Subject is not suitable for use!'

Percy's eyes widened in horror.

“No...” He said. Only... a copy? “No. No! No No No No NO!” Percy yelled.

He was by her bed in less then a second, grabbing her slowly stilling body. “Mom! Don't do this! Snap out of it!” He said, shaking her shoulders, wiping away the blood from her face.

~With the Chimera and Echidna

The Chimera was currently on the ground, roaring in pain and sadness. She felt a great ache in her heart, and sheer, icy terror pierced her brain. Both experiences were new to her, so they hit even harder, making the pain two-fold. Everyone who could hear her cry grew fearful, locking their doors. An unholy beast was prowling tonight, it seemed to them.

Echidna, however, just knew that something was wrong. Percy was feeling incredibly distressed. She wouldn't have needed to hear her daughters cries to know that.

So, since she was not able to comfort Percy, she did the next best thing. Holding the Chimera in her arms, stroking her mane as tears flowed down her cheeks, her tail lashing out wildly. She could only hope that Percy received some comfort from it as well as the Chimera cried into her chest.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
~In the underworld

Hades raised his head, going over some petitions from some of the administrative spirits. He heard a loud howling in the distance, and cries that were completely like those of a mortal.

“Alecto!” Hades called, the furry Fury appearing in a flash of fire. “Go see what that noise is. I need to finish these papers up before I can spend some time with my kids.”

The Fury nodded, her feminine frame covered in her usual rags of tortured souls. She needed nothing more. She bowed, leaving in another column of fire.

~ At the Gates of the Underworld

Souls backed away in sheer terror as Cerberus beat the ground, leaving craters where she hit. She howled in a fury, swatting away those who got close to contain her.

This was the scene that Alecto and her sisters came to find, with large chunks missing from the fortress like walls that surrounded the court pavilion of the dead. She held her flaming whip aloft, barking orders at her sisters.

“Restrain her! Corral the souls! Make sure that none escape!” She commanded, flying at Cerberus, lashing her whip out.

The whip wound around the beast-woman's wrist, the flames licking at her fur.

Not that it would Deter the mighty Cerberus in her rage.

Ignoring the feel of the heat, Cerberus moved quickly, mind solely focused on a new task. Her eyes switched between the red and blue/brown color violently as she darted forward, pulling the Fury along with her through the air, trampling souls that were too slow to move out of her way.

Cerberus ran, and ran, and ran. All the way to the river Styx. Even now, she could see the other side of the river, where Charon was lazing about again. She only saw one thing there though. A soul that just entered the lobby, waiting for passage.

Gaining more speed, moving as fast as she could, Cerberus leaped off of the cliff overlooking the river bank, plunging into the dark waters of the river of the dead with a mighty hiss, the flames extinguished.

~In the Lobby of the dead-sprint

Charon sat at his desk, rubbing his neck. It still hurt, even now. That godling had done a number on him alright, without any trouble.

“Man, that was worse then the time Hercules barged in here demanding Cerberus.” He said, flipping through his magazine, merely looking up at the new arrival for a second in disinterest.

Only to have it all fall apart as the wall fell to pieces where his ferry was docked!

Charon yelled in surprise, falling back in his chair.

Today was just not his day. It really wasn't.

Cerberus stormed through the crowd, crushing more souls who had been waiting for their turn on the ferry, heading towards the newest arrival. Water from the river flew from her fur, hitting spirits that were out of her way, making their after-lives so much more irritable.

Sally Jackson stood there, in the lobby, holding her head. It hurt something fierce. What happened? She... didn't remember anything really. Just... the Minotaur attack... had she died from that?

She didn't even notice the chaos, as she tried to puzzle out what happened. She only blinked when she felt herself being gently picked up, looking to see the face of Cerberus, who pulled her close like a teddy bear, growling at all the souls around her to back off.

'Alpha wants to protect her.' Cerberus thought, all three voices in her head saying it in unison. 'So we protect her for Alpha! Protect her from everything!'

~ Back at the Big House

'No life signs detected. No brain activity detected. Body not fit for use as a new soul host. Please find new subject for soul copying or find a suitable body for soul imprinting.'

That was all the monitor read.

Percy looked down, unblinking at the face of his mother.

The unblinking face of his mother stared back at him, but not seeing him.

She was dead. Pure and simple.

But it was so... so... unreal, even for him.

And he caused it...

A tear fell onto the cooling face of Sally Jackson.

Annabeth inched closer, not sure how Percy would react to sudden movements right now.

“Percy?” She whispered, moving a little closer.

“Why did I do it?” Percy asked, but Annabeth and Medusa didn't know if he was asking them, or himself.

“Percy?” Medusa asked, moving close enough to put her hand on his shoulder.

Percy didn't even flinch, didn't even feel her hand.

“To show her I would protect her from anything?” He asked, seemingly having an argument in his head. “She didn't need to see what I did to the fat bastard though.”

“Percy, please. Snap out of it.” Annabeth said, close enough to grab his shoulder as well.

“To give her somewhere familiar to wake up?” He asked. “No, that's a lie. I could have released her outside the camp. It would have been even more familiar to her. The last place she remembered. Could have had Grover talk to her.”

“Percy!” Annabeth said, shaking his shoulder.

Medusa on the other hand...

Well, let's just say Percy would have to clean splinters from his hair.

Percy blinked, feeling his gift to Medusa break over his head. It didn't hurt or anything, he'd taken far worse blows. But he didn't have that blank stare in his eyes anymore.

“Why didn't I just wait until she woke up?” Percy asked, his shoulders shaking. “I could have talked to Chiron. I know he has a lot of questions.”

“C'mon Percy.” Annabeth said. “Snap out of it!”

It was silent for a minute, nobody moving, Percy trying to take a few breaths.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“No... I can fix this...” Percy said, closing his mother's eyes. Respect for the dead after all.

“Percy?” Medusa asked, worried. “You don't plan on tearing apart the underworld to get your mother back do you?”

Percy shook his head, looking sorrowfully at the corpse of Sally Jackson. “No, but what I'm going to do is going to be dangerous nonetheless. Even for me. And you two are coming with me.”

“Percy, what are you talking about?” Annabeth asked. “What kind of dangerous are we talking about here?”

“Universal collapse, at best.” Percy said simply. “And the possibility that my mind may suffer some severe damage from viewing three places in real time and acting in all of them as well. Unfortunately, I don't know how that would effect Either Cerberus or the Chimera, having to deal with three sets of emotions at once, even if they are all the same.”

“What are you talking about?” Medusa asked, utterly confused.

“Time travel, Medusa. Time Travel.” Percy said, as if that explained it simply enough. Though, it seemed to do so, but it also brought up more questions.

“Okay, that part I get.” Annabeth stated, having done time travel herself, even if it was Percy's doing. “But what's that about three places at once? And damaging your mind?” She said, suddenly very worried.

“Simply put,” Percy began. First time he was able to use that on Annabeth, instead of the other way around, it seemed. “That as we go back, I'm going to split my conscious into three parts to do different tasks. One part each to go with you two to your past selves, and another to go to my own past self and merge with it, giving it the knowledge of what not to do.” Percy said, looking up for the first time. “I'm not entirely sure if it will be as horrible as I think it may be, but the most I've ever split into is two.” Percy said, shaking his head. “But I've got to do this.”

“But why take us with you if it's so dangerous?” Medusa asked.

“Because,” Percy said, suddenly holding both of them tightly against him, the computer and desk gone in a quick flash of light. “I want you two to understand what I'm capable of. What lengths I'll go for those that I love.” He said. “Now hold on, and close your eyes. Going through space is nothing like going through time. It might get a little rough.”

Both looked up at Percy, their eyes filled with both worry and love. They nodded, closing their eyes.

~ In the Time Stream

It felt something like cold water, but without getting them wet. It was swift, like a raging river, fighting to drag them forward and into the future.

But Percy wasn't having any of it.

He strode against the tides of time, both Annabeth and Medusa clinging to him as the flow of time tried to rip them from him.

There was also several familiar presences watching them, it felt. The Fates, for one. Percy could feel their eyes widening in shock as he backwards across the tapestry of fate they weaved.

Kronos was there, as well, but it was fleeting. As if Kronos forgot about him every second, then saw him again and remembered. Not surprising, since Kronos, even as the Titan of Time, lived in the present. The presence was weak as well, as if the titan barely was able to pay attention. Made sensem given he was still in Tartarus, and probably conserving energy to talk to his agents.

But they weren't the only two groups Percy could feel.

No. He sensed the white and dark-eyed presence, the one that watched him after his time with the Fates. How he knew it was that exact presence was simple. It did nothing hiding itself from him, appearing all around him at different times. It hid from the Fates though, so perhaps it was a curious out-of-universe god? It seemed likely.

But how did it know about him before he left the universe?

But there was one more presence Percy felt. It was very, very far off. Almost dormant as well. He couldn't place his finger on what it could have been.

But back to the task at hand. He could wonder what these extra sets of eyes watching him were later.

“Man, this is more difficult then the time with Nico and Bianca.” Percy said aloud, tightening his hold on his girls. “But that isn't going to stop me.” He said, determined to change the past.

Well, more then it already was, that is.

Now came the difficult part. Separating his conscious into three separate, yet connected, parts.

Percy walked forward's, trying to empty his mind.

It wasn't easy, given the circumstances that led to this, but he managed.

Three separate Percy's walked up the river of time, battling it's mighty power. Two of the pieces of Percy held on to a girl each, while one walked alone.

“This is going to cause the worst headache in existence, I can already tell.” They said at once. “But I don't care.”

They walked a little further, time's stream raging harder and harder the further they went.

“Okay, center body needs to go faster if this is going to work.” They said, making an obvious effort not to completely synchronize in motion. “No, wait. The one with Annabeth goes first, then the single one, then the one with Medusa.”

The bodies switched their movements again, the far left one walking faster, while the other bodies slowed down enough for it to be in front.

“That should do it. Wait, no. Damnit, I got it wrong again. Solitary, Medusa, Annabeth. No, all together simultaneously? Yeah, that's it. Man, thinking with three brains is hard. Especially when your fighting the god damned flow of time!” Percy roared, frustrated with himself.

If something else went wrong... He was not going to be happy.

So, with great effort, the three bodies moved for the last time as they neared their destination.

“Here we go!” Percy said. “Now remember! When you meet your past selves, you have to look them in the eye, otherwise you won't merge with them. And that would be very, very bad!”

“Got it!” Both girls yelled, before they felt a pull on their stomachs.

~ (On Olympus)

Percy blinked. He could hear yelling on top of Olympus. He could see that he held his Mother's soul in his hand.

But that wasn't all he could see.

“Everyone okay?” He asked, speaking through three mouths at once.

~With Medusa

“Yeah, everything's good.” Medusa said. “I... can see my past self now.” She hesitated to say that, her mind already starting to hurt at the implications. “Please don't ever make me do that again.”

~With Annabeth

“Good Medusa. Annabeth?” The third Percy asked.

“I can see myself now, if that's what your asking.” She said, having an easier time accepting what she saw.

Didn't mean that it wasn't mind-boggling even still.

“Good. Okay. Remember, eye-contact with your past selves. The merging might be a little jarring, but stay calm. A feeling of panic might kick up, but it should only last a second.”

~Back on Olympus

“You're not making this any easier.” Both of them said, at the exact same time.

Percy couldn't help but laugh. “Ahh, sorry you two. But it's just a fair warning. Now, we've got to hurry. Annabeth, I want you to tell Grover to meet me just outside the camp entrance before you do the thing with Ambrosia. Medusa, just sit there and look pretty. I'll be there in a second. We've still got trash to take care of.”

“With pleasure~” Medusa basically purred... Hissed?

“Good. Now we got to hurry. Not only am I getting the headache of the century, but I don't feel like drawing attention from anyone we would rather be under the radar of.” He said, thinking back on the unknown presences he felt moments ago... Would feel...

“Ugh... Time travel...” Percy said with a shake of his collective heads.

He absently wondered if this is what Cerberus had to deal with when she was still the large three-headed guard dog.
