1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy downed some Nectar and Ambrosia, making his headache go down slightly.

You know, it really said something when the blessed food of the gods did little to ease even a headache.

“Never again.” Percy said, holding an old-fashioned goblet provided to him by a minion, who immediately refilled it with the drink of gods. “Never again am I splitting my mind into three parts that are all connected.”

Chiron payed Percy little attention, still stupefied by the women who served him. One minute they were wild forces of Nature on the battlefield, tearing apart the well trained campers like a harpy through an unarmored demigod, and the next they were acting like perfectly trained servants, not even needing Percy to say anything for them to be moving.

Currently, Percy kept several around the Big house, cleaning it up, dusting and what not. He even had some of the... Robed ones, or as he liked to call them, the 'Blue' minions, up in the attic, going through the, admittedly, heaps of old junk. Percy insisted that they might be able to make something of the old trophies or broken weapons of heroes passed.

Something that not even the Hephaestus cabin was willing to try out.

Sally Jackson was currently laying in a room, recovering from fatigue and letting her mind rest. Mr. Underwood had told her quite a bit of her sons exploits from the future that was no more, as Chiron called it.

“You know, you should stop looking so dumbfounded by the minions Chiron.” Percy said, swilling his drink before taking another sip. “They can be quite mischievous if they think that you're easy prey.” He said with a humored tone, like the thought amused him.

That was another thing Chiron noticed. Percy seemed utterly at ease, yet he sat with a dignified air about him. It was as if he had sat in the throne of a king, by his own right, and knew exactly what he was doing.

Which, if what Percy told him was true, he had, and he did.

Chiron rubbed the bridge of his nose, sitting in his magic wheelchair. It was getting more and more complicated, the life of Perseus Jackson.

“One last time, for the sake of my mind, you're telling me that the glowing energy...cocoon... that is currently upstairs in one of the guest rooms is Ares.” He said slowly, trying to make sure he understood exactly what he was saying. “And that you, by some magic, have turned Ares into a woman, who will not remember anything about being the old Ares. Am I correct?”

“Indeed, Chiron. It is the truth. Though I'm not sure how the Olympian council will take this fact.” Percy mused, completely unconcerned at the thought of having to go to war with Olympus.

Chiron let out another sigh, sipping his tea. He could feel his age catching up to him.

And he was immortal!

“You know Percy,” Annabeth said, coming in from the hall. “When everything isn't moving so fast and you have had a little time to relax, you can be quite regal.”

She walked over to Percy, sitting on his lap and wrapping her arms around him. “Feeling any better?” She asked, looking up at him.

In the corner, the red minion who filled Percy's drink giggled perversely.

“Yeah, I am. Sorry about the mental break down back there.” He said, smiling sadly. “How are things going out there?”

“The campers are back in their cabins, Melum is currently overseeing the minions as they help the Hephaestus cabin repair things and stock pile their 'spoils'” She said, using air quotes. “Grover is busy talking to the council of cloven elders right now, though about what I don't know. And it seems that a quite a few of the Nymphs have heard through the grape vine that two people, one matching Melum's description and your younger self held a concert about twenty days ago with only a flute and singing. You wouldn't happen to know anything about that would you?”

Percy shrugged. “I had energy one night, and it was before I got used to the duties and pleasures of my new station. I think it was after I took you and Medusa out on that moonlit dinner from France. That Very same night, I'm sure of it.” He said. “Speaking of Medusa, do you know where she went? She kind of vanished when we got back here.”

“I think she said something about going to lie down. A killer headache I think.” Annabeth thought, though she was unsure.

“Well, I suppose committing both murder and arson twice in the same day will do that to you. Especially when it's on the same person and the same building, twice. Combine that with time-travel and I'd be surprised if she didn't have a headache.”

Chiron coughed, bringing himself back to their attention. “Yes, well, that is something I would like to call you on, I really can't. I can't really say the man deserved it, but I won't fault you for it. Hero's have done worse in the past.” The centaur said.

“Good.” Percy said. “Chiron, I respect you, so I will tell you this. I will not have someone call me out on doing things that don't fit with their world views because they can only think a certain way. As I told Charon, I am not a good person. But, that doesn't make me evil either. I can be kind, I can hold a meaning of justice, so on and so forth.” Percy said. “Let's face it. With all I've experienced in one year's time, something I've barely scratched the surface with telling you, I would say my moral code has changed drastically from what this world thinks a hero should be. I am not a selfless paragon of good, nor will I become one. I refuse to be controlled by the gods, as all hero's have been before me. But that doesn't mean that I will go on a murderous rampage. I'm not a monster, despite having killed people in the past and having demonic legions at my finger-tips. And if you can't accept that, then I will be willing to let us go our separate ways.”

It was silent in the meeting room, the sound of a fire burning in the fireplace.

“You seem stead-fast in that resolution.” Chiron said, the lack of windows making the fireplace cast shadows across his face.

“I am.” Percy said, hardening his face. If it came down to it... if it was necessary...

He would put the old horse down.

It was a tense silence, as the two stared each other down.

“You know,” Chiron said, pausing to sip the last of his tea down. “I've never had a hero say that to me before. And I've trained a lot of heroes, as you should know. They all tried to make their happy endings, did great deeds that gave them fame and glory. But they tried too hard, and they all broke down at some point or another. They tried to fit a mold that wasn't possible for anyone to fit. A perfect hero. Selfless, self-sacrificing, always putting the people first, not killing people without due reason. Honestly, I think only two hero's I trained ever came close. Your Name-sake, Perseus, son of Zeus, and Hercules. They still fell far, far behind on what the mold called for though. They still broke though, at some point.”

He shook his head, smiling ever so slightly. “But you are the first one to come out and say you wouldn't fit that mold, nor would you try to. I cannot say I condone your actions, but you are being honest with me. And you would probably do what needs to be done, not what you think would be right. People sometimes forget that they aren't always the same. Personally, I blame the Hollywood Cliche's.”

“Good. I'm glad we understand one another. Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm going to spend some time with Annabeth. I haven't seen her for a year, and I haven't had a chance to relax and enjoy the time with her.” Percy said, picking his queen up in a bridal carry as he stood up.

“Yes, I could understand why you would want to be with her.” Chiron said. “But... it feels so strange. Not even a month ago she was twelve, looking to go into the world to prove herself. Now she is a woman of the ripe age of sixteen. Sometimes I detest magic.” He said, shaking his head.

“We'll see you in a bit Chiron.” Percy said, carrying Annabeth out into the hall. The minion quickly cleaned up before going back to the minion gates, heading back to the Dark tower.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy walked through the camp seeing the minions keeping order. The campers were kept in their cabins, and this time around they suffered no casualties.

The sounds of the Hephaestus cabin already getting to work on repairing, having been the only neutral cabin in the inter-camp war they got special privileges, mixed with the barking of orders of the smarter minions to their small groups as they patrolled.

Not that it was needed, but it was something to do. Besides, they were still waiting on the Succubi to find a spot for a new Dark Tower.

“You know I can walk, right?” Annabeth asked, her arms still wrapped around Percy's neck.

“I know. But I prefer holding you close.” He said, smiling slyly at her. “Would you prefer being down on the ground?”

Annabeth seemed to think about it. “No, this is just fine.” She said, snuggling into his well muscled chest.

“I thought so.” He said with a smug grin, walking past a minion patrol. They stopped to bow, Muttering 'Master' and 'Mistress' with nothing but loyalty and devotion.

They kept walking, all the way up to Thalia's tree.

Percy's Thalia's tree?

How would that be named and titled really?

Percy's tree of Thalia?

Anyway, Percy sat beneath the tree, holding Annabeth close to him.

“She had dreams of you, you know.” Annabeth said. “Thalia I mean. I don't think I ever told you that. When it was just me, her and Luke she would talk about you, without really knowing who you were. All she knew was that she loved you. Strange how I forgot to tell you that. I wonder why she joined the hunters if you were with her though.” She mused. “Now that I think back on it, I somehow knew she was talking about you. I think Luke knew it too. Strangely, Luke didn't seem all that jealous.”

Percy stayed quiet, listening. 'That's how it works, huh? I knew it basically rewrote reality, but I just didn't understand how. I figured it would just be no one cared how I acted about Thalia.' He thought, listening to Annabeth ramble on about how Thalia praised him, knowing he would be strong, about how she was proud to be owned by him.

'Though how Annabeth can say that with a straight face, basically owning Thalia like she were less then cattle... Nah. I'll think on it later.' He thought. Besides, he had news that he wanted her to hear, and her alone for now.

“Hey, Annabeth, can I tell you something?” Percy said. “It's really important, but I didn't want anyone else to hear it for now. Just something between you and me.”

“What is it? You know you can tell me anything Percy.” She said.

“Yeah, I know. But this is a matter I don't want to reveal to everyone just yet. It's kind of shocking, really. Even to me.”

“Well, spit it out Seaweed brain. It's not going to tell itself.” She teased, but had a seriousness in her face.

“Well, you see... During my time as reigning Overlord, I had several mistresses to look after the tower while I was out doing... stuff.” He said, making Annabeth nod.

“Yeah, I remember. You told Hades that, back in the Underworld.”

“Yeah, well, like I said, there's one bit of info that I didn't tell anyone.” Percy said. “I... I'm a father Annabeth.”

She merely raised an eyebrow at him. “You really think that something like that would surprise me? To tel you the truth, I half expected it, no, almost certainly expected it.”

“Well, I figured you would want to have my first child, and I don't think I would have been a good Father-figure in that world. Being the embodiment of all they fear, no matter how good I am to them.”

Annabeth shook her head. “It's fine Percy. It really is. Besides, I'm not ready to be a mother yet myself, even though I would love to be one with our kid. So, who's the lucky lady?”

“Rose. Or as I like to call her, the good mistress. Maybe a little Naive, and a little bit stuck up, but nowhere near as her sister Velvet. Or Jewel for that matter, before I did something with her. Now Jewel could be considered the Neutral mistress if anything. Anyway, I found out shortly after my fight with the Forgotten god. Guess all that time making the tower shake caught up with us.” He said with a laugh and a far away look.

“I wonder how the woman's pelvis survived.” Annabeth muttered. She had a feeling that 'Shaking the Tower' was not a meaningless euphemism.

“Anyway, given the difference in time's flows between us that that universe, I would say that she's probably given birth by now. I'm going to go visit sometime. She is going to be the heir to the throne of the Overlord after all.”

“She? How do you know it's a girl?” Annabeth asked.

“Two reasons, but only one of them is important. One reason is that the forgotten god was the previous husband of that world's goddess. As in, she would be like Gaea. She was called the mother Goddess I believe. I don't really know her name, but I know that the Elves worshiped her. Anyway, I'm getting off topic. Since I am basically one of the two driving forces in that world, I can see the fate of that universe when I want. I know that my daughter will be basically the spawn of evil in that universe, becoming the next overlord and enslaving the minds of the people, but also ending the reign of a mad, oppressive emperor with both a inferiority complex and a superiority complex who wants to become a god by killing all things magical.”

“The second reason I know,” Percy said, not giving Annabeth any time to take in what he told her. “Is that I can't have male children. At all.”

“Really?” Annabeth asked, still trying to wrap her head around the first fact.

“Really. Something that the Eronomicon did to me without me knowing. It told me that almost every god was usurped by their sons, and that male children of gods tend to be jealous of their parents to the point of trying to kill them, or at the least seal them away and take what the god owns for themselves.” Percy said.

Annabeth was silent, before something dawned on her. “This means that...”

“Yes, I'll probably end up having sex with my daughter's, grand daughter’s, and so on. Hey, it's not as bad as some gods, who have kids just to sacrifice them. At least I'll try and care for my children, unlike our divine parents.” Percy said, looking with an accusatory glare at the sea.

“You know, with how many children you're likely to have it won't be possible to be with them all the time, especially with the different flows of time.”

“Yeah, I know. Even with all my power it's going to be hard to do so, but I'll be damned if I don't try.” Percy said.

It was silent, the only sounds the sounds of the camp rebuilding.

Percy closed his eyes, holding Annabeth close. It was a nice day to lay in the sun...

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy crushed the pit Scorpion Luke had attack him in desperation. It was a pitiful attempt to try and kill him.

“Run Luke. Back to your Master. Tell Kronos his days are numbered.” Percy said, standing still as he glared at Luke. “Just like Zeus.”

“You could still join us Percy.” Luke said, raising his sword. “Kronos would happily let you serve.”

“I serve no one!” Percy said, acting like he was going to draw his sword.

Luke gulped, his face growing white. He knew he couldn't take Percy in a fight, if the skills he showed before going on his quest were anything.

And that Percy wasn't built like a god.

Luke swiped his sword in the air, disappearing into darkness, running in mortal fear.

“About ready to go?” Percy asked, snaking the hand resting on her stomach up and underneath her shirt.

Enyo was breathing heavily, but she grinned in defiance, grinding back against Percy. “Almost. Just a little longer.”

Horny and angry Enyo? Oh fuck yes.

The rage sex was absolutely amazing.

Enyo growled. “I'll show you whose going soft.” She said, feeling her juices pool in her pants.

So, they drove a little more, Percy teasing and baiting the Goddess in his arms. The air around her was shimmering with her anger, and her glasses had long since melted away. Percy could hear her teeth grinding as he riled her up.

“Alright! That's it!” She yelled, bringing her skull back to bash him in the nose.

Percy leaned his head out of the way, the Motorcycle swerving at the sudden weight displacement. He grinned wildly, eying the furious, sweaty form of Enyo as the bike crashed beneath them, skidding to a tree. Both were unharmed though, having taken bigger hits from the other.

He took the time, slipping his gloves off and into his pocket, the ground around them shaking before he could reign in his power again.

Enyo lunged at him, swinging her sword with pure strength and fury, cleaving into the ground easily, knocking over several trees behind Percy.

Speaking of which...

Enyo rolled out of the way, Percy's fist sending up small spires of rock. She quickly stood, delivering a kick to where she thought his head would be.

Percy caught the foot, lifting her up into the air by it and slamming her into the ground.

“You getting Better, girl.” Percy said condescendingly, his eyes flashing to the same poisonous green that had brought many men to their knees in fear.

Enyo roared, kicking at Percy with her other foot as she tried to stab his legs.

“Ooh, scary.” He mocked, grabbing hold of her other leg and jumping in the air with her. “I remember you making the same mistake a few months back. How did it end up again?” He asked, using her body to spin in the air, throwing her down into the ground before landing on her back. “Oh yeah, something like that. Ready to give up yet?” Percy asked, grinding her hand into the ground.

“Fuck off!” Enyo yelled, throwing her body up with all the force she could muster. And when you are the living embodiment of destruction, that was a lot of force.

Percy's head collided with a tree, drawing golden Ichor from the spot. He coughed, licking his lips and tasting his own blood. “I'll fuck something alright.” He said as he got up. He ran at Enyo, who had just managed to get up, but was still going strong. He dove, tackling her as they both disappeared into thin air, leaving only a ripple behind.

~???

Enyo kept her mouth shut as rocks and dirt were ground into her face as she skid along the ground, Percy holding her down.

“I said, fuck off!” She roared, flipping onto her back, sending both of them Skidding away from each other.

Both of the warriors stood up, facing one another. Enyo gripped her sword, eying Percy, watching for the most opportune moment to strike with all her force.

Percy, meanwhile, held out his hands, a large, flaming Mace appearing in his hands. Holding the massive weapon in one hand, Percy grabbed at the air with the empty hand, water appearing around him en masse.

Meanwhile, in a tower over-looking them a woman sighed.

“Looks like Sire is not pulling his punches again.” The woman said, closing her book. “Giblet, can you keep working on that project of mine while I'm gone?”

The forge mistress nodded. “Yes tower-mistress. Giblet do good with project.” She said, going back to the forging.

“Morticia, would you mind helping in keeping the energy under control?” Eres said, pausing. “Yes, that means you'll have to come through the pathways.” She said. “Good. Giblet will be expecting you.”

Eres sat down, looking out the window at Percy and Enyo duke it out, the landscape drastically changing as they went at it harder and harder.

“Good thing Percy can fix all this.” Eres said, waiting for Morticia to arrive before leaving. “Being his universe and all.”

Eres paused again, looking up at nothing. “Ah, yes. Hello Mistress Annabeth. Have I seen the master? Yes I have. He's fighting Enyo right now. No, I don't think He's been to the construction site today. I don't know when He'll get done with his spar. Yes, I'll remind him. Yes. You're welcome Mistress.” She said, blinking her eyes back into focus.

If there was one thing she hated about her new job, it was that she acted like a call center for Percy and the far-away, or universally separated, members of his Harem. Well, hate was too strong a word. Maybe just generally disliked. At least the Minions weren't aloud to use it anymore.

“Well, better enjoy the show.” She said, kicking back in the air as she watched the power-houses collide again.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy slipped his gloves back on, once again making the world around him shake before reigning in the power again. He smacked the Goddess of Destruction on the ass, making her moan and slap at him halfheartedly.

“You may be good at fighting, Girl.” He said, still mocking her. “But your stamina needs work.”

“Oh, fuck you. We can't all be amazing sex gods you know.” She said, rubbing her rear, the ground around them stained with her and Percy's activities. As well as a few imprints on the hard, unforgiving ground, most of them looking suspiciously like various part of her body.

Including her ass, hands, knees, shoulders, one that looked like her face slightly.

What could she say? She liked it rough. Really, really rough. Being a goddess that specialized in war and destruction left her with a very high pain tolerance.

So very much unlike Ares before her.

But hey, before anyone calls anybody out, she did get to return the favors, somewhat. And she had taken her toll on Percy as they fucked as well.

“True.” Percy said, leaning back on the ground next to her. “But I can try my best to make you amazing sex goddesses. And I fully intend to do that. We could go for another round if you want to test your luck again.” He said, leaving it up to her if that was fighting, fucking or both.

“Nah. As much as I want to, I've still got to go do my job. There's been an area in Spain that's been pissing me off. I'm gonna go raise some hell there.” She said, before feeling a warm stickiness flow from her holes. “That, and I don't think I could take anymore. I'm stuffed.”

“I aim to please.” Percy said, shrugging with a grin.

“Yeah, I'll say.” Enyo said, scooping a bit of Percy's cum off her leg, licking it off with moans she had been making not even ten minutes before.

Slurping the last of the cream off her finger, Enyo pulled the digit from her mouth with a wet 'pop!'

“Ahh, better then any ambrosia.” She said happily.

“Having fun you two?” A voice said from above them.

“Hey Eres. What's up?” Percy asked, tilting his head to look at the glowing woman.

No, she was literally glowing. You know, being filled with Arcane energies and what not.

Eres stood at 5'7'', purple energy radiating from her body as light. She wore nothing, exposing her bare form to the world. Her purple skin looked like it was very much alive, looking like the energy she contained was rolling and billowing about her. Instead of hair, she had pure energy cascading from her head, only acting like hair. She even floated off the ground slightly, maybe an inch or two.

While her skin may have looked unnatural, that didn't mean she wasn't beautiful even still, nor was she any less of a woman. Her breasts were still as big as they were last time, and she was still very shapely, and very much sexually active. Something that she reminded Percy of every chance she got.

“I swear,” She said, smiling down at him. “You've been going to too many universes where the laws of physics allow you to do outlandish things. Stop breaking physics in more stable universes please.” She said, smiling even still.

“I can't help it.” Percy said, shrugging at her. “It's more fun to do that sort of thing. If I didn't have as much time to relax and have fun, with as much time as I spend planning and plotting and conquering, I would have snapped by now.”

“You saying that we're not fun?” Enyo asked, scowling.

“Not at all. But there's more to an immortal existence then fighting, fucking and booze. Trust me, I don't think I'll get tired of that for a long time, but still. Sometimes a guy has to let loose, break physics and all.”

“You know, wise-bitch is probably having a hell of a time still trying to figure out how you do that. She pestered me for weeks on trying to make you explain it to her.” Enyo said, referring to Athena. “I still think she's trying to figure out how you did that one thing. You know what I'm talking about.”

“Yeah, I think I do.” Percy said. “But all I can tell you right now, as I've said before, is adapting to other universes is not easy. How we look, right now, the texture of our skin and everything else, is completely unrealistic to them. Tell Athena to look at anything that is drawn, painted, or whatever, and think that to the people in the art, that is how the world is supposed to look. Physics also apply, along with thought patterns, fiction, reality and-”

“Blah blah blah. Don't care.” Enyo said. “ Quantum theory, or whatever it is you call it, isn't my type of thinking. I'll pass on the message for ya, but don't expect me to understand it.” She said. She was a fighter, not a planner. Unbridled destruction was her thing, not hard thinking or philosophy.

“Yes, well, anyway Sire.” Eres said seriously. “Mistress Annabeth wanted me to remind you that today would be the day the barrier's fail. You know, the barriers protecting the half-blood camp?”

“That was today?” Percy asked.

“Yes sire.” Eres said, nodding. “According to Mistress it is. You had Echidna pull away a few weeks back, remember?”

“Right, right.” Percy said, standing up and stretching. “Wonder how well they'll fare when the monsters bring the fight into the camp itself, and they aren't going easy.”

“Well, I got to raise me a town to the ground, maybe set fire to some crops or something.” Enyo said, standing up and draping her arms around Percy. “Mind dropping me off?”

“Sure. Just let me check on a few things first.” Percy said, the three of them appearing in the tower. “Eres, can you see if Melum is doing anything? I want to talk with her.”

The tower-heart personification bowed. “At once Master.” She said, stepping near a scrying pool.

“Hello, Melum? Are you busy?” Eres asked, an image forming in the small water basin. “Yes, Master would like to talk with you. Hold on a moment Sire, the image will appear in a second.”

The water shimmered, showing Melum's cheerful face. “Hello Master Perseus!” Melum said, smiling at him with a happy tone.

“Hey Mel. How are things going?”

“Just fine Master. Though there has been one person hitting on me. I'm sure it's a god though. Apollo I think.”

Percy frowned slightly. “Has he been too... insistent? Bothering you?”

“No.” She said, sighing slightly. “He's just an annoyance. After all, you're the only one for me Master.”

Percy chuckled. “I know, I know. You tell me that every time you see me.” He said, before turning serious. “Sorry to say though, this isn't a social call. I was wondering if you wanted to go on another little quest.”

“When and where?” Melum asked, her voice becoming the regal tone it was when she was serious about doing something for him.

“Few days, sea of monsters. Going to grab the golden fleece to protect the camp and bring Thalia out of the tree. Always something fun to do.” Percy said, skimping out on real details. “But you don't have to go. I know you're in the middle of recording-”

“It's fine Master. Besides, some time away from the studio might do me some good right now. And I truly miss being beside you all the time.” She said, reaching out to grab his face through whatever she was looking at. “Oh, right. You're not really here right now.” She said, blushing.

“If you're sure you want to go...” Percy said. “I'll pick you up in a few days. You go square things away with your managers.” Percy said, waving.

“Alright Master. I'll see you in a few days.” She said, blowing him a kiss. “Love you Master.”

“Love you too.” Percy said as the image vanished.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Enyo snorted. “Lovey-dovey bull-crap.” She muttered.

“You know you like it, especially when it's directed at you. Even if your version of 'Lovery-Dovery bull-crap' is us punching each other in the face.” Percy said, making her blush. “Could you get in touch with the fates next?”

“No problem.”

Once again, the water shimmered, before showing the chamber of Fate, the sisters currently sitting around a table, seemingly talking with one another.

'I'm glad we have the next few days finished in advance. The next quest is coming up.' Clotho said.

'Indeed. I wonder when Percy will call us to talk about the prophecy for the retainer of his. The daughter of the war goddess.' Lachesis mused.

'I suspect it would be-' Atropos started.

“Right now.” Percy said, making the Fates turn their heads to look at him. “Hey girls.”

'Hello dear husband.' They said together.

“Seems you were already thinking ahead, as usual.” Percy said.

'Of course.' Atropos said, smiling.

'What else would we do?' Clotho asked, shrugging.

'Well, we could always go back to knitting.' Lachesis said, smirking at her sisters.

“As fun as that sounds,” Percy said. “I would like to hear about the Prophecy.”

'It goes a little something like this.' Lachesis said. 'You shall sail the iron ship with warriors of bone.'

'You shall find what you seek and make it your own.'

'But despair for your life entombed in stone.'

'And fail without friends, to fly home alone.' Lachesis said, finishing it off.

“Sounds good. I really see no problem with it. Although, you three are the masters of this stuff. I remember what it means, so you don't have to spell it out for me. But tell me. Is there anybody that could use a little bit of a prison break?”

'Hmm.' Clotho thought, putting a finger to her cheek in thought.

'I wonder-' Atropos thought.

'Would she remember though?'

'And her cell mate...'

'And them?' Clotho wondered, making her sisters blink at her. 'What?'

For once in their lives, one of the Fates had surprised the others.

'Would it be wise?'

'Perhaps not.'

'But it would be unfair!'

'Remember that they too are prisoners.'

'Yes...'

“Okay, explain please. Who are you talking about?” Percy asked, putting a stop to their little argument.

'Well, the first is Scylla, one of the monsters guarding the sea of monsters.'

'A nymph, she was. Glaucus, a long-forgotten minor sea god who worked for your father fell in love with her. Due to some events that took place, she was turned into the monster she is now.'

'Yes, but that isn't all. For all this time, she's been consumed by her anger and sorrow. She may have lost her mind by now, but perhaps not.'

'Even so, we suspect that you could help her in some way, like with Medusa.'

“I dunno. I don't mess with mind of people much any more. Not since last year. Though I'll try, I won't be going into dangerous waters where I can do more harm then good.” He said. “The others?”

'Well, Charybdis as well. A naiad, a daughter of Poseidon and Gaea just before the primordial was forced into her slumber.'

'Your half-sister, if you want to be clear-cut. A powerful girl, Charybdis.'

'Yes. She claimed land in the name of the sea, covering the land in Poseidon's name. She was the second in command of the waters, and she claimed many lives.'

'But Zeus did not care for that. Only that she was taking the land away from his followers with which to worship him.'

“And let me guess. He cursed her, like so many other people.” Percy said, gripping the sides of the Basin.

'Yes. This one might be justified, except for the fact that Poseidon commanded her to do it. As his daughter, she couldn't have refused him at the time. It just wasn't something daughters did at the time.'

“Of course. The Olympian makes another take the fall in his place. Typical of Poseidon and Zeus.”

'Just as a heads up, Charybdis might have been a little...'

'Broken. While Scylla may have still had the ability to think, Charybdis was reduced to little more then the monster she is now. If she has any thoughts at all, they will be little more then eat and swallow the earth.'

Percy sighed, pinching the bridge of his nose. “And what of this third group? The one you seem to be indecisive about?”

The Fates looked at each other before Clotho stepped up.

'The Grey Sisters. You should know them.' She said.

“Grey sisters... Grey Sisters...” Percy said, tapping the side of the Basin with his finger. “The three old women who drive the Taxi of the damned? With the one eye and one tooth between them?”

'Exactly, yes.' Atropos said.

'They are the sisters of Echidna, and helped your name-sake on his quest to slay Medusa way back when.'

“And how are they prisoners?”

The Fates shuffled their feet, looking at one another. Almost ashamed of something.

'Well...'

'You see...'

'It's kind of...'

'Complicated.' They all said.

“What do you mean complicated?” Percy asked.

'Well... The Grey sisters were very powerful seeress's.'

'And they would have an immortal life due to their parentage.'

'Zeus wanted their power curbed, so as to not jeopardize Olympus's standing.'

'But they also wanted to bargain for a little more power.'

'We... granted both requests.' Lachesis said sadly.

'We gave them more power, but reduced them down to a single eye to share. With it, they would be able to see exactly what we weaved. But they would have to fight over it to see at all.'

'So, in essence, they are our prisoners.'

'Prisoners of fate.'

'But you Percy. You can fix what we broke.'

'What we, the Fates, were too shameful to admit.'

'We understand now that what we did was wrong.'

'But we cannot do anything about it.'

'Our cursed pride won't let us!'

'Please Percy! We beg of you!'

“Whoa, whoa. Everybody settle down.” Percy said forcefully, his power flaring, making the tower and the surrounding land for miles shake.

Somewhere in the tower, Giblet yelled as hot metal splashed from the forge and landed on her foot.

She'd be fine though. It would probably leave a light burn for her.

Toughest minion Percy had after all. It would take a medium-sized army to fight her and take her down. Little bit of molten hot metal wouldn't do much of anything.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“You know they didn't feel that right?” Eres asked, raising an eyebrow.

“I think they got the Message.” Percy said, looking down at the image of the three Fates. “Right?”

'Y-yes Perseus.' They said, bowing their heads. A faint trickling of power from beyond the universe reached them. Percy was not happy at all.

“Good.” Percy said curtly. “Now, I want you three to listen to me. I want you to fix this mess. You caused it yourselves. I will not fix it for you.”

'Yes Perseus.' Clotho said.

'B-but... can we ask you...' Atropos said, wringing her hands like she didn't really want to ask.

'To help us?' Lachesis finished, little more then a quiet whisper.

“In what way?” Percy asked, both angry and, now, curious.

'W-we don't think that...'

'We can give them their old forms...'

'We cast their eyes so far away that we wouldn't be able to recover them.'

'If we can make peace...

'And free them from their bonds ourselves...

'Will you give them that which we stole?'

Percy stared into the water basin, the Fates fidgeting under his glare. “Maybe. But you will try to fix it. Am I understood?”

The three fates nodded. 'Yes husband.' They all said, sorrowfully.

Percy sighed, looking at Eres. “You can cut the image now.”

Eres nodded, stepping away from the pool of water where she stood.

“It is done Maste-” Eres stopped mid-sentence. Percy was gone.

~In the chamber of Fate

'What should we do sisters?' Lachesis asked, sitting down at the table again.

'We should do as Perseus says. He is right, as we all know.' Atropos said somberly.

'We know that, sister.' Clotho said. 'But what about our husband himself? He seemed angry with us.'

'As he should.' Lachesis said with a sigh. 'What we did, to the Grey sisters, was unnecessary.'

'True, it was.' Atropos admitted. 'But we-'

'But nothing.' Clotho interrupted. 'We are in the wrong this time. If the Olympian's are being forced to change or die... perhaps it is time we did the same.'

'Yes. With a husband as powerful as our dear Perseus, it would be unwise to try and weave around this.'

'We should, as the mortals say, bite the bullet.'

The three sighed.

'I wonder...' Lachesis asked, drawing her sisters attentions. 'Does Perseus think of us in the same light as the Olympian's now?'

'I do not think so.' Atropos said.

'At least, we hope not...'

Icy fear stabbed their hearts. Yet another thing that was new for them. This last year or so had been full of firsts for them. Love, compassion, the fear of death, relief, the pleasures of the flesh, happiness... They were feeling it all, thanks to Percy.

Now it was the fear of rejection. The fear that Percy would see them in a darker light then what they wished him to see. That they were no better then those he was already fighting against, in his own ways. No better then those who punished for little to no reason, often a fate worse then death.

And, like the women of the olden days, they thought the world of their husbands. They did not wish to cause Percy to view them in distaste. Even if they had control over him still, they would have weaved him a life of happiness. Maybe trials, yes, but of happiness whenever he came home to them.

“Stop thinking things like that. You know I don't hate you.” Percy's voice said, from behind them.

The Fates jumped, something that they never did.

“Calm down now. I'm only here to talk to you in person.” He said as they stood up, turning towards him very quickly. “I just figured that you wouldn't want other people hearing this, even if it stayed within the 'family'.”

Percy walked over, gently pushing them back into their seats as Percy took one of his own. Something they had kept around in case he ever came up to talk with them.

It was a tense silence, as Percy looked at them, waiting for one of them to speak. And the Fates... well, they felt something else. Another first.

They felt like children, in a way. Children that were about to be scolded for something they did and tried to escape punishment for.

'W...We're sorry Perseus.' Lachesis said, bowing her head again.

'We did not mean to try and thrust our problems onto you.' Clotho said, hands clasped in her lap.

Percy sighed. “Girls, I just want you to realize that even if I am more powerful then even you, I won't be fixing up every little problem for you. Not even Annabeth, or Melum, or Medusa. I would help, but I won't be doing it all for you. And like I said, you caused this mess.”

The Fates each opened their mouth to say something, even if they spoke without even saying anything vocally, but they quickly closed their mouths. Percy was right.

“I'll be willing to be there when you speak with them, since I have business with them myself. If you can square things away with them, I'll talk to them about this myself. Deal?” He asked.

'Y-you're not mad at us?' Atropos asked, almost childishly.

'You're not disgusted by our actions?' Lachesis asked, afraid he would say yes.

“What? No, no.” Percy said. “A little disappointed, yes, but I'm not mad or disgusted.”

Percy stood up, walking over to Lachesis, who sat in the middle between Clotho and Atropos. He disappeared for a second, before three of him appeared in his place.

They moved exactly the same, each having a look of utter concentration on their faces.

With slightly clunky movements, there was a Percy standing in front of each of the sisters, whose eye's widened.

'You said you wouldn't do this again.' They said, a little stunned.

“Well,” They said. “It wouldn't be fair to only hug one of you at a time. Besides, I've got to practice it anyway. I have the feeling that I'll need it in the future... or Past. Time-travel still gets a little mixed up. But enough of that.” Percy said, holding them all tenderly.

“Don't think I could ever hate you.” Percy said.

The Fates didn't know how to react to that. They had feared the worst, but had only a minor scolding. Perseus still loved them.

Once again, relief washed over them. For the second time in their lives, they felt their hearts ease and flutter away.

And another first happened that moment.

They cried.

“It's alright.” Percy said, rubbing their backs as they clutched at his shirts, afraid to let go. “I'm not leaving you.”

~ The next day

Percy opened his eyes, feeling the warmth of the Fates around him. He was looking up at unending darkness, and the bed felt like he could fall through any second.

'Yep. Still in the chamber of Fate.' He thought, the Fates snoring lightly. It was a cliche name, he knew. And about a million different universes had something called the same, but he didn't really care.

'-ire? Are you awake Sire?' Eres asked.

'Yeah, I am now.' Percy said back. 'What's up?'

'The servant girl, Clarisse, wanted to know when, or if at all, you would becoming by the camp? The attacks from Kronos's army are growing stronger already.' Eres said. 'And that tree of yours with the girl has been poisoned.'

'Ah, shit.' Percy said. 'Does anyone know who did it?'

'The traitor, Luke Castellen.'

Percy sighed silently. 'Should have known. But it's always been an assumption over the years. Never a certainty. Thanks Eres.'

'It was no trouble Sire.' The ghost-woman said, her conscious fading from his mind.

'Well, I better go see Clarisse.' Percy thought. 'Check in on the campers as well. See how they're doing. I trust Clarisse though. She was most likely ready for this type of event. Probably been preparing the camp since I called off Echidna.' He thought to himself, vanishing and leaving pillows underneath the sleeping heads of the Moriae.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy appeared atop the hill, over looking the camp. Right now, the campers were fighting for their lives. Not the wild, yet controlled monsters at Echidna's command.

Nay, these were wholeheartedly trying to kill the campers, without anyone to command a retreat or cease-fire.

Though, even with the Campers in a full on war inside their own camp, for once, they were holding their own. All the time fighting Echidna's brood had done them good.

Being besieged for a whole year tended to make a person a good fighter.

But that wasn't what concerned him by now.

Percy placed his hand on the tree, Thalia's tree. He could feel as the poison burned her. Not just the tree, but the soul of Thalia herself.

“Sorry Thalia.” Percy said. “I hoped to have prevented this. Or at least try to.”

Time-travel may have solved a lot of problems, but it wasn't to be used willy-nilly. The few times he had used it for anything less then an emergency had been him messing around, but it was also very detrimental to the universal structure of, well, the universe.

It's... okay Percy.

That's what he heard the tree say. He could see Thalia writhing in pain inside the tree's soul, close enough to be called her soul.

It-It's not so bad... with you around... It doesn't hurt as much...

Percy smiled sadly. “That's my girl. Be strong.” He said, patting the tree bark. “Save your strength. Keep yourself strong. We'll get you out of here soon enough.”

Y-yes... Percy...

Percy felt as Thalia's conscious faded further into the tree, and the slight shimmer of the barrier began to fade. The monsters that were still fighting to enter found themselves tumbling in, causing more harm to themselves then anything.

“Small Fry.” Percy said, bored, but in a bad mood. He held out his hands, grabbing the mace he had used against Enyo from thin air. “But they'll have to do right now.”

He stalked down the hill, armor forming around him in its dark glory, Cape billowing on the flames of war.

~

“Move you bastards!” Clarisse yelled, her group dodging out of the way as some more monstrous beasts barreled towards them. She slashed at one of them, lopping off an arm in the process. “Got you, ya bastard!” She yelled, blood landing on her face.

Clarisse looked older now, just slightly. She had grown fit... well, fitter over the year, fighting constantly, training when she wasn't fighting. Hell, she had even sparred against Percy, though she knew he was going easy on her. But really, besides her godly mother, who else would be a good measuring stick?

She had cut her hair slightly, no longer having the hair to tie in a pony tail. Her arms were slightly muscled, and she could kick in a shield if she wanted.

Clarisse shook her head, trying to push his hand away. Still very sensitive, she moaned at his every touch, even the touch of the sheets was incredibly pleasing.

“W-what happened?” She asked, trying to keep the pleasure out of her voice. She really wanted to know what was done to her.

“I-I don't really know.” Percy said, grabbing a blanket from the side of the bed. He apparently had used this place before, and knew he would again, since there was fresh blanket. “One second I was myself, the next...” He shook his head. “I just don't know.”

“What. Happened?” She asked again, trying to keep herself from demanding what he had done outright. The lingering wisps of pleasure still clouded her mind, but an aching pain was clearing that up, along with a case of dehydration.

Percy pursed his lips, displeased with the turn of events. He hadn't expected something like this to happen.

A passion filled night, yes. Possibly give Clarisse one of the hardest, most pleasurable orgasms she would ever feel, yes. Not suddenly having his usual personality do a complete one-eighty and almost breaking her mind and turning her into a mindless human fuck-toy.

“Let's just say... you were this close to never thinking for yourself, or at all, again.” He said bluntly.

“What?” She asked.

Percy said nothing, merely brushing his hands against her cheek.

She moaned, even now still sensitive to every touch, every sensation.

Percy pulled his hand away, and Clarisse found herself trying to grab it again.

“No~” She moaned in disappointment. “Keep your hand right there.”

“That's the problem.” He said, pulling his hand away, much to her disappointment. “Just rest for a while Clarisse. You'll feel better in a few hours. I've got... something to check on.”

“Percy, wai-”

She looked at the spot he sat. She didn't even blink, and he was already gone. She didn't even realize her hand was trying to grab at what wasn't there until it hit the bed.

She stared blankly where he had been, her mind starting to really process what had happened.

“Holy shit...” She whispered, the truth hitting her like a freight train. “Fuck...”

Percy had sad that she was 'that' close to not thinking for herself again. The weight of that suddenly made her thoughts from earlier that night all the more true, and infinitely more terrifying.

Clarisse laid her head back down, her eyes looking up at the ceiling.

“Just what really happened with you Percy?” She asked no one in particular.

She would have thought on this further, but her exhaustion was too great, and her mind too fatigued. Slowly, despite her fighting it, her eyes drifted shut.

'What's going to happen now?' Was her last conscious thought before Hypnos claimed her for the night.

And she was right to wonder what was going to happen.

Was Percy alright? If he was only just able to stop himself from destroying her mind, someone he had explicitly said he trusted and cared for, in some fashion, what was he willing to do to other women who he didn't feel so connected to?

She would think on it in the morning. Right now, she needed her rest.

Too bad that rest would be plagued with nightmares of an sadistic, merciless Percy and her as a mindless whore.

~

Percy walked along the banks of a river. Not his river, mind you. Well, technically, it was his river. In this world, all rivers were his. Like the trees, the ground, the bugs, the stars...

But it wasn't the river he had taken from the river god, the first casualty of his gauntlets he almost constantly wore.

Sure, he could easily control his power now without them, but he had grown attached to them. Figuratively speaking of course.

It was an oddly satisfying feeling, being able to grab things that were otherwise intangible or impossible to hold in the first place.

Have you ever held a star in your hands?

It was strange, for a person who had been brought up as a mere mortal, even living the life he had lived as a son of a god and fighting supernatural monsters, to think of holding a star.

Especially one he had created himself.

We're getting off topic.

Percy walked along the banks of a river. In his world, Poseidon didn't have eyes and ears everywhere. Outside the universe he had been born into, Poseidon was as powerless as any mortal against a titan.

That meant Percy could relax in the water. Not have to worry about his father calling on him or spying. That was why he actively avoided going to even small bodies of water, such as a small lake, in that world.

He was always relaxed by the water, even after declaring that he would not follow his father.

Perhaps the Eronomicon had something to do with it. Maybe not. Percy didn't care too much.

No. What he cared about right now was his actions just now.

Why had he done that?

He had just, not even fifteen minutes prior, said that he didn't want mindless slaves.

And yet what he had almost done to Clarisse would have been much, much worse.

What was that just before he had snapped out of it? It was him, he knew.

But at the same time, not him.

His 'dark side' perhaps?

As cliché as it sounded, it seemed likely.

On one side, he had the Eronomicon slowly corrupting him to be more aggressive in his pursuit of women, loosing the chains of morality from his soul, and essentially making him into a horny devil.

He knew this, and he accepted it. So far, after two years of being around it constantly, since it was not only connected to him spiritually, but he also carried it with him wherever he went, he figured that something like this would have happened far, far sooner, if even at all.

On yet another side, he had the corrupting power of the Overlord and a dark god of all things evil, including lust, infused with his natural power. Gnarl, traitorous though he may have been, had been very knowledgeable about the power of an Overlord. Eres was even more so, since she had essentially become the personification of the one thing that knew more about the Overlords then Gnarl could have ever hoped to know.

The second he donned that helmet and armor he had accepted the power of the Overlord. Just as he accepted the powers of the Forgotten god when he ruthlessly butchered the deity, absorbing his power into his own.

But now, after so long, had the two somehow merged, creating a split personality? The ruthlessly evil mentality of the Overlord of all thing Evil, and the goals of the Harem god, mixed into one?

A truly terrifying combo, even to him.

Or was there some other explanation?

Was it just a heat of the moment thing? It was the first time he had attempted such a thing, splitting his mind into two parts for something like that, after all.

Percy didn't know.

And he was worried.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Unusual actions and unanswered fears

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Damn it.” He said, sitting on a rock as he looked into the clear water of the river. It reflected back his image, a grim look about him. “Why did this happen?”

'Sire, is something wrong?' Eres asked, communicating through the connection he shared with the tower heart. She, like the others who were connected to him such as Echidna or the Chimera, could feel his aggravation with himself.

“Most likely.” He said, not moving his stare from the river.

'What's the problem?'

“I almost went too far with Clarisse tonight.” He said, not clarifying what that meant.

'In what way? I know for a fact that you and her have been together before.' The ghost asked, clearly confused.

“I almost broke her, Eres.” Percy said simply. “Almost destroyed what made her, her.”

'Ah.' She understood now. 'Like what you did to Jewel that one time, a few years back?'

Percy sighed, pinching the bridge of his nose. “Yes, like Jewel a few years back.” He said, exasperated. “But, instead of that resulting from inexperience, this was the result of, seemingly, a split personality.”

'Really?' Eres asked, sounding intrigued. 'That is... very strange. I didn't sense anything different about you.'

“Please don't say that.” Percy said. “I'm already worried enough about this as is.”

It was silent, and Percy thought that perhaps the ghost was going to let it go.

Alas...

'What do you intend to do about it?'

Percy sighed again. “I dunno. This doesn't seem like something I can ignore. Who knows when the split personality, if that's what it is, might pop up.”

It was silent, as Eres thought over the words he had said. This was indeed a delicate situation. She could sense the undercurrent of worry in his mind, raging like a sea during a storm.

'Perhaps you should speak with someone about this.' She advised, as she was supposed to. 'Someone to help settle your mind. The Mistress, perhaps?'

Percy nodded slowly. “Perhaps... yeah. I will. Annabeth has the right to know what's going on. And the Fates, Melum, Medusa... Should also get in contact with Grover.” He said, mind starting to plan. It was a simple plan, what he would tell them. Nothing more, nothing less.

But it distracted him for a little bit, despite thinking indirectly about what the problem was.

'The Mistress is currently with her family, Sire.' Eres said, knowing he would go to her first. 'Medusa is currently working at her home. You know where Melum and the Fates are.'

It was a simple matter for her to determine where the other women in Percy's harem were. If they were connected to him, they were connected to her, in some fashion. The blues hadn't been lying last summer when they told Clarisse that serving Percy left a mark on their souls. If she focused, she could even see what they were doing.

Percy nodded. “Thank you Eres.” He said, standing up and looking at the stars he created. “I should go now. It would be better to talk about this sooner then later.”

'It is no problem at all, Sire.' She said, and Percy saw the image of her bowing elegantly. 'I live to serve.'

“Keep an eye on my daughter, please.” He said, before vanishing from the spot.

Eres closed her eyes, sighing. 'This is strange. Why would something like this happen?' She thought, before dismissing it. The Overlord had given her an order, and she was bound to follow it. 'Let's see what the little terror is up to now...'

~

“Coming!” Annabeth said, the knocking on her door ceasing when she had made herself known.

“Percy!” She cried, opening the door to see her love standing there. She quickly embraced him, something he returned with much gusto.

“It's good to see you Annabeth.” He said, holding her tightly to him with a smile.

“You too.” She said.

“Did I hear that Percy was here Annabeth?” Came the voice of one Frederick Chase, coming from one of the rooms. “Oh... How good to see you Percy. Come in, come in.”

Truth be told, the man was unsure of how to feel about Percy.

Sure, he had protected his daughter, and brought her back to him with not one single scratch on her. He was grateful for that, really he was.

But at the same time... His daughter wasn't the twelve year-old girl time demanded she should have been. She was older, having already blossomed into a young woman.

Percy had, in no uncertain circumstances, told the man that it was his doing. That he had turned his little girl into the woman she was now, also having had physical relations with her.

Frederick had, understandably, been upset about this news. So upset that, in a fit of paternal rage, he had taken the knife he was using to cut some frozen chicken and stabbed the semi-god with it.

Percy had taken this very well, merely chuckling as he pulled the blade out, stained golden with his blood. After cleaning the knife, Percy had told the man that it was good that he was protective of his daughter.

But warned him to not try that again, under threat of very severe consequences.

After calming both men down, Annabeth had told him what had, and would likely, transpire. The war, being flung back in time, everything.

Well, save Percy's conquest of her mother. He didn't need to know that.

Or about the harem. She didn't want her father to have a heart attack, go crazy and try to brutally murder Percy.

Again, that is.

So.. it was kind of iffy on where exactly he stood with Percy.

Percy was fine with the guy, personally.

“Hello, Mr. Chase.” Percy said, waving to the blond-haired man. “Unfortunately, Can't stay long. Urgent camp business. Annabeth knows what I'm talking about.” He said, weaving both truth and lie together easily.

There was urgent business, but not with the camp. On the other hand, there was camp business, and Annabeth did know what he was talking about.

“I was about to start heading there. Would have only taken me a few days, give or take.” She said, letting go of Percy. “Let me go grab my stuff first.”

She ran off, leaving the two most important men in her lives alone with each other.

It wasn't... tense. A little uneasy, yes. But not tense.

“So...” Frederick started, licking his lips. Percy seemed different then the last time he saw the teen. For one, his power had increased by an almost palpable amount. It was almost akin to a physical presence like the aura of other gods. One that screamed of power, even to mere mortals.

And then there was the fact that Percy seemed to be... anxious about something. Not a good anxious, either. It was hard to tell, though Percy made no move to hide it outside his normal emotional state, which was an air of control and calculated calm. Whatever it was, it was something big.

“How're Mrs. Chase and the other kids?” Percy asked, making casual conversation. He knew the man was uneasy around him, and had the right to be.

“Fine, fine.” Frederick said, unwilling to look Percy in the eye.

“That's good. Any monster attacks lately?”

“No, not for the past week. Something to do with the camp business?”

“Probably.”

“Okay, I'm ready.” Annabeth said, coming out with a backpack and a suitcase.

The backpack had clothes and other necessities.

The suit case on the other hand...

Well, let's leave that as a surprise, shall we?

The girl hugged her Father, getting a farewell hug in return.

“Be safe.” Was all the man could get out, his voice choking back sadness.

“Don't worry dad.” She said, pulling back. “I can handle myself. I've had to save his butt more then a few times, after all.” She said, jerking her thumb back at Percy.

“She's right.” Percy said, stepping up to grab her suitcase. “And anything she can't handle, I won't allow to lay a finger on her.”

The man nodded, trying his best to fix a glare on Percy. “If anything happens to my girl-”

“I'll be fine dad.” Annabeth insisted, interrupting him before he could go into his incredibly protective father rant.

He nodded, sighing. “I know, I know. Forgive a father for wanting his daughter safe.”

“It's fine, Mr. Chase.” Percy said, putting his hand on Annabeth's shoulder. “We should get going though.”

The man nodded, stepping back from his daughter's grasp. “I guess I'll see you soon then, Annabeth.” He said.

“Yep.” She said, waving. “Bye Dad.” She said, before her and Percy were gone.

~

They appeared in the Dark tower, in the master bedroom. The pale moon shone through a large window, the doors out to the balcony opened as wind blew in.

Annabeth blinked, looking around slightly confused. “Percy, why are we here? Weren't we going to camp?”

Percy shook his head, standing up from the bed where they were sitting. “While we'll be going to camp, there's something I need to talk to you about. And that's the urgent business. The camp is fine, save a few differences in the strength of the monster attack.”

Annabeth could tell Percy was shaken. He didn't show it, other then his pacing around the room. But, really, that was all she needed to see to know that something had disturbed him.

“What's wrong Percy?” She asked, getting up from the bed herself.

Percy stopped his pacing, opening his mouth before closing it again with sigh.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“I would have to say that the problem is myself.” Percy said, starting his pacing again, not bothering to even look at the first Mistress of his harem.

“What are you talking about Percy?”

“A split personality, maybe.” He said. “It seems most likely. I don't think that, in my right mind, I would ever try and do that.”

“Percy, please...” Annabeth said, steeping into his path, finally getting him to stop. “Tell me what happened.”

Percy sighed again, though there was a slight quiver.

“I almost did something horrible tonight Annabeth... Something that I didn't have complete control over.” Or maybe he did, but he didn't want to think about that possibility.

Annabeth moved closer, looking up at Percy's face. His brow was furrowed, and in his eyes she could see his mind racing. The slight downward curve at the edge of his lips showed her that he was thinking about something unpleasant, but necessary.

Percy was plenty worried, she knew that.

But for what reason?

“I was with Clarisse tonight,” Percy said, stopping her before she could even open her mouth to ask her question again. “Figured she should relax after defending the camp. And I wanted to try something special on her.”

Percy started moving again, moving to the side of Annabeth. His form began to jump about the room, though it was likely he didn't even notice as he recounted the problem to Annabeth.

“It started out normal,” There, on the far side of the room. “Foreplay and all. She had just gotten back from meeting the Fates for her quest into the sea of monsters.” Now next to her again, his form flickering in and out of her conscious view.

That was a really strange experience.

“I split my mind into two pieces, wondering how it would feel to have two bodies fooling around at once.” Again, he vanished, reappearing from the shadows, color slowly appearing on his silhouette. “I was teasing her at first, hoping to give her a very pleasurable night using a new seal from the book that I found.”

He often spent his time browsing through the Eronomicon, looking for anything that might either be helpful to him in the near future, or interested him. The girls knew he did this, since he made it no secret. It was no surprise when he found some new, interesting... thing... in the ancient tome.

“However,” He said, his body slowly turning into the shadows themselves as he walked through a patch of them. “Something went wrong. With me, really. I kept up pleasuring her, even when her mind was starting to reach the limit. If I hadn't stopped myself...”

Percy appeared next to her again, but upside down, standing in the air. He shook his head, somehow not noticing where he was.

“I don't exactly know what happened, as I said.” He vanished, appearing right-side up again as he continued his pacing. “But, for a brief instant, I didn't see Clarisse. All I saw was an object, given human form. To be used at my leisure. What did it matter if it had a mind?”

Percy quickly shook his head again, clearing those thoughts. “Her mind was almost shattered, seeking only pleasure, if even that. Quite possibly she would have retained only the most basic of brain functions to keep her alive, breathing and what not. Something... less. Less then an animal's instinct.”

He vanished, for the umpteenth time, appearing behind Annabeth, who was wishing that he would stay in one place, or at least on one plain of existence. He had stopped his pacing, almost none the wiser, with Annabeth looking around for him.

He wrapped his arms around her, pulling her close to him. She looked up at him, meeting his downcast eyes.

“Thankfully, I was able to stop just short of breaking her.” He said, looking directly at Annabeth. “But I don't know why this happened. Was it just a spur of the moment thing? A split personality? Something else entirely?”

His eyes, unblinking, looked directly through Annabeth, at something only he could see. “To be honest... I'm scared. What happens if this... whatever it is... happens again, and I can't control it? I couldn't bare the thought of losing myself to that, or you, Melum, Sally... anyone really. If it really is a split personality, what else would it be capable of?”

Percy let go of Annabeth, backing away. “What lengths would it go to?”

Annabeth, to be honest herself, quite understandably scared. She had a good reason, more then a few in actuality.

But right now, she needed to steel herself. Having a paranoid break-down wouldn't help anyone, nor would it help her try and figure out was plaguing Percy's mind; beyond his own assumptions, at any rate.

Taking a shaky breath, Annabeth calmed her nerves. Enough to hold a conversation in the calmest voice she could muster.

“Percy, why exactly are you telling me this?” She asked, turning around to look at him. “I mean, I'm glad you're telling me that something's wrong, but why?”

Percy blinked, coming back to the present. “I... don't know...” He admitted. “Perhaps it's the part of me, the old me, that always relied upon you coming up again.” He walked back to Annabeth, standing in front of her. “That part that always relied on your quick thinking, your plans and intuition.”

He raised a hand to her face, gently stroking her cheek. “I know you can't do much, if this is truly a darker aspect of myself. I couldn't expect you to. Using the full capabilities of the Eronomicon, with no moral boundaries, I doubt that any woman would be safe.”

Another prospect that was not comforting to anybody.

“But I felt as if I should have told you. Perhaps... perhaps I thought that you might be able to help me think of something.”

It was silent for a moment, the two of them just staring at the other.

Annabeth sighed, moving closer to Percy. “I don't know what I could do to help with this, Percy. But what I do know is this...”

She looked up at him with stern eyes, though not glaring. “It's not like you to be so doubtful of yourself. I know this is bad, especially if it is a split personality; But I know we can beat it.” Her eyes softened, looking away. “Don't know how... but I know we can. I know you can.”

Percy did nothing, said nothing, for a moment.

Then a small grin, followed by a low chuckle.

“As always, you're right.” He said, shaking his head as his low laugh died off. “Come hell or high water, I won't let this thing, dark side or otherwise, put me down or make me doubt myself. I really can't afford it, for me or anyone else. Nor will I allow it to do as it pleases.”

“Now that's the Percy I know.” Annabeth said.

“You always know what to say, and when to say it.” Percy said, looking down at her.

“It's a gift.” She said playfully. “I’m just glad you're out of that mood, no matter how short it was.”

“Yeah.” Percy said, smiling down at her again. “Thanks for that.”

“Anytime. Just don't make it a habit to start feeling so down on yourself. It doesn't suit you.”

“I won't, I won't.” He said.

The two of them walked out to the balcony, looking at the land, Percy's land, under the night sky.

The replica of the original Dark Tower stood tall, scratching at the sky. A giant black obelisk that was visible for miles.

Surrounding the base of the tower was an extremely large city. Despite being night, there was still the sounds of hustle and bustle about, though not nearly as much as during the day. Blacksmiths were still awake, working on their wares underneath the cover of darkness, selling wares that they would otherwise have to compete for in the day. Merchants, for the most part, had closed up their shops.

Only bars, taverns and inns were open in full force. The sounds of people partying, though very distant, were able to be heard by Percy at least.

The surrounding landscape was wide open plains. Though he could see the Ocean not far from the city. The beginnings of expansion already showed that he was having the city expand to the vast body of water.

Only he knew what lay across those waters.

“I still can't believe that you created all of this.” Annabeth said, looking over the world.

Percy chuckled. “Sometimes, neither can I. Though I wouldn't say that it's all that great. I still have to create my own animals, natural formations, and continue expanding. If this is going to be my main base of operations, I will need a bigger world. Not to mention the stability, especially around the pathways. Have to make absolutely sure that they won't fall apart and have the void come pouring in, erasing everything.”

“I'm sure you'll do fine.” Annabeth assured him.

“Oh, I know I will.” Percy said, his tone not conceited, only very sure of himself. “But I'm just thinking of the amount of work it will take that I alone can do right now.”

Percy looked up at the sky, seeing his copy of the constellation of Zoe Nightshade amidst the stars. “I have a few more things to do tonight Annabeth. Why don't I go take care of those real quick, and then we go for a walk on the beach.”

“Sounds nice.” She said, leaning into his side.

“I thought it would. Why don't you go down and talk with Eres. I'll be back soon.”

Before he left, Percy gave his First Mistress a deep, loving kiss. It conveyed everything he wanted her to know. His love, obviously, but also his gratitude, his happiness, the joy of just being around her... Everything.

When Annabeth opened her eyes again, Percy was already gone. Her arms hung in the air where she had circled them around him.

She smiled up at the night sky, watching as the moon slowly sailed across.

Turning, she made her way back inside. She wondered what news there was of Percy's little girl. That was something Eres always loved to talk about.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy sat in the throne room of the tower, listening to the reports from the various leaders of the factions that made up the city. Merchants guild, the leaders of the construction teams, the (admittedly pointless, to him at least) expedition leaders that just returned from their latest ventures into this new world, and so on.

“And we believe that we have the resources to finish building the wall to the designated port area,” A large, muscular man said, speaking for the construction teams. “Though we know for certain that there won't be enough to start construction on anything in the area, such as warehouses, homes, inns, or a ship yard. Even then, it will take six months, at the least, to even finish half of the new city limits.”

“When you propose that it would be done, ports, housing and all?” Percy asked. He expected something like this, but it was no major worry.

The builder's and masons all looked at one another, muttering a few things to each other before their speaker spoke up once more.

“About two years, at the least, Mi'Lord.” He said. “And that's if we work constantly, having teams during both day and night working on construction.”

Percy hummed in thought, placing his armored hand against his shadowed chin. It wouldn't do any good, working the people like animals. There would be accidents, people would be injured, and the construction would slow down.

“You have two and a half years to complete the wall and port district. In three and a half years time, I want ships sailing across the waters. No need to put people in danger over a matter as simple as this.”

The builders bowed, each and every one of them. “As you command, Overlord.”

“Now,” Percy said as his eyes looked over the gathered delegates of their respective communities. “I believe it was the heads of magic up next?”

A robed figure coughed. It was a man, just under middle-aged. His hair was a shade of gold, and his skin was a tad pale. His body was frail, frailer then most men his age. He had, next to his chair, a wooden staff. Nothing out of the ordinary about it, save for the small runes that had been carved into it.

“Yes, Overlord.” He said. His body may have been weak, but his voice was strong. “We have little to report since the last meeting. As per your instructions, we have kept a close eye on our magicks for any loss, or changing, of power. One of the only thing that is of note is that our magic gets stronger near the 'pathway's' to our old worlds. Other then that, me nor my colleagues have had any problems with the universal transition with either magic or body. The only other thing that I can think of, off the top of my head, is that some of the more... eager... member's of the magical community have been hoping that you would release the ban on mixing magic from different worlds.”

“Absolutely not.” Percy said immediately. “Until there is sufficient time and resources to build specific locations for such tests to take place, I will keep the ban in place. I am not so willing to allow possibly dangerous experiments to endanger the city, nor the stability of the universe.”

The man nodded, leaning back in his chair. “I thought as much. I may not be as experienced as some of the older member's of the various orders, but I have more then enough sense to not mix things like this haphazardly. I've destroyed many a good labs in my younger days, concocting both new magic and new potions. I know enough about unstable energies to understand the risk.”

“I would hope so, as the representative of magic in this court.” Percy said. “Remind the magic users that I will know if they start trying to experiment in this matter, and punishment will be severe. Also remind them that summoning outside forces, such as demons or gods that have not been cleared will result in the same. I don't want to have to fight another legion from the deepest pits of -” Percy made a noise, an unnatural sound to be coming from human, animal or, as some could attest to, demon. “-Again.”

More then a few in the room shifted uncomfortably, all having sudden, and very fierce, headaches. One man had to wipe some blood from his nose as his body twitched slightly.

While knowing that Percy was, essentially, a god, and that he was prone to doing things that they couldn't possibly comprehend, such as the noise he made earlier, helped ease the blow of it, the point of the fact is that he could still do things that were so incomprehensible to them that it could kill them all with just a few sounds. And even still, knowing that he could do all this, still did not stop their minds nor bodies from reacting to his otherworldly actions.

“U-understood.” The Wizard said, leaning back again.

'Eres, I want you to double the patrol's of blues in the city, and I want the green's and Browns to tighten security around the gates to the town.' Percy said mentally to the tower heart's personification. 'Starting tonight.'

'At once Sire.' She thought back.

Percy closed his eyes, looking at the heavens from his throne to see the position of the celestial bodies.

“This meeting has gone on long enough for today.” Percy said suddenly. “If there are any important matters to discuss that need my attention right away, stay seated. Otherwise, you are free to leave. We can pick up again in a few days time, barring any sudden emergencies.”

Most people, for there were both men and women in that meeting, agreed. They had been in this meeting for more then a few hours. They had work to finish up for the day, and several had families to go home to.

A retinue of browns entered the meeting hall, their normally air-headed personalities kept in check by the fact that Percy had commanded all minions to act seriously when these meeting's took place. Even from the simple-minded browns and bestial reds.

And, as Minions, they were both compelled and happy to do so. Everything that they did, everything that they were... was for the Overlord. Their lives, their souls (If they had such a thing), their bodies... everything.

But, did everyone at the meeting go?
