1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy watched as all the delegates stood up, muttering their farewell's to the fellow leaders of the community.

'How far we've come in such a short time.' Percy thought, waving at several who he had befriended during his time among them. 'Already a full blown city...'

Well, that was mostly due to him, several powerful magic users and a very diligent workforce in the minions and humans alike. He had sculpted the land to fit a city of great proportions, while the humans and minions brought materials for building. The magic-users had actually constructed the city, though they had said that they would only do it this once, claiming it was a waste of their talents and power.

Justified, in that any one of them could have leveled a city far grander by themselves as easily as putting on a magic show.

The only ones who weren't so adverse to the task, wholeheartedly accepting this task with glee, were druids and other types that used magic that could easily build something.

It was a very diverse city, with varying types living in it, all with their own thoughts on who a city should look. Their building styles reflected that.

The more nature attuned types had much more plant-life, for example. It was common to find homes that were made out of tree's that were grown just so, to provide a living space.

However, to counteract any problems that might have risen, Percy, and the faction leaders, had agreed to wall off segments of the city from each other. Not to segregate them though. It was a precaution, to ensure that the populace wouldn't overrun each other and cause undue problems.

It was simple to get through to whatever section you wanted to visit. There were gates along each wall, each half a mile away from the others. And, if you were on the opposite side of the city from where you wanted to go, there was an inner ring that allowed one to travel directly to other districts.

This inner ring was directly outside the walls of the Dark tower, which stood in the center of the city. It would take half a day to walk around it completely, with the entrances to each district little more then a mile away from each other.

And who made up the citizens of the city, you may ask?

Such an answer can be both simple and complicated.

The short answer would be everyone, though without context.

The longer answer would be everyone that Percy had come across during his travels that wished to move to a new city, providing they followed his rule.

The people who would have died in the explosion from the fake tower-heart were the first to populate the world, though they were quickly joined by others.

As Percy had gone to other worlds, other universes, he had done much in little time. Though he had not particularly gone out of his way to save anybody, he had come across quite a few in different universes that had required assistance with dire situations.

Others had joined him for various reasons. Some served goddesses that he had brought into his fold, others saw that what he offered would be beneficial to them, or any number of reasons really.

It wasn't just women that he saved and brought to the new city, though that had been the majority of the population. He brought men as well, as evidenced by the meeting just now.

Though he had, in no uncertain terms, told everyone who joined him just exactly what he was. A god of lust and perversion, and a hard but fair leader.

Percy, in a show of good will to the men and women with families, had given his word that he would not use his power in the city.

It may have gone against the nature of being the Harem god, but he was willing to do this.

He still had his principles after all.

Percy mainly used the minions as the peacekeepers, with the smarter blues leading groups of browns, while separate groups that consisted entirely of blues walked around the town to keep track of the magic that was in use.

Browns and greens kept watch over the gates,with the greens making sure no one tried to get anything past the browns. Sadly, that was a simple task, hence the greens being there in the first place.

The reds... well, the reds were kept in reserve. If the need ever arose to use them, then they were used. Otherwise, they were kept away from the city, mostly in the dark tower.

Not only that, but Percy had the Blue minions working with the more responsible magic users to create a security net for magic over, and under, the city. That way it would be able to detect magic, what type, no matter what part of the city, to make sure that the ban wasn't broken.

It should have been a simpler task then the language barrier's that allowed the people from different worlds to communicate easily, but it wouldn't seem to be. Apparently, breaking down language barriers that shouldn't have ever existed in the first place, due to being from entirely different universes in the first place, was simpler then detecting magic from different worlds. Though, obviously, there were just things not meant to be heard by mortal ears from any universe.

Not to say that only the minions were doing community work. There were 'human' guards for each district, all who had three 'human' commanding officers that each overlooked a third of the district, who in turn had a single, of course, 'human' commander above them that was the overseer of the entire district, who then in turn answered directly to Percy. Human being the term for any mortal being, obviously.

The 'pathways' that were spoken of earlier were actually outside the city, for the moment anyway, but all had outposts of mages and minions, the mages being stationed at the pathway to their own universe. While Eres was connected to them, it was nice to have people watching for anything that Eres might miss due to being busy with something else.

Percy had created these pathways to connect universes that he had brought people from, or had connections or footholds in.

As of right now, since Percy had no power over time, nor a goddess who could control time, Percy had connected the flow of time in the universe to himself. However fast time moved for him, it moved for the universe.

Except for around the pathways. Time was distorted around there, but not by much. The pathways speed up or slowed down the flow of time as one got close to them, causing strange phenomenon to those caught in it for extended periods.

The only pathways in the city were buried far underground, so they would have no effect on it. The one to Percy's home universe, and the one that led to the universe where he was mantled Overlord, where the dark tower used to stand.

Speaking of the dark tower, it should be said that this was the only thing that he created within the city structure-wise, for reasons that only he knew. He had made it to serve as not only his home, but also as the prison, court house, palace and other community functions on the ground levels, and training grounds, living quarters for special guests that he allowed to stay at the tower, or, should he ever get any other then the minions, staff for keeping the tower in order. He also kept a lab up there for mundane, harmless experiments, though with very powerful magic and construction for protection. The same could be said of a personal forge, used by either him or Giblet.

There was also the area underground, which served as home for the minions, training area for new minions, a forge that tapped into lava veins for heat, an armory, a lab for the more dangerous experiments that Percy had started to preform, and an incredibly large audience hall for when he wanted to address all minions at once and in person.

Despite all the empty room, Percy had made the tower that way in case expansion was needed. After all, where would his future daughters sleep?

And, just to top it all off, it was a fortress of its own class. Percy had planned, with help from great minds well versed in warfare, for any great attack. Percy knew he had pissed off a lot of the gods and goddesses whose universe's he had 'invaded' over the course of the last year. It would be no surprise to suddenly be in a battle against various gods and their armies.

The pathways were, unfortunately, a double edged sword. They granted Percy a way to easily traverse between them, and allowed mortals to travel between as well without asking Percy to take them.

However, this also meant that other things could come through. Monsters, demons, gods and the like.

And that was something Percy could not ignore. It was as likely as anything that a vengeful god would gather allies to launch a full blown attack.

And even if Percy could deal with them, he knew there would be collateral. Even with the help of the greatest warriors and magic-users, there would be collateral, in life and land.

It was a surprise that they hadn't been attacked yet, in reality.

Percy sighed, shaking his head. It would not do well to dwell on events that may never occur. And even if war did knock on his door, he already had plans in place.

Some may call him paranoid, but he needed to be prepared for absolutely anything.

In the vast, infinitely expanding multiverse, almost anything was possible.

And he would, hopefully, be ready for it all.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Several days later, Percy was looking at the half-constructed dark tower, scaffolding and other such dotted the smaller replica of the tower he personally created. Old-time pulley systems littered the top-most completed floors.

Percy could have gotten cranes and other modern things that could have helped the construction, but there were two reasons he didn't. One, the minions, and Tyson, worked well enough without the machines. The other was that... well...

Let's just say minions did not work well with machines beyond steam-powered technology.

It always, always turned out badly.

And not necessarily in funny or life threatening ways either.

Strange, that...

“Glad I learned those barrier spells from ɅɄɑɧʉʎʫЖҲỻἃ to make sure that planes and other stuff would fly around this. Dare I say it, it works better then the mist.”

At the sound of the incomprehensible name, a small area around Percy shook.

“Heh.” Percy chuckled a small bit. “Seems not even Gaea can understand things from outside the universe. It must have given her quite a headache.”

Percy strode into the half-finished tower, the minions never stopping their work.

Speaking of the minions, unsurprisingly, most were dressed in the bare minimum of clothing they could manage for the construction of the dark tower. Considering that mostly browns were working on the construction, that was bordering on bare skin. Anything that killed them would have killed a mere human several times over, so it's not like they could have been anymore protected if they wore work clothes of any type.

Besides, they had several teams of blues at the ready in case of any serious emergency.

The sound of a rope snapping above Percy reached his ears, and a whistling sound was rushing towards him along with the sounds of breaking stone.

Percy merely looked up, hearing as, what he could only assume to be, a large load of rocks was falling from way up the tower. He could see the stone above him crack, small bits falling around him before the entire portion of the ceiling he was under collapsed.

“Of course. Even without something controlling my life, it seems like my luck can be just as bad as usual.” Percy muttered, looking up unworried as stone fell towards his head.

He was about to raise his hand to do something about this minor annoyance, he felt someone charge at him.

“Percy!” A, distinctively male, voice called as Percy found himself being hoisted up from behind and carried out from under the debris.

Unfortunately, his carrier ended up tripping on their own feet, sending both crashing to the ground.

Percy put out his hand, putting a crater in the ground as he pushed himself and his would-be savior from the ground.

“Tyson...” Percy said, keeping calm despite his irritation. “Get off me.”

Percy's cyclopian half-brother scrambled off off him.

“Sorry.” He mumbled as Percy stood up and dusted himself off. “Forgot that Percy's really strong.”

“It's okay.” Percy said, patting Tyson on the shoulder. “No harm done.”

Percy thought it strange, being taller then Tyson. Instead of Percy being dwarfed by the young cyclops, Percy now stood nearly a foot taller. And while Tyson was built thicker with natural muscle, Percy could easily out-bear-hug his half-brother.

“How's it been going Tyson?” Percy asked. “Have the minions been giving you trouble?”

Tyson looked over at the closest minions, which had already gotten to cleaning up the pile of rubble, and blushed as he quickly looked away.

Percy laughed, patting Tyson on the shoulder. “It's okay Tyson. Come on now. Eres told me you wanted to show me something?” He said, pulling the embarrassed monster away from the main area of the tower.

Tyson's mood did a one-eighty, going from embarrassed to excited almost immediately. He was bouncing in place, grinning ear-to-ear.

As Percy and Tyson walked to the latter's room, something in the darkness slithered behind them.

~

“These are great Tyson.” Percy said, rolling up the last paper and setting it back on the table. “I'll see what I can do to get you the materials and send these plans to the minions in charge of construction. And I'm sure Giblet would like to see some of these herself.”

Percy had finished going over the last of Tyson’s design plans, for both the tower and other projects. While Percy would admit that Giblet was good at making armor and weapons, and the minions were a good workforce, a cyclops was naturally better.

Tyson was grinning still, happy that his idea's were worth something. And, having met the leader of the brown minions personally and seen her work, Tyson felt like he had won the lottery.

Tyson's room was fairly large, even for someone Tyson's size, with various little projects Tyson had going on at the moment scattered around, but not in the way of anyone's feet. Even more numerous were sketches that Tyson had made. Weapons, armor, anything that he felt like drawing.

Even Annabeth was surprised with how much detail the cyclops had put into the sketches for whatever he planned.

“Tell you what.” Percy said. “Why don't we go into town and have some fun. A reward, and to say sorry for not coming around very often.”

“Yay!” Tyson cheered, wrapping his arms around Percy in a tight hug. “Thank you Percy.”

“No problem big guy.” Percy said, returning the hug.

Percy was walking away from the tower, the moonlight casting a pale glow over everything it touched.

The forest was silent, the Nymphs sleeping in their trees. No animals were foraging, nor bugs buzzing.

It was completely silent...

To a normal person, that is.

“You can come out now.” Percy said, stopping where he was. “I can hear you, you know.”

A presence, one that had been following him around the tower and the surrounding areas all day, slithered from the shadows.

“I was wondering when you would acknowledge my presence.” The faceless voice said, moving around the darkened forest. “You know I hate being ignored for long periods of time.”

Percy chuckled, not even turning to look as his stalker closed the distance from behind, slender arms wrapping around him and two mounds of flesh pressing into his back. Hot breath tickled the back of his neck as a long tongue flicked out to lick him. Around his feet, a long serpentine tail was wrapping around him in a vain attempt to hold him in place.

“Having fun?” Percy asked as four sharp fangs were drawn across his neck, trying their hardest to make him shiver in pleasure.

“Very much.” The voice said, laughing at how he kept his poise in a situation that would make most people turn into a blubbering mess. “And you? Are you enjoying my attentions?”

“Very much.” Percy parroted, his legs completely wrapped in the coils. “Though I must ask, where are Peísma and the Chimera, Echidna?”

“Sleeping.” The mother of monsters said. “They were picking fights with the others, as usual. Today was a particularly energetic day for them all.”

Percy nodded. “I hope you find your new body, and the abilities it gives, suitable.”

Echidna chuckled, letting go of Percy as her upper body moved into his view. “I certainly do, my love.”

Where once her skin was tinged green and had scales on her arms, she now had unblemished, chocolate colored skin. Her hair was as long as ever, and her breasts had not diminished. Her pupils were slits, like a snakes, the previously sickening yellow from before Percy had changed her was glowing a hypnotic golden even in the shadows beneath the trees. The necklace Percy had given her was still around her neck, the charm of a small platinum heart with a diamond center hidden in the valley of her chest. Her stomach was slightly taut, a small layer of muscle being the only sign of her extraordinary strength as a monster.

From her waist down, though, was something completely inhuman. It was a large, snake like body, currently wrapped around Percy. It was covered in green scales, which shone like emeralds when exposed to light. It was about seven feet long, from where it started to the tip.

Her tail tightened around Percy for a second before letting back up as Echidna moved her face near Percy's.

“I must say though, the only things I liked about my human body were being able to walk among humans and laying with you.” She trailed a few fingers across Percy's face, a sharp nail drawing golden blood from him. “Though I'm sure if you were willing, we could... experiment... with this form.”

Percy shook his head. “I'm good. While I may be fine having sex with a furred person and demons, I'm still not sure about having sex with something whose lower body isn't humanoid.”

“A pity.” Echidna said, a slight frown on her face. “But I'm sure at some point you'll decided to try it.”

“Probably.” Percy said, shrugging. “I really wouldn't doubt it, given my nature. You'll be the first one I ask though, when that day comes.”

Echidna smirked, patting him on the cheek. “I would hope so.”

She leaned her face in, flicking her tongue out to taste his blood before tenderly kissing the wound.

Her lower body uncoiled from around Percy as she continued to lavish affections on him, and he lavished affection on her in return, wrapping his arms around her and hitting the right spots on her back to give her a pleasant feeling.

Echidna moved away, leaves crunching under her now human feet, scales negating any need for shoes.

“But for now, this form will do.” Echidna said, her eyes filled with the utmost love as she leaned against a tree, spreading her legs. “Take me Percy. Fill me with a new life.”

Percy looked at Echidna for a moment before walking closer to her.

That night, there was one Nymph that got no sleep as her home was shaken and a woman moaned into her ear.

“Are you sure this will help them?” Percy asked the Eronomicon as he stood on a street corner in New York.

'I'm one hundred percent sure, Marked one.' The tome said, three seals imprinted on Percy's hands. 'Have I ever led you astray?'

“Once, last summer.” Percy grumbled, his mood souring slightly. “I thought that the Database would have taken my mother's soul from her body. Not created a copy. I know you said that you were working with something when I sprung the sudden, urgent request on you, but even still...”

'To be fair, I have apologized countless times for that. Not only that, but I distinctly remember you asking for something to preserve her soul, no matter what. Technically, I did as you asked. You could have given the soul a new body... But perhaps it is because of the way this world works. It is easy for someone like yourself to go to the land of the dead, and it would be far from the realm of imagination for you to go there and happen to run into the true spirit of your mother.' The Eronomicon said. 'But I am sure that this will do exactly as needed. Restore the eye sight of these three women, and the de-aging seal has been worked into each seal so they won't be ancient in appearance.'

Percy nodded, fishing out a golden drachma from his pocket.

“Been awhile since I spoke in ancient Greek.” Percy said. “Though, thanks to you,” he said, patting the book in his pocket. “I guess I shouldn't have to worry about it. Still, it's still a pain having you cram as many languages into my brain as you can.”

'It is for the best, Marked one. Otherwise, you would not have been able to communicate with people of other universes, among other things. In any case, I haven't even gotten to the more powerful languages yet, despite what I have already given you.'

Percy sighed. “I know, I know. You told me that before. By the way, how long do you think that it'll take for you to cram all that language stuff into my head? I've been curious about that.”

The Eronomicon was silent for a moment, though Percy swore he heard muttering.

'Given how fast your limits are breaking now, and based upon that knowledge alone without factoring in future power spikes and increased growth speed provided by women... I would hazard a guess of about thirty five to seventy years, give or take.'

“That's a pretty big gap in time.” Percy said, eyebrow raised questioningly.

'True, but it also depends on if certain languages are needed faster then others. There are so many languages still to come, quite a few dwarfing what you already know in power, complexity and size. I find that it would be easier to work with the simpler things right now, work your way up in difficulty and make it easier to learn the more complex ones. As I said, I might need to force the knowledge into your mind instead of letting if flow, as I am now. Though, if you were to ascend, that would cut down on the time drastically.'

“How drastic we talking about?” Percy asked, flipping the golden coin and catching it repeatedly.

'Down to, at max, three years, with a minimum of six months.'

Percy whistled, grabbing the coin for the final time. “Well, as interesting as that is, we have work to do. We can talk more about my ascending to godhood later, and the fringe benefits it would give.”

Looking at the coin in his hand, imprinted with the empire state building and Athena’s head on the sides, Percy tossed it in the middle of the street.

“Stêthi, Ô hárma diabolês!” Percy shouted, the ancient Greek rolling off his tongue easily.

Compared to other languages, it was a trivial matter.

You could ask any one of the woman he had been with. His tongue could do amazing things.

Interesting how that worked, in all seriousness.

Where the coin had landed, the area around it began to smoke, the asphalt bubbling up as it turned to a deep, dark red.

With no notice, a black, smoke-like taxi burst from the red ooze. It leaped from the seemingly bottomless murk at full speed, landing many feet away with a screech of the tires as it drove wildly, turning and jumping the curb more then once as it sped back to him.

“Passage? Passage?” A mumbling, ancient voice asked from the crack of the passenger window as the taxi skidded to a halt in front of Percy.

“I'm here for business... Tempest is it? You should have been expecting me sometime this week.” Percy said simply, not making a move towards the vehicle of the damned.

It went silent in the taxi, not even the breathing he had heard incredibly faintly, even for him, was heard.

“So...” The same voice said, merely a whisper and now focused. “You are the one we were shown.”

“Yes, yes.” Another voice said, the same intensity but at the same time sounding very bitter. “Enter, enter. We would like to get this business down with and out of the way.”

The back door popped open, wisps of blue smoke wafting from it.

Percy shrugged his shoulder's, climbing in back.

As the door shut behind him, the ooze from before boiled from beneath the taxi, which slowly sank into the bloody abyss without a trace.

~

The taxi rose from a the abyss, at a much slower pace then before.

Percy looked out the window, taking notice of where they had ended up.

They were on an island, Percy knew. It was also very cold, if the snow was any indication. Lifeless trees dotted the over-all bleak landscape. Ice floated just off the edges of the beach that Percy could see.

An empty, dark sky hung above, stuck in perpetual night without the stars or moon.

How there was any light, Percy didn't exactly know.

“Hurry up Anger.” One of the three said, voice as cold and bitter as the landscape.

“Don't start with me Wasp.” The sister behind the wheel snapped. “If you would give me the eye, I could see exactly where I was going.”

“I don't have it.” Wasp said. “Tempest has been hogging it all day.”

“If Anger would give me the tooth, I-”

“Enough!” Percy said. He was not going to listen to three old ladies bicker about who had what body parts they had to share. “I will say this, if our meeting goes well today, you won't have to worry about such matters again. But I will not listen to this drivel between you the entire time. If you want any chance of being freed from your current torment, I suggest you three keep your tongues in check. Whichever one of you has the eye, give it to the one driving. The other two can fight over the tooth for all I care.”

Percy sighed, leaning back into the beaten-up leather of the cab, which seemed similar to the clothing and leather you could find made out of damned souls in the underworld.

How many different types of material did they manage to work souls into in this world?

Percy's hell was only able to torture people ironically. A dwarf turned into a golden statue for instance.

Maybe he should ask Hades how he did things like that.

The Grey sisters muttered in anger, sickening sounds as they switched out the eye and tooth between the three of them. Wasp and Tempest were fighting over the tooth as Anger stuck the eye-ball into one of the empty sockets.

“Good.” Percy muttered, rubbing his forehead as he tried to ignore the pink aura around the three ancient women as their faces tried to imprint themselves into his mind with the words above their heads. 'I really don't want to remember what they look like now.' He thought.

'Sire, I wanted to remind you that the empire will be approaching Nordburg in less then a week, about five days, according to the time of this world.' Eres's voice spoke.

Percy sighed again. 'Okay. Have Jewel deliver the last gift, and get the brown minions ready to move for assistance. I'll even allow them to take the wolves for this.' He ordered. 'Now, please, no more interruptions. If anything comes up, I want you to hold it off unless it is of the utmost importance.'

'As you wish, Sire.' Eres said, the image of the ghostly personification bowing reached Percy's mind as her presence faded from his mind.

'I hope this meeting goes well.' Percy thought, going back to his current situation. 'And I hope that the Fates are already there.'

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
The chariot of the damned reached the crest of the hill it was climbing, all four of its riders silent. The sight of the beach was lost long ago. But nothing else had changed with the landscape.

Percy could see through the windshield that the house of the Grey sisters was not large, by any means, nor grand or even in good repair.

A rundown house, with the paint, if there had been any, long stripped away. The shingles were falling off, and the cobble-stone chimney was half gone.

The only good thing about the house was that, despite all its faults, it looked well insulated for what it was. The windows seemed secure, there were no visible holes and the door looked very solid and heavy.

“Tempest, did you leave the fire going again?” Anger asked her sister. “If you did, I-”

“Wasn't me. Wasp dealt with the fire before we started today's rounds.”

“Don't blame me. I distinctly remember putting it out. Even shoveled the ashes because you two are too lazy to do it!”

“Don't you take that tone with me!” Anger and Tempest said at the exact same time.

Indeed, there was a large pile of ashes, almost covered by snow. It was just to the side of the door, but enough to not get in the way.

“Give me the eye, I want to see!” Wasp said.

With a sigh, Anger...

Well, let's leave the details to the imagination for how she extracted the eye, shall we?

“What going on?” Wasp asked, feeling rage build with her confusion.

Percy saw it as well. A smoke trail from the broken chimney, and an orange glow in the windows of the derelict abode.

But, seen only to him, three pink aura's were in the home, sitting around what he could only assume was the fire.

“It seems the others are here.” Percy muttered to himself. “Good.”

~

Percy sighed. He should have expected something like this.

No small amount of yelling had taken place in the last ten minutes, most of it just just the screeching of pure anger and hatred. Objects had been thrown and broken, and Percy had more then once had something directed towards him, which he casually avoided.

Atropos looked at Wasp, her face emotionless as both sets of sisters stared down one of the opposite group.

'Are you quite finished?' She asked, rubbing the charcoal marks from her face and smoothing out her dress.

Clotho and Lachesis did the same, never taking their eyes off their would-be attackers.

The worst they had done was give them a crappily done makeover with ancient utensils and ruffle their clothes.

Mind you, this was in an attempt to kill them with said utensils, probably in a gruesome fashion that included breaking their teeth and trying to cut their faces, smash their bones and various other ways.

The sisters Grey were breathing heavily, their faces slowly returning to a normal shade instead of the outlandish red they had sported not even two minutes ago from their attempt to scream the Fates into non-existence, damning their very names and curse everything they had ever done.

All in all, what anyone normally did if they met the Fates if they had a bad life.

Though, for once, it was justified.

“Now that that's over,” Percy said as he stood up. “Shall we get to what the point of this entire thing was?”

His tone made it clear he was not in mood to deal with annoyances.

~

“No!” Anger yelled.

“Absolutely not!” Tempest shouted, banging her old hands on the table with a surprising amount of force.

“Not even after the end of time!” Wasp raged, they eye glaring at all of them simultaneously in a frenzied manner.

Percy rubbed his head. 'Keep calm, this was as expected for the most part.' He said, trying to calm himself.

It had been about an hour since this discussion started.

In reality, it would have only taken five, maybe ten minutes to have the Fates say their part.

If only the sisters Grey would let them speak for more then a minute without starting back in or just getting up and leaving before Percy had to bring them back in forcefully.

And again, this was expected for the most part.

The true extent to their hatred was far beyond even Percy's expectations.

'I don't really see what you have to lose just by thinking on it.' Clotho said, still emotionless as she looked at the three people who hated them the most.

'Yes. We are offering not just our apologies, but also a way to fix what even we cannot.' Lachesis said.

'And do not resort to petty violence again.' Atropos warned, the only emotion she had shown for the last hour. 'As with last time, it will have no effect other then mess our appearance up. But if you do that again, there will be consequences.'

“You can take this 'deal' of yours and-”

“ENOUGH!” Percy shouted, at his limit. He slammed his hands on the table, smashing it into pieces. “Enough of this asinine bickering! I don't care what was done to you, but you have no reason to continue acting this way! They are trying to amend for what they did to you, which is a lot more then anyone from Greek history has ever done without being forced to do so! Are you going to let this chance to be free from your curse slip through your bony fingers because of some petty grudge?”

“How dare you call this petty!” Anger snarled at him, not fazed by what he had done.

“Yes, I dare this petty!” Percy shot back. “How many more people have had far worse punishments then you three? At least you can see, at least you aren't in pain every day! At least you aren't alone, stuck on an island for just being someones daughter! You haven't faded!”

Percy stood, standing on the debris of the table as he looked at the ancient sisters.

“And face it! You brought this on yourselves. You were already powerful enough seeress's on your own, from what I've been told. Sure, the Fates could have gone about it better, and maybe they let their pride get in the way for once during their work, but you were prideful as well!”

“They made us! They controlled us, as they do everything!” Wasp shouted.

'You don't seem to understand where we are coming from.' Clotho said, her voice suddenly very cold and bitter.

'You do not truly understand our power, or even the limitations set by it.' Lachesis said, glaring right into the empty sockets of Tempest.

'Though we may weave the lives of every thing in existence, we are still bound by laws. Just like everything else.' Atropos said heatedly.

'We may weave all destinies, but we must do so with the thought of how each person must act in order to get there.'

'Like a story-teller of the olden days, there must be structure for it to work.'

'If there was not, it would be chaos.'

'We cannot make things with no precedent happen, at least by ourselves.'

'You yourselves truly wanted power you did not need. We did not make you want the power.'

'It was simply the place you ended up on the road of choices that make up both life and destiny.'

'And even then, this is simply a very, very simple understanding of our power.' Clotho finished, her voice never warming.

“We don't give a-”

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“I said enough!” Percy roared again, Riptide appearing in his hands.

The less powerful trio of sisters flinched, all taking a step back. Even the ones who didn't have eyes.

'Perseus!' Lachesis said, reaching out to grab his shoulder. 'Don't kill them!'

Percy turned to look back at the Fates, his eyes glowing green, though they did flick to pink for a second, fast enough to where even Lachesis wasn't sure she saw it.

“I'm not going to kill them.” He growled. “But you really won't care what happens to them in a minute. Or they, in turn, care about you.”

He turned his head back to the three ancient women, shaking as he held his sword at the ready. He could easily see the bond the three shared with the Fates. It was the biggest bond they had.

Ethereal ropes, about a foot wide each, stretched from the hearts of the sisters, black with hatred and pulsing like the heart of a live beast.

There were smaller threads, connecting to far off places in different realms and planes of existence. Some were so tiny to almost be non-existent, while most were still tiny, but big enough to be seen.

There were no warm colors, nothing to signify that these women had an emotional attachment that was made from anything other then indifference and hatred. No signs of respect, nor compassion, or trust.

Not even between each other.

Percy could see the names tied to each string that ran from the sisters Grey. He could see every single person they had ever met, even the dead and forgotten, or even the people they merely saw for the briefest of moments out of the corner of their eyes.

Even the bond they had with him was black, and growing larger by the second.

Percy raised Riptide, swinging twice at the three largest bonds.

And just like that, most of the tension was gone. The hostile air was gone, though replaced with the sudden air of complete indifference.

It was just as smothering, to be honest, but in a vastly different way.

Even the bond between them and himself was changing, going back to a small indifference, though not on the level between the two sets of sisters.

No. Those bonds were completely gone. Even looking directly at the others didn't create a bond.

The bond between them and him was, by proxy, through the Fates. That's why the animosity was fading.

“We're leaving.” Percy said as he turned towards the Fates, Riptide disappearing. “This was utterly pointless.”

He turned his head back, looking Wasp directly in the eye.

“You wasted the first time you have been truly given completely free-will. Now you're going to be stuck like that, with no one to hate, no true drive. There was no controlling anybody here, neither from myself or these three.”

He turned, walking to the three Moirae, who didn't even regard the three other women's existence.

“I hope you think on this deal further though. I might offer it again, possibly with some changes to it though. Until then, you can stew with the thoughts of have a chance for freedom at your grasp, but you pushed it away by being petulant when they tried to make amends, even if you couldn't care less about what they did now.”

Percy didn't need the power of the Severer to know that the string connecting them was growing black once more.

Without another word, the group of four vanished from the island as the Grey sisters raged at Percy.

~

All four of them appeared in the chamber of Fate, Olympus far below their feet.

Percy sighed, rubbing his head.

“This is probably going to bite me in the ass later.” He muttered. “Somehow always does.”

He walked over to the bed, sitting down.

“I need something to calm my nerves. I can't believe it was that... that...” Percy growled out.

The three Fates sat on the bed, sighing as well.

Not in anger at the Grey sisters, but in exasperation as the fact that Percy's plan didn't work. Wasted time, when they could have been working.

Although, they felt like something was missing. A guilt of some kind...

'Wait, didn't you say that there was something special about your sword Percy?' Lachesis asked, pondering what this feeling was.

“Huh? Oh, right. I only mentioned that in passing. The Eronomicon had a blade in its possession to fight against beings who grew stronger the more people felt about it, be it fear or love. It's called the Severer, and it cuts the bonds between people. No trace of emotion between them whatsoever. You might even forget them in a few days. It did me the favor of mixing it with Riptide. Ironically, I did this for sentimental reasons. But I don't need to tell you that.”

'So your saying you used this...'

'On us?'

“Yeah.” Percy said, sighing angrily. “I was tired of hearing the same thing over and over again from them. You should have seen it though. The amount of pure hatred they held for you... I don't think I saw something like that. It was disgusting.” He said, voice mirroring his revulsion for what he saw. “It needed to be cut down. And really, it's a just punishment. For so long, they thrived off of hating you. Now, they have nothing to hate. They let it all slip through their fingers, just because they hated you all so much.”

It was silent as Percy leaned back on the bed, taking some comfort in the sheets of darkness beneath him.

'You look so tired.' Atropos said, leaning back onto an outstretched arm, placing a hand on his chest.

'Yes. Forget what happened. Relax for a while.' Clotho whispered sensually as she did the same to the other arm, also placing a hand on his chest.

'You did what you could to mend the situation. For that, you deserve a reward~” Lachesis giggled, her thoughts turning from the apathetic conversation they had been having to thoughts of something far more precious to her and her sisters.

Time with Percy.

Lachesis stood up, not having an arm to lean on. She moved between to stand over Percy, between his legs as they were firmly planted to the ground.

She leaned down, laying directly on top of Percy, giving him a full kiss.

Lachesis moaned into the kiss, her fingers entwined in Percy's hair.

Percy couldn't help but smile between the kisses, a soft chuckle escaping him.

“I guess I could spend a day or so here. I really don't spend enough time with you three.”

'It's fine, dear husband.' Clotho said, hushing him with her words.

'We are very busy, you know. And you have your own plans.' Atropos reassured.

'Though,' Lachesis started, pulling away with a coy smile. 'It wouldn't hurt for you to come around more often, now would it?'

“Not in the slightest.” Percy said with a gentle smile.

Behind them, another Percy appeared, walking silently over to them.

Seeing that he was in place, Percy smirked playfully at Lachesis as the body he had faded, leaving the Fates flat on their bed.

“C'mere you!” Percy said, picking Lachesis up by her waist.

That night, there was much bonding between the Fates and Percy. Not just sexual bonding, but emotional bonding and family bonding as well.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“So, uncle. How have things been around here?” Percy asked, tossing the red rubber ball in his hands across the fields of Asphodel for what seemed the thousandth time that day, Cerberus happily chasing after it.

“Same thing that's been happening since I took this position.” Hades said, relaxing in a smaller, less ornate throne. “Though I've been trying to make time for my children, whenever I can.”

“How is their training coming along since I last saw them by the way?” Percy asked, sitting across from his uncle at a small table.

Percy was, obviously, visiting the underworld. He had come to check in on Cerberus and his cousins training, among a few other things.

They were currently sitting outside the palace, off to the side in what amounted to a picnic area outside the normal garden of Persephone. It was a nice place to relax after a day of attending to the duties it took to run a kingdom, living or dead.

Hades sighed, rubbing his eyes in exasperation. “I detest these rules that I have to abide by. I can only leave cryptic messages to their instructors for them to figure out, which can sometimes take the better part of a week. But they are progressing nicely, I'm happy to inform.”

“That's nice to hear.” Percy said, taking the ball from Cerberus as she ran up to him, chest heaving as she took deep breaths. She was panting, tongue lolling from her mouth as she kept her eyes fixated on the ball to the extent. “By the way, how do you turn tortured souls in clothing and the like?”

Hades raised an eyebrow. “That's a sudden subject change. Might I ask why the sudden interest?”

Percy shrugged, throwing the ball again, this time to the other side of the sprawling field. “Some souls have started getting used to the torture that they've been subject to for so long. And I figured that the souls that are no longer receptive to the torture might as well be put to some use. After all, I'm sure I can figure out a way to make them useful for more then clothing.”

Hades chuckled, a deep baritone laugh. “Very well. Normally, the soul needs to be dipped in the atrocities that it accumulated during life...”

~Several hours later

“Interesting.” Percy said, stroking Cerberus's sleeping head as she laid it on his lap, snoring softly. “I'll have the reapers get right on that. Things like that are their specialty, after all. And Uncle, one more thing I would like to know.”

“If it's about Bianca, my answer is still the same.” Hades said, sounding only what a loving and protective father could sound like. “If you can win her heart, without your tricks and divine powers, then she will be yours. But be warned, that if I think that you are cheating in your attempts to court her, I will kill you. Immortal or not, and even if I die in the process, I will kill you. The treaty we have be damned.”

“Of course. And as I said last time, I would abide by your rule, as one god of the dead to another. I assure you, I wouldn't misplace the trust you or Bianca have in me. Besides, I mostly prefer to have some attachment to the women I bed.” Percy assured, keeping it to himself how it was getting harder to care these days about something like an emotional attachment. “But I think we should go check in on them, to see how well their training is going. Maybe give them a little spar.” Percy said, carefully picking Cerberus up, making sure not to wake the demon-dog woman.

~ Several hours later

Percy whistled, standing at the shore of the river Styx in a small cave-like inlet. He waited, looking over the black water.

Thanks to the blue minions effort, and actual effort on part of Styx herself, the water was less polluted. The oily substance, while still there, was reduced greatly from what had been far worse then Percy imagined. Less debris floated down the river as well, though there was still much of it as well.

It turns out that the debris that floated down the river was the regrets and dreams of the dead, made manifest by the great amounts of Mist that was contained in the underworld. It only appeared on the river Styx for a few reasons, namely the concentration of souls that crossed and their lingering sorrows, which were then in turn manifested by the magical force as they made their journey with the Ferryman.

Despite Charon being stubborn about taking people across, there was enough backed up sorrows to keep the river polluted for thousands of years.

Thankfully, the blues had figured out a way to filter, so to speak, the magic from the debris, causing it to vanish and disperse into the mist that made it up. These arrays of magic runes were all along the river's length, dispersing more and more as they floated down the river's current.

Of course, there was only so much magic that could be dispersed at once, so it wasn't a like a catch all net. Things still got through all the time, and some of the more condensed regrets had to reach the river Lethe to finally disperse.

But, all in all, it was much better then what it had been. The major problem was still the oil though, as the promises of the gods, or invoked in Styx's name, could not be so easily cleaned. Too many promises had been made in the titaness's name, and the water was still covered in the manifestation of broken or unfulfilled sacred promises.

Percy watched as Styx stepped from the river, her skin dripping with water. Her eyes were locked on him, her lips curled up into a sultry smile.

“Hello, Perseus.” She said, wrapping her arms around his shoulders and giving him a kiss of the cheek. “What brings you to my little part of the underworld?”

“I was visiting family here in the underworld, checking in on how Nico and Bianca were doing with their training.” He said, wrapping his arms around her waist. “I figured I'd stop on by to see how the river's cleaned up since last month.”

“Oh, I’ve cleaned up very well, as you can see.” She said with a coy smile, pressing herself closer against Percy.

“I was talking about the actual river,” Percy said, teasing her. “But I can't ignore the lady of the river when I make that statement, now can I?”

“I would hope not.” She said. “But you know I can't stay mad at you.” She said, nuzzling her head into his neck.

“Yeah, I know.” Percy said, almost sighing.

“But enough about that. How long will you stay?” She asked, her eyes lighting up in joy at the mere prospect of him sticking around.

“A while. I was going to try my hand at helping clean up the river, and just spend a little time with you.”

“Well then, we should get started.” Styx said, moving her arms down his back. “I know a spot that has need of your... cleaning.” She said hotly, a small laugh at the end.

She pushed back from him, out of his grasp. Turning, she ran back to the water and dove in, disappearing beneath the waves.

Percy grinned. “Tease.” He said, running after her.

“Ooh Yes! Right there!” Medusa moaned, writhing under Percy's touch. “Don't stop! Don't ever stop!”

Percy chuckled, removing his slick finger's from the woman's body. She moaned at the loss, feeling all strength leave her body. She didn't want the feeling to end!

“You know I can't do that.” Percy said, chiding her in a teasing tone. “Besides, I wanted this to be special. For a job well done.”

“Please... I need your magic fingers Percy~” Medusa said, panting.

“I think you've had enough for now.” Percy said, walking over to a desk. “Besides, don't want my massages to ever lose the magic touch.”

Grabbing a towel he had set there, Percy wiped the massage oil off his hands.

Currently, Percy was in Medusa's apartment, just above Sally's own. The massage was a reward for keeping up with her job, which Medusa had, at first, been reluctant to accept. But she found that she enjoyed it, and was quite good at it, thus taking the job to teach. The only part she wasn't fond of was having to grade the projects.

Taking a rose from a vase, Percy smelt the unassuming flower. To him, it was as good as a normal rose. To women, however...

This rose was a particular kind. Percy had only given out two of them personally, last summer. One to Medusa, and the other to the waitress in the diner in Denver.

These roses would draw women in, like a fly to honey. They would desire the flower, and they would take it.

However, that was when the trap was sprung.

They would, inevitably, prick their finger on it's thorns. In doing so, they would begin to obsess over him, and him alone, though Percy did not know the details of how it did that. All he knew was that the effect lasted until he either told the woman to wait for him, which would only pause the effects for a few months, or had sex with them once, which would stop the effects where they were at in terms of severity.

If he concentrated, he could find the location of the flower, and by extension, the woman who was captivated by it.

When he had come into this knowledge, Percy had remembered that he had given one to the waitress. It had slipped his mind, in the long year away from this world.

So, curious to see how the woman was, Percy had gone to her house. He paid no attention to the other points where he could feel energy. He figured that it had something to do with not being experienced in sensory abilities outside his eyes. Something that was merely due to his inexperience in the matter.

And what he found was a grim reminder of the damage that either he, or an item from the Eronomicon, could do.

The woman had been bordering on stark raving mad. Disturbingly accurate pictures of him were everywhere, and a large field of the flowers surrounded her slightly run down house. She had journals that described her descent into madness.

You know, the usual behavior of insane people in horror movies and the like.

Hell, she even had a cult of women that followed her, doing crazy rituals in their attempts to call him back.

Well, that certainly explained the extra points where he sensed the flowers.

His ego would likely have been inflated when they started bowing to him, offering themselves and calling out his name when he made his presence known, if not for two facts.

One, Percy felt responsible for the state of these women. They looked like they hadn't interacted with anyone for a long time.

Two... It was downright disturbing to him, the way the chanted his name with such fervor, begging to be taken.

It was worse then the minions when they got into it for special occasions.

In the end, Percy had no choice but order, for they took anything he said as such, to get their lives back on track before he even started to think about taking any of them.

He wasn't so far gone, yet, to where he would want women to dump their lives and worship him in such a crazy fashion for all eternity.

He was so far gone enough, however, that he allowed them to keep the 'cult' to continue meeting up, if they also talked about other things and stopped the rituals.

Seriously, they did nothing. He didn't even know they were preforming them until Desiree, as the waitress was named, had mentioned them.

Turning to Medusa, who was still lying down, he held up the rose.

“How many of these did you send out to women again?” He asked.

“Lots.” Medusa said simply.

“And the seeds they produced? You must have had quite the horde of them, having this for a whole year.”

Yes, another thing about these roses. Despite being cut from the bush, they still produced seeds, a few everyday. They were quick to grow, and never wilted, to Medusa's delight.

She kept a bouquet in her class room, and already had given some to the female students anonymously or if they asked for one, as was not uncommon.

“Flower shops, flower delivery services, green houses around the area... and I'm sure I planted a few around central park.”

Percy couldn't help but sigh slightly. That was an obscene amount of paces where they would be spread even further. Especially when special events, and Valentines day, rolled around. By then, Percy suspected that at least half the roses in the city would be from the Eronomicon.

And that meant more women would be tempted to take the roses, and prick their finger, and so on and so forth...

He was going to be busy, lest a cult suddenly pop up and get out of control.

He sighed again. The one thing that kept him from finding these seeds was the fact that he couldn't sense them without already having a woman under their power. Otherwise, he would have quelled the sheer number of plants that would be spread.

Not all of them though. He wouldn't deny himself a small power boost.

And, was it really his fault if some couples broke up because of pure random chance?

Percy put the rose back in its vase, turning to Medusa. “Well, what's done is done. I won't do anything that could destabilize the universe, so time travel is out of the question. But Medusa, next time please run this by me first. When this comes to a head, and those roses are distributed and bought and all that, I'm going to be extremely busy. Why did you do this anyway?”

“Just felt like... spreading the love.” She said, still running off the pleasant feeling of the massage.

Man, did Percy know his stuff around the female body, and not just for sex.

Percy looked at her from the corner of his eye, now holding a few photo's that they had taken over the last year, of time spent together in various places.

There was the time that they went to Egypt, which Percy felt eyes following them the entire time. He would have dealt with it, but it was of no concern. As long as they didn't attack, he wouldn't make a scene in ripping them to shreds.

There was the time they visited some Mayan ruins, which Percy found boring. He'd been to many abandoned temples over the two years he had gone traveling universes. You'd be surprised at how similar they all started to look after a while.

Finally, there was the time he had taken her to the top of Everest.

There was an interesting story behind that trip.

But that was a tale for another time.

“So, putting that behind us.” Percy said, putting the photo's down. “How about we relax tonight, the two of us?”

“Hm?” Medusa asked, bring her head up from its rest, half-lidded eyes staring at him with no true focus. “That sounds nice. How about dinner, dancing and a little walk through the park? I quiet enjoy our little walks under the moon, you know.” She said, smiling softly.

Percy smiled back, nodding. “You're right, that does sound good. Though, you'll have to forgive me if I trip up again. I may have fast feet meant for a thief, and everything the practice employs, but the fancy foot work for a dance floor is beyond me.”

It was something that he never really was interested in learning, the thought never really crossing his mind until it was brought up. He could weave through a battlefield, walk among the stars in the sky and had traversed where very few gods could say they have...

But dancing? Might as well give him two left feet.

“That's alright.” Medusa said, sitting up, her chest exposed. “I've been taking lessons myself, since my last attempt was a disaster as well.”

“I wouldn't say disaster...” Percy said, but trailed off.

Yeah, it was a disaster. He would be lying to say it wasn't.

“Why don't you go get ready. I'll be fine getting dressed on my own, after I wash off the oil. Besides, I want my dress to be a surprise for you. I'm sure you'll love it.”

“An hour then?” Percy asked “Or a little longer?”

“I'd say a little longer.” Medusa said, before winking at him. “But it'll be worth it, I assure you.”

“I'm sure it will.” Percy said, looking out the window at the night sky. “I'm sure it will.”

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy rubbed his head, trying to get the splitting pain to go away.

“Sometimes I hate immortality.” He grumbled, walking into the Big House at Camp Halfblood. “Regeneration is a bitch. Now I know why Prometheus is more then a little bitter about having his liver being eaten everyday and then regrown every night.”

“Ah, Percy.” Chiron said, walking into the room, his bow in one hand as he set his quiver down. “What brings you here?”

“Business Chiron.” Percy said. “And could you not talk so loud.”

Chiron raised an eyebrow. “Are... are you hungover?”

“No.” Percy bit out. “I just happened to take a Minotaur’s axe to the head last night, blade first. Twice.”

“Haven't you taken worse hits then that?” Chiron asked.

“If you're talking about my fights with Enyo, then yes. But I always prepare for those by making sure I pack some Nectar to cut down on the pain and regeneration time, plus Enyo is emitting so much lust energy that I can draw on that to help things move along painlessly and almost instantly. And Enyo's pretty resistant to most anything, unlike when she was Ares. I was, sadly, unprepared and, infuriatingly, caught off guard. Teaches me to not focus my solely attention on a nice night out.” He growled, wondering when the minotaur would reform again.

He wanted to make a nice leather chair from its hide. Perhaps snap a few more horns off, since they could come in handy later on. At the very least they would make nice trophies.

“But...” Chiron said, furrowing his brow. “You said twice? How?”

Percy said nothing, merely moving his fingers across his head, first horizontally then vertically.

“Ruined the night with Medusa, since the resulting gore made her sick. And this damnable headache has been bugging me since. I'll give Prometheus credit, since he had to deal with something like this for centuries.” He said. “I'm just glad that I was able to get my armor on quick enough to where it wouldn't cut into my chest, otherwise I wouldn't have been able to fight back reasonably well. You don't know how hard it is to fight when you have no head to see with, and your eyes are twenty feet apart and you can still see out of them. Very disorienting, to say the least.”

“Worse then having three consciouses on the same plane at once?” Chiron asked, remembering that night almost a year ago that Percy had told his story.

“Close, but not quite.” Percy said.

“I see.” Chiron said, walking by to his office and room. “Well, I hope your business here goes well.”

“I'm sure it will.” Percy said absently. “And Chiron, my offer still stands, should you grow tired of the Olympians and their games.”

“I'll... think about it.” Chiron said, stopping for a moment. He seemed to consider it before giving his answer and moving on.

“By the way Chiron, don't freak out if you see magic around Thalia's tree.” Percy warned. “That's part of my business here today.”

“Of course.” Chiron said as he walked away. “It is yours to do with as you wish, you know that.”

“Just a heads up. I know you don't like surprises.”

With that, Percy turned to walk out. The only reason he had even come to the big house was the fact that he was going to warn Chiron about his business with Thalia's tree.

He couldn't feel Dionysus' presence anywhere, nor was the god in any of his usual spots.

'Probably up on Olympus, all of them discussing what to do about Thalia's poisoning.' Percy thought. 'Soon, Chiron will be replaced with Tantalus, and things will get worse from there for the campers.'

He shrugged it off, walking to the hill where Thalia's tree stood. If Dionysus wasn't here, then it was better for him.

It wasn't that he hated the man, but damn, did the god just get on his nerves sometimes, despite Percy also promising to him that he wouldn't try and break him and his wife up as long as the god didn't rat him out.

So, in general, they had come to an agreement to just stay away from one another when possible.

Plus, if Percy kept away from him while he went about his business, Dionysus could truthfully say he didn't know what Percy was doing, and keep the god from more trouble. That, in turn, would have likely made the god bitter towards Percy, and likely to hold a grudge.

“Alright.” Percy said, announcing his presence to the group on the hill. “Blue minions, start the ritual. Greens, I want you to put the poison in the glass jars to take to Nix when you're done. She should find some use for it, and should be able to figure out the extent of its lethality.”

The Blue Minions nodded, their robes discarded in the early morning heat. It was a tad hot for the heavy cloaks that they usually wore, so they were in only their underwear, which were fashioned out of cloth. Their skin shone from the beads of sweat, as they had not anticipated the heat when the had come to the camp, thinking it to be cooler this early in the summer.

The green minions, though they themselves perspired slightly, kept their clothing on, as it was light enough to keep them from overheating. The only heavy garments they wore were thick gloves to handle the poison, since not even they were sure if the poison would be too strong for them.

Standing in a circle around the tree, the blue minions, about twenty in all, started to chant. Their tattoo's glowed with arcane energies, their hands twitching more and more as blue mist seeped from their hands, surrounding not just the tree, but the surrounding area as well.

Despite Thalia trying to keep the poison from spreading, it was too strong for her. In just a week, it had already spread around the hill, getting quite the distance in such a short amount of time.

But that was what the blue minions were taking care of. They were pulling the poison into Thalia's tree, and would then pull it out from there.

The reason it had taken so long for them to do so, or Percy to order them to do so, was the fact that it had taken time to research nature magic from the world where they came from, and then try to not only convert it to this worlds magic energies, but to also work in a secondary spell.

This spell would cause all who looked at it, even the gods, to see the tree as if it was still poisoned. Thus, they would to cure it, making it stronger through the natural magic of the world and Nymphs and Satyrs nursing it.

Not only would that strengthen the tree, which would be helpful for the camp as a whole, but it would strengthen Thalia as well, and make the transition from tree to human much easier.

As for why Percy didn't do it himself, with the gauntlets and power he possessed...

He didn't trust his ability to do so.

For one, nature magic wasn't his thing, nor poison.

Second, he knew he didn't have the precision to handle a matter as delicate as this. It would have been like handing scalpels to someone who was prone to having seizures and telling him to preform open heart surgery in a disco.

Sadly, the power of his boots didn't allow him to 'steal' the poison from the tree...

At least, he didn't think so...

Truth be told, he mainly used the boots for travel purposes, and walking silently. He hadn't really experimented beyond a few petty pickpocket attempts, and literally stealing the clothes off of women without their notice.

He'd have to experiment with that more, like with the gauntlets.

Percy turned his thoughts outward again, watching how the mist receded back into the tree, wrapping it up tightly. The grass the mist covered was now free of blight, fresh and green as if it hadn't been poisoned.

It hurts! It hurts!

Percy walked closer, mindful of the blue Minions as they continued their chanting, now increased in both pitch and speed.

He placed his hand on the tree, feeling the bark grow hot from the poison, the tree rapidly decaying.

'It's okay Thalia. Just hold on for a little longer. We'll have the poison gone then.' He thought, knowing it would reach the girl trapped inside. It always did, without him even needing to speak.

It burns Percy.

He could see her soul, writhing in agony as veins of some viscous liquid, the poison, were wrapping around her, piercing her skin. Her very soul wept, trying to break free of the poison, slowly engulfing her.

'I know... I know. Soon it will be gone.' Percy assured, watching as the tree turned a sickly shade of yellow. “Is it ready?” He asked, turning to look at one of the Blues.

As one, they nodded, their hands making gestures to the greens before they started the second part of the spell.

The green minions, each holding their glass jars open, walked forward as the mist around the tree slowly gathered to a singly point.

Percy couldn't help but cringe, Thalia's scream of pain reverberating in his head. He swore it was almost loud enough to be physically heard.

And it wasn't just because of his headache that he cringed.

With a few motions of their hands, pushing or pulling, depending on where they were in accordance to the point of magic, the blues began to draw out the poison.

Slowly, the small light grew, into a ball of magic mist, growing larger and larger.

The green minions surrounded the ball, which was larger then Percy was tall.

“On my mark.” Percy said, never taking his hand off the tree. Thalia was weeping now, though it seemed that the poison was completely gone.

The Greens readied their bottles, placing the openings to the magic sphere.

Percy looked around, making sure the blues were keeping themselves steady. If anything went wrong, it would be good bye to the entire hill, and possibly his minions.

“Now!”
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Taking the poison from her veins

choices: The day Percy's daughter comes to the dark tower.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
With that, the greens pushed the opening of the bottles into the sphere, puncturing it just enough so that they would fill with the poison.

And fill they did.

Quickly, the bottles filled with a pulsating black ooze, and Percy could see how vile it was from his spot.

“Quickly, the next ones!” Percy said.

The secondary team of greens, which had more bottles in case of such a situation, handed their comrades who were holding the filled containers another. Pulling out the filled container, the magic sphere closing before even a drop of the stuff could fall, they switched containers, giving the filled ones to the secondary team to stop up and get ready for trasport.

~

By the time they were done, there were more then fifty large bottles of the stuff, all rolled gently in wool to keep them from breaking as they were moved.

The blues had finished with the illusion, and were all catching their breath, their hands finally still due to using up so much magic.

Thalia was resting, trying to ignore the pain.

“Good job.” Percy said, to both the minions and Thalia.

“Of course Master.” Some of the green minions intoned all at once, their voice carrying their no nonsense attitude as usual.

If Percy didn't know better, sometimes he would swear the minions were hive minds.

“Percy!” A familiar bleating rang out, several of the green minions springing to the ready for a fight at the sound.

“At ease.” Percy said, leaning back against Thalia's tree. “It's just Grover.”

As their Overlord commanded, they relaxed, but most of them did fade into the scenery, standing guard over the poison.

“Percy!” Grover called again, rising over the crest of the hill. “What was with the... oh... never mind.” He said, taking note of the blue minions all sitting around. “I was going to ask if you knew what the whole blue mist thing was, but I guess you caused it.”

“Yeah. I had some of the minions go over some spells that would help Thalia's tree fight off the poison. As you can see, they were able to draw out some poison from the surrounding area,” He said, motioning to the bottles and the grass and trees around them. “Unfortunately, they weren't able to pull out much poison from the tree itself. It's latched onto Thalia's heart, or the equivalent of it while she's a tree. If we tried to pull it out, it would be like pulling the plug in a hospital. Strangely, the poison is keeping her alive, or she would have died quickly. It could be akin to a parasite, feeding off of Thalia's strength and creating more of itself, which would make for an interesting poison.”

Grover looked at the bottles, never noticing the guards around it. His nose wrinkled at the mere sight of it, turning away.

“So, who're the two kids? New campers I presume, obviously.” Percy asked, pointing behind Grover.

One was a large male, with thick muscles. He looked like no stranger to hard work, but his face was less then pleasing to look at, but not exactly ugly. Probably a kid of Hephaestus.

The second one was a girl, who was trim, but not like the girls of Aphrodite cabin. She had some muscle on her, looking like a runner of the sort. She had sunny blond hair, and it seems she had been kissed by the sun, given her tan. Most likely one of Apollo's daughters.

“Yeah, they're the demigods I was sent to get. Rather nice trip, overall. No horrifying monster attacks, no divine retribution, no running from mortal police... Not often that I get that on my job as keeper.”

“Excuse me, nobody is my keeper.” The girl said. “And I don't care what your stupid card says about it. The only reason I'm here is to keep my mom safe and get stronger.”

She looked at the minions, sneering in disgust.

“What, you guys keep to the old tradition that women aren't good for anything more then having kids or cooking?” She asked heatedly.

“Ah, no.” Percy said, standing up. “Those women happen to work for me, and have overworked themselves, so they had to remove most of their clothing in an attempt to cool off. And I'll have you know, that if you think we keep them uneducated as well, that these women have access to, and trust me when I say this, magical abilities. Those ones over there, by all the bottles, are actually highly trained assassins, also working for me, to keep monsters from breaking into the camp.”

“I thought you said this was a safe place?” The guy asked, looking at Grover.

“Oh, it is. I assure you.” Percy said. “It's just that we had a traitor poison the tree behind me, which is the thing that keeps the barrier up around the camp. Currently, the barrier is down, so there have been patrols set up, which I will soon be providing back up for. There's something being done about the problem now, but it will be a while before we find what we're looking for.”

“So you're saying a traitor can just waltz in and do whatever he likes?” The girl scoffed. “You must all be lazy or something to let someone do something like that to the defense of the camp. And why have a tree hold the defense? Seems stupid, if you ask me.”

Percy growled low, some of the greens getting ready to attack if he gave the order.

“You don't really get it. This tree isn't ordinary. It's the prison for a demigod, much like you. Though, unlike you, she had, and still has, friends. She actually cared enough about those friends to sacrifice herself to become the barrier to protect the camp, which was always on guard for attacks before she did what she did. And, also unlike you, she was powerful. Unfortunately, the traitor happened to be one of her old friends, who was bitter at the world he had to live in. So, before you go running your mouth about something you don't know, realize that you'll just make a fool of yourself, along with some nasty enemies.” He snarled.

“Percy, please.” Grover said, sighing. He didn't think Percy would hurt them, but they didn't need to get off on the wrong foot with the idea of the camp. It was supposed to be their home away from home, though at this home you risked serious injury and possible loss of life.

But, hey, how were you supposed to become a hero otherwise?

“Um, excuse me.” The guy spoke up again. “Grover here explained a little bit about camp during our trip here, mainly about the cabins, a history of the gods and how they actually exist and all that. You've obviously been around here for a while, and I was wondering if you had any tips for us while we're here.”

“Good head on your shoulders, I respect that.” Percy said. “Well, for one I can say stay away from Aphrodite's cabin, and any of the campers from that cabin, if you can. Horrible teases, all of them. If you're not good with teasing from a guy or girl, you'll often find yourself having one or more teasing you most of the time. Also, don't try and go all out on the obstacle course for a while. Learn the feel of it. Lastly, don't fight with any of the kids from Ares/Enyo cabin... you will lose, no matter how big you are. Remember, this is a camp where people learn how to take down monsters and fight for their lives. Fighting a human is a piece of cake for most anyone here.”

He dusted his clothes off, getting some dirt off. “Oh and before I forget, and pay attention to this girl.” He said, getting her to scowl at him. “Don't go messing with the women that don't look like campers, as in older then a teenager, or the Nymphs and Naiads. The ones who look older then the campers have been given special permission to beat the living crap out of anyone who attempts to interfere with their work under the assumption that they are also a traitor. The Nymphs and Naiads are also horrible teases, but are more prone to go through with the deed. Trust me when I say you couldn't stand the gossip that surfaced afterwords.”

“You two.” Percy said, pointing at two green minions. “Would you please escort these two to Chiron? And introduce him,” He said, pointing his thumb at the guy. “To Beckendorf. He looks like he'd be good around a forge.”

The minions nodded, motioning the two to follow before walking away, not even bothering to wait for them.

They guy, finally noticing how they were dressed, blushed, averting his eyes as he started after, though Percy could tell he took a few peeks here and there.

The girl scowled at him, apparently not liking the fact that he talked down to her.

“Two more, follow unseen. Keep an eye on the girl, especially. The last thing I want is to have her bitching at me for being some sort of sexist bastard or something because of the way you act on your own time and what you decide to wear.” He said.

He could handle someone talking to him like they were tough shit. But he would not have somebody slander him, or bitch about him, while not knowing his circumstances. He felt he had a good grasp on respect for women, despite his station as the Harem god.

The minions nodded, two more quickly scampering off into the brush on one side of the hill.

“So,” Percy said, looking at Grover. “How are things with Juniper?”
