1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy sat down next to a bed, a small form underneath the blankets. It was shivering, making noises that were slightly unnatural.

Several minions entered quietly, looking curiously at the bed and their master.

Percy didn't even notice them though, gently moving a strand of cold hair from the form's face.

“Move along, darlings.” A soft voice whispered, shooing away the minions.

The minions did as ordered, moving along on their way, off to do other things. If they could remember, they would tell other minions the good news!

Percy looked up, smiling gently.

“Hello Rose.” Percy said to the first woman he had bedded after becoming the Overlord, and the mother of his first child. “Eres told you, I see.”

“Indeed she did, Sire.” Rose said. “Though I won't be able to stay long, since 'Emperor' Florian is paranoid about anything going wrong without my presence.”

“He is of no concern, Rose. You know that.” Percy said.

“I know, I know.” She said with a sigh. “I just don't want to listen to his whiny voice as he talks down to me if I'm gone for a day or two. Nor do I want to listen to that creature he calls a right-hand man try and propose to me anymore. You know how hard it was to keep myself from letting the minions deal with him?”

Percy growled, pulling Rose down onto his lap a little forcefully before shaking his head. “Sorry about that.” He whispered, looking at the mass on the bed. “I wonder how she'll take it all?”

Rose sighed. This had always been a point of contention with her since she found out herself.

“I honestly don't know, Sire. I was always against it, you know that.”

“I know... I know.”

Percy sighed. What he had done was something he found... unsavory.

After all, hadn't he just abandoned her to a backwater town of moronic bigots for eight years? Sure he had Jewel and other minions watch over her, while he created, or had Giblet create for him if he was elsewhere, gifts for her. Though he knew what would happen in the future, with the Elf, he did not prevent it so he could watch his daughter grow...

Why?

Was it because he wanted her to become the next Overlord? He said that, a year or so ago.

But as he watched, silently and from afar, how many times did he want to burn the town to the ground and slaughter them all in pure paternal anger?

All because his daughter was different from an ordinary human. Blue-tinted skin, glowing green eyes, the ability to use magic in some small amount...

Was he really any different from his own Father for doing this?

They even threw her to a genocidal empire for no reason other then to save their own skin!

It was only thanks to the minions that she had been able to live through that ordeal, because she had fully armed, though poorly trained, soldiers trying to kill her!

Honestly, it was only due to his knowledge that she would be perfectly fine that kept him from bringing a horrifying death to them all.

“I think that... tomorrow... she should meet her parents. For the first time.” Percy said, though unsure of himself. It was going to be awkward to say the least.

“I agree. But, who will train her?” Rose asked.

“Me, obviously. Though... I really don't want to have her along on a quest. I know I could protect her, but she'll need to get used to being around people first. To be honest, I'm surprised that she even worked so easily with the minions as she did. They seem human enough, and I know she has a distrust of humans from her time in that damned village.”

“Perhaps it is in her genes, Sire. She is the daughter of an Overlord, after all. She may have known they weren't human, despite how they look.”

“Possibly.” Percy said, looking at his daughter, laying shivering on the bed. “Well, I can certainly say she didn't take to my affinity for water. Maybe your affinity for fire or lightning perhaps?”

“Oh, I hope so. I would love to be able to teach her something that will help her later on. Will we have Jewel join in on training her? I'm sure she'll take to sneaking about like one of them ninja of yours.” Rose said, almost raising her voice in her excitement.

“I don't think so. We can try to have her learn, but I suspect she'll be a bruiser more then anything.” Percy said, only to get a slap on the shoulder from Rose.

“No fair, using your ability to see the future.” She said, pouting.

“Rose, she's going to tower over people by several feet. By the time she finishes growing, she'll be a giant, at almost eleven feet tall. Thievery is not for her. Besides, that's literally what the minions were made for, to do the work in which the Overlord cannot do themselves. Well, other then being an easily replaceable fighting force.”

Rose sighed. “I guess you're right. Though I wish she would have taken more after me, in terms of inherited traits.”

“What, it's not enough that she got your hair color, magical affinities, natural body shape or beauty?” Percy asked teasingly. “All she got from me was monstrous strength, some inherent knowledge of otherworldly languages, my eye color and the genes of an Overlord. I'd say she benefited more from you, then me, in terms of her genetics.”

“You're forgetting one thing though, Love. She has the parentage of a god, so she'll be made of much sterner stuff then any regular human.”

“Much good I've done at being a parent I've been these past ten years.” Percy sighed. “I still don't understand why I did what I did. I can see her future, see the outcome if I molded it in any way even hypothetically, and yet I still did this to her. My first born daughter...” He said, looking to the side.

“Sometimes, I wonder if my mind is my own sometimes. Given the fact that I sometimes confuse even myself with my actions, and find myself wondering why I acted as I did. Even when I was mortal, before I came into possession of the Eronomicon, I was like that. Not as often as now, surely, but still. For example, that tree I was telling you about, the one with a friend of mine imprisoned in it. I don't know why I did what I did, taking complete ownership of it, and my friend through that. Perhaps it was the power of the item that allowed me to do so, and that was the first thing that popped into my mind. I just don't know.”

Percy shook his head, leaning back in his chair and pulling Rose back with him.

“While I'm not happy with your plans, whatever your reasoning, I'm just glad I can see our daughter in the flesh for the first time in years.” Rose said, before her jaw cracked with a mighty yawn. “Oh, forgive me. But that blasted Elf has me working from dawn to dusk, wanting his own plan to be flawless, dealing with incompetent soldiers he sends to me to experiment on. Something about creating a super-soldier, whatever he means by that. My only saving grace are the little cherubs that work under me. So caring, despite what they were like as those little imps before.”

“By the way,” Percy said, having remembered something. “Remind me to kill that Cyclops Yeti hybrid that took my daughter from the minions while they were distracted and tried to bring her down with it to a watery grave. I don't care if it's technically related to me through mythology, or similar to actual cyclops from my world.”

“Of course. I'm sure it would make a nice rug by the bedroom.” She said, unconcerned that it was technically an innocent creature.

It tried to kill her daughter, even if it didn't mean to do so. Did you think she would let that go?

“Why don't you go to bed.” Percy said, stoking Rose's face gently. “I'm going to stay here tonight. Send in a red to light a fire, and I'll have one of the blues give her a quick once over tomorrow. And tell Eres to contact Jewel. I want to speak with her in person.”

“Of course, my Overlord.” Rose said, Kissing him goodnight as she stood up to leave.

Rose looked at her daughter, who was slowly relaxing into a deeper, more calm sleep as the shivering subsided. She sighed wistfully, wondering what it would have been like to see her grow up from a mere babe, instead of waiting for eight years after only caring for her for ten years.

With that, she was off to go about her duties before turning in.

Percy kept watch throughout the night, his daughter muttering in her sleep. Most of it was gibberish, nonsensical and without meaning. But there were a few words here and there that actually had meaning.

Mother, father, please, why, Kelda, everyone, die...

Not exactly in that order, and there were a few more, but those were several of the more prominent ones, and spoken in varying languages.

But they gave Percy food for thought as he racked his brain, trying to think of what he should tell her. Not as an Overlord, or as a god who knew her destiny... but as a father, and one who wasn't there as well.

In the morning, he would have little more then what he started with.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy was looking out the window, watching the sun rise over the horizon. The city was starting to awaken, and smoke rose from Chimneys as meals were being prepared before the day's work began. The window he was currently looking out of overlooked the area of the city that common folk, those without magical power or any inhuman attributes lived. The market area was next to it on the left side, while the more industrial area that housed the workshops of blacksmiths and carpenters and other such craftsmen set up their shops was on the right.

Percy heard a grunt from his daughter, who slowly began to stir from her sleep.

He looked over, seeing her sit up and rub her head. After she looked around, she noticed that she was someplace she had never been before.

As such, she was immediately on guard, springing to her feet with her hands balled into fists. She was wrapped in dark cloth that hung loosely to her young body, two separate pieces for a shirt and pants. Her eyes were constantly glowing a darker shade of green then Percy's when he was angry, and her face was twisted into a snarl, showing her teeth, which were jagged and looked ready to rend flesh from bone much like the minions teeth were.

“Sit back down.” He said, making her jump and turn towards him, holding her fists up. “You're in no danger here.”

His daughter looked at him, her red hair falling down her face in dirty strands as she regarded him with hostility and caution. Her thin frame, though sporting some muscle, was a testament to how she would have to steal food, when Jewel or the minions didn't leave her food. She had a faint scar across her face, not unlike the scar Luke sported.

Percy would make sure that it wouldn't turn out like Luke and Hermes though. He wouldn't let that happen, despite his horrible job of being a Father.

Well, horrible was putting it lightly, but even Percy didn't know a word to really say what he felt about how badly he fucked up.

She said nothing, her eyes darted quickly around the room, trying to find an escape while trying her best to keep her eyes on him.

But then she seemed to notice something above his head, staring at it as her head cocked to the side slightly.

“Good?” She asked, though obviously speaking to herself.

To her eyes, above Percy, floated that single word.

Good.

She had only seen that word a few times. Over her friend, Kelda, and the women from last night with the big wolves.

She otherwise only saw the word bad above people.

People who had the word 'bad' above them were not nice to her, and would hit and yell at her if they didn't ignore her altogether or avoid her.

Well, they all avoided her after a while, if they knew what was good for them.

Kelda was the only person who was nice to her, and those women who saved her but then lost her to the stupid bear thing. They all had good above them, except for the bear thing. It didn't have a word above it, like animals or masked people.

“Good?” Percy asked, genuinely confused. She didn't seem to be addressing him.

She looked him in the eyes, before looking at the word above his head. “Good.”

She seemed to relax a little, though she still looked at him with a cautious curiosity.

Percy took a tentative step towards her, wondering if she would move away. Seeing that she didn't, still staring, he moved closer, and closer until he was standing next to her, her neck craned up to look at him.

Honestly, he would have felt more guilty if she had flinched. He didn't want his own daughter to be afraid of him.

Then why'd you leave her alone?

'Shut up.' Percy thought, trying to shut his guilt out. He could do better now. 'I don't need to deal with you every time I interact with her.'

So you say...

If Percy wasn't worried for his Sanity beforehand...

“It's okay.” He said, crouching down to look her in the eye. “No one here's going to hurt you.”

She looked him in the eye, trying to see if he was lying. But the words had never been wrong before. They had never lied to her, unlike what so many people tried to do when they had to interact with her.

“Who are you?” She asked, her voice a little more masculine then a girl her age should have sounded, but nothing overly noticeable.

“A friend.” He said, though against his better judgment. “I sent those women to help you last night.”

Percy went to move some of her hair from her face, when by reaction she grabbed his wrist, a surprisingly strong grip trying it's best to break his wrist.

“Don't touch.” She growled. Despite him being 'good', she would not let him touch her. It had been months before she had even let Kelda see her face, keeping her body wrapped up entirely so people wouldn't see her skin.

“Now now, there's no need for that.” Percy said, though he did move his hand away, pulling it from her grip. He could tell that surprised her, probably used to people being reduced to crying wrecks as their wrists snapped like twigs. “Are you hungry?”

She nodded. Of course she would be hungry. What a stupid question.

“Then follow me. We'll get you some food.” He said, standing up. He walked over to the door, opening it as he looked at her expectantly.

She looked at him, seeing if he was going to do anything, but still didn't sense any hostility, and the word good never changed either.

So, deciding that this person wouldn't try anything again, she walked out of the room and into the hallway.

“Master!” A cry rang through the halls, making the girl crouch down with her fists brought up again, back pressed against the cold stone wall.

A woman in armor walked up to Percy, looking like one of the women that had helped her last night. She, too, had the word 'Good' above her, so the girl relaxed slightly at seeing what seemed to be a familiar face. The only difference seemed to be the clothing, since armor not unlike what the soldiers that attacked her wore, though it was shinier and seemed to provide better protection, replaced the fur that they women wore the previous night.

“Mistress Eres said... said...” The woman said, before scratching her head. “What did Mistress Eres say?”

The woman was stupid, the girl could see. Though, in her books, she was smarter then any of the people in Nordburg.

Better looking too.

And smelled nicer. The people of Nordburg always smelt absolutely putrid, and it was horrible on her sensitive nose.

And she had the word 'good.' That had never lied to her about people.

“Oh yeah!” The woman exclaimed, smiling proudly. “Mistress Eres said that she was going to take a sleepy-break. And that Master would need to see her when her sleepy-break was done!”

A nap? Did the woman mean a nap? How stupid was she?

“Ah, right. It's that time of the week again. She probably knows that I've been dealing with a lot of things these past few days, so held off as long as she could.” The man said to himself. “Thank you for letting me know. Go down to the kitchens and let them know to prepare some breakfast for Mistress Rose and our... guest.” Percy said, almost letting the word 'daughter' slip from his tongue.

“Yes Master.” The woman said, both saluting and bowing before she quickly went back the way she came.

“Glad to see Rose and Eres have been able to teach them some manners. If only they remembered that they only had to Salute or bow, not both.” Percy said. “Come along, we'll wait in the dining quarters for the food.”

~

The girl ate the food, though it was very... different, from what she normally ate. Instead of seal meat, raw potatoes or carrots and possibly rabbit, she was having some, what did the man call them? ehgs?

There was some strange meat called haym, and something called milk for her to drink. The most she really ever drank was melted snow. There was tons of it in Nordburg year round, so she was never thirsty. And the little sparks she could create created fires on logs well enough, so it was just a matter of taking some cookware to melt it and finding enough dry wood.

She forewent the knife on the table, using the one she kept with her all the time in the village. The man had given it to her when they entered, saying that it was on her when they brought her here.

“Little witch.” She said, answering the mans question before she went back to eating her food. He had asked her what her name was, or at least what the villagers called her as he ate, and a woman with the word 'good' above her as well. At first, she doubted the word above the woman, as she stared at her for a while, watching her every move and making her nervous.

Several more women had entered, though they were quick to leave. All had the same word above them, and seemed to hold no Ill will, nor were they repulsed.

“That's hardly a name for someone like you.” The woman spoke, her eyes looking directly into the girls own glowing ones, showing no fear. “How about... Millicent? That seems like a fine name for you.”

'After all, it was the one you were given at birth.' Percy thought, watching as his daughter decimated the food placed before her.

He knew he was going to get an earful from Rose later that day.

And he could only say he deserved it.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Curse his stupid decisions

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“You're pretty tall for someone your age, and much too skinny.” Percy said, standing across from Millicent. “And you're strong, I know. We'll start your training today to help you get back at those bastards in Nordburg for what they did to you.”

Currently, they were in a large room underground. Percy had told Millicent that this is where the women that she had seen around the tower, and that helped her, trained.

There were racks upon racks of training weapons, and the room was large enough to train over three hundred people at the same time with enough room to keep the fighting separated.

It was made for small scale battle training after all, though it was mostly used when the red minions were involved.

Didn't want them to burn down the countryside, now did he?

They were the only two in the cavernous room, at the moment. Torches lit up the walls from top to bottom, with a few hanging braziers that held flames for the central area of the room.

The two of them were dressed for their purpose in this room, with non-restrictive clothing, but not so loose as to trip them up.

Millicent currently held a wooden club in her hand, much like the one she had used in the village when she wasn't using her knife.

She grinned devilishly at the thought. Get back at those who made her life miserable? The thought almost made her happy. It would be so nice to see their looks of fear as she cut them down, one by one.

“First of all, we'll need to see which weapon, or weapons, you are good with. That's what we'll find out today. Any of those weapons you can lift,” He said, pointing at the weapon racks. “You can use. I want you to attack me with everything you have, with every dirty trick you can imagine. In a fight, there is no such thing as being cheap, or dishonorable. It is a fight for survival, and only the strongest and smartest will make it. We'll start with the club, seeing as how you used it so well before you were rescued from the soldiers.”

Millicent nodded. Who was she to argue if the man wanted her to attack him with everything she had? She had taken down entire houses before when the people were still active in their hatred of her, instead of avoiding her and her ire.

Though, she did feel as though seriously hurting him would make her regret the act. The one time she had hurt Kelda, Millicent had actually felt remorse.

Remorse!

Her!

Holding the club in both hands, Millicent ran at him, faster then the bulky clothing that was required in the cold climate of Nordburg normally allowed.

With a roar, she attempted to bring the club against his leg, which would have snapped his kneecap if not shatter it.

“What are you doing? You missed by a mile, swinging that early.” The man said, though not taunting or teasing her.

What? She knew she was about to hit him!

Sure enough, her weapon hit the ground, leaving a small crater as the, surprisingly, sturdy wood held under the force of impact. She looked up, seeing the man standing a few feet away. Had he tricked her, using magic of some kind?

Millicent brought her club back up, and without a seconds hesitation, she ran at him again She wouldn't be falling for that trick again!

~

“Good, good. You did well.” Percy said, his daughter looking at him with her eyes narrowed, the club broken on the ground. “Go choose your next weapon. It you can hit me, we can take a small break. And don't waste time to rest either.”

He hoped he knew what he was doing. He honestly didn't know if he was being a good teacher, never mind the father part right now. He could only hope he could create some type of relationship with Millicent during her training as the next Overlord.

Millicent huffed, kicking the remains of the weapon to the other side of the large room, where it broke into more pieces.

She was angry at him for toying with her, for not taking her seriously. He had dodged, avoided or tricked her the entire time, making her look like a fool! Why didn't he stand there and take it! At least those soldiers took the hit, even though it crushed their shields and killed the person holding it.

Though, given that this man was able to easily escape her grip and had no fear of her strength or strange skin or magic, she shouldn't have been surprised. This man seemed... more then what he let on, despite the word that constantly hung over him. There was a... glow around him, unlike any other person she had seen. It was dark, yet at the same time, not.

Strange.

She would have to figure it out later though, as she looked at the weapons. There were four that caught her eye. A sword, and even larger sword that might have taken two hands for a normal person to carry, a large mace and what seemed to be a large ice pick, though one side was blunted and looked like a hammer.

She picked up the pick-like weapon. She had some knowledge of them when she would steal them from the village and go climbing, just to see what was in the mountains. She had made a nice little home away from the village, though she had remained relatively close since she had to steal a little here and there and had to bring it up the a steep hill that she needed the ice pick to even get to. Amazing strength or not, she only had two arms to help her get up, and she needed both of them to do so, and it was hard enough with just her clothes to make it.

No bringing crates of food up there for her.

The only reason she chose it was the fact that it was far enough away from the village that she could sleep in peace, and it was a nice cave that blocked out the wind.

Too bad she had to deal with the brats that attacked her on her latest supply run from the village, and was thus kicked out by those stupid people to save themselves.

She got back at them though, as the women who saved her knew enough about siege weaponry to use a trebuchet, and as if sensing her desire, used it to not only destroy a large group of soldiers that would have been in their way, but to also smash some houses in the village, hopefully killing some of the worthless peasants inside.

“The war hammer?” Percy asked, raising an eyebrow. He didn't expect her to go for that, seeing as how she would mainly use swords and maces in the future.

But, then again, he'd also been caught off guard by the fact that she had some kind of ability in her eyes, not unlike him, but with a different application.

She could, apparently, see whether or not people had good or evil intentions for her, though she had grown up using it to tell if people were going to hurt her.

It didn't work on animals or people with concealed faces, possibly indicating that it had to have a humanizing characteristic. Though, he wasn't going to rule out only needing a human face either.

Maybe due to the fact that she was the daughter of a multiversal being? But then, why was he able to see her destiny so clearly? Was it because that is what her destiny was supposed to be, if he wasn't her father?

He didn't know. He still didn't entirely know what it meant to be a multiversal being, or any effects that it might have on his children.

Percy barely dodged out of the way, the spiked end of the weapon catching his shirt, barely missing him. A torn bit of the cloth was hanging on the spike, and Millicent was already getting ready for an overhead swing as she stepped towards him with the intent to, apparently, crush his skull.

'Well, at least she's eager.' Percy thought, moving to the side as the blunt end moved towards him.

~

“Alright, that's enough.” He said, a few beads of sweat on his brow. “If you keep that up, we can move past combat training faster then I would have thought.”

He was, once again, genuinely surprised. He didn't expect Millicent to be that fast on her feet, and with him not relying on the power of the boots to move, she had actually managed to keep up slightly, though she was still a ways away from matching his speed.

Craters littered the room, some large then others. Scars from a blade marked the spots she had tried to back him into a corner, only to miss as he dodged over her.

Millicent was gulping down air, drenched in perspiration. In her hands was all that remained of a sword, just the handle and guard. The blade was stuck in the ground from where she tried to stab his foot to prevent him from moving.

She had her eyes narrowed, showing her annoyance as she tried to glare him to death.

She hadn't hit him once, and thus had been allowed no breaks. Given the lack of sky in the cavern, she had no idea how long they had been training. It felt like hours, and for all she knew, it had been.

“I'd say you earned some rest.” He said, looking around the room. “And we'll have to find a better place to train, since I don't want to keep having this place repaired. Maybe an island, there are hundreds of them that would suit this purpose, and would really allow you to grow and test the limits of your power.”

He looked back to her, ignoring the annoyance she held for him. “Before you rest, however, we're going to see Giblet. She'll fit you for some armor, and should have it ready tomorrow morning, at the latest. We'll grab some dinner after that.”

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Are you sure you'll be fine watching over her training for a few days?” Percy asked, standing in the heart of the tower.

“Yes, I'll be fine. Trust me, Overlord.” Eres said, sitting on the large glowing orb of magic that she currently was bound to. “I'll make sure that the minions are thorough in their training on the island, and Giblet has already made some new training weapons with magicks that will keep them from breaking, even with her immense strength. They'll leave a miniature version of the tower-heart in the heart of the island, allowing me to observe, but not much else.”

“Alright, I know I can trust you with this.” Percy said, nodding. “But remember, she isn't the Overlord yet. And make sure Velvet keeps the Netherworld tower in good condition. If I have to go down there to fix another of her screw ups because she decided to have the minions dig for some jewels or gold in a important structural foundation again, I will not be happy. You know how I hate going to places with Lava and too much heat. It's why I stay out of Hell.” He said forcefully.

And a giant stalactite hanging over what amounts to an abyss that Lava from the core of the planet falls endlessly into, leading to Hell itself on a one-way plummet, was not the ideal place for him to be.

They had more then a few close calls when Ember and many blues were actually called in to repair some structural damage to the Netherworld from her making the minions work on digging out shiny things.

Velvet liked shiny things, more then a cat likes string.

Percy swore that sometimes she was worse then the browns and their love of hats and battle.

“Yes, yes. I know.” Eres said, stroking his arm as he stood next to her. “Now, Mistress Annabeth is wondering where you are. Seems the centaur has been fired already. The one you call Tantalus, the Child-eater, will be arriving soon. The god who watches over the camp, besides you Sire, is there as well. I could never bothering to remember his name.”

“Dionysus, Eres. That's his name.” Percy said, looking around the room. The scrying pool, filled with clear water, and the library that Eres had been working on filling out with knowledge from the tower-heart. There were shelves upon shelves of books filled with information already, and there were still stacks of books on her desk, filled with nothing but blanks pages.

There was no bed, since Eres retreated into the tower-heart itself should she require sleep. And she required no food, since her energy was supplied by... other means. Namely Percy giving her some of his energy through intercourse, though if he was busy for extended periods of time, and she wasn't, she could draw back some energy from the minions like Percy does when he takes bits of their life force for smithing or enchanting without sacrificing them.

Though that normally required lots of minions.

Whenever something like that happens, Eres normally just went into the tower heart to sleep and conserve energy.

“Thanks for letting me know though.” Percy said, looking at Eres. “I trust that everything will be handled here for a few days, as usual. If anything important happens, let me know. And I want Giblet to look over Tyson's designs again when she has the time. She couldn't give me an answer last time, due to being focused on a project and forgetting about them.”

“Of course, of course. I'll have her look them over again.” Eres said, nodding her head absently. “Now go, Already Mistress Annabeth is getting fed up with the Child-eater, and so are the servant girl and the minions stationed around the camp.”

“Oh no.” Percy said flatly. “I guess I had better stop them before they hurt him.”

With that, he waved at Eres before vanishing, walking through the void to his home universe.

Man, did he need to name them or something.

~

Percy appeared next to Thalia, who was still resting from her ordeal the other day. Night had fallen on the camp, and already Percy could see the campers sitting down for dinner at the pavilion.

“Master.” A minion said, emerging from the bushes in dark clothing and bowing. Her dark hair helped hide her in the dark, though her green eyes shining in the moonlight worked against her.

“Any news to report?” Percy asked, watching as satyrs and nymphs joined the campers for dinner.

“None, save for the fact that the Child-eater is grating on even the brown minions.”

“Really, that bad? I figured Eres was talking about you and your sisters.” He said. “But if he's annoying the browns...”

He looked at her, seeing her want, bordering on need, to deal with the annoyance in one of most violent ways possible.

“When you switch out patrols, see if Nix is done with the poison we sent her the other day. Before he's sent back to his prison, we'll give him something to remember us by.” Percy said darkly, though with an evil smile.

A smile that the minion was happy to share.

“Of course, my Overlord.” She said, none too subtle in her happiness.

With that, she melted back into the foliage, letting the shadows consume her as she started back on her patrol.

'Well, better go deal with this.' Percy said, ignoring the signs of a recent battle all along the hill side. It was nowhere near as bad the day Thalia had been poisoned, which showed that it wasn't time for Clarisse to leave on her quest.

~

“And now for some changes in the summer activities this year.” Tantalus said, giving the campers a crooked smile in his prison jumpsuit. His pale skin shone with an eerie glow from the light of the fire. It wasn't a raging inferno, but neither did it look like it was on the verge of dying.

The campers looked at him questioningly, wondering what in Tartarus he was talking about. Couldn't he see they were not in the mood for any news right now? They wanted to eat, set up patrols and go to bed.

“We'll be reinstating the chariot races this year!” He said with a demented glee.

Murmurs broke out amongst the tables. Chariot races? They'd been canceled for years!

“Now, I know that they were canceled some years ago due to, ah, technical problems.” He said, almost wistfully, thinking on those 'technical problems' that led them to be canceled in the first place.

“Three deaths and twenty-six mutilations!” One of the campers called.

“Yes, yes!” Tantalus said, the sadistic glee barely hidden from his face. “But I know you will all welcome me in reinstating-”

“Will you just shut up, you demented child-killer?” Percy said as he walked into the dining pavilion, glaring daggers at the man. “Anyone who knows your story, and how bitter you must be, knows you just want people here to die.”

“And who, exactly, are you?” Tantalus asked, narrowing his eyes at Percy.

“Not denying it? At least you're honest about that. As for me, I am Perseus Jackson.”

“Ah, the child of Poseidon I was told about.” Tantalus said, his eyes darkening with disgust. “It must be nice, having daddy back you up. Though you are older then what I would assume for a camper.”

Percy growled at the man, the area around him darkening. “Shut your mouth, you miserable waste of life. I do not rely on Poseidon's power or name for anything! To assume so would be suicidal on your part.”

“And what could you do to me?” Tantalus asked, strangely haughty for a damned soul. “I'm already dead, if you've forgotten.”

“Make no mistake, child-eater.” Percy said, his voice as cold as steel. “Whether or not I can kill your soul doesn't matter. It's whether or not I can make your afterlife even more miserable then it already is. And trust me when I say that I can, and if you cross me, I will.”

“Pah, you can try. I've dealt with my torment for over three thousand years. Nothing you could do could make it worse.”

“Believe that if you want, but realize that you brought it upon yourself.” Percy said, on the edge of the pavilion. “And aren't you going to say something Dionysus? He is your responsibility while he's here, after all. If something were to happen that would draw the ire of the other gods because of him, well, I'm sure they won't go overboard in your punishment for his actions.”

The god sighed, obviously not happy or interested with what was happening. Though, when was he ever happy when he was at the camp?

“Yes, as much as I loathe being stuck here as well, I must ask that you keep your exceedingly unpleasant tendencies to yourself. Though, I do miss the chariot races as well. If we give them time to prepare, it would cut down on the casualties and dismemberment. In a week's time, we shall have the first race in years. Finally, something that's entertaining.” He muttered at the end.

Tantalus fumed, but chose not to speak. He tried to wildly grab at a plate of ribs that had been set on the table a while ago, but the plate flew out of his reach faster then the man could move, which was a surprising amount of speed for someone who had been starved for three thousand years.

“Yes.” The horribly thin man said testily. “Teams can sign up in the morning. And the winning team shall have their cabin exempt from chores for a month.” He said, obviously not interested anymore if there wasn't the chance that someone would die.

Percy ignored the glare the man, if he could be called that, sent him, as if promising to make his time at camp as miserable as possible.

“Hey, Beckendorf.” Percy asked, walking up to the leader of Hephaestus cabin.

The African American looked up at Percy from his project, moving the welders mask from his face.

“Hey Percy, what can I do for you?” He asked.

“I was wondering if you would mind setting up Tyson with a bunk for a while. He'd be more then happy to help in the forge.” Percy asked.

“Sure, sure. It's no problem. It'd be great to have a cyclops in the forge. Besides, he's so creative with his designs. Last time he was here, he built a mechanical horse that could turn into a bird and fly around. It's like having the imagination of a five-year old with all the skill to build one could ever want.”

The normally silent leader of Cabin nine was grinning at the thought of working with a cyclops, his normal scowl gone.

“Thanks. I'll bring him by tomorrow then.” Percy said. “By the way, if Tantalus tries to have Tyson driven off because he's, well, a cyclops...”

“Don't worry.” Beckendorf said, hefting the forge hammer he had next to him. “We at cabin nine will make sure that the man doesn't try anything. Cyclops are well known for being our father's assistants, and Tyson's considered an honorary camper while he's with us. Tantalus can't touch him. If he does try something...”

“Good.” Percy said, nodding. “And good luck with the chariot race.”

With that, he turned and left the forge, Beckendorf quickly going back to his project, whatever it may be.

~

“Hey.” Percy said, appearing atop the climbing wall.

“Hey yourself.” Clarisse said, pulling herself over the lip of the cliff-like training course. She was sweating slightly in the noon heat, a few holes in her clothing where the lava burned through. It wasn't lava though, more of a... magic gel? That's really all it could be called though, since while it was indeed incredibly hot, it wasn't something that would kill someone if they fell it it, which a lot of people did. It, at the most, gave light burns on non-vital areas of the body, such as eyes or throat, and burned a decent bit of their clothing.

And no, Percy hadn't tampered with it.

The stuff that the Harpies used in the kitchen to wash the dishes was closer to actual lava though, which was why campers needed special gloves.

“What do you want?” Clarisse asked, barely breaking breathing hard from her treacherous climb.

Her body was toned from fighting all year, training harder and harder, breaking past her old limits, creating new ones and then crushing those ones as well.

“Nothing much. Can't a guy spend some time with his loyal servant?” He asked.

“I guess.” She replied. “But normally you only come to camp when it's important, or speak to me when you have to.”

“I'm hurt.” He said, faking emotional pain. “You don't remember Christmas, do you? Or your birthday? I thought I did a good job there.”

Clarisse blushed slightly. “Yeah, I guess you did.” She admitted.

What can she say? Sometimes even a warrior woman needs to feel like, well, a woman.

She didn't get all dolled up or anything, but it was nice to relax, and let her... less masculine side out. Clarisse would never admit to having a feminine side, even remotely.

“Why don't you sit down with me.” Percy said, patting the stone beside him. “I just want to relax.”

Clarisse nodded, admitting she could use a little break before she got started on her chariot with her cabin.

What, you expected her not to enter?

“So,” She said, sitting next to him. “Heard you finally met face to face with your kid. How'd that go?”

Percy flinched slightly. “Yeah... not so well. She doesn't really know I'm her father, or that Rose is her mother.”

“What?” She asked flatly, clearly not believing what she was hearing.

“Just because I have an unbending will doesn't mean I don't have my own share of fears, so don't start.” He said. “And I've already beat myself up over that, and still am. There's that ever annoying voice called guilt in the back of my mind, and I actually allowed myself to be chewed out by Rose over the fact, after I told her that we weren't going to tell. But I will tell her, at some point. And if she tries to kill me, I'll let her take her best shot.” He said, rather heatedly. “But really, I'm not sure how to be a Father. You can sympathize with me there, not having a Father around. Hell, half the camp can sympathize with not having a father around, and everyone without having both birth parents around! My only example for so long was that bastard, and the gods aren't very good parents most of the time. Even with my knowledge of her future, I did what I did and I don't fucking know why!” He said, slamming his fist into the hard rock. “Now I have to live with my mistake, despite having so many chances to stop it! I'm reluctant to use time-travel, because that could damage an already cracked world, due to the magic explosion, and I really don't feel like dealing with split time-lines in trying to fix the time stream when I have no Idea at what I'm doing. And even then, that would only set things back by a year in this world, ten in the other!”

He took a breath, calming himself a bit. He knew he was getting more then a little agitated. “Sorry, but I know I fucked up being a parent. But trust me when I say I want her to get her revenge on everyone who made her life hell. Even if that includes me.” He said, looking down with a heavy sigh.

“Well,” Clarisse said. “This took a turn for the depressing.”

“Yeah.” Percy said, though he didn't sound angry at Clarisse. “I'll let you go now, to build your chariot with your cabin. And keep an eye on that new girl, with the blond hair and tan. She's a nasty piece of work.” He said, vanishing. The only sign he had been there was the imprint of a fist on the cliff.

~

Percy was floating around in the ocean, looking at the sky.

He was angry, but not at anyone in particular.

He knew he screwed up. He couldn't seem to escape from that fact.

Not only was his own guilt building, his mind not letting him forget his mistake, but it seems everybody was going to bring it up as well.

'Why did I do it?' He thought, looking up blankly, focused inward.

Yes, why? It did no good for her.

'I know that!' He said, arguing with himself. 'You being here is proof of that!'

That still doesn't change the fact that you caused her grief, and you don't know why.

'I know...' He thought, turning over to look at the darkness of the sea. 'But what am I supposed to do now? Time travel is out of the question, since it would possibly damage the world irreparably. For all my knowledge of the fate of that world, I seem to be screwing up more and more since things are changing beyond even what I can see. I didn't expect that even a small amount of my power in the fake tower heart would cause ripples in the foundation of the universe when it exploded. The destruction was greater then what it should have been, and the world, as crazy as it was, is more at risk then ever. Time travel could cause it to destabilize, not only retroactively killing Millicent, but Rose, Velvet, Jewel, and everyone else. That would also cause more problems, since I've brought the minions to other worlds, and that would effect them as well, leading to who knows how much chaos.'

Excuses...

'Then what? Then fucking what?' Percy asked, gritting his teeth. 'What do you think I should do then?'

…

'Yeah, that's what I thought.' Percy said. 'You're just the guilt that's eating away at me. You don't know any more then I do.'

Percy looked down at his hands, sighing. The bubble of air floated up past him, bursting on the surface.

'Despite all my power, I just have no idea what I have to do. I try and plan ahead, but I failed at being a Father. If I could punch my past self in the face, I would. But making eye contact is impossible with myself, considering the whole one-eighty degree thing.'

Percy sighed again, another air bubble escaping. He looked down, his divine eyes piercing the darkness of the ocean he created.

'I need to stay occupied right now.' He said, diving down slowly, leisurely kicking his feet. 'I can think on it after I've calmed down.'

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Let's see if those stupid birds will appear again.” Percy said, looking over the race track from the top of the big house.

“Birds?” A certain sapphire-eyed goddess asked, standing next to him asked. Her voice, so gentle and soft, was lifted slightly in question. “What damage could simple birds do?”

“Stymphalian birds, Melum. Nasty little beasts, with beaks made of razor sharp bronze.” He explained. “They love to kill, tearing flesh from bone in a mad frenzy. They're incredibly fast, even for birds, and they move like a horde, never very far from one another. They all attack at once, like a cloud of death, and possess some cunning to them.”

“I see.” She said, turning back to watch. “This is the first time I've seen these chariot races. Mortals never invented these in my universe, as far as I can tell. So this may be interesting, unlike those races that are popular in the mortal world.”

Percy chuckled, putting an arm over her shoulder. “I hope you enjoy this then.” He said. “This'll be the first time I've seen one as well, when I'm not the one behind the reigns that is.”

“I'm sure you are marvelous.” She said, resting her head against his shoulder. “I would have loved to see you race, though.” Her pure blue eyes were sparkling at the thought.

The goddess was currently wearing a simple black dress, her black hair was let down, cascading down to the center of her back. Her skin, which was still the slightly pale yet shiny skin she had when Percy freed her from the music box, was warmed under the sun. The ring finger on her right hand had a diamond ring perched upon it, dazzling in the light.

If someone had asked her, then she would say that it was evidence of her marriage, always commenting that her husband wished to remain anonymous. There had been a few times the paparazzi had tried to press her for info about her life, and the magazines that had interviewed her under more professional means had done the same, but she always ignored the question.

The only other piece of jewelery she wore was the necklace Percy had made her almost a year ago. She almost never took it off, only to sleep or shower. She took care of it, making it look almost as if it was brand new every day. For her shows, during the times she toured, it would dazzle those who came to see her, shining as brightly as any star in the sky. The sapphires, which Percy still claimed were less beautiful then her eyes, glistened brightly in the midday sun.

“I would love to as well, but I detest being near the child-killer.” He said, venom dripping from his lips. “I would not want him to ruin such a good day.”

“Why don't you just kill him, Master?” Melum asked. “If he displeases you so much, and is of no importance.”

“He's not worth it, to be honest.” Percy said simply. Campers were starting to fill the stands. “And besides, he'll get his comeuppance soon enough, and it will be sweeter to me then simply killing him.”

“Hmm.” Melum said, her eyes half-lidded as she placed a hand on her master's chest. “I see. If it pleases you, Master, then it must be good. Though, if you wish him gone, I shall be more then happy to sing the song that kills his soul.” She said, sounding so deadly for such a gentle voice.

“I know you would, my dear.” Percy said, smiling slightly. “I know you would.”

And so, the two stood there for a while longer, watching as the chariots and their riders rolled up to the starting line.

The Ares/Enyo cabin's chariot, driven by Clarisse and one of her cabin mates. A boy, with weapons strapped to his back, and inside the chariot itself. The blood-red chariot was drawn by two skeletal horses, almost certainly war horses from years long gone, having died in battles long forgotten by the mortal world. Truly, the only dead Enyo could call upon were the dead that died in battle. Dead human's, dead animals, or dead weapons of war.

Next came the chariot of cabin nine, Hephaestus cabin, driven by Beckendorf. It was wrought out of bronze and iron, the metal built for both speed and strength. The horses, bronze automaton's that snorted fire, were horses that would never tire, built with control in mind. Many a trick was hidden inside that otherwise unassuming chariot, by magic or sheer skill depending on the trap itself.

The Apollo chariot was third to line up. Crafted from gold, it shone in the sun, an attempt to blind the other chariots no doubt. Filled with long ranged attack options, mostly arrows, the chariot was designed to hold a veritable silo of ammo for the fighter. It was drawn by two palominos, obviously well taken care of.

Second to last was the Chariot of Hermes. Befitting the house of travelers, the chariot was worn, looking like it had seen many a journey in it's life. The green paint was slightly chipped and weathered, but it looked sturdy enough to get you where you needed to go. The Stoll Brothers, co-counselors of the cabin, manned the chariot, sly grins adorning their faces. The horses that drew the chariot were nothing special either, looking like the kind one could find at any farm or ranch.

Lastly was the chariot of Athena. It was a greyish-blue, in honor of their mother's eyes. A spear was emblazoned on the sides, but that was the only decoration. Otherwise, It was simple. And in it's own way, that was Elegant. Like most other chariots, it was built for speed, sleek and maneuverable. A few weapons that required the precise and steady hand that few could attest to, outside of Athena's cabin, that is.

“And here comes the loathsome wretch now.” Percy remarked, seeing Tantalus walk with no real enthusiasm towards the staff table, which Dionysus was already sitting at. In contrast to his usual demeanor, and the downright unpleasantness of Tantalus that the man emitted every second he was alive, the god seemed to have some interest in what was happening for once.

Then, something caught Percy's attention, fluttering in from the sky.

“Hmm?” He looked at it, seeing the gleam of bronze in the light. “Ah, and here comes the winged creatures now. Strange that they would arrive with Tantalus. Almost as if the man was so horrible that he drew monsters in to attack others, since I don't recall him ever having a scratch on him the last time this happened.”

Gradually, more and more of the aerial devils gathered, blocking the green of the trees with black feathers and gleaming talons. Their eyes were locked on the chariot racers, as if waiting for a distraction before they began to swarm.

“Melum, get ready.” Percy said. “When they attack, we're going down there.”

“What would you have me do?” Melum asked.

“I want to try something, which happens to be something you excel at. I want you to try and sooth the birds, sing to them with that beautiful voice of yours. If horrible noises, such as brass bells or Dean Martin, make them flee in fear, perhaps the sound of your voice can calm them down.”

“And if that doesn't work, I am to make them flee?” She asked.

“Obviously.” Percy said. “But, I have no doubt your voice can calm them. After all, if you have the earth itself obeying your commands after hearing you sing, it should be simple to captivate simple minded creatures such as these. Ah, and there they go.”

Percy turned his attention back to chariots, which now left the starting line. The Hermes and Apollo chariots clashed, with Conner Stoll tossing Greek fire at the wheel of the opposing chariot.

The enchanted fire quickly melted the soft metal, though it did blind the foolish demigod and render him defenseless as the Apollo chariot fighter quickly shot a blunt, but heavy, arrow at him, knocking him into Travis.

This, in turn, caused Travis to lose the reigns, and the two of them to be tossed from the chariot just as their golden opponent's wheel gave, flinging the two children of the sun god from their own chariot.

“Hopefully that'll teach them not to build something entirely out of gold.” Percy muttered. “At least add some other metals to it and make it an alloy.”

“Mistress Annabeth is fighting for the lead with the bronze chariot, Master.” Melum said, somewhat excitedly. “Go Mistress!”

“It won't last for long, unfortunately.” Percy said, watching as some of the Stymphalian birds rose from their roosts to attack. “We should get down there now, I suppose.”

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy appeared in the middle of the race track, Melum almost clinging to him, her arms wrapped around his upper body.

“Damned birds!” Clarisse was shouting, swinging a sword around her head in a futile attempt to disperse the birds that attacked her and her half-brother.

Already, in the span of seconds, the birds had become a cloud of death. Flying through the air, ripping and clawing at any exposed skin on anybody, and any skin that was clothed was soon bare. Cuts appeared on bodies as the winged devils descended on the campers, doing their level best to rend flesh from bone.

“Disgusting creatures.” Percy said, swatting aside several that tried to attack him and Melum. “Mel, you're going to have to do it soon. Otherwise-”

Percy had to close his mouth, as one bird tried to rip out his tongue. He grabbed the bird, making it pop in his grasp. A bronze beak fell to the ground, along with a few feathers.

'Gonna have to clean that off later.' He thought, though his face did not change to one of disgust as he shook his hand.

Melum nodded, drawing in breath through only slightly parted lips.

One bird, seeing what looked like an opportunity for some flesh, dived at her, with several of its brethren swooping after it.

'Oh no you don't.' Percy thought, swatting them away from the goddess, feeling a piece of his his ear being taken. A few cuts appeared on his face, golden Ichor rising to the surface.

'There are more then I thought, and they're faster then I expected.' He thought, lashing out at the next batch that dove at them. 'And I think I'm drawing attention to us right now.'

Indeed, more of the birds turned their attention to Percy and Melum. Due to Percy killing some of their number, or the scent of Ichor in the air, he didn't know. But the fact of the matter was the fact that the cloud of feathered death seemed to grow tighter and tighter around him, the sun starting to blot out above him.

Several dove for Melum again, aiming for her face. Percy brought up his arm again, seeing as several more were just behind them.

Percy didn't want to use the power of the gauntlets here, since there would almost certainly be collateral damage to both life and property, thus drawing the attention of the Gods to him, despite anything the Fate's would do.

Percy currently didn't feel Dionysus anywhere, showing that as soon as trouble started, the god ran elsewhere to avoid dealing with it.

But that didn't mean the god wasn't watching from afar, just out of his sight.

The flesh on his arms was torn, and while it did indeed hurt, it wasn't as painful as having his head sliced into eight pieces, nor anywhere close to the fights he had with Enyo. He really had no need for his armor to deal with this, for the moment.

Melum was about to sing, and bring an end to this awful noise. Thousands of birds squawking was not a pleasant noise, to say the least.

No order to it, and while she could see the beauty of the sound of chaos, this was just ugly.

She had just parted her lips a little more, her lungs filled with air, when she felt it. It was one drop, then two, and more soon followed.

It was warm, likely blood. She expected that to happen, as her Master could get messy with his kills when he used his hands alone.

But she knew it was different, since there wasn't the sound of a beak falling to the ground, and she felt her Master twitch in her hold just slightly.

Against her better judgment, the goddess opened her eyes, catching a few more drop falling down to join the ones that had already landed on her face.

Golden blood.

Her Master's blood.

Shed because he was protecting her.

Despite the lack of pain on her Master's face, she knew he was hurting. The birds that had embedded themselves in his arm soon had their necks snapped by his other hand, dispersing into a fine golden dust.

But she wasn't paying any attention to that.

Her eyes were focused solely on the trail's of blood that flowed from his wounds.

Caused by protecting her.

Melum's heart beat within her chest, in a flurry of sudden emotions. Anger, sadness, guilt, hate, worry, anxiety...

She had failed to protect her Master, and he was hurt because of it.

She had failed to do as he had asked of her, and he was wounded because of it.

Her Master bled for her, and she hesitated in her duty as his servant.

These birds had caused her Master pain, because she had failed to do as asked of her.

These birds were the reason her Master had to defend her.

The birds were the reason for her Master's pain.

Those feelings that swirled around in her heart soon filled her chest, mixing with the air in her lungs.

Her Master had never had to defend her before. She had been able to take care of herself, for the most part.

Though, in hindsight, they lacked training against multiple foes at once. Especially ones as small, fast and vicious as these.

But that wasn't the point, to her at least.

No, the point was her Master was hurt.

And those that hurt her Master...

Melum's mouth opened fully, a high-pitched, inhuman sound that even the gods of Olympus would cringe at coming from her. It wasn't like the time she defended against Hades, nor like the time she had attacked Athena. While those had had some semblance of singing to them, this was different in almost every way.

This was a sound that would make a Banshee seem silent, and the sounds of a thousand screaming souls seem like a symphony. Nothing less then the pure Emotion Melum felt that moment was poured into her voice, fueling it far after the air had left her lungs.

What need for air did she need, to let her wail be heard? She was a goddess, and such things were of no bother to her.

Her wail drowned out the sounds of the birds completely, drowned out the screams of the campers.

Almost as soon as she began, everything stopped. The birds began to fall from the sky, Melum's power tearing them from the air. The Campers were forced to their knees in pain, even Annabeth and Clarisse. Tantalus was laid out, flat on his stomach on the ground, unable to handle the power of the goddess.

Even the trees around the track were hurting, groaning as they tried to lean away from the source of their pain, Nymphs emerging from their trees in attempts to flee only to fall to their knees, clutching their heads.

Only Percy was unaffected by the pain of her wail. In fact, he felt slightly better, the small pain in his arm numbing. It felt like someone was trying to soothe him, not just in body, but in spirit as well.

Soon, the field was littered with bird corpses, all slowly turning to a fine golden powder. Their beaks were left behind, still as sharp as ever, in small, numerous piles around him and Melum, stretching out for at least fifty feet in a circular area.

Melum closed her mouth, a few tears trickling down her face. She took a few breaths, attempting to compose herself.

She looked around, finally hearing the silent weeping of the campers, curled up on the ground as they held their heads in pain, many unconscious from said pain.

But they didn't matter to her, save for Mistress Annabeth.

She would have to apologize later, make restitution for her mistake.

She looked up at her Master, seeing that his arm bled no longer. He looked dazed slightly, staring off into nothing.

“Master,” She asked gently, her voice laden with guilt and worry. “Are you alright?”

“Huh?” Percy asked, shaking his head slightly. “What? Yeah, yeah. I'm fine.”

Melum sighed in relief, hugging her Master tight. “I'm glad...”

“What just... happened?” Percy asked, looking around.

“Forgive me Master.” Melum said, with some guilt for causing harm to her Mistress, but not the others. The servant girl was debatable. “But when those creatures attacked you, drew blood from you, because you were defending me because I wasn't quick enough...”

Melum cast her eyes down, looking subdued. Her eyes held no tears, not anymore. If she were to be punished, she would accept it.

Percy looked around, sighing. 'Eres, could we get a full team of blue minions out here?'

'At once.' The apparition responded. 'If I may ask, why though?'

'Melum got upset that some birds managed to draw some blood from me.' Percy answered. 'And prepare a bed in the tower for Clarisse.'

'Of course.' Eres said before fading from his notice.

Percy appeared next to both the Athena Chariot and the Ares chariot, grabbing his first Mistress and his... head slave?

He never did give Clarisse an official title for her position.

Hefting one each over different shoulders, both Percy's walked back to Melum, who was now kneeling on the ground, having sunk to her knees after Percy had vanished.

As they got closer, both Percy's managed to... fuse together, resulting in one Percy that was holding both downed women over his shoulder.

“I think we need to talk.” Percy said, looking down at Melum.

The goddess could only nod, merely placing her hand on his leg before the four of them disappeared.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Banshee's wail

choices: A few days later, after the start of the quest.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“What the fuck were you thinking?” Clarisse yelled, glaring right at Melum.

“I do not answer to you.” Melum simply stated, looking at the enraged face of Clarisse as the imposing girl stood over her. “Only to Master Perseus and the Mistress.”

“I don't give a damn!” Clarrise shouted, stepping closer to Melum. “You'll tell me why you did that, or so help me, I'll-”

“Be silent, Clarisse.” Percy said authoritatively.

“Percy, she-”

“I said,” Percy reinforced the statement, leveling a cold gaze at Clarisse for a second. “Be silent.”

Clarisse opened her mouth to protest again, but after seeing the way he looked at her, she decided against it. Self preservation was very important to her.

It was several hours after the incident, and they were currently in the Dark Tower.

More specifically, they were in one of the roomier infirmary wards. It wasn't anything fancy, and there was no modern-day equipment that one would find in a hospital in New York, given that the blue minions didn't need any of that for their magic.

Besides, no electricity.

Currently, Clarisse was in a more... medieval style of dress, given that her clothes were shredded by the Stymphalian birds. She had a few scars left on her body from the healing process, though they were in no danger of reopening.

“Melum, I want you to explain yourself.” Percy said, turning his gaze at her. “Why did you attack everyone but me? The campers were no threat, and I wanted you to calm the birds, not destroy them.”

Melum stood firm, looking at Percy without faltering. “I did what I did, Master, to protect you.”

“Protect me?” Percy asked, raising an eyebrow.

“Yes. To protect you, to stop you from shedding your blood for me. You have no need to do so for me, no obligation.” Melum said. “It is I who should shed blood for you, take the pain so that you do not feel it. I faltered in the duty you asked of me, and I caused you pain with my hesitation. The blood you shed fell upon me, showing me that I had failed you.”

“Melum, you don't need-”

“Don't!” Melum said suddenly, fearfully. “Please, don't say I don't need to protect you! You are my master, my everything!”

Melum looked at him, her eyes wide with worry, the blue orbs glistening with tears.

“I know you are strong, and I know you are capable of so much more then I, a lowly slave. But that does not mean that I can put you at risk through my failings!”

The goddess quickly wilted from the refined stance she held before, falling to her hands and knees.

“I would do almost anything for you, Master! If it pleases you, I will walk the edge of fading, lose my identity and my power for you! I will kill your foes with mere whispers and deliver my sisters to you happily while they curse my name! I will do all that, but please...” She trailed off, her body suddenly wracked with sobs.

“Please...” She whispered, barely loud enough for even Percy to hear. “Let me keep you safe. Even if you are immortal, there are things that could kill a god.”

Percy looked down at his own hands, clenching his hand into a ball.

How many times had they tasted the blood of immortals, ending the endless?

“I know.” He said. “But even still, you had no need to do what you did. I barely felt their beaks anyway.”

“Lucky.” Clarisse muttered, clamping shut when Percy turned his gaze to her for a moment.

“I know, Master, I know... But the mere thought of you hurting because of me, because I, in any way, failed you... The mere thought of you hurting in any way, shape or form...” She choked out, unable to even describe what it would feel to her.

“That still doesn't excuse your behavior. I know you can direct the intent of your voice at someone specific, even in a crowd. Many of the campers were knocked unconscious, and I'm pretty sure even the undead horses from Clarisse's chariot were in pain and wanting to die again. Even Annabeth was knocked unconscious Melum!”

“I will make restitution to the Mistress, rest assured. I have no intention of escaping from any punishment that either you or the Mistress give. My only desire was to keep you from pain, my Master. I did not intend to harm anyone but the foul creatures that were attacking, but... I lost control. I am deeply sorry, and beg forgiveness from both the Mistress and yourself.”

Percy looked at Melum, still on her hands and knees and her head bowed, with a sigh.

This is where things got all muddled with him. He really should do something about Melum, but he honestly doesn't think he can without changing her. If he wanted her to stop acting like she does, and fearing his displeasure, he would have to rework her entire personality, and he wasn't sure that was something he could do.

With Styx, or Jewel, it was simple, though still different cases. For one, he didn't know Styx at all, other then her name and her role in the world, minor as it had been. So, without knowing who she was, it was simple to mold her to what he wished her to be with the least amount of regret.

Jewel had been shallow, twisted by the influence of his predecessor in the title of Overlord. Even before that, she was still rather... unpleasant.

She was lucky Khan was so stupid as to not take offense to her during all the time they spent stuck together.

Melum though, he knew, to some extent. She was loyal, immensely so. She was also kind, and that was always a plus in Percy's book, and he wasn't talking about the Eronomicon.

But it was acts like this that could cause undue trouble.

But Percy wouldn't change Melum, in any way. He wouldn't have her any other way, then who she was.

But at the same time...

Percy rubbed his brow, already feeling the headache start. He wouldn't be doing something so drastic to Melum as to change her entire personality.

“Look,” Percy said, sighing. “I appreciate the fact that you couldn't stand seeing me hurt, even if I didn't feel anything in the first place, but that still doesn't excuse the fact that you had collateral with the campers and Annabeth. I gave you that necklace to help control your voice, and you still let your emotions get the better of you. You can't lose control every time I get hurt or defend you.”

“I understand...” Melum said, a few tears dropping to the stone floor.

“But, that said, I can't really say I want to punish you for your actions. And I know Annabeth would forgive you, if give you a lecture. I understand why you did what you did, but I'm really torn on the matter. You should be punished, but I'm not the person to do it. I really don't have it in me to actually punish a woman, and not because I think you're fragile.” He said, adding the last part because he could already tell Melum would say she could handle any punishment he gave her. “The worst punishment I can think of would be Isolation, but I know that would effectively kill you.”

The sudden tensing of Melum's entire body when he mentioned Isolation, being separated from him, told him that he wasn't wrong.

“So she's getting off without punishment then?” Clarisse blurted out, indigently. “What a load of-”

“I never said that Clarisse.” Percy interrupted, turning his gaze back to the girl. “I only said that I wouldn't be the one to decide her punishment, since I can't really think of one for her and have no desire to do so. She does deserve punishment, but you'll be the one to both think of and carry out the punishment. In the mean time, Annabeth has been wanting to talk more with Melum about her original universe, so she can leave now until a punishment is decided upon.”

Melum took that as her cue to leave, and rightly so. She quietly slipped out the room, Clarisse sitting back on her bed as Percy locked eyes with her.

“You want me to... what?” She asked, the gravity of the situation dawning upon her.

“As I said, you will be the one to punish Melum for her actions. As I see it, you are the most vocal about it out of the three of us, meaning Annabeth and us two. I know Melum should be punished, but I don't feel like going through with it myself, since I don't exactly feel the need to punish her despite what I said earlier.”

“So you were-”

“Obviously not, otherwise we wouldn't be having this conversation right now. I'm just going to lay down a few ground rules for the punishment. One, no trying to have her become isolated, as I feel she's dealt with enough of that in her immortal life. Two, and let me be very clear on this, absolutely no physical harm save that of physical labor, if you decided that is what she is to do. Lastly, no trying to change her from who she is. I quite like Melum the way she is, so no trying to rework her personality.” Percy said, before realizing something. “And I would hope you know that mental or emotional trauma is forbidden, given how quickly Melum's emotions changed from a respectable goddess to a grovelling slave.”

“What can I do then?” Clarisse tried her best to not growl out.

“I'm sure you'll think of something.” Percy said dismissively as he turned on his heel to leave. “Rest up for tonight, because you'll be breaking the news to camp about your little quest.”

With that, Percy left the room, hoping to deal with a complaint from the magical community before things got out of hand.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy walked around the deck, looking over the rigging and lines, making sure that everything was, pardon the pun, shipshape.

Deckhands, both living and deceased, were working hard, making repairs.

Amongst the living were the Minions, blues and browns alike. The blues would give orders to the browns, and the browns would diligently work under their leadership.

The blues had seemed to siphon off more of Percy's abilities then he realized, seeming to know their way extremely well on a ship. The browns as well, seeing as how the blues would order them to a certain part of the ship, and the browns would know exactly where to go.

Though, Perhaps that was just something that their original creator, the Black Baron, had used the minions for originally.

Percy was really going to have to go to an alternate universe that was close enough to the one where he had risen to the title of Overlord. He really wanted to meet the man, just to see what he was like. Perhaps the first Overlord as well.

In any case, they were not the only crew the vessel had.

Among the minions walked the dead, reanimated skeletons.

They wore tattered naval clothing, holes letting the wind blow through their empty rib-cages. They milled about their tasks, going through the motions with no real vigor.

They had fought their battles, and now they wanted rest. Rest, which currently, was being denied because of their defeat in the civil war.

That was the price of losing a war in a world with gods like the Olympian's, it seems.

“Are you sure your crew will be fine on a more classical ship then the steam-powered one you used in life, Captain?” Clarisse asked, sitting with the leader of the dead portion of the crew as they plotted a course for travel.

The dead man nodded, the shimmering illusion of his face a second behind. “Aye, we should be. Though, I don't know if my men will be able to do all the fancy climbing.”

“That's why the minions are here.” Clarisse said, looking over the chart again.

The ghostly face sneered. “Bah, women on a ship. I don't understand why you allow them on board. They have no place here.”

“Are you saying I have no place on this ship?” Clarisse asked, looking at the skeleton with a raised eyebrow. “That could be counted as insubordination you know.”

The man sneered again, but grit his teeth. “I'm bound to serve you, if me and my crew wish to finally rest. We'll do as you ask of us, but that doesn't mean we like it. We have our own standards and protocol.”

“Good to know.” Clarisse said dismissively. “Besides, they may look like women, but they're demons, and good at what they do. Running a ship seems to be one of those things.”

“Be that as it may, I only see them for what they are.” The captain said, before he himself looked over the chart again. “If we can keep the ship from being torn apart by monsters, as you say it likely will, we should make good time to the island. Though, without steam power to keep us going, we'll be a little slower if the winds don't favor us. With a good headwind, it will take a week or so, give or take any stops we might make along the way.”

“And we will be making stops, Captain.” Percy said, entering the smallish room. “And you don't have to worry about not going fast enough. The Blue Minions can take care of that, easily enough. And if you don't like women on the ship, I suggest you throw yourself overboard now. These stops will mostly be getting more women, and monstrous ones at that. I don't think they would take kindly to any sense of hostility.”

The captain scowled, but stayed silent.

“Now, have you decided on the course?”

“Yeah, we have. We'll head directly to the sea of monsters, since we're well stocked on provisions. After that, well, we'll see what happens.” Clarisse said.

Percy nodded. “Alright then. And remember, I'm officially not on this quest with you. I just happen to be going the same way. And I still won't be here much, since I'll be with my daughter. Annabeth and Grover will stick around, so you can get in contact with me if necessary. And, as per your request, Melum is going to be stationed on the ship to act as a storm breaker if the need should arise. If anyone can calm a storm, it'll be her. Now, if you'll excuse me, I want to be out of my father's domain. Safe trip.”

With that, he walked out of the room and off the ship. He wanted, and needed, to train Millicent some more.

She needed to be ready, and the fact that time was so incredibly fast compared to this universe meant that drastic measure's may need to be taken to ensure she can take her place as the next Overlord and rise to the challenge of taking down an empire.

Plus, given the things that he might not know about her now, such as with her eyes, he needed to make absolutely sure he knew all she was capable of.

Now if only there were a way to do so without having to deal with the whole process of time flowing and aging him...
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Bon voyage, I've got my own stuff to do right now.
