1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Are you serious?” Percy asked, looking down at the cover of the Eronomicon as he held it.

He was currently sitting in his room in the dark tower. The sun had set a few hours ago, and several candles were lit on his desk, the embers flickering as a warm breeze blew through the open window. The sounds of the nightlife in the city reached him, but he ignored it as he would a fly on the other side of the world.

'As ever, Marked one.' The tome spoke directly to his mind, as always. 'While technology isn't my forte, to be honest, it was a chance I couldn't pass up. To be able to gain not one, but several powerful items such as these, I would have to be more of a fool then anyone who would stand against you.'

Percy rolled his eyes slightly, but nodded in acknowledgment.

“You seem to have everything, don't you?” He asked, only semi-joking. “Well, show me exactly what you're talking about.”

Setting the tome down on the desk, Percy watched as the tome flipped open, perusing its own pages quickly as it made it's way to the requested item.

Finding the right page, the paper halted in its maddened fluttering and came to a rest.

“Let's see now, what are the details of this little beauty.” Percy said, leaning over as he pulled the tome closer.

The page image was of a cube, with an arrow pointing to the side at a picture of a hand held device. Under those there were several small boxes.

“The reflective video game. Huh, sounds interesting.” Percy mused, lazily scanning over the details, knowing the book would talk about it in depth.

'Indeed, Marked one. Using these may be the solution to your current problem, with the help of some magic.'

One of the boxes started to glow, but not in the way that happened when something was being brought out or put into the tome.

'This one in particular. It will allow you to train you offspring without actually aging either of you physically. Mentally, on the other hand...'

“Alright, and tell me what's so special about this box.”

'Well, the first thing you should know is that this little box is, essentially, a miniature multiverse, in a sense.'

Okay, now Percy was interested. Very much so, in actuality.

'While not exactly infinite, it is close. It houses an enormous amount of universes in it, each available for journeying and questing that so many people seem to find themselves in.'

“Sort of like what I did a year ago with that merry band of idiots before I took my place as Overlord?” Percy asked, though he already anticipated the answer already.

'Essentially, yes. But, that's not all. It operates on the same principles as the actual multiverse, for the most part. There are countless scenario's of your choosing, each with almost limitless potential to mold to your wishes. The level of danger, the tensions of political factions, civilizations progress, landscape, pantheons... Everything a god could wish for in building a world.'

Percy's mind was already thinking of ways that this could benefit him and his girls.

“Alright, it sounds good so far. But what's the catch?” Percy asked. “There's always some kind of perverted catch with you... Not that I really mind, but I would like to know beforehand if possible.”

'I'm glad you asked.' The tome said, and Percy had the feeling that if the book could giggle perversely it would do so in a heartbeat. 'You see, when I commissioned these, I had the stipulation that all monsters would be female, and more or less humanoid, though with the ability to transform into their monstrous primal forms under extreme circumstances.'

“I see.” Percy said, a Cheshire grin spreading across his face. “I'm not seeing any downside to this. You are amazing, you know that?”

'It is all to further your glory, Marked one.' The Eronomicon said, and the image of a featureless person, even more featureless then Eres without an item to be bound to, bowing in worship. It even lacked any sense of falsehood, being one hundred percent sincere, with no backstabbing adviser vibes, unlike Gnarl when the minion was still alive.

But Percy's mind also turned to questions regarding this.

“I have a few questions about this though. First of all, explain what you mean by not physically aging.”

'Well, when the item is activated, it will pull your mind and soul into the world, creating a physical body for you upon arrival in the world. Until then, you would control things mentally. So, while your mind and soul would age, your physical body will not. Also, time inside any of those worlds is drastically sped up to a point so that you could, hypothetically, live out hundreds of thousands of lives and it would merely be a day out here, or most any other universe.'

Percy frowned upon hearing that.

“But that means that time would still pass here, in this universe. It's connected to my soul, you know.”

'Ah, yes.' The Eronomicon mused. 'That would be troublesome, to say the least. If you used this here, in this universe, your body would feel the effects of the time spent in the item. Hmm... what to do, what to do.'

Quite the conundrum, that.

“I can't exactly evacuate the city and send everyone back to their own worlds for eight years, at least from my perspective.”

That's all he needed, eight years. More then enough time to train Millicent. Physical combat, magic, leadership...

Tell her the truth about her lineage, for better or worse.

“So, does this item have a training program, something that would be suitable for my intentions?” Percy asked, curious if he would be able to do what he needed to do quickly, or if he basically had to live his life as normal with nothing else changing besides him, Millicent and Rose.

'If you're asking about a tutorial, as I think they are called, then yes. It will teach you how to use the item, far better then I could.' The tome said.

Percy sighed. “Not exactly. Well, it looks like I'm going to have to figure out what I'm going to do about this. It seems to be the best option, considering that any other will have time will pass back home with Annabeth, Melum and everybody else. But, other then that snag, I'm still not seeing a downside to this. To me, it seems that I could use this item to, in theory, increase my power infinitely. I create a universe that is populated only be women, have all of them insanely strong, and have entire pantheons of women that are even more powerful then that and claim them all. Or, do the inverse and populate the universe with nothing more then insanely powerful men and fight them all to the death, to take their power as my own.”

'Those both sound like good options to me, Marked one. The technomancer I received these from was close to his deathbed when I commissioned these, and he was desperate enough for his magnum opus to be powered that I doubt he would care to iron out such an exploit in the system when he made these.'

“Hmm, well, my darkness and fire affinities that I got from the Forgotten God have needed a boost, though my power over death is sufficient enough for the moment...” Percy mused, before shaking his head. “No, at least, not now. Even if I could, it would make my existence more a chore then anything. In fact, I highly doubt I would be able to contain my power enough to enter a universe if I did either of those options.”

'Hmm, yes. That does sound like a problem. Though, I should also tell you that these worlds play by rules similar to something called RPG's, or Role-Playing Games, as the mage called it.'

“Ah, yes. I've heard about those back home. They're a genre of video game, so I guess it fits. I think they were all turned based or something.” He said, shrugging. “I don't know from personal experience though, since I was never one for such things. My first foray into the lair of those damned Lotus Eaters was the first time I actually touched anything of the sort. Anyways, I need to think on whether or not I should use this. If so, I'll need too evacuate the city and send people back to their own worlds for a while. I'll need to calm the winds and seas, stagnate the vegetation, so that when I get back the place isn't in ruins. I'll also need to move the minions into the Netherworld Tower, along with the tower heart and Eres. They'll have to spill up into the surface world for a while. And... you said you were the power source behind it, correct?”

'More or less.'

“Very well. I'll think on it for the night, and we'll see where this path leads.”

'Very well Marked one. Should you require further information about this, I'll be more than happy to explain in detail.'

Percy rolled his eyes, pulling his hand away from the book. Standing up, he moved silently to his bed, which would be empty save for him. A rare occurrence anymore.

Closing his eyes, Percy fell into a sleep that was as empty of dreams as the void was of existence.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Eres, let the patrolling minions know that I want all the guild leaders and district officials in the palace for an emergency meeting. Have them deliver the message as soon as possible, even if it means forgoing the patrol routes to deliver it.” Percy said, appearing in the heart of the tower, next to the tower heart.

“At once, my Lord.” Eres said, not stopping in her writing. It was as simple as a stray thought, not interrupting her thought process. “Done. By the way, did you know that in the universe the minions came from, the last dragon was killed by the Black Baron just months before he vanished? He had it hidden away in his own personal cache of rare monster remains that he personally stuffed, and, quite possibly where he went to die?”

“Interesting.” Percy chimed monotonously. “I'll have to find this some other time, just to see if any of it survived. If only his soul was in hell, I could force him to talk. But that stupid goddess of the Elves, bah! If only I didn't want Millicent to have a challenge in her life, and for her to reach her true potential and take the fat wretch down. How Elves allow their priestess' to gorge on so much food to put sumo wrestler's to shame... all in effort of mimicking the slob of a goddess... What did the Forgotten god see in her?”

“Obviously not much, considering he cheated on her with a mortal women.” Eres said, putting the last dot above the last 'i' in her latest book that covered the newest batch of knowledge she had divulged from her soul-bound object.

“True. All she does is sit in the heavens, soaking up all the praise and prayers that what few remaining elves there are give to her daily. I should have kept that statue to mock her. But no, I had to be the nice guy and give it back to a bunch of ghosts after capturing Jewel and all the plunder she had accumulated, including said statue.”

“I know, I was there after all you know.” Eres said with a sigh. Even with a body made entirely out of arcane energy and the natural lust and perversion of the universe, pulling a three day scribing binge could tire her out. Not to mention she hadn't had any energy from her favorite, and only, source, nor in her preferred way in that time, with her mind barely focusing on the other task she had been given of watching his first born daughter as she trained on an island with several groups of minions when Percy wasn't there himself to train her. “So, if I may ask, what's this meeting for?”

“I have learned of a way to train Millicent in more then enough time to ensure she's ready for her journey, but not without having time pass by in this universe. During that time, I won't be able to be contacted, nor will I be able to give energy to you for maintaining the pathways. More so, I do not feel like leaving the entirety of the magic community alone with the possibility of them trying to satiate their curiosity as to how different magical energies would react to one another, possibly undoing all my work in creating this universe and killing everybody in it! It was hard enough to create it the first time! It wasn't easy easy to create a star or planet the first time around, and I doubt it will come naturally to me after this one time! Hell, I haven't even learned how to actually 'create' anything! Hells, I have yet to deal with the other half of this planet's landscape! Damn it all, I doubt any gods born with this power had to deal with situations like this!

“Alright, alright, I get it!” Eres snapped, rubbing her temples. “You don't want everything to blow up, fine! Now, unless you are here to give me some of your energy I kindly suggest that you let me rest, because right now I am incredibly tired. In fact, please don't give me any because I want to experience the closest thing to sleep I can right now. I'll let the minions that are currently with your daughter know that you are on your way, as I know you will be. Now, please leave before I go insane from the stress I've put myself under for these last few days and have a meltdown that will make the fake tower-heart explosion seem to be as devastating as a zit being popped!”

Percy frowned, not liking the way she was acting. “I never asked for you to strain yourself, you know? So I suggest, before I damn the consequences and stuff you into the deepest parts of the Eronomicon and forget you're even there, that you change your tone. If you want to go on these binges of recounting all the info the tower-heart has seen since the time of its creation, that's fine. But I will not be the subject of your ire due to you not knowing when to take a break.”

Eres growled, opening her mouth to retort. But a vicious glare from Percy and his reaching for the tome in his pocket made her realize that it was not an idle threat.

“Fine.” She huffed, crossing her arms and turning away from him. The journal she had been writing in was surrounded by the same energy her body was made of, floating to a book shelf that was just out of sight, certainly heading for the spot that was reserved for any information regarding the Black Baron.

His glare softening, Percy sighed. Slowly walking up to her, he wrapped his arms around her.

“Look, I'm sorry that you're feeling tired. It's such a foreign concept to you, I know. And, given that you've been focusing on so many things all together throughout these last few years, it's no surprise that you are starting to feel everything catch up with you. The next few days though, you'll have plenty of time to rest. But I will not accept you lashing out at me for the reason of simply laying out my reasons.”

He paused, a small epiphany over came him.

“Though, perhaps I can do without the monologue. It seems to be the downfall of any Overlord type position.”

He coughed, getting back to his point.

“Nevertheless, I expect you to cool down for the next few days. I'll be closing the pathways down once I have the population evacuated to their original worlds. You, and the minions, will be moved to the Netherworld tower. I'll give you enough energy to sustain your physical form for a few days, two weeks at most if you keep to the tower-heart unless when necessary. And no more three day writing marathons for a while. Alright?”

Eres nodded, stifling a yawn that threatened to overcome her as she leaned back against Percy.

“I'm sorry.” She said sleepily, her eyes half-lidded.

“It's alright, this time.” Percy said, moving a few strands of her ethereal hair from her face before picking her up in a bridal carry. “You just rest for now, I'll handle everything for the rest of the day.”

He walked over to the Tower-heart, which floated in the middle of the room. He looked down at Eres, the eons old ghost already asleep.

“Sleep tight. You've more then earned it.” He said, laying her down inside her soul-bound object, watching as her physical body dissipated and merged with it.

Without a word, he left the heart of the tower, letting Eres sleep without him watching over her. He had to prepare for the meeting, and some of the district officials would most likely not be happy that it was so early in the morning.

Oh well, they would just have to sit there and listen. Percy was not going to walk on eggshells in his own universe.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Any objections?” Percy asked, looking down from his throne.

There were murmurs of discussion amidst the officials. Was it a wise idea? Was this in their best interest? Was it fair to tell everybody to pack up and leave, even if just for a little bit?

Percy sighed, rubbing the bridge of his nose. “I take it that there are.” He muttered, given that several people were speaking in less than pleased tones.

“What would be the consequences if we objected to this?” One official asked, standing up.

“A fair enough question. I would say that it would be whatever consequences that befall you from my absence, most likely including the breaking of the ban I placed upon magic users as well as not being able to use the pathways for supplies or escape from whatever comes from the magic experiments. And, given that I have not populated the world with animals, it would soon become a vegetarian only world. Well, unless you people started to resort to cannibalism.”

“I see...” The official said as they sat down, uncomfortable with the topic now.

“Look.” Percy said, standing up. “I know this is unexpected and sudden, but this information was given to me last night, so I've barely had a night to think on it myself. It's still not a sure thing, and I might find another way to do what I want. But, at the same time, it is also a great opportunity for not just my daughter, but for myself as well. From the information I've received, I will be able to learn how to create from nothing better than what I can do now. If so, that means I will be able to at the very least create a supply of meat should something like this happen again. So, I think it will be beneficial for everyone involved, even if it is a hassle to move the entirety of the population back to their worlds for, at most, a few weeks.”

“What about the work done on expansion? Surely what's finished will be rotted or weathered away.” The head of the construction teams asked.

“And the crops will be long rotted by the time we get back!”

“I have a solution to that, though it is only a small one. While I can't do anything for the crops that have already been harvested, I am going to try and stagnate the growth, and death, for the crops that are still growing or are ready for harvesting. As for the construction that's been done, or is underway, I am going to make the winds die down until I get back, and I'll also make sure that the oceans are calmed. The only reason I want the people out of here is human error, as I said earlier. While I can't stop time, I can do something close to it.” Percy explained before signaling one member out. “Tarn! I want the magic district cleared out first, every wizard sent back to their own world. As official of the district, I place that burden upon you. You will have as many minions as necessary to ensure the more defiant will have no choice but to comply with the order, as well as move current experiments and supplies that will decay over time that I can do nothing for.”

“You plan to act as if going through with this!?” Another council member asked, as if surprised.

“Yes, I do. The only reason I called this meeting in the first place was to let you know of the situation so it would not catch anyone flatfooted. I could have done this without giving warning beforehand and caused a panic. But I would like to keep the population on civil terms. And try not to forget that you hold no real power here. You are merely a group of people who have been chosen because you seem to be the most reasonable, have had recommendations by a large portion of your respective districts or, in some of your cases, are more then capable in your respective fields. Make no mistake, you are in my world. I allowed you entry here, and I can deny you the same privilege, or throw you back to your old masters, be they king or god. I am sure that they would not be so happy to see, what you amount to in their eyes, traitors.”

More than a few had to grit their teeth. He was right. They had abandoned their old worlds, and thus their old allegiances. He had made it perfectly clear when he offered them the chance to live in this world.

His world.

“Now, now” Tarn, the golden haired, pale skinned head of the magic district spoke up. “I don't believe it needs to devolve to threats. It shall be as you say Overlord. I'll have the district cleared within a month, rest assured. I'm sure my more knowledgeable colleagues will have their own ideas on how to solve this dilemma in a manner that doesn't involve emptying the city while the young and impulsive will try to object.”

“If any competent and knowledgeable person of the magical persuasion thinks they have a better idea, then they can come tell me in person. I'll be all ears.”

Sitting back in his throne, Percy looked over the council room, gauging each persons feelings on the matter.

Some were still feeling negatively about this, though that was expected. Most were neutral, leaning variously to either negative or positive on the matter without fully committing to a stance. The smallest group was of those who thought positively about the matter.

Tarn was one of such people who thought positively about it. Percy could already tell the man was thinking of ways this could effect the limitations on magic in the city. If he, Percy, grew more powerful, then perhaps he would be willing to help experiment with mixing the magical energies without having young, inspiring minds be put at risk to see which magic was capable of mixing together and which ones would be... volatile.

“Tarn, you are dismissed. I want you to get on this right away. I'll mobilize a retinue of minions to escort you. They'll be waiting outside the wall for you.”

The man bowed in his seat before he stood, grabbing his staff as four minions entered the room, two blues and two browns, to escort him out.

Once he was gone, Percy looked over the remaining council.

“Now, we should focus on which districts to empty after the magic district is cleared. I'm open to ideas and reasons behind them.”

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“This... has escalated quickly.” Percy said, overlooking the city.

From his balcony, high above the world, he could hear the shouts of the people from every district, save the now empty magic district.

“It's only been little over a month since I made the announcement. How have they set up a rebellion so quickly?” He asked himself.

Have you really thought about their best interests?

'Oh, you're back? Great...'

I will never leave you until the guilt is washed away with atonement...

'Atonement? For making sure they weren't trapped in a world with little food and only half finished? Please, I am doing them a favor right now. Besides, if I can learn anything from the worlds in that miniature multiverse that can help with me actually understanding the abilities a god should have, such as creating life from nothing, then it will be all for the better.'

So you s-

'Don't even start with that again.' Percy said, cutting off the voice of his guilt. 'As it is, I'm running low on time. Clarisse and the rest are almost to the sea of monsters, maybe a few days off in their world's time. That amounts for a few more weeks here. I don't have the time to deal with some unfounded guilt.'

You will lose the trust of the population...

'And?' Percy asked as he walked back into his room. 'I know they were already weary of me because of what I can do. This is merely a reaction to learning that they would have to leave their homes for a while. If... the hell is that whistling sound?'

The tower rumbled, the sounds of something crashing to the grounds soon following.

“Don't tell me...” Percy said, slapping a hand over his face as he walked back outside and looked over the balcony.

Large boulders, a dozen or so, littered the ground, debris surrounding them from their spot of impact against the tower.

Not from the tower itself, but from where they had cracked themselves on impact.

Percy gazed up, seeing the siege weaponry that had launched the stones.

…

…

“...How?”

There, outside the city limits, were what seemed... no, they were exactly that.

Giant catapults.

“How are they even structurally sou... Oh, damn it all.” He said, rubbing the bridge of his nose to stave off the encroaching migraine. “Of course they would. Enchanted wood is not easy to make, I hope they know. The druids won't be happy, that's for sure.”

'Percy, what was that? I felt the tower shake.'

'It seems we have an uprising, my dear Eres. A lot of people were not happy at my declaration. They've used the wood that was enchanted for some of the more outlandish projects that the magic district had wanted to work on in the future to make themselves... giant catapults.'

'…'

'…'

'…'

'Eres?'

'You're kidding, right?'

'No, though I wish I was. Come up to my room and see for yourself.'

While he waited, Percy could only watch in wonder as the rickety, yet sound, giant weapons of war were slowly cocked back to reload.

“Oh you have got to be...”

“So glad you could join me.” Percy said, not tearing his eyes away from the spectacle.

“Why are they doing this?” Eres asked as she floated next to him, eyes wide in absolute wonderment at the sheer...

Stupidity didn't cover it, did it?

“Because I asked them to leave the world for a little bit. It seems they like their quiet life and don't want to give it up for anything.”

“This is the opposite of quiet!”

“I know. Look down to the inner grounds of the wall.” He said, pointing straight down.

Doing so, Eres had to keep herself from bashing her head into the railing.

“Of all the stupid, childish, disrespectful-”

“I know, I know.” Percy said, though he didn't sound angry. “At least I know the tower will hold against siege weapons now. Still not sure about a giant attack though... maybe I should have Cerberus test that out when everyone is gone.”

“What are we going to do about them?” Eres asked, pointing in the direction of the catapults.

“We're going to do several things.” Percy said simply. “Eres, have all the brown minions gather down in the audience hall below the tower. Every single one. Even Giblet.”

“Really? Isn't that overkill?” She asked, only to have Percy merely look at her expectantly. “Alright then. Give me a minute...”

“While you do that, I'm going to go pick up Millicent. This should be something she sees.” Percy said as he walked away, vanishing.

~ An island far away ~

“Now, where could she be...”

“Run away!” A high pitched cry rang out.

“We didn't mean to disturb sleepy break!” A similar voice cried.

Both these were soon followed by the sound of breaking trees, likely being broken by an angered punch, and surprised yelps as the minions dodged.

“That was simple enough. Just follow the sound of terrified screams.” Percy said, more then a tad amused. “My, will that girl ever watch her strength? And it seems she inherited her aunt Velvet's temper regarding the little things.”

Off to save the minions from a brutal death, or at the least a beat down that will make them wish for the embrace of death, Percy made his way through the forest that covered most of the island.

The minions should be glad they were quick on their feet, for their cries were soon joined by the sounds of more destruction and angry roars of a sleep-deprived ten-year old.

“Now, I believe that is quite enough.” Percy said as he walked into the, newly made, clearing. Up-turned soil and wooden debris lay scattered about, gaping wounds in the earth signified where trees had been moments ago.

Millicent had caught up to the minions, grabbing their shoulders tightly and forcing them down to their knees. They were whimpering in fear as she glared at them, and her eyes were glowing enough that Percy could see the light that radiated from them even though her back was to him.

His first-born wasn't winded in the slightest, despite her raging as she chased them. She slowly tightened her grip, feeling as the bone in their shoulders was strained, cracking under the pressure.

“I don't care if you look like the women who saved me.” She growled out, every word laced with hatred. “No one wakes me up like that. Isdlauays!”

Translation?

Die.

In a very painful, mind breakingly horrifying way that would leave each reincarnation of you a gibbering wreck.

“Did you hear me?” Percy asked, louder this time. “I said, that is enough.”

With a nod of his head in her direction, watery bindings appeared around the girl, clamping tight to ensure she couldn't move. Each of her fingers had what amounted to rings around them, seemingly connected to the rest of her encasement.

If she moved her fingers in an attempt to hurt the minions, it would cause the water around her arms and head to essentially tighten, the water growing dense and heavier while compressing itself.

“Master!” The two cried, looking up at him past the bound form of their captor.

“While I would like to know what exactly happened, I don't have time for it today. Millicent, you will release them this instant, or there will be consequences.”

She growled, tightening her grip. What should have caused pain from that motion did nothing but annoy her, making her growl louder and narrow her eyes.

As expected. She was made of far tougher stuff then a regular mortal after all.

The two in her grasp whimpered louder, eyes screwed shut in agony.

Percy sighed. He really, really did not have time for this.

“I warned you.” He said with a shrug.

More water appeared around Millicent, condensing to a point where it seemed that the water was more solid then liquid.

The water forcefully pried the girl's fingers from the shoulders of the two minions, already starting to swell from the broken veins.

The two quickly scurried away from her, towards Percy before hiding behind him, like kicked puppies.

“We'll talk about this later, you two.” Percy said to the two behind him. “But I have things to do today.”

With another lazy nod of his head, Millicent's watery bindings clamped her arms to her side, making her stand straight with no chance of moving even a toe.

“The same goes for you.” Percy said, turning her to face him, her eyes glaring at him with, not hate, but something greater then anger. “Don't give me that look. I'm pretty sure I made myself loud enough for you to hear me over your attempted murder of these two. As I said, I'm very busy today, but there is something I want you to watch unfold.”

With that, Percy vanished with the three, traveling back to the tower.

But was that the only stop he made before dealing with this uprising?

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy covered his nose, to the best of his ability since he had donned his armor and helmet, grimacing.

'I hate it here, but I don't feel like leaving any thoughts of rebellion in the minds of those ingrates.' He thought, trudging through the burning landscape, ignoring the screams and moans of agony.

'Are you sure you want to do this, Sire?' Eres asked. 'And most of the brown minions have arrived.'

'Absolutely.' Percy thought back. 'Now call Morticia to the assembly hall. And do not object to this course. I merely want them to understand that to rebel against me is meaningless.'

He could hear her huff of annoyance at his preemptive dismissal of her concerns, but she quickly closed the link to do as he ordered.

'Now, where is she?' Percy thought, overlooking the ocean of lava for a sign of his target.

“Sweet Mother Goddess, help me!” A damned soul cried out at the top of their incorporeal lungs. “No! NO! KEEP HER AWAY! AHHHHH! I'M SORRY! FORGIVE ME! AHH! NO! NO! NOOOO-”

And again, one of the ways to find what he was looking for that day was to follow the tortured screams of terror.

Was there some multiversal theme he didn't know about for this moment across all universes?

One of the sure fire ways he knew it was his target was the fact that the Reapers would have let the victim scream longer, making their torture progress in such a gruesome fashion that they would beg to be killed, in as much as one could when already damned, just for the moment of respite before their body repaired itself for even further torture that would be even worse then before.

Another was the use of 'Her' in their wording. Only two women ever came to this place, and Morticia was not in this infernal place.

Succubi didn't count, since they didn't actually take part in tormenting people. They were more-so there to tempt people and lure their souls to Hell. The only time they actually tormented people was if the only sins they committed were Lust based.

Crossing the ashen wasteland, Percy came upon a sight that was not all uncommon in the land of the damned.

The soul of a mortal, looking to be a man in his thirties from Nordburg or one of the smaller communities around there.

Percy looked at him, seeing what he had done to earn a spot way down there.

Ah. A whaler who, while not living in Nordburg, had visited there quite often. He had taken part in adulterous affairs with several married women, killed a man in cold blood by tossing him overboard their ship during a trip, weighed down with rocks in deathly cold waters that held abominations against the Mother Goddess at their deepest depths, and vicious animals near the surface, and had more then once been rude to his hosts.

Recent arrival, it seemed.

His body was held down by many large rocks, several of which were clung to his genitals by chains that pierced clean through.

He was held above a special lake of liquid fire, several hands made of the stuff reaching for him, several already wrapped around his wrists and ankles, pulling on the boulders that hung from them. His skin, that which wasn't burnt that is, was stretched as his limbs were forcefully pulled down by both gravity and the hands of magma. In more than one place, the skin was ripped, some just as Percy was within the perfect distance to watch it happen if he were a mortal man, showing the muscles and sinews beneath.

He was foaming at the mouth, his eyes rolled back into his head.

Well, that explained the sudden silence. His mind had shut down, for the moment anyway, mid-scream.

And the reason for that currently had her hand wrapped around several of the chains that pierced the man's lower region.

This hand was different from the ones made of lava. Instead of being semi-liquid, it was solid with a flame raging around it, making the chains burn bright red from end to end. While the lava around it was more orange then any other color, the hand was a dark, smoldering red with two-inch claws in place of nails.

The hand was pulling on the chains, as if wondering what they did, only causing the man to spasm and cry, his tears turning to scalding hot steam to burn his face.

“Ember! Quit playing around! There's something I need you for!” Percy called into the small pool of torture as he stood at the edge.

The hand, and the magma equivalents around, jerked at the sound of his voice, two large hands emerging from the lava in what seemed to be an attempt to drag him in.

Only to wrap around him in a very loving, almost childish manner.

One thing Percy was glad that he didn't have to train in was natural resistance to all things fire related.

Sure, it was incredibly uncomfortable to him due to naturally being more inclined with water, the opposite of fire, but he could take anything fire tried to do to him.

Now, only if his control over the damned element was as natural.

As he was being smothered by the lethal liquid hands, a figure emerged from the pool, leaving the poor man hanging there without the extra torture.

For now.

She, and it was definitely a woman, was very... Well...

She stood at Six foot eight inches tall, with very well defined muscles all over her body. Her skin was the same smoldering red color from her head to her feet, flames dancing across every inch of it in a beautifully chaotic manner.

Her hair was fire itself, though different from the fire that danced around her body. It seemed to try and eat itself, but was also always growing, causing it to change length constantly. It also seemed very adverse to mingling with her fiery aura.

Her eyes were a burnt orange, pupils gray like smoke instead of black.

She sported bull-like horns on her head, not unlike a certain bipedal cow that had been a thorn in Percy's side. They were easily two feet long, and they were much pointier than the original Minotaur’s horns.

Speaking of which, he had four Minotaur horns now. He should really find something to do with them.

Anyways, she also sported a long, thick tail, more draconian then Echidna's in her human form, with black scales that bounced all light off of them, It swayed to and fro as she walked, and Percy knew it was more than capable of knocking someone through the air without much trouble.

This was Ember, the 'leader' of the red minions. As much of a leader a beast can be, that is.

Stepping out of the magma pool completely, the fiery liquid dripping from her body. She smiled at Percy, slowly walking towards him with her arms out to reach for him, like a toddler walking to their parent. Her smile was held both the innocence of a child and the grace of a predator, her abnormally sharp teeth, even among the minions, stained forever with blood.

At least the lava she liked to bathe and swim in had long killed any bacteria, and the raging inferno around her kept any from forming on her.

Another thing about her was the fact that she was completely nude, due to the aforementioned fire that surrounded her destroying any clothing that she wore, and the lava melting anything else that she tried to wear.

The footprints she left behind charred the already burnt landscape, leaving flames flickering in wake of her travel. Wherever she walked, the three-toed, or perhaps it should be said three-clawed, footprints were burned into the earth for years to come.

The most powerful red minion at Percy's disposal, one of the most powerful minions in terms of sheer destructive force. Ember was akin to a force of nature embodied. All things related to fire were hers to command, and she could control lava like the blues controlled water.

But she was also the one most driven by instinct. She was a wild animal given the power of fire, and then a human form. She acted on her whims, but never truly thinking of the consequences.

And she was his to command, and only him. Even Eres had a hard time ordering the minion around.

Ember reached through the lava, grabbing hold of her Overlord and pulling him close, a rumble from her chest making clear her happiness.

“Yes, yes Ember. I'm happy to see you too.” Percy said, returning the hug she gave him. “I came by to see if you wanted to cause a little mayhem.”

She made a sound, the animal equivalent of asking why.

Not that she didn't enjoy partaking in mayhem or destruction, mind you.

“Well, it seems some people are not happy with me, and are being very naughty.” Percy explained, talking as if to a child. “I was hoping you could help them see the error of their ways.”

And like that, it seemed as if something in the minion's psyche had flipped. Her happy rumbling had become menacing, the lava within a hundred yards boiling with her anger. Fire flicked between her teeth and her eyes had become those of a predator.

All innocence had been lost.

She stepped back, looking at Percy before she finally spoke, one of the few sentences she knew and remembered. Her voice was a great rumbling sound, dark as the deepest pits of hell. The entirety of Hell itself shook with her utterance of three words.

“For the Overlord...”
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Hell and the demon pet of the Overlord

choices: Rough seas for Clarisse and Co.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy watched as the last of the Brown minions scrambled to join the crowd below the dais he stood upon.

In the span of two years, he had acquired enough life force for this army, this horde of his.

Merely one of four factions, and it was the most numerous by far. Forty thousand strong, and always on the rise.

It was more than overkill for the situation. Eres had not been wrong about that. Not even a quarter of them would be needed for this, to be perfectly honest.

Putting Giblet out in the field would further reduce that number, the forge mistress being the physically strongest minion, more powerful than Ember. With reckless abandon, the eldest of the minions could level the entire city herself without breaking a sweat, pull down a fortress with ease.

Placing Ember with Giblet would reduce it to a few teams. The two seemed to have worked together in the past, it seemed, as part of a specialized team, if the info Eres dug up was to be believed, and could deal some nasty damage that would change the landscape.

Adding Morticia to the mix was tantamount to genocide. The Blue Reaper, as she was known, was no slouch in battle, be it magical or physical, the latter unusual among the Blue minion tribe.

Speaking of the three minion leaders, they had joined Percy up on the dais.

Morticia was standing, looking at something only she could see with an empty gaze. Her robe, different from her sisters in that it was black instead of blue, with bones sown in at random places. It was tattered, but not exactly falling apart.

Her eyes, the lavender depths dulled, almost lifeless, had bags under them. Her skin was a ghostly pale, not unlike those of the undead soldiers Clarisse currently had at her command. But, where their skin was fake, an illusion, Morticia's was real. In one were to touch it, other than Percy, they would feel the warmth drained from their bodies.

Arcane energies seeped from her feet in an ever present mist, a fog that made it look like she was floating above the ground, an ethereal specter come to claim their souls.

She also sported a mask, carved from the skull of Gnarl. A testament of her loyalty for her Overlord. It was held in one hand for the moment, the other hand holding a scythe that stood taller than Percy.

The pole was a darkened wood, with innumerable small notches carved into it, like a tally of some kind. It was sturdy, enchanted heavily to ward off decay, termites, water and physical blows.

The blade of the weapon, which had a reach of three and two-thirds feet, gleamed in the light of the assembly hall. It was made entirely of iron, with a coating of silver around the edge of the blade to deal with otherworldly monsters that could not be killed with steel alone. It was polished, almost as if religiously, with not a drop of blood staining it. The edge of the blade itself had been carefully maintained, by hand, with a whetstone that Morticia carried around in a small satchel.

Also inside the satchel were various bones, tiny pouches of ingredients for potions that allowed her to maintain her stamina during a heated battle, or round of bedroom activities, and a purse that held not coins, but souls.

As the most powerful Blue minion, Morticia was a powerful necromancer. She was the only minion besides Ember that went into the Infernal Abyss on a regular basis. She could use souls in her magic, unlike any other Blue, and rarely used anything but her dark arts and the abilities afforded to her from her connection with her Overlord.

She had little need of anything else.

Yes, in all of the Blue minion tribe, Morticia was the most powerful in the arts regarding death. While it had been difficult for the first few years, she was becoming increasingly competent in her new station, with her new body and powers.

Giblet stood on her left, separating the Minion Minion mistress from the demonic beast known as Ember. While the undead blue disliked being in close proximity to the walking inferno, who was causing the stone around her to melt in her current state of anger, Giblet felt right at home.

The Forge Mistress, and head of the Brown Minion tribe, was idly swinging her beloved hammer back and forth, wishing she could go back to making all sorts of little trinkets and baubles. It had been a slow few months for her, since her Overlord had required so little of her expertise.

She also wished he would bring the cyclops back to help in the forge.

Not that she didn't work fine on her own, but the times her master had helped, or needed help, with forging were few and far between. It was nice to have someone who could appreciate the craft on a professional level to work with though.

Having worked the forge for... how long had it been?

Giblet stopped swinging her hammer, devoting all her mental power to trying to remember how long she had worked the forge.

At least... twelve years?

Ah well, it wasn't important. She liked her job. Given her strength, she was on the reserves of the minions, always in the tower in case there happened to be a little home-invasion problem.

Be it rats or 'heroes'.

Blegh, the word left a nasty taste on her tongue. While she could grasp that she wasn't the sharpest blade in the halfling, she knew how much grief had been caused for all her previous masters, and how much her current one disliked the word.

Giblet started to swing her arms back and forth again, looking around the cavern for no real reason. There were no shinnies to be found in the stone, no metals for her to tinker with. She knew this perfectly well.

The Forge Mistress stood at six foot three inches in height. She wore a light cotton shirt, permanently smudged with soot and ash and sweat, on her upper body. Atop that was a blacksmiths apron, reaching down to her knees. On her lower body she wore a crude rendition of shorts, made from cloth and tied with a leather belt around her waist.

Atop her head, she wore a welder's mask, something Percy was quite baffled at, since it seemed she had it around for a very long time judging by the slight warp and the patchwork she had made on it.

Her skin was, appropriately enough, browned from her long years at the forge. A few small patches of skin, one of which happened to be on her foot, were of new, untanned skin, due to accidents that ended up with molten metal on her.

Not that it was more than an inconvenience to her. She had taken worse injuries when she had been out in the field, such as the time she had lost three-quarters of her right hand. Thankfully, some Blue minions had been able to fix her right up.

And the time she had been set on fire by a dwarven mechanism...

Shot with an arrow...

Been run through with a spear...

The sheer amount of cuts she received from blades, broken legs from trolls and other large creatures...

The list went on. And for it all, she had gained incredible defense to near-almost anything.

'Cept poison...

And magic...

And acid...

Okay, so maybe she hadn't gained a defense for almost everything.

But that didn't mean she wasn't sturdy though!

Yes, Giblet was probably the toughest minion, save the essentially immortal Morticia. And, outside her skill at the forge and immense strength, she had little else that deemed her 'special' from the other Brown minions.

But that was fine with her.

After all, when you were as strong as her, as skilled at metalworking as her, could handle pain as well as her, you really didn't want anything else.

Ember was to the far left of the Dais, the stone around her melted, leaving her to sink a few inches every couple of minutes.

The flames around her were whirling around, frenzied. She hissed, her chest rumbling with her displeasure. She wanted to go out and destroy those who would disobey the Overlord, not sit here and wait!

But, the Overlord had commanded her to wait, saying that soon she would be able to teach them all a lesson. He asked her to strain a resource that she had very little of for any other than him.

Patience.

Flames leaped from her tongue as she ground her teeth, her claws ready to be like the blood-soaked daggers in her mouth.

All three snapped to attention, as much as any of them could, when Percy cleared his throat.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Little intro for two of the tribe leaders

choices: Watch the battle from afar, with commentary from Eres and Millicent
Up close and personal, with a bit of commentary from the rebels
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“I'm glad all of you could make it.” Percy said, his voice echoing throughout the cavern. “It seems we have a bit of a situation on our hands. One that, while I'm sure most of you are unneeded to solve, I want to make myself perfectly clear on my position.”

The minions were silent, all focusing on the Overlord.

“It seems that some people are unhappy with my decision. As it was, I gave the more powerful magic-users time to think on alternate solutions while they were being moved through the pathways. They could not offer one that I felt would work well enough. And so, I feel that I am doing what is better for the people. But they don't like that.”

A dark mass started to form at his feet, swirling around him as it rose.

“While I anticipated that they would not wholeheartedly except my course of action, I had not anticipated how much they would defy this action. While I had expected outcry, I had not expected rebellion. While I would have forgave damnation and hatred...”

He paused, his eyes flashing in anger. The dark mass had risen to his chest, forming a solid curtain that obscured his body.

“I will not forgive this traitorous action!” He roared, the assembly hall vibrating. His voice had grown deeper, and his mouth was set in a snarl.

“I brought them here, offering them my protection from whatever may have befallen them! I promised fertile lands for farming, so that they would not go hungry! I had promised that all previous crimes they may have committed would be ignored if they obeyed my law!”

The dark mass was above his head, fully enclosing him in a pillar of darkness, the light of his eyes the only thing visible.

“I had promised them that I would refrain from using my power, be it as creator of this world or as the Harem God, on the people in the city! I have had all of you help them, be it healing the sick or building their houses! And this is how they repay me? Repay us?”

The dark mass was dispersing, two lights joining that of his eyes, around the spot his hands would be.

“Right now, they are making a pitiful attempt to lay siege to the tower! They have used precious resources to aid their childish actions!”

The curtain of darkness was gone, revealing the armor-clad form of Perseus. The eye-like gems on the back of his gauntlets were looking around wildly, sucking in the light.

Wanting to feed...

“We will not stand for this! Blood shall be spilled this day!”

The minions were getting giddy now. Excited murmurs and fidgeting born of anticipation spread throughout the crowd.

Giblet was now hopping up and down, her eyes alight.

Morticia's eyes seemed to focus a bit, the hand that held the mask raising it slowly to her face.

Ember gnashed her teeth, her tail into the ground as she climbed out of the magma puddle, paying no mind to the super heated rock around her.

“We shall unleash Hell upon these traitorous curs! Let the dogs of war gnash at their throats!” He said, getting a roar of agreement from the crowd. “This shall be a warning to all who come after! No one betrays the Overlord!”

All the minions were cheering, whoops and cries of excitement echoing, not just within the cave, not just within the underground...

~

“No one betrays the Overlord!”

The very foundations upon which the tower stood shook, and not from the fifth or sixth volley of giant boulders.

Millicent was on the balcony at the top of the tower, watching as the rebels took out their frustration over nothing on the tower gardens. They weren't doing much else with the artillery.

“It seems he won't take this sitting down.” Eres said with a sigh, floating next to the girl. “Nor will he take this at all.”

Millicent said nothing, only focusing on her thoughts.

It would be so much easier to control them. Take away their free will, or break it. Either one would have worked. Otherwise, things like this would happen.

If they showed signs of growing a spine, break it. Tear it out, throw it on the ground and crush it beneath your heel, leaving them to weep as they did as ordered.

She had seen it happen in Nordburg. Though, it was the women who did it to the men, and it was over something as little as an extra helping of seal, or even imaginary things such as a woman thinking that their man had cheated on them without having any reason to be suspicious.

Or, what they tried to do to her, for a while. Before they were forced to abandon that prospect.

“Though, I shouldn't be surprised. After that incident with those seven, he seems to detest betrayal to an insane degree. It was his personal quest for a while to kill them, or in Jewel's case capture, instead of conquer the lands.”

She sighed again, though this time it was a wistful sigh.

“Still, seeing him about to unleash hell upon these rebels has got me more then a little excited.” She said with a smirk. “I can't wait for him to come back. Drenched in blood, excess energy to burn off... possibly twenty or so minions that he'll want to bring to bed...”

Millicent glared at the woman. Was pleasure of the fle... whatever she was, all she thought about?

It seemed so to her. Every time she had been around the woman, she had mentioned sex in some form or another.

“Just be quiet.” Millicent growled, moving a few steps away.

“Now, now. Don't be like that.” Eres said with a grin. “Why, I'll bet that when you've grown, you'll have to stab the suitors with all manner of sharp sticks to keep them away.”

“Not likely.”

'Well, she's probably right, but not for the reasons she's probably thinking of.' The apparition thought, looking at the Overlord's daughter from the corner of her eye. “Anyway, the massacre about to occur should be a delight to behold.”

“Not that I can see much.” Millicent mumbled. Her eyesight may have been beyond human, but even she couldn't see more then a mass of people, almost a blob, from the distance.

The wind whipped around the tower, clouds that had already looked like they would rain letting loose their deluge.

More than should have been normal, really.

“Oh my. It seems everything is going against these rebels.” Eres mocked, the carnage about to unfold making her quiver with excitement.

Lightning flickered across the sky, striking the ground.

“Oh, what a wonderful spec... Wait.” Eres stopped her short-lived clapping of joy. “He hasn't gained power over lightning, not even here. And something else seems-”

Another bolt of lightning flashed, Eres's eyes narrowing.

It wasn't coming down...

It was going up.

“It seems that we may have a naughty little mage in our-”

Two more bolts of lightning went up into the clouds, as if trying to disperse them.

And it was working, as a hole started to form where the bolts struck.

“Make it three, possibly four.” She mused. 'Perseus, we may have a problem.'

'What now?' He growled out mentally.

'Mages. Three or four of them. They're trying to disperse the clouds you called.'

'I didn't call any damned clouds. Must have naturally formed. As for the mages, I know how to handle them. Never again shall they think to defy me, or question my power.' He bit out. 'Morticia! I have a special job for y-'

With that, the link was cut, and Eres was left to silence as she watched several boulders sail through the sky again.

“Well, that explains how they were able to obtain this much ammunition, as well as hide these things.”

~

“I want the wolf-riders to mount up! We're hitting them with everything we've got!” Percy barked, sending a hundred or so Minions scrambling out of the cavern. “Everyone else head to the armory! Gear for heavy battle! I want these people kneeling before me, be it chains or in death! Gabby!”

A minion, near the front of the crowd, ran up and knelt before the dais. She was dirty, and a miner's cap was on her head with a pickaxe clutched in her hand.

“Yes Master!”

“I want you to get started digging tunnels behind their lines. I want them confused, scared and panicking. You can have a team of forty to help you. There are extra picks in the armory for them to use. Make them big enough for the wolf-riders to get through as well.”

“As you wish it!” Gabby, the second in command of the brown tribe said before she quickly ran into the crowd to pick out decent minions that could help her.

Percy watched as the crowd was becoming a surging mass of chaos as they scrambled to fulfill his orders, happy cries and shouts of joy

Exactly what the minions were made for.

He turned to the three tribe leaders.

“You three are sticking with me until we get into the thick of i-”

'Perseus, we may have a problem.'

This day was growing more and more irksome by the second.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Assembly, stowaways, and gearing up

choices: Skip to after, with a few hundred people, at most, kneeling in chains, beaten
Show a few more scenes, like a word montage or something
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“I swear, I heard something a little bit ago!” A man exclaimed, dressed in slightly dented armor that he looked unused to wearing. It was obvious the man was not a soldier of any kind.

“You're just hearing things. Stress about this whole mess must be getting to you.” Another man said, taking a sip of water from the river. “C'mon, we got to get back and get ready in case something happens.”

“I still don't understand why we're doing this.” A third said, a youth that was only just starting to grow facial hair. “It seems a fool's errand to fight the king and his forces.

“Quiet, boy.” The second man said. “It's the principle of it all. We won't be run out of our homes at the whims of anybody, king or god, and not for eight years either! Besides, if the king is so great, he should be ab-”

Suddenly, the sounds of earth being moved, great amounts of it, filled the air. The sounds of women shouting accompanied it.

“Ta-da!” One woman cried, poking her head above ground.

“It's one of them!” The boy cried. Even dirtied as she was, there was no mistaking one of the minions.

“Kill it then! He must be making his move now! Hurry, back to the others!”

However, as the man stepped forward, unsheathing his sword, he felt something give in the ground beneath him.

The man didn't even have time to scream as he fell down, sending the minion under the earth toppling over.

He shook his head, looking down before he quickly recoiled. Women they may have looked like, but he didn't like them. He wanted to be as far away as he could from them whenever possible.

“Looksies at what we got here.” Another voice said, accompanied by the sound of a wolf growling.

The man looked up, and the last thing he saw was the fangs of a wolf as it bit down on his head.

“Bad wolfy! Master said offer chance at surr... sirre... sar- giving up.” The minion riding the Wolf said, giving it a stern look. “Oh well. Master also said never waste food so... num nums!” The minion said, mood turning completely around. “But get outta everyone's way first.”

The wolf wasted no time, picking up its meal and walking up to the hole before climbing out.

Around the remaining men, holes were opening up in the ground, large enough to let two oxen pass side by side with their handler between them, though that would be a bit of a tight squeeze. Giant wolves, taller than a full-grown man, were climbing up out of them, one having the now headless corpse of their squad mate.

The younger of the two couldn't help it, upon seeing the corpse of man, with blood dripping from the large animal's jaws, he retched. The sounds of crunching bone probably didn't help.

The elder tried to unsheathe his sword, doing so in a clumsy way that made a few minions laugh before he found a spear at his throat.

“I-I'm sorry! I give, I give!” He cried, throwing down his sword.

“Aww.” Several minions groaned in disappointment. They were really looking forward to more bloodshed, or at least a good fight.

“Okay!” Gabby called, pulling herself up from a hole as more minions, on foot like her, did the same. “Digging team is heading back once everyone is clear!”

“Gabby!” A mounted minion called. “This guy says he gives up!” She said, pointing at the man who threw down his weapon, making an awful sound as he shook in his armor.

“Spoil sport!” Another minion called, pouting as she scratched her wolf behind the ears, cooing softly about how he would get a nice chew toy that day.

“He did, did he?” She asked. Well, that was fast. “Well, somebody tie him up then! Master said he wanted everybody that's going against him kneeling before him in chains!”

“Or death!” A foot soldier called, climbing out of a large hole.

“Right! Or death!” She called, walking over to the young man. “And what about him?”

“Dunno.” A minion close to her shrugged. “Too sick to talk.”

“Aww, poor little baby.” Gabby mockingly cooed as she stepped next to him, not minding the bile that was splashed all over the ground.

She grabbed him by the shirt, effortlessly picking him up so his pale face was looking her in the eye.

“So, what do you say?” She asked, smiling a little too wide at him. “Give up?”

The boy shook harder, seeing those sharp teeth so close to him.

Losing her patience real quickly, Gabby shook him, grinning even wider. “Do. You. Give. Up?” She asked, a growl becoming more obvious with each word.

This was it. He was going to die. Why had he joined this stupid rebellion?

“Fine.” Gabby growled out, her smile never leaving her face.

Without so much a second's hesitation, Gabby tossed the boy, as effortlessly as she had picked him up, to the side.

Right into the waiting maw of another wolf.

A brown walked over, ignoring the sounds of crunching, almost wondering if she should steal an arm. The wolf wouldn't miss something so small, would it? Besides, the arm was tasty. Not as tasty as, say, the stomach or liver, but still good.

Deciding that it was a possibility for later, the minion picked something up from the ground that lay just underneath the wolf's mouth in a puddle of blood.

A small brown orb.

Life force, what minions were created from.

“Give that here.” Gabby said, smacking the minion out of the trance the shiny orb caused the minion to enter as she grabbed said orb. “I'll give that to the master.”

“We got another one!” A foot soldier said, climbing out of the earth with another orb in her hand.

“Ooh! Ooh! I'll take it!” Another minion said, bouncing up and down with a pick in her hand. “Master will be so happy!”

Upon those words, it dawned on the minions, those that would be heading back anyway, that Percy loved it when they brought back the minion making energy during times of battle.

And, as all devoted minion did...

They started to fight for it.

Biting, clawing, pulling hair, knocking out teeth, attempts to break bones or feed to wolves... They did it all. The poor soldier who held it was swarmed, being tackled back into the opening in the earth with more minions following the first group, ending in a giant pile of squirming bodies as they attempted to grasp the ethereal object that would grant them their Overlord's favor.

Among the sheer amount of brown minions there were, it was a dog-fight-dog world to rise above the regular rank-and-file. Not to say that there was bad blood in the tribe. It was more of a healthy competition to keep things interesting.

“Come on, enough of that.” Gabby said, not really angry or irritated. “Master's waiting for us. Now, Move it!”

~

Screams echoed down the streets of the city, making those who had not taken part in the rebellion, but had not yet left, cower in their homes.

Some wept for those they knew, friends or family, that had entered into this suicidal endeavor.

Houses burned, and blood ran through the streets as the minions cut down the rebels that would not surrender. Those that gave up upon seeing the horde were treated little better, wrapped in chains and rope as they were tossed, most times literally, to the side like trash to wait until they were brought before the king.

The minions cried out, happy with the slaughter and wanton destruction. The ripped down doors, broke the bones of the rebels, bathed in the blood of the fallen.

Morticia was among the horde, but her objective was different. While she did not hesitate to cut down anyone who stood in her path, whether or not they surrendered, she paid little attention. Her orders were to head out of the city and raise an army. She collected any and all souls she came across, heeding not if they were traitors or an unfortunate innocent who had tried to flee the city at the wrong time, to help her along with this endeavor.

Giblet was in the gardens of the tower, grumbling about how these rebels were making extra work for her so she couldn't join in on the slaughter. She was picking up the boulders, a little troublesome even for her because the rock was incredibly dense, therefore much heavier then it appeared. Still, she did manage to lift the blatant misuse of earth and, with a little help from Ember to balance the, now incredibly hot, rocks, toss them out of the city.

There was one reason Ember was not incinerating a path through the city right now, and it was because Percy wanted to keep the destruction in the city to a minimum. The mess a minion horde caused would be far simple to clean up then the mess Ember would make if she was let completely loose.

Outside the city though...

Well, I'm sure you get the idea.

As for Percy himself, he was back up in the tower, standing with Eres and Millicent as he decided on which weapon he should use.

Riptide was out, since he wanted people to remember these people for ages, whisper about their foolish actions.

He wasn't keen on the giant mace that he used during the monster attack on the camp. He absently made a side note to himself to think of a name for the weapon.

His gauntlets already had something planned for their feast, but it wouldn't hurt to allow them to feed more. The hand washing would be a bitch though, since Percy would not allow anyone else to touch one of the single most powerful items at his disposal without them being securely on his hands.

Thinking on this, Percy also made note that he really needed to expand his own repertoire of weapons and abilities, as well as train those he already had.

Well, that was another thing for this training trip, he supposed.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Munchies and weapon decisions.

choices: The horde crawls out of the city, descending on the opposition
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Perseus, I'm getting reports from the minions that the city is back under control.” Eres said, making Percy look up.

“You say that as if it was ever out from my control.” He said. “Though it seems I may have missed out on all the fun.”

“Yes, a shame that.” Eres said, feeling that her hope of a blood-soaked Percy was slipping away slowly. “But, there are still people outside the city that you can slaughter.”

“Good.” Percy said, nodding as he cast his eyes over the burning city beneath him. “Send out some green minions to gather up those who surrendered and all the life force. Will Gabby and her crew be back soon?”

“It should be a few more minutes. After all, they don't have to dig back this way.” Eres said, mentally ordering about four hundred or so green minions to go look for captives and gather what would in the near future be their sisters.

Percy nodded slowly, turning to Millicent. “What do you think of this?” He asked, genuinely curious as to what his daughter thought of it all.

She grunted, crossing her arms as she glared at both him and Eres. “I don't know. I couldn't see much. It's too far for me to see clearly.”

“Really?” He asked, looking at Eres from the side of his eye. “Anyway, that wasn't what I meant. I was asking what you think should be done with these traitors. Those that live, anyway.”

“Kill them.” Millicent said without a moments hesitation. “People who act like this don't get second chances. Better to make them rot in the ground then let them try something like this again.”

It was something he'd considered. It wouldn't even be a waste of human resources, since Morticia could always raise them back up as undead workers. In fact, it would be beneficial to do so as it would remove the need to waste food on these ingrates.

Yes, very tempting.

“Or, You could break their minds.” Millicent continued. “Rip out their spines and make sure they never grow back. But killing them would be so much more satisfying.”

“I love the way she thinks.” Eres commented, a grin plastered on her face as the energy that made up her body roiled around in a manner that seemed like a silent laughter.

Millicent seemed a little disgusted by that fact.

“Giblet dear! We have another volley incoming!” Eres called down, the scream of rage that drifted up making her chuckle.

She wasn't lying either. The last volley that they would make was flying through the air.

“Stupid!” Giblet yelled, hefting a boulder onto her shoulders.

“Mean!” She roared, lifting the boulder above her head, digging her fingers in deep.

“Bastards!” She cried, rearing back and heaving the giant rock through the air with all her might.

“Giblet just wants to have some slaughtering fun!” She yelled as she dug her claws into the next boulder.

With nothing more then a cry of rage, Giblet threw that one as well, her muscles straining her shirt as she worked them in a fit of blind anger.

The first boulder she threw hit the opposing projectile, the one that was roughly in the middle. They collided with such force that the kinetic energy behind the two caused both rocks to completely shatter, the remaining energies creating a shock wave that sent the other boulders that were heading to the tower to the sides, going wide of the tower and likely to hit the town.

The second rock she threw went through the falling debris, well over the city walls.

Percy took pleasure from the screams as one of the catapults was crushed as the rock landed on it. People scrambled to run from the giant siege weapon, from the threat of being crushed beneath either the falling contraption or the boulder itself.

Now, mind that these boulders were not small either. These were easily larger then an elephant, and had they been normal rocks would have weighed several tonnes. These rocks had been magically condensed to that point, making them multitudes heavier then they would appear to be.

When that boulder hit, it sunk into the ground, sending a lot of people into the air who would not survive the impact.

Percy chuckled darkly as he listened to Giblet descend into a frenzied string of curses as she began to hurl boulders haphazardly, fueled by her anger.

“I'm so glad I had the earth that the city was built on packed to the point where things like these boulders wouldn't leave too much of a dent.” Percy said before his eyes looked at the other catapults. “Well, there's no reason to let so much rain go unused.”

Lifting his hand towards the weapons, Percy made a tight fist in the air above them.

The rain that was falling slowed before stopping, hanging in the air. Soon enough, it was flying back to the heavens, collecting above the war machines. All the water that pooled in the streets of the city, the barrels and the gutters joined with the large mass of water. Even that water that was soaking the ground returned from whence it came, rising from the ground like snakes before rising into the sky.

Satisfied, Percy spread the water evenly into five different spheres, moving them above the catapults.

“You should really stop with the theatrics, you know.” Eres lightly chided him.

“Fine.”

Commanding the water, Percy formed five fists in the air, hanging menacingly.

More screams filled the air from beyond the city walls, and Percy drank it all in.

Feeling that he was starting to let this go on for too long, Percy brought his fist down into his other hand with a loud smack.

He wasn't very surprised when four of the five watery fists were destroyed by lightning, the large amounts of water falling uselessly to the ground without his power.

“Must be halfway decent mages.” Percy evaluated. “Even as low power as that was, I doubt a novice could have done as much.”

Still, one of the catapults did suffer destruction, with a little less damage to the area than Giblet's retaliation caused.

“I'll be taking control now, Eres. Try and make something so Millicent can watch this.”

'Morticia, are you ready?' Percy asked the devoted necromancer mentally.

'Almost, my Lord. All that is needed is to give the word and these cretins will know fear.'

'And the wolf-riders?'

'Yeah, yeah! All ready Master!'

'Good. Ember, Giblet! Get ready to go. Forget anything left in the gardens.'

A shout of joy reached his ears, coming from the bottom of the tower.

'I want all browns in the city to move to the north district! Morticia, raise the army in five minutes!'

With that, Percy stepped through space to appear in the garden, absently calling some water from the kitchens to put out the fires caused by Ember's mere presence.

He grabbed Giblet first, pulling her close as he vanished, reappearing several yards away to grab the embodiment of fire.

Again, they vanished, appearing half a quarter of a mile west of the enemy.

“You know what to do, right Ember?”

A grunt and nod was all the response he got, and needed.

“Good.”

Dropping the red minion off there to do what he had laid out for her in incredibly simple details that even she would be able to understand, Percy stepped back into the city via the shadow Giblet cast.

How he managed to pull someone through their own shadow is best left unexplained.

“I don't like this.” A man said, looking to his three companions. “You'd think that he'd have been serious about taking out the catapults. I don't doubt that he could, if what some of the people say about him is true.”

“It's true alright.” Another said, shaking his head. “He's toying with us, it would seem.”

“I've heard tales he doesn't take betrayal well. Something about some companions of his in the past.” A third proclaimed with a sigh. “I still feel like something's not right though...”

“Don't be so depressed!” The fourth and final member of the group exclaimed, their voice betraying their energy. “If we can show him that we can work together, he'll have to acknowledge that our magic is no different.”

“That's right, my dear.” A fifth voice said, but not from anywhere specific. It seemed to surround them, an all-encompassing presence. “And people like the king only respect strength. You will likely have to fight him with your combined might. But, I'm sure you four will be able to convince him that his ban on mixing magics is foolish, though not misplaced in heart.”

“I guess.” The third voice spoke, rubbing the back of their head with a sigh. “But, did we have to incite rebellion?”

“Unfortunately, there was no other way. If you tried this before hand, the king would have stopped you all, and likely put you to death. If there is one thing about the king, it's that he wants to keep the people safe. A little heavy-handed in his ways, yes, but he knows that people aren't as durable as him. I doubt he will do anything... drastic, in response to this little uprising.”

“Besides, everybody was high strung with the news that they'd have to leave for a little while. It isn't easy to pack up on the fly if you don't have magic.” The fourth voice chimed in. “The king shouldn't hurt anybody, at least not too much, for this little bit of stress relief.”

“Yes. The king can be a compassionate fellow. He should be able to look past this incident, if he is as powerful as some people can proclaim.” The first voice said, nodding.

“I hope so. I just hope that no one in the town got hurt by that last volley.” The second voice said, concern thick in their tone.

“Fear not. I watched as the king himself destroyed the artillery before it destroyed any buildings.” The fifth voice proclaimed. “Now, I believe you should take care of the troops, call them from the catapults. They will be of little use now that you have his attention. Calm those who are panicked, tend to those injured by the destruction of the two catapults. He'll be here soon.”

With that, the voice faded, and an aura that no one noticed permeating the air went with it.

The third mage shook his head, like clearing away sleep. “I suppose I should go see if there are any survivors from the catapults, or if they need help pulling people from the wreckage. I doubt that there are many though. Anyone who was caught beneath them is surely dead.”

“Right.” The first one said, nodding. “You,” They pointed at the second mage. “Go with him to help. We'll stay here and prepare for whatever may come and try to slow the king down, and hopefully impress him with our magic.”

Nodding, the group split up, off to do their jobs.

“Still,” The third mage sighed. “I can't help but thinks something's very wrong here.”
