1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy slowly phased back into existence, coughing and sputtering. His body was burnt, charred by the unstable energies of those four imbeciles.

“Damn,” He choked out. “That was worse then I thought. Barely managed to get it out of here in time.”

Standing up, gritting whatever teeth he had left in pain, He looked around.

Suffice to say, his body looked like it was in better shape.

The area around him, where he had taken the brunt of the magical attack, was reduced to... something. It was more then the nothingness of the void, but only just. It seemed to be pure primordial energy, twisting and convulsing and screaming and crying and living and dying and doing neither at the same time...

“I think I'm going to be sick.” He muttered, coughing again. “Okay, got it. Mixing of unstable energies that were never made to interact equals something that can't be said to exist or not. Fan-fucking-tastic. Now I've got clean this up and figure out what to do with the abomination against life, non-life and oblivion.”

'Perseus! You're alive!' Eres yelled in his head, making it hurt worse than having it split into eight parts by an ax.

'No need to shout.' He told her. 'How long was I gone?'

'Three hours.' The ghost said. 'What happened?'

'I don't want to talk about it. It'd be too difficult to explain anyway.' Percy dropped to one knee, his hand almost falling in the anathema to both non-existence and all creation. 'Just know that I hurt, and I feel like I'm going to be sick. Hell, this feels worse then the time I suffered from an overabundance of godly energy in a weak body and nearly exploded.'

Struggling to stand back up, Percy shook his head. 'Is the entire area clear?'

'Yes. Once the magics started to combine, I called all the minions back. Morticia was against it, but before she could do anything, both you and the resulting energy were gone. Did something happen there? Do you need any assistance?'

'Don't send anyone here. There's... something here. I don't like it, and I don't want anyone to touch it. It seems like some type of energy, but it's like a liquid and a solid at the same time, and it's doing some things that energy can't do. I can't say that it's alive, or even if it exists. In fact, looking at it is making me feel worse...'

'Can you make it back alright? You sound horrible.'

'Yeah... Yeah, I think so. I just gotta find out what happened to those four idiots first.'

Percy got the image of Eres frowning, shaking her head in exasperation. 'Fine. Just don't do anything stupid, alright?'

Eres cut off the link, sighing with both irritation and relief. “He's safe, at least. I really shouldn't have expected anything else, but even still...”

'Of course you shouldn't have.'

“Shut up, book. These last few hours have put me in a foul mood.” The apparition growled out as the ancient book lay on a table.

The book merely chuckled, though it had no real warmth. 'The marked one is too powerful to die. Even if he could be killed so easily, he'd be too stubborn to stay dead. He'd fight his way back from the void if he had to.'

“And what would you have done if he hadn't survived?”

'That doesn't matter in the slightest now, so I see no point in bringing it up.' The Eronomicon replied. 'Besides, both of us would have known something was wrong, even if you couldn't contact him for the past few hours.'

“Sometimes I wish I never found you, you aggravating pile of parchment.” She bit out.

'And you should not have tried your luck when you did.' It countered. 'But I will not bother bringing up `what if's` with you. For a being such as myself or the Marked one, things like that have little consequence.'

“I don't have time to deal with you right now, you tattered old tome. Perseus will likely want reports about everything. Damage to the country side, the stability of the universe, the pathways... not to mention the amount of prisoners we have collected, any loss or addition of minions...”

“And his daughter.” A third voice said suddenly.

“Wha-” Eres turned around to see who had entered the master bedroom, her eyes widening.

~

Percy slowly made his way away from ground zero, taking small steps in the air over the primordial whatever it was. It wasn't exactly energy, but it wasn't some kind of slime or ooze or what have you.

It just was.

And Percy did not want to touch it, at all.

Hell, he didn't even want to look at it.

Occasionally, the stuff seemed like it would reach out for him, almost seeming alive, but in a way that not even he felt he could describe.

But, alas, he had to stomach looking at it even as his stomach churned at the sheer wrongness of the stuff.

He had seen the very essence, or lack thereof, of nothing itself! He had traveled it, fought it, and carved out this universe!

But this? This strange result of magical energies mixing together when they had not been created with the chance that they might ever come into contact in the infinite possibilities of the multiverse?

Well, there were really no words for it.

“I'm beginning to think that those four didn't survive.” Percy muttered. “Damned shame. I was hoping that whatever happened to them would at least leave remains so I could show people what happens when you don't think the important things, like mixing unstable energies, through.”

“Guaahgh...”

“The hell?” Percy asked, hearing the pitiful cry. It was distorted, and it sounded like several people were making the same noise together in some mangled fashion.

Following the cries, He found himself at the edge of the affected area.

A tree that was unstable, likely having been partially uprooted by whatever shock wave occurred in the magical explosion, fell over and landed in the primordial energy.

As soon as the branches touched the stuff, the sound of a high-pitched whine filled the air, accompanied by a... a sizzling sound, he guessed.

The branches seemed to become distorted, warping and dying before they seemed to just fall apart, disintegrated.

“Really don't want to touch that stuff now.” Percy muttered. “And I have to get it out of this universe. I'm sure I could find a dead one to place it in.”

He paused, a thought coming to mind.

“Why isn't it going through the earth?”

As if to taunt him, the energy-like stuff started to spread out slowly, the earth disappearing slowly.

“When am I going to learn to keep my mouth shut?” Percy groaned. 'Eres, we need to evacuate! I want the civilians taken through one of the pathways under the tower!'

He waited, but did not get the response he usually got.

'Eres? Are you listening?'

Sighing, he gave up trying to call out to the tower heart's artificial personification.

“Great.” He mumbled. “What else could go wrong?”

Without another word, he called out to the Eronomicon. As expected, the tome appeared in a flash of light in his hand.

“Finally, something that's normal.”

'Marked one, there is trouble at the tower.' The tome said, as calm as ever.

“Of course there is.” Percy bit out. “There's trouble here too. We need to get everyone out of the universe. And right now, I feel like crap. I doubt I could make it to the city on my own power. Anyway, what's the problem over there?”

'It seems that the reason behind all this is because of a demon.' The tome explained. 'Given it's form, I would have to say it is a demon of stupidity, rash actions and stubbornness.'

“You've got to be kidding.” Percy muttered.

'Unfortunately not. It seemed to have caused Eres to go into a catatonic state, though I don't exactly know how.'

“Great, just...” Percy coughed again, interrupting himself. “Anything else I have to deal with right now?”

'As far as I know, no.'

“Rhetorical question. Look, I want you to see if you can find whatever is making that sound and bring it to me if possible. If its not safe to touch, just leave it and come back to me. Don't touch the stuff that's eating away the world either.”

'As you wish, Marked One.' It said, floating out of his hand. 'Do you wish for me to give a little bit of my energy to you? I have a surplus, though not much.'

“Yeah, that'd be nice. Anything you can spare without losing your own power would work.”

'Very well.'

Wisps of pink energy seeped from the tome, connecting to Percy. They throbbed, like the beating of a heart, for a few moments.

Percy could feel the pain lessening, his skin healing as he finally coughed out the last bit of the foreign particles in his lungs. His head felt better, and he could now focus on the things around him.

Though, still looking at the energy-like stuff beneath him, which was now starting to reach out into the air randomly, made him feel sick.

The tendrils of energy fell back, merging with the tome once more. It didn't droop in its flight, showing that it followed Percy's order to the letter.

“Thanks.” Percy said. “I think I can make it back to the city now, and deal with whatever problems are waiting for me. You have ten minutes. I doubt whatever I'm looking for will survive longer then that.”

'Of course, marked one.'

With that, the tome turned around and floated off, easily avoiding the mass that reached up near it.

Shaking his head, Percy stepped backwards, the view around him blurring as the landscape beneath him changed rapidly.

It just went to show how badly he was weakened. He was just on the outskirts of the city, and not instantly in the tower like he wished to be. Like he could have easily done before.

Taking a few more steps, he was at the base of the tower.

And what he saw nearly drove him blind with rage.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
He held back though...

Barely.

The grounds outside the tower were stained red, decorations of flesh and organs hanging from the trees like a party for demons.

Minions... His minions...

Dead.

Whatever had done this was powerful. No signs of a fight, just a slaughter.

Percy's eyes hardened as he turned his head to look up at the tower.

Whatever was in there, be it a demon, or something else entirely, would pay.

They would pay so very dearly.

It passed over the surface of his thoughts that they might have done something to Eres, and all the heavens forbid, his daughter. He couldn't dwell on those thoughts though. Not if he wanted to keep his wits about him.

Walking through the tower, Percy was completely silent. The entire tower reflected that.

He finally stopped in front of the door to the main hall, which served as mainly the throne room and the meeting hall.

He could feel something on the other side, in the back.

It was a presence that tried to cloud his mind, cloud his senses. It tried to make him barge in, losing what little self-preservation he had being immortal. And that self-preservation was reserved for dealing with the void and other things that could kill gods.

Growling filled the air as Percy pulsed his power, destroying the feeling before it had a chance to latch onto him.

It was quickly back, however, pressing against his mind once more.

That was a testimony to the being behind the presence. Most others would have quailed in fear, reigning in their aura to avoid his wrath. Even if they couldn't, as some beings were burdened with, the aura itself would be hesitant to touch him, if they were not suppressed or outright destroyed by his power lashing out at them.

He had learned about it over a year ago during one of his first encounters with demons. They were demons whose very presence compelled those with weak wills to be influenced by the demons sphere of control. Lust, gluttony, envy, pride, and yes, even something as outlandish as stupidity.

Not very strange in the grand scheme of things, really; just look at beings like C'thulu.

Actually, don't. Not very good for the mind, unless you are someone who can comprehend things from a universally detached perspective when faced with horrors that most mortal minds can't comprehend.

Back on topic, that was the 'unbending will' he mentioned when talking to Clarisse. The power that kept him from falling victim to outside influences that tried to control him in any way.

He wasn't exactly sure when he picked up the ability, but he wasn't complaining.

Flexing his power once more, Percy opened the door.

He didn't throw it open, nor even open it quickly. His anger had gone full circle. Where he would normally be a walking bastion of fury, like he had a little over three hours ago, and be destroying everything in his rage, he was engulfed in a tranquil fury.

He looked up at the throne, seeing the demon. His eyes quickly scanned the room, finding...

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Eres was there, sitting down with her back against the throne. Her eyes were vacant, and she wasn't moving save for the small movement of her chest. Even the energies that were contained within her body were still.

The book hadn't been lying about her condition.

Then again, when had it ever lied to him?

With a mental shake of his head, he looked around as he slowly walked in.

No one else. Hopefully, that was a good sign.

“Ah, so the king shows up at his castle. Surprised to see someone sitting in your throne?” The demon asked.

Indeed, it was sitting on his throne.

And, truly, it was a demon.

It had the head of a pig, larger then it should have been and misshapen. It's body, twisted in a grotesque fashion that had ribs jutting out in many places while sunken in others, seemed to be rotted hide, and only now was he noticing the smell. Its left arm was bone, while the right arm was covered in some sludge like material, which dripped from the seven-clawed hand.

It stood on the legs of a mule, one foot that of a human, the other befitting the animal the legs mocked.

Nine or so beady eyes, all on that pig head, stared at him. They were dull colors, every single one of them.

'Creepy looking fuck.' Percy thought, walking slowly towards the throne. 'Won't matter in a minute though.'

“Ooh, come on.” It whined. It's voice was high pitched and childish. “Say something!”

“Won't matter to you in a little bit.” Percy said stiffly.

“Ooh, I wouldn't do that if I were you.” It taunted before it started laughing, squealing and snorting. “Don't you want to know what happened? Why the people rebelled against you?”

“Oh, I already know.” Percy replied. “Because I'm so cruel, so unreasonable, thinking that I can have them leave their homes for a few weeks, leave the world that I created. Not to mention those four using this as an attempt to do something this incredibly stupid.”

If anything, the beast just laughed harder, doubling over as its tongue flopped about.

A second mouth, situated on the back of its misshapen head, spoke up, a deeper voice coming from it.

“I love miscommunication, don't you?” It asked. “Gets everyone confused, spreads rumors. Makes people jump to the wrong conclusion as the tales grow taller.”

“Look, I'm not in the mood for this. Something, Which I'm going to assume was you, slaughtered my minions just outside my tower. I've had to deal with an uprising, and I took a blast of magic that would have caused wide-scale destruction, to the face. Only to come back, find three hours of my life wasted, and some bullshit residue from the magic that shouldn't exist, at all, eating away at my world. So, you can imagine that I'm not the happiest person right now. Then, I come back to find some uppity demon trying to make some grand performance, implying that it's the whole reason behind this entire debacle. I'm absolutely furious right now, and it is only because that fury went full circle that I'm not tearing out whatever may pass for your throat, or throats. I just want this day to be over, and I have so much to do before I can call it a day.”

“Please, indulge me then. If you think I'll be so easy to kill, let me give my final speech. My last hurrah, if you will.” It said, though no less condescendingly.

A hand burst out of its chest.

“No.” Said a second Percy, yanking the demon upwards along with the back of his throne. “I have no reason to do so, and You've caused me nothing but grief if you are the puppeteer behind these events. That just means that I have even less reason to do so, and I certainly don't want to hear you talk more. Your voices are annoying, and your laugh is grating on the ears.”

Bringing his other hand up, the gauntlet growing longer, sharper claws, Percy drove his 'point' home.

Right through the malformed head of the demon.

But he didn't stop there.

He pulled his hand back out, driving it in again at the demon's shoulder, sending bone and ooze flying.

Again and again, Percy pierced the demon, leaving holes in his body and chunks of what used to be its body on the floor.

Even without noticing, he could feel the demons power seeping into him. He didn't exactly know what that power was at the moment, but he didn't care. He just wanted it dead, and he had gotten just that.

He was tired, his body was still sore, and he had so much to deal with.

Still, it did ease the pain, if only slightly.

Letting the carcass drop, Percy shook his arm free of the guts that clung there. The manifestation of his will that stood in the middle of the room disappeared, making his mind whole once more.

“Knowing my old self, I would likely have heard him out, wasting precious time that my world does not have right now.” He muttered. “I don't understand why people would do that, heroes or otherwise.”

Stepping over the ruins of his throne, Percy gently shook Eres.

“You alright?” He asked, a groan all he got for an answer. “Come on, wake up.”

“Huh?” Eres lazily moaned out. “Whas happin?”

“Demon's gone, Eres. You should start feeling better here soon.”

“Gone?” She slurred, slowly coming out of her stupor. “No ish not... Can still feel it... pressing against my brain...”

It only took Percy a few moments to realize what she was talking about.

“Ah, hells.” He muttered, cursing himself. “The book said it was a demon of stupidity. Mixed with the aura it put out and the not so subtle hints it made, I just killed it. Which means that...”

Percy only had one word for the situation.

“Shit.”

'Tome, we have a problem.'

'What is it, Marked one? Should I come back at once?'

'You were right about that demon. A demon of stupidity. And I just killed it with my own two hands.'

The Eronomicon was silent, thinking over any possibilities as to why this would be a problem. It came up with several, but there was one that was more likely to have been the reason its master was dubbing it as trouble.

'The aura.'

'Bingo.' Percy told it. 'Look, forget looking for whatever it was making that noise. I need you to go tell Rose that she needs to come to the tower and evacuate the city. I don't think Eres will be in the right mind to order the minions by herself. I certainly can't deal with it right now.'

'At once, Marked one.'

With that, there was the unmistakable 'pop' of the traveling tome hopping into the void while their connection was still active.

'Man, I hate having multiple auras.' Percy thought, picking up Eres, who had once again fallen into an almost brain dead state again. 'One aura that I'm not used to was bad enough. It's twenty times worse when I get a new one now. Great. How is this going to work with the training trip?'

He'd get to that when he could. Right now, he had to ensure that the world was vacated, not just of people, but of all things of even minor importance in the tower. Books written by the blue minions, Eres's memoirs from the tower heart, experiments that the blues were working on, the entire floor dedicated to housing poisons for the greens, Giblet's armory, the minion homes that were held far beneath the tower, the tower-heart itself, and most certainly Eres herself.

He was certain he would be able to deal with the world-destroying energy with no problem...

If he were in peak condition, not tired, hurt or suffering from a severe bout of frustration.

Which was to say... Not right now.

At least he didn't have to worry about Millicent. He knew Eres was not stupid enough to keep her here if the world was in danger. For him to be gone for three hours, with no way of communication, along with four idiots breaking the most important law he had, she would have had the girl through a pathway to her home universe in a heartbeat. Likely off to stay with her aunt for a few days.

Using the power of the boots, Percy traveled through the palace's halls till he made his way to the very center, where the tower-heart resided.

He set Eres onto the large purple orb, which reflected her condition. Seeing her slowly sink into it, Percy sighed.

'One thing down...'

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy stood a good distance away, watching as Rose talked with Eres on the balcony of his room. Far enough that he hoped the effects of his newest ability wouldn't so much as make them stutter.

Rose was giving orders to Eres, who was still slightly out of it. She, in turn, relayed them to the minions.

Rose had told him, through the Eronomicon since he didn't want to risk having the ghost girl fall prey to the new aura again, that the blues and greens were complaining about all of them felt like Eres did. Sluggish in the mind, second guessing themselves.

A lot of them even equated it to their time as imps, with their lesser brainpower and weaker bodies.

However, given that they were in the middle of a crisis, they didn't spend much time focusing on it.

People were being ushered through gates, the minions trying their hardest to keep those with the same language together so as to avoid the chaos that would undoubtedly ensue if they were just tossed into different worlds.

Percy looked back from his position in the air, looking over the walls.

He could see it, the non-energy, slowly encroaching upon the city.

Even now, he could feel the air slowly thin out as it was devoured, destroyed or whatever it was that was happening.

'Marked one.' The Eronomicon said as it appeared.

“Yeah?”

'The mother of your first-born wants you to know that the mortal population has been evacuated, save the prisoners. She also wishes to know what you wish to do with them.'

“Have Morticia sacrifice enough to bring back the minions that were slaughtered by the demon, as well as those lost in the attack on the rebels. If there are any left over, take them to Echidna and her brood. They could do with a nice hunt.”

'Very well. I shall let her know immediately.'

With that, the tome vanished, a tiny ripple in the air all that remained.

Percy looked on, watching as the world he had created was slowly destroyed.

It had taken him a while to do so, as well.

With him not being able to create something from nothing, which he hoped to soon rectify, he had been forced to acquire bits and pieces from other worlds, by they living, dead, or somewhere in between.

The earth, the plants, the water, the moon... even the stars, technically. Those he had taken the gases necessary to create them, compressing them into the pinpricks of light you could see in the night sky. And the day, in the sun's case.

That was how he created this world. He fought for the space to build, and then he took bits and pieces from everywhere else to do so. He had sculpted the landscape with brute force, using what miniscule amount of power over the earth he had from his father, which had grown while the Eronomicon had destroyed the limits of his human body and he had gained many powerful women, to do what strength alone could not.

And now, it was seeming like it was all for naught.

“Damned mages.” He muttered. “Wish I could see whatever became of them.”

Having nothing better to do, Percy traveled through the air. He wanted to see how far this had spread already.

Standing three yards away from the current edge of the devastation, Percy forced himself to watch as it slowly ate the world.

He was on the far side, in the middle of what was once a thick forest. A river ran without heed into the maw of oblivion.

He held a thick branch in his hand, at least five feet in length.

He took a deep breath, wondering if he was really going to do this.

It seemed so. Yes, he was going to poke the world devouring abomination with a stick.

Was his new aura getting to him?

Slowly, Percy stepped forward, inching closer and closer to the edge of the energy until he could just touch it with his crude inspection tool.

Bracing himself for, well, anything, Percy lowered the stick.

Dipping the first five inches in, Percy quickly pulled it out.

Percy watched as the part of the stick he dipped quickly died before they simply stopped being anything.

'Huh. Interesting.' Percy thought, stepping back a good twenty feet. 'Tome...'

With a flash, the Eronomicon appeared once again.

'Yes, marked one? How may I serve you?'

“I need you to bring me one of the prisoners. Blindfolded, if you can. And having them gagged would be appreciated.” He said, not wanting to have them blubbering about their innocence right now.

'Wait one moment, marked one.'

With that, the Eronomicon was gone.

Percy looked back at the stick. It was a clean... cut would suffice, he guessed. Other then the sudden missing part, the stick looked largely unharmed.

It seems that this energy didn't leave any residue on things partially devoured.

Nor did it effect the whole. Just whatever part had direct contact.

Even with his gauntlets, Percy was glad he didn't actually touch this stuff.

'Guess that's something else I can thank both the boots and my gauntlets for.' He thought. 'Quick and nimble fingers that can grab anything. If I hadn't been able to pull the four different magic energies apart without actually touching the result, something tells me I'd be missing a hand. Or worse.'

Yeah, this stuff did seem like it could kill a god. If even he could barely stomach looking at it, it had to be some nasty stuff.

'Marked one, I have brought you the prisoner as you requested.' The Eronomicon spoke as it appeared. 'Mistress Rose also wanted me to tell you that she is not happy with this course of action.'

With that, the tome flipped open. Settling on a page, it started to glow before a person appeared out of thin air.

They were obviously terrified, seeing as they struggled to stand up and run, screeching through the gag. They couldn't see, and ran into a tree for their efforts.

Falling on their ass, the sacrifice whimpered, trying to curl in a ball and seem as small as possible as they cried.

It almost filled Percy with a sense of pity.

Unfortunately, he had to test some things, and pity was not something he could afford himself.

Walking over to grasp the man, and it was definitely a man because of Percy's nature and his way of running things.

“Stop your whimpering.” Percy said coldly, hoisting the man up by the collar of his shirt. “You brought this upon yourself, traitor. Joining that rebellion was almost guaranteed suicide, and you're lucky I don't kill you with my bare hands right now.”

Turning him to face away from the non-energy, Percy tore the blindfold off the man.

“Now, when we turn around, there is going to be something that will break you. It will invade your mind, and destroy every concept your mortal brain can ever think of, and even the ones you didn't know you could imagine. There will be nothing left of you, and you will become a husk of your former self, a shell of a man.”

As expected, the man was not thrilled about the idea.

Alas, Percy continued.

“And if you think that's your punishment, you would be wrong. No, you're my little guinea pig for an... experiment, if you will. It will almost assuredly end with the cessation of your very existence. And no, I'm not sorry about that in the slightest. I'm going to dip you in that, like Thetis with Achilles in the river Styx.”

The man wouldn't get the reference, but it didn't matter.

“Unfortunately, I doubt you'll become nigh invulnerable.”

Screaming, pleading for his life and sanity with his mouth gagged, the man was turned around.

Percy watched the things that could happen to a mortal upon seeing that which was not meant for their eyes once more.

His body started convulsing, in ways that the body should not have been able to convulse. His ragged cries grew louder, wilder as they tore his throat to shreds, blood staining the cloth in his mouth. His eyes rolled in his head before...

pop!

His eyes quickly swelled until they burst, his screams growing louder still.

His skin turned ashen gray, but incredibly hot to the touch, and even his fingers bent completely backwards of their own accord, snapping bone that cut through the skin. He voided his bowels, then and there as he continued to thrash.

Percy dropped the man, stepping back to watch him thrash about for a little while.

It ended soon after, though what was once a man still had minute spasms here and there. Its breathing was ragged, and it was very likely that its vocal cords were destroyed.

“Yeah.” Percy said, picking up the mindless shell of the man. “That's some nasty stuff. Couldn't be so weak as to cause instant death, after all. But not powerful enough to ret-con his existence just by having him look at it.”

Walking back over to the edge, feeling the air tug slightly as it was consumed by the primordial force, Percy held the husk by its midsection above it.

Slowly lowering him, Percy dipped his test subject's feet into the primordial energies.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Like the stick before, when Percy raised the man back up, there was a twisted, dying part of the man that was once flesh, and soon stopped being entirely.

“Well, it's a slight comfort to know that it won't destroy a living thing instantly.” Percy said, stepping back once more. He reached down, pulling a leg up to assess the damage. “Perfectly cut once more.”

'Marked one, just what is it you're trying to figure out?' The ancient book asked, for once confused.

Percy shrugged, dropping the shell of a man on the forest floor. “I don't exactly know myself. But it doesn't hurt to know a little bit about this.” He said. “Now, I'll need another prisoner. Same restraints, please.”

The tome said nothing, just vanishing once more.

Percy looked down the barely breathing form of the prisoner. It didn't make any movements, nor did it seem to feel the blood flow from its eyes or temple.

Strangely, it wasn't bleeding from its feet.

Percy nudged it with his foot.

Not even a groan.

He sighed, taking some small pity.

It would be best to put it out of its misery...

If it could even have that.

Picking it up again, Percy threw it into the advancing energies. It made no splash as it hit the surface of the stuff, just twisting into a dried out husk before ceasing its existence.

'Marked one...' The tome announced its arrival once more. 'Rose wishes to tell you that she is not happy with you experimenting on the world devouring primordial energy with human lives.'

Percy sighed again. He was definitely going to hear about this later. “I'll deal with that later. She'll have eight years to chew me out about it after all. Did you at least get the prisoner?”

'Of course. Even if she is against this, my loyalty lay solely with you, Marked one.' The tome scoffed at the thought of listening to anyone other then the Marked one.

Unless he ordered it, of course.

Flipping open again, another prisoner appeared in a flash of light.

Percy quickly grabbed the man, for once again it was a man, and held him above the ground.

“Don't even start trying to scream, run away, or anything else. This is your punishment for the rebellion. I've already dealt with one person making a fuss about this, though I can't really fault anyone for that. So, unlike the last one, I'll offer you a deal. Even if I don't really need to, seeing as you are completely at my mercy. If you survive this, and don't cause me any trouble, you get to live and quite possible walk free. Clear?”

Seeing the man nervously nod his head in understanding, Percy walked over to the energy again.

“Now, tell me if this hurts.”

Percy could feel the man tense up at his order before he dipped his feet into it.

The man flinched when his feet met the energy, but he made no noise.

Even as Percy pulled him out, his feet rapidly decaying and being destroyed, he didn't so much as utter a sound.

Raising an eyebrow, Percy stepped back, far enough that the trees blocked the view of the primordial energy.

He sat the prisoner on the ground, undoing the gag.

“What's going on? Why can't I feel my feet anymore? What did you do to me?” He asked, trying to keep the panic from his voice, but failing ever so slightly.

“Let's just say that you don't have feet anymore.” Percy said bluntly. “I'm surprised that you felt no pain either. I would expect something like what just happened to make you lose your mind with pain.”

“What'dya mean I don't have feet?” The man asked, coming close to full blown hysteria. “What did you do!?”

“Calm down. At least you're alive. Be thankful for that.” Percy told him sharply. “Now tell me, what did you feel?”

“I-I don't know.” He stammered. “One second I could feel my feet, and the next, nothing.”

Percy nodded, taking the information in, trying to figure out what he could do with it.

“H-hey, what am I going to do now? I mean... I was just a carpenter before all this. B-but, if I can't walk anymore...”

Percy turned to look at the tome. “You have anything that might help?”

“Huh, why are you asking me?” The man asked, thinking that Percy was talking to him. “And what are you asking me about?”

'Yes, I believe I do.' The Eronomicon said, ignoring the man. 'Something I picked up in the event that the marked one was crippled in some way, or had someone close to him that was crippled. It's called the lizard's limb seal.'

The Eronomicon paused for a moment before continuing.

'Though, I do not know if limbs lost to something so closely resembling the void, and as unnatural as that, will be able to be healed. I've never tested it one someone that has had a limb cease to exist, since they usually go with the limb.'

“Guess we'll find out now then, huh?” Percy asked, holding out his hand.

'It seems we shall.' The book said, flipping open to a spot near the physical back. It floated over to meet the outstretched hand, letting Percy's fingers touch the impossibly old ink.

“Lizard's Limb Seal times two.” Percy muttered, feeling ink form on his skin through the gauntlets.

Taking his hand away from the book, and the gauntlet from his hand, Percy looked at the seal.

It looked very much like its namesake, and the ink slowly moved as it showed the lizard it formed slowly regrow its tail.

Percy pressed his hand against the spot where the foot went missing, causing the man to scream in pain.

“AUGH! OH GODS, IT HURTS!” He tried to pull his leg away, but Percy had already moved onto the other, pressing his hand against the open wound that didn't bleed. “WHAT ARE YOU DOING TO ME! IT BURNS! STOP IT! STOP IT! AAAUUGGHGH!”

Ignoring his pained cries, Percy watched as the openings slowly scabbed over, and the scabs became flesh.

“Well, it seems that your feet may be returned to you yet.” Percy told him, patting him on the knee. “Take him back to the tower, and have the blue minions try and relieve the pain. Have four or five brown minions guard him. As of right now, this man is no longer a prisoner.”

'As you wish.'

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy stood on the cusp of the pathway leading to his home world. All he had left to do was close it, and he could finally do what he had been planning for the last month.

Both town and tower were empty, devoid of anything save what they were made of. Just four hours ago Eres and the tower-heart were taken to the Nether Tower. Since then, Percy had closed off the other Pathways, sealing the world in a type of isolation that only a being like him could breach.

It left him feeling not quite empty, but not exactly cheery either.

“I won't let this be the end of it.” He said simply.

With that, he turned and walked through the pathway, seeming like nothing more then a ring of light that ran on infinitely without physically showing it, grabbing at the edges and pulling it in on itself.

As the ring of light disappeared, it seemed that the world would soon become consumed by an existence that should never have been. A tomb that would be consumed by the abomination it contained, leaving only memory.

-With Percy-

He grunted slightly as he finished folding the other end of the pathway in on itself.

“Forget punching universes apart.” He said, whipping away the sweat on his brow. “And fuck traveling in between universes. Anything dealing with universal pathways is the real work. Though, I suppose it doesn't help that I'm still not running on full. Damn, stupid aura making it so I can't go near anyone who could have given me enough lust energy.”

Turning, he looked at the skyline. It was almost night, with the chariot of Apollo slowly sinking below the horizon.

With his business done, Percy traveled through the air to his destination.

~

“You sure this is a big enough place?”

'Yes. The device isn't very big at all, despite its power and function. Besides, the tecnomancer took it as a self challenge to fit a spacial compressor into the design without losing functionality. So, technically, it's far larger then it looks.'

Percy looked around the room where they would set this whole thing up.

The living room of Sally's apartment.

“Alright then, let's get it set up then.”

With a flash of light, which was barely kept hidden by the double layer of blackout curtains, Percy called out the two items the entire plan was based around.

The first item was fairly small, and easily able to be considered a hand held device like a gameboy, or whatever it was that he had seen other kids at his various schools messing with.

That is, if not for the shape.

It was shaped oddly, not being square or rectangular. It was more of a pyramid shape, but it was slightly taller then it was wider. There were strange carvings, runes carved into it that were filled with a seemingly infinite amount small wires, connecting everything.

The second was a small box, looking like it would be a close fit if it were placed in the pyramid shaped object. It was an incredibly cold metal, seeing as the carpet started frosting over the second it landed, and judging by the loud 'thunk' as it hit the floor, quite heavy as well. It also had the strange markings, but it was a continuous design. If he were to trace it, his finger would cover every nanometer of the surface.

Curious, Percy went to poke the first item...

Nothing.

“Okay, so how does this work exactly?”

'Give me a moment. It's been so long since I collected this object, and I have not attempted to test this.'

The book floated over to the first object, letting power seep out and reach for the pyramid.

Instantaneously, the runes buzzed to life, the noise filling the room with a low droning sound. The tiny wires detached one end from the miniature structure, seemingly feeding off the energy as they twisted through the air towards the ancient tome.

As the first one pierced the cover, the tome only had one thing to say.

'I'm glad I don't feel pain.'

With that, more wires struck, pulling the Eronomicon down as each individual wire started to glow, the droning growing louder as the pyramid grew brighter.

Now, normally the sight of this would have made anybody fear for the destruction of the book. Heck, even Percy would have been worried if he hadn't seen it survive much worse.

The Eronomicon ended up pulled beneath the pyramid, which lifted itself up by the wires to sit atop the book. Both light, which now included the runes, and sound seemed to reach their climax.

Before it all went silent.

'Please choose either home console or hand-held console.'

Okay, that was weird.

“Home.”

'Acknowledged. Please insert game core.'

“Before I do that, tell me if the Eronomicon will be fine.'

'Please insert game core.'

Percy sighed. “Fine. I guess you won't say anything until I do that, right?”

'Please insert game core, or say “cancel” to end process.'

“Yeah, yeah.” He said, picking up the cube, the frost on the carpet now half-inch thick ice and the air around it filled with cold mist. “Here you go.”

He offered it up to the device, pulling back his hand when the army of wires grabbed at it like a drowning man for a life preserver.

Lifting the cube above it's point, the pyramid let out a soft hiss, like air being released from a canister, before it opened its upper half. The four faces folded outwards to ninety degree angles.

The wires, wrapped tightly around the cube, retreated into the new opening, which snapped shut before Percy could look into it.

'Game core accepted. Running scan... Checking power levels... Downloading extra content... Please wait five minutes.'

Percy sighed, sitting down on the couch. 'Extra content? Wonder what that means.' He said, closing his eyes.

He could do with a small nap. He had barely slept a wink since the whole world devouring energy problem started.

While he didn't need much sleep anymore, it was still nice to be able to do so.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“You are the one that's making all the waves, aren't you. The son of Poseidon.”

Percy's eyes opened slowly upon hearing the voice. Not like the owner could possibly hurt him, could they?

When the words finally clicked, Percy said one thing.

“That was a bad joke, and you should feel bad.”

The ceiling above him, which looked like his mother's apartment, wavered.

“I've heard tale that you're more than what you should be.” The voice said, keeping calm. “I can see that they're right.”

“Yeah, yeah.” Percy said, yawning as he sat up. Scratching an ear, he looked around. “So, which immortal figure am I talking to? I've had a very rough week, and I'd like a little shut-eye.”

“Shut-eye?” The voice chuckled, seemingly amused at the notion. “Dear boy, you have no need for sleep. You are currently in my realm, under the thrall of my father. While with other gods you may get the vague image or two, I can do so much more.”

Percy nodded slowly. Not from caution, just from the mental fatigue that came with sleep-deprivation. “Yeah, okay. So... Morpheus?”

The voice chuckled again, though this came from right beside Percy. He was unsurprised to see the god sitting on the couch next to him, looking at him intently.

“Correct.” The god said, his mouth turned up in a small smile. “So many people confuse me with my father, it gets a little annoying. It's been a while since anyone recognized my domain as my own. For that small acknowledgment, I will avoid all the usual hoops I make people jump through.”

“Alright then. So, what is it you want?”

“Two reasons. First, because you interest me. Second, because it seems that you will be the deciding factor in this war, a greater piece of this game then previously thought. And trust me when I say that one like you, a child of the big three, was already deeming important enough to issue a kill-on-sight order.”

“Tell me about it.” Percy muttered.

“Yes.” The god said, clearing his throat. “And, seeing as I've also heard you have little love for the Olympians, I am certainly interested in seeing where exactly your loyalties lies.”

“Look, if you've come to try and recruit me into Kronos's army, it's pointless. I won't be joining my grandfather.” Percy told the god of dreams. Having never actually met the god, Percy had no reason to be hostile towards him. Of course, that meant he had no inclination to be all buddy-buddy with him either.

The god sighed softly, looking away. “I figured you wouldn't if what the son of Hermes was saying was true. I must say though, claiming that the titan of time has his days numbered...”

“I must be stupid?” Percy asked, noticing Morpheus trail off.

“Either that, or very powerful. I hope I haven't offended you.”

Percy shook his head. “Nah, it's fine. I can see why the gods would think that. After all, I'm just some upstart that was born of a broken promise. Someone who, by all rights, shouldn't exist. At least you're polite enough to not make me do something nasty.”

“Given how calm you seem about this, I must ask. Were you expecting me?” The dream weaver asked, narrowing his eyes slightly.

“Expecting you? No, not in the slightest.” Percy told him. “In fact, I'm surprised that you even found me.”

“And why, pray tell, would that be?”

“Deal I worked out with the Fates.” Percy said, shrugging. “And you don't need to know anymore then that.”

Morpheus let his eyes linger on Percy for a moment longer, trying to see if there was anything off, anything that would make him slip up and talk.

Morpheus gave a tired sigh, finding nothing. Such things were not his specialty, after all.

“True, I suppose. It really is none of my business.” He said. “Though I must say I find it hard to believe that you have set up a deal with the The Three Sisters. But, as you said, it is none of my business. However...”

Morpheus turned to look at Percy, a veil of... something akin to darkness fading onto his shoulder. His eyes, which previously seemed to be consumed by the need for sleep, shone brightly. The world around them twisted away, slipping away beneath the couch.

“No matter how interesting you may be; no matter how important you are to this prophecy... I cannot allow you to live.”

Percy just looked at him, raising an eyebrow.

“Before you commit to that action, I want you to know some things. One, I'm allied with Hades. If I were to, somehow, end up dead, whoever did it would soon have the entire kingdom of the dead after them. Secondly, I have my own loyal army, both living and dead, who would seek retribution against my killers. Third, and the most important I would think...”

Percy lashed out, grabbing Morpheus's face. For good measure, he dug the newly formed claws of the Alpha's Armlets into the god's skull, drawing Ichor from his now mirage-like body.

“Is that I can kill you, end your very existence, quite easily.”

He pulled Morpheus close to him, looking him in the eyes without blinking.

“That's right. I can kill gods. Because, in the grand scheme of things, I am beyond you. I've gone places that you could not begin to understand the dreams of those who dwell there. I could easily kill any being in this universe, be they Zeus, Kronos, Typhon... Anybody. I've already killed one god in this universe, though he was only a minor river god.”

Slowly tightening his grip, digging further and further into Morpheus's skull, slowly letting the power of the gauntlets flow.

“You might have absolute control in the world of dreams, but my power is above your own. You cannot control me, nor can you kill me. My loyalties lie with myself, and I will not have some weak peasant,” He spat out, making the Sandman blink as some landed in his eyes as his own gained a green luminescence. “Of a god trying to cow me into submission.”

Pulling his claws out, taking some flesh and Ichor with them, Percy pushed Morpheus away from him, off the couch. The god landed in an undignified heap, clutching at his bleeding temples.

Propping his feet up on the god, showing him place, Percy slowly pulled back his power.

“Now, I don't normally do this.” He said, the light of his eyes dimming to more mundane levels. “But, since I'm in a decent enough mood, I'll let you live. You can run back to Kronos if you want, tell him and his little lapdog Luke what you've heard if you want. It would make this entire war so much more interesting if they double their efforts, futile though they my be.”

“Oh, and by the way,” Percy said after a slight pause. “For a god who doesn't fight, you have impressive pain tolerance if you didn't scream as I started crushing your skull. Good for you.”

With that, Percy woke himself up with a quick, painful pinch.

~

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“As a quick reminder, I am not yours.” A voice that Percy had never heard before barked. “I chose you.”

Willing himself to look around, Percy saw...

Nobody?

“Down here.” A different voice said, light and pleasant compared to the gravelly tone of the first one.

Turning what he assumed vertically, Percy found himself facing two men that he had never seen before.

The first was wearing a simple outfit of a man on a long journey, with his shirt and pants being somewhere between clinging to his skin and hanging ever so slightly off his frame. He had a cloak, not unlike one would wear in the event of a storm fastened around his shoulders, the hood pulled down. He was also wearing some kind of cloth around his neck, like a mask for keeping sand or ash from filling his mouth. His shoes were worn, though they were well maintained by the look of them.

The color scheme of his clothes, if it could be called a color scheme at all, was what would have tipped anyone off that this man was anything but normal. They were made from all manner of elements, splattered here and there without any rhyme or reason. Brightest light, deepest shadow, all the hues of a painted desert, a pattern of greenery that wouldn't look out of place in a forest, the grays of stones in the mountains, several different materials for everyday clothing and even the decaying flesh that one would find at the scene of a massacre.

What was even more interesting was the fact that they all mixed together, changing and mutating to even more variations, twisting around one another in a way that should have been seamlessly if not for the fact that none of them mixed well with one another, but made so much sense at the same time! It was a paradoxical clash of being both right and wrong, both in terms of aesthetics and, very likely, practicality.

The man himself was old, no two ways about it. His face was worn, weathered by years of travel in harsh climates. His face was clean shaven, with unruly gray hair atop his head that looked matted and unwashed. His body was thin, and it was likely that if he was human, it was about the age when he would have to settle down, no longer able to bear the burden of long journeys.

All in all, if one did not take into account his clothing, he would look unassuming. Just a wandering old man.

Except...

There was an odd gleam in his eye.

It was not unlike the Stoll brothers when they had their little prank wars on the camp during his second summer at camp. They had no thoughts of abiding the rules, casting aside what little restraint they were forced to uphold, no thoughts of letting anyone tell them 'no' without having them face a consequence for keeping their divine blood from satiating itself.

It was that gleam in his eye, along with a quick look at his, now, bare feet that told him all he needed to know.

That old man was the spirit of his boots, the boots that the Eronomicon had found stranded in the void, the boots that had shown him exactly what happens to those who tackle the nothingness unprepared or arrogant of their own power.

The other was, despite the oddity of the other man's clothing, the decidedly more strange of the two. Instead of a hulking behemoth of a man that towered over the likes of Typhon in both stature and presence, like Percy would have expected from the soul of the gauntlets, he was...

Well...

“What?” The average looking human spirit asked, arms folded as he looked at Percy. “Not what you were expecting, am I?”

“Ah, lighten up a bit.” The eldest looking of the three said. “It wouldn't be all that surprising for those who know what you grant your wearer to think you'd be a little more, I don't know... Intimidating? Although, I'd still say he's at fault for not using those fancy glasses of his to see how we were doing and having a nice chat.”

He gave Percy a look of disapproval at this, shaking his head ever so slightly.

“I'll say,” The most average of the three commented briskly, turning to look away from Percy like a scolded child. “Even having worn us for almost two years now. You hear that!?”

He quickly turned around, marching up to Percy and sticking his finger, which Percy could see now had a small metal band on the middle finger, right in his face.

“Two damned years you've worn us, using our powers! And what do we get? Fucking nothing!” He yelled into Percy's face before he turned his back on the black-haired Being. “No thanks, no appreciation... Not even a damned proper washing!”

“Now, I wouldn't say we got nothing, per say.” The old man said, gaining a slightly cocky grin. “After all, I always did enjoy a free show when I could get one.”

“Fuck your 'free shows' you old bastard!” The youngest looking of the trio said, flipping the eldest off. “I'd rather get some then sit back and watch, stroking my dick as I try to get off to some piss poor fuck that can't even please a woman without a magic book messing with their minds!”

“My, aren't you just a vulgar one?” The old man scoffed.

“Eat shit!”

“Will the both of you just shut up for one second!”

The two souls whipped their head, looking at Percy, while he held up his hands.

“Wasn't me, I swear.”

“Of course not!” The voice spat, coming from... beneath them. “A pitiful little mongrel like you doesn't even have the backbone to tell your own spawn she's yours!”

The group of three looked down, in a sense, as they tilted their soul manifestations to face where their feet had just been pointing.

It was...

Another Percy?

Except... this one had an aura of pure malice and hatred, his eyes illuminating the dark with a green so foul it could give someone the plague as they withered under his stare. The darkness around him seemed to caress him, like the embrace of a lover...

Or a mind-raped worshiper.

His face was set in a sneer, staring between them as if unsure of who disgusted him the most with their presence.

“Huh.” Percy said, raising an eyebrow. “I'm guessing you're the part of me that takes after the role of the Overlord the most, aren't you?”

“Ooh, figure that out all by yourself did you?” His other self asked, mocking him with a high pitched voice. He promptly spit at the original Percy, wiping his mouth in disgust. “Of course I am, you sniveling pile of filth. I refuse to be deemed as any other part of your damned psyche, and I hate not being the one in control of the body we inhabit. If I were in control, we would not be playing these games with those weaklings you call gods, and that rebellion would have been stopped before it even began. All opposition to my rule would have been crushed, and any survivors would have been subjugated to the worst tortures imaginable before being either executed, or having their very souls bound to my will.”

“Oh please, spare the details.” The soul of the gauntlets said, dismissing the Overlord persona and his tirade. “You're so great and powerful, bask in the greatness that he wouldn't have if not for me and the old goat doing most of the work.”

“I would suggest you still your tongue,” The Overlord said, narrowing his eyes so that the light was barely visible. “Before I cut it out.”

“Oh yeah?” The soul of the gauntlets asked, turning to face the darker side of Percy. “Bring it, you fucker!”

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Yes, more fighting.” Another voice joined, sounding very depressed. “That's exactly what we need now.”

The original Percy and the soul of the boots turned, as the soul of the gauntlets and the Overlord side of Percy started trading blows in the background, to see who else had joined the conversation.

It was, yet again, Percy. The thing about this one is that it produced an aura of self loathing and depression. His skin was pale, and his entire body was hunched over like he couldn't make the effort to stand up straight. His black hair was filled with grease, and the rest of him was just as filthy, giving the image that he just didn't care anymore.

He clutched at a robe that was thrown over him, pictures of past events cluttering the fabric.

“How many more mistakes can we make, I wonder...” He said, looking at them with eyes unseeing. “Before we realize our folly?”

“And there's the guilt, worry and depression.” Percy sighed, rubbing a hand down his face in exasperation. “Just what I needed.”

The thousand-yard stare that the depressed Percy had vanished, his head turning at a frightening angle to stare directly at Percy.

“Yes... I am what you need.” It said, standing up straighter now, his voice rasping over single syllable like sandpaper over a chalkboard. “I am the one who tells you your misdeeds, the things you regret!”

“I have no regrets!” The Overlord roared, slamming his fist into the stomach of his opponent. “I have no need for such a concept!”

The depressed Percy glared at the Overlord, his wish that he didn't exist clear in his eyes. That soon faded with a sigh, as he hunched over again, his eyes emptying of recognition once more.

Percy sighed again, rubbing a hand over his face.

“You're not all there in the head, are you?” The soul of the boots asked, walking to stand beside the original Percy.

“I had my suspicions...” Percy said. “Ever since that night with Clarisse...”

“My doing, thank you very much!” The Overlord exclaimed, seemingly happy to revel in that achievement before he took a right hook to the face, sending him sprawling as the darkness surged to cover the spot, which would almost certainly sport a bruise.

Can a soul, or manifestation of the psyche in this case, bruise?

“Yet another failing on our part, a failure to keep ourselves in line.”

“Shut up!” Percy yelled at his depressing counterpart.

The old soul chuckled, putting his hand on Percy's shoulder. “It seems most gods have some kind of problem, so don't worry too much. My original owner had problems traveling by himself, despite his sphere of control. Always walked with at least two other people, but he liked caravans the most.”

Percy gave a small laugh, though it didn't last long. “So, am I really such a bad, er, owner?”

“You could be worse.” The old soul said, shrugging. “But, ever since my creator went and pushed his luck, you're the first person to use me. And an artifact like me is meant to be used, so...”

He gave Percy a not-so-lighthearted glare. “But really, you need to learn to enjoy the journey more often. Jumping from place to place without knowing what's in between, or stopping to smell the roses, is very limiting.” He lectured briefly. “But, then again, you're the one who tells me what to do. I just do it.”

“Also,” He said after a pause. “You need to learn how to use my powers for more then just traveling. I know you know about my other abilities, or at least some of them, since you've stole the pants off women without actually taking them off. You know, I remember hearing about a thief that could steal anything that wasn't nailed down and on fire, and had actually stolen more treasure than actually existed in his world. I think there was something about stealing from himself in the future, but I don't quite know all the details. If you're going to one-up my dead creator, you'll start needing to do stuff that makes that seem like child's play.”

“And what did he,” Percy asked, pointing a finger over at the most normal looking of the group as he and the Overlord were grappling, trying to throw the other to the ground to strangle them. “Mean by cleaning?”

“A bit of a washing would be nice now and then, maybe a nice treatment of oil if I'm formed into leather or any type of metal.”

“And the free shows?” Percy asked, giving a knowing smirk.

“Don't go calling the kettle black now, you hear?”

“I won't, I won't.” Percy said, placating him. “So, is there anything I should know about the soul of the gauntlets?”

“I know about as much as you.”

“Great...”

“Fucking die!” The soul of the gauntlets yelled, picking up the Overlord Percy by the throat effortlessly and throwing him across the black expanse. The darkness desperately clung to the Overlord, trying to impede his flight and catch him once more.

“But, that still doesn't exactly explain why they, or you, are here.”

'WARNING! WARNING! MULTIPLE INSTANCES OF PLAYER ONE (1) DETECTED!'

Everyone, save the Overlord who was fading into the distance now, looked up to see the message that glared above them with flashing lights in more colors than the human eye could comprehend.

“Seems there might be a little screw up in this device that's caused us to be here.” The old man said.

“Amazing.” Percy muttered, rolling his eyes at how this was turning out. “So, how do we work this out?”

'THERE MAY BE SEVERAL SOLUTIONS TO THIS PROBLEM. WOULD YOU LIKE TO TROUBLESHOOT, OR END PROCESS AND EXIT THE GAME?'

“I wish this thing came with an owner's manual.” Percy grumbled, before looking up at the message. “Troubleshoot.”

The words 'troubleshoot' flashed in front of the warning sign, prompting both to disappear. In their place, several two-dimensional boxes appeared, the information on them flashing by as it searched for all the solutions it had available to it.

Several more boxes appeared, each with a different course of action.

“Let's see... Merge all souls into one for the duration of the game?” The old man read aloud.

“Hell no! I won't be sharing a body with any of you!” The gauntlets' personification cried out, not looking winded from his fight.

“I don't like the sound of that either.” The old man said, shaking his head. “What say you, Perseus?”

“I'm not to keen on the idea of merging with anyone other than what was originally part of me. So, that's a no. The next one reads... separate all souls for the duration of the game, deciding among the group which one will be the actual first player, designating the others as player one point two and so on.”

“Wait, does that mean I'll have an actual body?” The foul-mouthed soul asked. “If so, then I'm all for it!”

“I don't like the idea of my other selves running around freely though. Given that the part of me that you just fought will likely be evil down to the very core... well, best not to think on what he would do.”

“So, you admit you're really evil deep down?” His guilt asked, narrowing his bloodshot eyes at Percy.

“Look, will you just go away?” Percy barked angrily. “I don't need you to constantly hang every little thing I do wrong over my head!”

“I will never leave.” His guilt whispered, narrowing his eyes even further till they looked closed. He gave a pained breath before moving to look like he was sitting down in the blackness.

Percy could feel his eyes watching him constantly, looking for any sign of weakness to exploit, but payed him no mind. As long as he didn't let him get to him, he'd be fine.

“Erase all so- nope. Definitely not an option.” The spirit of the boots said, pushing the box away.

“Can we just pick one already?”

“Be quiet. We're trying to work this contraption out. Why don't you look through these to find a suitable option?”

The gauntlets' spirit grumbled, crossing his arms.

“Isn't there a way this thing can create a solution that would fit our needs?” Percy asked, mostly to himself. “I mean, if it can do so much, why not?”

“Damn it, why couldn't you have told us earlier?” The personification of the gauntlets yelled, waving his arms around in his anger. “Fine! Since the weak ass human over there doesn't want the darker part of him running free, we would have gone with the first option! But me and the old sack of bones over there,” He yelled, thumbing over at the spirit of the boots. “Don't want to be stuck as a literal part of him! So, you'd better do your damnedest to make a solution that will make that possible!”

“You're a very angry person.” Percy said, raising an eyebrow.

“Shut it!”

'Three parts of the same soul, two other souls still connected to the main player one. Request: Merge the souls that were originally one, while keeping the two other souls apart for the duration of the game. Is this correct?'

“Yes, for the love of all things decent, yes!”

There should be no guessing who that was.

“Well, I can't say I'd be against having a body for once...” The eldest looking mused. “But, you really need some guidance in our powers. So, until I deem you adequate enough to work out the intrinsic power's I grant by yourself, I'm going to be stuck with you.”

“Fuck that, the first thing I'm doing is hitting a bar. You do whatever it is you want to do, because I don't give a rat's ass about it!”

Percy's guilt looked at him, sighing in resignation once more.

“If I cannot possibly make you see the error of your ways, all is already lost. Do what you will.” He said before he was enveloped by the darkness.

Percy heard something in the distance, likely a scream of defiance before he felt that darkness wrap around him and pull him... somewhere.

~

Blinking, Percy found himself looking at the two personifications once more.

“Took you long enough.”

“How long was I gone?” Percy asked, looking at the more reasonable of the two.

“Well, considering there's no way to tell time in here, I'd have to guess an hour or so.” The old man shrugged.

“Well, damn. At least we can continue, right?”

'Please select Player One point one.'

“Oh, come on!”

'It is important to know which player is first and foremost, the leader of the group. They will be the one with the most power in controlling the management of the system.'

“Management? Yeah, no. I hate making decisions.” The gauntlets claimed. “I'm more of a 'let others do all the work' kind of guy.”

“I guess that means that you're it.” The boots' spirit claimed, looking at Percy. “After all, this was your plan of action.”

Percy nodded, having the darkness wrap around him once more.

~

Upon opening his eyes once more, Percy was blasted with the loudest, most disorganized fanfare ever.

“Welcome! To! LIIIIIFEEEE!”

Laid before Percy's eyes was an incredible sight. Trillions upon trillions of what looked like stars, with incredibly large clusters dotted here and there. Some were flickering dimly, while others outshone those close to them. There were lines, both faint and bold, drawn between some with no organization, making it hard to follow one with eyes alone.

“This simulation allows you to take a break from reality or spice it up! Choose from an ever expanding pool of scenarios in which to live life anew!”

The voice was booming, surrounding Percy. It came from everywhere around him, slamming against his ear drums.

He noted it sounded vaguely like the Eronomicon, but with more robotic droning.

“And now, a word from the creator...”

Another box popped up, showing a video feed.

An old... no, old didn't begin to cover his age. An absolutely ancient man appeared in the video, lying in a bed. He had a multitude of machines attached to the metal frame of his bed and his body, monitoring a great number things. His heartbeat, his breathing, brain activity, blood flow and so on.

“Hello, who I am to assume is the Harem god. If you are watching this, then the absolute worst has not come to pass. While it isn't the best situation, but the fact that this video exists is grand enough. That would mean that my greatest achievements, my life's work, survived as well. You have no idea how happy that makes this old man.”

His voice, despite his appearance, was strong. Was it really his voice though? Percy doubted it. This man could barely breath, let alone speak.

“However, that also means that I am long dead, and likely something far, far worse than the clutch of the Reaper. In fact, I would much prefer death's cold embrace... If it existed within my world. A god, I mean. One who governed anything in a way only a god could. Unfortunately, the truth of the matter, that no gods exist that watched over my world is the sole reason that I have, by the time you've watched this, ceased to exist.”

All the machines shuddered, seeming to phase out for a moment.

“No... It is a certainty that I have been consumed by the void. There is not much time left for this universe, and my creation has damned it to die a final death.”

The ancient fell silent, the world phasing once more. A machine vanished, not returning once the phenomenon had passed.

“Already, it begins.” He mused sadly. “Though, should this survive, I wish to explain the reason for this mess. But, I will leave you a challenge. I will leave bits and pieces of the story around the various game worlds for you to search for. And I would like you to believe me when I say it will be my life's story. A way to prove that once, T'quaro Fstaurla existed. As a side note, this message will play in each of the games upon the first start up.”

Again, the world phased. This time, part of the background vanished, leaving Percy with the image of the void swallowing the sky.

“I cannot stay much longer. Is that everything?”

That was the Eronomicon. How it had a physical voice, he didn't know.

“I have one last thing to say to the Harem god, and then you can leave. Harem god, if you can grant this remnant of a man one last request, it would be to enjoy my last creations. They have cost far more than you can ever begin to imagine.”

With that, the video was cut, leaving Percy to stare at where the video had been. Beyond that, the stars, the worlds, all twinkled, blissfully ignorant of the price of their existence.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Heavy, isn't it?”

Percy merely turned his head, looking at the new person.

Like the spirit of the gauntlets, they were utterly plain, with no real distinguishing characteristics that one couldn't find in a billion other universes. Even the lack of definite gender wasn't strange.

While not featureless exactly, it was about as plain as one could be.

“I take it you're another part of this?”

“Correct. I am the main artificial intelligence of the game core you currently have inserted into the console. I take it from your question, as well as the lack of data on the shared data space of the console, that this is the first time you've logged in.”

“Yeah.” Percy said, nodding. “So, are you here to help me or something?”

“With the start up and initial questions, yes. After that, most of my time will be devoted to making sure everything is running as it should. Tutorial programs will be available to you afterwords, should you choose to accept their help.”

“That would be nice. I really don't know technology all that well. Going to universes that are still stuck in the dark ages or working with those that cannot handle anything more advanced than steam power can really distance a person from technology as a whole.”

“Very well. I shall try to provide all the answers I can. Ask away.”

“Thanks.” Percy said, nodding once again as he pondered his first question. “So... I didn't see Rose or Millicent back there, before I came here. And,” He looked around the vast expanse. “I'm not seeing them around here anywhere.”

“Millicent and Rose?” The machine asked, confusion etched on its features for the smallest fraction of a second. “Oh, you must be referring to players two and three. They, along with players one point two and one point three are in a type of stasis at the moment. None of them are aware of time passing, nor will they be until the start of the gaming session. It was programmed this way to prevent fights from breaking out over decisions of game configuration.”

“So, that back there, with the other souls-”

“An error debug room. Your real body is touching items that have sufficiently advanced souls, as well as repressed facets of your own soul. That would explain the multiples of you. I am also to tell you that they have not been permanently repressed for the duration of the game, and they may be able to give themselves an avatar.” The A.I. said, as blasé as one could get.

“Great.” Percy grumbled. “Thanks for the warning.”

“Do not thank me. It is merely protocol.” It said. “Now, any more questions?”

“Not off the top of my head, no.”

“Very well. Then let us begin the start up tutorial.”

From there, it was a long, but fast process of the main A.I. giving Percy the gist of how things went. It even went so far as to load up a few worlds to show him what different icons on start up would mean.

The interface of the game could be used like a touch screen, or with vocal commands. It didn't matter which language he spoke them in, seeing as how the book had given the knowledge about languages to it during the time he contained it.

It could also be activated with pure intent, willing the game to do the work. But, in order to do that, one had to either communicate solely with intent, or the player had to have an incredibly offensive, controlling will that could fight against legions of the best of the best the multiverse had to offer in terms of battles of wills.

There were so many configuration options and settings just for world creation it took up what seemed like three hours just to explain a quarter of it all. With all the customization available, he could decide on things up to a universal scale, such as the number of galaxies, the size of the galaxies, the number of stars, star systems and actual planets. Comets, shooting stars, constellations that he could create from scratch, and so on.

It went on further down, from the number of planets that had life on them, how intelligent the life was, how fast the life would progress, Etc. down to the smallest details of how the atoms worked, and even further then that.

Looking at the options, he could give sentience to a rock! Not a rock monster, or a god of earth either. But just a simple, ordinary rock.

Now he was wondering what a rock would think of...

Even supernatural elements were customizable. From microbiological virus of supernatural origins to cosmos eating horrors that could turn you inside out without even knowing you were there. Pantheons of preset deities existed, with the ability to mix and match. Or, if he wanted, he could create an entirely new pantheon of gods that he created, customizing everything from what they held dominion over to their personality.

Heck, he could even control whether or not they had free will or souls! They, of course, being anything created for the game session, obviously.

Remembering the conversation he had with the Eronomicon and how he could, in theory, make his power infinite using this item... It seemed like there was nothing to stop him.

“And that concludes the start up tutorial. If you need the message repeated, you can find individual tutorials that can help you in a briefer manner.” The A.I. Said, the two of them back at the main menu with the twinkling expanse of worlds. “Once we are finished here, I will doing my job of making sure everything is running at optimum capacity with no errors. Unless there is something horribly wrong, you won't see me until you finish your first game session. Before I go, are there any more questions?”

“Yeah, just one.” Percy said. “Now, when I was outside and the console was, uh, 'plugging' into the Eronomicon, it said that it was downloading additional content. What, exactly, does that mean?”

“It means that the console has created copies of the items for use inside the games. And, unless something is added or changed inside the Eronomicon, it will be a one time thing.”

“Makes sense, I suppose. Thanks for all this.”

“As I said earlier, don't thank me. It's the procedure I was programmed to follow, no matter what. Even if I somehow went rouge, I would have to do this.” It said, eyes half-lidded. “The creator was very thorough in all his endeavors, as you'll see from his video logs. And now, I bid you farewell.”

With that, the form of the A.I. Sort of blinked out, like how one would see in cartoons when electronic screens were turned off.

Had the little noise and everything.

Turning back to the main menu, with the backdrop of stars that represented the worlds, he hit the option for a new game.

“Now let's get started.” He said, looking for anything that he thought would work.
