“Can't be too advanced technologically.” He muttered to himself, watching an entire portion of the list disappear. In the field of stars, he idly noticed a few disappearing at the same time.

“Magic is a must for part of the training.” Once again, portions of the list and the connecting stars vanishing from the list of choices.

It went like that for a while. Percy thought over the specifics of what he wanted for training, what would be necessary. The list grew shorter and shorter, from the impossibly high numbers that had no names as of yet, down to a small several hundred thousand for the moment.

“Countries to conquer. At least one pantheon of deities. An ongoing war is optional. Monsters of all kinds. The threat of danger would be a good motivator and challenge for her, so there has to be some legitimate threat. Other supernatural elements are necessary as well.”

For what would likely have been hours upon hours, he listed both the specific needs and the vague wants and optional things that would enhance the experience. From the several hundred thousand that he had after weeding out the candidates that didn't fit in with his plans, he had finally whittled it down to just six worlds.

“All of these seem like good candidates, really.” He said, looking over the small list. Compared to what it was, it was smaller than an atom. The vast expanse of blackness, which had once been full of stars and lights, was now empty. Just those six worlds to break the unending black space. “It's so hard to choose between them as well.”

“Having a hard time? Perhaps a crossover would suit your needs.”

Another being blinked into existence in front of Percy, as nondescript as the last A.I., but still different.

“You the world selection and creation tutorial?”

“Of course. Who else would I be?” It said, looking at the tiny little lights. “As I said, it seems like you're having trouble deciding what world to use, despite having sorted through so many.”

“I figured these worlds are the best for my current needs. And they all have something that sets them apart from the other five in this particular group.”

“I see.” The A.I. Said, moving close to the lights.

They were floating in a circle now, orbiting an invisible sun. The A.I. looked over each one, analyzing the details of each world without having to look at the screen Percy was using.

“Well, if you were to combine all six, that would solve your problem.” It told him. “Of course, there would be conflicts in world settings that would have to be worked out, but that's not so hard. But,” It paused, picking up one of the stars as it passed. “This world here is a nexus world. It connects to other worlds, whether you want it to or not. You see these little threads leading away from it?”

Peering closer, Percy did see them. They were tiny, fading away millimeters from the light of the star, which made it hard to see with a casual glance. There were hundreds of them, all fading into the darkness.

“These threads mean that worlds are connected. One or two, and it's likely just a few small things that connect them. But, once those threads reach at least fifty, it becomes a nexus world. That allows travel between worlds that are connected with absolute ease, when you find the right gateway. Even worlds that aren't selected for a crossover. If you have a cross over between these six worlds, those gateways will still be accessible. And, seeing how many threads this world has, you're likely to stumble upon one every other week for at least one years, even if you stay in a hundred square miles of where you start. You're also more likely to have settings from other worlds lapse into existence for a time, though it's very unlikely they'll be in effect for more than a few weeks.”

“I'm not even going to pretend I fully understand what you're saying, but alright. I'd like to have a crossover with these six worlds, if you don't mind.”

“Well, you're the player.” The A.I. said, shrugging.

The A.I. wove its hand over the seven worlds, causing a second set to appear next to it. Gathering the second set into its other hand, it squeezed the balls of light into one single orb, six times the size of one star.

“There you are. One crossover world, to use at your leisure. Now, all you have to do is adjust the settings when you select it, fiddle with a few more options and you can start. Have fun.”

With that, the being blinked out as well, leaving Percy with one world in a 'tab', as the main A.I. called it earlier.

Tapping the icon with his finger, the menu filled up with statistics. The star, now the only one in the black expanse, grew to the size of a small moon as it took on features, such as continents, oceans, mountains, etc.

There was a flashing button, labeled as settings, that Percy hit.

“Fuck...” Percy said, looking at the list of customization options for the world. “I just want to get started!”

~ Unknown length of time later ~

'Do you wish to apply these settings?'

“Yes, for the love of creation, I do!” He all but yelled, hitting the apply button with all his might.

'Please select location you wish to start in.'

“I don't care! As long as Rose, Millicent and Myself are together, I don't give a rat's ass! This has taken too long already, and I just want to do something other than look at lists!”

'Acknowledged. Players One point one, Two and Three will start together. Players One point two and One point three will start else where. Location of start for all players is random otherwise. Also note, as you are player One point one, you will have administrative powers that are otherwise locked off.'

It was silent, the only movement being that of the screen randomly selecting several spots to place them.

'Start up is complete. Please enjoy your gaming session.'

Before Percy could even growl out 'finally' his vision exploded into a myriad of colors.

~

Percy blinked, feeling the sensation of solid ground beneath his feet.

“Perseus? Where are we?” Rose's voice asked from behind him.

Looking around, Percy saw that they were in a town square of some sort. People were walking around, not even paying them any mind despite his armor or Millicent's blue skin.

There was a fountain in the middle of the square, with three ways to leave and still be able to go somewhere. The fourth exit lead up to a large castle.

“From what I remember, it's some place called...”

“Ah!” He was interrupted by somebody running up to him. It was a rather skinny fellow with a protruding chin, with several bags around his waist and a large red hat atop his head. “Sir, I have a letter for you!”

That's not what he was expecting. “Who are you, and how do you know my name? In fact, how do I even have a letter? We just got here!”

“I'm the post man! It's my job to know everybody by their name!” He said, digging into a bag and drawing out an envelope. “Here you go!” He said, holding out the letter without answering any more questions.

It's like he didn't even hear them.

“What's it say?” Rose asked, leaning around him to look at the writing as he took it from the strange mans grasp.

“Well, I'll be off now. The post doesn't deliver itself, after all!” The man said before he turned around, taking off at full sprint.

Turning the envelope over, Percy took note of the fancy writing.

“From the royal family of Hyrule...”

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Ripping open the envelope, Percy pulled out the letter and skimmed through it.

“It seems we've been requested to stay in the palace at the behest of Princess Zelda during our stay in the lands of Hyrule.”

Boo-weep!

'New Objective: Head towards the castle!'

The world around the three paused, dimming slightly as a text box appeared in front of them.

“Oh my...” Rose said, putting a hand over her heart. “I wasn't expecting that.”

“Better not do that again.” Millicent growled. “When are we going to get on with the actual training?”

“Patience. And, I would guess that it will be doing this a fair number of times, so get used to it.” Percy told the girl. He continued to skim over the letter. “And, it says that her coronation is in a week's time.”

Boo-weep!

'New Objective: Attend the coronation of Princess Zelda in one week!'

Millicent barred her teeth at the text box, detesting how it opened up in her face like that with such an annoying sound.

If this happened much more, she was going to kill someone!

“Well, this is one way to start an adventure. In all my years of reading, I've never read one that started with a royal letter inviting someone to a coronation.” Rose said, looking back at the castle. “I wonder what our standing in this world is, if we've been asked to attend such an event.”

Boo-weep!

With a roar, Millicent dove at the text box, trying to smash it. Her reasoning being that if it was destroyed it wouldn't come back.

Unfortunately for her, she fell flat on her face, smashing her nose against the stone bricks of the town square.

'Would you like to know your character history in this setting?'

“Ask and ye shall receive, it seems.” Rose said. “Yes, I would, if it's not such a bother.”

Bwoop!

A large screen appeared in front of her, with several tabs along the top. There was inventory, avatar, quests, journal, skills, magic, map, perks, and the currently opened one, avatar bio.

“Just a quick read, please.” Percy said, seeing how it started from her birth. “I really need to do something other than sit around and read.”

“Do I have to?” She asked, looking up at him. She motioned around her, at the frozen world. “We have all the time we need to look it over. And, I don't know about you, but I intend to use this to make sure I know my fake background so I don't look like a fool.”

Percy sighed. “Fine, fine. But, at the very least, wait a day or two. I've done nothing but read, look at lists and make decisions for what seems like days. My mental capacity for such things has reached its absolute limit.”

“Really?” Rose asked, raising an eyebrow. “It didn't seem like more than a few moments at the most between the world going dark and appearing here. At least, for me.”

“No, trust me when I say it was a long, long time.”

“Poor baby...” Rose said playfully, smirking when Percy gave her a look that said 'don't push me'. “Fine, fine. It can wait, I suppose.”

“Good. Get up, Millicent.” Percy said to his daughter, watching as she punched the bricks, which were stained with her blood. The stones around her fist caved in, crumbling to dust. “We should go see what this Princess wants with us.”

~ Some time later ~

“That was nice.” Percy said, sitting in the room he and Rose had been granted. “To actually be greeted as an equal for once. How long has it been since that happened, I wonder?”

They had been led into the palace with fanfare, their arrival being announced throughout the city by both town criers and rumor, the latter the much faster way of letting the news be known.

Upon reaching the throne room, they had been greeted ceremoniously by Princess Zelda, welcoming them to her kingdom, and thanking them for coming all this way for the coronation. That it would surely go a long way to solidifying their places as good friends and allies.

Zelda was a fair maiden, every thing about her elegant. From her dress to the way she moved, not a hair was put out of place as she did her royal duties in welcoming the rulers of another land.

“I must ask though,” Rose said, turning away from the vanity she sat at. “Did you have Millicent labeled as our daughter for this... what did you call it?”

“A game session, and no, I didn't.” Percy answered truthfully. “The only thing I made sure of in our history is that I still had the title of Overlord and the position of the ruler of the infernal abyss. Other than that, I told it to fabricate the rest of our lives in this world.”

Standing up, Percy walked over to his queen in this world, looking in the mirror. “However, my greatest surprise was that this device held a copy of our world. It would seem there is more to this than I thought.” He mused.

“Hmm... Maybe.” She thought, picking up a brush as she turned back around. “But what of Millicent's training?”

“It will still proceed as planned, don't you worry.” He told her.

“Aye, and your training as well.”

Instead of shrieking, as one would normally do when a new voice unexpectedly joins a private conversation in a private room, Rose merely turned around to look at the newcomer.

She had a lot of experience keeping calm when someone appears out of thin air with Percy.

“Ah, it's you.” She heard Percy say to the old man with the tattered cloak.

“Yes, it's me.” The old man snarked at Percy. “Don't sound so surprised now.”

“Percy, who is this?” Rose asked calmly.

“Ah, right. Rose, this is the spirit of my boots. Boots, this is my lovely wife, Rose.”

The ancient spirit fixed Percy with a hard glare. “You call me boots again and I'll leave you in the middle of the void. At least call me by an actual name.” The spirit paused, thinking. “ Thom will do.”

“Very well, Thom.” Percy said, not wanting to deal with such a trivial matter as a name. “So, what brings you here?”

“You deaf? I already said that we'll work on your training as well!”

“Right, right. Sorry. I'm still at my mental limit, and some sleep will likely do me some good.”

“Sure, sure.” Thom said, rolling his eyes as he sat on the windowsill. “I'll see you on the morrow then.”

With that, the old spirit melded into the dying light of the setting sun, leaving Percy alone with Rose.

“Anyone else I should know about?” She asked, quirking an eyebrow.

“Actually, yes. The spirit of my gauntlets is elsewhere. From the few words I exchanged from him, he's not all that pleasant of a fellow.”

“Then, pray tell, what exactly are you wearing on your hands and feet?” She asked, looking at the gauntlets and boots that looked identical to the ones he wore in the real world.

“I'm just going to say that it's like when I split my mind into two bodies. I am both here,”

“And here.” His newly conjured second body said from the ceiling. “And, as you can see, I still retain the abilities.”

“Oh? And what about that new aura of yours? The one that caused you to stay away from Eres and myself?” She asked. “As you can see, I'm not being affected by anything, since my mind is still my own.”

Both Percy's blinked, looking at one another. “Yes... quite curious.” He said, letting his mind become whole again. “Skills menu.”

The world around them dulled once again, the light evening breeze that flowed in through the window coming to a halt.

“Search for Aura.” He told it, making the list of skills he had shorten considerably. “Let's see... Lust aura, evil aura, dominating aura, aura of darkness, power aura, death aura... Ah, here it is. Imbecile's aura.” Both he and Rose suppressed snorts of laughter at the name. “The sheer presence of this person causes people to do incredibly foolish things, makes them susceptible to being coerced into things they might not do, and saps the intelligence of those affected by this aura. While a passive skill, it does not work on friends or allies. Can be unleashed to full power if used as an active skill, but will affect allies as well as enemies. Can be used during negotiations with friends or allies, though it must be activated.”

Closing the menu, he sat down as the world resumed moving once more.

“Now that,” He said, a grin forming on his face. “Is incredibly helpful.”

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“And... done!” Percy said, finishing his reading of his created back story. “I could go back to sleep already.”

“Oh shush.” Rose said, almost done with her own life story. “Quit being so dramatic. I've seen you calmly listen to those council meetings back home that took hours on end with all their bickering.”

“I think it comes with the position of Overlord, if not the status of a god.” Percy said. “Though, it's more likely the latter than the former, really. Or maybe it just runs in my father’s side of the family.”

“Whatever the reason, I ask that you keep a lid on it. Why don't you go see if our daughter is doing her reading?”

“I doubt she is.” Percy sighed, scratching his chest. “But, it would be something to do.”

Pushing open the door to the guest quarters he and Rose had been given, Percy walked out into the halls of the time-stilled castle. Even as early as it was, the sun barely reaching over the mountains in the distance, there were servants about, frozen in time as they went about their daily tasks.

“Quest menu.” He said, not bothering to watch where he was going.

Looking at the window when it popped up, he looked at the active quests.

“Alliance with the kingdom of Hyrule...” He read, one of the objectives beneath it the one that popped up first in the town square. “So that's part of the reason why there was no notification that we'd completed a quest.” He mused. “And why it said to meet with the Princess when I woke up.”

Opening the map, he also thought what the game told him about 'administrative powers' or some such. He figured that it would be on one of the tabs, like the avatar bio or inventory... but no! He'd searched through the skills list, perused the perks tab, but found nothing! Not one thing that said 'administrative'!

“So, what could the game have been talking about?” He asked, entering the room Millicent had been given for the duration of their stay, and where her little blip on the map was.

She was still sleeping, the blankets laying in such a fashion it looked like a nest around her. Her hair was splayed out, her blue skin clashing against the red sheets. She was breathing softly, her hands balled into fists as she jerked around every now and then.

“Must be dreaming of battle.” He said, somewhat proud, and somewhat saddened. Proud that she would be able to look after herself and hold the title of Overlord with honor, sad because of the hell he had left her to face since she was two and a half years old and the fact she needed to fight.

He sighed, thinking of how, before the Eronomicon, he would have wished for a world in which his kids didn't have to fight. How he would have settled down with Annabeth, monsters afraid to go near them due to fighting the primordials and coming out on top. Lulling Gaea back to sleep, pushing back Tartarus as he threatened to engulf the world in the abyss.

Knowing this would have come to pass, having seen the plan the fates had weaved for him if he hadn't been marked by the Eronomicon, made it so much sadder.

Shaking himself from his thoughts, Percy proceeded to shake Millicent awake.

“Get up.” He said, letting her swat his hand away with a grunt. “There's so much to do before we can begin training, and it would be better for you to wake up and take care of it now.”

She spoke to him, using a language that would make someone who didn't understand lose five minutes of memory.

“You know that doesn't work on me.” He said with a frown. “Now... UP.”

Against her will, Millicent was forced from her sleep as her body moved to acknowledge the command of raw power.

It was not the first time such a thing had happened. She had told many a minion who had come to wake her to leave with the language, making the already forgetful browns that woke her forget why they were even there. In turn, Percy had commanded her to wake, letting a language of power, one that demanded obedience, seep into his words.

Always left his throat sore for a while though.

Millicent glowered at him, wishing his head would explode in her anger.

“Don't give me that look.” He said, rubbing his throat. “You had best read up on your history for this scenario. After that, I will see about finding an area where we can train.”

“Yes, 'Father.'” She spat out, sleepily bringing up her avatar bio.

Not that Percy would hold it against her. He wasn't much of a morning person himself.

Leaving her to grumble as she read up on just the necessities, as Percy was sure she would find only what was needed to survive this scenario with some pride intact, Percy started to wander the halls.

Since the world was paused, he took his time in wandering throughout the castle. It was a tall structure, with grand halls and staircases on most floors. There was a barracks to one side, complete with stables for horses bred for war. A graveyard stood on the opposite side, filled with the bodies of the royal family and their most trusted servants.

“Why not have a large tomb for the royal family?” Percy wondered, looking at a weathered headstone that was barely legible.

Moving along on his self-guided tour, Percy found himself back at the entrance to the castle. Two guards were positioned there, though they were not at attention, as they should have been. They were lazing against the wall, weapons forgotten as they talked to one another from across the way. Cups that smelled of ale were haphazardly hidden away, and anyone who was looking for them could have seen them.

Now, Percy had never let the minions on guard duty slack off. They were alert, and ready for any attack.

To see such disregard for the importance of their post, the negligence of their princess's safety, even during a time of peace, he was so incensed that he took a swing at one of the men.

Instead of bouncing off, like he expected after Millicent had tried to slug a guard across the face during one of the other pauses, his fist connected solidly with the man, sending his, now unfrozen, form to the ground.

The man cried out as his helmet hit the stone steps, a tooth being jarred out violently.

He looked around rapidly, holding his bleeding mouth.

“Wha's goin' on?” He asked, spitting out a bit of blood onto the ground.

Percy stared, not expecting that in the slightest.

The man stood up, his armor shaking. He turned to look at Percy, lifting a finger with what he could only imagine being wide eyes beneath his helm.

“You!” He cried out, before he cowered upon seeing who he was talking to.

“'You' What?” Percy asked, seeing this supposed soldier cower. He knew he could be imposing, but he wasn't even trying to intimidate the person! Was the guard that afraid of him? Was it his stature, his title, the supposed ruthlessness he had when angered in this world?

The man didn't answer, averting his helmeted gaze as he nursed his bleeding mouth.

“Pathetic.” Percy muttered, turning his head away as he walked back into the castle with disgust. He didn't know the man had become frozen in time once more, not really caring either way.

'You have attacked one of the palace guards! Reputation with Princess Zelda has decreased! You'll be sure to get an earful about this!'

Slamming his hand against the close button, Percy stormed his way through the palace to his room.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy was in the throne room, having been brought before the Princess under armed guard. He was currently listening to Zelda coolly berate him, holding her sword like the gavel of a judge, ready to bring it down on him at one misstep.

“So what say you, Lord Perseus?” She asked, eyes boring twin holes into him. “What defense do you have for attacking a soldier at their post?”

Percy sighed, shrugging. “Honestly, I let my temper get the better of me. Though, I will say that, had I been an enemy, the castle would already be littered with bodies with little notice, until well into my massacre”

“Oh? Should I take that as a threat?” Zelda asked, narrowing her eyes.

“Take it however you wish, though I don't mean it as a threat. Just an observation.” Percy said, looking at the guards around him with their weapons at the ready. Their grip was calm, no shaking swords or shields. “These guards are competent, unlike that slack-jawed layabout at the gate. No drinking on the job, weapons at the ready should I twitch in a way that they deem a threat to your safety, minds alert... Good soldiers. You should wish that every soldier under your command was like this.”

Zelda regarded him for a moment before looking at another soldier. “Go see if what he said was true.”

With a salute, the soldier did as told, hurrying as fast as his armor would allow.

“You likely won't find anything, since the two that were standing guard looked like they had done this before. They knew of a spot to stash the evidence, and if I had been in another spot then I wouldn't have noticed. They were at utter ease, talking to one another without a weapon at their waist or in their hands. While I admit that my reaction was more than necessary, and incredibly out of line, seeing lax guards has always been one of my greatest aggravations. And, as my wife will tell you, I can have quite the nasty temper. Though, to be completely honest with everyone here, I could have done so much worse, and you could have been down one guard.”

“Be that as it may, I cannot allow you to attack the palace guard. But,” She said, sitting in her throne. “We shall see if your story holds any measure of truth first.”

It would be many minutes till the guard returned with information that, yes, the guards had been drinking at their posts. So, to bide his time, Percy looked around the throne room.

It stood at the top of the castle, unlike many other castles that he had seen. It was large, with an open archway for a door that would easily let something the size of Cerberus, when she was still the hound of Hades, enter. The windows were all stained glass, depicting various scenes of Hyrule's history, but always bearing the Hyrule family crest as well as the three golden triangles.

In fact, above the throne there stood a sculpture, of three feminine figures surrounding the triangles, one holding fire, another breathing wind, and the last with her arms wide open. The ceiling was vaulted, pillars arching up to hold the weight of the roof.

The throne itself was, in comparison to the rest of the room, modest. It was made of something that looked similar to gold, but was likely some metal that Earth, nor the world of the Overlord, had. It had red silk cushions on the seat and back, so that the ruler could rest easy as they did their duty to the people.

But, Percy thought to himself, the real jewel sat upon the throne.

As stated before, Princess Zelda was incredibly precise, every move she made being elegant and for a reason. She did not lean to one side in her chair, but sat poised should he try anything. Her sword was gripped firmly in her hand, laid across her lap ready to strike out. She did not blink unnecessarily, nor dart her eyes to look for the messenger.

He would come soon enough.

He brown hair was braided to frame her face, and a tiara rested on her brow.

Her dress was perfectly made, not a stitch out of place. It was designed to be as beautiful as the one who wore it, and the princess made it absolutely stunning.

Her blue eyes regarded him with a calm, icy coolness, wondering if she should still try for the alliance as she had planned.

The guard she had sent away trotted back in, barely breathing hard despite running up the stairs in full armor.

“Your highness, It seems that Lord Perseus was telling the truth. There was a skin full of ale, and one empty, found under a loose cobble stone that hadn't been placed right. We had found two cups as well, all showing signs of being recently used.”

“I see.” She said, looking at Percy. “It seems your story is true. Guards, leave us. I wish to talk with Lord Perseus alone.”

Every single soldier in that room saluted, turning on heel to leave the soon-to-be queen on her orders.

“As I said,” Percy told Zelda as she stood once again. “You should wish to have more soldiers like those under your command. The one this case involved was a sniveling coward. I must ask, are your armies getting soft in this time of peace?”

Giving him a sharp look, Zelda stepped down from her raised throne.

“Just because I allow my armies to relax during times of peace does not mean they are getting soft, Lord Perseus.” She said. “Not everyone practices your tactic of always having a standing army to fight at a moments notice.”

“I understand that, Princess.” Percy said, looking her square in the eyes. “Once again, I apologize for my behavior. If there is something I can do to make amends, I will do it.”

“We shall see how our talk of Alliance goes first.” Zelda told him. “Then we can talk about repaying small transgressions. I agree that the guards should not have been drinking, and if not for you, I would have reprimanded him myself. However, having his jaw so brutally attacked by you should be enough of a reminder.”

Percy stared at her for a second, to make sure he had heard that right.

“That was your attempt at a joke, wasn't it?” Percy said, daring to crack a knowing smirk at her.

“Perhaps...” She said, returning his smirk. “Though, I must ask. The guard said that the world seemed like a washed out painting, with not even a breeze, and his fellow guard was frozen in time. Was that your doing?”

“Frozen in time?” Percy asked, feigning curiosity. “I had nothing to do with that. In fact, I didn't know that time had frozen. Maybe he had a little too much to drink?”

Zelda gave him a sideways look, raising an eyebrow. “Maybe... Though, it is no secret that your wife is the most gifted magician in the known world. Perhaps she has a spell that would allow such a thing to be done.”

“While I admit that my wife is talented,” Percy said, remembering how Rose was apparently the greatest battle-mage the world had seen in a long time. “I doubt she could do something such as freeze time. Though, if you put her to the test, I'm sure she would be able to find something.”

Zelda nodded at him, walking past him towards the exit of the throne room. “Well, I do believe that this affair has been dealt with. Would you and your family care to join me for a late breakfast?”

“We would love to.” Percy said, walking beside her. “Though, I apologize in advance for my daughter's table manners. She spends too much time with the soldiers for myself or Rose to have drilled proper etiquette into her head.”

'Standing with Princess Zelda has risen! Becoming Allies will be much easier now!'

'New Title Available: Novice Negotiator!'

'Title?' Percy thought, before brushing it off. 'I'll look at it later.'
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Answering for crimes

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Begin!”

Red hair whipped in the wind as she ran as fast as she could in the heavy armor, arm pulled back with the hand made into a fist. She jumped over the leg sweep, bringing her fist crashing against Percy's unprotected face.

Percy retaliated, grabbing her arm and throwing her to the ground. He brought his foot up, ready to bring it down on her chest with enough force to snap steel in twain.

Rolling out of the way, Millicent got to her feet as she stared at Percy with anger. Blood was flowing from his nose, a pure golden color, as the nose itself was a smashed mess, the cartilage broken and twisted.

Pulling his foot from the ground, Percy ran at Millicent, leaning forward for a tackle.

Millicent dodged to the side, spinning so she could run after him. She jumped on his back, wrapping her hands around his neck and did everything in her power to kill him. Twisting, choking, jerking, snapping... even going so far as to try and gouge out his eyes with her fingers.

Before she could dig her fingers in, Percy grabbed her arm, pulling her to the side as he tossed her to the ground, where she rolled and sprang to her feet.

She was unprepared for the wall of shadow that rose up before her, slamming down on her with the intent to smother.

Percy watched as his shadow struggled to drag Millicent back to him, the now physical darkness struggling to contain his rage-filled child. There were a few times when it looked like she would rip through the absence of light, but a small exertion of his power over darkness caused it to clamp down like a vice.

It's not like he expected her to be able to fight him at full force, really. Even half force was going too far. While she would be much stronger in the future, enough for him to actually fight instead of toy with, for now she was still a child.

They were in the eastern fields, a swath of land that was mostly barren and unused. Percy had asked the princess if there was any place where he and his daughter could spar without causing much damage, seeing how their fights tended to cause small scale destruction.

She had allowed them the use of the field, seeing how no one used it since the bridge leading from the castle town had broke. While it would have been better to have it fixed, no one was complaining about it.

Strange, vulture-like birds sat in the trees, circling the wasteland that was the eastern field. It was barren, rocky and wholly unsuited for anything like agriculture. It was likely that, should expansion on the town become necessary, they would build on this field.

Percy rolled out of the way, sensing a type of light magic heading towards his back. Calling his shadow back, Percy turned to face this enemy with his mace forming from the darkness in his hand.

It was a winged person, bow in hand and drawn, a glowing arrow notched and ready to fly.

She wore a white tunic, hemmed with golds and reds along the bottom, fastened on her shoulder with a large red jewel. A brown belt with a silver lining and golden triangular buckle kept the tunic from fluttering in the wind. Leather bracers with gold and bronze rings on the ends protected her arms, with another ring of gold decorating her upper left arm. On her feet were beige leather sandals with overlapping bands over the top, decorated with tufts of white fur. To top it all off, a golden laurel crown sat on her head, keeping her long brown hair from whipping around as she flew.

“Dark Lord Perseus! In the name of the goddess of Light, I shall banish you!” She yelled, letting the arrow fly.

“Hey, can't you see I was doing something!” Percy yelled, jumping out of the way of the arrow. “And-” He jumped again, another arrow almost piercing his leg. “Hey! Watch where-”

“I saw all I needed to!” She yelled, letting arrow after arrow fly, each one magically forming from pure light. “I didn't figure you for a kidnapper on top of all your other crimes!”

“Kidnapper?” Percy yelled, vanishing just seconds before each arrow struck him. “That's my daughter!”

“Daughter?” The angel asked, holding her fire. She looked at Millicent, who was trying to regain her barrings after being held in darkness and dragged around. “Ah! The barbarian Princess!”

She seemed to debate with herself, shaking her head as she took aim at him once more.

“Still, you were using dark magic! That alone is enough reason to bring you to justice!”

“Yes, I was using dark magic, but it wasn't black magic!” Percy said, throwing his arms up in the air. “When will people learn that dark is not evil? There's a difference, for crying out-” Percy was cut short, grunting as a light arrow pierced his chest.

“Stop trying to defend yourself!” The angel yelled. “You will be shown judgment by the Lady Palutena!”

Arrow after arrow she fired, each one finding their mark in Percy. He grunted after each hit, feeling the light energy seep into him.

'Damn, I knew I should have killed that god of light a few months ago. Wouldn't have this problem now.'

It wasn't that it hurt, necessarily. But the light energy was conflicting the dark energy he possessed, gained after killing the forgotten god and taking over the infernal abyss. It was hard to make his body respond with the polar opposite energies swirling around in him.

“I won?” The angel said, looking at the arrow riddled form of Perseus. “Well, that was surprisingly easy.”

“You're right. It was too easy.” A dark voice said from behind her.

The angel spun around with a small scream, bow coming apart into duel swords.

Percy floated in the air, his dark aura keeping him afloat as his eyes burned through the miasma that surrounded him.

“That was a very foolish thing to do.” Percy growled at her.

“Eh heh heh... I'm sorry?” The angel said with a nervous laugh, wings backing her away slowly.

“And where do you think you're going?” Another voice said, once again behind her.

Spinning again, the Angel came face to face with another Percy, this one surrounded by an aura that gave off the smell of fresh graves and rotting corpses. The air around him twisted into faces that screamed in untold agony, the earth beneath him becoming even more bleak. This one also wore armor made of bone, human and animal alike. The very heat of the air was sucked into him, leaving the cold of death behind as his skin became gaunt with rotting skin.

“Uh... Uh...” She tried to form words, looking back and forth between the two, wondering how to get out of this mess. “Lady Palutena... A little help please?” She finally asked, looking at the sky.

“Yes.” Both halves of the to-be harem god said, the body riddled with arrows dissipating along with the arrows. “We want to know why we've been attacked. We have done nothing during our stay in these lands to warrant such an attack!”

“Lady Palutena... Any second now would be good...” The girl squeaked out.

Her altitude dipped for a second, like she was about to drop, before she shot off into the sky like a bungee cord had been attached to her back.

“Oh no you don't!” Both Percys yelled, flying up after her.

The angel looked down, seeing the two parts of an angry god racing after her. “Oh boy... this isn't going to be fun.”

The two halves of Percy raced after her, too angry to even think about using the power of the boots to catch her at the moment. They were running with the powers they had, and them alone as they flew higher and higher, reaching the clouds.

Bursting through the fluffy looking layer, the chase became even more heated. The angel was ducking under the blasts of dark energy and death magic, diving in and out of the clouds in an attempt to lose them.

But Percy would not be so easily escaped.

“Not good...” She breathed to herself, narrowly avoiding the newest blast of dark energy that nearly took her foot off.

Percy saw her wings lose the blue glow for a fraction of a second, making her lose some altitude and speed before correcting herself.

“Aw, is the little angel getting tired?” The dark Percy asked, a savage grin spreading across his face.

“Do not think you can escape me so easily.” The Percy clad in bone rasped, his voice rough and grating.

“Ah Jeez. Sorry about this Lady Palutena, but it looks like we'll have to fight them on our doorstep.” She said, speeding up as they neared a large ruined city atop the clouds.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Training and angels

choices: Palutena tells him what she knows, trying to make amends
Palutena doesn't tell him, thinking he'll side with them to spite her
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Touching down as the blue glow left her wings, the angel continued to run. She was far faster than any human, and so was barely able to outrun Percy as the two halves of his power tore through the already ruined temple.

Whatever the death half touched crumbled into dust, being blown away in his flight. Whatever the dark half touched turned black, twisting into something that could not be recognized as stone before it collapsed in on itself.

“Lady Palutena! Please, keep the centurions away! Who knows what will happen to them if they try to fight!”

It seemed that her prayer worked, as no help came, despite Percy both sensing and seeing multitudes of life, female at that, just out of mortal sight.

All of them had the same sentence above their heads, dictating just how to earn their loyalties.

Earn the loyalty of Palutena.

But Percy paid it no mind, his focus solely on the one angel, who also had the sentence above her head as she ran.

“Your lungs must be burning by now, little angel!” The dark half taunted, dragging his hand along the wall he flew by, purposely touching everything he could.

“Stop running, and face your dues!”

'He's right...' The angel thought, her breathing becoming more ragged with every breath. Sweat poured down her beet red face, the muscles in her legs burning with every motion. 'But I can't stop until Lady Palutena figures out what to do! I'm in no condition to use the three sacred treasures either...'

As she turned a corner, a loose stone caught her foot. With a yell, she went head over heel into the wall.

Sitting up as she rubbed her head, she looked around for an escape.

“A dead end?” She asked, groaning. “Why do we even have these?”

“Caught you!” They cried in unison, rounding the corner.

“Can't run now!”

“You cannot escape!”

“Ahem...”

Turning around, the two halves of Percy were assaulted by the form of a goddess.

She had skin the color of polished ivory, green hair flowing down to her ankles. Her emerald eyes were staring daggers at both bodies of Percy. She wore a flowing white dress, simple if not for the numerous golden decorations that adorned her body. A large golden necklace, two belts with many golden ornaments hanging from them with another large red gem to hold them, bangles and bracelets, a large laurel crown made of, you guessed it, gold. The last ornament she had on her body was a golden bracer that covered almost the entirety of her left arm, ending with a large, feathery design at the top that curved outwards.

In her hands were clasped a scepter made of gold, once again, and some strange blue metal, with a floating blue ball hovering over the top, as well as a shield that shone like a mirror. It didn't look very durable, but as anyone with even a passing interest in magical items would tell you, anything wielded by a god was nigh unbreakable no matter how fragile it seemed.

“Lady Palutena!” The angel yelled, seeing the countenance of her goddess.

“Keep quiet now,” She said, not exactly harsh but not too kind either. “Dark Lord Perseus. I ask that you cease chasing my general and causing destruction to my kingdom.”

“Why should I?” The dark one hissed out, touching the wall next to him out of spite, causing the entire wall, and a portion of the ceiling, to turn black and collapse in on itself.

“She attacked us, when we had done no wrong!” The one shrouded in death claimed.

“Yes, yes. I know what she did. I was watching the whole time.” Palutena said, only looking slightly miffed about the wall. “However, you must admit that what you were doing looked mighty suspect.”

“We do not care!” The dark one roared out. “We do not take unprovoked attacks lightly!”

“I understand that. However, I insist you calm down. I will not let you destroy my kingdom because of a mistake.”

Both Percys glared, one at Palutena and the other at the angel, for a long while. The angel dare not move, and Palutena kept calm, though a divine glow did start to form around her.

“Very well.” They growled, their respective aura's fading away. They slowly drifted to the floor, the powers made manifest by anger fully reigned in once they touched down.

“You'd better not shoot me in the back again, little angel.” The Percy looking at the less divine of the three said before he faded away, the only Percy left looking at Palutena. "Now, make this worth my time, or there will be little left of these ruins."

The glow around Palutena faded as well, though she never stopped levitating a few inches above the ground.

“Thank you.” She said, somewhat forced given his last threat. “Now, how about we go to my main temple to discuss this. There is something you should know about.”

~

Percy was sitting in a relatively quaint room for the palace of a goddess. While it still had the flair to it that mortals could not possess, it was not so over the top like most other temples he had seen.

He had sent a piece of his mind to Millicent, telling her that something had come up and that she should go talk to Rose about starting her magical training, if only in theory. Of course, this was done as the world was paused, as he had to reread the little tidbit in his bio about his relationship with the kingdom of light as well as a small bio about the faction itself.

Honestly, the centurions sounded exactly like the minions... except the minions were more versatile, autonomous and incapable of flight.

Sure they were relatively strong, and could fly under their own power, but other than that they really had nothing to really stand out.

That aside, his relationship with the faction was... strange. He, being a dark lord, was their prime target and suspect in almost all things. If something happened in the world of mortals, they would assume he had a hand in it. But, without proof, they could not, would not, attack him.

They also wondered why someone like Rose, who mainly used her magic to heal when not at war, would even think of being his queen. Such a delicate, though powerful, person such as her with the big bad Overlord who used her talents to further his hold on the world and blah blah blah.

“Typical. Always think that just because she can hold her temper that she's pure and innocent. The only reason Velvet has her beat in the bedroom is because Velvet spent time with succubi!” He said, glaring at Palutena. “And trust me, when she loses her temper, there've been swaths of land reduced to wastelands. She also has a mean backhand.” He finished, recalling the time Giblet was feeling frisky after getting shitfaced at the celebration of the creation of his world.

Rose was, for some reason or another, not feeling in the mood, and Giblet was too plastered to take a hint from anyone other than Percy. Even when drunk, the forge mistress was steady on her feet... and yet Rose knocked her on her ass like it was nothing with a single back hand.

Giblet complained about a welt on her face for the next week, wondering where she had gotten it. As for Rose, she had always wondered where the strength came from since.

“Maybe having so much sex did something to give her that.” He mused, looking at Palutena's frozen face. “Or, maybe it's because she's Millicent's mother. Ah well, it's not like you can hear me anyway. Don't know why I'm saying all this like you can.”

“Now,” Palutena said, continuing to move about the room like nothing had happened. “I know we haven't always seen eye to eye on things, what with you seeking to take over the world and all, but there's a reason my top angel assumed the worst.” She said, tossing some spices into a cauldron, taking a small spoon out to taste the concoction. “There's been a dark force on the rise, heading straight for Hyrule. It's ancient, powerful, and wholly unpleasant.”

“Like me?” Percy asked.

“Well, you are the keeper of hell, as well as a dark lord. Dark and unpleasant is your M.O., you know?” Palutena said, looking over her shoulder back at him.

Ah, yes. Did Percy forget to mention he was also the keeper of the inferno in this world?

Once again, it's something he didn't actually tell the game to do. It just sort of happened.

“And I figured you knew that hell is not a place where demons are born and bred.” Percy retorted.

“Well, you have to admit they do escape from there a lot.”

“Not my fault exactly that they like to rush through my realm when I'm busy with my kingdom.” Percy said, recalling the bit where he apparently hated how they escaped through his realm into the human world while he was gone. “Anyway, what's this evil that's coming? I want them to understand that their very existence has caused me an... inconvenience.”

“Right, inconvenience.” Palutena said, turning around to give him a deadpan look. “That's why you were tearing through my kingdom.”

“Forgive me for losing my cool when someone attacks me and claims that I've done something I haven't.” Percy snipped, crossing his arms. “Now, Tell me what's happening.”
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Wanton destruction caused in anger, and a goddess

choices: They enjoy the night, but notice something weird about the game
They enjoy the night, but it's interrupted near the end
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“I don't exactly know what it is myself. The only thing I can tell is that it wishes to subjugate the entire world and drown it in darkness. And it will start in Hyrule. That's why I had someone scouting out down there on high alert.”

“And, of course, my presence there automatically made me the prime suspect.” Percy retorted, feeling his anger grow once more.

“Well, you and I both know that you aren't the nicest person, so...” Palutena said, shrugging as she poured some greenish-blue liquid into the pot and stirred. “And you being there made her a bit jumpy. Couldn't you, I don't know, forgive her or something?”

“Let's see, your General attacked me for no reason, accused me of using the most heinous magicks, accused me of kidnapping my own daughter during training, filled me with that damned light magic you use, and then she insinuated that it would be so easy to take me down.” Percy said, calmly counting on his fingers. “I'm not seeing why I should let this slide, Palutena.”

Sighing, Palutena put down the carrot and knife she had.

“Well, if that won't change your mind...”

She turned around, finger to her lips as she pouted, giving him a look with watery eyes.

“Please~~” She asked, making her voice all sweet and adorable.

“No.” Percy told her adamantly. “And I find it offensive that you think I'll bow to any pretty face.”

Huffing once more, crossing her arms under her bust, Palutena twirled around back to the counter.

“Fine. What do you want from me to sweep this under the rug? If the other gods hear about this, I'll never hear the end of it.”

“How about you stop accusing me of everything bad that happens to mortals, for starters?”

Palutena turned around again to retort that it was his fault for the reputation, but Percy was already gone.

~

“Oh, hello Perseus.” Rose said, looking up from her book as he appeared in the living quarters. “Millicent just went to her room after almost blowing herself up with magic. I told her we would be taking it slow and start with theory, but she just had to take after her father in regards to her patience.”

“Good to see you too.” Percy said, rolling his eyes. “Did Thom come around at all?”

“I think he did, but I'm not quite sure. I thought I saw him in the window earlier, but when I tried to take a better look there was nothing there.” She said, pointing at the window the spirit had appeared on last night. “So, what exactly was it that required your attention?”

“Believe it or not, I was attacked by an angel.”

“A pretty face, or an actual angel?” Rose asked, smiling knowingly at him.

“Actual angel. Wings and everything. Do you remember what you read about a kingdom of light, with a leader named Palutena?”

Rose nodded. “Yes, I remember. Always pestering us, or at least our backstory selves. Claiming they were always doing the mortal world a favor by trying to kill you, always thinking I was being controlled or threatened in some way by you.”

“Now there's a thought.” Percy said, grimacing. “Anyway, it doesn't matter right now. What matters is that Palutena said the reason I was attacked was mostly because she sensed a dark presence that wanted to engulf the world, and that it was somewhere in Hyrule.”

“And?” Rose asked, eyebrow raised once more. “I know my husband can take care of any pesky tyrant-wannabe. The only question is, do you wish to do anything about it?”

“Actually, not really. I'd rather just go about the world doing whatever, the two of us training Millicent as I grasp the more complex, if basic, powers of the boots and gauntlets while working other things on the side. We've got at least eight years to work with, so why not make the most of it?”

“And the politics?”

“Always hated them anyway.” Percy said with a shrug. “Though, I really don't mind being treated like an equal around here. I just don't want the three of us to be wrapped up in some quest for the fate of the world.”

“Had too much of that in your old life?”

“Got it in one, my lovely queen.” Percy grinned, though it was slightly forced. “However, that doesn't really matter right now. How about we have a night on the town?”

“Really Perseus? I would think that you wouldn't be able to go anywhere in the town without somebody knowing who you, we, are.”

“Who said it had to be this town?”

“An excellent point.”

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“I must say,” Rose started, patting at her lips with a small cloth. “That was a good meal. Almost reminds me of my mother's cooking. I haven't had anything like that since I was a child.”

Their 'night on the town' had taken them to various towns across the world, courtesy of the world map giving the names and locations, as well as a little background on them all.

They were far away from the lands of Hyrule, far from the land known only as the Dominion that Percy ruled over. The dinner had been at, not a fancy restaurant or palace, but a small border town inn.

Rose's idea, really.

Not that Percy would complain. It was surprisingly good food, for what it was.

“I agree. The food was good, and I wouldn't mind coming back here again.”

“Neither would I. Now, how about we talk more in depth about the events of your day. I want to hear how you managed to insult our host in such a way that she had armed guards escort you to her.”

Percy shrugged. “Sure, why not. It all started after I left the room and had an... altercation with a guard about his lack of respect for his job.”

From there he went on to explain the events of the day, from having to stand on trial before the Princess to training with Millicent.

As he got to explain the fight with the angel, realizing he never got her name as Palutena always referred to her as her general, Rose brought something to his attention.

“You flew?” She asked, furrowing her brow. “I know that your boots allowed you to walk on anything you please, even the air itself, but flying is something new for you. How did you do that, and so naturally from what you describe?”

“I...” Percy paused, before he really started, to think over this piece of news. “How did I fly? And while using the powers of darkness and death? I really don't recall being able to do that in the real world. It's very strange, really.”

“And, since just before breakfast, none of those strange little boxes have popped up either. I thought they would be a little more common, if we got a quest from reading a letter.”

“Really? I hadn't paid any attention, really.” He said, thinking back on the tutorial program. “The A.I. Said that most things would have an impact... you know, like life does.”

“Can you figure out why?”

“Well, the most I can do is take a look at the skills menu, I think.”

With the usual sound, the menu popped up in front of Percy, pausing the game world around them.

“Search aura.”

Almost instantly, the list shortened down to a more manageable size.

“Let's see now... Aura of Darkness.” He said, reading silently as Rose did the same over his shoulder.

'Aura of Darkness - Level 2: All light within five feet is completely drawn into you, and all light up to ten feet away is dimmed by 40%. A feeling of general unease effects any person within thirty feet, even if they do not have direct sight of the user. Those with weak wills will go temporarily insane.'

“And... that's a bust.” Percy sighed. “Nothing about flying. I highly doubt the Death aura will say anything about the matter either.”

“Maybe you're going about this the wrong way.” Rose said, now shamelessly draped over him. “Maybe it's not an aura. Why don't you try searching just for darkness?”

“Couldn't hurt. New search, darkness.”

For a second, the list defaulted back to showing all skills, but quickly removed anything that had nothing to do with darkness.

At the top, there was the Aura of Darkness.

But, there was something new below it.

Something with sub-categories.

'Dark God Form - level 1: Darkness incarnate, the Corrupting Deity. Who are you in the dark? - Only accessible after training, or with strong enough emotions.

Poking the little box just beneath, Percy looked at the sub-categories of this.

Abilities include:

Flight – level 1: Take to the skies! Top Speed of 100 MPH. Higher levels increase top speed and acceleration.

Corrupting touch – level 1: Anything you touch is infected with darkness. Blessed and Holy items and materials crumble into nothing. People touched will be corrupted, bringing out the darkness that dwells within them. Current level does not allow slightly holy people, such as priests, or those with divine protection to be corrupted. Higher levels increase corruption per second (CPS), and allow you to infect holier beings.

Dark amplifier – level 1: Abilities that make use of darkness that are available without accessing the Dark God Form are boosted twofold when in Dark God Form. Higher levels increase multiplier.

Godly body – level 1: Physical stats are doubled. Health is tripled. Higher levels increase stat boost.

“I think we've found our culprit.” Rose said, looking at Percy out of the corner of her eye.

“I think so, too.” Percy said, eyes scanning the words again and again. There were more sub-categories beneath that, but Percy had seen all he needed to. “New search. God.”

The new list that popped up had six main entries, with sub-categories on two of them.

Water God Form, Death God Form, Dark God Form, Fire God Form, Evil God Form and Harem God Form. Water and Harem God Form's had the sub-categories.

“Well. It seems that I should look more into this.” Percy said, grabbing one of Rose's hands. Entwining his fingers with hers, he turned his head to look at the mother of his first-born. “Though, that can wait until the end of our night.”

“Agreed.” Rose said, hugging Percy from her position behind him.

When the world resumed motion, the inn was missing two occupants. The inn-keeper would find a note and a valuable jewel in his safe, while the few patrons in the border town inn would wander home thinking they had drank too much.

People just didn't disappear into thin air, after all.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
The first Mistress looked across the Horizon, eyes shaded by her hand. Around her, the crew of the ship bustled around as they did their jobs.

Already she had broken up a few fights between the minions and the ghostly naval soldiers. The most recent one had started over one of the browns having bumped into a soldier, and quickly escalated into a brawl.

She had been able to stop the minion from throwing the skeleton overboard, though she had needed Clarisse to keep the soldiers in line so that they didn't all rush the minions.

It's not like it would have done them any good, though.

Clarisse, the official commanding officer for the ghost crew had already dismissed three particularly aggressive soldiers, sending them back to their original ship in shame without actually relieving them of their debt.

Annabeth smiled cruelly, knowing that it was unlikely that they would be called upon ever again.

And, while it worried her that she was becoming as bad as, if not worse than the Olympians, she couldn't find it in herself to care. Those soldier that had been dismissed had been quite rude to every single one of them, save Grover and Clarisse.

“Mistress...”

Turning around, Annabeth smiled, nicely mind you, at the goddess on board. “Yeah, Mel? What's up?”

“Not to sound impatient, but how long will it be until we arrive?”

“We'll arrive just outside the entrance tonight. We're gonna wait until tomorrow for Percy, sleeping just outside Charybdis's range.” She said, quickly taking note of the sun's position. “Why?”

“I have that feeling I'm being watched from all sides. And not by the undead on this ship.” She said, glaring at the horizon. “Only Master can watch me when I'm not on stage.”

“It's probably Poseidon.” Annabeth said with a sigh. “I'm sorry Mel, but there's nothing we can do about that. Unless the fates are interfering, or something else draws his attention, Poseidon will know who and where you are.”

“And this Poseidon... He is the Master's father, correct?”

Annabeth nodded. “Yeah. He's also the one who's partly responsible for what happened to Medusa.”

“I see.” Melum went silent for a moment. “And he knows what I am?”

“A rough idea, from what Percy told me. You're a primordial, the one who embodies, and allows, all sound. At least, that's what those who have a vague idea of you think. Knowing the gods, they are probably individually conspiring to curry favor with you, hoping to get into your pants.”

“And given that we're in the heart of Poseidon's territory...”

“Exactly.”

“But...” Melum's brow furrowed in thought. “Why would the master ask me to join on this quest? Not that I'm not enjoying the time away from the studio, but still. Why would he have me-”

A vicious wave smashed against the boat, everybody on board tumbling closer to the side Melum and Annabeth were on.

“And I think Poseidon's going to try the whole 'shipwreck and take you down to his palace' routine.” Annabeth said, quickly grabbing the railing so that she didn't fall into the salty waters. “Mel, care to dissuade him for the moment?”

“It would be my pleasure.” The foreign goddess said, grabbing the railing as she steadied herself. “Though, don't expect me to sing him a love song. Those are for the master only.”

Leaning over the rails, staring straight down into the quickly frothing sea, Melum opened her mouth.

The sounds she made would make any and all sea creatures incredibly hesitant to even come near the boat. Poseidon quickly diverted his attention away from the goddess, tail between his legs like he had seen Typhon coming right for him as he was stranded in the middle a desert.

Standing back up, Melum allowed herself a smile. “There. We should be left alone for a while. I can no longer feel this Poseidon's presence watching us.”

It was true, as the waters had gone completely still, afraid to act without her command.

“Thank you, Mel.” Annabeth said, giving the goddess a thumbs-up sign, noticing that the sky was completely cloud free and the sun seemed less harsh on the boat. “Fantastic job.”

“Thank you, Mistress.”

Unbeknownst to anyone, something was happening deep in the sea. So deep, in fact, that it couldn't really be on most planes of existence. Something primal was taking place. Something terrible and wonderful and horrifying and enlightening, all at once.

Three beings stirred within the unfathomable depths of the primal sea. Eyes that did not exist opened, mouths without voices spoke, and minds with thoughts incomprehensible began to churn away the dreamless eons they had slumbered.

And, with their stirring, their brethren began to feel the call, signaling that the time to wake was nearing.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Morning came upon the world quickly, covering it in the morning light as dusk ushered night away over the horizon.

Percy grunted, his eyes opening as sleep departed him with the night.

Rose groaned softly, snuggling into his side. His arm was wrapped around her shoulders, an arm of hers resting on his chest as she slept.

Not wanting to wake her, Percy closed his eyes as another body formed with its eyes open.

Looking down on his other body, since neither one could technically be called the original, and Rose, Percy cursed himself for not taking the chance to kill Morpheus when he had the perfect opportunity.

As he enjoyed the shared warmth between them, the mobile body clad itself in the clothing that the game had seen fit to give him. Feeling particularly lazy that moment, he used the inventory screen to 'equip' it all, the apparel materializing on his body.

Moving over to one of the windows in his room, this one facing the eastern horizon, Percy looked out to see the castle town as it started.

And froze.

Blinking, rubbing away the sleep from his eyes, Percy looked again.

No, his eyes weren't deceiving him. They never had, so why should they start now?

“Ah shit.” Both mouths cursed, the one on the bed sighing as the one by the window tensed even further. “Rose, wake up.”

“No more, Percy.” She murbled in her sleep, pressing her face deeper into his side. “I'm tired. We can go again after breakfast.”

“And this is what I get for being the personification of lust.” Both sighed, pinching the bridge of their nose. “No, Rose. You need to get up. Now.”

“Hmm?” Rose ruefully cracked her eyes open as she lifted her head slightly to look at him. “Percy, what is it? I'm still tired.”

“We need to leave, it would seem.” Percy said, the one that was up vanishing to wake Millicent up. “Whatever forces are planning to sack Hyrule are finally making their move.”

“Really?” Rose asked, yawning before she turned on her other side. “Well, they can do so later. I need my beauty sleep, or I'll end up acting like Velvet. And I don't feel like putting either of us through that. One of my sister is more than enough for anyone.”

“You realize that you're talking to a guy who has bedded the very embodiment of war and destruction, right?” Percy asked, poking her back with his finger. “Yeesh, I must have robbed you of your usual mannerisms last night.”

“Percy, please.” Rose muttered, weakly swatting at him. “Just... do whatever you want. If we're leaving, please just take us somewhere I can sleep without invasions interrupting.”

Percy gave a small laugh. “As my queen wishes.” He said, giving her a light kiss on her neck before he left the comfort of the bed.

Quickly dressing, again, Percy left to inform the princess of the imminent invasion.

“And how quickly it came upon them is certainly a surprise.” Percy mused, armor molding from the darkness around him. “This is why it pays to have a standing army.”

“Help repel the invasion?”

~

The barriers reached up past the clouds, distorting the light near them into a perfect image of a nearly set sun, bathing a great deal of land in the otherwise normal light.

Zelda stood on the balcony just outside the throne room, defiantly staring down the walls of magic.

“What is it you see, Lord Perseus?” Zelda asked the visiting Overlord, who was standing next to her.

“Surely you can see it yourself.” Percy returned.

“I can.” The princess said, a grim nod being the only action she allowed herself aside from talking. “But I wanted to make sure my eyes were not deceiving me.”

Both looked upon the strange black mist that flowed from the wall of physical magic, seemingly without end. It was moving fast, and it seemed to hold... things. Things not human, and certainly not friendly.

“Are you sure you can't be persuaded to stay?” Zelda asked, her voice steeled as she looked upon the paltry fighting force she had been able to call upon on such short notice. “The help of you and the Lady Rose would be a great boon for us, and one that would not go unrewarded.”

“I'm afraid not.” Percy told her, watching the black mist draw ever closer. “Whatever is attacking, who's to say it is not preforming the same on my own kingdom at this very moment. And, while I cannot be sure at this time, I must fear the worst. If they were to, somehow, take the capital, there would be little stopping them from using some of the more powerful artifacts that my family has in our possession. Not only that, but I must think of the safety of my daughter. She may be strong, but she still has trouble with multiple opponents. If this is a full scale invasion, she will very likely be grievously injured. If that were to happen...”

“I doubt there would be much left of Hyrule.” Zelda finished.

“Exactly. Though, at least the invasion would be dealt with.” He finished with a smug, if grim, grin.

“Is there no aid you can give us though?” Zelda asked, turning to enter the throne room where her sword rest.

“I could always send help, if my own kingdom is not under siege. However, it would be a paltry force, as I would require the majority to set up defenses against possible invasion.”

“I understand.” Zelda said, grabbing up her sword. “Though I do not like it, I understand. If I were a parent, I would want my child as safe as possible.”

She understands what you do not...

Percy flinched slightly, quickly quashing the voice of his guilt for the time being.

'It seems the game wasn't lying about this.'

“And Hyrule isn't your country.” Zelda said, checking the sharpness of her blade. “Though, I will admit that this will make an alliance harder for the people to accept. There will be tensions, people declaring you a coward for refusing to help.”

“Let them claim what they will. They do not know the struggle of ruling a country, and especially not with the possibility of outside threats being more than just paranoia.”

“True.” Zelda said, a grim smile forming as she gave the sword a few swings. “But, if you plan to leave, it should be soon. The enemy will be on us within a few hours. I expect your wife to use her magic to take you and your family away?”

“Something like that.”

“Very well.” Zelda said with a small sigh. “I hope that you find your lands untouched by this opposing force.”

“And I hope yours survives. Let it be known, if my daughter were more capable in battle, we would help.”

With that, Percy turned on his heel and strode from the room.

Zelda stared after him, though she did not allow herself the pleasure of another sigh.

With Percy, as he went back to his room, he quickly read through the text window that popped up.

“Warned the princess about the invasion, but will not help repel it. No change in standing with Princess Zelda. No reward for quest.” When he closed that, another popped up. “New quest! To boldly flee! - Take your family and return to the capital to prepare for the possibility of an invasion.”
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Invasion comes with the morning sun
