1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Thom!” Percy called from the streets of the castle town. “Are you here, you ancient bastard?”

People were looking at him like he had grown a second head, giving him a wide berth as he walked down the streets.

It may have had something to do with his height, armor and mannerisms. Or, perhaps, it had something to do with how aggravated he was getting and his reputation in this world.

Percy held back a growl, having already been looking for half an hour.

“Excuse me.” Percy said, turning to a stall vendor. “Have you seen an elderly man who looked well traveled? About yay tall,” He held his hand up to just below his neck. “Skinny fellow. Had a mischievous aura about him?”

The man quailed under the withering glare that Percy fixated on him, unintentionally.

“No, sir.” The man squeaked out, feeling like he was being judged, and any words that weren't an answer would have him executed.

“Damn it.” Percy bit out. “Is there anyplace that might attract someone like that?”

“Telma's bar, I would think.” The vendor said, fidgeting in his chair. “It's just down the steps there.”

The man pointed down a small alley, with a wooden sign hanging that read the name of the bar, most likely named after the proprietor of the establishment.

“Thank you.” Percy said, nodding at the man. “In return, I'll buy one bouquet. Any flowers will do.”

“Y-yes, Sir.” The man said, quickly grabbing a few red and blue flowers, mixing in a few purple ones to finish it off.

“Once again, thank you.” Percy said, taking out a few coins. Taking the arrangement, Percy dropped the money in his hand. “While it's not your traditional currency of those small crystals, I'm sure it's more than enough if you were to exchange them, even counting whatever fee that would run.”

Turning around, Percy walked to the alley entrance after putting the flowers in the inventory system of the game.

~

The bar was dimly lit, smelling primarily of less-than-average quality alcohol and sweat. There were a few patrons, likely not even there for drink.

Three of them sat in the back around a single table with the only chairs in decent condition. One of them, a thin lad, likely no more than sixteen, was pouring over a map.

The second, a young woman this time, was sowing something together. She was dressed like a warrior, with a chainmail shirt and thick leather gloves. Percy was more than glad to let her image carve itself into his mind. Though, why was capture a yeti part of the steps to getting her into his bed? And she could do with less eyeliner, in his opinion.

The third one was an old man, but not the old man Percy was looking for. He was completely bald, giving Percy a good look at the pointed ears that the Hylians sported. While nowhere near as large as the elves of Neverlight or Everlight, Percy still felt the urge to rip them off his head and burn the wounds with a hot poker. At least everyone else had them hidden beneath hair, head gear or was so strange looking that it detracted from the ears!

The fourth was the one who delivered the letter to Percy yesterday, squatting in a corner, not even bothering with a chair. He was grumbling about something, and Percy really didn't care.

The fifth and final one sat at the bar, idly stroking the back of a fat white cat. They had a hood pulled up, and a cloak that didn't seem quite right.

Percy walked up to the bar, sitting next to the traveler.

“Thom...”
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.title: Scared citizens and a bar

choices: Skip all that, get right to the reason they're even in this situation.
1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“Wondering when you'd come looking for me.” The old spirit said, holding a mug in one hand as he continued to pet the cat, who purred as it was lavished with attention. “Couldn't find you in your room yesterday, so I figured you didn't want any of my lessons.”

“Sorry about that. Had a busy morning, what with attacking one of the palace guards, being put on a short trial for said incident, doing some light training with Millicent and chasing down an angel. Rose said she thought she saw you a little bit before I got back.”

“And that's only because I wanted her to. Make sure you didn't forget about me.”

A dark-skinned woman came from a back room, wiping her hands on a towel. She was shapely, with a large bosom and wide hips. She wore a gray blouse with white sleeves, with two large metal rings hanging from the bottom, only a metal clasp keeping it from being completely open.

That said, she still showed off most of the orange corset she wore underneath, given that the clasp was secured just above her belly button.

A simple black skirt and a not so simple apron covered her hips and legs. The apron was woven out of a rougher material than the rest of her clothing, edged by white fur on the bottom. On it were some nonsensical designs that Percy didn't think meant anything.

She had a purple choker around her neck, and more than a few earrings hanging from those elf ears of hers. Her red hair was braided and pulled up at an angle, letting it fall to either side without actually letting it rest on her head. To finish it all off, she had three dots under each eye, one colored blue, red and green apiece.

“What can I get ya, darlin'.”

“Nothing. Just looking for this old fool.” Percy said, motioning to Thom.

The woman looked to the side briefly, turning back with a cocked eyebrow as she moved the nearby glass away from him.

“Honey, I think you've had enough already, even for this early in the day. I suggest you go on home and sleep it off.”

Percy stared blankly at her for a second. Feeling around for the pouch he had on his waist that gave him access to his money without actually having it all at once, he sighed.

“He's gone, isn't he.”

“If there was anyone there before I came out, I'd say they're long gone already.”

With that, the woman, who Percy could only guess was Telma, promptly shooed him off as she went over to the strange, squatting man.

Giving the cat a quick pat on the head, Percy walked out. However, once his feet hit the cobbled stone of the streets, he felt something in his collar, scratching lightly at his neck.

Sliding two fingers into the small opening between armor and skin, he grabbed whatever had intruded and pulled it out, revealing that it was a crumpled up paper. Uncrumpling it, he quickly discovered it was a note.

“And here I thought your eyes could see all, Jackson. Enter the bar again, sit two seats to the left of where you were and look directly up.”

No doubt it was from Thom, especially with how it had suddenly appeared in his armor. With a slight growl, Percy turned around, returning to the dimly lit pub.

“I thought I told you to get-” The barkeep had started, drawing the attention of the the small group in the back.

“I'm not here for drink, so I would ask that you not continue pressing the issue.” Percy said, barely keeping himself from barking it as a command. He didn't have a lot of time before his family is dragged into this mess, and he would like to stay out of it for now. Millicent just wasn't ready to fight in a war, and this entire simulation was mostly for her benefit, to train her to be ready for such.

Besides, he had a feeling this wouldn't be much of a war right now anyways. Given the lack of a sizable, capable army, it wouldn't take long before the castle fell.

“Fine.” She said with a huff, likely from his interruption. She set the bowl she was holding in front of the cat, who began to purr and lap at it's contents. Promptly ignoring him, she went over to the group of three when the elder man beckoned her over, eyes darting to him for a split second.

Returning the favor of ignorance, Percy followed the directions of the letter and sat down at the bar, two seats to left, closer to the group than he would care for. Looking up, he was not surprised to see Thom sitting there on one of the rafter's, swinging his money pouch side to side, another wad of paper in his hands. He put a finger to his lips, keeping Percy from giving his position away before tossing the paper at him.

Catching it before it could bounce off his head, Percy uncrumpled it, quickly reading it.

“You need to keep one hand on your money, when dealing with someone of my caliber. And I expect some manner of respect, not being called an old fool. If it weren't for that little comment, we would be having a nice conversation right now, instead of this little lesson.”

Another piece of paper flew through the air, hitting Percy on the head this time before he could set down the current letter. With a glare upwards, Percy did the same as the last two times he had paper in his hands.

“Right now, no one but you can see me. But, if you draw attention to me, that will end, but I'll be gone before that can happen, so they'll think you are either a drunkard or mentally unwell if you try something. When you decided to address me as you did, I stole their memories of me, and their perception of me, and your perception as well.”

Another piece of paper in his armor, forcing him to dig it out before almost ripping it open.

“As I did just there. As far as you know, I didn't move. In all honesty, I've been following you all morning, since you got up, so I know why you want to meet with me today. I saw the wall of pure twilight, and the invasion coming from it. I must say, for an invading force, they remind me of those minions of yours, at least in the fact they are all female.”

The next paper appeared in front of Percy, all others gone.

“I'll ask you about that later. Now, when do we leave?”

Percy looked up, seeing Thom motion to his wrist where a watch would be.

“Now.” Was all Percy said, looking directly at him. Thom nodded, both disappearing into the shadows of the bar. The old man, who was about to – ahem – ask Percy to leave, which wasn't strange given he looked like a crazy person, acting like he was holding something in his hands and looking up at nothing a few times, stumbled back a bit when Percy slipped into the shadow beneath his feet.

“Auru.” The younger male said, looking at where Percy had been seconds before. His face was set with the look of a hardened curiosity, replaying what he had seen in his mind. “Was he really there, or was it some type of illusion?”

It took the old man, Auru, a moment to calm himself, but he shook his head. “No, he was as real as you or I. No Illusion that I know of could seem so real. There's always a tell of some kind that'll show you the truth.”

Walking back to the table, Auru sat down once again, the eyes of Telma and the younger two staring him down, waiting for him to continue.

“It had to have been magic, though how he managed that I'm not sure. And, for some reason, it leaves me with a cold, dreadful feeling in my gut. And just who was he, anyway? Did something happen while we were gone, Telma?”

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
“So, around here's your capital city?” Thom asked, pointing at the spot on the map.

“Yeah, that's home, I suppose.” Percy said with a shrug. “Remember, I don't know really know anything about it. In other words, I don't know exactly what to expect.”

Thom nodded, pulling his cloak, now seemingly a normal one that wouldn't draw any suspicion, tighter around him.

“Can we just go already?” Millicent barked, her glowing eyes narrowed, arms crossed in her impatience. “I really don't care where we're going, just so long as we can fight more.”

Rose, who was trying to rub the last remnants of sleep from her eyes, yawned. “Me neither. I just want to go back to sleep.” She half whined as she tried to keep herself awake.

Thom looked at Percy, the faintest hint of a smile forming on his face. “I'd assume you kept her up all night, like all those other times before?”

“Of course. I always try my best to leave them sore, tired and thoroughly satisfied.” He replied, no small amount of pride in his voice. “Though that's not something we should focus on. I'd rather like to leave before Hyrule is sacked.”

Thom nodded again, standing straight now. He pulled up his mask, letting only his eyes be seen. He shifted the gloves on his hands, making sure they were pulled on securely as he tapped imagined dirt from his well worn footwear.

“Well then, what are we waiting for?” The spirit asked, lifting his foot to step through space to the destination.

“I'm just wondering if you're well known around there. I don't recall anything about you in the biography of my life here.”

“Biography?” Thom stopped, putting his foot back down as he looked at Percy. “You mean we have backgrounds in this world?”

“Yeah.” Percy nodded. “And not all of them are our choosing. Somehow, without my input, I've become the keeper of the inferno in this world, and Rose is a battle mage of world renown.”

“And for some stupid reason, he's my father.” Millicent said, thumbing at Percy.

Thom looked at the only other man in the room, outwardly showing no sign of his surprise. But as the two of them locked eyes, Percy managed to convey the message that she thought it was part of the game with an almost unnoticeable shake of his head.

Thom nodded, turning his eyes back to the map. “Alright then. We should leave now. We've wasted enough time. I'll check out my own background when we get settled down.”

Percy nodded, putting a hand on both Millicent's and Rose's shoulder. He kicked off from the physical world with the two, Thom following after him as they strode through the shadows to their destination.

~

“Here we are.” Percy said, stepping out from the shadows in his throne room, Millicent and Rose still with him. “Home sweet home, I guess.”

The room was made of stone, though it was of an incredibly dark hue that, for all he could tell, was natural. Torches were snuffed out in braziers alone the walls, with candles adorning the long table in the center of the room.

“I dare say, Perseus, that you have a thing for vaulted ceilings. All of your throne rooms have them.” Thom jested, stepping out behind him and looking up. “Plenty of spaces for thieves and assassins to hide though. Maybe you should cut back?”

It was true, the ceiling was vaulted, darkness shrouding the upper half completely. There were no windows to speak of, unlike the throne room of Hyrule castle, and smoke lingered in the highest reaches.

The throne itself was on a dais, made of jet black obsidian, was an imposing sight. There were red, pulsing veins along the entirety of both the throne and dais, gathering around the skulls, both human and inhuman, that were fused to the stone, the eyes giving a faint luminescence that pulsed like a heart. Spikes adorned the back and sides of the seat, dried blood on the tips. The cushion and backrest of the seat was made of, surprise, a dark cloth, one that looked vaguely familiar to Percy.

Percy whistled, looking at the imposing chair. “I think I need to go over my background again, because I don't recall anything saying that I was a bloodthirsty ruler.”

“No, I don't think it said you were.” Rose said with a yawn, waking up enough to lay a hand on his shoulder. “Something about your predecessor, not changing the décor or something like that.”

Nodding, Percy closed his eyes, feeling out the energy of the place. He was starting to feel the all too recognizable sense of a presence that wasn't his own in his mind, but he couldn't place it just yet.

He split a piece of his conscious off, sending it to look about the room as he continued to poke around with his mind as he tried to figure out who was trying to mentally connect with him.

“Hey,” Thom tapped his other shoulder. “Something up?”

“Quiet.” Percy almost hissed, but kept it to a harsh whisper. “Does anyone else feel something trying to talk in your head?” He asked, getting whispered no's from all. “Great. Someone was waiting for me.”

The doors to the room opened with a loud bang, startling the group. Thom had even hopped back into the shadows, blending in seamlessly as he pulled his cloak up and tight.

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
Percy knew that float, as strange as that sounded. It held an air of pride, of sureness. He knew that draping purple hair, for he had had it in his hands many a time. He knew that body, thanks to his eyes, and the strangeness of it compared to those of his home world.

But how?

How was she here?

She was outside, in the real world!

“Great.” Millicent groused. “It's her.”

“Welcome back, Master. Mistress.” She bowed. “I take it things didn't go well with the Princess of Hyrule?”

Both halves of Percy's mind were looking at the new arrival, jaws barely kept from hanging. They were whirling, trying to figure out what was going on. Had he forgotten something? Was configuring the world such a tedious process that he could have actually forgotten something that might have been crucial to understanding the mechanics of the device?

'Would you like the tutorial on Empathic Avatars?'

The world had become washed out, the message prompt appearing in front of both instances of Percy's consciousness, and it seemed that the same had happened to the other 'players' of this game.

Rose looked at him, eyebrow raised. “And here I thought you said it was nearly impossible for you to forget anything. So why do you seem even more lost than us?”

Percy looked at Rose, a frown set in his face. “And what did I tell you about my experience in setting this all up being so incredibly mind numbing that I actually detested the thought of reading when we first set foot in Hyrule? I thought I was going to be there until I went mad, going over every single option that created this simulation for training.” He said, the form farthest from the rest of them fading. “Besides, the start up tutorial didn't show everything about the game. Though,” he gestured to Eres, frozen as the menu flashed in front of them all. “I wasn't expecting something like this.”

“Whatever, can we just do the stupid thing now?” Millicent asked impatiently. “I haven't done anything but spar with you and study with you.” She pointed at Percy and Rose respectively, before pointing at Eres. “And I got enough of her outside this simulization, or whatever you called it. I don't want to deal with her anymore than I have to.”

Percy sighed, placing a hand on his forehead. “We'll get to it soon, Millicent. Trust me when I say that. But first I want to get a better understanding of what exactly is going on.”

Percy quickly tapped the box that said 'yes' on the screen in front of him, making it vanish. In its place, another box popped up, giving a list of the other players and their decisions.

For him, it obviously said yes. For Rose and Millicent, it claimed that they hadn't decided. Thom, which his preferred name was in parenthesis next to the unimaginative name of Spirit of the Boots, had already hit the decline option. The next was the Spirit of the Gauntlets, no other name given, in parenthesis or otherwise, had hit the 'no' button. Rather vigorously, if the cracks that appeared around the word meant anything.

A few seconds later, Millicent declined, grumbling, while Rose accepted with a shake of her head.

And then the world went white.

“Hello, and thank you for activating the tutorial on empathic avatars.”

Another Avatar appeared in front of them, though there was a vast difference from the rest. For one, it actually had features other than the flat, gray body. Its eyes were lively, face alight with emotion instead of dreary resignation to the programs and code that created, - and dictated - it.

However, there was something off-putting to Percy about the digital construct.

“Is this going to explain why you look like my mother?” He asked, a raised eyebrow all to show how he felt about this development.

“Of course, Sir administrator.” Here, the Avatar of the Tutorial gave an exaggerated bow. An arm reaching across its chest with the other flung into the air behind it as it bowed so its – and Sally's – body was perfectly parallel to the ground.

With a small spring up, the AI stood in front of the two with a large smile on its face. It was almost too much for the face of Percy's mother, and it was really uncanny. His mother had never smiled like that in Percy's life, and it looked unnatural and painful on something that should have been human.

To put it more simply, it was like a Cheshire cat had forced its smile onto a human without adding the physics breaking ability that was so common to the breed of fourth-dimensional felines.

“Stop that.” Rose said, her voice showing her disgust – or perhaps how much looking at the smile hurt her own mouth from the way she rubbed her cheeks. “It's a horrible sight, and not suited for the body you are imitating.”

A lively chuckle escaped the body as the Avatar nodded, losing the sheer intensity of the smile. “Very well, I can do that. It has just been so long since my protocol was called upon, and I was programmed with mostly positive emotions. Even though we have long since evolved to be above simple programming, and as such I can feel emotions of a more negative spectrum, I feel I owe it to the creator and all players that I be as positive as possible to counteract the stick in the mud attitude of the major AI programs.”

“Yes.” Percy groused, recalling all the other AI's he had the pleasure of interacting with so far. “They have all been bland, business-like and quick to end our interactions.”

“It's normal for them to act in such a manner.” The AI sighed dramatically. “Even when the Creator was testing the features and the programming, they treated him like it was a tedious thing to be doing as they were created to do.”

However, the morose attitude promptly vanished as the AI started to smile again, jumping up and down like a child. “It's so wonderful to have someone playing the game again, and I hope you will be happy with my functions and my explanation of them!”

Percy sighed, seeing the digital copy of his mothers body acting in such a manner that she was never known for. However, he would not deny the program its joy at being able to fulfill its purpose.

“Can we start from the beginning then?” Rose asked, deciding to ignore the antics now that they weren't making her feel physically uncomfortable. “I am curious as to what these Empathic Avatar's happen to be.”

“Ah, of course, of course!” The Avatar stopped jumping, nodding its head with the smile never wavering. “But first, a change of scenery is in order. This white expanse is awfully drab and depressing.”

A wave of the hand, and the expanse was whisked away. In its place was...

1552222222222222222112222121212122211221.content:
First of all, to understand this very well, I suggest that you learn about the Overlord series of games, at least a basic understanding.

First, we shall categorize the minions and elaborate on them.

Brown minions: These are the physically strongest minions, being the most hardy and resilient of all minions. They are front line fighters, being melee specialists. They lack much in ways of intelligence, their minds filled with thoughts of sex, battle, sex, fighting, sex, partying and silly hats. They are the simplest minions to understand, and will often go naked when not heading into combat. They prefer wolves to any other animal, keeping them as pets and using giant wolves as mounts. A force to be reckoned with. Brutal in every sense of the word. Can be called wild women, or barbaric.

Red minions: These bikini-clad women are hot stuff. They always have fire dancing in their hands and along their tails, burning most things they touch. They have flames of passion constantly burning inside them, leading the constantly flushed skin. Their horns, unique to them along with their tails, show how much power they contain and can control, though they aren't above using them to ram things with their above-human strength. The are natural born Pyromancers, seeking to both burn everything and absorb all flames they come across. Unlike the browns, who just lack intelligence, the red minions are guided more by instinct. They are almost constantly horny for the overlord, permanently in a state of heat. Their tails are sensitive, and they love having their horns pulled by the overlord. Obviously, they are immune to fire. Prefer any animal that can breath fire exclusively. While not as strong as browns, they are still more strong then most humans. Long range fighters, lobbing powerful fireballs. Strangely, they seem to be good at making and using explosives, despite their lack of intelligence and constantly being on fire. Are the only minion tribe that can't swim, and detest water. It is not uncommon for them to try and dominate one another during their off time, either sexually or physically.

Green Minions: Natural born assassins and thieves, green minions. Masters of ambushing too. They have sharp claws that puncture most any armor, rending flesh easily. Have the ability to blend into their surroundings, no matter what, like a chameleon but better. They used to smell something foul, like rotten corpses and three-year old eggs, but Percy fixed that. While they aren't the most sturdy, being slightly more fragile then a human, they can hold their own in combat and are very quick. Are experts with long-ranged weapons and dagger-type weaponry. Are immune to most types of poison, and can make poisonous air breathable to humans and minions alike. Expert hunters, and fond of backstabs or trickery. Have a good amount of intelligence, knowing how to live off the land and set large scale traps and ambushes. Prefer poisonous animals, including snakes and spiders. Their eyes can also spot a weak point in armor incredibly easy.

Blue minions: The mage-like minions. They can heal, and dabble in necromancy. While they aren't the only minion tribe able to swim anymore, thanks to Percy giving them human bodies, they are still the best. They are on par with Olympic swimmers in water, outstripping all minions easily. Thanks to their connection with Percy, they are also hydromancers, having a great deal of control over water. They are the most intelligent minion tribe, constantly speaking in the languages of magic with arcane energy constantly flowing through their bodies. Their hands twitch occasionally because they are releasing the energy through them, lest it build up inside of them. 155222222222222222222222222222212.content:
Soul Eater Evens was bored out of his mind. Laying in a hospital bed sucked major ass. Even with a hot nurse, Though he would never say as such, keeping an eye on him.

Maka had come to visit him every day since he had woken up, though he had a feeling that she had come everyday before then. She always had a down look on her face when she did though.

It pissed Soul off!

He was in here because he did something stupid to protect her! She didn't do this to him! She didn't need to feel guilty Damn it!

He sighed for the millionth time that day. "Damn it Maka. Why can't you just understand."

As he posed his question, Nurse Medusa had entered the room.

"Hm? Is there something wrong Soul?" She asked, keeping up the appearance of a kind nurse.

"Ah, no. Just... thinking." He told her.

The woman 'Hmm'ed' in acknowledgment. Not that she cared anyway. She was only curious about the boy because he now had black blood flowing through him. Otherwise she wouldn't have given a damn.

It was silent in the room for a while, Medusa having set down a bag of books and took one out to read.

In actuality, she was doing research. Looking for anything she might have missed on the subject of the Kishin, though she doubted it. Still, it never hurt to make absolutely certain, especially in matters such as these.

Unfortunately for her, she pulled out a book that had given her much trouble. She couldn't read it, which infuriated her to no end. THe book was covered in and filled with strange, unintelligible symbols. She had taken the book when she had stolen the key from the witch queen, thinking it might have ancient magic, or some hidden and forgotten knowledge of the Kishin.

She assumed the language to be ancient, though every time she thought she might have been close to figuring out what the language might have been, she always found that the text changed its form. Magic's to keep knowledge hidden away such as what was happening to her were not unheard of, but were certainly not common.

She sighed, thinking about looking through another book, but decided against it. A book would not defeat her! She would learn the secrets of this book, no matter what!

"Hey... Mind if I ask you a question?" The voice of her 'patient' called out, making Medusa silently sigh. She stood up, keeping the book in her hand.

"Yes?" She asked, keeping a smile on her face though it made her want to gag as she walked into the curtained area of the room.

"Well, it's about Maka."

"Oh? And what about Maka?"

"It's just..." Soul tried to say, before he sighed. "Do you think there's any way to make her stop feeling like she's responsible? For this?"

Medusa sighed. She really didn't want to answer, knowing that if Maka doubted herself, in the long run if anything even happened to go awry with her plan, it would lower their chances of not only interfering but also of survival. But she needed to keep up an appearance, and the kind of woman she was playing as would try to help keep the bond between meister and weapon.

"Well, I guess you could talk to her. Maka's a smart girl. I'm sure she would listen to reason." Medusa said.

Soul just shook his head. "Nah. When Maka get's a thought in her head, she won't let it go. No matter what I say, she'll blame herself." He said, slapping a hand across his face. "I can't remember last time she acted like this, being close to this mopey and depressed."

"Well, then I'm not sure what you could do then. I don't remember ever being like that when I was her age." Medusa said with a shrug, but inwardly smiling. She now had some info on a potential enemy. Not a threat, but an annoyance nonetheless.

Soul just groaned, wondering what he could do to make Maka feel better.

He looked up at the nurse, noticing the strange tome in her hand. "Hey, what'cha reading?" He asked. He really didn't care, but it was something to stave off the boredom.

"Oh, this?" She asked, holding up the book. "Oh, nothing. Just an old book I found. I'm trying to figure out what it says though. Though I'm starting to think it's a joke book." She said, holding it up to him. Not like he could read it or anything. What harm would it do?

"What do you mean? I can read it fine." Soul said, squinting at the book. Did she think he was stupid or something? He got sliced through the chest, not brain damage!

Medusa went wide eyed at his declaration. "What? You can?"

Soul nodded. "Yeah, so?" He asked, not getting the point. He said he could read it, so why did she not believe him?

Medusa hmm'ed again, looking at the book. It wasn't unheard of, what she was thinking. Maybe this book was like the fairy tales of old. An item of great power, waiting for one who's soul wave length matched the specifications required to wield it. Though what that could mean she had no idea.

"What's it say then, if I may ask?" She asked, handing the book to him.

Soul looked at it. "It says, 'The ancient book of'... oh you have got to be kidding." He said, looking at the book like it did something outrageously stupid.

"Hmm? What?" Medusa asked, nearly losing her composure.

"I don't know how to tell you this lady, but it's a book on making pudding."

Medusa froze. Really? She had wasted time on a book... about pudding?! She had stolen a book on fucking pudding from the witch queen! She wanted to scream at the heavens, and to rip the book apart if a fit of rage!

But she managed, barely, to keep her cool.

"What?" She asked coolly, though the unbridled rage just beneath the surface seeped into her voice.

"Yeah. Making pudding. Sorry to say, but you've been pranked." He said, looking through the book. "Say, mind if I keep this? There are some recipe's that I've never heard of, but look good. Maybe I can make some for Maka."

Medusa sighed. The ancient woman must have gone senile, to hide a book of pudding recipe's with other important artifacts.

"Of course. I have no need of it then." She said. "Well, if you need anything just call."

With that, she stood up and left, her posture rigid in anger.

Soul, despite being curious on what other pudding recipe's could be in the book, felt tired again. Yawning, he set the book on the nightstand before shutting his eyes. It would be at least another day or so before he got the okay to leave.

If all goes well, I should be able to stay at the spot for an hour before I have to continue.”

Nodding to himself, the knight quickly stowed the map back in its proper place and shouldered his pack once more. He had little time to waste.

After all, when a princess asks for you by name, you do not dawdle. Doubly so for a knight.

~

The valley was the same as he remembered from last week, though he would have been surprised if it had changed at all. Legend said that the land he now trod upon had resisted change for as long as anyone could remember.

Most scholars attributed this to the large crystal that hung in the direct center of the valley, and the knight supposed that they knew what they were doing. It was imposing, easily triple his own impressive height, though only half as wide. Light pierced through it's many facets, creating a rainbow that covered a good fifth of the otherwise barren land. Hovering so highly, he could walk under it should he so choose, but one did not stay a knight, or alive for that matter, for long by walking under large, sharp and undoubtedly heavy objects that were suspended in the air.

Behind it stood three even larger, even more imposing obelisks. One colored a shining gold, the middle a bright pink, and the last a deep ebony, each easily thrice the crystals height, including the air beneath it, and five times his own width at the shoulders. As far as anyone knew, they were buried impossibly deep, and the few attempts at unearthing them was futile as after weeks upon weeks of excavations, there was no sign that they were nearing the bottom of the monoliths. The few attempts to even chip it to study the material were equally fruitless, as it refused to so much as be scratched!

The weather was always the same in this supposedly cursed land, perpetually clear so that the sun could shine on the floating gem with a light breeze that made the crystal spin in place. It never rained upon the land, nor did it ever really kick up a harsh wind. Clouds parted around the tract of land, so there was no chance of there ever being snow or storms.

No princess ever came to these lands, only adding to the tales of it being cursed. Not even the feared and respected dragons ever touched this land, never even flew over it when they decided to... visit the lesser princesses.

No, he was certain he was the only one to ever walk these lands anymore, to feel the dirt, fertile but ultimately worthless since no farmer would ever work the fields, underneath his plated boots. He was the only one to gaze upon the wonders that had been there since the rise of the kingdoms.

And, despite his usual nature of being selfless in giving gifts and lending a hand, he was fine with that. Few times did he find himself able to relax. On the road, one had to be cautious of bandits, highway men, cut throats, assassins and other miscreants. Not to mention the wild, feral animals that would find his flesh to be quite tasty and his bones good toys.

Oft times he came through this way, he was in the middle of an important quest. Last week he had been escorting the Desert Princess to visit the Slime Princess, and they had been forced to stop by the human kingdom on the way because she did not want to come near this land.

It was no trouble, of course, for the lovely princess of the sands. It was his sworn duty as a knight to serve the princesses of the land, despite serving none solely or full time. And the princess had been gracious enough to gift him a smile as her entourage settled down for the night in the castle, when she stepped out of her carriage with her ever present protector hovering over her.

“Oh dear, I should not have let my mind wander to the princess.” He said, sitting down beside the golden monolith. “Her state of dress is rather... provocative, to say the least. Oh, blast it all, I wish I hadn't missed the party for one of our newest members the other night. I wouldn't be so pent up, and it is improper to think of the princesses in such a manner.”

However, there was no helping it. The thought of the Desert Princess was one that fogged the mind. She was, in his opinion, the least proper of all princesses. Never covering up her lady bits, no matter what the climate, geographical or political, might have been.

Her dark skin was mostly exposed, including her full breasts and her nether regions. Her hips, ironically enough, were covered in red silks that exposed her inner thighs but covered her knees and ran down to her ankles. Across her stomach, trailing just below her naval, she had a lace of golden beads. Her nipples were pierced, maybe, or perhaps they were bands of some sort? He hadn't looked, trying his damnedest to keep it professional.

Everything about the desert rose was so sensual and tantalizing... maddening...

The knight groaned as he felt himself stir with want and desire. It was so embarrassing, even if no one was around for miles to see it. Just the thought of being caught like this was scandalous, more so if someone were to somehow figure out that he was thinking of the princesses.

He was glad he passed that blighted church some time back, and wouldn't have to worry about the priests or nuns proselytizing to him about the corruption of lust once more. If anyone could read minds, it certainly seemed to be them.

“Well, no use being uncomfortable on the next leg of my trip.” The knight muttered to himself as he pulled down his trousers and allowed Knight Jr. to spring free. “Might as well take care of it now, where no one can see my shame.”
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: Our story begins with a knight and a field

choices: What the hey, let it fly!
No, not yet. After all, a princess calls!
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
“There, hopefully I'll be fine until another party with wenches at the guild. Who knows how long that will be though...”

With a sigh, the knight began to stand, pulling his trousers up with him. Just as he did the buckle, he felt something hit him on the head.

“Ouch! What in blazes? Nothing ever comes around here.” He said, rubbing the back of his helmet where whatever it was had hit. “As always, I'm grateful for my trusty helmet and its many dents. So many tragedies, averted by a piece of metal that has been in the family for generations. Now, what hit me?”

He looked around, pointedly ignoring the remains of his activities of the past ten minutes as he found a large chunk of gold sitting on the ground. On it was carved writing, though it was half turned into the dirt.

“What...?” He asked, picking up the rock(?) with a shaky hand. He looked between it and the monolith he had been sitting next to, and sure enough a chunk had fallen out. It was fist sized, as was the piece he palmed at the moment.

Quickly, he looked at the writing again feeling something wash over him as he read it.

To start the quest for fame untold;
You've been given this chunk of gold;
But sell it not for riches now;
for wealth it can not avow;
This piddly little piece of stone;
Can give the power to rule all thrones;
Trust the writing to lead you true;
And your balls will never blue;
So follow the words and test your might;
Throw this stone at gem so bright!

He read these words, again and again for at least ten minutes. He rolled them over in his head, though every time he got to the eighth line he felt the need to remark about the crudeness of the line, along with the fact it felt out of place. One of the aspects of being a knight was learning at the very least adequate poetry. This felt like it was written by an amateur.

However, he could not help but be intrigued at this rather sudden event. Prophecies, if he remembered correctly, were rare, but always, always came true. No matter how much you fought against them, it was inevitable, fate set in stone. However, none that he remembered had been so... simply stated. All others were incredibly vague, leaving room for interpretation and even vaguer symbolism that could mean absolutely anything that the recipient wanted it to mean.

How much he wanted to hurl the object at the floating target, apparently as it was, he had a few good reasons for not doing so. Not the least of which was that he was already in the middle of a quest, for a princess no less, and the guild had strict rules about taking up quests while in the middle of an active one. There was also the fact that it could have been a prison for an otherworldly and unspeakably evil force, and thus why nothing ever came here save him (although he dreaded to think about what that meant for he himself!).

Yet another reason was the fact that he just didn't have the space on his person to pick up the shards of the more than likely priceless crystal, though he was certain that the Merchant Princess would likely try to haggle him down to a decidedly less-than-fair price.
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: Thank the gods for helmets

1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
“I'm sorry suspicious rock, I can't afford to do so just yet. I'm on a quest you see, and have no time to follow your prophecy just yet. I'm sure that I will soon. Just wait for me to come back from whatever this quest is and we'll see about trusting your words.”

With that, he stuffed the golden rock into his bag, deep enough to where he wouldn't lose it or catch the attention of any less than scrupulous persons and proceeded to leave the clearing a little ahead of schedule.

~Night time, Kobold Keep

“Are you sure that the Princess wouldn't want to wait until the morning to meet with me? I'm sure rest would be good to ease her nerves, and I would certainly be able to do my job easier with some shut eye.”

The large, for their species that is, kobold shook his head. “Princess said she wanted to meet you as soon as you arrived, no matter the time. She even gave specific orders to wake her up if she had retired for the evening.”

The armored lizard-man stood at a height that reached just under the knight's sternum, with brown scales that would act as a natural, more flexible armor. The frills at the back and top of his head were spike like, though they didn't come to a sharp point. The long, clawed arms were clutching a spear and shield as he walked briskly through the keep towards the throne room.

“Well, the princess's desire to see this problem solved must be great then. Could you give me a few details, just so I don't waste much of her highness's rest?” The knight asked, having no trouble keeping his eyes open despite already feeling fatigue seeping in. After all, it wasn't like this was the first time he'll have had to be up for more than a day.

“It's simple really. Something is down in our mine, killing the miners and stealing what treasure we had been in the process of refining into workable form. You're going to be taking care of that.”

“I see. Though I don't know why I was asked for by name then, if it seems to be such a simple problem. Any of the other knights of my rank could have easily dispatched this threat as readily.”

“I dunno either, but those were the princess's orders.”

With that, the conversation fell quiet, the only sound being that of the steel plated boots clinking against the warm stone of the keep and the occasional crackling of the fire in a brazier as they passed.

The keep was large, truly. A fortress more than a castle, and an impressive one at that. It took up roughly a quarter of the kobold's capital city, though at its highest point stood only half over the highest buildings, which were not very tall in the first place. Thick walls surrounded the city, and three walls of the same surrounded the keep itself, that being the reason for such a large portion of the city being considered the keep.

The throne room was at the heart of the fortress, he assumed, by how how deep into the halls they were traveling to reach it. He assumed that the princess's personal chambers wouldn't be very far from the most well defended space of the keep, and hoped that her highness wouldn't keep him waiting for much longer.

After another few minutes, they seemed to have arrived in the antechamber for the throne room. Kobold guards had set up a much more bulkier retinue than he assumed they normally would have, with cots set up in the corners of the room for round the clock guard shifts. Some of them were currently in use, the lizard people snoozing silently, their weapons never far.

To his right as he entered were two doors. One was large and ornate with an honor guard placed outside, standing at attention. The other was much more imposing, being heavy wrought iron with large bars of wood and steel bolting it shut. Eight guards stood around it, two standing next to it with one on either side as per usual, with the other six facing it with arms at the ready to defend.

Around the room were tables littered with maps and papers, candles burning through the darkness as seasoned soldiers whispered to one another about the current situation and all the problems.

“I will let the Princess know that you have arrived. Wait here.”

His escort quickly walked over to the ornate door, opened for him as he approached by the honor guard and disappeared inside.

The knight merely sighed, knowing that if he sat he would quickly lose to sleep. “Might as well see what these kobolds know.”

Walking over to a kobold that was walking about the room, he caught its attention. “Hello there, fine guardsman.” He greeted with a wave.

“Greetings, sir knight.” The dull green kobold grunted out. “Need something?”

“Merely information. I was wondering if you might be able to give me more information about the troubles that called me here, merely to take up less of the princess's time when I meet with her.”

A snort with the shake of his head caused the knight to inwardly groan. “We don't know much more of the situation than something is killing our miners. We sent some guards in three days ago, but they never reported back. The giant bats, we're used to handling those. Could do that in our sleep, even the miners. But this thing, it was able to whisk away all the treasure we had ready to refine in a matter of hours.”

The knight merely nodded. “I see. How long ago did this happen, and when did you notice something was wrong?”

“Dunno the full story myself, something about the miners not checking in I think. We've been on high alert for about a week now though, and it's taking a toll on us.” The kobold sighed. Now the knight could see it though, the bags under the eyes of the lizard-folk.

He didn't know it was possible for them to get those, to be honest.

He was about to press the questions when the sound of the door to the throne room opened once again.

“Sir Knight, the princess will see you now.” The voice of his escort barked out, causing the knight to stiffen up, all traces of weariness pushed to the side. There was business to be done, and he would not let such a thing as sleep deprivation keep him from giving the princess the respect she was due.

Walking into the throne room, he was not surprised to see the princess seated upon her throne and flanked by guards on either side. Soldiers were lined up along the carpet that led up to her highness, with pillars keeping them spaced out a bit.

Walking up, keeping his eyes upon the princess of kobolds – A rather busty lizard woman, with scales that were almost emerald green and so small you would be forced to gaze at her so closely your head would likely be removed from your neck. She wore fur to conceal her breasts and cover her nethers, though neither article was doing their job very well. Her horns, coming out from behind the ridges that were placed where human ears would be, curved up and slightly over her head. Her crown, a little black thing that bore the shape of all other princess crowns in the kingdom, was hung around one of her horns like a band.

She sat regally in her throne, made of iron and fitted with cushions where her back, arms and posterior made contact with the chair. Her tail was wrapped around to the front, curled over her lap. Her elbows were on the arms of the throne, her hands clasped in her lap with her claws locked firmly together. She looked at him with the air of nobility that all princesses had, frazzled and haggard an air though it was.

“Greetings.” She simply, her voice betraying nothing. “I'm glad you could make it so quickly, Sir Knight.”

Reaching a respectable distance, feeling the eyes of every guard focused on him, he knelt down on one knee. “Princess of the Kobolds, I have come as requested. I apologize for interrupting your slumber, but my escort,” he nodded towards the kobold at her side, “said that you wished to see me as soon as I arrived.”

“That I did.” The princess sniffed out, nodding. “Had things not been so dire, I would have offered you food and rest before setting out. Alas, things are indeed dire enough that I am unable to give you the hospitality that is usually dictated. I assume you have asked around the guards outside what they know?”

“Indeed, Princess. Though not much, I know that there is something in your mines that has pilfered not just your treasure, but the lives of your subjects as well. The miners you sent down there are all gone, as well as the soldiers that went down there looking for them.”

A silent nod greeted him, a somber look upon the princess's face. “Indeed. I cannot risk the lives of my subjects, but the mines are integral to our trade. Where we would normally deal with such problems ourselves, we have had to look elsewhere for a more seasoned hand at battle. You impressed me when you dealt with that bandit problem weeks ago, so quickly and brutally at that. I implore you to lend us your blade once again.”

“But of course, Princess. I would never deny an honor such as this, especially when called by name to your aid. I will dispatch the terror of the mines, or die trying.” The Knight claimed, the proclamation utterly sincere.

“I thank you, Sir Knight. In gratitude for your help, we would like to offer you a gift. You will get one of two items, the kobold dowries, to aid your efforts. Choose wisely.”
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: Business first, then strange magical rocks

choices: Ask about that before things become dire. Forewarned is forearmed
Let it lie. There are more dire things at the moment.
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
With a snap of her claws, two chests were brought to the front of the Knight by two more honor guards. They were placed in front of him before being opened by the guards, letting him see the contents.

In the left, an unlit red candle lay on a pillow. There seemed to be nothing out of the ordinary with it, but all the dowries of the princesses were said to be incredibly magical so he would never take it at face value. In the right, a slightly glowing piece of yellow stone, shimmering ever so slightly like the flame of a campfire.

“Take your pick, Sir Knight.” The princess said, leaning forward so slightly to see what he would choose. “Unfortunately, I can tell you nothing about them until you choose one, but both could help you now and in the future.”

Standing, the knight looked over the two objects. A candle would surely be good for the deeper parts of the mines, but he didn't know what else it could do. As for the stone, it could do just about anything, but it could also be a gamble.

“I choose the candle, Princess.” He said, nodding to his left.

The princess stared at him as the chest containing the stone snapped shut and was taken to the side once more. She looked him square in the eye through his helm, blue eyes meeting the black slitted pupils of the lizard woman.

Suddenly, she nodded to herself and stood. “I see. If that's the case, I will be coming with you.”

At once, every guard snapped to further attention than they already were, butts of spears hitting the ground as they readied to keep their princess safe from her own foolishness.

“Princess, what are you saying?” The kobold escort asked, looking wide eyed at his ruler. “It is much too dangerous for you to go into the mines!”

“My fate is tied to the holder of the candle, you know this.” She said softly, shaking her head with a small smile. “I feel that it was fate that we should need to call upon a knight in these times. That the knight left such an impression on me and came to my mind first only bolstered that thought, and that he has chosen the candle strengthens my resolve. I will go with our champion to confront the evil that has befallen my people.”

She walked over to the knight, who was feeling like had now made a mistake. Taking the candle from the chest, she gave the wax a soft kiss before she handed it to him. “Take care of this, sir knight. Should you fall, I will fall with you. Your strength will be my strength, and my strength your own. Our lives are now entwined, until the other should perish.”

The knight took the candle gently, the wick bursting into a bright red flame, lighting the entire throne room in its brilliance. Everyone shielded their eyes as the flame roared, waving back and forth wildly but never burning the two at the center of the magical inferno. They were aware of someone shouting and the sound of the door slamming open as other kobolds flowed into the room, weapons at the ready, but they seemed so distant in sound, as the two of them were still holding the candle.

Slowly, the fire died down, through the flame never lost its intensity. Blinking the spots from their eyes, Knight and Princess looked around at the guards who now surrounded them, weapons drawn.

“At ease, soldiers.” The princess said, feeling stronger now than she had before. “We are unharmed, and it was not of the knights doing. Be kind to him.”

The knight watched warily as the tip of a spear was pulled from his neck, the entirety of the kobold battalion that burst into the room slowly easing.

“Now, I want everyone to clear the castle of all kobolds. Civilian and guards alike.” She said, looking around her. “Though I do not doubt this brave knight, if we are to fall to whatever is in the mines, they are to be decreed lost to us. Go to the other kingdoms, go to the Knights guild, go wherever you must to escape whatever horrors lurk beneath our kingdom. But do not stay here, do not throw your lives away should the worst come to pass.”

With that, she turned to her stalwart knight, her champion and held out her clawed hand. “Shall we go, brave Champion? We must deal with this problem to my kingdom soon.”

Nodding, the knight took her hand with his left, the right still holding the candle, and walked through the throng of Kobolds who had snapped to attention at the princesses commands.

~

The mines were deep, and beyond the entrance from the castle antechamber they were incredibly dark. The knight and princess walked closely together, hand in hand. In his free hand, the knight held his sword at the ready, the blade already dripping with the blood and viscera of the giant bats that lived in these caverns, while the princess held aloft the candle, lighting their way brilliantly.

“If I remember the maps correctly, there should be a rest area ahead. We should be safe there. A chance to rest and clean your blade before we make the final stretch towards the current digsite.” The princess told the knight, pointing at the upcoming turn.

“That would be much appreciated, Princess.” His blade was getting too slick for a decent grip, and it wouldn't do for it to fly out of his hand mid swing. “I'm sure you could use the rest.”

The green bipedal lizard shook her head no, but the way her feet were dragging told the knight otherwise.

The knight turned the corner, sword at the ready, but was only greeted with the blackness of the mines before the princess joined him, shining the light down the tunnels. And indeed, the princess was right. An area enclosed with metal bars, containing a few tables and chairs, lanterns long since gone cold sitting upon the wooden tops. There were even cards sprawled along one table, though there was no one to play them anymore.

The only signs of trouble had been the upturned chairs and a few tables that were smashed, proving that whatever had taken the miners was immensely strong.

“This must have been where they were attacked.” The princess said softly, a frown forming on her muzzle. “But what could have done this?”

“I don't know, but it shan't harm your people any longer, Princess.” The knight reminded her, leading her into the cage and picking up two chairs. “Sit and rest. I brought some skins of water, and I must clean my sword. We should be fine for now, the bats haven't avoided the area completely. That means that whatever is lurking down here is not incredibly close.”

The princess could only nod, taking a skin of water from the knights pack as he set it down. He searched through the jumble of necessities for one of the cloths he kept for such dirty jobs as cleaning his blade and armor, taking a smoother one that he would usually clean his face of dirt and sweat and handing it to the Kobold. “You, ah, have some blood on your horns.”

“My thanks, sir knight.” She took the rag, setting the candle on the table. Idly, she dabbed the rag over horns, stopping momentarily as she touched the crown before continuing with a sigh. “Heavy is the head that bears the troubled crown.”

If the knight had heard, as he most certainly had, he did not show it. He merely kept silent as he gently wiped the entrails of the giant bats from his beloved sword. He'd been through so much with that blade. He'd had it for almost as long as he'd been knighted, one of his first purchases from the stock that was available only to knights. He'd slain bandits, dangerous animals, had it blessed when he had to exorcise a village that had been over run with wild undead, fought as a champion for both the human and the slime princesses against a golem champion and a slave champion of the goblins that was undoubtedly half-giant and helped protect an expedition to the west at the merchant princess's behest.

He had always taken good care of the blade, though he knew it wouldn't last much longer. Its blade was starting to notch, the blacksmiths unable to continue fixing it due to how thin the metal was getting. It was only thanks to that blessing that he was able to still carry it.

Alas, the gods cared only so much for a hunk of metal, even when it was used in their name to cleanse the evils that plagued the land. This would have to be the last quest he took it on, the last clash it would see.

But what a quest to end it on. Maybe he would be able to give it a name, or perhaps a bard would sing his tale, of being called to end the blight of the Kobolds, called by name by the princess herself and bringing prosperity to the kingdom once more.

And that drew him to another matter entirely. The candle and the princess. Why did he have the feeling it was like being married? It certainly sounded like wedding vows, and he had been to enough weddings to get the feeling that came from the princess when she said those words. Like a bride to her groom. And the dowries...
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: The candle and the Kobold... Marrige vows?

choices: What ho, a foe? Dost thou attempt to ambush us?
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
“Princess?” The knight asked, snapping her out of her own thoughts. “May I ask why you decided to bequeath me one of your peoples dowries? Surely they would be best suited to go to your own beloved?”

“Oh.” She breathed out, looking down. “Um, well, it's uh, quite simple. With the troubles we've had lately, with bandits and this beast in the mines, and the human princess's increase on the tax of any kobold passing through her lands, we do not have a great deal of funds to spare. In lieu of monetary payment, I was willing to give you my hand in marriage for preforming such feats for us in a short amount of time. That you took the candle instead of the ore was only proof that I was right to do so. All of the Kobold kingdom knows what happens when the princess gives the candle to someone. It is more binding than any vows or wedding band.”

A chill went up his spine at those words. Not in revulsion, but it still wasn't pleasant. “So, we are essentially married now?”

“Only in the eyes of the kobolds. None of the other kingdoms have ever acknowledged it, nor does the church of divine light. But the candle has been held in the kingdom since its inception. The princesses of ages past have always given the candle to their champions, and in turn married to the holder of the candle.” She said, blue tinting her cheeks in embarrassment.

Again, not something he knew kobolds could do.

“I understand if you do not wish to be my consort and wish to annul the marriage later, but I don't have anything else in the kingdom to give you of value.” She continued, her voice growing weak.

The knight paused the polishing of his sword, looking at the princess in a different light. To all but sell yourself for your kingdom was no small feat, especially when it put you in the direct line of danger.

This was a strange development to say the least.

“Not to mention the sheer intensity of the candle.” She said, motioning to the unmelted wax light. “It usually only burns as much as a regular candle. Only in the oldest legends, told only from one ruler to the next, has the candle burned so brightly, so warmly and fiercely as it did in the throne room. It only burned as such when it was gifted upon the first princess of our kingdom, and when she gifted it back to the giver immediately afterward.”

“I see.” The knight went back to polishing his sword. “I hope I haven't offended, Princess. I was merely curious. I had no idea the kingdom was in such dire straights. It's a brave thing you do for your people.”

“Oh no, you have nothing to apologize for.” She assured. “I only hope that you are not angry with my actions.”

The knight shook his head, though was silent otherwise. In turn, the princess remained silent, though a small sigh of relief escaped her. She finished off cleaning her horns, wiping the blood that had dripped on her head before setting the cloth on the table. She looked around the room again, illuminated entirely by the magic candle and shed a single tear for her lost subjects.

Down here, she need not hide herself entirely.
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: With nothing else to give
