1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
“Just down this tunnel and in the door to the latest vein of gold. It was a huge one, and we'd hoped that it would have solved our issues for the foreseeable future.”

The knight nodded, pushing the princess behind him. He readied sword and shield, slowly creeping up on the open door. Just as he was on the threshold, he raised his shield and charged in, ready to spring to the side.

Hearing no danger, the Kobold Princess followed her champion into the room, albeit far more cautiously. As the light from the candle she carried illuminated the room, both knight and companion could only look on in shock and awe at the sight before them.

Heaps upon heaps of gold. Veritable mountains of shiny yellow rock, hills of glimmering ore, ready to be processed into anything they could need it for.

“All the gold...” The Kobold princess breathed out. “The miners had said they had hit the largest payload in decades, but I never thought...”

The knight could only nod, still at the ready for any foe. But still, for so much gold to be here, the Kobolds could have toppled the Goblins from their long held economic control.

They slowly entered the room, skirting around the mountain of valuables. The knight was ready to pounce at a moments notice, but weather that be to attack or defend was debatable.

The kobold princess opened her mouth, about to ask the question that was on both their minds when something made them stiffen.

A deep intake of breath, pulling some of the treasures into a gaping maw underneath it all and the sounds of rocks being chewed up before a large, audible swallow.

The kobold princess couldn't help her knees shake, almost letting out a squeak in fear and dropping the candle as the knight readied to get the princess out of danger.

The monster let out a large belch, sending the treasure that had piled atop it scattering down across the floor. It sat up, stretching its arms above its head, wings unfurling in the spacious cavern as it let out a large yawn.

As the two smaller, much smaller creatures looked up at the form of the 'monster' of the mines, Kobold princess had wished that it was something simple as a strong monster.

But no, it couldn't have been so simple.

“Ah, that hit the spot. Such delicious treasure. Those stupid lizards would have ruined it. Unrefined is much tastier than trinkets.” Grumbled the being who caused fear in every person, from peasant to princess with merely the thought of a visit.

The Dragon Princess.

“Though, I don't remember it being so bright in here...” She said, looking around. “That must mean there's a little thief running about. And after my treasure!”

As soon as the thought that someone might have taken even a single bit of her horde, the Princess turned around and caught their eyes before they could even move.

“And there they are. A little rat and his accomplice.” She said, standing to her full height as the gold rolled down her body. “I expected you to leave me be, Kobold Princess. Killing your subjects should have told you that I did not want to be disturbed.”

“D-dragon Princess!” The Kobold yelped in fright, though she tried to keep from shaking even more. “W-we didn't know you were coming to grace us with your presence... W-why have you c-come?”

“Don't play dumb with me, Princess!” The Dragon roared, making the cavern shake. “You know why I'm here, even your tiny brain knows that.” She said, tapping a claw to the side of her own head as she stomped over, crushing any ore that fell beneath her feet like she was walking through a puddle. “I'm here for what's mine.”

“Y-yours? W-what is y-your-”

“EVERYTHING!” The Dragon roared again, fire licking between her teeth as she stared at the two of them with sheer greed and contempt. This time, rocks fell from the ceiling as the ground groaned around them.

The Dragon Princess was very tall, with a long neck atop a slightly pudgy body. Massive knockers hung from her chest, with thick hips supporting her form. Large, leathery wings graced her back, with a long and thick tail sprouting from just above her plump rear. Her scales were a deep red, not unlike the candle that shook in the lizard girls hands, with a light pink running up her belly from her inner thighs to her lower jaw.

Thick, long and sharp claws were fixed on the ends of her fingers, and most likely her toes as well, and she had two gems in her forehead. Atop her head, between the two horn ridges, was a gleaming ruby crown that would have made the kobold princess look small if they stood on even ground. Her eyes gleamed red in the light, embers occasionally floating into view.

Around her neck she wore what the knight could only assume was an incredibly large feather boa, also red. The only clothing she wore could possibly be described as “barely underclothes” but even that was stretching it thin...

Wait, no. Stretching it thin would also describe the fabric. Her breasts were barely contained in the bra she wore, and it seemed like it would bust at any moment. The same for her small clothes, which highlighted and emphasized her lower regions quite immensely. The stings that held the whole thing up were barely visible threads, sinking into the supple and slightly doughy skin of her waist.

“When I'm through with your gold, I'll be taking everything else in this hovel you call a castle!” The princess stated, merely a matter of fact to her that this would happen.

“B-but Princess,” The Kobold stammered out. “How will my people live if you take everything?”

“This is none of my concern.” The dragon dismissed the worry, leaning her head closer to the duo. “I am the ruler of this land, and if I say I'm taking something I don't need to explain myself. Especially not to a little ground lizard like you.”

She pulled her head back, finally looking at the knight once more, sword and shield at the ready still. She gave a little smirk, drool dripping from between her teeth now. “Unless, of course, you plan to fight me. But even you can't be that stupid, Kobold. Your kind aren't fighters, you're barely even worthy of bearing the title of Princess!”

Something in the kobold princess's demeanor changed – her cheeks puffed out, shoulders squared and the ridges on her head flared – and she strode forward just past her champion. “That's enough, you overgrown salamander! We Kobolds have suffered enough! You are leaving! Right! NOW!”

The candle in her hands flared brightly, burning blue for a moment, but doing little else. The dragon looked down at the princess, regarding her like a piece of trash.

Suddenly, her face was right above the smaller lizard, fangs bared and fire leaping from her tongue. Her arms were spread out, claws poised for use as her wings flared out and beat to cause a large gust of wind.

“Make me.”

That was all the warning she gave before letting loose a torrent of dragon fire from her maw, liquefying the stone that had been where the two smaller people stood merely seconds ago. The sound of ores scrapping along the stone floor told her that she had missed and that her prey was fleeing.

With a roar, she turned to her left, swinging her tail to the right to catch them in a much smaller area. She wouldn't miss again.

“Run, Princess! Run for safety!” The knight yelled, dropping his sword to bodily throw the Kobold over the oncoming tail towards the door. “Get your people out of here! I'm sorry for choosing the candle!”

He was lucky to get that out as he raised his shield against the massive, muscly appendage to keep it from flattening him or crushing his ribs. Grunting in pain, he was flung across the room and into the claws of the dragon as his shield was flung off his arm uselessly.

"Well well, what have we here?" The dragon taunted, gripping him in her large hand. “A champion for the brainless lizard?”
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: Meeting the monster, lizard on lizard animosity

choices: There are multiple ways out, but that one was the closest. Make to the next one!
There's no need to worry, the destruction of the keep will help make an escape!
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
“In fact, yes.” The knight ground out, ignoring the fear that caused his heart to beat faster. “I was only told that there was a monster in the mines and was asked to deal with it. Nobody knew it was one of the feared dragons taking up residence in these caverns.”

The dragoness looked at the knight, sizing him up. She gave a little squeeze of her hand, making the armor cave ever so slightly in her grasp. When he didn't squeal or yelp in pain, she smirked at him.

“Oh, and if you did, would you have refused the job?” She asked, her fangs showing as she brought him up to her face. “Would you have let the Kobolds suffer?”

“Any good knight would have taken the quest, regardless. Especially when called by name.” The captive knight said, ignoring the sharp bits of metal that were poking him all over his body. “It would be an act of cowardice to do otherwise, and the one who did would forfeit the title of knight forever more.”

Again, the dragon regarded him, scrutinizing him under her withering gaze as he made no move to escape. She was much too strong for him to do anything in his current position. But he needed to do something, anything to escape.

“You are a good knight,” she admitted at last, through grudgingly. “But an incredibly stupid one. What hope would you have of defeating myself or my sisters, let alone my mother?”

“None, princess.” The knight also admitted, though his was humble, the long years of serving the various royalty kicking in. “But for my honor and the sake of others, I would have walked to face your entire family should it buy them even a second to flee.”

The dragoness preened under the title, savoring the respect that she had heard in his voice. However, as he continued to speak, her gaze turned sharp, looking not quite at him but not quite through him either. Her grip tightened a little more, causing several bits of metal to dig into his skin.

But still, the knight did not let his agony show.

“A foolish knight indeed.” She whispered, flames flickering from her maw once more. Before blinking, her anger momentarily forgotten as she felt something on her tail.

Turning around, she dropped the knight as she spied the little lizard that she thought had scurried off was biting her tail!

The larger of the two lizards lifted her tail up, slamming it back down to dislodge the green irritant, the knight all but forgotten. She found no satisfaction when the pest bounced along the floor, hitting a few of the larger rocks before hitting the wall with a heavy smack.

“You dare to touch me, let alone attack me?” The red titan growled out, stalking up to the soon-to-be deceased leader of the lesser lizards. “You attack your ruler? I was only going to punish you beforehand, but now it seems I must remind the Grand Tower Kingdom of exactly why they fear me.”

The Kobold Princess shook her head of the fog, feeling her head bleeding and pain in her jaw. But she looked up at the greater in strength of the two of them defiantly.

“I hereby sentence your entire kingdom to death.”The Dragon princess told her, dragging out every word with unadulterated loathing and contempt. “To be carried out immediately by yours truly. Fields will be burned, your castle reduced to rubble and your people reduced to ash. Starting with YouuUUURRGH!”

The knight pulled his blade from the foot of the dragoness, avoiding her knee as she came crashing down. He slashed at her arms as they went to grasp her wounded foot, drawing more blood and cries of agony from the great princess of terror. She tried to grab at him again, but he swung his sword once more, slicing her hand from the middle of her palm down to the wrist. She jerked her hand away, sobbing in pain as the sword was pulled with her hand from the knight as if it were a giant metal thorn.

“Quickly Princess, we must flee!” He said, pulling the smaller princess to her feet and running from the room. “We must gather my supplies and alert your people. I don't know what the dragon princess will do when she recovers, but your people are no longer safe in these lands.”

The kobold princess said nothing, having to pant to keep up with the running knight, having just enough time to grab the candle from outside the door as they left the dig site.

“You little thieves.” The mighty princess sobbed, tears flowing onto the floor as her entire body shook. “I'll be back for you all. You'll rue the day you attacked me!” She moaned out, fury mounting as what happened really hit her. “You'll all BURN!”

Head turned towards the ceiling, she let loose a gout of flame in a wild roar. She turned her head, this way and that, covering everything in fire as the earth around her shook at her rage. Roar after terrible roar she unleashed, more and more dragonfire setting what rocks didn't melt ablaze in the mystical fire of her family.

With effort she stood, flapping her wings. Taking to the air in the spacious cavern, she let loose one last tongue of flame at the floor, reducing it to magma and melting the ore back into the earth. Then, with eyes filled with rage and pain, she blasted through the hole in the ceiling that she initially made when she entered the caverns via the mountains, melting it as she flew out towards the surface.

~

However, the damage that the dragon had done was not so contained. All around the mines, tunnels were collapsing like a house of cards, only to then collapse on one another again and make deep, treacherous pits that would eventually become the home of those dark, abyssal creatures that children saw in their nightmares. The giant bats that called the caves home previously were all stirred to panic, chirping and squeaking in the rush for any of the vents to the surface to escape certain death.

The knight and the princess, the former having quickly discarded their armor once they reached the rest area and gathered his pack of supplies, tried to reach the path that would lead back to the palace.

Unfortunately, the fates were not so kind to them. As rocks fell down on the helm of the knight, who was doing his best to keep the kobold Princess from harm of the slightly larger rocks, he had to skid to a stop when he reached the last junction before the series of tunnels that would have led them to safety only to discover a pit that had fallen down three 'floors' of the extensive mine that run under the Kobold capital.

“Princess, please tell me there is another way out of here? A entrance for the workers to take their haul out without going through the palace?” The knight asked, holding the princess back from running headlong into the pit.

“I-I think so,” She gasped out, trying not to choke on her own saliva as she struggled to draw breath. “It's t-that way...”

The knight felt that he had dealt with enough for the day to let out a groan of irritation. The way the princess pointed, while not directly across from them, was still over the yawning chasm that loomed before them. Merely to the left of them though.

“I can throw you that distance, my lady.” He said, about to pick up the Kobold again. “But I doubt I can make it myself with my pack.”
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: Try to stall!

choices: Hours later, she awakes to the stars in the sky
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
The princess was about to object, saying that there was multiple ways out when the ground shook again. A great, resounding crack and the sound of stone grinding on stone filled the tunnels and seemed to be coming from-

“Move!” The knight yelled, grabbing the smaller being and dove back into the relative safety of the tunnel away from the pit. He covered her body with his, grunting as stones fell onto his back and cut into the already torn skin of his extremities.

But he could not allow harm to come to the Princess! His knightly vows would demand nothing less than his best in keeping her from harm, and his self-worth would only demand more! He would not fail, never again!

A great sound, the thundering of the earth as it tore itself apart, shattering and reducing itself to rubble roared in his ears as he felt the air forced from the chasm they had just been at the edge of. When the vibrations had settled, aside from the larger quakes directly caused by the dragon Princess that were still going on, the knight dared to look up and back.

“It seems we are possessed of some great luck today, princess.” He said, feeling lightheaded at the turn of events and a little bit of blood loss. “Come, we must go now!” He yelled as he pulled her up yet again, all but dragging her along the now filled pit over the rubble of what was a bit of the kitchens.

“Princess, please pick yourself up!” He asked, stopping to allow the Kobold to right herself. When he looked back, her could only sigh as the Princess had trouble standing, her breaths ragged and shallow. “Fine then. Forgive my insolence for this, but needs must.”

He scooped up the princess, who clung for dear life to both candle and knight, into a bridal carry, making sure he had positioned her tail correctly so it wouldn't trip him as he took off on a dead sprint, grateful that his armor had been discarded.

Bounding down the still shaking halls, he followed the tunnels thankfully single hall, the dead ends being boarded up as the earth groaned again and again. Each new sound was enough to stop his heart, fearing that the ground would split in twain at each footfall and swallow the two whole.

But, soon enough they saw blessed sunlight, far off but enough to give the knight a rush of hope, and with it one last burst of energy.

With a primal yell, the old way of telling the world he would not die here, he pumped his legs harder, ignoring the creaking of his tired and battered bones as he threw every last drop of strength into escaping alive with the shaking woman in his arms. The sprint became a maddened, frenzied dash of sheer adrenaline rush and terror of death looming all around only increased the potency of it as the light grew closer...

Closer.

Closer!

Sweet air! The sunlight was beating down on the earth as the hills shook, fire and smoke billowing from the mountains as the bats from the caves, the lucky ones at least, made a cloud in the sky before they flittered off into a nearby wood in the slime kingdom.

And still, the knight did not stop. He could vaguely hear, over the sound of his blood pounding in his ears, the cries and shouts of all the kobolds that were still escaping the collapse of the capital. But he could not stop now if he wanted to. His body was no longer under his command as he sprinted right through the mining district of town, passed the long thrown open gates of the city where whatever small amount of Kobolds still lived in the starved for work part of town had fled from at the first sign of trouble.

He did not stop to watch as half of the Kobold Keep had sunk into the earth, nor did he stop when they crested the hills and when they could no longer see the soon-to-be ruins. He did not stop for another hour, a testament to the endurance of the knights, his own fortitude and the sheer danger that they just escaped from to instill such terror.

Finally, when the sun reached its zenith in the heavens did the knight stop. Breath shallow and ragged, legs pulsing an angry red and knees shaking in weariness, so far from the danger that he could no longer feel the ground shake beneath him did he allow himself to all but collapse at the side of the road still clutching the Princess in his arms.

However, even his arms fell uselessly down, allowing the princess to finally roll free of his grasp. She had been trying to get him to stop for close to the entire hour he had ran, ceasing her actions when she realized he wouldn't listen to her at the moment and resigned to being held in his arms until he stopped. Despite herself, she felt much safer being held in her champions arms than she had in her entire life being surrounded by the royal guard.

But now she had to act. Her knight was barely able to breath and he needed to cool off quickly! Using her claws to slice the straps of his pack, she pulled it away from him and grabbed at the water skins he had and dug out the potions made by the alchemists of the knight guild, Inc. that no knight ever left without. She threw anything that wasn't the desired items carelessly to the side until she spotted the cloth that the bottles were usually wrapped in to prevent fractures, cracking and breaking of the bottles.

Gathering what she needed, she turned back to the knight and poured the water over his legs, wishing she had some other way of cooling him down but not knowing what else to do. The last of the skins emptied, she quickly pulled off her savior's helmet, turned him over while uncorking a bottle and pouring the liquid down his throat, gently lifting his head to make the task slightly easier.

“Calm down, brave knight.” She said, looking into his eyes that starred blankly outwards, pupils as wide as the eye of a needle and shaking. Sweat poured down his entire body, his skin flushed red all over. His cheeks struggled to keep up with his need for air between administrations of the potions. “We are safe here. Do not worry for now, just take deep breaths. Yes, that's it. No, don't try and move your head anymore than I have. No, not your arms either. I will sit on you if you try to move again, so stop it!”

The knight, while not there mentally, seemed to be recovering as expected with the potions. While they wouldn't be able to do much more without a stockpile, he would be ready to move in a few hours. Already his arms had gone from utterly useless to shaking and twitching which was much better, right?

The Kobold princess sighed, setting the last bottle to the side. There was nothing more she could do right now than wait. And right now, all of her adrenaline was leaving her system as well. Her eyes drooped, and she found herself laying her head on the tunic covered chest of her knight, her champion.

As her eyelids drooped, she glimpsed what looked to be a piece of golden ore as the world went black.
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: Grim convinences and through strength of will

choices: The princess asks about the stone, seeing a chunck missing
The knight decided to use the stone on his own
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
The Kobold princess struggled to open her eyes, drained as she was. Sleep was already trying to claim her again, but she knew it was necessary for her to do so. She must ensure the well being of her knight!

And that dragging sound was really bothering her.

Bleary eyed, blinking away the sensitivity to the light, she squinted so she could see better.

Was she moving? Yes, by the bobbing of the trees in the distance she was moving. Being carried, to be precise. And, by the feel of the arms and the chest, now bare, she was being carried by the knight she had worried about.

Oh, he must have been dragging his pack along, now that it had no straps. She twitched in shame, making her knight do so much work after he had done so much for her already, despite losing her kingdom.

At least she still had the candle, carefully placed in her arms by her knight, and the hope that enough of her people were safe. They could rebuild the castle, but she would need her subjects to help.

“Sir knight.” She murmured, causing him to halt. “Tell me, how are you faring?” She asked softly.

“Well enough, princess.” He replied, his voice hoarse and raspy. “You?”

“Much better than you, I should think. Please, set me down. I do not wish to burden you more than I already have.”

“'Tis no – ergh – burden, princess.” He replied before sucking in a breath. “But it would be appreciated.”

Slowly, the knight let the princess touch her feet to the ground, keeping her steady as the last vestiges of sleep left her weary body. His body moved slowly, gingerly from the neck down. His legs still pulsed slightly, but nowhere near as bad. And indeed, it was his bag that he was dragging along behind him, secured with some rope that she remembered tossing out earlier to get the potions.

“Oh, sir Knight...” She whispered, reaching up to touch the helm he wore once more. “How can you stand to move in such a state?” She looked at the scars of the wounds he had sustained in the mines, from where the armor had pierced his body and then rocks had slashed the skin.

“As I said in the mines, needs must.” He said, taking a gulp of air and sighing. “Now, we mustn't dawdle. I know a safe spot for us to camp for the night, and we'll only just make it there by sundown. That should give me enough time to set up camp at my reduced pace, though we'll have to make due without a fire or a hot meal.”

Nodding, the princess took up stride by the bedraggled knight, helping him when he stumbled every so often. She tried to help pull the pack, but it was an awkward affair and her knight insisted on doing it himself, though he meant no harm in it.

And so it was, hours later just as the sun started to fall below the horizon that they arrived at the edge of the cursed valley. The Kobold Princess felt a shiver run down her spine, seeing the land in all its unnaturalness. She could not help but stop just as the knight crossed the threshold of the forsaken land.

“Sir knight, is it wise to enter this area? No one has traveled this accursed valley in a long time. Not even the dragons dare come here.”

“Exactly why it's safe.” He simply said, walking further in, dragging the pack in the dirt. He was so close to a resting spot where he could let his body give out once more. He would not stop until he could rest.

The princess looked around nervously, twiddling her claws as her tail constantly tweaked itself in fear. However, that one sentence made her shove aside any other fact for the moment and quickly try to catch up with her knight. Even when the gem and the three obelisks got closer and closer, she stuck by her knight, knowing he would keep her safe.

It was only when they reached the obelisks did they finally drop. The knight didn't even bother to put up a tent, his limbs so sore. He sat against the golden monolith as he had the day before, eyes bleary as his eyes drifted up to the floating gem. He did not even notice, tired as he was, when the bipedal lizard curled up next to him, trying to absorb any warmth she could from his body.

She snuggled close, trying to ignore the myriad of unpleasant feelings the coursed through her. Her body wanted to leave, horrible tingles arcing through her nerves constantly that had only gotten worse as they neared the landmarks, buzzing in her skull like she had swallowed a bee hive with all its denizens and her tail would not still for all she tried. Her stomach churned, though she knew not why as every rational part of her mind, nay, her very soul screamed at her to run as far from the land as possible, to take up shelter in the open plains rather than this wretched land.

Alas, she could not... No, she would not leave her knight. Not now, or for a very long time. She just had to do her best to ignore the whole thing until they reached better lands than these for her own comfort. Her knight needed all the rest he could get. He deserved the rest.

“Sleep tight, my knight.” She breathed out, letting her eyes close once more as sleep claimed her quickly. Unconsciously, she snuggled even further into his side as she slept, candle held close to her chest.

As for the knight, his eyes kept drifting from the floating gem to his pack. The stone kept coming to mind, more specifically what it had read.

To start the quest for fame untold;
You've been given this chunk of gold;
But sell it not for riches now;
for wealth it can not avow;
This piddly little piece of stone;
Can give the power to rule all thrones;
Trust the writing to lead you true;
And your balls will never blue;
So follow the words and test your might;
Throw this stone at gem so bright!

Oh, if he had listened to that... Maybe, just maybe, he would have been able to stop the dragon princess from destroying the city. The power to rule all thrones sounded like it could even tame the queen's rage, and that certainly would have been useful when dealing with her less powerful daughter.

But alas, he hadn't. Now, the kobolds pay the price when he could have done something to prevent it. He had been forced to drag their princess into the cursed lands, away from her desperate people who probably thought she was dead by now, lost to the beast of the mines and their homes destroyed.

He himself was down to only his trusty helm, every other piece of armor rendered useless by the dragon princess, and the clothes he wore under them with some extras in his pack. He had no water, no potions, no weapon and he could only just feel anything in his arms or legs, though none of the feeling was any good except to prove he wasn't dead yet.

As he stared at the gem one last time, he could no longer resist the call of unconsciousness and tumbled down into a forced sleep.

~

Groaning, the knight awoke to the sun just coming over the horizon. The opposite end of the sky was still dark, but that was slowly fading away with the coming day.

Every joint was stiff, aching from what he had done the previous day. He flexed the fingers in his right hand, every knuckle popping something fierce and making him groan again.

Looking to his left, he spotted the still sleeping form of the princess leaning on him and cradling the candle to her bosom. The flame was stronger now, having recovered from a tiny wisp of fire to the strength of a normal candle.

“Princess, it is time to wake. I must make it back to the guild. We can send envoys to the corners of the kingdoms to spread the word to the rest of the princesses and any kobolds they come across of what the dragon princess has done and the news that you are still alive.” He said, shaking her shoulder as he ignored the feeling of her breasts pressed against him, covered only slightly by the thin fur clothing she wore. They were surprisingly soft, not as tough as he figured they would have been with scales though...

No, bad knight! That's highly unprofessional of you! Such disrespect was unwarranted!

She groaned, shaking her upper body as she opened bleary eyes once more. She blinked, rubbing the back of her arm across her face as she looked around before looking up at her knight.

“Oh, sir knight.” She mumbled, sitting up and away from him, her body craving his warmth in this foul land. “Apologies. Your arm must be sore, and my sleeping on it did no good.”

“Worry not, princess.” He said, holding back a yawn as he slowly flexed his entire arm, rolling his shoulder around and getting another pop and a hiss. “It's fine.”

The princess nodded, but did not look convinced of his wellness. A groan rumbled from her stomach as she opened her mouth to speak. She snapped her muzzle shut, faint blue appearing across her face as she turned her eyes away in shame.

Despite himself, the knight couldn't help but chuckle slightly, his own stomach joining the chorus as he reached over for his pack. “It may not be what you're used to having, Princess, but I do have some travel rations that will ease the pangs. It should tide us over until we reach the guild by tomorrow midday.”

She nodded, taking the dried meat and fruit as he offered it, slowly nibbling the meat as her eyes warily roamed the valley, occasionally being forced to stare at the four features again and again. Nothing sat well about this place, and she recalled her mother having the same problem and well as her mother before her.

None of the princesses had ever wandered into this valley, preferring to give it a wide berth whenever they traveled near it. It was the same from generation to generation, from mother to daughter. Even the golem princess never dared travel these lands, and she was surely the longest lived princess being an automaton. All she would say on the matter, however, was that she had purged those records from her database with a reminder to never set foot in this place again.
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: Into the valley to follow her knight

choices: They walk away, forgetting to throw the stone
The knight does as the stone asks, throwing it at the crystal
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
It was on the seventh or eighth pass of the golden obelisk that they lay at the foot of did the princess notice the flaw in its surface. She tilted her head, puzzling where she had see that exact color of stone before, and at that size too. Could it have been that rock she had seen the other day?

“Sir knight, would you perchance have a yellow stone in your possession?” She asked, handing back the uneaten fruits and meats to her stalwart companion.

“Huh? Oh, yes. And before you ask, it did come from this monolith behind us. Hit me on the back of my head. If it weren't for my helm, I would never have made it to your kingdom.” He said, rapping a fist against the steel perched on his head before taking out the rock from the other day. “I never really take it off for just such reasons. Anyway, here's the rock.” He said, passing it over without really caring. He didn't think the princess would get angry at him for not following the instructions on a mysterious rock from the land where no but him ever ventured.

The princess took the rock, ignoring the feeling of disgust that threatened to overwhelm her at the mere touch of the stone and looked it over as she peered between it and the hole in the otherwise perfectly flat surface.

Indeed, it was the same chunk of stone that was missing, being perfectly flat on one side while every other side was roughly round. But, what was the strange writing? The words seemed to twist and snake around one another before her eyes, sometimes vanishing and reappearing on other spots of the rock that wasn't the flat side while others they seemed to sink deep into the core of the stone or surge forth from it, turning as if they floated in the water. They weren't any symbols she recognized though, and it was giving her a very bad headache just looking at it.

“Sir knight, did you see this writing?” She asked, pointing out the various squiggling lines and curves. “It's curious, isn't it? What do you think these symbols mean?”

Unseen, he cocked an eyebrow. He didn't know the Kobold princess was illiterate. Or maybe she took a harder hit to her head than he originally thought when she was thrown against the wall.

“I read it the when I first picked it up, princess.” He told her, looking at the top of her head. No, no blood or bruising to suggest brain damage. Maybe the back of her head?

“Oh!” She said, looking at him in renewed interest.” I had no idea you were a mage or scholar as well, sir knight. Please tell me, what do these strange symbols mean? I feel myself getting woozy trying to keep track of them as they move around. They're not any language I am familiar with either.”

“Move around? Princess, it's written in the common tongue, plain enough for anyone to read.” He said, slight worry creeping into his voice. “I think we should be on our way and stop by the capital city of the humans to have you looked over by a doctor.”

“No, it's not. And my vision is fine, thank you very much.” She said, puffing out her cheeks in indignation. “If you can read it, tell me what it says.” She pushed the stone into his hand, feeling slightly better once it left her palm.

“As you wish.” The knight sighed, turning the stone in his hand to read the words once more to the princess, who listened very intently, her stomach dropping with each line that he completed. There was no doubt that it sounded like a prophecy.

Her knight had been given this piece of stone to start another quest, perhaps by providence. He would gain untold power, though the stone itself was worthless. But not entirely, because he had to throw it at the floating gem behind her so maybe it was a key and nothing else? And she tried to ignore the feeling that wormed into her heart when he read the line of trusting the writing to never let his balls blue. He would become the most famous man in the world if he completed this quest, which she felt was earned by the knight already. To fight against one of the dragon princesses and come out alive was already worthy of songs for ages.

Still, the line about gaining the power to rule all thrones made her feel a tad bit giddy at the thought of the dragons getting their comeuppance for all they had done over the years. Maybe they could finally live without fear of the queen's wrath should she be dethroned.

“I think you should do it.” She said, feeling something stir within her. “Throw the stone and take whatever power awaits you.”

The knight looked over at her, puzzled once again by her. “But should I, really? I mean, what if this is an act of deception by infernal forces? No one but I had walked these lands for a long time, Princess.”

“I think it matters little what you choose now, sir knight.” She told him, looking at the hanging target with such intensity that it should have shattered then and there. “A prophecy always comes true, and for power such as this to call out to you in such a manner it might be spurned by not taking it sooner rather than later. And it would be best for you to take it rather than let it fall into the hands of another. You have already proven yourself to be kind and noble, so I doubt you would use this power for evil purposes.”

The knight nodded at her reasoning, feeling his cheeks flush when she praised him so earnestly. It was not often that any of the princesses offered praise outside the occasional smile at a knight. But still, there was something she wasn't telling him if the grip she had on the candle when she picked it back up meant anything.

“And I take it that you wish to see the dragons pulled from the skies?” He asked. “The power to rule all thrones does sound like it could do so with ease, after all.”

“I will not lie to you, my knight.” She told him evenly, turning to stare him squarely in the eye slits in his helm. “I wish to see the destroyer of my kingdom on her knees and in chains before my rebuilt throne. I want my people to know justice for their loss, and I will not lie and say vengeance does not sound sweet to my ears. To have that fiend at my mercy as we were at hers, to take everything she holds dear away from her. If she would destroy my people for my rescuing you, then I would have her suffer.”

The knight stared back at her, matching stare for stare as he searched her eyes. He could see the hatred in her eyes, smoldering into her soul. It was a hatred he had seen too many times before, but amplified by magnitudes of power. This was the wrath of a displaced princess after seeing her people torn from their homes and all their work for naught. He didn't know how many had died, likely never would, but for the princess it was almost certainly a far greater loss than she had ever felt.

Even still, the anger and hatred would do no good to let it consume her, not now when her people still needed her if only for the hope she could inspire.

“Princess,” He started. “I would caution against focusing on vengeance. It brings only more problems down the road.”

“Then what would you have me do!?” She yelled at him, tears forming in her eyes as she threw one hand up, the other clutching the candle to her tightly. “Do we not live under the tyranny of the dragons? They take and take and take and never do anything else. When was the last time the queen or her daughters ever did anything to help the people that live under their rule? The Princesses of the kingdoms at least try and help their subjects, give them a goal to strive toward while keeping the peace where possible!”

She took a deep breath, shuddering and blinking away the tears. She cast her eyes down, her entire form drooping in a combination of deep sadness and righteous anger. “I do not mean to take my anger out on you, sir knight. I am merely at my limit after so much has happened to my people.”

The knight slowly nodded, tentatively putting his hand on her shoulder in a comforting gesture. “I understand, princess. It is not easy to lose those closest to you, and I can faintly understand what it must be like to lose an entire kingdom.”

She sniffed, looking back up at her knight. She gave a small smile, using the back of her hand to wipe away a few tears. “I thank you, my champion. No matter how long it takes, I will make sure you go down in the history of the kobold kingdom as a hero.”

The knight smiled back at her through his helm, chuckling softly. “We'd better be on our way then, shan't we?”
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: Questions, use for power and a wish for vengence

choices: A deep. deep hole is what they fall into
Stone, yet not stone, is what greets him
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
“But, the stone.” The Kobold reminded the princess, looking at the apparent key to untold power. “You should still use it now. Even if nothing comes of it, it would be better to clear the doubt from our minds that it might help us.”

The knight looked back to the rock he had set aside. The princess was right, and it was a simple process. Just throw the rock and be done with it.

Rock now in hand, he tossed it up in the air lightly a few times to get a good weight as he took aim. It wouldn't be difficult to hit the crystal on the first shot.

With a whip of his arm, he set the rock to fly with a whistle. It struck the crystal, sending cracks throughout the hovering jewel as it embedded deeply inside its target.

Eerily silent, the clear gem shattered, clattering to the ground as time seemed to stop. The world waited with baited breath, but for what neither knight nor princess knew. Nothing moved, even in this dead land, as the shards settled to the ground.

As moments ticked by, there was a subtle change in the air. It was heavier, ominous and ever so slightly oppressive. It caused sweat to form on the brow of the knight and the princess began to shake at the knees.

Not completely in fear, however.

Then, as the knight moved to stand closer to the lizard-folk royalty, he felt it. The most important change in the air of the land. It was a surprise he hadn't noticed it before, being an altogether pleasant change compared to the others.

A slight breeze.

Looking amidst the shards without moving, he noticed what appeared to be a small crack, like a door in the ground. From the slight upward movement of the air, it was coming from there.

“Princess, do you see this as well?” He waited, not receiving an answer. “Princess?”

He turned to his companion, only to find her fixated on the crack in the ground. Her entire body was shaking now, though it was only half terror now. Her pupils had widened to incredible size and... was that drool?

Before he could start moving towards her to see if there was anything he could do, the lizard woman started moving towards the crack in the earth, the crystal flowing around her like water as she moved.

It was time to move.

“Princess!” He called, walking as fast as he could, which wasn't very fast still, leaving his pack behind. As with the princess, the crystal seemed to flow around him, touching him but just so, never for very long and it returned to shape as he passed. “Princess, wait! Where are you going?”

But, she would not answer him. She moved towards the opening, which was now growing wider as the two approached, like a woman possessed. Something down there was drawing her into a trance of some kind!

“Stop, princess! Stop!” He yelled out, fearing she would step into a hole and fall to her demise. “Don't get closer to the hole!”

Still, she did not heed his warning.

Straining his already sore muscles to their limit, the knight sprinted towards her just as her foot went over the edge. He tried to angle it so a flying tackle would send both of them to the side...

Oh no.

It didn't work. The knight turned as much as he could, clutching the princess in his arms as they fell into the darkness lit only by the candle. He would rather his back shatter than allow the princess to get hurt or worse. He would not fail again, and his honor would not let him do any less.
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: The path is opened

choices: He reads it or something else
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
The knight grit his teeth, waiting for the pain to arrive. This was surely a steep staircase, as he had yet to hit a single step. He knew he was still falling down, the air rushing past them as they fell into this chasm.

“Oof~” the air was pushed from his lungs as he felt his back hit the stone. Yet, it did not hurt him. It gave way, like a feather pillow but to a greater degree. He resisted the urge to cry out as he was flung back into the air, still going down the stair way.

Bounce

Bounce

Bounce

Bounce

Bounce

Bounce

He bounced at least a good ten more times, almost biting his tongue but barely managing to do so. The world was turning and spinning and rushing past him so fast he could make no sense of what he was seeing other than the fact that there were walls.

He grunted in shock as he hit a wall, likely a landing, and was sent even further down the twisted ride he had found himself on. Faster and faster and faster they went, Kobold Princess much calmer than she had been up top, though he wished she would stop drooling on him and trembling in what he knew now was not terror in the slightest.

Down, down, down, down, landing, down, down, landing, down...

Honestly now, thought the knight as he kept Kobold Princess close even as she started to hump his body. When will this end? It feels like I've passed through the world at least twice now. Surely it must be getting to be night time on the surface.

At least the air wasn't musty and moldy as it should have been. With how far down they were, it should have been impossible to breath. Plus he was curious about the nature of the stairway, and more than a touch nervous. Would they be able to get back up, or would they be trapped?

And just like that, the bouncing stopped. Rather abruptly at that, though still not painful. Just enough firmness that he wouldn't bounce anymore.

As the knight sat up, Kobold Princess still tucked away into his arms as she ground her squishy bosom and her wet nethers into his body, drooling against his neck as the Red Candle nestled in the cleavage, he could feel the ground return to a firm state that felt as rocks should, not that springy, bouncy feeling that it was before.

After a few moments, spent equally between trying to clear his head and pry the lizard woman (and what a woman she was!) off his person, he gave up on the latter and stood with an arm keeping the princess from falling to the ground. He groaned when he had to dig the red candle from her bosom though, needing the light source to not run into a wall or worse.

He cautiously took his first step, making sure he wouldn't be sent on another bouncing adventure as he looked around.

Stone walls, dark blue in color where the light of the candle touched, were all that greeted him. They were smooth, and when he ran his elbow against one it slid easily along its surface. The floor was smooth as well, but not nearly as smooth as the wall, and he tried to slip to no effect. Braziers dotted along the hallways, which were ever so occasionally broken by branching paths and hallways that looked like more of the same.

However, he kept going down the central corridor that he first landed in. No need to get lost, after all. Plus, loathe though he was to admit it, it seemed like the princesses “affections” were getting stronger the closer to the center of the place. Soon, the lizard woman could only moan softly, eyes rolling into the back of her head as her body went limp against his, tongue hanging out with a mindless smile stretched out across her muzzle.

The hall way opened up into what looked like a throne room, though barren and lifeless he could not imagine what princess it had belonged to.

The only thing of interest was the throne itself, which was high backed and imposing, with spikes surrounding the top of the back rest and loops of metal surrounding the base with piles of dust beneath them. Possibly ropes and the loops to bind them to the throne?

Curious, though cautious, the knight dragged the princess up to the throne, ignoring the drool that soaked into his tunic. He raised an eyebrow at the large book he found upon the throne.

It was dusty, though the leather was in decent condition. It was the size of the Merchant Princess's ledger, which was no small thing. Some of the other knights had joked about how she had written more than some particularly active wizards in a single tome than they had studied about magic.

He always had the feeling they were more correct than they thought.

“How queer.” He muttered, setting the candle on an arm of the iron throne. Taking the tome up in his hand, no small feat given the size, he gave it a look over. No markings on the front cover, nor one the back. Along the spine were wispy lines of gold and pink encircling an ebony bar of metal. The lines moved even as he gazed upon them, twisting and turning and growing wider and thinner at seemingly random.

Like it was alive.

“Stranger and stranger.” He muttered once more. “I wonder what this is. Perhaps a journal of some kind?”

Setting the book to the side opposite the candle, the knight weighed his options. He could either take the book now and read it later, or he could read it now. He was worried for the princess, but if this was a journal maybe there was some explanation as to what was happening to her and ways to stop it.
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: Stone, yet not stone, is what greets him

choices: Something startles the Knight (Not the one in the journal)
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
The knight sighed, hefting the princess further up his body as he turned and sat in the cold, dusty throne. It was blasphemy among knights to sit on any throne, but he supposed that he would keep this a secret. It wasn't like anyone was going to catch him now, was there?

No, certainly not. There were no footprints in the dust of the room besides his own.

Situating the princess so she was sitting on his lap, he jumped a bit when she suddenly lunged for his chest, only to relax as her arms wrapped around him and she began snuggling into his tunic once more.

“Perhaps this is already wearing off,” He whispered, placing a hand on her shoulder with a sigh. “Whatever it is. Please come back to me, Princess.”

Still, without having to hold her, the knight was able to pick up the book much easier now. Flipping open the first page, the knight began to read.

Day 57, weather: stormy and volatile

Strange weather patterns have been plaguing not just the continent of Am'cela, but the rest of the world. In these winter months, there has been little sign of snow, worryingly enough from what the Atmomancers tell us. Instead, it has been unusually clear, with strange lights in the sky. First they were rarely seen, once every week or so, but they have been increasing in their frequency at a rather alarming rate. The church is of no help, merely claiming it is the last days and the Stygian shall come from the beyond and devour the material and ethereal alike. The Kingdoms are on the brink of war, with “rumors” of the princesses having been taken.

How I wish these were just rumors.

However, I am a knight of the realm. My orders have, thus far, been to try and keep the peace in these trying times. However, with this recent development, priorities have been changed. As such, I have been tasked with saving one of the kidnapped princesses, along with several other knights of the realm.

Word is that these strange towers have popped up around the world. Armies have attempted to siege them, but they have all failed. It was thought they were impregnable until a rather strange enchantress approached the king of the High Forest, my own lord, with news of how to enter.

A Champion, a Knight, would have to enter the tower, alone, and face the trials. We might find the answers then, and perhaps the missing princesses.

And, if I read the missive I received not two nights ago right, then she had vanished into pink smoke upon uttering those last words, only to appear before another court. I am still awed by the speed of the messengers that run between kingdoms for news to travel as swift as it had among the courts.

And so, I head for the tower closest to me, at the north western edge of Am'cela in the wild lands. It was only thanks to the soothsayers, the scryers and the prophets that work under our kings employ that I would not have to head in the opposite direction, this tower being unknown till just hours before the missive was written.

Unfortunately, I must press on with less than I had expected to arrive at the tower with. I must have angered the gods, as my wagon was crushed beneath a tree. And then struck by lightning. Twice. At least I hadn't been hit by the lightning or the tree, so I must also give thanks for that. As well as the fact that I still have my horse, a small pack of supplies and my bed roll.

At the very least, I found the cave I am writing this message in. It seems that there was at least one person living out here, a hermit of some sort. The last settlement was at least a day and a half away in the best of weather.

I found this journal that I now claim as my own. My previous one had been lost in the fire just hours ago. Not very knightly of me, but needs must. I must keep a record of what I do to present to the King when I return, and I am likely to forget all the things from before this journal.

Now, however, I must rest. I only hope the hermit of this cave will forgive me for taking his journal and using his home for a single night.

Day 58, weather: frustratingly hot

This weather will be the death of me yet. It must be. From yesterdays storm to this sweltering heat? It's as bad as the one time I was escorting an ambassador to visit the Lady of the Deserts in full regalia. Full plate-mail under the scorching gaze of the sun? Never again. I would make due with mere chain-mail and little else if I have to.

Anyway, it seems that the hermit that I have *A few splotches of ink told the knight that the previous owner struggled to find a word to justify his theft* taxed of his book was no mere hermit. Despite the rather sparse nature of the cave home, it seems I have been unlucky enough to pilfer a spell book of all things! I dread to think I might have only turned the odds further against me, in taking this. I can only hope that the wizard doesn't track me down to recover his book. Though why the first dozen or so pages are blank I'll likely never know.

I can't quite make out the words of the spells, merely snippets here and there, which is a shame. A spell book would come in handy.

Now, I wonder what princess lies in the tower...

Day 61, weather: Pleasant, like a spring day

I can see the tower, merely a quarters day journey from my campsite. With only my sword, my armor, my horse and the few supplies I keep in the pack that I thankfully had next to me when the tragedy of my wagon going up in flames happened, I have little hope I can survive whatever it is the tower wishes to throw at me.

Speaking of the tower, the thing is almost a castle all its own from the look of it. Towering up amid the trees, scrapping and scratching at the night sky as if it meant to take the moon and stars, blacker than the night it stood against. The one saving grace is that I can see a pinprick of light on the upper portion, near the top. Maybe it's My princess? I certainly hope. That enchantress said they might have been in the towers, or at the very least possible answers to their whereabouts.

I have also been studying the spell book as well. Where I could barely make out a few words beforehand, now I could make out little over half of what I read.

And I must say, I am very intrigued about what the hermit was studying and creating. Spells for inducing and enhancing lust? A ritual for emboldening ones stamina and fortitude but at the cost of a permanent state of increased arousal? Potions that would partially turn women into beasts?

I want to say it is depravity of the worst sort, but there is something about it that seems different. In a way I cannot describe, it is not as bad as some of the things nobles have gotten into. I see no real blood rituals in this book so far, nor human sacrifice, so at least there's that.

I wonder. If this is truly the end of the world, than it wouldn't hurt to at least learn about this type of thing, would it?

Hmm, perhaps I'll think on this tomorrow. I might have to use that ritual for stamina despite the price if I am to survive this endeavor.

I hope My princess is happy to see me.

Day 65, weather: Still

I must admit I am slightly disappointed. Instead of the stunning beauty of Lady Irene, Princes of the High Forest, daughter to his Majesty, King Maximus, I have found myself guarding the crown princess of the Kobold people, Princess Altea Draketooth, daughter of Rosmouth Draketooth, the High Lord of the Kobold nation.

The only thing challenging about the tower was the fact that I had to climb up all those stairs. At least fifteen levels, mostly empty save a few skeletons and a gibbering imp that was beheaded by my blade. Rather a disappointment, considering that I had used the ritual for stamina thrice over in preparation for both combat and climbing. I had also read up on some spells that would allow me mastery over creatures. Unfortunately there were no creatures that would be worth the trouble of casting the spells which includes slapping a piece of paper with a sigil on them. I had set up four just in case I ran into trouble, but it's good to be prepared.

I wonder...
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: A previous owner?

choices: Something interrupts the knight reading, or a different journal reading
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
Day 66, weather: chilly but dry

I must now keep this journal secret from King Maximus, and woe betide me should Lord Rosmouth get his claws upon this.

In fact, I might not be able to show my face again. A pox upon me for besmirching the title and position of Knight of the Realm.

But I must write it down for my own sake. So that I remember not to fall into this same trap again.

It started out with Altea clinging to me as we left the tower. Her happiness upon rescue was to be expected, surely. To be whisked away, and by what she could not say, so suddenly and thrown into a cold empty tower must have been terrifying for the poor Kobold.

Then, as the day went on, she clung to me near constantly. Despite riding on a horse, where she would have clung to me regardless, her advances were unbecoming of any princess, save the barbarian tribes of the plains and their wild heiress.

As the day wore on further, the weather took a turn for the worse. A winter wind descended from the north, sapping the Lizard of all her strength and warmth. Despite giving her my cloak and some drink to warm her did little to help. I spent the greater part of an hour battling with myself, wondering if I should bring her to sit in front of me despite my newfound problems with my loins. I was pent up, ready to “sow my seeds” as it were since the day I had saved her, the day I used that accursed ritual!

Damn me thrice over!

I tried, I really, truly tried to dissuade her from her affections. I had little attraction to her, really, being more at ease with ladies of human lineage instead of her scales and claws. Not to say that she was ugly, per say, but damn it! I was hoping to win the hand of Lady Irene from this quest!

She had begged me to “share the Warmth” as it were, her cold blood keeping her from regaining the warmth the wind drained from her body as easily as a human or dwarf from what I remember. Her shivering was genuine, I could feel it as she huddled against my back. Despite my fears, I knew I must put aside my misgivings and protect the princess from the elements.

As soon as I had done so, however, the demeanor of Princess Altea changed entirely. She pressed herself closer to me than was strictly necessary, mostly upon my aching manhood. I groaned at her ministrations, even through my thick pants and her scaled backside. This seemed to delight her, as she cooed at the way I hunched so slightly forward, trying to ignore these sensations.

Again, I must damn that ritual. To be pent up for days on end, and for a woman to be so eager to please, my mind was swiftly taken by lust. As soon as we found a spot to make camp, I took the princess like an animal, her teasing having driven all reason from my mind in my accursed state!

She did not fight me, as she constantly begged for me to hold her close, to warm her in all way possible. To take her and flee, flee from her father and her responsibilities as princess. To breed her again and again.

I have found the peak of delight I don't know how many times this night. I sit here next to a warm fire, The Princess, my Lover, asleep in my lap, leaning against me as I write this, my maleness still speared inside her.

I doubt she would wake if a dragon roared next to her.

I must get a separate journal when we reach town. That one to give, one that is removed of all of my shameful deeds. Even if I don't give it to the King in person, I can still send it off should I see a royal courier. I only wish I knew what to say to explain my absence.

Day 70, weather: Gentle spring rain

My aching loins. Not a day goes by where I am satisfied, despite Altea's eager efforts. She has scarcely left my lap since that first night we coupled. She has even torn a hole in my pants so that she can engulf my pride in her soft folds as we ride towards the next settlement. Only to relieve herself does she leave me. Not to sleep, eat, drink or anything else.

I think she's pleased with my “endurance” as it were, because I have never once heard her complain about a single thing since then. She has been warm, content to do nothing but try and breed with me as if she were in heat. But I know from previous warnings that the Kobold heat isn't until the summer months, and it is only now nearing spring.

Despite the surprisingly nice weather these past two days, she has claimed that her actions are for “warmth” and little else. At least, until the night where I can take more action.

I also think the horse is quite tired of our actions upon its back.

Extra apples for it when we get back to a proper town instead of these backwater settlements.

I wonder when it will be, and if I can keep news from spreading of our activities when we ride into town as we are. There will be no way to hide it when we do, I imagine.

The knight continued to read, blushing. He noticed something strange though. The book he was reading, this journal, had said that only the first dozen pages were blank. However, he had read at least two dozen, and there were still more. There was something strange about this book, and now he wanted to get to the bottom of this.

The journal went on to talk about how the Knight of the Realm, Sir Ace as he was known, gained strength beyond mere men, feet faster than any messenger or horse, endurance that allowed him to go for days, and shortly after, for weeks without so much as a minutes break doing any otherwise tiring task. He had tested this on Sir Laurence the Lone-Heart, another Knight who was supposedly half giant. Giants were known for their amazing strength, even their half-breeds. For him to simply toss the man as if he were a piece of parchment was astounding, to say the least.

The knight also read about Sir Ace's use of all the books contents. Not merely spells and rituals, but artifacts of great power and worth. For example, the passage he was currently reading, not noticing the Kobold Princess sleeping soundly against him.
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: A knight's shame

1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
Day 141

This book has given me yet another artifact. I have yet to find Lady Irene to test the previous effectiveness, but I have heard rumors of a tower in the heart of the deserts of the south that is yet untouched by a Knight, though there have been tales of it being an exceptionally hard tower from a supposed survivor of the tower who went mad shortly after. Maybe the Princess is there? And if I find her, I shall utter the word that resounds in my mind still.

Regardless, I now have something called The Lover's Necklace. I should give this to a woman who I desire, and she will love me forever more. If I had found that first, I might have spared Altea the shackles she now bears. Though she seems much happier to bear them than she ought, I would think. I am still ashamed and aroused in equal measure as I remember that day.

Regardless, I wonder why it gave me this item now, and not one of the other mystical objects it contains.

Nevertheless, I must continue searching for Lady Irene. I must also try and obtain a wolf's heart still for that ritual that would keep woman from running me out of town by themselves. I would only need to worry about the men then.

Day 143

What luck! A desert wolf ran afoul of me today, and I have taken its heart. Now I await the heart to cook over the fire, all other preparations complete. With this, I should have little to fear from women again. No more cookwares being thrown at me, or waking to bar wenches trying to turn me into a eunuch or girls crying for their fathers when I pass no matter how much I cover up. It's almost as if they sense something off about me, but I don't know.

Also, I had to dispatch some more warrior monks sent to kill me from the church. If I was still as weak as I was when I started this journey, I would surely have died. It was only thanks to my enhanced ability to dodge and attack at immense speeds that allowed me to kill them. No doubt these monks were sent directly by an angel to kill me.

I fear what will happen soon.

Day 145

Two days of fighting the angel. When the monks didn't report back, it seems the angel that sent them had had enough of me killing their agents. To come and fight me in person, there must have been something I did to anger the entire heavens, but I don't know what.

Even the angel, Saraphaea she tells me, does not know. She was only told that I must die to prevent a terrible future.

I doubt that our fight has gone unnoticed, even in the miles of empty desert around us. We reshaped the landscape as we did battle, with Saraphaea turning a good three miles of desert to glass in the beginning.

I must thank this book, for the gods seem to want me dead now, for helping me win this. Without its influence, I would be dead a hundred, a thousand times over. It was only thanks to the necklace it has given me that I was able to come out of this alive.

Yes, the necklace that now lies around Saraphaea's neck. She leans against me, snuggling into my side as she rests from our fight. Since she has put on the necklace, she has treated me with the utmost love and compassion, the kind that exists only in bards songs and the hearts of hopeless romantics.

Even now, her touch is feather light as her hand explores my chest, her breath airy as she breaths in my scent and giggles to herself. She even cooked the meal that fed the three of us as if it was her duty!

Truly, this book is the greatest boon a man could ask for.

Day 150

Three companions join me on my adventures today. Only one of them was expected, that being the Lady Irene.

When I first entered the tower, Altea and Saraphaea in tow, I was not expecting to find a vault of treasure with a lone occupant among the horde. A mimic, the most advanced I'd ever seen at that, tried to assault us for trying to take some of her delicious treasure from her. Of course, it was only after Altea had attempted to pick one coin up, as she merely smiled at me when I approached, having picked up a few gems myself for ritual components.

It was only thanks to my quick reflexes, again I must thank the book for them, that allowed me to slip a third artifact onto the humanoid mimic. This one was called The Empathic Rings. I was wondering if I should use this on anybody, but this saves me from feeling like I have killed the mind and soul of a sentient being, or at least locked it away.

I now wore the male ring of the set, while the Mimic, who I have decided to call Thespiea,bears the female half, allowing me to control her emotions, and in turn her simple mind. I could feel the never ending hunger, just bubbling beneath the surface. She hungered for treasure, for flesh, for all things.

Mimics, a voracious race. Devourers of anything that fell to their traps. Some claim them to be punishers of the greedy, others claimed that they were the souls of particularly greedy people who were turned from paradise and became monsters after their death. Many theories surrounding these, the bane of adventurers and plunderers alike.

A terrifying species.

But, with my control, I decided to twist that hunger into something useful for me, for my growing group. A hunger for my love, an unwavering need for my approval and an insatiable yearning to make me powerful in anyway she could.

Simple instructions for a simple creature.

With a few words to her, a stroke of her cheek, Thespiea devoured her horde of treasure, the entire thing, with her dress. It let out a small burp as she sauntered back over to me, eagerly putting my hand upon her head with the two arms that emerged from the mimic body that made up her hair.

Three mimics fused into a single entity. That's what I deduced Thespiea was.

She really seemed to like me petting her head as well, if the way she drooled as my hand massaged her head mimic was any sign.

After that, it was a simple fight up the tower, with Thespiea eagerly devouring any monsters in our path. I still had yet to find any that I would like to enslave with the seals I made so many weeks ago. Maybe if I found a mythical beast such as a manticore or a dragon?

Yes, they would do nicely.

Anyway, we scaled to the top of the tower, Altea riding my now permanently aroused girth as usual, Saraphaea floating at one side while Thespiea clung to my other side, growling in happiness at my mere presence and her recent meals. When we reached the top, I opened the door to find the Lady Irene, waiting eagerly for us.

Despite her dirtied and worn clothing, she seemed to be in great health. No signs of starvation or dehydration, no cuts or scraps, not even the expected smell of her waste from being in the tower for many months.

She seemed surprised at who her rescuers were, as well as embarrassed at the state of Altea and I, but she quickly rushed to embrace me, thanking me over and over again for saving her. She rained kisses upon my face, ignoring the fact that she pressed Altea between us, touching my engorged maleness or the constant dripping of my fluids onto her dress.

I almost forgot the word, so happy to see My princess safe and sound once more. But I still managed to utter it to her, after asking if the word meant anything to her.

I must confess, the blank look on her face both worried and excited me. Once I told her she could go back to what she was doing, she smiled once more, giving kisses to me again and again as before.

It seems I am gathering a harem of princesses, and I would have to be blind to see it. I thank this book a million times over once more.

The last companion was the most surprising. Lady Helena Fellsword, Leader of the Moon's Band mercenary guild, Knight of the Realm and dubbed the “Princess” of all Knights. Rather telling about my luck, is it not?

A simple conversation in the tower, helped spurred by both the fact that Helena wished to know how I fared in the supposedly unbeatable tower and that we were both old acquaintances. I had dueled her in a few tournaments beforehand, and it wasn't surprising to see at least a squad or two of her men while on a quest.

It was simple to present her a second necklace that the book gave me, The Amulet of Twisted Justification, which would allow me to tell her anything, absolutely anything, and for her to rationalize it.

A few tests, such as asking her to exercise, to give me leadership of the Moon's Band, to lick the flat of her sword, to kiss Irene, bark like a dog, get naked, pleasure herself, tell me her darkest secret, sweep the entire first floor of the tower, sing some bar songs and lick Altea's nether lips clean of my seed all culminated in telling her she should become my own loyal Knight, Lover and Slave all rolled into one.

All of which she rationalized to herself, even going so far as to present me her Grandfather's sword for winning her loyalty and love alike. Graciously, I accepted, but quickly returned to her so she could adequately preform her task.

I think my plans have changed.
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: Change of heart
