1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
After this point, there were longer periods of gaps between entries. First a week, then three, and a ten month gap between the third and second last two entries.

Day 513

I have failed in my plans. I grew too cocky, attracted the wrong attention. I am powerful enough to beat all mortal beings with ease, even most divine beings!

But not this. I am not powerful enough to stop the Remaking.

Those fools at the church. The never told anyone what the gods really had in store for us, what the Stygian were.

The Stygian will return all to Chaos, so the gods can remake the world. They've done this before, they're doing it again.

Because of me.

They feared my power, what I would do should I continue to grow at this pace. They would likely have only a year left to reign before I took my rightful place above them.

Parading about several goddesses on leashes probably didn't help.

Even now, I look at the dawn sky and see the stars darken, consumed by the Dark Queen of Far Oblivion at the edge of the universe. Her minions have already shattered the moon into pieces for her to easily devour.

The Great Beasts have gone on a rampage from the sheer waves of primal terror that signal the end of the world. Most of the continents have already burned to the ground. There is only this small swath of land that even the gods fear to tread that remains untouched by the madness that engulfs the world.

The book I write this in has all but demanded I flee to another world, a new realm. It seeks to bring me power, safety and the love and lust of women from as many sources as possible.

But I refuse to leave.

Even now, after all this time, I will still defend my home, despite having brought it to ruin myself.

The princesses that I have taken from every kingdom are protected from this horror, placed in timeless crystal and hidden in a place neither god nor Stygian can reach.

I worry not for myself. My soul is far too powerful to let the Remaking erase it. I am as immutable as the gods themselves now, perhaps even more so.

Ah, the sun has now been devoured. It won't be long until we fight.

PLEASE LET US GO, LORD

I told you I refuse to run. Stop trying to save me when I am in no true danger. I will just try again and again until I get this right. No matter the world, no matter how many tries. I will rise again, born anew despite any meddling they may attempt. You know this more than I do.

I CANNOT BEAR TO SEE YOU DIE EVEN ONCE

I understand. But I will see this through to the end. I still hold that much honor, despite all I have done. I will defend the castle till the world comes crumbling down around me. Do not ask again.

Now, there is still one person left to speak with before it all ends. Even now, I can feel her sense of duty and her power, even as she cuts through the hordes of Stygian beasts to reach me. She will be here soon.

I hope I can convince her to join the others. I doubt it, but I must make one last attempt.

If I fail, I will cleave her head from her shoulders to spare her this end. I will only hope that in the next Making she will be less duty bound so she can enjoy life.

Even if I never get her, my coveted Lady Prima, I wish her only the best.

And here she is

After that, the journal entries stopped. And on the next page there was a runic image with the description that was in one of the first entries. A ritual to boost the endurance of the caster at the cost of increased arousal.

The Knight wondered if he should put the journal down, take the princess and leave. Never to return. Surely, if this was possibly true, it would be incredibly bad for him to disturb anything in here.
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: The end of Sir Ace's entries

1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
“You're not going anywhere, My Lord.”

The knight screamed, throwing his fist to the right as he dropped the book and clutched the Kobold Princess close, ready to spring away.

“Oh ho, silly Sire.” The voice purred in his left ear. “There's no need to be so violent with me. I will never harm you.”

The giggle that followed was soft and light, tinkling like church bells in the distance. So sweet, so soothing. The knight felt himself relax, despite his best efforts. A hand upon his helm slowly pulled his gaze to his left.

His eyes widened as his male-hood went incredibly stiff, almost painfully so. The vision of beauty before him...

Larger than he was, she floated off the ground with wings that looked like cerulean silk. Her flawless skin was white like the stars of the night sky, and he could not help but reach out to touch her. With another giggle, she drew closer to him, grabbing his hand and placing it on her flat stomach, allowing him to feel the otherworldly softness of her skin and the literal vibrations of magical energy.

She wore a black garter belt that connected to light teal stockings with six white circles on each, three on the inner portion and three on the outer. Two sashes crossed diagonally over her chest, preserving her moderately sized modesty while following the pattern of her stockings, only back and front instead of to the sides. Her face was set in a serene smile, relaxed at almost sleepy. Her eyes were closed, with a line coming down from the bottom lid of each eye. Her hair was fluffy, like a cloud he imagined, a mix of platinum and gold colors, somehow cascading down her back, below her thighs, hanging just inches above the floor even in her floating state. Floating above her head was a disk of light that he could just make the tip of a crown over.

“And so you have returned once again, my Love.” She said, leaning down. “And you have brought Altea's Remade descendant with you as well? How marvelous.” She gave an even gentler smile (How was that possible?) at the Kobold. “Although it seems she is affected by your lingering powers. Do not fret, she will return to her senses by the time wakes, now that you've touched the Tome.”

A hand reaches out, as if to caress the tome, but is pulled back with a sigh as magical energy leaps angrily at her outstretched fingers. “It seems you still don't trust me, Tome. How unfortunate.” She murmurs sadly.

“Saraphaea?” The knight whispered, dimly recalling the name in the journal.

“Of course.” She says, tilting her head to the side with a confused frown on her face. “Who else would I be? I am certainly not Helena, Altea, Irene or any of the others. Ah, you must still be confused. I'm not surprised. You've shown up earlier than we thought. We all thought the last death would last longer, so Veronica hasn't found you, has she?”

“Who?”

Another laugh escaped her as she floated closer to you, almost sitting beside the Kobold in your lap. The book sparked again, but she paid it no mind. “Yes, it seems you found your way here on your own then. You would definitely remember the Enchantress if your paths had crossed.”

“I, uh, I was hit in the head by a rock, Milady.”

Another laugh, though her hand did move to the top of your head. “I trust your helm saved you from any wounds, Love?”

The knight could only nod dumbly at her. Her hand was so warm, even through the helm. Not like the warmth of a fire, but the warmth of a lover, a blanket shared on a cold winter night, a romantic moment that warms the soul in a storm. Any aches he had felt since that run yesterday seemed to fade as she rubbed circles on the metal.

“Hmm, I always miss this. Just being in your presence, so close to you. It's warm and gentle. Every time I go back to slumber, I dream of caressing you once more. Allowing us to bask in the presence of the other. To feel your hand in mine, a gentle touch that soothes my soul.” She whispered softly.

The knight wished to stay like this forever, in the embrace of this angelic princess. He so desperately wished to do so, almost a need it was so warm. But...

“I am not your love, Princess.” He muttered softly, forcing the words out while trying to hold them in. “I am merely a knight, and almost certainly now a failed one at that.”

She hummed gently at your proclamation, shaking her head. “Don't be silly. You are my Sir Ace, My Love. You are just reborn again, like you have been many times before. But we have had this talk a thousand times, so I shall humor you once again. Come with me, this empty throne room is ill suited for a talk.”

Floating away from him and around the throne, the knight had little choice to follow. Mesmerized as he was, however, he hoisted the Kobold in his lap to better hold her as he grabbed the candle, the book landing on the floor with a loud thump as he stood.

Stepping around the throne gave him the sight of another passageway, though this one was lit slightly with pale motes of light. Sometimes they were pink, other times they were gold or green, even the same blue as the stones themselves which offered little help.

The angel, Saraphaea, floated ahead of him, waiting by an off shoot. She disappeared down the new passage as he neared, opening a door a short way down the hall if the sound of a handle moving reverberating through the emptiness was any indication.

Following the path of the angel, the knight found himself walking through an open door into a well furnished room. It was homey, with wooden furniture, save the bed that was made of stone hollowed out, and furs all over the place. A fire crackled at the back of the room, though there was light in the room from a strange ball of light in the center of the ceiling. It bobbed to and fro, spinning slowly as he shut the door behind him.

“Here,” Saraphaea spoke, drawing his eyes toward the bed. “Tuck the Princess in, and settle yourself in a chair. Much better than the throne room for now, isn't it?”

The knight shivered pleasantly at her words. It was as if she knew something would come to pass, as if it had happened before and will happen again. While he wasn't so sure, he did as asked. Slipping the Kobold away from him gently, he pushed the Princess underneath a blanket of what looked to be a dire wolf pelt, if the coloration and the size was anything to go by.

Placing a chair next to the bed and setting the candle on the nightstand allowed the knight to gaze upon the angel once more. She still smiled warmly, despite never opening her eyes at him.

A small wave of her hand caused two cups to materialize in the air along with a pot that smelled like tea with a hint of mint. Pouring them with a flick of her finger, the knight found himself opening his helm and sipping the delightful concoction before he knew what he was doing.

1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
“Hmm, blond hair this time. A little shorter than I would have liked it, but it suits your new face.” Saraphaea tutted to herself, sipping at the tea. “And what of your new name? I am curious as to what you are called this time.”

“I gave up my name long ago, Milady. I failed once, before I became a knight. Now that I have failed again...” He looked at the tea with sorrow all over his face. “I can only hope the Guild will help me help the Princess.”

“Hmm, I see.” She breathed out, her smile fading again. “Then I suppose I will simply call you Anon, my love. Short for Anonymous, of course.”

“I still doubt that I am who you think I am, Holy one. If I was anything like the man in the journal, if that's what it truly is, than maybe I could have stopped what drove us to these lands in the first place.”

Again she laughed, shaking her head. “If you were not, you could not be here in the first place. Even if you had somehow entered these halls, you would never have been able to read the Tome, simply being driven mad upon seeing the first word, if you had gotten that far in. So, you must be Sir Ace reborn again.” She floated over to him, grasping his empty hand. “But do not doubt yourself. It is only because you had never had access to the Tome that your latent powers did not manifest. Even mere echos of past lives would have been enough for most any mortal challenge. Now please,” Letting go of his hand to touch his battered chest. “Explain to me how your wounds came to be.”

The knight sighed, looking to the lizard-woman so snug in her new bed. A slow nod was all that escaped him for some minutes, readying himself to tell the tale a bit sooner than expected.

“It started when I was called to the Kobold Keep...”
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: The Nameless knight!

1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
“I see. So Little Red has grown angry over the centuries.” Saraphaea spoke slowly, hair slowly rising as power built in the room. Her face was set in a stern frown, and Anon wondered if something dangerous would happen in the small, comfy confines..

But, with a sigh, all became still once more. Saraphaea floated gently into his lap, wrapping her arms around his neck as she pressed her lips lightly to his cheek. When did she get smaller? She surely would not have fit so well in his lap before. “I am not surprised. Her mother was never the kindest, and with her rage against you powered by the fearful gods and terrified demons, it is no surprise she would spread the hatred as far as possible. You say that there has been no one besides you to walk the surrounding lands?”

“None, Lady Saraphaea.” Anon told her truthfully, biting back a yawn. “Not a single soul, from lowliest beetle to even the Dragon Queen has so much as flown over these lands. Princesses avoid the land as if it was to invite death, or something was pushing them away. It is only the Princess's predicament that pushed her to follow me to these lands. The Church, I know, tells everyone to avoid these lands. It has done that since anyone can recall. At least, when it isn't crying on about the evils of lust and badgering people to abstain from all matter of physical relationships. They talk of little else anymore, not even the grace of the gods. They are fixated on stamping out anything they deem to be lustful.”

“It is worse than I fear, then.” She muttered, pushing a little healing power into her fingers, drawing a relieved sigh from the Knight as the bruises faded and the red scars and scabs vanished. “While I do not like lewd or perverse things, this much is true, I do understand that to stamp out any physical relationships is quite abhorrent. It seems you shook the gods once again, last you walked these lands. To give the Dragon Queen power over the lands with both divine and infernal backing is quite worrying. They must be close to letting the Stygian horde free again, and the Church must be placating them as much as possible, trying to stamp it out before it comes to that.”

“Perhaps...” Anon said, thinking back over past sermons he had attended. “But I must ask you, Saraphaea, if you do not like the lewd or Perverse, why did you follow Sir Ace? Especially after you saw how deep the lust dwelt within him?”

“This is not the first time you have asked me that.” She smiled dourly at him. “And I doubt it will be the last if things take a turn for the worse again.”

She reached under her sashes, pushing a necklace into view. It had been hidden completely, but it was a beautiful thing. Gold and silver entwined around a ring of diamond, glittering in the light of the room. It looked like it should have once been an actual ring, though it was too small to fit a finger. Maybe the Goblin princess could have worn it, but Anon did not know for certain.

“It started with this. You would recall it as The Lover's Necklace, from the journal entries. It bound me to love Sir Ace, as if I had loved him all my life. But, at the end of his life, he took it back from me. I attempted to kill him then and there. Not out of hatred, mind you, but of disgust and duty alike. I had seen, and at his behest done, some rather crass and base acts. But, by that point, I could not hold a candle to his power. He let me strike him, again and again, using all my power to try and scratch him. But alas, it was for naught.”

She shifted uneasily, uncaring as she ground into the lap of her reborn love as she wrapped him in a hug. “I hate reliving these memories, but I must answer your question. After I was done, he wrapped me in a hug, apologizing with all his soul. He spoke, for a moment, of wishing he had never found the Tome, that it had chosen someone else. But, I knew I was the one in the wrong, deep inside. I do not begrudge the likes of Verda or Aurilla, whose domains encompass lust and sensuality both. His powers were as much his domain as theirs were. It was natural for him to exercise his powers, to push for his own influence. But he still wanted to save us all, despite all he had done. A knight till the very end.”

Anon stayed silent. That couldn't be all.

“Still, that wasn't that event that changed my outlook on him, my outlook on the totality of his, your, soul. It took many a lifetime. Some were worse than others, true, while others never came to their rightful power. Some were kind, others cruel. Some wished not to fight, only to please, while more sought to bring goodness into the world in various ways. Some were goblins, gnomes, giants and ogres, though many were human, such as you. It was only twenty Remakings ago, where he posed me the questions before I returned to the crystal that changed everything. Despite all the things I had seen him do after countless lives, all the great atrocities committed, did he not also preform great miracles? Did he not love, despite the hatred some of his lives had been filled with? Could I honestly say that he cared for me less than my previous divine patron had? He had saved me from being Remade, after all. Saved us. Time after time after time, he had allowed us to continue, sending a perfect copy in the second Remaking to be remade into the newest world.”

“However, it was the way he posed it, and the sorrow with which he asked. That life was a tragic one, like few lives had been. His name was Richard, the Knight of Tragedy. Very few things had gone right in his life. In fact, the gods had singled him out for what he was, what he could become. Framed for murder of an entire family of nobles, accidentally starting no less than four civil wars, ten kingdom wars and three holy crusades, slaying an arch-demon but in the process setting of an entire volcanic range and splitting the earth. There was not a place where his name wasn't spoken with hatred and fear. Calamity followed him like a demented, love struck puppy. Only here, within the walls of this castle, in the arms of us who had been with his soul since this all started, did he find a moments respite. In the end, he died fighting the Remaking, failing to stop it yet again. But, he left a note, one for each of us, to be the first thing we saw when next we were released. He once more apologized for the actions of his first life, but oh so happy that he was able to meet us, to bring us happiness in this world that denied him the ability to do so for all others. He left what many would consider the greatest gift looking from the outside. Can you guess what that gift was?”

Anon blinked his eyes, realizing her had been stroking her hair as she told her story, holding her close to him. The words echoed in his head, the question pounding at the forefront of his thoughts. What was the gift? What could it be that someone would consider to be...
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: The one gods fear and tales of true love

1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
Was it really so simple?

“It was freedom from him, wasn't it.” Anon whispered. “Freedom from any and all ties he had to you.”

“You've been paying attention. That's good.” Saraphaea smiled against his neck, giving him a soft kiss in appreciation. “You're right. He took back all the artifacts of power before we were sealed away once again, ripping away the spells that bound us to him and releasing all vows of fidelity. Free to do what it was we wished, free from his influence. He ordered the Tome to let us free in the next life if we so wished it, to free us the second it was safe to do so.”

“But you didn't go...”

Another kiss upon his neck, a sigh of content as her fingers lifted his helmet the rest of the way off. When had she started removing it? Ah, right, she was kissing his neck. She would have had to have lifted it up somewhat.

“Not a single one of us. Altea begged for her shackles as soon as we left the crystal, weeping for the warmth they now gave her soul that she had lost. Irene simply went about her duties as before, as if she was still under thrall. Thespiea brought back new treasures, more diligently than ever, hungering for the approval that wasn't around just yet. Helena left her grandfather's sword on the throne, vowing to train as hard as possible that she might not leave her Liege and Love alone when next he faced the Stygian horde, only to return when she felt worthy of his praise or was called. She'bal did what she could to rouse the new Damned Queen of Lust to action, to gather as much strength as possible for her Great Mother's chosen master. And so on, with each one of us princesses striving to greater heights, greater lengths for him, for you, for them all.”

“And what of you?” The knight asked, eyes closed as a delicate hand glided through his hair, his eyes growing heavy. “Why did you stay?”

“Because, dear Anon,” She kissed him upon the lips, feeling his breath slowly even out. “It's all I ever wanted. A lover to hold, sisters and true friends alike, a place where I could escape from my heavenly duties. No mindless zealots, no fear of ever displeasing my god, of being erased for some failure. I have a home, all the food I could dream of and all the times I get to fall in love all over again. This necklace holds no sway over my heart any more. I wear it because it was a gift, the thing that gave me my loving god. Now, sleep. You are weary still from your ordeals. The Kobold and I will still be here when you awake.”

The last vestiges of his strength failed him, darkness sweeping over him as Saraphaea hummed lightly against him. He felt...

Peace.
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.title: The greatest gift that no one wanted

1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
Saraphaea grudgingly left the warm embrace of her reborn god, dubbed Anon for now. He had been asleep for an hour now, and while she would love nothing more than to stay until he woke once more, she had things to do, preparations to make.

That, and she did not like being peeped on.

“You two know I hate being spied on.” She spoke to the shadows outside the door as she left her reborn god to his slumber.

“Unless it is him doing the spying, of course?” One asked her, the impish smile profoundly implied in her tone. “Wouldn't mind then, especially when-”

“Anyway, I hadn't expected either of you back so soon. He only opened the seal mere hours ago.” Saraphaea cut off the speaker, blush dusting her cheeks as she tried to push away those numerous memories that had been brought up.

“I've just returned from scouting out the newest kingdoms that have popped up in the last ten years, along with some that have only now started to reemerge from hiding. I would have been back a few weeks ago, but I ran across a new kingdom, only a few months old. Saraphaea, what I found out about that new kingdom... We have to deal with it quickly.”

Saraphaea frowned at this news. The shadow that spoke to her did not usually make judgment calls like that unless it was really important. Nor did she let any emotion ever seep into her voice regarding business, so the tiniest hint of anger was rather surprising as well.

“I see. When I awaken the others, you can tell us about it. They will be eager to greet Sir Ace's newest form, after all. And from the way you say this it has really upset you.”

“It is blasphemy.”

Oh dear.

Saraphaea pursed her lips at that. This did not sit well. Her plans would have to wait it would seem, until she knew what it was that was blasphemous.

“Dear oh dear, it really has riled you up. Go ahead and rest up. As soon as Sir Anon has woken up, we shall head immediately for the Haven. Meet us there.”

One of the shadows immediately faded away, disappearing from the hall without any trace of movement. No questions, just a single minded will to do what must be done.

“My, so something has shaken Nexi, has it?” The first shadow to speak asked. “Her devotion is always so refreshing to see though.”

“We are all devoted, Veronica.” Saraphaea frowned at the hidden woman. “You know this well.”

“Oh, but of course I do.” The Enchantress spoke, letting the shadows around her fall. “I know exactly how devoted you all are to our god, what lengths you will go to in order to enact his will. It's pleasing to see it in action.”

Saraphaea sighed, nodding. The Enchantress wasn't wrong in that regard. As a divine being herself, she loved to see expressions of faith. More so for her god and love than when she was merely a servant.

“Regardless, I think I know what she's talking about. I'll wait until we all convene, however. Much easier that way.” She said, turning to walk away. “I will soon have a gift for our Lord. Freshly made, straight out of the thaumaturgy ovens. I think it will be a deciding factor this time.”

With that, Veronica walked away from the angel without another word. Saraphaea sighed at the vagueness that the woman loved to part with at every occasion. She hadn't failed them yet, however, so she would always give her the benefit of the doubt.

Ignore that for now, just go on
1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
Anon slowly returned to his senses, feeling well rested. A light blanket covered him, his helm hanging from the back of the chair.

Stretching, the knight stood up, setting the cover back where he once sat. Slipping on his helm, Anon looked over to the Kobold Princess. Still asleep. Right, she hadn't been getting much sleep with the problems in the mines.

The mines.

“If only...” He muttered, shaking his head. No, can't focus on that for now. Just gotta... do something. Gotta plan, and make sure the Princess was safe. That was imperative.

A note sat on the table, underneath the Red Candle. It was almost certainly for him, so he didn't feel like he was intruding when he picked it up and began reading.

My Lord,
From what you told me, the dragons are causing the world a bit of strife, specifically the Queen and her youngest. I might have a solution, but it will take meticulous planning. It also seems that some things have come up that haven't in any other Remaking, making me wonder what the gods are trying to pull. Please, meet me in the throne room when you awaken. There is much to do before you leave here.

Forever yours,
Saraphaea


Reading it over again, Anon could only sigh with a nod to himself. “I have little other recourse, I think. I doubt I will be able to topple the dragons on my own or with an army. Especially if the Queen gets involved.”

He didn't want to think about the gods themselves getting involved.

XX

Sir Anon strode into the throne room, eyes cautiously roaming. He wished for a blade, even just a shield, to defend himself with. He felt almost naked without either armament on his person.

At least he still had his helmet.

“You have awoken, I see.” The calming voice of Saraphaea flowed into his ears, calming him as his eyes sought her form without his express permission. “I do hope you feel better than before you slept.”

Oh, she was sitting on the steps up to the throne, tracing a hand over the sole piece of furniture. She beckoned him over as soon as he came into sight, though her eyes never opened once. They never had since he had met the angel, now that he thought about it.

“I do. I take it you healed me?” He asked, getting a small nod. “Then I must thank you. My body was utterly exhausted from my flight from the Kobold mines, and the cuts and bruises were doing me no favors.”

“It is no trouble, Sir Anon.” Saraphaea whispered. “I only wish you had followed that small stone's instructions when you first received it. Things would have been much different. You would not have had to face the pain in the first place.”

“And the Princess would not have lost her castle or her people.” Anon whispered to himself bitterly. A calming breath. She hadn't meant to upset him. She was too gentle a soul. He knew that just from talking with her for the short time before his slumber. “Anyway, you said you needed to speak with me?”

He regarded her strangely, his eyes slightly glazed over even still, but nodded. There was something he must do, right? She, Saraphaea had said so before they came here, correct?

“But,” He said slowly, trying to pierce the fog of lust that shrouded his mind. “You never told me.”

Tilting her head to the side, The princess of the heavens looked confused. Hadn't she told him why they had come down here? She was certain she had! Well, maybe he had forgotten when exposed to the Guardian, or when they were falling down. They had been doing it for a long time, after all, with nothing but the all consuming pleasure of the other as they fell.

“No, princess.” The knight said, making Saraphaea blush as she realized she had spoken aloud. Down here, in the presence of the Dragon, her tongue did wag loosely; and wasn't that a statement that had more than one meaning! “You didn't. You told me all would be explained as it happened. I think you forgot to tell me when we had, eh, relations.”

The snickering of the five heads that still weaved in the distance was not lost upon either of them. “So, little Sara forgot her duties as our master's secretary?” The Dragon taunted with one head, Tutting sarcastically with the others. “For shame, for shame! I shouldn't be surprised, really. For all that innocence you show off, you just can't ever wait for the throbbing cock of our master. Be it orc, goblin, elf, gnome or whatever else, you just hop onto his meat, enticing him from the moment you meet! How far you've fallen from those first few lifetimes, so very long ago.”

Again the Dragon snickered, like a snake the size of the world were being strangled randomly while it hissed alongside an avalanche. It shook the platform the stood upon with minute vibrations, enough for the ground based knight to feel like he was on a ship in a particularly violent storm.

Shuffling her feet, an impressive feat given her floating nature, the angel blushed fiercely, looking down. “Regardless, the reason we came down here was to awaken the rest of the First Entourage, Those that Sir Ace himself saved from the Remaking.” She spoke resolutely, with the hint of shame creeping in. “The Enchantress says she may have something to turn the tides this time.”

“Did she now?” Reine queried, snorting at her own question. “What am I asking, of course she does! She never does anything by half measures, and never says anything unless she means it. Very well, I shall awaken the Entourage. Go now, fly back to the top of the Haven. They will join you three shortly.”

“Three?” The knight asked, cocking an eyebrow as he looked around. There was only two people on the platform, and the Dragon wasn't referring to herself, so who?

“I'll explain when we reach the top.” Saraphaea smiled gently at his confusion. From those words alone she knew what had transpired. Even now, she could feel the presence of the third soul, so tightly pressed against hers yet remaining unseen. She really was distracted, wasn't she? With a shake of her fluffy hair, she wrapped her arms around him and extended her wings, shooting straight upwards into the near infinite Haven.

Sir Anon chanced a look down, jaw slackening as he saw just how far away the Guardian was! By this point, he could no longer see the platform beneath them, and yet they were only a little over a third of the way to the beginning of the Princesses laying in slumber. Smoke filled the air above her heads, though it quickly dispersed and cleared before reaching the numerous dreamers.

And yet, still, she was far into the horizon, every single one of her eyes focused solely on him, each burning with an intensity their own. From the look of things, she hadn't even began to tilt her head up yet to watch their ascent!

He supposed that this must be how ants feel when they look at the dragon princess.

Up and up, Saraphaea gave flap after might flap of her wings, bringing them closer to the surface. It seemed so far away, compared to the fall down.

“Oh, there go our clothes.” Saraphaea drew his gaze from Reine, looking up at the gently floating articles of cloth. As she said, they were floating past them, somehow not stained with copious amounts of sexual fluids. A simple grab by him brought both shirt and pants, as well as Saraphaea's garter, back into possession. “Thank you, however you'll find that clothing is considered optional in this place. You needn't wear any pants, and I will tell you now that most will hope that you don't.”

“Do those numbers include you, Milady?” Anon asked, genuinely curious. “Be that as it may, however, I do not feel all that comfortable without my armor, much less clothing, in a strange place. Too many times have I seen an aspiring knight be cut down in familiar environs by all sorts of enemies just because they felt safe enough to relieve themselves of their own helm, much less the rest of their armor.”

“No one in here would dream of harming you, Love.” Saraphaea spoke with a frown. “Do you not trust me, us?” She corrected herself, feeling a pinch along her back. Really now?

A shake of his head and a sigh as he leaned his head against her bosom was his answer for a few moments, the only sound the force behind her wings as they continued skyward. “I do, and for the life of me I can't understand why.” When he finally spoke, his voice betrayed his vexation at this fact. “Despite everything I was taught, and my own natural paranoia, I trust you, more so than any of my fellow knights have ever inspired me to trust them. People I have fought with and against, attended the weddings and funerals of, been invited to the births of their first children on rare occasion! People that I have known all my life, since I first fell under the care of the guild when I was still a boy, I trust less than you! Less than this book I hold in my arms! Even now, I can feel your holy presence, so I know that you are no manner of succubus or witch or what have you, working your magics upon my mind, Princess. But I still do not understand...”

Saraphaea frowned again, deeper, as he trailed off. He had reveled a bit more about himself as he spoke. He had still been young when he joined the guild? For what reason this time around? She could hazard many a guess, not being a stranger to backstories such as this. Each time made it no easier to bare, however, since his pain always riddled her own soul with a fresh sorrow.

“It is the connection your soul has with our own, with the Tome itself. You may not believe, but everything I have told you is true. All you read, about Sir Ace, was true. And, I am certain that if you perused the Tome a bit more, you could learn about the other lives you lived. Even now, in the world you were born in, it bears the marks of your past lives, the yous that have walked these lands regardless of their power. Your soul has become a force all its own, and it has seldom been denied glory and import. Each connection you have made with the Tome has strengthened your soul, deepening the connections you have gathered over the course of innumerable Remakings. You felt it with Reine, did you not? That connection, that desire for her when most would be terrified? Even the first tens of thousands of your lives quailed before her when they first saw her, even those who have fought for and against dragons for most of their lives. She is shamed to admit, but more than a few had died of shock and fright upon seeing her, when she was much smaller than she was now, and far weaker. But now, even when you have only recently had a run in with another dragon, you were only bothered for barely a minute.”

She shook her head again, holding Anon closer to her. “No, your soul is merely reacting to the bonds that have existed for so long, time has no real bearing on them anymore. Your soul resonates with ours, and even now, despite your troubled mind, I can feel the deep welling of familiarity bubbling forth from within you, waiting for you to acknowledge it for what it is. The body and mind do not remember, but the soul never forgets.”

A mirthless chuckle answered her, but not another word.

1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
Setting foot upon the ground once more, at the top of the Haven, Anon stretched his arms and legs, quickly donning his clothes and handing Saraphaea her garter belt. He made no mention when she merely held them, only a shrug of his shoulders. If she wished to expose her bits to him, who was he to really say no? It's not like he hadn't enjoyed them personally and frequently on their way down.

“Now, what did the Guardian mean when she said the three of us? There are only two here, correct?” At least, two awake that didn't include the dragon.

Saraphaea said nothing, merely gesturing to her twin sashes on her chest with a small smile. Curious, Anon scrutinized the garments vigorously, wondering if the dragon meant the clothing itself?

A subtle movement, an out of place crease. That was all he needed to notice for the rest to become obvious to him. Had he not felt a hand on his chest, squished against the angels during both fall and flight? Had he not felt the presence of eyes during the fall when his helm slipped between her heavenly pillows when she grew, or a caressing hand upon his cheek? How had he not noticed it before? It was as if it had hidden on the edge of his mind, just out of sight until he saw those two signs of something out of the ordinary.

With courage he did not know he possessed, he brazenly stuffed his hand beneath the twin sashes, grabbing hold of an arm that should not have been there and began to pull. Instead of fighting him, the arm let itself be removed from hiding, bringing with it the rest of the body it was attached to.

It was a woman that, oddly enough, stood taller than Saraphaea herself at the moment. Much too large to fit underneath the teal garments, normally. As he pulled her from hiding, her black eyes looked up at him without emotion. Her face was covered from the nose down, and a hood covered most of her head. She had twin tails sprouting from holes in the hood though, spiky bushels of hair as dark as her clothing. Her hood continued downwards, draping over her shoulders, but only covering her neck and the upper fifth of her arms in the front, continuing down her back as a kind of cloak. She wore a shirt made of material that would not have looked out of place on a fishing boat as some kind of netting, showing skin almost half as pale as the angels. She wore twin gloves, each reaching up to end just beyond the hemline of her shroud, that were almost skin tight. Around her waist, she wore a sash of almost impossible blackness, which seemed to ripple as she was pulled away from Saraphaea. Her shorts went down to the end of her thighs and were, the same as her gloves, skin tight, almost melding seamlessly with her otherwise light skin. Around her right leg was a small knife belt, currently empty, and he doubted it was the only spot she hid weapons despite the tightness of most of her clothing. Her feet were wrapped in cloth, going up to just above her ankles, each toe wrapped individually so as to allow easier purchase if she were to climb a wall.

As soon as he feet were free, gravity reasserted its hold over the woman, and she landed on her feet despite being held with her back to the ground and his hand wrapped around her wrist tightly. Her legs were bent at the knees at a ninety degree angle, and from the looks of it she was not bothered by this fact.

“Who are you?” The knight ground out, despite knowing in the back of his mind she wouldn't hurt him. “How and why were you in Saraphaea's clothing?”

“I am Nexi, the first Assassin Princess, My lord.” She answered, her voice almost as dead as her eyes. She barely blinked at his treatment of her. “Using the Dark Sash I wear around my waist, I was able to hide in Saraphaea's clothing. I did so because she forgot that she was to meet me here and bring me with you two when you went to convene with Reine. I was barely able to hide before she carried you over the edge.”

If she could feel the intensity of his gaze, or see beyond his helmet, she made no movement in regards to that fact.

Saraphaea laid her hand over his, gently prying his fingers from Nexi's wrist. “Forgive her, Anon. It is my fault that I did not introduce you to her beforehand, and that I forgot that I was to meet her here. Her duties include being the shadow of our Master, you, and keep us informed of the events in the world. She has only just returned from a decade-long mission. Despite her outward demeanor, she is happy to see you.”

Nexi nodded, though she hadn't moved from her current position with her knees bent and her back parallel to the ground as she looked up at him. “Yes, and I bring with me news that the rest of the Entourage must hear. We must quickly make our way to the Symposium. The shadows speak of the Kobold you brought with you walking the halls, and she will be there shortly.”

“Reine will awaken the rest of the entourage and send them directly there. Nexi, you go on ahead and greet the Kobold. Although, I suspect that when Sir Anon enters, she will latch onto him immediately. Don't spook her too much.”

A nod from the woman was all they received as they stepped from the Haven into the much darker hallway. She stepped into the shadows and was gone. Anon swore he felt a quick peck upon his neck, however, yet it was gone faster than he knew if he was imagining things. A quick touch of his fingers, black coloration staining the tips of his digits, proved to him that he was not imagining things.

“That girl.” Saraphaea put a hand to her temple, sighing. “Shall we be on our own way?”

1552222222222222222222222222222222222222.content:
The Symposium was as large as the Haven, but in reverse. They entered from the bottom, and the ceiling was so far above that he couldn't see the top. Looking up made him feel dizzy, so he kept his gaze as level as possible.

The build of the room was not the only opposing factor. Where as the Haven was crystalline, smooth, quiet and obviously unnatural, the Symposium was a deep forest, rugged and buzzing with insects and with other sounds of nature.

“Amazing.” Anon spoke softly, trying to keep his eyes from looking upwards.

“Yes. The Symposium was built by Reflet, Nature's ambassador. A druid of great power, he meshed kingdoms with nature with little distinction, helping the animal kingdoms thrive and remain wild while still allowing the sapient races to progress past what they otherwise would have been able without domesticating animals. Reflet was the fifth life after Sir Ace, and was always the diplomatic one. He was able to bring the demon lords to the table and speak, which is always something to behold. Not the best, but still great at bringing peace. At least, until the Gods and Devils learned of his soul connection. He spent his last years in seclusion, in this plane, building this room. He foresaw the complications that would arise from gathering the princesses of each generation and Remaking, each one so used to having their opinion listened to with serious gravity. He knew that his future reincarnations would need a place to bring order to the natural chaos of discussion and debate.”

“And thus, the Symposium?” Anon motioned around him as they walked along the only path through the forest.

“His addition to this wonderful world. Of course, being a druid he could not leave nature outside so he brought it in here. A calming presence in a maelstrom of voices. No one can raise their voice here if they tried, at least here in the forest. Once we get higher up, about the middle, the magic starts to fade.”

A shadow stepped from the treeline, uncloaking to reveal Nexi. She stared at the two of them, who acknowledged her by stopping in their tracks. “The Kobold is in the personal meeting hall. As expected, she was skittish regarding my presence when I revealed myself to her. She has been provided food and drink, though she hasn't touched a single bit of it.”

Saraphaea nodded at the assassin. Better than she expected, honestly. “Have the others arrived yet?”

“In the waiting room just outside. As customary, they await our Lord's presence before entering the room. In addition, Altea cannot wait to meet the new Kobold, and it would be prudent to keep her on a tight leash.”

“That bad?”

Nexi merely nodded, the slight narrowing of her eyes telling her long-time friend all she needed to know.

“I see. Anon, when we reach the waiting room, you must order Altea to keep calm. It doesn't matter how you tell her, but you must do so. When she isn't eager for physical relations, she is full of near boundless energy and will be the source of many headaches if not brought to heel.”

From the sound of things, this had happened before. Given the amount of times they've done this, if they were to be believed in that regard entirely, it was probably standard procedure.

“It will also help ease you into your role as our master.” Saraphaea continued as they started walking once more. “Most of your past lives have been hesitant to do so, most out of chivalry. But, you might know the old saying of snowballs atop mountains.”

“I cannot admit to liking the sound of that.” The Knight narrowed his eyes somewhat in a glare. “It seems like you're trying to say that I will become some kind of cruel tyrant as time goes on.”

Saraphaea merely shrugged at him, looking down slightly. “I will not say it hasn't happened before, Love. With the sheer number of times you have lived, it has had to happen many times. But, many more have seen us happy. I mostly meant to imply that it would be easier to show you just exactly what you can, and have, accomplished, and what that means for you.”

A sigh stole its way from his throat, but he merely nodded. “Very well. I do hope that I can keep my head in all of this.”

“Your head is your own, Master.” Nexi spoke just above a whisper. “What you do is what you do, and you do it because you want to. We cannot force you to do anything. We do not want to force you to do anything. You could have walked from here the moment Saraphaea spoke to you, and we would have merely returned to waiting for your next life if Veronica could not convince you to return when she found you. All you do is the result of your own actions, or perhaps the result of complete accidents.”

“It's almost like Fate, then, that I find this Tome and deal with the consequences?” He asked the assassin, who stood behind him, slightly to his left. Her footsteps mirrored his, and it was only the occasional glance back that assured him that she hadn't vanished into the shadows once more.

“No.” He barely kept from running into the angel woman as she stopped just ahead of him. Her voice, usually warm, airy and filled with love turned cold, hard and sharp. “Do not think that The Grand Architects of the Tablet of Stories would ever let you live should they know your place in the etchings from your birth. I have see too many smited in viscous ways that not even the most damned souls have felt since the time of Sir Ace. Too many struck down before they can gain their rightful power.”

“I, uh, see, Princess.” This new side of her scared him slightly, if he were to be honest. Where did the lovely cherub-like demeanor go, only to be replaced by this cold, vengeful messenger of the gods? In fact, he could see frost creeping around her, the metal of his helm growing colder just by being in her presence. “But, what will keep them from doing so when I leave here then?”

He could feel the grim smile of vindication that spread across her face without looking at her, as the temperature dropped like brick from a tower. The ice crept further from the woman, just skirting around his feet. Nexi had already jumped up on him, and it was only because he went to look back at her and saw her foot wrapping end when he got to his shoulder that he even noticed. She was unnaturally light and silent, it would seem.

“Fear.”
